review_text: Big sad

I'm sorry to say but this was one of the most disappointing games of my lifetime. If I could, I would have refunded it for wasting my time. The one thing that I really liked and sunk way too many hours in was the ship building. Surprisingly good, definitely wish they flushed it a bit more and got deeper into it. Everything else falls flat unfortunately. It feels like I was egged along believing things might expand and get more interesting but it doesn't. Every quest eventually breaks and soft locks itself and I lose hours of progress. I've never played a game that made me feel so much pain for no reward. Listen... I'm a big fan of what Bethesda was creating aesthetically. I love Sci-fi themes and space ships but no denying this was the second biggest cat-fish of gaming history.
Amazing game from what it use to be at launch. Highly recommend revisiting this game.

Really love the concept of this game.  Is it perfect?  No ,  no game is.  Its been my go to game since December 2024 so I did not play from launch.  Really love exploring planets,  ship building and getting frustrated at outpost building but still do it anyway.  Creations are cool lot of really cool content there to add flavor from indy folks.
Good game

Despite being a Bethesda fan, I was hesitant for the first couple of years. I finally took the plunge and was immediately and completely hooked. The criticism is mostly valid. This game is compared unfavorably to many other, more focused games that do the same things but better. But by bringing together so many different things, Starfield creates a bigger, more immersive world. So many people say they played like 200 hours and "beat the game." BS. They barely started the game. There is so much to do and see, and so many different ways to go about it. I've played over 1500 hours and there are still many missions I have not done and many game mechanics I have not explored.
TONS OF FUN

This game is weird until you put 20h into it.
The main story line is mostly crap, but you unlock an essential feature through it
Exploration is mostly useless and bad. 
But:
The side quests are the best I've played in any RPG ever.
The NPCs are the best written that I've ever seen.

You cannot play this like Skyrim. You pick a quest and see it through. This is the way to play this game. 
And once I understood this I absolutely loved it.

Been playing since launch. It's a fun game to play, even for a game that feels made by committee and plays it safe, undercooked, and generic with certain of its quests and characters. Environments while planet hopping have left me taking it slow to enjoy the sights and sounds (music at the forefront of that). The shipbuilding is easy to get lost in and the ships are fun to play with as your home out in the stars (if you like the light base building, there's some of that too). Flying them is enjoyable. I like the planetside traversal, it just needs better tuning and variety. Photo mode provides lots of fun moments. The gameplay pace generally is slower but I like it for that. For every lacking aspect of the game, another aspect is done decently or well and the experience tallies up to worthwhile.

It's a solid 7/10. Not terrible, not amazing. If the things I thought were negative got fixed up it's an easy 8/10 (and if it got some major additions there's room for a 9/10 game in here).

If it strikes a chord with you then that's all there is to it. I do hope that Bethesda gets at least one more major update out for it. I'd welcome more than that.

It's a nothingburger. It's like going to Burger King and ordering a burger with bread and meat only. What is there is mostly okay, and it'll fill your stomach at least for a little while, but by the end you'll still be wanting something more substantial.

What I can say is it has the best character creator out of all the Bethesda games, bar none. People actually look like real people and you can do a fair amount with it. I had fun messing around in the character creator and I actually, for once, really liked the way my character looked. Good on Bethesda for that, but everything else needed about another decade in the oven.
now that no mans sky have ship building i have no reason to continue playing this game
Boring, Mods do not work properly. Boo Bethesda. Waste of Money.
Did not live up to expectations but still fun.
Todd Howard.
Boring

Fuck this game. The writing is awful, the environments feel dead and lifeless, the massive number of planets with procedurally generated terrain is a stupid gimmick, and the art style is crap. I despise the weapon designs, most of the character and outfit designs are trash, and none of this is helped by how generally ugly this game is. Starfield looks and plays like a PS3 title at best. What a fucking disgrace. I can't believe I wasted 70 bucks on this piece of shit. Fuck you Bethesda

Well. It's not bad. It's just not what we all expected from a developer this big. A lot of bs talking from Todd and other devs on top sealed it for many people.

But I came for a space game. And for that it's nice

When women and children get to decision power that's what you get. Terrible writing, terrible dialogs. Heads that don't fit the vioces and etc. Terrible and clueless main quest. Might as well be doing nothing. Terrible random ladders in every ship. Greatest ship constructor. Unfortinately for me it is the only space saga worthy playing that is open world. 1000 hours+ in game. I can't recommend it, but there is nothing else. Nothing. And don't even get me started on Mass Effect, it is not open world.

70hours in and I am still enjoying the game, Story is good, gun play is good and the ship battles are good. Would of liked a few more options on some of the quests but that is just nit picking. Really don't understand all the hate this has got when in reality its Fallout in space!
bethesda's best game yet

i wont pretend this game isn't deeply flawed, but its also deeply fun. ive spent 600+ hours hopping around pretty planets and scanning cool aliens and customizing ships and building resource networks and collecting cool decorations and building giant outposts and i look forward to doing another 600 hours of that

play this if youre looking for a pretty decent story with great sandbox elements, dont play if youre looking for phenomenal story. inevitably anything todd howard touches will be imperfect but this is still a very enjoyable game despite him

A lot of my time played on this game has been alt-tabbed in the background, but I HAVE spent a lot of time on this game. But like, it's the kind of time you put in on an open-world game when you're hopeful you're gonna find something fun or interesting. You invest.

This game will make you invest and will never, never give back to you. Play AC Odyssey for fun exploration. Play the mass effect trilogy, or Andromeda even, for fun sci fi stories that make you go whoa. Play Hades, or Wanderstop, or Greedfall, or just play Skyrim again. Don't buy this game. It's not fun. The combat's boring, the loot's dull, the exploration is more vanilla than Oblivion, the characters are INSANELY dull, there's less in this universe than in a Borderlands DLC, and the building is frustrating, both ship and house. Just don't play it.

I gave this game EVERY opportunity to be my new love affair
This game is amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (if you add star wars mods)
I maxed my bounty on console at about $14,000,000 until it kept freezing, I'm only here to break that record.

i love this game, and while i understand some criticism from concerned fans of bethesda games (myself included), the game, at its core, is a good ol’ classic bethesda game. it’s the same formula from skyrim and fallout, but it’s just in space.
i understand that the procedural generation, having multiple planets to go to, plus the loading screens for every landing and travel, has its flaws — especially when you mix it with bethesda games — and in my opinion, compared to the single-focused worlds from previous entries like skyrim and fallout, it might have a tiny negative impact on your gameplay pace.

but still, i can imagine myself getting past that and pouring the same amount of hours into this game as i did into fallout and skyrim, if time permits. the writing style is the same as the other games in the franchise. bethesda’s focus point has never been great writing for their stories, but rather a beautiful open world, role-playing, and astonishing world-building — which they did one hell of a job at again.

the skill-check dialogue is a bit weird, because the dialogue options it presents for persuading a character are so goofy that most of the time they don’t make sense or feel realistic XD. even more so than fallout 4.

now to the good things:
one thing i appreciate the most is the new tab for items you recently picked up. because oh boy, how many times have you picked up an item and had no idea what it was? now this new tab has you covered.

another thing that i should have mentioned at first is that you can fast-travel around locations within the city through your scanner by simply pressing “e” on that specific location’s icon. you can’t imagine how much this improved the pacing of the game for me.

the inventory management is a hell of a lot better than in previous games. i did criticize the questionable UI design, but the inventory, on the other hand, takes the cake for me. you can actually sort your items by their names and weights, which you couldn’t do in other bethesda games without using a mod.

the story so far is perfect. i like the different factions in the game. i’m 120 hours in and i still haven’t touched the main quest (classic bethesda game way of playing XD).

TL;DR:
starfield is a good game — just what you’d expect from any bethesda game you’ve played. there are some questionable design choices, but they don’t hurt your experience at all. just try the game yourself and don’t bother with the negative reviews.
It was pitched as Skyrim in space. In actuality it is a boring empty soulless game that they've already abandoned.

Positive review due to the excellent modding community.

I've played through Starfield when it first came out and got through the main story. At the end, I had felt nothing but regret and disappointment. Yet, I finally  found a mod collection that rectifies this.

"Odyssey - A True RPG" -- A Nexus mod collection of 230+ mods.
I'm 30 hours in and this collection sets itself apart, with it being meticulously balanced for extended gameplay, and enjoyment.

Get yourself a Nexus account, download Vortex, find "Odyssey - A True RPG", and follow instructions (MUST DO) on the page for installation.

I'm going to start this off by saying that in the time since this game has come out, I've put 103 hours into it. You would think that means that I'd like it and highly recommend it, but that's not the case. Honestly? The game sucks. It's largely empty and boring, nothing ever really feels all that interesting, the choices they made with the story were bad, the world building is bad, just the whole thing is bad. I run it with probably over 100 mods just to make it interesting enough that I'll play it for a week every 6 months maybe. No matter how many mods or creations i add, it's just boring, bland, and an obvious example of what bethesda gives us now that todd howard runs things. You have a studio known for interesting locations, creatures, factions, and races, and you get none of that here. They said "skyrim in space" like we'd have multiple alien races to choose from, or at least interact with like in fallout, but no. All the aliens are alright animals at best, which are rarely even especially interesting designs, all the planets in the "massive exspansive universe" they promised are just boring procedurally generated garbage that you have to add mods to actually make interesting. The leveling system sucks, and again, you have to add mods to make it work, all the weapons are forgettable and all the space suits are lack luster unless, you guessed it, you add new ones with mods. Basically every system of this game is a massive let down, made all the more shitty, by the fact that todd howard pushed this at as as hard as he could like it would be the next great game of our age, when in reality, it's just another example of why in the next 10 years bethesda is going to go bankrupt and dissolve, because they keep giving us garbage because todd is their god, even though he has no idea what makes a game good, and hasn't since fallout 3. I have not met a single irl person that enjoys this game beyond something to do to kill time sometimes, unless space is their autistic special interest/Big hobby, and even then, it was only 1 person that actually seemed to like it, and even they had complaints. This game is not worth how much it costs and the time and effort and additional money you have to put into modding it and buying creations. If you TRULY think this is the game for you, please, for the love of god, wait until it goes on a very steep sale
It lacks a soul, it lacks depth and interest, it lacks... everything that could be good.
Loving it so far

Starfield was a major disappointment. I love space themed media and love Bethesda games despite their flaws. Unfortunately, Starfield takes the worst elements of Bethesda games and a lousy excuse for a space-themed story and combines them in this awful excuse for a game.

The positives:
Visually, the game looks good. That is the one plus I found playing this game.

The negatives:
- Crashes frequently on multiple machines (tried on a 4080 super and a 3060, both crashed at multiple points in a single hour of gameplay)
- Bugs (sound cutting out, skipping dialogue, characters getting stuck in geometry, etc.) Seriously, I thought the game didn't have gun sfx for the first 40 minutes because my sound glitched out from the very beginning. I had to reload a save to get it back.
- Corny, lame voice acting/ dialogue
- Bland combat
- Dog fighting/ ship combat is slow, unintuitive, and boring
- Story makes no sense (oh miner guy, because you saw a mystic vision from a piece of rock I will now give you my ship and send you to meet my space cult brothers. No there was no build up to this. No you can't refuse. Yes all of your dialogue options make you way too enthusiastic for this.

I can't recommend this to anyone. I was bored to tears after the first ten minutes, and after watching someone else play past where I was to see if it got any better... it got worse. If you REALLY like bethesda and anything space-related, you may be able to find something you like from this. However, I doubt most will. My recommendation is give this one a pass (or if you're really into modding you could try it with that but I couldn't be bothered.)

Rating: 1/10
Empty passionless game not worthy to be called a bethesda game.

This game was the death knell for any hype I would carry into a game that had yet to be released.

This game fell into the same pit that doomed Cyberpunk 2077 in that the developer promised a genre-defying look on RPGs. An open-world game located in space with a ship-building system, base building, procedurally-generated worlds offering endless exploration, and a newly created universe for you to explore.

Overall, it didn't land most of what it was promised but I did enjoy the ship building system even though it was limited (and still is) in what it can do. The overall story is rather unremarkable and the best compliment I can give is to call this game Skyrim in space. There are a handful of major cities but not much to do within them and a lot of quests take you on a tour of the universe that offer a one-stop-shop of what the game has to offer. Never did I once feel as if I was in a lived-in world comparable to what Skyrim made me feel, but it is still go in its own merit.

I still recommend it, at least for the modding scene since you can create whatever your heart desires.

Only bought the game to play the Star Wars Genesis modlist. Modlist is cool. The base game tries really really hard to be bland. Props to Bethesda for rigging up space combat in the Morrowind engine, but it is the worst space flight combat I've ever experienced.

It's just not worth time or effort. Every feature half baked, nothing and no one interesting to find. Very soon you start asking why am I doing this as the world is just empty.
Save your money.

Likes: There are a lot of ways to play the game. You can focus on outposts for a little while and build some fun things, get into space battles with a ship you can customize with a lot of unique styles, focus on the quests or just explore different planets for a while. Granted, too much of any can burn me out but that's why it's great to have options to switch between when ever you feel like it. Also, IT'S SPACE! I like the experience over all. Keep making it better Bathesda!

World-building shines in the lore-rich Settled Systems—New Atlantis buzzes with intrigue, while Akila City's saloons echo Skyrim's taverns. Ship-building? It's Fallout Settlement mode on steroids: Design your fleet from modular parts, then dogfight in real-time or board like a space Viking. Combat evolves from pew-pew basics to modded mayhem with gravity grenades and companion AI that actually covers your flank.
Sure, the galaxy's vastness can feel isolating at first (hello, loading screens), but patches and the Shattered Space DLC have tightened pacing without losing soul. Mods? Already transforming it into the ultimate RPG playground. Starfield isn't just a game—it's a universe begging for your legend. To all fellow RPG wanderers: Strap in, Constellation awaits

Starfield – A Massive Space Sandbox, But Not Every Toy Shines the Same

I went into Starfield with a big mix of excitement and caution. After spending years in Elder Scrolls and Fallout worlds, the idea of Bethesda finally creating a brand new universe felt huge. But a part of me kept wondering if a game this enormous could really live up to its own ambition.

After many long hours, here is the truth. Starfield is huge, packed, beautiful and sometimes genuinely magical. But it is also uneven. Some moments feel like you are exploring the endless frontier of space. Other moments feel like you are staring at menus in a sci fi simulator.

The World and Atmosphere: A NASA Punk Dream, But a Safe One

The Settled Systems look amazing. The space suits, the ships, the cities, the planets and all the handcrafted zones show just how much effort the art team put in.

New Atlantis is clean and futuristic.
Neon is a neon soaked cyber city full of corruption.
Akila City feels like a frontier settlement pulled straight out of a space western.

Everything has personality.

The problem is that the universe is not always surprising. For a sci fi game with billions of possibilities, Starfield rarely feels truly strange or mysterious. It looks great, but it plays safe.

Story and Quests: Big Ideas, Good Execution

The main story about Constellation chasing mysterious artifacts has strong themes. Multiverse concepts, cosmic mystery and philosophical questions are all here.

But the actual storytelling is solid rather than unforgettable. It works, but it does not always hit with the emotional power it could have had.

The faction quests are much better.
The United Colonies feel militaristic and righteous.
Freestar Rangers give you a space western sheriff fantasy.
Crimson Fleet lets you live a full pirate life.
Ryujin Industries is all about corporate espionage.

These questlines consistently deliver better drama and more memorable moments than the main plot.

Exploration: Thousands of Planets, But Same Feeling

This is where Starfield stumbles.

On paper you can land anywhere. In practice most planets feel similar. The same structures, the same enemies, the same loop of scanning and looting. It starts exciting but settles into routine quicker than expected.

The handcrafted locations are the real stars. Whenever the game takes you somewhere designed with intention, everything improves instantly.

Space Travel: More Menu Than Adventure

Flying your ship sounds amazing in theory, but most of the time you are jumping through menus and fast travel screens. The game looks like a space exploration RPG, but the spaceship gameplay rarely reaches its full potential.

Walking inside your ship is great. Building it is even better. Actually traveling in it is limited.

Combat, Weapons and Skills: Solid but Not Revolutionary

Combat in Starfield feels good. Weapons have impact, zero gravity firefights are fun and enemy reactions are decent.

The skill system is fine but not extremely deep. Some skills feel essential, some feel pointless, and build diversity is limited compared to other RPGs.

It gets the job done but does not redefine anything.

Ship Building and Systems: The Brightest Part of the Game

This is where Starfield shines brightest.

Building ships is addictive.
Adding new modules.
Tweaking engines.
Rearranging the interior.
Creating something ridiculous but beautiful.

It is easily one of the best ship creation systems in any game.

Outposts are more divisive. If you enjoyed base building in Fallout, you will find something fun here. If not, you can ignore them completely and miss nothing important.

Technical Presentation: Beautiful but Interrupted

Starfield is visually impressive. Lighting, interiors, cities and planetary landscapes all look fantastic. Character models are much better than previous Bethesda games.

But the loading screens break immersion. There are many. Enter a ship, enter a room, land on a planet, leave a planet. These small interruptions add up over time.

Verdict: A Huge Universe, But Still a Foundation for Something Greater

Starfield feels like the first chapter of a much bigger vision. The framework is huge, detailed and full of potential, but not all systems shine equally.

It is a game you can lose yourself in.
It is a universe worth exploring.
But it is not the perfect space RPG people dreamed of.

Even with all its flaws, Starfield delivers a memorable journey. It is good, sometimes great, but not legendary. At least not yet.

8.5 out of 10 – A vast and impressive space adventure with massive potential for the future.

This game dissapointed me. If I could talk to bethesda, it would not be in a hateful way, but in a way that a father speaks to his son to try and mend a dissolving relationship.  Id sit them down on the porch, wrap my arm around their shoulder, and speak. "Hey," Id say, "I love you." I feel a lump in my throat, but push it down and hide my distain. "But you have been disapointing me." fire in my chest. I love him, but I have to say what I feel. I cant lose the one ive loved for so long, but I feel i dont recognize who im talking to.  "30 fps? dogsh!t questlines? NPC's that constantly spew MCU dialogue? what is happening?" I turn away. My face is wet at this point. My cheeks are red and I can barely hide the cracks in my voice. How can i feel this way? I love bethesda. I love fallout. How could I be having this conversation? I push these thoughts away as I look into the eyes of my chud son I used to love. "You used to care. you used to be something." I stare at what used to be my son. I loved him, but i realize I couldn't call him my own because of the dissapointment i feel. A single tear rolls down my eye, and I turn my head to try to hide it. I wanted to be proud, but i have failed to live up to what i had hoped.

For $69.99, I CAN'T recommend this game. If you can purchase it on sale and you really like Bethesda games, MAYBE go for it.

The world-building was shallow; it feels like stepping into a very shallow but wide pool. It's large, it's vast, but there's not much there. The depth of world-building and lore that you find in the Elder Scrolls series is not present. The story is "mid" most of the time. The new game+ system is creative but very punishing for those who enjoy hoarding loot and leveling up fully. The game can be very repetitive at times.

Overall, the game is alright. Not the best that Bethesda has done, and I really had such high expectations for it. Tbh, I wanted to like Starfield, I really did. However, there are so many better games out there. Go play them instead if money is tight for you.

This game does not deserve all the hate it gets. If you're basing it off of games like fallout or skyrim of course you'll be disapointed. But if you're instead basing it off something more like Andromeda or No Man's Sky then this game is for you. The pace is as fast or slow as you make it, and your choices actually have consequences in the verse. Ignore the hate and give it a try if you have a few extra bucks.
Bethesda Casts: LOADING SCREEN

i don't think this is a bad game, but it's definitely disappointing.

i should preface this with the fact that i do have some bias, as i find sci-fi to be a much more boring setting than their other series in a fantasy or post-apocalyptic world. that said, i still have lots of issues with this game which go far beyond my lack of interest in the setting.

the gunplay in this game is a major improvement over any previous bethesda games. it still doesn't feel as good as other modern first-person-shooters, but i don't think it needs to. i really feel like it's gotten to a point where the gunplay is as good as it needs to be for what is really an open-world-rpg first, first-person-shooter second. a small gripe i have however, is that the gun designs themselves are a bit uninteresting. in their pursuit of a nasa-punk visual theme, a lot of the guns don't actually make sense in how they would function. which i think is fine! however while the fallout series has plenty of guns which wouldn't make functional sense in the real world, their designs can be really unique and interesting. i found the guns in starfield to be unfortunately really forgettable - i think the corporate dystopia theme of the game played into this in a negative way, i would have liked to have more weapons i could get attached to. there wasn't any "starting 10mm pistol" to get fond of, nor was there much in the way of single-appearance unique weapons like the junk jet or deliverer from fo4. all uniques were just name and stat changes (sometimes with a paintjob swap) of an existing, normal weapon type. actually unique uniques do take more work but i feel like they're really important in giving the player something to get attached to over the course of gameplay. also, the really fun weapon (and armour) upgrade system from fallout 4 is back, but i feel like it's implemented far worse in this game. there is not nearly as much visual change with the upgrades in starfield, and overall it just feels like a much more shallow, uninteresting system which is easy to ignore for your entire playthrough. considering the potential shown by the already good system in fo4, i'm really disappointed that the modularity of weapons and armour took a major backstep rather than introducing further depth. 

a quick touch on character progression perks is that the system feels a little more rpg-ish and encourages specialisation at the start which is nice, but i really feel like far too many perks are simple number boosts, there is not nearly enough unique abilities in the perk trees to feel gratifying enough to specialise into. number-based stat improvements are boring and don't feel rewarding. specialisation as a whole also falls of a cliff, as this game strongly urges the player to spend lots of time on one single character, which means you'll become a jack of all trades at some point anyway. it makes the upgrade system feel rather meaningless.

touching on clothes and armour, the modular multi-part armour system from previous games is gone, but i feel like it hasn't sufficiently been compensated for. the armour system in this game is so disappointingly inexpressive. you always have to be wearing a spacesuit in this game (unless you're in oxygenated settlements) which is fine, that makes sense. my problem is that the spacesuits are so incredibly samey and boring. they all take up one single equipment slot for the body, along with a helmet for the single head slot, and that's it. what's worse is that the spacesuit upgrades (using the fo4 upgrade system) don't make any visual change to your suit whatsoever, meaning that the only way to get a new look is to find a different type of spacesuit alltogether - of which there are only a limited number of types. the limited amount of equipment slots, and further limited alterations to that equipment means the total number of combinations for your look is really small, and that's just really disappointing as someone who values customising their character a lot. it's a shame when they introduced a genuinely really impressive new character creator.

one major gripe i have there however is the small number of hairstyles, with no long-hair options. this feels like more of a cop-out to fit in spacesuit helmets than anything actually reasonable, more hairstyles are needed not just to make your character feel unique, but for npc variation too. the character creator in every other way is a major upgrade though, and the reintroduction of traits and the background system is super cool, i only wish it affected your playthrough more strongly to encourage specialising and trying multiple different characters out. 

the most important parts of these games for me are the quest design, characters, and open world though, and unfortunately, these three aspects are where the game flounders the most. i'll try keep it brief to not hit the character limit, but essentially: 

i found the quest design to be an improvement in some ways (the basis of most quests was really interesting), and the game makes an effort to have the player express themselves conversationally in the quests. however these points of expression feel shallow, as one recurrant theme in the quests of this game is the lack of outcome diversity. you constantly feel railroaded into one or at most two outcomes, which cheapens the effect of you expressing anything different in conversation. the most divergent outcomes come from the ending of faction questlines - however even these divergences lack npc responsiveness and integration into the world, which makes it feel like your choice didn't really matter.

characters have improved in some ways and fallen flat in others. the follower system in starfield is fantastic, the followers each feel far more fleshed out and grounded in the world, their reactivity is really important, and i think this is one of the best thing starfield does, and needs to carry into future bethesda games. the problems here are that there are only 4 unique followers in this game which have this fantastic depth, and they're all rather samey since they're from the same main story faction. i feel no reason to use the more generic followers when they don't feel like real characters who react to what i do the same way the main four followers do. i just want more of this good system, that's all. 

outside of the four major followers, i did unfortunately find a vast majority of characters in this game to be bland and forgettable, even compared to other bethesda games. the innoffensiveness of the four main followers can even include them in this conversation, despite them having the most depth in the game. i unfortunately just did not find there to be any jarl balgruufs or ulfric stormcloaks or nick valentines or mr houses in this game. i wasn't particularly excited to see anyone or learn more about anyone, it's a major point of disconnect between me and this game's setting, there aren't many people in the game's world that i actually care about. 

finally, the open world. or worlds. this is the worst part, unfortunately. bethesda's strengths are in their interconnected open world design. and this game just doesn't have that interconnectedness. they still kill it at the atmosphere and visual design of the environments, but the world (or galaxy in this case) struggles to find meaning when everything you do, and everywhere you go, is so separated from everything else. the world is cohesive and makes sense, i just struggle to find meaning or enjoyment when it doesn't feel like there's anywhere to call home - not even my ship. having a thousand different worlds doesn't make the game feel bigger, it just makes every world feel smaller, and that lack of the human touch in an interconnected world design squanders bethesda's biggest strength. 

i do think this game gets far too much undeserved hate, i think it's a good game, but not a great one. 6.9/10.

Instead of The Elder Scrolls VI or Fallout 5—the games fans have been waiting for for over a decade—what we got was Starfield. To me, it wasn’t the bold, visionary return to form we were promised, but a procedurally generated, sterile slop universe that felt utterly soulless. For many long-time fans, myself included, Starfield wasn’t a step forward—it felt like the final, definitive nail in the coffin. The moment where Bethesda’s decline stopped being something we debated and became something we accepted.

The backlash was intense, especially toward key creative leads like Emil Pagliarulo, who became the face of many criticisms about Bethesda’s writing direction. And rather than leading the charge to restore faith in the studio, he departed X for Blue Sky, where he could have his safe space with all the other blue haired wokesters.

Real Reviews from actual players:
“This is not a game to be dismissed lightly. It should be uninstalled with great force.” Dorothy Parker  
“Full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.” William Shakespeare

They rebuilt the engine but not the ideas, making Starfield the best-looking argument yet that Bethesda never learned the right lessons. The new engine soars but the gameplay remains earthbound by design choices old enough to collect a pension, and the problem isn’t the ambition, it’s that the ambition is attached to the same broken machinery.

Starfield proves that you can improve everything except the things you refuse to rethink, and they brought their best effort and their worst instincts. The result is a game that stands as a monument to effort and a memorial to imagination, where every improvement only sharpens the contrast with the ideas that should have been left behind.

It has the ambition of a space opera and the gameplay depth of a damp paper towel, and never has so much been done to reveal how little has changed. Starfield tries so hard you can almost hear it strain a pity the strain is the most exciting part.

It could have been better, though.
The time and money spent on making each planet ~*unique*~ should have gone to the story, game mechanics, and character development..
I haven't even played the Shattered Space DLC because every minute of this game past a certain point is a slog, which sucks because I wanted so badly to love this game. Instead it's just... meh. And, no, that New Game+ feature does not add to the replayability.
There are no choices that really mattered in the end, which I guess could be argued is part of the game's theme. The payoff just doesn't match the ambition of what the game wanted to be, though. It could have been GOTY material if they had focused on other aspects of the game, or scrapped things that didn't serve the forward motion of the story. Did we REALLY need the ability to land wherever we want on any planet, complete with procedurally generated landscape, flora, and fauna? I would have rather seen the same thing everyone else does and be immersed in an engaging story than see something completely unique with my cardboard cutout companions and forgettable story.

Is Starfield Perfect? No. Is Starfield still a great game that can give you hundreds of hours of enjoyment? Yes.

I mostly liked the main plot, but it lacked that feeling of urgency that previous Bethesda games had. I felt no real need to finish the main quest line, and instead felt more engrossed in other quest lines, some of which felt more urgent.

The weapons are also a big issue in this game. Some of the weapons look good or okay for the most part. Others... no. Just no. The Freestar Collective weapons look like steampunk and sci-fi had a horribly disfigured baby. What I'm saying is, their design doesn't look practical enough to actually be semi-believable.

The combat gameplay is fun, though I did find it necessary to tweak it with mods. I didn't like that one part of the galaxy was full of high level enemies, while another would have low level enemies. Space combat is amazing. I love the different ship weapons available, and I love customizing my ships.

I don't care for the crafting, so I've downloaded a mod that makes modifying weapons no longer require crafting components. Gathering resources and putting points into perks I really didn't care about was a bit of a buzzkill. Busywork, I guess you could say.

I found some of the characters likable and interesting, others not so much. I really don't have any glaring complaints in this regard.

As far as DLC is concerned, I haven't really played it.

I love the idea that the space suits are your primary source of armor, but I also hate it too. This makes regular outfits an afterthought, which kind of annoys me.

Overall, I'd give Starfield an 8/10.

Just Skyrim in space.

Yet another Bathesda game, here we go!

Are you still considering this title? I'll share my point of view.

I'm great TES fan, lost ton of hours in Skyrim some time ago. This is important, because I have soft spot and Starfield has many similarities - it's the same engine!
I'm also casual gamer, 30+y/o with family. That's also important.

I'm 30h in, did fights, exploration, storyline, upgrades. I think I touched most of aspects of the game. It feels fine, but not for everyone.
Game gives me option - I can set up my own pace of action, change the diffuculty and choose more immersion / more comfort. Are you in the mood to jump straight into shooting again and again? You can do it. Fast quest progression? Sure think! Manage inventory and ships upgrades? Let's go. Slow sightseeing and photo-mode? You're welcome.

It's not only that you will choose how to deal with adventures, how to approach another "bandit camp", but gameplay gives you more option, like more survival if you are into this. It's not only "difficulty level", there are more in-depth variables.

Emptiness.
Yes, that's a thing. So think about it - are you ready to deal with it? Space is empty and that's a fact. This is "NASA Punk", not StarWars.

Slow-paced.
More often, than not. I'm not bothered by loading screens, but they are here. And yes, 20% of the time you will spend in some menu, doing researches, upgrades etc.

Estethics.
You like it or not. It's a bit cluncky, not so far away into the future. You've seen the videos.

Further customisation.
There is a lot to do around the game. Not only gameplay option, but creations from other players as well.

Conclusion.
I recommend, but not to everyone ;-)

Hope that helped.

Any and all interest you MIGHT have in sci fi or sci fantasy, will not be quenched with Starfield.
The most interesting part of the game is the ship builder and it's not even that good because it's intertwined with one of the most horrible and barbaric " rpg " systems I've ever seen. You complete essentially " achievements " to increase your perk levels in Starfield and that restricts genuinely everything your character is capable of. Want to use jetpacks? Perk with achievements for upgrades to use the better jetpacks. Want to fly a faster ship? Perk with achievements for upgrades to buy better ship parts. Want to be able to mod your weapons to not be literal dogshit? Perk with achievements for upgrades to make better parts. The entire game is like this, and it's genuinely the least statistic based RPG I've ever seen and it's all the worse for it.

Enemies aren't just sponge-y. Anything over level 30 or so that's not a common rabble is toting enough HP bars ( yes enemies have MULTIPLE HP bars for you to chew through in this trainwreck of a game ) to bore you to death before they actually drop. 

The questlines are a joke, the writing is dreadful and feels like something made up by a 10 year old who just kept doing that thing ( if you're a parent you know ) where they go " And then a dude in dark armor shows up and attacks the town, and then a portal shows up and a bunch start pouring out, and then you have to run away from it, and then... " ad infinitum. It's BAD.

Performance is the worst in any bethesda title so far and the loading screens. The LOADING screens. Even with an SSD in a 40 hour playthrough you're looking at around 4 - 6 hours of load time combined. It's THAT bad. Everything is fast travel, EVERYTHING. There's no feeling of space flight whatsoever and although I personally like the dogfighting, it's still SOOOO barebones and basic. Judging from what others have said it's clunky to use. Idk arma does something to a man what can I say?

I really wanted to enjoy this game... I love the art direction, the ships, the outfits, even the stupid gun styles, but in 2025, the Creation Kit is just too limited for type of game. The story and gameplay is mostly "meh" and I think even the Modding community agrees.

I'm getting really tired of Bethesda outsourcing their games to be fixed by their own player-modder base. It's rude and it's lazy of them to charge $70 for a game that needs to be fixed by their own customers... It was really charming and exciting at first back in 2011 when there was only 100 people working for Bethesda at the time, but they still made games that millions of people were really passionate, and people's expectations were naturally lower. This game just doesn't have the same vibe. It's dull, it's slow, it's under-cooked, and it's heart-breakingly shallow. You are going to spend half of this game in the Fast-Travel UI because of the way the Creation Kit handles loading and unloading scenes and tilesets. 

The excuse / mantra I keep hearing from fans: "Well, it's a Bethesda game, so what do you expect?" That nonsense isn't going to fly for much longer. Especially if this studio is still planning to make Elder Scrolls 6. The writing is on the wall. Bethesda Game Studios now employs over 5 times that amount of people (maybe more). and currently has 4 different office locations. They are not a scrappy, underdog, Indie studio anymore... The fact that they've embraced that mantra as part of their brand identity as a AAA game studio is just terrible. and in my opinion they should feel ashamed.

Star Citizen is a more complete Space Exploration game than Starfield. It has actual ships that you can fly, with proper physics simulation, It even has a handful of planets that you can land on and explore that don't all feel like empty deserts. So is No Man's Sky. which also now has ships that you can build like Legos- just like Starfield. So this game ultimately has very little to offer in terms of originality, exploration, crafting, story, or fun. 

Maybe one day, if this game cost $30 on sale, I'd say go ahead and give it a shot. But I can't in good faith recommend this game to anyone- unless some crazy mad-lad made a mod in this game, to make a better game than Starfield.

I used to struggle with severe insomnia, to the point where I had to take strong medication just to fall asleep.

I don’t need those anymore—because no game I’ve ever played is as boring and empty as Starfield. I can’t even explore a second planet for more than ten minutes before my eyelids start to droop and I feel like I’m about to fall asleep on the spot.

I really tried to play and enjoy it for what it is, but I can’t shake the feeling that the game was scientifically designed to be as unengaging as possible.

When I was a kid and adults said video games were a mindless waste of time, I never understood their perspective. With today’s AAA releases like Starfield, I absolutely get it now.

There are some interesting parts of the game. I like the combat gameplay, I think building modular spaceships is cool, and it was really interesting learning about the universe the game is set in while visiting Earth or exploring those ruins found on some planets. None of that is enough to save this game from how utterly empty it is. It feels like they had tons of great ideas, but then they didn't create a world where players could interact with any of it. 

I also expected more from outpost building. Fallout 4 handled it great with their settlement system, but it was a buggy mess which ruined the game after about 60 to 100 hours of playtime. I figured they could fix those bugs and let you build colonies on habitable planets, but instead you just gather resources and setup machines to auto-craft items. I guess I was hoping for something like in Mass Effect: Andromeda, but with a more hands-on approach instead of just completing some quests to have colonists move in on their own. You can decorate your house if you get one, but there's no point in ever getting a house because you have no reason to ever go home. The most I ever used my house for was storage. It was a glorified warehouse with a bed and my plushie collection. I stored most of my items in the cargo holds on my spaceship, so building up storage at home was mostly just a never-ending cycle of trying to build more storage to store more resources in hopes that eventually I could actually get enough space to store enough resources to craft stuff I would actually want to make. Progressing your character also requires you to wipe out all the progress you make on this front, so it really doesn't feel worth it. You're better off grinding credits to buy whatever it is that you want.

The exploration is also just awful. Big empty worlds with nothing of interest. You just go around scanning stuff. Sometimes you find abandoned buildings which can be fun to explore for the first time, but then you go to another planet and find the same building there, story elements and all. I wouldn't mind exploring the same places if I reset the world, but the fact that I can find the same point of interest on four different planets in a single playthrough really makes those rare finds in the vast nothingness Bethesda has provided us with completely meaningless. 

If the game wasn't so empty and boring for the vast majority of playtime then I would keep playing it, but I can't be bothered. I'm also not going to hope the DLC fixes all these problems. I really can't express enough how much I don't want to play this game again despite how much I enjoy the good parts. I bought the game on launch and I put a lot of time into it hoping that I could figure out what makes the game good, but I never found it. I was weary after seeing how Fallout 76 looked on launch, but I was willing to give it a try. After playing this game I started to worry that even Elder Scrolls 6 won't be any good. It is almost like Bethesda forgot how to make an RPG after they finished working on Fallout 4.

Seriously forgot I had this game(purchased on launch) until Fallout 4 recently broke again thanks to Bethesda's inability to do anything right and read the room, so I got frustrated. As a decades-long Bethesda Game Studios fan, this is one of the most boring, uncompelling games I have ever played. I didn't even know it was possible to make a game this boring, but I guess when you base a game's design around PlayStation 1 loading screens and literal emptiness you get this. I can't rationalize why there are so many loading screens when there is seemingly no content to load. This was the first BGS game I could not finish because it felt like an obligation rather than a game. I stopped at the "big reveal" because if that was the best the game could offer then it wasn't worth finishing. Sure enough, I looked up the "ending" of the game and it ended exactly how I expected, glad I didn't stick around and waste another 10+ hours. That's not even the worst part, they genuinely thought it was a great idea to [spoiler]erase pretty much all of your progress just for some "haha isn't that crazy?" kind of BS[/spoiler] at the end of the game. PlayStation fans shouldn't even be upset that they didn't get this game because they missed nothing of value. I can think of probably a dozen other games that do exactly what this game tries to do and more. If there is one nice thing I can say about this game, it's probably the new lock-picking mini-game is kinda fun, but that's the only thing that comes to mind. At this point I have no faith that The Elder Scrolls 6 isn't going to be total dog water.

Starfield is just painfully mid. It doesnt even fullfill the bethesda game craving. Theres a lot to like, and the first hours i had with this game were pretty fun, but the facade breaks apart pretty quickly, and you find out, oh, this is all there is. its just not as fun as it seems on paper. A lot of the game design is outdated, clunky, not interconnected, and it all just falls apart in an incredibly unfun way.

Which is a shame! I had followed news for this game for years, and was INCREDIBLY excited for it! i watched all the pre release shows and dev interviews and stuff, followed online discussion, and i really genuinely truly thought Starfield would be something special. Something like Skyrim and Fallout 4, while being incredibly flawed games through and through, still had that special something, that Bethesda magic. That feeling of exporation, of having a huge fun sandbox to fuck around in, interesting lore, and rpg mechanics engaging enough to have a good time and become ridiculously powerful after coming from nothing. I have thousands of hours in other bethesda games, yet despite giving Starfield a *genuine* go, disconnected from all the online criticism, and genuinely wanting, craving to love it....

I walk away after only 30 so hours, not really wanting to play anymore. and its a shame! Its so obvious that a lot of very passionate and talented people worked on it! I see the vision, the old timey sci fi conventions and stuff, the whole nasa "punk" aesthetic thing, ooooh mystery and ADVENTURE and being campy and a good time, i was all for that! and the game looks beautiful! the music is pretty damn good too! ship combat is pretty fun! and a lot of the questlines are middling to pretty good!
But its just loading screen after loading screen after loading screen, meaningless fetchquest that couldve been an e-mail one after the other, and where that sort of thing was fine in skyrim, it just falls apart here. The Starfield doesnt feel like a living, breathing world, due to the way you actually interface with it, mostly consisting of fast traveling and constant loading screens. Sure, in skyrim, you could play like that if you liked to, or you could walk, and find something interesting along the way, a billion new quests, random encounters, whatever. here, its the only way to play the game.

I want to love starfield, and i have for years, but this game breaks my heart.

Will not recommend.

Is this the great game it could be? No. Do I have fun playing it? Yes.

It's what one would reasonably expect from Bethesda with their track record (e.g., lots of irrelevant but illusion-breaking bugs with a decent story line). I don't expect their games to be perfect but I do expect them to be fun and engaging while allowing for a true sandbox experience and they deliver that in spades.

In an infinite sea of potential, which shines on the surface like an oil slick, it manages to drown in the mediocrity below. 

Bethesda is, in theory, capable of better writing than this. 

But when even the linearity of Fallout 4 feels better implemented, and the setting feels so utterly devoid of the depth it demands and could have, I cannot imagine how we should ever expect anything better.

Building ships is fun! Good job!

Building outposts? Practically useless, boring, and you cannot do anything interesting with them. They have no impact on the game itself other than dull resource extraction and storage.

Factions? Under-explored, and each feels like it's engaged in petty squabbling, lacking any real ideological or ethical complexity.

And, like Fallout 4 before it you have no important choices to make, you have no lasting impacts.
All is blown away in a stale, dusty wind. Over and over again.
Ignore the naysayers, Starfield is great and gets better with every playthrough.

📣 Starfield Feedback: A Game That Feels Unfinished
After investing over 11 hours into Starfield — just to complete the first mission — I’ve hit a wall. Not because I ran out of content, but because the immersion collapsed under its own weight. I wanted to believe in this universe, but here’s where it broke down for me:

Companion AI is broken: Sarah repeats herself constantly, fails to keep up during missions, and teleports into the ship mid-combat with no continuity or reaction. It’s immersion-breaking and emotionally flat.

Planetary exploration is hollow: I landed near the Chlorine Ocean on Earth hoping to see a beach — but no matter where I clicked, I got the same prefab zone. Earth has no ruins, no landmarks, not even a single dilapidated building. It’s a texture map, not a memory.

Modding is still locked: Without full plugin support (.esp/.esm), we can’t get dynamic animation mods, companion overhauls, or meaningful adult-themed content. Collections exist, but they’re scaffolds — not systems.

I skipped the DLC: I didn’t buy Shattered Space because recent reviews were overwhelmingly negative. As of now, only 48% of recent Steam reviews are positive — meaning more than half of players are dissatisfied. That told me everything I needed to know.

Nobody is saying people don’t want to like this game — or that the development effort isn’t impressive. I’m just disappointed in the end result, and I don’t want Bethesda to give up. They’re off to a great start, but we need community involvement like with ESO and Zenimax, and regular 3-month updates with actual improvements.

We don’t need more paid mods that muck up our ability to install mods from Nexus. I’m really sad this is happening. I expected more from Bethesda — and the fact that Microsoft bought them should have improved things, not made them worse.

I’m not here to troll or flame. I just want to see this game become what it was meant to be. Right now, it feels like a myth half-told — beautiful in concept, but unfinished in execution.

I’m so disappointed. I really want this game to succeed, but I feel like the company has already given up on it. I’m unhappy with it in its current state. It needs a lot of work — but it is off to a great start.

I’m being open and honest about my feelings. The concept is solid. The end result isn’t finished and needs development — not more DLCs or paid mods.

I’m someone who normally gives positive reviews. I look for reasons to be generous. I just can’t do it here. But if Bethesda and Microsoft turn this around and work on the game — get it up to par with everyone’s expectations — I’ll be the first to change my review.

A deeply flawed disappointment, troubled by poor writing and unimaginative exploration. Redeemed only by decent action.

--------------------------

Pros:

Gunplay is satisfying for a Bethesda game, almost feeling like a dedicated shooter in how entertaining blasting opponents can be.

Zero-G movement is incredibly fun and implemented really well. By far the best new feature this game adds.

Cons:

Despite the focus on the spacecraft, they are largely an afterthought - space combat is far too simple, ship components are horrifically unbalanced, and there is no actual flying to be done. Jumping systems, travel to planets, landing, and takeoff are all merely loading screens. Rather than feeling like an open galaxy, the world of Starfield feels more like a series of rooms with a starry backdrop.

Similarly, outpost building is an utter waste of time. There is no need to ever build an outpost - no colonies to build up and populate with settlers, no resource incentive (since you would have to build a dozen outposts to get the right combination of useful resources), and the story never touches on the feature even a little.

Apart from the problems with the space content, the actual RPG elements are all over the place. There are far too many features locked behind perks, far too many levels for each perk, and the loot system took all the worst parts of Fallout 4's insistence on being able to pick up everything while simultaneously removing any utility in doing so.

The companions in this game are mostly dreadfully dull people. I liked Sam well enough, but they are all still just a single personality trait personified. They have no nuance in thought, no real differences of opinion, barely any backstory of note. They exist merely to fill crew positions and repeat the same 3 lines of dialogue whenever you switch loading screens. You would think a guild of explorers would be full of bright-eyed, scientific, and curious minds - but you quickly realize that these people will offer nothing of value in the actual act of exploration.

Speaking of exploration... There is almost none to be had. You can land on planets, scan minerals, flora, and fauna; yes. However, there is nothing else to it other than the same randomly-generated pirate outposts, abandoned labs, military facilities, or mining outfits. There are no hand-placed nooks with secrets to find, no environmental storytelling, no surprises. It's all just an algorithm spitting out random junk and passed off as "exploration". The only incentive to even explore at all is selling the survey data - you don't get anything other than money for having done so. Of all my issues, this is the most egregious and the one that really spits in the face of any fan that was once excited for this game.

I'm not a fan of Bethesda games. I've tried Fallout 3 and New Vegas and they did not feel like Fallout 1 and 2 but were more like a 3D caricature of the games I loved. I've tried Morrorwind, Oblivion, and Skyrim and found them boring. The hours I have in Skyrim are only because I kept starting and quitting. Starfield is the only Bethesda game that really hooked me.

Sure it's still buggy. The main quest is kinda boring and jarringly shoved in an otherwise decent sci-fi world. But I'd rather play this than any of their other games or even Baldur's Gate 3. I hope they don't give up the IP and ditch the weird magical multiverse crap in the next one.

I can't recommend this game to everyone, as it is not for everyone, sadly. The reviews are mixed because some like it, and others don't. I happen to be one of those that do like it. Story's good, relatively riveting in parts; plot twists abound. Gun-play could use some work to be honest, but it isn't the only part of the game that matters to me, so it's easily overlooked. 

Difficulty can now be adjusted in the game play section of the settings menu. You can make enemies deal less damage and yourself deal more, and that is welcome because as someone who doesn't spend that much time in first person shooters, I don't have years of experience with those--I'm much more of an RPG guy that uses melee weapons such as swords, bows and arrows, magic, etc etc.

Now the bad: Without spoiling too much...if you don't do something a certain way at the end of the game, you can and will be stuck with the same outcome over and over. I did not know this going in, and every new game+ felt like a bad episode of The Twilight Zone, lol. Way too much deja vu every time I began again, in other words. That is pretty much the only thing I hate. Had my real life friend who enjoyed this game as well told me this without spoiling too much, I might've been spared repeating scenarios. 

There are mods to fix this for that reason I'd guess, but if you want achievements I'd focus on the above relatively vague advice. Also I believe every new game+ means you deal less and less damage to enemies...something you'd have to look up because Bethesda does not tell you this...

The price point for the game plus the DLC is rather disturbing too. But...all in all...if you love a solid story, don't mind halfway-decent gun-play, and can afford to shell out a little over $100 for the game and the DLC, then go for it! Otherwise, wait until it goes on sale (if ever) and get it then. I am not writing a glowing review...I'd give this a 3.5 out of 5 stars for not explaining in-game how to avoid the twilight zone (and the price point). Not everyone makes enough money to afford a nearly $100 game with the DLC included...jeez. Plus I hear Shattered Space isn't even that good. Having not gotten there yet as I took a gaming hiatus...I cannot say for certain.

Meh, it's not that you can't get enjoyment out of it, but the game feels like it has no soul. On top of re-using so much assets (You'll explore the same bases in a different location over and over again) everything just feels so... meh. For example, I romanced Sarah Morgan, and it felt like nothing happens, no kissing, no sexy time, no emotions, nothing, you say your vows, you're done. Go back to playing the rest of the game. Then if something happens to her because of my choices, minor spoiler, still it feels like nothing happened and the game moves on. Basically no weight behind anything you do. I haven't played since launch, I'll probably play it again at some point, but there are just better games out there, I have yet to play Outer Worlds 1 for example. I'll recommend it but only if you can get it for cheap, the game is enjoyable just don't expect to be emotionally invested in anything that happens, everyone has the personality of a toaster oven. I've played this game a lot and I can't explain why. There are so many kernels of what could be a great game here but the devs did not follow through on them. There are constant references and attempts at emulating better games or ip's but references are all they are. The thing that's kept me engaged is a story I've crafted in my head filling in the blanks that Bethesda keeps empty, playing through quests and imagining little ways that Bethesda could have done those quests so much better if they had tried. So many design choices are baffling. So many lore choices are ludicrous. Certain quest lines, particularly those involving the two criminal factions (Crimson Fleet and Ryujin Industries) are so poorly implemented, so clearly unfinished that I am shocked that anyone at Bethesda considered them appropriate for release. This whole game is a pile of things that Bethesda started and refused to see through to completion. This game feels like half a rough draft of an essay turned in 10 minutes before the deadline. Where is the follow through?

This is a Bethesda game, you get a Bethesda game. Lots of loading, lots of walking, but also everything for the most part can be interacted with. The main game will run you about 40 hours if you do the main quest and many of the side quest. I wouldnt say it is as good as fallout or oblivion. It does hold interest for a while but has its flaws. All the menu items can break the feeling of the game, the loading screens can pull the user out. But if you like space games that can last a long time this one has the potential for that.

Side note: I purchased the DLC with the early release version of the game, I have not yet played the DLC because after 40ish hours of playing the game I am for the most part done with it.

Beautiful environments, great skill tree, beautifully revamped player models, and lastly lovely space craft builder.

Sub-par story (at best), POIs repeat too often/less explorability for a space exploration RPG game, genuinely terrible exploration in space as well, lackluster combat mechanics and weapons (guns, I need more guns instead of different variants of the same damn few guns), paid mods (I support mod developers but damn, they just push this on you more and more). For how big the game is, there is so little to do at most times. Mods are genuinely the only way to have fun and that is bad, especially again with paid mods being a requirement if you want good mods that aren't available elsewhere (and when most modders decided to leave this game).
Also, absolutely terrible base building mechanics and options...

90% of the game lacks content, its not good at all.

Not worth full price. Recommended only if you wanna play large mod packs (like Starfield Genesis) or want to try some mods out. Vanilla gameplay is not worth the original price at all.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

I do still enjoy the game when I have mods so I personally will enjoy it but as a person who wants things to do and lots of things to stay occupied, this is not it.

The simplest, yet perfect way to describe this game is as follows; Bethesda game design in space. If you like Bethesda's game philosophy, you'll enjoy it, I know I did for a while. However the main problems with this game is the insanely bloated amount of obvious loading screens, and the overall writing for a majority of quest lines. The game calls itself an RPG, yet the game constantly railroads you during quest lines. Almost all choices result in the same outcome, making multiple playthroughs almost pointless.

Aside from what I personally call the "Emil Pagliarulo Problem"(the poor writing problem), the other glaring issue is the insane number of loading screens. If I got a dollar for every loading screen I had in a three hour play session, I'd probably have $100. That doesn't sound like much but that would be roughly $33 an hour. Obviously I was being over-dramatic, but let me just lay out how frequently loading screens are. You enter a ship? Loading screen. Travel to a different solar system? Loading screen. Travel to a specific lunar or planetary surface in the system? Loading screen. Want to land on the planet? Loading screen! Want to exit your ship? Loading Screen!! I could keep going, but I think you get the point.

Overall, kinda fun every now and then and I would recommend, however I can't shake a slight feeling of disappointment due to the previously mentioned issues.

Game is OK, it's not amazing or anything. Feels bloated at times. The amount of dungeons is limited and during main story you encounter repetitions. Finale was a nice surprise, although the concept of multiverse is nothing new. 

But to better enjoy the game mods are a must have. If I were to judge the game without them I wouldn't recomend this game.

From the perspective of the base game alone, I wouldn't recommend Starfield. When you think of Skyrim or the Fallout series.. those legendary Bethesda titles, it's clear they wanted Starfield to be the next big thing. Unfortunately, it ends up feeling like a shadow of those older games. You can see what it wants to be, and maybe a future iteration will get there, but right now it’s a pretty shallow take on a sci-fi RPG.

That said, there’s a Star Wars mod out there that's really making waves. I won't name it directly here, but if you can find it and grab Starfield at a heavy discount, that mod turns it into a much better experience. It's essentially a total conversion and actually quite fun. So if you're going to dive in, that’s the way I’d suggest doing it.
Great game
Great Game

Starfield Review: 8/10

Yeah, it’s got flaws, the menus are clunky, the loading screens are constant, and some of the planets feel pretty empty. But even with all that, I still had a good time.

Exploring space, upgrading ships, and finding weird little side quests kept me hooked way longer than I expected. The gunplay’s actually solid, the music’s great, and when the game hits those big cinematic moments, it really feels epic.

It’s not Skyrim in space, and that’s fine. It’s more chill, more about wandering and building your own adventure. If you go in with that mindset, it’s a good time.

Despite the flaws, I don’t regret a single hour I put into it.

I suffered it enough to build my own ship and that's it.

The first time you walk into somewhere you think 'This is brilliant!', but after you walk through the same building on a dozen different planets, it isn't just tedious... its disappointing. Its not even like there's a huge amount of different enemies to spice them up either.

You could make the argument that space travel and settlement on the edges of known space would be tedious and repetitive. That there'd be a lot of emptiness, that the cold clinical HUDs are functional as you'd expect to see, that all the colours are drab, everything seems clinical, and that Bethesda may be onto a nice arcade-like space sim here. But this isn't being marketed as a sim, its being marketed as an adventure; exploration, combat, space flight, new places, new challenges etc. and it only JUST scrapes in to meet that definition.

The ship builder is pretty good though. Adding weapons and modules to create something that looks like no other is damn fun but the grind to get there isn't really worth it.

Bethesda has some wonderful hits, so naturally, they're bound to have misses.
Next time, shrink the universe and diversify it. 

Honestly, go buy No Mans Sky.
Its the culmination of 10 years of development, reward the devs for that alone. The game its beautiful and colourful, there is life, depth, and emotion to it. After the intro, it welcomes you in and you actively want to stay and see what it has to offer. There are repeated assets (of course) but there are a lot of different ones for the game to choose from.
While it doesn't have an in-depth shipbuilder, it does have a big settlement and structure element to it. Combat is minimal it must be said, but you can whittle away hours building a place of your own and look back at your results and feel like you've done something, unlike in Starfield. 

Put it another way. In only one of these games can you grow illegal space weed and use a portal to go to the nearest space station to avoid all the authorities and cargo scans and make huge profit... and that game isn't Starfield.
this is the worst of bethesda design and greed and im still addicted, stay away. - an* oblivion fan

Okay. I'm gonna go on a small story time rant here. GOTY 2015. There were a few titles in the front running for winning it. Ended up going to Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. W3 is an absolutely beautiful game. But, we're not reviewing this one. W3 beats out Fallout 4, but not because W3 had a better or more compelling story. W3 beat FO4 because in EVERY way, W3 was a better game, the story, the combat, the world building, the crowd functions, the DLCs, the beautiful replayability. Todd Howard thought for some stupid reason, this was a 1 off, and that his game should've won. The problem is, FO4 was a result of Todd, and by extension Bethesda thinking that because they had two flagship titles (Fallout and The Elder Scrolls) no matter what people would buy their games. So they make something average. The thing is, The Witcher 3 wasn't just GOTY in 2015, it set the GOLD STANDARD for RPG games afters that. Games should be at least what W3 is in order to be considered mediocre nowadays. So unfortunately, Todd spit this crap out for players thinking the same thing. "I'm Todd Howard from Bethesda, people WILL buy my game." Yeah, okay buddy. Barely 3,000 daily players. 

The game is less-than-average, no better than a 3.5-4.5/10. The main story is mid. The only storyline I enjoyed was the Crimson Fleet. Side quests are reused constantly, with very little breadth. I expected the classic fetch quests and "go here, kill this enemy" quest, but jeez, Bethesda really didn't write anything that well.

Characters are written really poorly, with your entire crew seemingly being okay with some big poly-orgy going on on the ship. On that note, the 4 options you have for romance is really, really disappointing. You cannot really fully get into the game and roleplay how you'd like. 

The ship building is the only saving grace this game has, coupled with the ship combat, it makes everything else sorta bearable. In addition, mods make this game playable. Star Wars: Genesis is the only reason I have put any reasonable time into the game. Which is a mod I HIGHLY recommend. The only downside is the fact that you have to give $90 to that burning husk of a company known as Bethesda Softworks in order to enjoy that gorgeous mod. 

Don't buy this game, don't buy it on sale, and don't play it. It's genuinely a bad game and it was VERY poorly executed. Before any idiots decide to say, "if you didn't enjoy the game you wouldn't have put 500 hours into it", no. Stop. $90 means I should be enjoying this game for years to come. Not pick it up, play for 10 and never touch it. I have games for less than $10 in my library that I have been playing for years. 

Seriously, this game sucks.

Is it Skyrim good? No. Is it Fallout 3/4 good? Probably not. But do you like the Bethesda sandbox style of play? Do you like space and the idea of traveling to other planets? If so, the game is worth your time. It didn't live up to the hype but it does scratch that Bethesda itch.

Do yourself a favor and download the Star Wars: Genesis conversion mod. Makes this game actually worth playing. Don't bother with the base game... but if you do, mod the hell out of it to make it way better.
Just go play Elite Dangerous or Star Citizen. At least those are fun.

The story was so bad it became a chore to go through much like the rest of the game. forgettable characters and poorly written dialogue. The only enjoyable things were the ship building system, and the graphics. What a shame

If you are here for a classic bethesda experience look elsewhere. Wanted skyrim in space, instead, you get those popping things that you buy at gas stations to entertain your kids for the car ride for the temple fights. This game is like an inch deep ocean reflecting the starry night sky; it looks deep but once you step inside you realise there is almost nothing there. I wanted to love this game, I really, really did. However it has so many problems that it almost feels like a fake game, like something one would see a teen playing in a movie where the director vaguely understands the concept of a video game. If you want a space exploration game about ship building, base creation and more check out No Man's Sky or literally any other space game (Astroneer, Elite Dangerous, etc). There are so many loading screens (every time you enter/exit a building or your ship or enter/exit orbit or travel to another planet). The areas you land on planets are limited and extremely generically procedurally generated - using the exact same structures over and over. There are surprisingly few weapons and boring skills. The missions themselves are mostly generated fetch quests for side content and the handcrafted stories fall flat. The base building system seems like an afterthought as does how systems connect with each other. Additionally, the Starfield tries to mimic locations of several other games without success. There is a Western Read Dead Redemption 2 esque city, a Cyperpunk 2077 Night city esque city, a generic scifi utopia but not city that are all incredibly small. The cyperpunk one is essentially a single street with side passages on the outside. There is nothing new or interesting to see. Starfield is an inch deep ocean reflecting the Field of Stars of far more innovative games it so desperately tries to convince you it competes with.

This game launched originally to a lot of mixed, if not outright poor reviews. And to be fair, it promised a lot and delivered...less than that. 

I still love the playstyle of this game and the storytelling it has mixed in to some of the most interesting planet designs I've seen in a video game. (Hard to beat No Man's Sky...but let's be real here). 

In true Bethesda fashion, they've created a wonderful story, a believable universe full of twists and turns, and some really amazing and memorable characters that keep you on your toes. I love this game so much.

Its got all the makings of a great game. A lot of planets and stuff to explore but the world still somehow feels small. Like why would the capital city of an interstellar empire be so small I could walk across it in like 45 seconds? It gives me uncanny valley vibes. Like, it looks like a good game, plays like a good game, has all the characteristics of a good game, but for some reason, it just wasn't that good. I do recommend it though because I still played and beat it. The ship building is cool, base building is cool. The game is absolutely gorgeous imo and you will enjoy it for a while. You know what I just realized, its a good game, but I feel let down because it didn't live up to its potential. I think they need to keep building this game up, it could be incredible with time.
