[h1]Make Starfield great (again)![/h1]

There are still thousands of us exploring the stars every day — building ships, tweaking mods, and losing track of time.

I’ve spent hundreds of hours in this universe, and honestly, you don’t do that with a game you don’t love.

So come on, space travelers — drop a positive review and keep the fire burning for Bethesda and all the amazing modders out there! 🌌

This game doesn't know what it wants to be. Clearly, Bethesda was inspired by No Man's Sky but the open world nature of that game conflicts with Bethesda's strengths as a studio. The procedural generation of the planets results in content which commits the cardinal sin of gaming, which is that it is BORING. There are a few scattered points of interest, and some resources to gather and animals or plants to scan and that's basically it. NMS has all kinds of interesting things to find but not here. Plus the fact that you have to scan objects multiple times is just pointless busy work.

You do get the signature Bethesda RPG features like fully voice-acted dialog but, honestly, who cares? Who is actually listening to all of this? It worked in Skyrim because there are a lot more interesting characters and the world is more flavorful but here, IDK, I just did not really care about most of the characters I met and most of your companions are so goody two shoes and bland.

The combat is okay - it is serviceable at at least. Some of the extended quest lines are not bad. And the ship building is decent if kind of generic. My main issue with the gameplay is that Bethesda didn't commit to their own mechanics. You can mine and extract resources but they can all be bought so cheaply from basically anywhere that there is little point. You can build a base but your ship has all the features anyways so what is the point? And again, that's because the game doesn't know what it wants to be - it has some of the gathering-crafting mechanics of NMS but they feel relatively pointless. Some of the quest lines are pretty good but the core of the game is extremely generic and lazily implemented procedurally generated worlds which are boring and stale and just not fun to run around. In my opinion, it would have been better if they had concentrated on a more limited number of planets which were more densely populated with content and locations. This mish-mash of survival game, procedural generation, and hand-written quests just does not come together. It is like a bunch of disjointed parts that don't play well together.

And though I didn't ever get there, the NG+ mode is not a good fit for a game like this. You spend dozens of hours building bases and ships, finding the best gear, and doing all the quests and you want me to do it all over again, just with my better skills and abilities? Yeah, no thanks - I have no interest is resetting my progress. This is yet another feature that just seems tagged on which doesn't work well with the whole.

I will say that I did have some fun with this game and it has its merits. But for most of these boxes they were trying to check off here, you'd be better off playing No Man's Sky, which does "endless" space, procedural generation, and survival-crafting extremely well. There are also minimal loading screens - dear god, don't get me started with the ludicrous number of loading screens in Starfield. It's absurd.

Space: The Final Frontier (of Boredom)
Hours Played: Too many for how little fun I had.

I want to love Starfield. I really do. Every year I reinstall it thinking, “Maybe this time the stars will finally align.” Then I make it about three hours in before realizing I’d rather be alphabetizing my ammo inventory in Fallout 4.

Don’t get me wrong — the gunplay is solid, the worlds look pretty, and there’s enough stuff to do to fill an interstellar Walmart. But the story? Man, it moves slower than a cargo ship with broken thrusters. Every quest feels like it’s daring me to care — and I’m losing that challenge hard.

If you like pure sandbox exploration, you’ll probably have a blast scanning rocks and stealing sandwiches from space pirates. But if you’re looking for that classic Bethesda storytelling magic — the “I accidentally became the leader of every faction” kind of fun — you might want to orbit elsewhere.

Starfield isn’t bad, it’s just... tedious. It’s like the game hands you the entire universe and says, “Do whatever you want!” but forgets to make any of it feel meaningful.

Maybe I’ll try again next year. Maybe by then, they’ll patch in fun.

I WANTED to like this game. There's so many good aspects of this game where you can see the potential. The New Creation Engine is amazing, the features for gravity, shipbuilding, and space combat feel really good.

People will shit on the engine or the loading screen frequency or any NPC animations, but these are all shallow things that don't affect the actual quality of the game. They're not the problem.

The problem is the questline design, and nothing makes it more clear than those few questlines that are designed well: The UC Vanguard Questline. It's makes such good use of the new engine and mechanics, it has good writing, you can explore a lot of what this game CAN offer.

Then you play anything else, like the main quest. Get thing from planet, go back to New Atlantis. Go to new planet, come back again. They have a huge playground in space that they just don't use. They have a few populated planets each with only one city - a little immersion breaking but I understand the limitations. The problem is they keep making you go between planets for the most inane things. If you're focusing on a questline you rarely stay in one place for long, and when you travel somewhere else there's no excitement or danger: you go through a loading screen to travel then go through another loading screen and another. If it was a loading screen to space and then there was something to do in space before getting to your destination, that would be SOMETHING. The reason everyone points to the loading screens as a flaw isn't because separate cells are unbearable, it's because Bethesda treated most of this game like all their others where everything is one single continuous map with some interiors. The separated maps aren't the fatal flaw, they're merely the lens that exposes the flaw.

This COULD be a good game - if it utilized its own systems and tech upgrades, but it doesn't. The engine feels modern, but the gameplay loop most questlines thrust the player into hasn't caught up. It's a disjointed, incongruous experience that occasionally shows you a 10/10 experience hidden beneath a pile of mediocrity.

One more message specifically for Todd Howard: We play your old games because they're fun to REPLAY and try different builds or factions. Cutting off certain parts of the game for one character based on the player's choices does not limit player freedom, but rather increases and rewards it. Removing consequences from player's choices does not increase player freedom, it renders it meaningless. Stop taking the wrong lessons from your older successes.

Edit: I played 50 hours on gamepass, stop whining about the playtime, Steam is not all-knowing.
GREAT GAME

I think its a good game. It has some good elements in it that I like. I like being able to steal enemy ships, I actually like the cut scene spaceship launches and landings. Nothing is over complicated. But it does feel just like skyrim in its gameplay. 
               While everything is new as far as characters, items, weapons and textures... the subconscious feeling is that I still feel like I'm playing Skyrim. It has the same FEEL and with that being the case, id vote that I would have rather seen a new Skyrim. I have over 2000 hours in Skyrim and that"s just on steam, not including all the time I played it on Xbox and I still play it from time to time. What made me so happy with Skyrim was the ability to look up anything in the console and manipulate the game with what I would say is 10000 cheats and I do appreciate that it was somewhat also available in this game. 
              I can see myself playing this game also for some time. But I would have much rather seen a brand new Skyrim. Wouldn"t even need to change much of the mechanics, just another continent to explore with a new beginning and background. Morrowind Remade or something. I played this for 37 hours and got bored, not because its a bad game, but just because it feels like I played a heavily modified Skyrim for 37 hours on top of the 2500 (give or take) hours I already played of Skyrim. 
              I do feel like the engine you are using in both this game and Skyrim works so much better for Skyrim than for a space game and can't really describe why. Every location in Skyrim was unique and was able to be so because most of the environments were somewhat expected to be the same but had different "lore" with each one. 
              Starfield feels more bland to me, there doesn't feel to be much lore between anything except the Sol system. Other than that, each location felt like it might as well be on any other planet. I felt it would have been interesting to have planets divided between factions instead of just player level. There is somewhat this division but you don't really feel or see it on the star map. 
              I found the whole main quest to be uninteresting, not because its bad, but more because a space game comes more in an interest in exploration and carving your own path than doing a job for someone else. I didn't like that lady telling me she had something to give me almost every time I got on the ship. "Ok, its the fifth time you told me lady, I don't need reminded for the fifth time that you got me a piece of space cabbage." like really... I think I shot her in the face a couple times over this and she still didn't shut up. I was trying to do the usual Skyrim stealth archer thing and she kept giving away our position and annoying me. I liked the idea of her coming along... at first.. until she proved to be incredibly annoying. Sorry, just a little bit about her, I usually tell her to stay in place as soon as we get off the ship. Then I got a new NPC lady later on, she was a little better because she would cloak with me when holding still, but then she started spouting off crap too. Now I had two people I just couldn't wait to drop off at home. 
              I didn't like quests that stuck me with people for a certain amount of time. I use the console to unlock the door at the trackers alliance so I can get to the console to do my own thing. I constantly start new games to try new builds and its a pain to go through the same quest over and over again. I like to freely do what I want in a space game. 
              Being able to buy new ships and upgrade them the way I want was fun, I didn't like how difficult it was to actually find the upgrades I wanted though. Level locking them didn't seem fun or realistic. Why cant I be some nobody with a lot of money and just start buy good ships and parts. Took away from being able to decide how I wanted to play.
               Ship registration prices were a bit of a boring way to balance the game in my opinion.
         No gambling in the red mile... that was a surprise... I was expecting a New Vegas experience but it was completely empty of that, I was a bit disappointed but at least there were a couple mods for it. I understand the "illegal in other countries" thing. So oh well, I guess they are to blame for ruining that one. I just don't quite understand that though because Star Wars Outlaws had gambling in it. 
             Anyways, I guess the biggest flaw with the game is that it already feels like the other 2500 hours I already invested in this engine. If we are going to stick with the same engine, then I would have liked an improvement to what was already great and still is... Skyrim. Skyrim 2 or Morrowind Remake, not a Morrowind retexture but a remake. I loved fighting Dagoth Ur at the end and loved the lore of his back story. Seeing that again with Skyrim graphics would be awesome. You really did have some great lore in Morrowind, loved going in and doing battle with Vivec to test my strength.
              Sorry Bethesda but you have Skyrim stamped on your forehead now, and you'll either have to do better and better versions of that or change your company name so you can side step expectations.
             But I do like Starfield and will be playing it more as time goes on. But if you ever make a Elder Scrolls Six, Starfield is going to collect dust.

Contrary to the negative reviews, this game is freakin' awesome.  I always look over negative reviews before deciding to purchase a game.  The negative comments for this game are pretty lame, frivolous, and without merit.  Yes, there are irritants with companions...so don't use them, as I don't.  
Once I started this game, I haven't been able to stop...197 hours so far...and have only completed one main quest (I did this with Skyrim as well).  I've done most of the faction quests, and find hunting bad guys to be fun.  The open world concept is great, as I travel to planets to farm.  I use ballistic weapons, and sniping opponents has been a real joy.  For me, the variety of weapons has been perfect.  Yes, ammo is expensive, but acquiring wealth in this game is pretty easy if you like farming...all you have to do is take out enemy encampments, which are easy to find, sell their weapons and gear, and you're set.  
A lot of my time has been spent on crafting.  I have built a custom ship, which is also my home hub.  I do have a few apartments, but having a luxury ship is better for me.  
If you liked Skyrim and Fallout 4, then you'll love this game as well.

I don't usually write reviews for games, but I felt like writing one for this, which says something about it.

The game starts up very promising... The beautiful scenery and worlds, nice graphics, mysterious story about the artifacts that promises excitement and adventure, the vast universe with countless worlds and dynamic and exciting characters. On paper it sounds amazing, right? Well... on the surface. 

The main problem with the game is that the story is kind of boring. I wanted to get invested... but I often found myself not caring or skipping dialog just to move things along. Whenever that happens, you know you have lost your audience. There is just not enough soul in the story to make you care, to make you want to see things through to the end, as was the case with the Mass Effect games 1, 2 and 3. There is nothing like that here. And that is why ultimately this game has failed. 

Second, there is no space exploration as you would imagine it. Yes, you get to jump and land to many different world's VIA the loading screen, but you cannot explore space itself, for all you get is a sky box with a fairly low resolution planet in front of you. Even the jump sequence is not that exciting (as was the case in Elite Dangerous or Star Citizen). 

Now I know you can argue that Mass Effect games also did not allow you to fly around space yourself (you just got a loading screen video showing you jump between different Mass Relays), but Mass Effect was never promoted as an exploration game, Starfield was. 

The planet world's are beautiful in themselves, but a lot of times they lack those handmade cities or locations that make an open world game exciting to explore. Yes, there was plenty of beautiful flora and fauna to see and generic space structures scattered around the map, but after a while, it gets boring. And no, there are no massive planet-wide cities here, all you get are about four custom settlements that would fit into a neighborhood or two. 

Third, the game Engine is outdated and it shows. This is the first game that I absolutely had to install on an SSD for it is unplayable on a regular hard drive (I mean it plays, but with very frequent lags in audio and video). The interface is not very intuitive and at times frustrating, and too much emphasis was placed on collecting all sorts of useless objects on every turn, as this was meant to impress us with the variety of content. 

So this is what you have, and RPG without an exciting story, a confusing interface, and a space exploration game with no space exploration. Now, this game will probably be enjoyed by a niche audience, or someone who doesn't have a lot of expectations for this game, and buys this on sale or receives it as a gift. 

Now don't get me wrong, I had a lot of beautiful and exciting moments in Starfield, but they were kind of far in between. This is the type of game where you can put 40 hours into, and then watch the ending on YouTube because you get too tired of it. 

At the end of the day it seems like Bethesda needed a new "bread and butter" game to release, they smartly chose the space exploration genre, but were not willing to fully invest their time and energy for development to make an epic game, but still branded it as epic. I think if they give you an opportunity to fly around the space and add more depth to the story, they can salvage this game to make it truly epic.

Thoroughly enjoy Starfield. I always enjoy a good Bethesda game and this is the most Bethesda one of them all. Typical Bethesda quirks are present but satisfying loot and an abundance of questing means there's pletny to do. Love the art, there's something really special about how this game looks. Is there room for improvement? Yes, there always will be in every video game. Would I still recommend it anyway? If you enjoyed Fallout and/or The Elder Scrolls, yes. It's kind of like Fallout in space.

Summary: 
Starfield is definitely a good game. If you like the gameplay of Fallout or Elder Scrolls, this is basically the same in a sci-fi setting. There's exploration, looting, traditional combat, ship combat, resource gathering, equipment upgrading, settlement building/upgrading, ship upgrading, skill tree development, and factions to join or fight. And the game engine feels familiar. Despite what the social media and message board echo chambers say, the vanilla game was completely playable, just like every other Fallout and ES game I've played. I'd give it a biased 7/10. The gameplay appeals to me the way ES and Fallout do. The story is good. It definitely has some annoyances/flaws and took longer to get into than their other games, but there is much more to like than dislike. And they've continued to tweak it and make improvements. Plus, I have more hours in my 1st play-through of Starfield than any other game's 1st play-through - 425+ hours prior to the DLC and now over 525 hours with it. That surprised me.

Details: 
This took a little longer to get into than Fallout and ES games. I can see why some folks may have quit early. I arrived at New Atlantis 4-5 hours in. Immediately had side quest overload. About 15 hours in, I remembered there was a main story I was supposed to be doing. Somewhere between 20-30 hours, I was hooked. And aside from being forced to go undercover and join a side faction, I played the entire game joining only the main story faction. Despite the joke 'Most Innovative Gameplay' nomination, it did have a pretty cool game and story mechanic about half or two-thirds through the main story that should have been used more. Where I found No Man's Sky (about 120 hours played) *interesting*, I can't say that the game was always fun, especially being 3rd person. For me, Starfield was a lot more fun than NMS.

The main story is interesting, but didn't give me the sense of purpose their other games did. The more I played, the more depth it had, but the writing tends to keep it from ever being great. If Witcher 3 writing is S tier, Starfield is probably B tier or marginally A at best. The voice acting is the same - generally good, rarely great. The humor is similar to their other games, especially Fallout. There are editorial overtones about corporations and different societal values. Quips, comments, and responses by followers and NPCs can be interesting/entertaining the first time, but get repetitive and little annoying after that.

It's interesting to see the ship and hab design mostly influenced by the 60s and 70s space program and movies. Though tech for interstellar space travel is common, hand tools from the 20th century are all over the game because they are apparently still used - just not by players. I generally don't enjoy settlement building and upgrading, but have had fun upgrading my ships and tweaking the design as I gained access to better modules and weapons. The boost packs for the suits are fun, especially on low G planets or moons - it's like the marsupial mutation in Fallout 76 on steroids.

I played on Normal difficulty. I could take out multiple enemies 5-10 levels higher easily. However, I'm not too experienced with space combat (mostly avoided it in NMS) and found it frustrating early. I had to do other quests before I could upgrade my ship and skills to get past some quest-required space fights against 3 or 4 ships less than half my level. That's probably more of a 'me' issue, and the majority of fights are now much more manageable, but I do think the difficulty skews harder with ship combat resulting in an imbalance compared to regular combat. I saw they added options for raising/lowering regular or ship combat difficulty in May 2024, so thanks, Bethesda.

Surveying eventually got to my OCD and I 100% surveyed every place I visited. Surveying planets and moons is VERY chill for times when I want that. I ended the main story with over 500 planets and moons fully surveyed. It's a little disappointing that on nearly every planet and moon I visit, there is human development within view. Some folks have complained about how empty the game is, but on the scale of a galaxy (they say universe), it's incredibly highly populated. Bethesda is trying to balance scarcity of life and anything interesting that most planets would realistically have by adding human development to see or explore, some with a human presence to either help or fight. But, the variety of those random quests is lacking. They definitely reuse too many assets and situations too frequently. Certain random facilities on different planets and moons will not only be physically identical, but have the exact same situation (usually overrun by one of the pirate, cult, or mercenary groups) down to enemies doing the exact same scripted actions. Once you recognize these, it's easy to avoid if you don't want to bother. But, if there are enemies and you want to choose violence, it can be a fun way to try out new weapons and there is always loot. As I progress, I continue to find named stations or habs that are more unique and add more interest, depth, or back-story to the game. They usually have aspects I cannot access, so I assume are related to the faction quests I have almost completely ignored.

Some landscapes and skyscapes are very beautiful, even breathtaking. Despite a lot of diversity in planets and moons, a lot of icy moons are similar, if not identical. Many planets provide environmental variety with areas ranging from frozen plains, deserts, forests, savannas, hills, mountains, beaches, etc. Planetary traits get reused across many worlds, but based on the environment, may be snow and ice covered in one place, but in the middle of a rocky desert on another. I get it - they saved time and money on design and can drop an environmental layer on it to add variation. Although some weather can be annoying from a survival aspect, the weather changes add variety, which I like. IMO, the game is lacking in extreme weather. I would have preferred some planets/moons - Venus, for example - that require special gear, such as a mech suit or specialized vehicle. Speaking of which, since the buggy was added, I reloaded my last save before end-game and started exploring again. I enjoyed running around with the suit, but the buggy is a little faster. It's pretty basic, but a decent addition.

I've only encountered one quest breaking bug that others had, but it was a side quest and was fixed in one of the winter 2023 patches. Like most Bethesda games, the vast majority of bugs are on a spectrum from funny to annoying, but they rarely ruin the game. I haven't had many crashes (maybe 20 or so in the first 400 hours) and several early ones were driver crashes.

I have an AMD 5800X and had an OC'd PowerColor RX 5700 XT with 8GB that was showing its age. At 2560x1440 on mostly medium settings, I generally got 35 to 55 fps in outdoor areas. Planets with thick flora and higher human/alien populations dropped into the upper 20s. Lowering game resolution to 1920x1080 and using upscaling increased it by 5+ fps. Upgrading to a PowerColor RX 7900 GRE with most settings on high and using a tweaking guide has it running at 80-120 fps (my set cap) most of the time, only rarely dropping below 60 in highly populated areas with thick flora.
The only reason to play this game is for Star Wars Genesis. Incredible mod that builds a masterpiece out of a subpar Bethesda game.

I've read a lot of the reviews, and Reddit, etc. And I see the ratio of likes/dislikes on the store page. Honestly all that scared me away from this game until just a week or so ago, when I decided I just had to try it. I searched for some "how to appreciate Starfield on its own merits" discussions, and I really think that helped.

To truly enjoy Starfield, I had to unlearn my expectations from past Bethesda games. If you go in expecting "Skyrim in Space," you'll miss the mark. But if you embrace it as a space RPG, with emphasis on Space that I'll get to in a second, you'll find a fun and rewarding adventure that captures its own kind of magic.

That classic Bethesda feeling of discovery is definitely here. I’d be randomly hopping from one star system to another and stumble upon a distress call that turned into a fantastic, multi-part quest like "Mantis" or "Failure to Communicate." That familiar, satisfying loop of exploring a hostile base, winning a firefight, and then methodically looting everything you can find is alive and well. The rewards for just getting lost and seeing what's out there are piles of clutter, a few credits, and loads of weapons and armor. Just like I'm used to.

This sense of adventure extends well to space itself. Hunting from horseback in Skyrim was fun, but hunting space pirates for bounties and loot in Starfield is a blast. The game truly shines when you're dogfighting between asteroids, boarding an enemy ship, and then making the choice to either sell it for scrap or take it back to your shipyard and rebuild it into your new flagship. The freedom to become a pirate, a bounty hunter, or just a humble trader is fantastic.

Finally, a note on the loading screens. In a medieval world like Skyrim, walking everywhere makes a certain kind of loreful sense. In a game spanning countless star systems, it was never going to be possible. I honestly think that Bethesda kept to their spirit here, and tried to make space exploration as practical, without being silly hand-wavey mechanics, as possible. For instance, if they were going to make it so that you could fly to orbit from the surface, it was always going to be a quasi-loading screen like No Man's Sky. Basically a short animation that plays, then boom, you're in space. Now you can do space stuff. That's basically what Starfield does, but you can't interact with the cutscene, just watch. And after you get used to it, it doesn't bother you any more.

Planets are vast and the distances between them are unimaginable. The loading screens are a necessary concession to that scale. For me, they function just like real interstellar travel would: you set your destination and wait a moment to arrive. The payoff is the wonder of stepping out onto a barren moon and just admiring the view from an alien world, which Starfield captures beautifully—often with a cave or an abandoned outpost nearby to sweeten the deal. If you enjoyed games like The Outer Worlds or even the quiet exploration of Kerbal Space Program, give this a try.

My only gripe is the limitation of the landing zones. It's true, that when you land on a surface you get boxed in and can't fly around and explore the surface. I wish they could do something about that, and maybe they will, but given the way they randomly drop points of interest in as you go, maybe not. Kerbal is remarkable in that all the worlds are pre-made and you can fly over them in real time, Starfield does lack that. But when you DO pick a spot, land, and start exploring, I find it to be just as magical.
It's a grim glimpse into the future of bethesda

I wanted to like this game. I really did. I normally quite enjoy bethesdas RPG's, and prefer science fiction over fantasy, so it should have been easy.

The game is a loading screen simulator. If you want to change planets: loading screen to go outside, loading screen to launch to orbit, loading screen to the new solar system, and another when dropping from orbit.

And even the populated areas of the world are dead: long gone are the old bethesda details of living cities with routines, schedules, and habits. Everyone just chills at their counters... all day. Every day.

That's not even counting the obnoxious nature of the creations store. They are absolutely pushing the paid mods, and they've clearly prioritized the demand to monetize their games.

Gun play is smooth, and fluid, largely takes advantage of the various environments they take place in... but that's about it. Voice work is great, characterization is pretty damned good... but those three things alone are not enough to overcome all the other obvious flaws, deliberately bad design choices, and engine limitations.

If you must have it: get it on uber sale. Otherwise, I advocate skipping.
Really average game. Far too many loading screens.

This game is basically a much much better version of fallout 4 in every respect and has almost the exact same major problems, which is mostly pacing. The thing they said about it getting good after 10 hours is basically right. The intro takes forever - you have 2 fights that take less than 30 minutes and fly a ship for 30 seconds in between and then it's like no joke 3 hours of just talking to people.

It is a good game, made way better with the introduction of cars. The combat is actually good if you crank up enemy difficulty (there's also very good difficulty settings). Flying and shipbuilding is fun, there are a lot of good side quests. They basically brought back the freedom of movement from Morrowind. But for all of those things they also seemingly made backsteps in a lot of areas (to fallout 4 levels). Plus they don't give you any information through the UI at all, weapon info, ship info, just missing QOL stuff which surely exists. It's as wide as an ocean and some parts of it are pretty deep and some are incredibly shallow but they all look shallow. Also they just didn't put enough assets in the game, Atlas shrugged and the cowboy factions and neon look like they have character but then you go into any other building and all the interiors are exactly the same.

all of these problems should be so easily solvable. Why did they spend so much time on the outpost system who is playing this game to make outposts??
really enjoy the story love this game

Starfield is a massive disappointment. A vast, lifeless galaxy that mistakes size for substance. The game feels empty and soulless. Exploration quickly turns dull as every planet blurs into another barren, copy-paste landscape. The story and characters are flat, the dialogue lifeless, and the gameplay loop repetitive to the point of exhaustion.

Glad I finally decided to try it.  The mixed reception kept me away for a while but this is easily the biggest difference between a game's Steam review rating and my enjoyment of said game that I have ever experienced. At this point I have only really done the freewheeling space adventurer style of play, so I can only vouch for that, but I have had a great time. 

I will say the writing of the main questline is probably the flimsiest of the major questlines in the game, but it isn't bad for Bethesda, frankly, and there is plenty of cool and memorable bits in it as well. 

On the other hand, the various faction questlines are nothing less than excellent. Best Bethesda faction questlines since the Oblivion Thieves Guild, but it's all of them in Starfield. And, probably my favorite bit, the game also has several random mid-length side questlines for you to stumble on to which are also well done. Almost 80 hours in and I'm still finding interesting mini-campaigns just from flying to new stars or following distress signals.

Love most Bethesa games and even enjoyed this one somewhat, played main quest a few times and most faction missions etc but the fact that most of the world is extremely bland and boring and that I have to access 3/4 menus just to get from one place to another is painful, ui and writing is terrible as well.
Lots of loading screens as well.
Nowhere near as good as fallout 3/4, new vegas, skyrim, oblivion etc.
I genuinely wish they would just stop working on this game and make ES 6 and FO5.
I played with some mods as well to try make it better and running around doing bounty missions as boba fett is quite awesome but the multiple menu's and loading screens is genuinely just off putting.

I have 81 hours into this game. I have all my time played within the first month the game came out. I have not touched it since. This game is flat out boring. Just everything about it is boring and pretty much every negative review you read will say the same. The gunplay, the characters, the story, the side quests, the factions, the planets and their moons, the environments, the gameplay mechanics, boring, just boring. I was so hyped for this game, I bought the $100 edition to play it early and that is one of the biggest scams of the modern gaming, paying extra to play early, because they know their game sucks but they will sucker in a good chunk of people to pay more for literally no reason other than hype. This game is boring... Boring, boring, boring... just like Fallout 4, and I am a DIEHARD Fallout fan. I have played Fallout 3 and NV to 100% completion on PC, PS3, and 360 numerous times over. Bethesda has been in a funk since Skyrim, their last good game, there is a reason why they keep milking it. I'm sure in 10 years we will see a Starfield Remastered, a game literally no one asked for. I doubt we will ever see a starfield 2 because this game was such a failure. I really want to know how much Bethesda (Microsoft) lost on this game because it has to be billions, this game was in development hell for literally ever and its super obvious this is an abandoned IP already. Don't bother wasting your money.

So, honestly, most of my hours spent on this thing were on gamepass. First and foremost, is this game worth it? No. 

This is a game that does not respect storytelling, progression, your time, or your money. It is halfhearted at best and an insult at worst. That being said, as a waste of time, it fufills its point. I've ranted and raved years ago about how the mechanics feel dumed down and there have been some changes since. Some modifiers added for more exp and a harder gameplay loop. 

That being said, if you have an excess of time to kill a desire for worthless progression, and a story that makes cat in a hat seem deep in comparison, then this is the game for you. 

Now, on the positive side, I appreciate the status ailment system being what it is, but have a greater distain for how there is not a simple, apply aid button when you have a multitude of them in inventory. You either have to A: Add to favorite bar or B: Pause, go to inventory, then find the aid you need. That being said...for the hardcore masochists there is always mods for that. Either to remove pausing, or to apply aid.

So..to sum it up. Screw you Todd, my time is worthless and I got this on sale.

That said if you've got s good pc it looks absolutely amazing its just lacking something and its hard to pinpoint what.

首先是整体世界观背景和对应做出来的内容，加入联殖的先锋队任务会给你像展厅一样讲人类殖民外星系的历史，末日、对抗和虫灾（这很重要而且我为什么要提这个下文会说），一路发展到了人类几大阵营：联殖、自由星系、龙神、深红和其他等等。初期玩我觉得，嗯没什么问题，越玩越觉得有一个很大的问题，那就是农业！我实在不理解可以建立新亚特兰提斯城、阿基拉城、霓虹城等等宜居/类地星球里宜居城市和各大空间站的人类会放弃农业技术，过的特么的跟末世一样，吃的都什么东西，是地球母亲（那这算不算人类背叛地球母亲呢？）毁灭时人类没有保留任何种子和技术且在新星系尝试了各种办法都没有成功和任何进展吗？导致每次我走在各大城中就觉得都是一场“幻梦”，当我看到有mod作者做这方面的东西我笑了~
那么为什么在能像“纠缠不清”能时空错乱的“星空”世界中Bethesda不放个神器做出地球为何毁灭的内容让玩家游玩？采用的是跃迁回去直面废土地球，把作死的故事塞进文本语音记录然后让玩家看到废土中的NASA航天站感叹？我猜还是做不出来或者压根没想着做。虽然说“人类从历史中得到的唯一教训就是人类无法从历史中学到任何教训”，但宏观视角和作为玩家主角的个人的微观感受也互不影响，为什么不让玩家游玩这一过程。如果我们不知道从哪里来，又怎知道往哪里去？这，和我说的农业技术是相关联的。

其次我们来说一下多重宇宙和神器，用大家都在玩多重宇宙设定也行，但目的是有问题的，还是经典多重宇宙那一套即多个我多个重复却不同走向的人生。用“多重宇宙”这个东西，目的为何不能是突出宇宙“大”这一特点？我猜Bethesda是太想走“太空歌剧”的神秘和浪漫主义路线了，所以是经典的多重宇宙构架，但你那“归一”浪漫吗？我只在临门一脚时多个势力存活的队伍道别时看到了它，那“归一”它是什么属性？对此我研究了一下，显然不是用科学上的具体到微观粒子指它，创作团队应该也不会去研究我们道家思想，结合最后任务前见的老头子，还是西方哲学和宗教里的“归一”，但这在游玩时很难去理解到它，主要体现在哪里？你的多重宇宙构架已经完全覆盖了“归一”的表达，我还得选星狩或星使打对面呢！
再来说神器，提到神器我还是要说宗教元素的问题，在现今西方的文化作品中俩个特别重要的东西，即“宗教”和“家人/family侠”，数不胜数的内容都会往这方面引，家人侠我是接受的，游戏中陋室的伙伴就算家人，我能理解西方一些宗教国家下创作人的目的但我接受不了一点，这对本土人是好事但放眼全球可不是，你的故事到底还是科幻底色。对此所有往宗教这方面引导的作品我都不会满意甚至反胃，只有它来丰富故事可能会好一点，我不相信存下来的文明的未来是返回人类初始状态的各种崇拜。
主线上的一些任务触发很有问题，它会和阵容任务打架（如果你第一次玩没遇到我觉得很幸运），造成很糟糕的游玩体验且极其糟糕，而且联殖的指挥官有些任务触发和情节对话设计比较荒唐，会逼着玩家往深红走。
获得太空龙吼的互动过程还挺不错的，这值得夸，但龙吼神庙的宗教底色还是尬...
再说神器作为未知之物（媒介）和归一是互补的，但再整个设定框架下神器的存在被远远淡化了，于是我开始思考整个故事最后的高潮要回到太空史诗歌剧这个玩家对游戏的感受，这就引出了我最后的观点——

最后是平淡的结局，我对此表示理解，设计立意已经逃不出这个归一和多重宇宙循环的框架了，导致路只能这么走，这  就是概念先行的结果！你们没有把视角聚焦在具体的人物——主角（玩家）身上，虽然玩家从一开始所扮演的小矿工是极其具有Bethesda“个人飞升”特色的主角，但故事其实没有什么力量。
既然是太空歌剧和史诗为什么不作一个简单而有力量的结局，神器的铺垫——源自于人类已探索过的星系之外，宇宙之外，主角在某种机缘和群星伙伴的帮助下接触了这种“认知之外“，就像我们此时此刻地球人可能在未来接触某种未知一样，主角团窥见这种未知后要一起研究谜团，玩家作为主角的选择会导致不同的结局。
如果我充满信念和勇气，我可能作为先驱，再次踏上我作为人类向前探索的步伐，有可能我回不来了，我在宜居星系做任务的过程中的感情线，玩家和群星可能要考虑很多，要不要带上爱人或信赖的队友，玩家“我”是怎么看待这件事的？同生共死还是不想把好人拖下水？这取决于玩家的性格和对话选择，那么当我做出这个决定与好友、组织势力一一道别后踏上征程，对应游戏结尾的星图和BGM，这是不是人类勇气的赞歌？也回归到了”人“本身，对宇宙探索需要的勇气。
如果我对此比较麻木，觉得活在时代下的现实世界不易，或者你接受了游戏塑造很好的npc建议，与众人道别的会不会是巴雷特？莎拉？或其他人，玩家处于目送的人群之中。
这其实就是整个游戏的基调问题，“个人飞升”的主角光环走着设计好的路线但偏偏感受不到自我存在。游玩体验没有浩大战争可以理解，但战斗也没有，bilibili的up主已经用电子斗蛐蛐的方式证明，如骇兽大举入侵的百人大战场面是可以实现的，Bethesda没有做。
Main idea of the text    AI-T
First, regarding the overall worldview and in-game content: The United Colonies (UC) Vanguard quests walk you through humanity’s interstellar colonization history—covering the apocalypse, conflicts, and insect infestations (key context for later)—culminating in factions like the UC, Freestar Collective, Ryujin, and Crimson Fleet. Initially, this works, but a major flaw emerges: agriculture. How can humanity build cities like New Atlantis or Neon, yet abandon farming and live like post-apocalypse survivors? Did we lose all seeds/tech when “Mother Earth” fell, with no progress since? Cities feel like illusions—and modders fixing this says it all.
Why, in a Starfield where time bends (e.g., the “Entangled” quest), didn’t Bethesda let players use an Artifact to experience Earth’s destruction? Instead, we jump to a wasteland, read logs of humanity’s mistakes, and stare at a ruined NASA. I suspect they couldn’t (or wouldn’t) do it. Even if “humanity learns nothing from history,” letting players witness our past wouldn’t harm the story—how know where we’re going if we forget our roots? This ties directly to the agriculture gap.
Second, the multiverse and Artifacts: Using a multiverse is fine, but it’s wasted on the cliché of “multiple versions of me.” Why not use it to highlight the universe’s vastness? Bethesda clearly chased “space opera” mystery, but its “Unity” feels unromantic—I only felt it during the final faction farewells. What is Unity? It’s not scientific (e.g., micro-particles) or Taoist; given the elder in the final quest, it’s Western philosophical/religious “oneness”—hard to grasp because the multiverse overshadows it. We’re too busy choosing between Starborn Hunters and Emissaries to care.
Artifacts bring another issue: Western works over-rely on “religion” and “family.” I accept “family” (crew as family), but religion ruins the sci-fi core. It may resonate locally, but globally? Future civilizations won’t revert to primitive worship. The main quest also has broken triggers—conflicting with faction quests, and absurd UC Commander design forcing players toward the Crimson Fleet. Unlocking Starborn Powers (space “Shouts”) is great, but the temples’ religious vibes are cringey. Artifacts (as Unity’s complement) are also underdeveloped—undermining the “space opera” feel.
Finally, the underwhelming ending. I can understand this: the core design concept is trapped in the framework of Unity and multiverse cycles, so the story can only follow this path. This is precisely the result of prioritizing concept over execution! You failed to focus on the specific character—the protagonist (the player). While the player starts as a lowly miner, a classic Bethesda protagonist archetype built for “personal ascension,” the story itself lacks emotional weight.
If this is supposed to be a space opera epic, why not create a simple yet powerful ending? The Artifacts could have been foreshadowed as originating from beyond humanity’s explored galaxies—beyond the universe itself. The protagonist, by some chance and with the help of their Constellation companions, could come into contact with this “beyond comprehension” force—just as humans on Earth might encounter the unknown in the future. After glimpsing this unknown, the protagonist’s group would work together to unravel the mystery, with the player’s choices leading to different endings.
If I were filled with faith and courage, I could become a pioneer, embarking once again on humanity’s journey of exploration—knowing full well I might not return. The romantic subplots from quests on habitable planets would add depth here: the player and their Constellation companions would face tough choices—should they bring a loved one or trusted teammate? How would the player’s “self” view this? Facing life and death together, or refusing to drag good people into danger? This would depend on the player’s personality and dialogue choices. Then, after saying goodbye to friends and factions one by one, the protagonist sets off—with the game ending showing a star map and background music (BGM). Wouldn’t that be an ode to human courage? It would also return to the core of “humanity”—the courage needed to explore the universe.
If I were apathetic, feeling that survival in the current world was hard enough, or if I took the advice of a well-written NPC, maybe Barrett, Sarah, or someone else would be the one saying goodbye, with the player among the onlookers.
This all boils down to the game’s tonal issue: the protagonist has the “personal ascension” aura and follows a pre-designed path, yet the player barely feels their own existence. I can accept the lack of large-scale wars, but there’s barely any meaningful combat at all. Creators on Bilibili (a Chinese video platform) have already proven with “digital cockfighting” (simulation videos) that large-scale battle scenes—such as a massive Terrormorph invasion with over a hundred combatants—are achievable. Bethesda just chose not to make them.

I was really excited when I bought this game a few years back. I imagined flying my spaceship freely from planet to planet, entering atmospheres and exploring without interruption. But instead, every transition just ended up being a loading screen which was a bit disappointing.

Still, the story started off strong and felt fresh. There’s a wide variety of locations to uncover, and the base-building mechanics are actually well done. It has potential, and some parts truly shine.

When Bethesda announced Starfield, I was stoked. Finally an open world, do what you want, build your own ship game that I was itching to play. Then it released and I was playing day one of release. When I sat in the captain's chair and fired up the ship for the first time, I was over joyed! 

Fast forward 506.1 hours played in the game. 

Do I still get excited? Sure, but less so now because I know most anywhere I go I have seen it many times before due to the cookie cutter plants and POIs. I also know that I am going to have to save often so I can reload when, not if, a glitch happens to break my game. EXAMPLE: Just last night I couldn't get into the lodge because the doors were stuck. I had to log out and back in to get them to work. 

Now there are creations and while some require to be purchased, there are some that do not. Have I paid for some? Heck yeah I have. Not only do they enhance my game play QoL, but it also supports the creators and encourages more content. Right now, I have about 20 mods on the game and it has made a huge difference in how the game plays. From planet bioms to different POIs and NPCs, the creator content definetly is worth the price if you read them and they interest you. 
Some add brand new stories and missions with new places, armor, and weapons. While others add to or enhance existing features. 

The base game is good, but it isn't great or fantastic. It has many issues such as flying corpses when you kill someone or AI glitches with your companion getting stuck somewhere because pathing isn't working (I mean they won't even jump over a rock). 

Bottom line is that Starfield isn't perfect by any means nor is it God aweful bad either. It is a game worth playing especially if you like Fallout or Skyrim style games. It is open world, some choices matter, and it has spaceship building! :) Could it be better? Of course, but that shouldn't stop anyone from at least getting in and immersing yourself in the main storyline and enjoying the game and if you want to spice it up a bit, head into the creations and pick up some goodies. 

Above all else, just have fun and enjoy playing it. After all, it is just a game.

Oh me, oh my. I never wanted to make this review. Especially with that red thumbs down you’re seeing. 

I am going to be perfectly clear—319 hours speaks a lot for how entertaining this game can be for someone like me, a Bethesda fan. However, I want to stress that just because the game was entertaining for me, and I was able to find a good level of fun within this game, does not at all mean that it succeeded in the areas in which I have labeled. The points listed below areas of the game where I was consistently telling myself felt incomplete my entire time playing this game. While I refuse to outright call Starfield a "bad" game. I will call it a game that has failed to live up to the Bethesda formula. Especially where exploration is concerned.

I loved the idea of this game. But as it sits today, Starfield has failed expectations for me (and many others) in three large ways.

One: 

Space exploration is nothing but loading screens attached to loading screens attached to menus. This is NOT Bethesda DNA. I have been hearing many rumors that this will be changed soon, and if they do, this review will reflect those changes as soon as possible. But as of right now, they have FAILED at space exploration. The ship is a glorified fast travel station/storage home. While that is not in itself a bad thing, a huge idea that most people had in their heads was that you could explore the contents of each star system without a loading screen or a menu. Obviously, when you go into a planet, there will be a loading screen. But, a more engaging experience would allow players should be able to fly throughout the star system without fast traveling and encounter a random event naturally along the way. This would feel more natural to Bethesda’s formula, and I feel it is the direction they should have gone for success for a game like this. No one should have expected Elite Dangerous or Star Citizen. But at the very least, bombarding the player with constant menus to navigate ruins the experience.

Two:

I could EASILY forgive the repetitious planetary exploration if it were not for the fact that the space exploration was so incredibly limited. Simply put, I have never noticed the repetitious dungeons of Oblivion or Skyrim. But in Starfield? It was more than simply noticeable. It was blatant and in my face within 5 hours of playtime. 314 hours later, I yawn at these buildings and places that I have been to hundreds of times over. I am not at all saying some repetition is bad; of course, not every single interior is going to be 100% unique, but I think that the simple lack of any variety ruined the ground exploration experience for me.

Three:

The final point is purely subjective. The narratives in this game lacked the iconic feel of their past titles. Skyrim, Oblivion, Fallout 3, and even Fallout 4 had great stories and narratives that were at least engaging and interesting to see to their completion. To make this point clear. I am over 300 hours into this game, and I have not completed its main story. The story did not at all grab, entice, or interest me. I call this my subjective opinion because I think many people did enjoy this story. 

Maybe this review will change. Maybe it will not. But I hope it does. I loved the combat in this game, and I loved the art. I adored the soundtrack and ship customization, and while I would recommend people try it if they are die-hard Bethesda fans, I cannot recommend this game to people who are looking to get into a good space RPG. It simply failed in every aspect that has made Bethesda special in the first place. While there will be those people who whine and cry about how this game did not do anything innovative, I don't think it needed to. I do not think every game needs to be groundbreaking and a technological masterpiece. It just needs to be fun, engaging, and interesting, and Bethesda’s Starfield simply fails in these categories where it counts.

I hope they read reviews like mine and take them to heart. This review comes from a childhood fan of Morrowind, Oblivion, Fallout 3, Skyrim, and Fallout 4. I have loved Bethesda's games since I first laid hands on them. This negative review is a response to a company that I feel has lost its touch—its charm, and that is something I genuinely hope changes with their upcoming title, The Elder Scrolls VI

Originally, I thought Starfield was a fairly average game, a 5/10.

But the more I played it, the more I realized that the game isn't well thought out enough in many ways, so it's currently a 4/10 in my book.

----------

The straw that broke the camel's back was outpost building. Now, as someone who has seen multiple engineering/automation games, Starfield utterly fails at making a satisfying experience setting up bases to extract resources from.
1. There is no easy-to-access central hub where you can view all your outposts and cargo links and what they're mining
2. There is no sorted storage (ie. Iron-only storage, Chlorine-only storage) which means that you WILL run into bottlenecking issues at some point when it comes to storage.
3. It is not fun to mindlessly run across a randomly generated surface map looking for good spots to make an outpost. There should be a resource map on the surface map, similar to how it is in planetary view. I am true gamer nerd, it is in my blood to look for the most efficient spot to mine from instead of having 3 outposts on one map for 3 different resources.

------

Incidentally, while Starfield does a good job of handholding for very casual gamers, the holes will quickly become apparent to anyone who likes to experiment.

GUN BALANCING
I have never used a Kraken pistol in all of my hours of playing the game. Never. It was always worse than any gun I had on me at any moment.
The guns are horribly balanced. The automatic weapons usually were worse than their semi automatic counterparts. Sometimes I just really want to unload bullets but you know, I only have so much ammo and I don't want to spend time and credits to get more when I could be saving up for new ship parts.
Automatic guns SHOULD carry similar DPS, INCLUDING RELOAD TIME, to their semi-automatic counterparts. It's especially true when you consider that it's easier to get headshots on semi-automatic guns because of recoil.

--------

Skill perk challenges actually provide no real value at all. First off, 90% of the time they're not challenging. They just...happen to be there. But they also make it so you are gated from actually leveling a skill until you have completed the associated challenge. So they essentially force you to grind meaningless tasks just so you get to feel stronger the way you want...which is a bit antithetical to a true freeform RPG.

Also, skills suck. I am not excited to level up so I can get +10% handgun damage. The skill upgrades should genuinely feel meaningful. Leave the damage in the hands of weapon mods and crafting. Skills truly shine the most when they introduce meaningfully interactive gameplay while staying simple.

---------

The main story writing is quite mid and very cliche, the characters are not very memorable even though they do clearly have some vision behind them (ie. Barrett is wisecracking space rogue, Vasco is funny robot man). The characters just feel a bit too safe, as if they were all handcrafted so they would all be unoffensively likable.

----------

The following is not really a detailed criticism, but it's a necessary one to make because of the feeling it evokes: there are too many loading screens.
If you're going to make a freeform space RPG, you're pitting yourself against other space sims out there which handle immersion much better than Starfield does. I'm aware there might be tech restraints but it really does feel like every area is a loading screen, including your own ship.

I don't know how to solve this specifically, but the ratio of meaningful gameplay to loading screens is too low.

--------

Finally, gunplay and swordplay.

Gunplay is fine, very average.

Swordplay is...kinda mediocre and slapped together. Almost feels like they added melee just in case people wanted to be a sword swinging space ronin, but then the devs forgot the part where they actually had to make melee more engaging than "I hold forward and press left click multiple times." There's no point in blocking with a sword. Just left click until you are done.

---------

This kind of covers much of my complaints. Starfield is basically a really cool vision with disappointingly mid execution. I hope that for their next game, the devs really try to figure out what makes a game fun for someone who isn't just a very casual player. I think the best milestone to show that they can figure it out is if I no longer feel the urge to mod my game after 30 minutes. Mods are good for BSD games yes but they may unintentionally be used as a crutch for the devs.

If you manage to not have some crazy unrealistic expectations, this game is pretty solid....Is it an endless and filled to the brim universe like they may have led some of us to believe? Absolutely not. This game is filled with a good amount of planets with generated environments and an okay amount of POI's that tend to repeat themselves with the vanilla game. Yes, a lot of them are the same and yes it can at times get repetitive after a while...BUT if you treat this game as a light RPG, and a light space exploration game, its actually pretty fun. The story is okay, nothing ground breaking but pretty decent, the gameplay and shooting is pretty decent aswell...

As of right now, with the creations feature, Starfield is pretty good...having played on launch and quickly dropping it, I'm here to say I've given it another fair shot and its actually pretty fun. It also has an endless amount of amazing mods that further bring more life to the game. If you happen to catch it on a decent sale...I would def give this game a fair shot because it's actually pretty fun.

It feels average while playing Starfield. Although I am a huge fan of space, something about the game feels empty. The whole game content is so shallow and soul lacking. Space can be empty for sure but I cannot imagine the possibilities human discovery and expeditions could reveal for other worlds/civilizations. None of these exist into Starfield. We only see the empty side.

It's a good game. I have to give it a positive review, since herd-like consumers have taken unrealistic stance on it, and the statistics of total reviews do not reflect reality.
 I will try to give a fair shot at it.

First, there is a plethora of negative reviews from people who have played the game for many hundreds of hours, per player. That is multiple times the game length of a single-player campaign standard (for a LONG game: +20h). 
You can experience all the mechanics, main features and gameplay loops in the first few hours. 
What then, drives people to invest hundreds more, and leave a negative review? 

For example, I tried to play Death Stranding, I tried my very best to "get into it" but it's not for me. It seemed an interesting game, but the mechanics wore me down. It just wasn't enjoyable (for me). Didn't take me 200h to realize that.
 
I have done multiple runs of Starfield now, and I clock in 170h. One vanilla, other runs with mods. 
I cant, for the life of me, imagine a game that would take me 200h, or 100, or even 50, to realize it's not for me. 

There is no other game this much review-bombed, and still having people played it these amounts. Did someone make them do it at gunpoint?

Still, to be frank, the only clear advantage is exactly just that; the landing / taking off -planets. And thats it. Everything else is shallow in No mans sky. It feels cookie cutter to me atleast.

I don't think open world space games work, on a fundamental level. Part of the appeal of Morrowind/Oblivion/Skyrim/Fallout is being able to pick a direction, go that way, and find something interesting. This game feels like more of a spiritual successor to Daggerfall where the world is incomprehensibly vast, but also devoid of anything interesting. If you want to go places, you *must* go through a loading screen to get there. I had the most fun when I was just doing quests which were entirely contained within the cities--it felt like the classic Skyrim gameplay we all know, just with new stories, characters and cities. For what it's worth, I did also really enjoy the ship building system--it honestly is the most novel and interesting part of the game by a pretty good margin. 

All in all, I think there was definitely a vision for this game, and lot of passion for its creation, but because of the fundamental problem of trying to make an open world game in space, I can't really recommend it. After playing Starfield, I'm not exactly as doomer as most about TES6 as most people are--I'm just sort of lukewarm. I think Bethesda absolutely could deliver with it, but we'll have to wait and see.

This is one I was excited about when I saw it but after putting over 48 hours of my life into it...I really cannot recommend it.

There is the bones of a great game here but a lot of the execution is severely flawed.

The world itself feels...empty. Populated places are unique and interesting, for sure, but outside of the handful of populated places you go there's just carbon copies of the same set of pre-generated structures over and over and over again. There's no reason to go there and do anything with them other than to grind skills. 

Money is kind of meaningless because you can usually craft or find better things than you can buy and materials are all over so there's rarely a need to purchase any. Doing things to make money is also sort of pointless because of money sinks that area in place.

You could be a pirate and hijack ships...but then you have to pay a registration fee to register the ship before you can sell it and that fee is most of the sale price so you've made no money. Ships rarely have much valuable cargo so there's not much point in stealing it plus the cost of bounties will very quickly outstrip any profit you make from piracy.

Without going into spoilers, the New Game + mechanic is genuinely an interesting bit of writing but it feels like they took that as an excuse not to do as much. The way its presented feels like it should add more but it really doesn't and then you realize you can blast through the entire game in less than an hour just to have everything reset and you get to do the exact same things over and over and over again. Sure you can do them a different way but there's usually not that much of a different way to do them.

The rewards for a New Game + also mean that a lot of your skills become kind of useless. You don't really need to modify suits or ships anymore since you get one of the best one of each in the game. 

The biggest issue is the lack of Workshop support and the lack of mods in general. Vortex is an option and it works well but a game like this is absolutely screaming for a huge modding community. There's hundreds of empty planets and places with nothing that could benefit from people making up cool new places to explore or see and there's just...none of that. 

If you do go for mods, absolutely one of the first ones to get is a mod that removes or makes much easier the lockpicking minigame. It brings the game to a crashing halt and takes way too long. Before I modded it out I was actively avoiding lockpicking things despite having the skills because the minigame was just so annoying. 

The bottom line is I reached the bottom of what this game had to offer well before I was finished playing the game. The poor mod support means there's not much flexibility in expanding it. 

If you get it, get it on *deep* discount at best.
Waste of money. Go play New Vegas.

It's all been said a million times already, there are countless videos online about the many issues with this game, so I won't really get super into it.  The short version is this: Starfield takes no risks and is not interested in delivering ANY kind of experience beyond killing time.  The systems are shallow and disconnected, like they were made to simply say they exist.  It doesn't try to specialize in any one thing, and as a result every aspect of the game is shallow and un-engaging.  Whereas a game like No Man's Sky put all its effort into the procedural generation of planets and none into the spaceflight, combat or story and a game like Elite Dangerous put all its effort into spaceflight and ship combat and none into ground gameplay, Starfield puts no effort anywhere.  Neither space gameplay nor on-foot gameplay rises above "serviceable" in quality, and the writing for quests and NPCs certainly doesn't save it either.

Starfield really is only good at one thing, and that's being a second-screen game.  Normally how it works is you play a game and have a video or something playing on the second screen to occupy your ears, but this is the reverse of that.  If you have a video or podcast or whatever that you want to pay attention to but want to keep your hands busy, Starfield is what you put on for that.  I initially played this game on gamepass and only bought the game on Steam during the sale with gift card balance, which is really the only way I'd recommend you buy Starfield: as cheap as possible and not with your money, and only as a glorified fidget toy.

Starfield I think really puts the spotlight on Bethesda.  There's been a discussion for years about if Bethesda really is capable of making a game the quality of Morrowind or Skyrim anymore, especially after Fallout 4 and 76, and I think Starfield really was the last chance for most people (myself included).  At this point, I have no good expectations for Elder Scrolls 6, and it's going to take a lot for Bethesda to convince me they're worth taking a look at going forward.  They need to rework their process, it's just not working anymore.  Skyrim's magic is now nearly 15 years in the past, you can't keep expecting people to pay for your games purely on that memory and expectation.  I know that sounds kind of dumb from someone who just gave them money for this game knowing full-well its quality, but there's a difference between a bored person buying a year-old game on-sale with a gift card and someone actually wanting to buy a brand-new game on launch with their salary money.

i wanted to like this game so badly. the writing really was on the wall with the "thousands of planets" pitch. the story and characters didn't particularly speak to me, and the procedural generation takes the joy out of exploring.

Wanna know why this failed? They expanded loading screens and didn't realize people only tolerated loading screens in previous titles. If you want a real space exploration experience, do Star Citizen or No Mans Sky. I tried to like this, but everything from the story to the gameplay is so irritating.

The game lied on its resume and somehow got away with it. There is an impressive number of features, very few of them unfortunately properly implemented.

Since I could become who I wanted, I decided to role-play a non-violent diplomat. This absolutely did not work as almost every questline has unavoidable combat sections. The game’s underlying themes are presented in a bland and trivial way. Locations are uninteresting, main story has lots of copy-pasted segments, dialogue is generic and dogfighting among other minigame-like features is underwhelming. Exploration means clicking a fast travel point in your menu apart from those generous situations where there is actually two clicks and a loading screen in between.

Ship building is honestly speaking one of the few well implemented features but the ships itself are merely set pieces between loading screens. Actual gameplay around them is very shallow and this is a huge, missed opportunity.

I did not exactly suffer while playing but I describe the experience as disappointing.

I was never a big fan of Bethesda games, but I decided to give it a shot.
It was the most disappointing gaming experience of my life. It's the most overhyped, boring, soulless game I've ever played.
I might've messed up by jumping into this game right after playing Cyberpunk 2077, but after that, while this game is technically an RPG, there's only one role you can play.

I'll have to give credit to Bethesda. The ship-building aspect of the game is incredible. The spaceship and part designs are also interesting, unique and believeable too. Gunplay is ok space combat is also OK but it gets old very quickly.

It looks like Bethesda's strategy of putting out a half-baked game and then waiting for the modding community to step in and fix it has worked again.

This game took a lot of flak when it was released.  I tried it out now after letting it bake for a couple of years.  Sadly, it is still full of holes.  It is poorly optimized.  My tired GTX 1060 which handles Fallout 4, 76 and other Bethesda games fine gets absolutely wrecked even with reduced texture mods and is unplayable.  My RX6600M handles it with a reduced texture mod, but the UI is filled with needless delays and cutscenes which slow gameplay.  Speedup mods that cut the videos and accelerate animations help.   The quests have you spend a LOT of time flying back and forth between planets, and running back and forth across the three main cities, opening doors, waiting for load screens, and talking to NPCs that monologue before you can engage them.  Ship building is pointless, you get better value for your credits by upgrading your free ship in the ship builder as new parts become available, which are skill gated.  Space combat is fun for a while but stealing ships is financially nerfed by a huge "registration fee" which makes stealing them to make money basically pointless.  A big stolen ship maybe gets you 5-10k but to buy a big ship, 400k+.  Skill progression is very slow and large parts of gameplay are skill-locked.  At the end of the main quest [spoiler]your reward is to reincarnate and play the game again.  first playthrough you are locked out of half the fun by skills, second playthrough your accumulated skills and knowledge let you shred everyone and provides no challenge.[/spoiler]   Game has a huge flaw where if you side with a certain faction in a quest, the majority of enemy outposts stop being hostile to you, destroying gameplay.  All in all, it took me 100 hours to get through the game and become tired of the repetititve gameplay loop.

Having finally ground out the last achievements to the game (Reach Level 100, Max Relationship with a Companion, and Collect 500 Organic Resources, which for some ungodly reason means only resources from plants) I finished the game... then promptly started a new game to get the last achievement I needed to 100%, which was first achievement you're supposed to get in the game, but was bugged when I first played it.

Now done I can only describe this game as a slog. There's many places to go, but typically f@#k all to do when you get there. You'll usually be hanging around 1 of 2 major hubs to sell things you don't need, to upgrade your ship, so you can carry more things you don't need to sell off. The game allows base building, but the only reason to undertake base building is to build more bases... and the associated achievements with base building.

Initially, exploring a planet required you to walk the planet, risking picking up too much, being over encumbered and losing the ability to fast travel as per all Bethesda games... which is really tiresome. The games understand the passage of time, and passes a rough amount when using fast travel, just make it pass more if over encumbered. Later they did add a vehicle you can use to drive on planets, which you either drive like a car on high gravity worlds, or bouncing around on low gravity worlds.

Space combat was interesting and there's quite a variety of weapons you can equip on your ship, but as you progress through the game, it seems to become more rare, and you'll find yourself heading to the hub cities to pick up repeatable quests so you can grind out skill progress.

It's like NMS was on launch: A million miles wide, 3 feet deep. I'll admit the gunplay and space dogfights are fun. But it doesn't cover up the dead universe that Bethesda created. It doesn't feel like it 
truly matters. It's just a dull shooter with randomly generated environments. It starts fun, but it doesn't feel original, it isn't innovative in any way, and for all the open world games Bethesda has made over the years, it really falls short. Todd Howard and Emil Pagliarulo need to step away from developing these games since it feels like everything they touch slowly turns to shit.

Starfield is one the most boring and poorly thought out sci-fi settings in gaming. It's a universe that once you finish the main story gives you an option to completly reset everything you did so you can do it all again and get slighty stronger versions of your mediocre magic space powers, without ever giving a good reason why. This multiverse bethesda creates is duller than the current MCU, because nothing changes universe to universe except the status of constellation. Bethesda themselves have not delivered any content for this game in around a year, and have been poor at talking to their fans.

If you just want a mediocre lite-rpg go ahead and buy it. but if you want something of more than middling quality you best look elswhere.
I really don't expect this game to be so fun, I really recommend this game to players that love cool missions, exploring the universe, grinding, and more

[h1]💭 Final Thoughts – 9/10[/h1]
[b]After fully completing it (mod-free), I can confidently say: no, it doesn’t quite match Skyrim’s magic, but it delivers a solid Bethesda experience with unrelenting force![/b]
[b]Starfield doesn’t always know what it wants to be — part space sim, part action RPG — a bit like Lydia. Sometimes you’re having a blast together; other times you want to Fus Ro Dah the other half into oblivion 😤. It does a great job, but falls short of becoming that timeless, endlessly re-re-released classic.[/b]
[b]If you’re patient, love slow-paced exploration, and get excited by creatively “realistic” planetary discovery, this is a great experience. If you get bored or annoyed easily, or prefer fast-paced gaming, this might not be for you.[/b]
[b]In a way, it really was StarRim… Ew, I mean… SkyField! Yes SkyField, and I loved it! 🗡️🚀[/b]
[hr][/hr]
[h3]🕹️ Gameplay – 8/10[/h3]
It’s that Creation Engine jank we know and love, but improved, refined, and more immersive than Skyrim. Movement, combat, and interactions feel noticeably better. Shooting is definitely fun.
Realism adds a new layer: sprained ankles, back pain, broken bones, coughing — it’s real life! But with more space dust [i]cough cough[/i]. I dumped points into health skills early, which helped with that a lot. And if it gets too annoying, you can tweak difficulty sliders to suit your vibe.
Oxygen management is frustrating… but not as much as inventory management. It’s tedious, but hey — eventually you’ve got to clean your room. Flight and combat are simple, fun, and engaging. Customisation? Robust. Plushie-filled beds for happy time? Done! Alien egg ambushes waiting for Sarah in the bathroom? Also done!
I just wish there was more variety in suits and clothing. I wore the same set for hundreds of hours and I didn't even shower.
Oh and Chunks are nice! Chunks are really nice!
[hr][/hr]
[h3]🎨 Graphics – 8/10[/h3]
The game is beautiful. Just… don’t stare into people’s eyes. Feast on cityscapes, vistas, and skies. Really, just don’t look at people.
Important NPCs look great. But the everyday Clinty and Natty? They wandered in from a wax museum that forgot to pay its lighting bill.
[hr][/hr]
[h3]🎵 Sound & Music – 9/10[/h3]
Atmospheric and perfectly tuned. Combat feels epic, and when you reach a mountain peak with two moons hanging over the ring around Uranus 😏 — it just hits.
Sound effects are crisp, voice work is varied and memorable. Adam Jensen dropping remarks, Cisco Ramon musing about the universe. It’s those little moments that make the world feel alive.
[hr][/hr]
[h3]📖 Story & Characters – 9/10[/h3]
The main story is great, but only as deep as you make it 😏. Talk to people, dig into dialogue, explore your surroundings, and uncover a lot of hidden lore. Rush through it, and it might lack depth.
Characters follow the same pattern. You can breeze past them, or dive deep and genuinely care. The main companions shine — and get to know them you should. Feel for them you should. Fall deeply in love with them you should. Because… well, I’ll never tell! 🤐
[hr][/hr]
[h3]⏳ Replayability – 8/10[/h3]
Feels like launching into Skyrim, with side quests, exploration, space flight, good times. But Starfield adds a clever New Game+ that’s not just “play again,” but a fresh experience with new twists and incentives — if you’re not fried after hundreds of hours 😅.
It rewards curiosity and commitment. A bit like your commitment to Lydia… I mean Sarah… I mean… 🙊
There’s more than one playthrough here — if you dare to find out.
Mods! Dare I say more? No! Mod the space balls out of it, because you can!
Best part though? You get to eat more Chunks!
[hr][/hr]
[h3]📈 Learning Curve – 8/10[/h3]
Lower the difficulty sliders and it’s a gentle ride. But play with all systems active — injuries, inventory, crafting, farming, fighting, exploring, researching — and it’s like enrolling in Space University.
Thankfully, the game guides you reasonably well. And the best part? You don’t have to do everything. Pick what you enjoy, ignore what you don’t. It’s a sandbox, not a syllabus — and nobody’s grading your space potatoes… Or are they? 🥔
[hr][/hr]
[h3]🫂 Multiplayer – 10/10[/h3]
The only real multiplayer element I found was the girlfriend laughing at me because I screamed, “Fudge! I have a brain haemorrhage again!” 🤯
[hr][/hr]
[h3]⚙️ Performance – 7/10[/h3]
I’ve played extensively and haven’t hit many issues. Starfield can be heavy to run — city hubs hit the GPU hard with visual complexity and global illumination, while NPC simulation and AI scripting can hammer your CPU.
Use upscaling and frame generation if you can — it helps. I’m on an RX 7900XTX with an ultrawide display, so it’s been smooth and beautiful. Like, space-poster-on-your-wall beautiful. I know that’s not everyone’s setup, and Starfield can be demanding, but with the right tweaks, even mid-range systems can shine.
Most major issues are patched, but bugs can still pop up. For me, one quest completed, but its marker lived on forever. Save often, and treat your save files like precious cargo. 🧳💾
[hr][/hr]
[h3]💰 Value for Money – 10/10[/h3]
Starfield is vast and expansive, and if you’re okay with patient play, the value is solid. Take it slow, soak in the details, and you can spend months here.
It’s not about rushing to the credits — it’s about wandering, wondering, and occasionally yelling “Why am I farming space potatoes again?” 🥔 The value is there… if you’re the kind of player who likes to earn it.
[hr][/hr]

When I first played Starfield I had a hard time sticking with the game. I felt the story was too forced and it took me away from the "space fantasy" that I wanted this game to be. However, now that I've returned to it (this time on PC) I feel that my mentality about the game has shifted. Instead of going for the main missions and trying to follow the crumbs layed out by Bethesda, I decided to go and explore my own universe. To do this I just decided not to help the Constellation, at least not initially. In my own head cannon my character had been following rules for all his life and this time was the first time that he could be free. So I turned around, picked up my ship and explored the universe. This made the game more interesting and allowed me to build my own narrative. I ended up becoming a bounty hunter and spent most of my time in a colony supporting their people. Due to an accident with one space pirate I saw my self being forced to improve my piloting skills and spend money on upgrading my shit if I wanted to continue to help others. This was a lot more interesting that anything else I had experienced before. Will it make sense once I go back to the main missions? Probably not. I would love for them to react to what I've been able to accomplish and do but I don't expect it. Even if I decided not to go back to the main missons I feel that I will be able to continue to have loads of fun.
How is this game so (LARGE!)

I've been playing for two years and I still enjoy it!  I'm in my second play through and enjoy ship building, outposts, space combat and FPS elements of the game.  Lots to see and do, and have been adding more of the Creations over time.
Lots of people complain about the game but I like to take my time and explore so it's been great for me.  Plus I only play about 3-4 hours per week.
I really appreciate Bethesda for trying something new. Starfield my not be everything I want it to be but it makes me want a Starfield 2!

In Starfield, I traveled the galaxy… and somehow still couldn’t find the fun.

There’s something oddly beautiful about Starfield. You stand on a barren planet, the stars stretching forever — and all you can think about is how many loading screens it took to get there.

It’s not a bad game. It’s just… a quiet one. A massive universe that somehow feels a little empty — like a space museum where you can’t touch anything.

But every now and then, you see a sunrise over a crater, your ship gleaming in the distance, and for a brief moment… it clicks. You remember why you keep playing.

7/10
