[h1] Ale się zawiodłem [h1]
Pytanie brzmi: dlaczego? 
No cóż liczyłem na pełną wrażeń opowieść, niczym w Skyrim. Dostałem? Dziwną konwersję Fallouta4. (Nawet niektóre dźwięki  były wyciągnięte prosto z Fallouta) i to najbardziej mnie zabolało. Po wyjściu Starfielda marzyłem o tej grze i kiedy udało mi się ulepszyć sprzęt na tyle ,żeby ta gra spokojnie poszła na najwyższych detalach........ no i marzenie zderzyło się z rzeczywistością. Gra do której (jak mi się wydawało) będę wracał i przerobię w niej lekko 400h................... Sprawiła że po 1 ukończeniu gry w ustach pozostał mi metaliczny smak. Gdybym miał wrócić do Starfielda... to na prawdę musiał bym nie mieć co robić. 
[b] Klasycznie lecimy z plusami i minusami [b]
[h2] Plusy [h2] 
+ Bardzo fajne bronie ( ciekawe) wraz z "przyzwoitym" systemem dodatków do broni (gripy/ celowniki/ tłumiki i generalnie wszelkiej maści hamulce wylotowe etc)
+ Świetny system budowania statku ( spędziłem chyba z 15 godzin na 105 rozegranych żeby dopieścić swoją latającą fortecę [spoiler] może trochę przesadzam z tą 15 ale z pewnością dużo godzin i to satysfakcjonujących upłynęło mi na przerabianiu, poprawianu i ulepszaniu statku [spoiler]
+ Pierwsze zderzenie ze światem starfielda robi przyjemne wrażenie
+ System walki jest okej (w sensie walki i strzelania) [spoiler] mimo ,że czuć w nim tak dużo fallouta [spoiler]
+ Główna linia fabularnia jest też w porządku mimo braku rewelacji pojawia się kilka ciekawych Plottwistów
+ Fajne frakcje w sensie fajnie wyglądają 
[h1] MINUSY [h1]
-Postacie poboczne są.... ależ one są obrzydliwie nudne.... bo leci to tak. Poznajesz postać X i ma ona swoje powiedzmy usposobienie. wystarczy ciągle dawac 1 opcję dialogową ( pełną współczucia i empatii i klepania po pleckach) i sobie nabijamy tę "pozytywną relację"
- System ulepszeń pancerza [spoiler] o kur*a [spoiler] po za ulepszeniem statystyk... nic się nie zmienia. Jak by fallout przyzwyczaił mnie że kiedy daję sobie dodatek do pancerza dajmy na to jedno z kilku ulepszeń to chociażby kolor tego pancerzyka się zmieniał
- Mimo kolejnych wersji pancerza wszystkie wyglądają tak samo nie ważne czy to pancerz z 1 poziomu czy z 50 [spoiler] znów fallout przyzwyczaił mnie do tego że w późniejszej części gry dajmy na to pancerz X dostaje nowe elementy jak płytki ochronne albo kolejne części ochrony klatki piersiowej i tutaj tego brak a to ogromny minus który właśnie odbiera urokowi wizualnemu tej gry [spoiler]
- w moim wypadku ta gra trafiła do kategorii "przejdź i zapomnij"

Generalnie starfield nie jest złą grą... jest grą która w moim mniemaniu jest za mało dopieszczona w pewnych kwestiach.
Postacie poboczne nie wzbudziły mojej sympatii ,jak działo się to w skyrimie czy F4.
Najważniejsza rzecz która reguluje moje podejście względem gry to jest to czy warto kupić ją za pełną cenę a tutaj [h3] definitywnie nie warto [h3] ,wydając kasę bez promki i to takiej conajmniej 40% to ta gra nie jest warta tych pieniędzy. Despite prevailing public opinion, I genuinely enjoy Starfield. The ambience is nice, including sounds, the skybox, and attention to detail within ships. The upgrade to the Creation Game Engine really shows!

I only wish there was a VR version, like Fallout 4 and Skyrim.

I enjoy these mods: Falkland Systems, Lyria, The Apollo Residence and Fleet Commander on Creation Club; as well as the NoMoreFlat VR Mod on Patreon. 

These are all paid mods however. Another caveat is that adding new mods mid-game may destroy the game's functionality, such as The Bountiful Harvest Mod. So, like how many Game Enjoyers in the 2020s have realized, you should factor in setup time, in addition to price, before purchasing Starfield & its many mods.

Surprised how much I'm loving the game so far going by the reviews these days 

(Do we really take notice of reviews anymore? I know I don't which has me wondering why I am bothering doing one myself)  

And the comment section... well I'm pretty certain quite a few have mental issues... its just senseless ranting over pixels but others make good points about their criticism. 

I am currently playing a modded version, I haven't tried the vanilla version but I'd have to admit if it wasn't for the mods, quite a lot about the game would have annoyed me, resulting in me uninstalling. 

So far I have 80+ mods to turn the game into a living breathing RPG that requires me to eat/sleep/drink/pay taxes/crew/crew food/fuel/maintenance costs/repair parts and a tonne of other features that adds so much more to the already enormous amount of content.

AI mods have made the enemy excellent and I'm playing on the hardest settings... they are actually slick I have to admit, quite a few of them know how to stage an ambush or hide... other mods have fixed POIs and added more variety etc, so I won't be suffering from copied and pasted encounters.

Without mods I would have down right hated space in this game but with Astrogate that lets me actually travel across a system in my ship with the added bonus of autopilot, ship boarding mods where enemies will close in to board (AWESOME) then with fuel and subsystem mods... I have a fully functioning space ship that I can walk around in, a Cargo bay I can walk around in with or without cargo being present while having to do manual maintenance that require spare parts to complete the repairs, cook food, work on benches or study the system map while in transit or be the pilot myself. 

Everything I dreamt of having the ability to do in Elite Dangerous... not to mention build the ships too... It's  what space fans have always wanted. 

However... they really dropped the ball on space travel and how important a captain can interact with their ship is... I hope  they fix this because mods went far and beyond towards addressing this. 

They could also add in trade routes between planets, possible encounters, radio signals, distress signals, Search and Rescue ,space horror, crew/ship events to deal with... They don't have to be constant every Kilometre throughout travel (That would be awful) but just make it a possibility of happening is enough.  

Maybe new ship combat too that is modelled more towards submarine warfare instead of dog fighting... (Like combat in The Expanse, the dog fighting could be used to fight off a boarding attempt)

If asked to describe the Starfield I'm playing I would say... Imagine The Expanse and For All Mankind mixed with Alien Covenant, planets that would remind you of Riddick and Firefly include hunting (I have it modded where animals are scarce so I have to look for them, they also drop meat which is why I hunt) that reminds me of Jurassic Park... but in the form of Fallout 4 in Space. 

Those thoughts crossed my mind when playing, I just thought to myself its awesome. 

Loading screens... 1-2 secs... 5 seconds when starting the game after logging on... I counted and I continue to count to this day and I think I always will, people are either extremely petty, need to upgrade or the game has been updated to shorten the loading screens because 1-2 seconds is nothing... I forgot all about them. 

(Well when you go to land on planets reminded me, the sudden switch from gameplay to the screen then the landing cutscene... they should include a cutscene of the approach to the planet) 

I'm only 17hrs in, the story and writing is typical Bethesda, it won't win awards for cinematic's and the writing will get the point across before unleashing you into the sandbox to proceed how you like... I think its ok, I'm enjoying it. My focus in the game is making money so I can get a crew so we can put a team together to then capture bounties, put them in a brig and send them to prison... I'm a long way away from that but its my goal all the missions and story content is just a bonus waiting for me to try when I'm ready. 

Would I recommend it... with mods absolutely... (A list of mods should be suggested to install for the best experience)  I'm loving it at the moment but as I write this, aside from fast travelling everywhere, I have no idea what people do between getting to and from missions... they're missing out in so much. 

Hopefully Bethesda fixes this

How much I was looking forward to Starfield... 
I had such high hopes for the creators of Skyrim and Fallout. Worlds that invited me to explore and made me forget the passage of time. 
But ironically, the strength of the previous titles is my biggest criticism of Starfield. Apart from the numerous loading screens, the endless galaxy with it's more than 1,000 planets, is alarmingly empty. Realistic, yes perhaps... but how are you supposed to lose yourself in this world? Whereas in Skyrim I only reached my destination after hours because I was distracted by Dwemer caves, random side Quest's, or dragons along the way, the journey through the Settled Systems is enormously underwhelming.

The visuals, however, more than satisfied me. Sure, there are prettier games, but the ships, equipment, worlds, and people looked amazing. If only they weren't so incredibly soulless. These puppets, with their lack of character traits and unbelievable wooden dialogue, which are supposed to pass for humans, shock me deeply after experiences like Cyberpunk or RDR2.

After enduring one more dull quest with its illusion of choice, I gave up on Starfield around the 30 hour mark. 

I still hope Bethesda will awaken from their creative slumber and, much like CDPR, deliver a 2.0 update that pulls Starfield out of its pit of disappointment.

[h2] Starfield’s Hollow Sky [/h2]

A galaxy promised, yet never revealed,
A dream of the stars, but the cosmos is sealed.
To soar in your ship? a screen takes its place,
Immersion is shattered, no journey through space.

Endless transitions, a cycle that grinds,
A frontier of loading, not worlds to find.
The guns speak in echoes, familiar, mundane,
An engine of old still tethered, unchanged.

If Fallout in space with barriers galore
Is the kind of adventure you’re searching for,
Perhaps you’ll endure the illusion they weave,
But for seekers of wonder, best turn and leave.

Not even the modders, with passion and care,
Can salvage this piece of shit of despair.

Starfield is a game that has an extremely wide reach, with the depth of a puddle. I don't even know where to start complaining about this pile of garbage. You can't fly your ship around the planet, you just land it in a fixed spot in a procedurally generated wasteland that might have some things you can footslog to, look at and maaaaybe even shoot at. Maybe. Space flight is a waste of time too, you don't actually get to move around the planet or system you're in. You're basically flying in a big empty box that might have space pirates in it. You can't land on the planet you're visiting, you do it all through fast travel menus. Sometimes you'll find an asteroid field. Crash your ship into one of them and see what happens (Spoiler alert: NOTHING!). This game is fucking stupid, designed by stupid people. Seriously wasted potential here.

Crowds are basically the same 20 npcs copypasted over and over again that have no dialogue aside from "hi" or "hello." Remember how Skyrim's cities, almost all of the NPCs had names and were all involved in at least one quest or relevant to a story somehow? Not anymore, those days are long dead and over. You get generic NPC slop now. Enjoy it!

The big feature with this game is the Creations store. You spend real money, to get "credits" that are used to buy paid mods in the store. Of course, the amounts you can buy credits in, are not multiples of what the paid mods cost. So you have to always buy more credits than needed.

Some of the paid mods are good. Some are complete garbage. But the fact is you always have to buy more credits than you need. So you can end up with quite a lot of credits. I had a lot of credits, while waiting for something worthwhile to spend them on. In a fantastic example of anti-consumer behaviour, these "credits" have an expiry date. A date that you can not see anywhere in game.

Imagine the happiness and satisfaction I felt to log in and discover all my credits have expired.  A shame because I found something I had wanted in the Creations store. Obviously, that's not going to be purchased now that Bethesda has stolen the credits. Clearly they must be so hard up for money, that they have resorted to stealing from customers. That should give you an idea as to the actual state of this game. If it was actually good, they wouldn't need to steal from their customers.

Considering how many bugs and problems I have encountered in Skyrim, Fallout 4 and Starfield, I was genuinely surprised to see that this expiry system appears to be completely bug free. It clearly shows where the bulk of development went in this game. I have to applaud the development team for proving that if Bethesda wanted to, they could create bug free code. They just won't do it for anything they actually want you to buy from them - like for example this game.

I will be voting with my wallet in future. This is the last Bethesda game I will purchase.

I’ve got about 18 hours in now, and while I’m enjoying parts of Starfield, it’s definitely a mixed bag. The visuals are gorgeous, the gunplay is fun, and scanning has honestly become one of my favorite features. It’s not just filler; when you scan a plant or creature, you get little bits of info about how it fits into the ecosystem, and that adds a nice layer of lore. It actually makes exploring planets feel rewarding beyond just collecting loot.

But a lot of the world feels flat. Most NPCs come off as bland and copy-pasted, with only named characters having even a touch of uniqueness. It doesn’t really feel alive the way I hoped it would. The constant loading screens don’t help either. I don’t mind loading when traveling between planets and space, but every single building needing its own load screen breaks immersion fast. Skyrim modders had fixes for this back in 2014, so it feels wild that a studio with this kind of budget didn’t tackle it.

On the RPG side, the dialogue feels thinner compared to past Bethesda games. You can be a little rude at times, but there’s no real villain path or “bad guy” roleplay. Companions especially push back against any violent approach, and after a while it feels like the game is steering you into one “correct” way of playing. I’ve ended up soloing missions just to avoid their constant complaints.

Overall, Starfield nails the visuals, the shooting, and that classic Bethesda exploration loop, and I really enjoy scanning and uncovering bits of hidden lore across planets. But it’s dragged down by lifeless NPCs, way too many loading screens, and shallow RPG elements. That said, I am still giving it a positive review because it scratches that Bethesda itch, just not the full scratch I was hoping for.
Gigantic disappointment when compared to all other Bethesda titles. Not even worth any more words.

So Star field, I have to say I really love this game, the story lines are to me absorbing, the scale of the game  is amazing and at first it is an adventure, looting shooting getting space ships and modifying them, meeting new people starting new quests building outposts, modding guns and space suits love it all.

There are however some serious flaws, I apologise in advance if my comments upset any true believers and fan boys out there.

You soon realise that every planet (almost) has identical locations with loot in the same places, sort of get this, to make them all unique on a game of this scale would be prohibitive in time to create. It does get a little boring though.

The game regularly freezes, loses sound, or crashes completely, normally at a bad time.

The REV, what can I say, it is better than walking and that is about it, all but uncontrollable on snow type ground, when jumping it has an incredible ability to land in a tree or hit a rock, it is meant to be an off road vehicle, all I can say is thank goodness Bethesda staff were not involved in designing the Land Rover car.

Space suits, by their very nature they are sealed systems, so how the hell can you get a cough?? I could understand the suit getting damaged, but a cough because of caustic air? 

The shattered Space DLC was welcome and top notch, I would like to see the next DLC to be along the lines of "Naeva Mora returns" or "Naeva Mora is back" She appears to be heartily disliked by all and sundry on the forums, however we must not overlook the fact that all of her dialogue responses are written by the Developers (she is not a real person) so you would never get a reaction from her other than what was programmed. Her plans for revenge on the UC for killing Jasmine and to a lesser level Delgado could be epic.

Right am off now, just starting new game four, on the third one I married Sarah (normally it is Andreja for me) my god Sarah is an annoying stuck up whiner, forever telling you where you are going wrong, Andreja for me again this go around.

This feels less like a game made by a team that has made 3 elder scrolls and 2 fallout game and more like a team making their first game.

Exploration: needs a pretty big overhaul. Having just one big procedurally generated map for each planet with POI's moved closer together would be preferable (imo) to the infinite empty maps the game generates. Loading screens for space travel also need to be replaced with cutscenes of the players ship transitioning in/out of atmospheres and traveling through the warp tears would lessen the break in the game flow.

Gathering: Too much useless junk in the environments that creates excessive clutter making it easy to miss actual useful crafting materials. All useless junk should be able to serve as crafting materials to lessen time wasted examining everything, ya know, like it was in Fallout 4.

Crafting: is very wasteful, mods should not be lost when replacing them. Either the resources for the previous mod should be refunded (unless the new one is a clear upgrade), or the mod should be removed and placed in inventory/storage to be sold or attached to other weapons/armor.

Spacesuits: These need to be heavily streamlined so the player doesn't need to carry multiple (one of the heaviest items in the game) or just find themselves screwed in certain situations. All Environmental Hazards should simply be protected against by spacesuits, only being issues if the player has none or suffers a suit debuff during combat. i.e punctures or tears in the suit allowing lesser environmental damage through until its repaired. Suits should also just focus on physical defense with beam defense being handled by a dedicated mod slot that can be upgraded or replaced with better shield mods to increase energy defense.

Settlements: One of my favorite mechanics from Fallout 4 has been ruined in this game. The main uses for settlements is to gather resources. While the quantity you can get is good it often requires half a dozen settlements on a single planet to gather all it's resources which then has to be repeated on dozens of planets to establish a decent mining network. While this is time consuming to setup it is also a massive resource investment itself due to the structures you need to build and hiring staff to work the colonies. This can be easily streamlined by just letting the player mine for all available resources on a planet from one settlement per planet.

Story: Without any spoilers the story is designed to push the player into constantly restarting into newgame+'s for random loot. While you don't HAVE to do this it is still poorly designed considering the rest of the game is designed to encourage you to explore this large sector of the galaxy, but then you lose everything you've done and have to redo it which will get tedious if you do go with the story's intended goal.

Final Verdict: The game has plenty of good ideas that could make for a fun experience for those who want a more story focused space experience similar to other Bethesda Games. Spaceship customization is the best mechanic here (Even No Man's Sky has copied it now). Side content continues to be more interesting then the poorly written "main" story. But all of the games systems and mechanics seem to have also been built in vacuums disconnected from each other with no clear or even logical flow to how they supplement each other. Why invest in crafting when your constantly going to replace your upgraded weapons with ones that have random modifiers you cant craft? Why explore and build settlements to gather resources to lose all of it on a Newgame+?

While i often enjoy adding mods to Bethesda games to enhance the experience, this is the first time i've felt a desire to make an extensive overhaul of the entire game. I know Bethesda is working on improving the game but without a complete overhaul that would likely break all existing save files i don't see how this game can be salvaged to a fun state. Maybe in 25-30 years when they make Starfield 2 they'll be able to pull everything together more cohesively. This also makes me very concerned for Elder Scrolls 6 as the same people who made this disjointed train wreck are making that game.

Here we are. Two years later and the game still costs SEVENTY DOLLARS! Ludicrous. 

I got a free copy with my new video card (two years ago), and because I didn't pay the obscene full price that is still in effect, I enjoyed running around and killing bad guys. Because I didn't pay full price for this game. If it retailed for twenty dollars, then I would say it was worth buying. Maybe even thirty, but that's only for those of us who have enough income we don't strain to pay our bills every month.

The story is full of holes, and you are forced to endure one of the most annoying characters ever created, Naeva Mora. She can't be killed. You can kill the leader of the Crimson Pirates (who is also annoying), but Naeva always escapes. It helps if you save the game, then shoot her repeatedly in the face with an automatic shotgun. 

The worst part. You'll never really be able to unravel the greatest mystery of Starfield. How did a giant of deeply immersive RPGs spend seven years making such an empty and repititive game universe?
I have been playing since day one, and I love it.

Don't believe people that have 100+ hours and say it sucks.

Believe me. This game sucks.
This game sucks, save your money and buy something else.

Starfield is a bold step forward for Bethesda and a must-play for fans of sci-fi and RPGs. It’s a game that invites you to lose yourself in its universe, and rewards you for doing so. Whether you're a lone explorer, a cunning smuggler, or a diplomatic envoy, there's a place for you among the stars.

I got my copy of Starfield with the purchase of my AMD GPU.
I put off playing it for a long while because
A) I wasn't that interested in a Bethesda RPG
B) I had other games to play

I finally decide to play it and run into crashes. Constantly. Looking online there are all sorts of tips. So now I've disabled Shadows completely, and turned down other settings. I still get crashes but sometimes I can eek out an hour straight of playing.

That's just the tech side. 
The game is boring. Mission organization is a disaster (why can't I organize them by location?). Garbage everywhere to pickup (I've been told that this is a staple of Bethesda RPGs but WHY?) drowning out the useful things to pick up. Character animations are super weird, especially if you start any conversation with an NPC outside of directly in front of them. Some missions are just broken because I can't interact with an NPC. 
The game is just a mess. I played Cyberpunk 2077 AT LAUNCH on PC and didn't run into as many problems with it as I have with Starfield years after release. 

I'm going to finish this game because I just am. But I'm going to spend as little time with all its systems as I can get away with.

I've played this game for 138 hours and I cannot play anymore. This game is just MISSING EVERYTHING there is nothing but a vast lifeless expanse with repeat encounters on every planet, endless fetch quests and just derelict emptiness. The "cities" in game are a sad excuse. There is nothing memorable about almost any of them let alone the sheer emptiness of scope. The cities are meant to feel alive and look alive but they aren't. Bethesda made this game to imitate a game, imitate a city, imitate imitate imitate. This game is a sad excuse for a game and it shows by how little has actually improved from the developers over the past two years. I cannot stress enough how much I do not recommend the game to people.

I slogged through all of it just so I can say I didn't waste my money. In the end, it wasted my money and my time.

Okay, so I'd like to say right off the bat that I did NOT like Starfield in its base, vanilla form. I just couldn't really get into it. It seemed empty and lacking. However, when I redownloaded the game, installed the Star Wars: Genesis mod, and started anew, I'm finding the game much more interesting. DeityVengy did an awesome job of converting Starfield into a Star Wars fan's dream game. The lore, assets, cities, dialogue, quests, and so much more has been changed. It doesn't feel like Starfield so much anymore. DeityVengy and team are also providing constant updates and improvements. I and my husband are very surprised how much I'm enjoying the game now.

Thanks Bethesda for creating a great foundation for DeityVengy and their team to build Star Wars: Genesis.

Okay so as you can tell from my 400+ hours, I actually liked this game, but if you're expecting anything other than 'slightly shinier fallout in space' you are going to be extremely dissapointed.
Content is lacking, settlement building is somehow worse and more restrictive than Fallout 4, the planets are most empty rocks with copy/paste points of interest. With the word 'interest' being stretched to the limit.
The paid mods thing is back and worse than ever, with Bethesda pushing regular updates that do nothing but disable work-arounds modders have found to avoid the awful creation club.
The DLC is powerfully dull, but ever since the update where it was release, performance has tanked. Even with all the graphics settings set to 'Very Low' I still regularly get 0.5 seconds of input lag and stuttering when literally up until the day of that update I was running with everything on Ultra without dropping a single frame.

I just really hope Bethsoft get their act together or TES 6 is going to be the last game they ever make at this rate.

A late review, but I wanted to share some quick thoughts.

I like Starfield. I've played through it a couple of times by now and often get the itch to play even more. I enjoy the theme, the quests, the music, and the gameplay. While I certainly had a lot of little pet peeves when the game first launched, many, if not all, of them have been fixed by now. It scratches the space exploration itch slightly better than No Man's Sky. 

The biggest drawback for me is the lack of unique locations and POIs. The major cities are cool, as are the unique POIs, but outside of that, you only see a randomized mix of stuff when exploring. If you ask me, the game would be significantly better with more static places to visit.

If you're interested and can get the game, try it. See for yourself. Maybe you'll like it as much as I did.

The game starts off pretty good, you slowly get into it, but it soon becomes very repetitive and an actual chore to play. It's as if bethesda unlike the games I love only put half the time into the stories, quests, factions and general variation of content,buildings and "dungeons". It becomes the same sh** over and over very fast.

Huge let down from bethesda, only buy it when its the complete edition and only then when its 75%+ off or something. It's not fit to lace the shoes of the elder scrolls or fallout games.
I really wanted to like this game, I was so hyped for it, but I feel like the developers lost something in their formulaic process.

Alright, so here goes.

I've played this game for significantly more than 339 hours. I actually started playing Starfield when it launched on Gamepass, and then ended up purchasing the game later on Steam. There is a whole process for converting your save game data from xbox to PC. I believe I had roughly 120 hours into the game before I decided it was wise to make that transition. 

With that said, and I cannot stress this enough, base game Starfield isn't very fun. Sure, it still kept my interest for awhile, and I know for others it scratches certain itch, but it does get outshined by other games in nearly every category. The game that most closely resembles Starfield but is better in every way (except for combat) is No Man's Sky, and it's not even close. The ONLY advantage this game has over No Man's Sky is the combat system, because No Man's Sky (NMS) has a near non-existent combat system in its game, or at least it did the last time I played it. 

Whether it's base building, exploration, interesting sites, secrets, ship building, quests, or multiplayer, NMS has base game Starfield blown out of the water. Now, I give this game a positive review simply because of mods. Were it not for mods and the creation kit, this game would not be nearly as fun or keep feeling "fresh" to me and so many others. The notable mods I have installed that keep the game fun are downloaded through Vortex from Nexusmods.com, as well as a few from the Creations Kit. 

Enhanced Combat, Energy Shields, Additional Missions, Enemy modifiers, Enemy overhauls, Ship Builder tweaks, Boarding encounters, player ability overhauls and additions, armor & clothing sets, companion overhauls are the kind of mods I have installed. The most important mods are the Enhanced Combat, Energy Shields, Additional Missions mods, and I will explain why.

After about 30 hours into your first run, you may start to notice yourself getting very strong, and neigh unkillable to anything on 2 or more legs. After about level 70, you're functionally a god and can't be killed by anything but your own hubris. Doesn't sound like such a terrible deal, right? Wrong. It makes the game very unfun after that point and normal people would lose interest rather quickly. The Enhanced Combat and Energy Shield mods I have installed fixes that issue. The Enhanced Combat mod changes your maximum health pool to 400 instead of allowing you to get to ludricrous numbers even as high as 15k. Some enemies can also get extremely beefy without this mod reducing their maximum HP. With the Enhanced Combat mod installed, it makes it so EVERY encounter with enemies no matter what level they are can be deadly. To place it into greater perspective, 400 maximum HP is a very low number, and it makes it so you can use just about any vanilla weapon in the game and be competent in combat. For the higher level/rarity weapons, you will find yourself 1 shotting enemies with automatic rifle fire...but the same can also be said for enemies to you. The risk of yourself getting 1 tapped by automatic fire is also VERY high, and makes it so you have to play far more tactical than before, almost like you're playing Rainbow 6 Siege.

To help alleviate the "issue" of fights taking extremely long to fight through because you get 1 tapped so often, the Energy Shields mods comes in clutch. Energy Shields stops yourself, and eligable enemies from getting 1 tapped by any weapon damage, which is also fully customizable how strong the shields get, and how often enemies will have shielding active, and if it's enabled by default before combat starts or not. If you have it toggled like I do, it allows for you to play stealthily when clearing dungeons, allowing viable stealth gameplay.

With Additional enemy modifier, and additional missions modifier mods, it's something that I feel should have been including in the vanilla game. It increases the enemy count by 10x, and missions by about 10x, as well as mission slates that can be picked up from random enemy corpses. It significantly raises the immersion of gameplay and helps the game to be filled out and look nothing like the "dead game" so many people say it is. Having massively enhanced enemy numbers also of course makes the game significantly harder, and helps you level up much faster especially at the later glory levels (150+).

Vanilla game for Starfield when it comes to customization is only somewhat good for Ship Building. It becomes very clear however that there are a couple of weapons that vastly outshine others, and its not even situational. NMS ship builder is a bit better, but the truly massive distinction is the usage of the player home/outpost building. In Starfield, building an outpost is almost completely useless unless you want to use 1 outpost to expand to another planet and use another. For some, I'm sure that's fun, but for people like me that don't enjoy playing farming simulator with dead outposts, it feels dumb. In NMS, your outpost building actually means something and has a large impact on the game. Also, you have an incredibly higher degree of customization for your outposts and can make your player homes truly impressive and then show them off to the player community. 

I could go on for much longer different pro's and cons to Starfield or even No Man's Sky, but I think you get the point. If you're going to buy Starfield, I highly recommend a PC purchase and get ready for some heavy modding for it to be a fun game.

One of the many GAME BREAKING bugs from launch still existing in Sept. 2025:

-Damage resistance (DR) from consumables becomes permanent if you save and reload. You inevitably will have permanent 85% damage reduction after a few hours of normal gameplay. This can only be fixed with console commands and not consuming any consumables that give DR.

-There are also still the same archaic engine bugs being patched out by mods that were patched out in Oblivion.

-The worst Bethesda game to mod because the engine is already at its limits. E.g. enemies have such a short range of detection because raising detection range in xEdit by just 10% causes CTD at multiple POIs.
I would only recommend this game if you can buy it for less than $15 and have a quantum computer to run it. Gameplay, story, and performance are all incredibly dull.

I like this game. I like the settings and most of the dynamics. The only thing that disappoints me, is the building dynamics. I 'liked' the way the walls and floors/ceilings 'snapped' together. I also liked that you weren't limited to a select few prefabs that you could build with. I've tried building custom buildings or just adding walls to some of the unfurnished prefabs. But when they didn't snap into place, I found the buildings leaked like sieves on planets with toxic atmospheres. I was actually kind of hoping and expecting that Bethesda was going to use the same building mechanics as they did in Fallout 4, with different, more futuristic skins on the building parts, hence my disappointment. I kind of hope they do something about the building mechanics sometime soon, to make it easier to build bases.

I know it sounds like I'm shooting down this game. But I really do like it actually. I like the open world play and the base story line. I also like all the different adventures, missions, and exploring available that are available.  I would also like to get into the resource economics system a little more. Hopefully, Bethesda will do something to improve the building mechanics to make that a little easier.

Anyway, if you enjoy open world games with multiple gaming styles, then I think you will enjoy this game.

When this was being hyped back in 2023, I was looking forward to playing it, then I saw some of the system requirements and I was concerned that I might not get the full experience. So I decided not to buy it but it did make me get a really good SSD drive and a 3 month Microsoft Game Pass so this allowed me to at least trial it for 3 months. I have to admit at the time, I hated it. Graphically poor, buggy and it all seemed like a Fallout 4 rip off (Fallout 4 is in my top 5 of games).

A few months back the game was on sale and after GFX upgrade made earlier in the year I decided to buy the premium edition (it was only (£29), and boy was it the best decision I have ever made, to the point that Starfield could very well be one of the best games I have ever played. Its clear that this game is not for everyone and there are parts of the game that I am not a huge fan off, but I tend to find that it a lot of my favourite games.

I have yet to complete the main story line but so far I have enjoyed what I have played although I have tended to focus more on the side quests were are amazing, such as the story line of the Terrormorphs which clearly has been influenced by Starship Troopers. I like the Outpost building elements of F4, and that has transcended into Starfield. My only gripe with this though is that there are loads of cosmetics missing such as bathrooms even though they feature through out the game on NPC outposts and towns. A minor gripe.

I like the weapons on offer in the game, and there is enough customisation to allow you to play to your style, some of the creation mods also add a little more flavour to this so its worth checking out. The game is also visually stunning if you have a reasonable GFX card, especially when in space. When it comes to exploration I feel like this could have been a really cool Star Trek game as it has everything you could possibly want. Its also clear that there are so many references to the world of SciFi, such as the Disney movie Black Hole as well as the classics of Blade Runner, Aliens and as said earlier Starship Troopers. Some have complained that there is a lack of sentient alien species that ruin the game, well why does there need to be? After all the Alien Verse and Starship Troopers doesn't, even shows like Battlestar Galactica and The Expanse doesn't, so to me that is a mute point.

One thing that I don't think works, at least not well is the introduction of vehicles. You can't customise the one you can get and there are no more you can buy unless you get them via creation mods. Driving is also crazy and I had to make so many tweaks to the controls to get it right for me. Again a small annoyance and once I hope gets looked at in the future.

Its clear that this game divides in so many ways, but I for one recommend it. If your a fan of Fallout 4 and Star Trek, this game is defo for you.

I'm not sure why this game would have mixed reviews.  Its a great sci-fi game in the tradition of all Bethesda games.  It's hugely expansive, has great stories and missions.  The voice acting is first rate and the settings are gorgeous and memorable.  I can only conclude that it doesn't fit what some people "wanted" it to be, so they're complaining about it.   If you don't like Bethesda games, you probably won't like this.  It is very much like Skyrim and Fallout 4.  If you like those, go for it!

If you want a first rate sci-fi RPG, this is one of the best around.
Game was pretty fun, pretty buggy but good, got it on sale, pretty pissed the Achievements didt work though..

This game is exactly like Skyrim, except it's space themed instead. I find it extremely odd that despite being a space game, it feels unfinished and rushed for some reason, especially with the planets you discover. Most of the planets you discover are just empty with little interest to do. While the ship modifications and building were a nice feature, it still didn't flesh out well enough in my opinion. Not to mention, the story in this game is not that great, especially when there is no action by the events of the game. 

I don't hate this game at all, I think it's okay but not good enough and I think it still has better potential. I don't know if I regret paying this for a full price but I am definitely not enjoying it so far. If you still want to try the game, then waiting for a sale is an absolute must.

The number 1 rule to playing Starfield: It's not as good as Skyrim or Fallout, and it will feel disappointing if you compare this game to those. That being said, it can be a lot of fun, especially with mods! Like most Bethesda games, you'll have the most fun if you ignore the majority of the main plot and just have fun with the sandbox environment.

Starfield: The Bethesda Cosmic Toybox

Setting Expectations

Starfield has taken its fair share of criticism, much of it familiar to anyone who has played a Bethesda RPG before. Complaints about bugs, loading screens, or repetitive quests tend to follow every release. As a long time Bethesda player, I see Starfield less as a flawless new beginning and more as the next logical step in their formula. If you come in expecting Elder Scrolls VI levels of hype, you’ll be disappointed. But if you approach it as a cosmic sandbox in the Bethesda tradition, with all the quirks and strengths that implies, it’s easier to appreciate what it does right and forgive what it doesn’t.

Empty / Repetitive Worlds & Planets

General criticism: planets feel copy-pasted, exploration isn’t rewarding.

My take: Starfield’s procedural system isn’t aiming for the infinite variety of No Man’s Sky or Elite Dangerous. It’s closer to Bethesda extending the world building of Fallout 4 or Skyrim outward, using procedural methods to generate wilderness beyond handcrafted hubs. Land in a biome like “swampland” and it will look familiar no matter where, but the game is pulling from a large procedural pool. Each planet map is divided into regions where the game generates explorable tiles on demand. It’s less about infinite novelty and more about creating Bethesda-style wilderness wherever you land. Most remote areas hold raider camps, mercenary forts, or the occasional Starborn ruin or Terrormorph cave, much like stumbling upon a random cave in Fallout. The system keeps exploration consistent without becoming overwhelming, and the handcrafted Settled Systems remain the real highlight.

City Design

Bethesda’s cities in the past have often felt too small or compressed.

My take: In Starfield, the city design is a leap forward. Akila City is much larger and feels like a believable city rather than a compact hub. New Atlantis stretches across a large worldspace with towering skyscrapers and hubs of activity, giving it the presence of a capital. Together they create settlements that feel more like functional metropolises than compressed quest hubs.

Excessive Loading Screens & Transitions

General criticism: constant loading breaks immersion.

My take: The loading screens in Starfield follow Bethesda’s long established rules for worldspaces. Entering a ship, docking, or moving between planetary surfaces and interiors always triggers a transition, much like entering a building in Skyrim or Fallout. The difference is simply frequency due to the galaxy’s scale and layered travel systems. Once you understand planets and cities are modular worldspaces stitched together, the loads feel more like Bethesda’s philosophy applied to a bigger canvas than a flaw unique to Starfield.

Main Story / Narrative Weaknesses

General criticism: bland or generic story, characters underdeveloped.

My take: Starfield is best approached as an open ended narrative sandbox. The main quest carries the gravitas and drama of Skyrim and veers into metaphysical territory, but it’s more a canvas for your role in the Settled Systems. Character creation supports this by giving backgrounds and traits that shape dialogue. The story shines less as a linear epic and more as roleplay freedom: you can be a cyber runner ronin for Ryujin, or a Flash Gordon style gunslinger for the Freestar Collective. It really is Skyrim in space with Fallout 4 style crafting, and New Game Plus even lets you subvert the main quest for replayability.

Performance, Bugs, and Tech Issues

General criticism: buggy launch, performance issues on some hardware.

My take: Starfield is a technical leap over Fallout 4. You could even see it as a working demo of the Creation Engine 2. Bethesda could have polished more, but if your system meets the specs, performance is stable. Post year one, the game is far more stable than older Bethesda launches. Modding support has already improved optimization and bugfixes, much like Skyrim’s ecosystem. I don’t meet the official system requirements, yet with mod optimization and lower environment textures I can still play. The game can run on Fallout 4 level horsepower, though it’s more resource heavy due to asset streaming and higher fidelity.

Repetitive Missions / Busywork

General criticism: quests feel like chores or filler.

My take: By around level 40, you’ll likely have wrapped the main quest if you beeline it, but the game is built for a slow burn sandbox. Unlike Fallout 4’s defined role, you start with miner origins until you become Starborn. That open endedness mirrors Skyrim, where the main quest is only one thread. Repetition sets in if you only chase big set pieces, but embraced as a sandbox, the design makes sense.

Lack of Depth in Certain Systems

General criticism: shallow NPC behavior, combat repetition, loot reskins.

My take: I won’t lean heavily into system depth, since I was modding them right away. That’s typical for Bethesda. The base framework feels underdeveloped in places, but with mods the systems quickly become richer.

Expectation vs Reality / Marketing vs Experience

General criticism: game didn’t live up to the hype, not revolutionary.

My take: Starfield launched with hype like Elder Scrolls VI, but it shouldn’t be judged as that. It’s a standalone franchise and a technical preview of what Elder Scrolls VI will likely run on. As a Bethesda toybox—part narrative playground, part sandbox, part crafting—it scratches several gaming itches even if not revolutionary. It sets the stage for the future while offering its own flavor of storytelling.

Cost & DLC / Value Concerns

General criticism: DLC pricing vs content value, some issues remain unaddressed.

My take: The base game is worth it for the modding potential alone. I never felt I missed anything by skipping Shattered Space. I liked Andreja and House Va’ruun lore, but the DLC feels worth it only on discount or for mod framework needs. With about 50 mods, the base game already transforms into something sweeping.

Closing Thoughts

I recommend Starfield for anyone who enjoyed Fallout’s weapon crafting and settlement building. Bethesda needed more time to polish its systems into full sandbox features, but shipped an RPG as is. If it had leaned harder into those systems and their accessibility, it might have launched with a clearer identity. Still, that flexibility is its strength. With a light modlist, a mediocre game becomes an engaging toybox where you can roleplay, build capital ships, or just take a stroll through the Well.

Despite all the negative reviews I’ve seen, I’m honestly having a blast playing Starfield.

The main story is decent, but just like in every Bethesda game, it’s really the side quests and faction quests that shine. The UC Vanguard line in particular hooked me, and I found all the faction storylines to be engaging.

Ship building is another highlight, the sheer freedom to create whatever you want is amazing. You can design sleek vessels, bizarre frankenstein monster ships or anything in between, and they’ll still fly. Outposts are also a neat feature; they’re as simple or as detailed as you want, especially if you enjoy decorating.

Visually, the graphics are fine, not great not terrible.

What did disappoint me a little were the procedurally generated POIs. After a while they start to feel repetitive and soulless, no matter which planet you’re on. I really wish these areas had been handcrafted instead, because that would have made exploration far more rewarding.

On the positive side, companions are fantastic. Sarah and Vasco became favorites of mine, and traveling with them made the journey feel more alive.

Mods are a game-changer. StarUI is a must, and with a bunch of mods installed the game instantly feels so much better.

All in all, Starfield may not be perfect, but I still find it pretty fun. If you go in with right mindset, you might find it really addictive, as I did.

It's a very good game.
I understand it may not live up to some people's expectations, and I can also understand that the pace of the game (slow at times) may put some people off. But to go so far as to call it a scam, a disgrace, or whatever... that's just dishonest.

I loved the atmosphere from the very start, and immediately felt immersed. I was amazed by the environments, during space exploration or on the many (too many?) planets. I enjoyed some excellent stories scattered throughout the galaxy. I spent hours creating or modifying my ships, and took great pleasure in wandering from planet to planet to discover their secrets.
There are flaws, of course. The companions are too bland/similar, the weapons and equipment could have been more varied/original. And many planets feel too empty, even useless.

But the biggest issue in my opinion is that I would have liked more. Even more quests, even more types of starships, even more companions, cities, factions... And in my opinion it's not a real flaw, it was just good enoough for me to want to play longer and discover more things. Plus well, there's already a lot.
Overall I would have liked it to have been more successful, that more people would have taken it for what it is and not what a few loud people would have liked it to be.

Anyway, if you want a grand space adventure, do yourself a favor and give this game a chance.

Hundreds of hours in Starfield so far, thousands across all Bethesda titles. While I somewhat enjoyed Starfield due to being a lifelong Bethesda fan, I couldn't recommend it to anyone.

The writing is sophomoric and predictable, the characters unbelievable and frankly boring, besides Andreja. Any serious moments are undercut by weirdly out of place sarcastic humor. You often have no dialogue options approximating how people actually talk to each other. 

The tone of the game and dialogue is juvenile. It seems like they did a second pass through the entire game to make sure nothing could possibly offend anyone, as so many themes and plot points teeter on the edge of real gravity and should be handled with maturity are instead childish and bland. The game is rated M, but all the dialogue and characters are rated E, its very anachronistic and immersion breaking. The in game pirates act like middle school bullies in tone and speech, which is entirely at odds with the reality of people who survive by piloting ships through space to victimize innocents at the risk of the own life. 

The main story is bland and uninspiring, the loop is self defeating, the meta narrative actually discourages engaging in the NG+ mechanics, the side factions quest lines are dull and juvenile without any real stakes to 3/4 of the available factions. The Freestar Rangers are an offensive patische of US western culture that could have been done very well but seems undercut by present day biases and lack of stakes and player agency. 

The gunplay is the best feeling BGS has accomplished so far, however the overall combat experience is dull and unserious due to the bullet sponge issue. 

The Starborn powers are literally the Skyrim shouts, with like three original ones. 

The space combat is boring and requires mods to make it anywhere close to engaging.

The exploration loop is fun at first, and while the game is capable of great vistas and photographic moments, the random POI system is an absolute dud, especially due to POI weights meaning that you'll visit the same exact 10 POIs across the majority of the breadth and width of the galaxy. 

There are functionally no survival mechanisms in a game about space exploration and survival. Starvival fixes that, but its an absurd oversight. 

The four main cities are too small, Whiterun seems larger than Akila city.

The Creations store is predatory and host to a variety of reskins they want you to pay $10 for.

The alien wildlife generation is elementary and uninspiring. There are zero mammalian type creatures across the galaxy, everything's a bug or dinosaur or a mix between the two.

You can't go underwater. You're wearing a space suit, which astronauts train in giant pools with in real life, but you can't go underwater anywhere across the galaxy. 

While you can download 200+ mods to make Starfield into a fun game worth playing, never before has BGS fumbled so hard in so many areas across the game. Don't buy it until it's less than $20 USD, that's the value I'd pay for vanilla Starfield now having put so many hours into it. 

I have lost faith in BGS as a studio, and now fear the ES6 will be as large a disappointment as Starfield. Todd has lost his way. Emil should be exiled. The studio itself engages in inflammatory and divisive social media rhetoric pertaining to outside current day US politics which is abhorrent and unneeded. I will preoder ES6 and I'm going to play 500 more hours of Starfield, as being a BGS fan is a Sisyphean punishment dealt from on high.
I would rather playing Fallout 4 with mods for 4657345634753456th time than playing this garbage.

TL;DR: solid 7/10, maybe not for everybody, mod the eff out of it. I'll be playing for a couple hundred more hours I bet.

If you were anticipating Skyrim in space, then you may be disappointed to know it's 50/50 at best (or worst).
Here's a few pluses and minus' that I personally feel might be relevant:

(-) You get the same intermittent, annoying, funny and sometimes game-breaking bugs.

(-) You get to enjoy deadpan delivery of what, on paper, you'd expect to be an epic space-opera or journey.

(-) Enjoy Fallout 4's same two combat music tracks that played in the Commonwealth when in a fight? We have that here too. The Theme is serviceable in its own right, although besides the main menu and specific scenes you might not hear it very often.

(-) Enjoy an EULA which basically forces you to agree that the $70, 125GB application on your hard drive is indeed not yours.

(-/+) Space combat was (mildly enjoyable), when there was ever more than 2-3 enemy vessels at a time; which when you get mid-to-late-game modules and weapons said battles will be over way too quickly.

(-) The weapon variety tries, although due to the fact weapons don't particularly scale, you'll likely loot a high-DPS weapon off a mini-boss or high-level zone and just make that your new, permanent primary. If you don't then you'll quickly notice how fast enemies become spongy to damage as you progress outside the starting area.

(-) Weapon upgrades are tied behind multiple skills- which wouldn't be so bad, if it wasn't for the fact that compared to Fallout 4's system is INCREDIBLY grindy at times. Many will point out guides on the University of YouTube/Reddit, however if I have to follow a 15-minute guide on how to cheese the game balancing or XP grinding, then why would I even try to play legit in first place? I like to cheese when it's for fun, but not if I am obligated to avoid a 10+ hour character grind right at the start.

(+) The graphics are pretty. I mean, in the wild areas the landscape generation can look a little funny if you have things scaled down, but it's evident they at least tried to make something visually appealing. This is definitely a game that shines when the settings are topped-out, but certainly not on the lowest values.

(+) The sound design, when it works, is tickling to the 'tism. Guns sound punchy, ship engines sound crispy, etc.

(-) The sound design, when it doesn't work. If you're not running a beefcake rig, then when in areas with a lot of explosions, gunfire, enemies etc. you may notice some audio may cut out or not play at all. Definitely circumstantial, but still jarring nonetheless. In more extreme cases, I've personally had to avoid using headphones in certain areas due to 'popping' or crunchy sound effects that sometimes take place which can be generally unpleasant when using surround sound or Dolby/Atmos.

(+) I found the ship construction and modification to be entertaining. Out of my 67 hours, at least 33 hours of that was me making unreasonable vessels and screwing around with different set-ups and styles of cabins. There could likely be more freedom in how it's done, but considering this is one of the first games they tried this with, it's serviceable enough. There are plenty of Workshop/Creation mods that rectify this by including more modules, tweaking or removing sizing limits, etc. My personal flavor of autism is spaceships and spaceship customization- so I am likely biased when I glaze this point.

(+) The Creation Mods. There are a lot of tweaks that make this game a bit more enjoyable, or fix known issues. Community made cosmetics are also appetizing. Very nice.

(-) The Creation Mods. A lot of the larger or simply cooler files and tweaks cost points. Which cost real money. Not nice. Forgive me if I do not enjoy modding my $70 game with $20 worth of points to download a fist-full of mods that I think would make me enjoy the game a bit more (personal preference).

(-) The loading screens. I'm sorry, but dear god the loading screens.

(+) Gay Space Cowboy romance is possible with a character voiced by Elias Toufexis if you chose a male character. 
(Because we know you wanted to bang Adam Jensen from DE:HR) Just what Jake Gyllenhaal and Heath Ledger fought for.

You know, despite the memes, I unironically got a chub at the idea of Skyrim in space.
The TES formula with a space plot/verb swap for the script not only sounds neat (albiet campy), but also incredibly easy. 
So why, pray tell, does it look like they struggled so badly? 
Why does it not have the same magical hold that drew me before?

I'll be honest, it's not even the worst game I've played. 
There were times I got really annoyed, and times where I really enjoyed myself.
It's the price tag.
Prices. Set. Expectations.
When I booted up the game, I was fully anticipating $70 worth of fun- even when a quarter of my C: Drive was molested to make space. Instead I got what I personally believed should have been a $20 Indie spin-off or even a Early-Access beta.

Making something different is good. It's risky. It's exciting. It's beautiful.
But when only half of the effort shows, it has the opposite effect:
It's mundane. It's a bore. It's abrasive.
And that would be fine, except one thing:
125.6 GB base game; $70 Retail price.

I believe video games are like art: they require passion, purpose, fulfillment.
There must be something with soul, something that draws you in; wanting more.
I just don't think we've hit that mark just yet.

(5.5/10) - It tickled my space-flavored autism, all I crave is space.
Throw everything else back in the oven; it's under-cooked.
Best planet landscapes in any game ever.

From Mullet to Mass Murderer: My Starfield Story

Rolled an epic hero with a majestic mullet.
He was an extrovert, a mamma’s boy, and worshipped a snake god.

Started as a humble miner. Found a shiny rock. Touched it. Brain went “woooosh” and suddenly I was the Chosen One.

Met a mysterious black dude and his sassy robot. They invited me to join their “definitely not a cult” space book club. I joined, because free snacks.

Visited my parents — yes, I actually picked that trait. Now I have to pay them an allowance while I’m out saving the galaxy.

At cult HQ I met a space cowboy and his daughter. Also a posh British lady with the accent of someone who’s never eaten a freeze-dried potato.

Teamed up with the cowboy, saved a whole planet of space cowboys, became a Ranger and a bounty hunter, and helped him with his ex-wife drama like some interstellar Dr. Phil.

Teamed up with the British lady, joined the Space Marines, hunted for a cure to a creepy bug, got promoted to captain, saved the galaxy, then married the British lady. “Boinked her a lot for the XP boost” became my main build.

Helped the sugar daddy of the cult build the biggest ship in the galaxy. He loved it. I loved it. It was ugly as absolute space-sin — like a flying space-dumpster with wings — but it was mine.

Met an emo thief chick. Together we stole everything that wasn’t bolted down and then some that was. Saved the black dude from pirates and helped him unlock his own cosmic powers.

Became a First-Class Citizen of New Atlantis and got my own penthouse for saving everyone from the space bugs — finally living the deluxe space-dad dream.

Unlocked even more space wizard powers. Watched my wife die because I helped the cowboy protect his daughter. Attended a Bethesda funeral (awkwardly long load screen included).

Married the emo chick. Put her in my late wife’s clothes. Went on a galaxy-wide revenge spree. Got arrested. Went undercover as a space pirate. Brought death and destruction to the stars.

Got a pardon. Did the good guy act. Went to the Unity. Started New Game+. Saved everyone.

Now my formerly dead wife is alive again and has gone full righteous paladin and gets on my nerves. (Yes, I married her again.) I regret it. They say everything happens for a reason, but now I miss the life I had with the emo chick.

10/10 — Starfield let me live, die, love, boink for XP, pilot a hideous flying space-dumpster, and regret my cosmic marriage choices. Would do it all again.

Few years after release, game still feels a lot like initial release of No Man's Sky just with more bloated budget to look fancier and add theoretically more things, but almost all of which are as shallow as a puddle.

For example: Trackers Alliance(Bounty Hunter faction) questline is whole 1 QUEST LONG, after that it's all just radiant quests with generic randomly named enemy targets. You can make it 2 quests long however... IF YOU BUY PAID MOD WITH IT IN CREATIONS. This is just blatant laziness and greed from Bethesda.

If I bought the game for full price, I would be really pissed off because it feels lazy and unfinished in a lot of places, only to offer PAID band-aid solutions in Creations: Spacers are an extremely generic looking enemy faction, supposed to be this gang of psychos... if you want them to look the part you must buy a paid creation in the store. A lot of convenience stuff such as placing faction mission boards in your outposts is also gated behind Creations store.

There are also missing important features such as being able to personally decide where doors and ladders should be inside our own ship, because the automated way it's done often makes absolutely no sense, leading to nonsensical labirynthine mazes inside your own ship.

The few genuinely good things about the game are the gun customization(Which is just lifted from Fallout 4...), and shipbuilding(Except for aforementioned missing ability to decide where ladders and doors are) which is far better way of making your own personal "base" than building outposts(At least in my opinion).

Also as a side note, despite what pronouns in character creator implied, I didn't find too much blatant propaganda in the game, EXCEPT from Trackers Alliance leader obnoxiously making it clear he "never identified with gender binary" and likes that his job lets him be officially considered a "they/them"... which is cringeworthy, but seems like a separated incident, rest of the writing is just boring and uninspired slop.

I was lucky to get the game as a free code with an AMD CPU, because if I paid full price I'd honestly feel quite scammed...

Bethesda isn't the same anymore—they inject their games with certain political ideals in mind. It's almost like they've undergone some sort of......transition. Perhaps Microsoft will steer them back someday, but I won't hold my breath. RIP Bethesda.

I avoided Starfield when it came out due to bad reviews, but received the game from a friend so decided to give it a go after having it in my library for a while. 

The game is enjoyable, but it required me to change the way I'd usually approach a Bethesda game. The systems in the game seem very disjointed and the progression system is totally broken, which means you can play for hours and level up and barely improve your character, since you only receive a single skill point on levelling up, and all skills require a skill point to unlock and upgrade. There are mods which can change this but I am playing on vanilla with the difficulty settings maxed for the extra XP bonuses. They could easily have improved this system, but instead implemented a "new game plus" mode, which doesn't make any sense. 

The story also shoves you in before you've even explored any of the systems or games mechanics, and within an hour you have your own ship and are in one of the capital cities and have many of the companions (this makes hiring crew obsolete before you even learn you can hire ship crew). This seems like poor writing and design as they could have let you develop your character before introducing you to the main quest, allowing you to slowly explore the first few star systems.

There is no karma system or faction reputation that really effects your play through, which for a vast game like this seems like a missed opportunity for a deeper experience, and would have allowed greater replayability. I was also able to simply start the main faction quests without having to first prove myself in any way, which seem a bit unbelievable from a story and RPG perspective. This also makes the "new game plus" they added kind of pointless, why would you start again when the play through is not really going to change much?

It seems way too easy to progress and get credits, everyone is just throwing credits at me, making skills persuasion skills seem redundant, since everyone is willing to just hand over rewards. There are so many activities to do in this game to earn credits, but they all seem pointless since credits are just showered on you. It would have been a better approach to allow characters to earn the first ship and make a name for themselves before the main quest pops up. Again the writing seems kind of simplistic and short sighted in what could have been done.

I think they art style and graphics are good. The combat is alright, it would be better but I am limited by the skill progression system, I would have to be level 40 just to have 10 fully upgraded skills - and on the higher difficulty some like fitness etc are a necessity just to be able to function and carry ammo etc. I do find the exploration elements fun, and have done some basic outpost building, again limited by the progression system. The space combat is ok - it feels like Star Wars Squadron style combat, and the random encounters in space have been entertaining, as well as distress calls etc, though space travel eventually becomes a matter of fast travelling - which I don't mind, though all the pointless animations for docking, landing, or even standing up from the cockpit etc become a bit annoying. It would have been more fun to move through space more and encounter things randomly rather than fast travelling.

I am intrigued by the story and faction quests and some of the followers I currently have, so I will likely try to finish the game eventually, though I don't see myself replaying it once I've completed it, which is a shame, as I have replayed all Fallout games from 1 - 4 many times over and same for the Elder Scrolls series.

tl;dr - I don't recommend this game...yet

You could argue that after 125.6 hours into this game you could say I got my money's worth in entertainment. In some ways, I did, it was kinda fun to explore some of the mechanics - settlement building, ship building, levelling up and getting more powerful weapons/attachments. Ultimately though, they made a massive sandbox, vast and wide with lots of planets - but no content.

I've played Fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas, Fallout 4, Oblivion, Skyrim (and modded the heck out of all of them). They are a beautiful tried and tested formula. I had such high hopes for Starfield. I watched a reviewer of starfield that made the comparison that every landmark in the other Bethesda games (excluding Starfield) were handcrafted (or at least appeared to be) - usually each having a story, a place in the world. Starfield will have you fly to random star, generate random encounter with pirate ship/other vessel, land on procedurally-generated planet, go to one 6? Maybe 8? copy and pasted points of interest...every "Science Outpost" is the same as any other "Science Outpost" down to the last coffee cup and scattered papers on the desk... Now take this and multiply this by 100's of planets. Don't get me wrong there's a number of beautiful hand designed places, but even these are hit and miss. Beautiful yes, but devoid of life, and caged within loadscreens. Some are better, Neon and the Mars colony are quite well done. I spent most of my time here as these felt the most alive and atmospheric. I enjoy some of the quest elements, and when they did design specific areas/quests you could see Bethesda shine through - there's one quest that has you enter a 'blood race' which was a race to the death - classic Bethesda. These little custom encounters make me look back at Starfield and remember the good times, but these just make me so disappointed in what could have been. There was a lot of core components/elements that made Skyrim/Oblivion/Fallout so good - but they tripped over trying to make it too big. If you want a procedurally generated sandbox, go check out Empyrion Galactic Survival.

So how would I fix this?
- I would reduce the scope of the galaxy to maybe 5 star systems with a limited number of planets
- Each star system is 'governed' by a specific faction: 1 Western-styled (cargo runners, space cowboys), 2 High-tech explorers (maybe slightly alien/psychic/cyborg? Star-trek style), 3 Militaristic (looking to expand but super strict and rigid to a fault), 4 Zealous/Religious (Looking to bring everywhere else under their fold, has a jedi/force-esque element, but can be overbearing), 5 This star system could be the "mysterious 5th faction" which is dangerous to all but doesn't communicate or wish to expand. All other factions will want to explore/conquer/mine/encroach on the planets in the 5th star system.
- As there's only 5 star systems, each with 1-2 planets that you could go on (no you can't go to Venus/Jupiter type planets), they would be a lot more detailed handcrafted with unique points of interests.

I know this has never been a strength of Bethesda, but the gun play is quite bad - you can say that's 'quirky Bethesda' but in this day and age, there's so many other games they can draw inspiration from. I understand they wanted to have unique gun designs but the animations, but full bullets coming out of the shotgun (after it's fired???) - I won't harp on this point, there's a bunch of videos discussing Starfield gun design.

Pros
- Beautiful visuals
- Zero G is fun
- When you stumble upon a unique quest in a custom made area/design it's good.
- Some of the world building was really good, the starborn storyline was good.
Cons
- Something is missing. Planets are empty.
- Copy and pasted points of interest.
- Repeat interactions with space pirates/space police which get really repetitive
- Load screens on top of loadscreens - one of the best parts of Skyrim was you could walk from Whiterun to Dawnstar and all the along the way points of interest, beautiful vistas, quests etc. Starfield you have to loadscreen from city to city.

Maybe i hyped this game up to much...and while there were parts that were good, Starfield didn't live up to the potential it has.

To this day i revisit the Starfield steam page hoping something comes along that 'fixes' it....i feel this day will never come.

Just finished up a few dozen hours in Starfield and honestly, I’m impressed. The game nails that feeling of stepping into a massive universe where every corner hides a new story or discovery. The mix of space exploration, ship customization, and on-foot missions kept things feeling fresh, and the level of detail in some of the planets is just stunning. Sure, it’s a Bethesda game so you get the occasional odd bug, but it never pulled me out of the experience. Abominable, reprehensible, and utterly nauseating—Bethesda Softworks has plumbed new depths of ignominy with Starfield, a game so deplorable it stands as a monument to their creative destitution and morally bankrupt ethos. This interstellar travesty is a perilously hollow experience, plagued by monotonous gameplay, glitch-riddled systems, and a narrative so vapid it insults the intelligence of its players. Yet, the true horror lies not in its technical failures but in the vile, stomach-churning behavior of Bethesda’s developers, whose reprehensible conduct in mocking the tragic assassination of Charlie Kirk—a real human being slain in an act of political violence—evokes nothing short of visceral disgust.The sheer audacity of Bethesda’s now-deleted X post, showcasing a Starfield character sneering about “fascists” while petting a creature with the caption “good kitty,” is an affront to human decency. Timed mere days after Kirk’s brutal murder, this grotesque stunt reveals a studio so steeped in moral turpitude that it would exploit real-world tragedy for cheap, ideological provocation. The thought of such callous, inhumane behavior—celebrating a man’s death in front of his family—makes my stomach roil with revulsion. Bethesda’s frantic deletion of this evidence only underscores their cowardice, a futile attempt to evade accountability for their perilous depravity.The developers’ actions reflect a broader pattern of contemptuous disregard for the sanctity of human life, transforming Starfield from a mere game into a loathsome vessel for their odious worldview. Every loading screen, every clunky space battle, feels tainted by the knowledge that this studio revels in such despicable mockery. To engage with this game is to wade through a miasma of ethical rot, a prospect so sickening it induces nausea. Bethesda’s hubris has birthed a product that is not only technically deficient but morally execrable, a shameful blight on the gaming industry.Spare yourself the torment of this detestable creation. Boycott Starfield and shun Bethesda’s forthcoming releases, lest you lend credence to a developer whose behavior is so beyond disgusting it defies comprehension. Let them wallow in the disgrace of their own making, a cautionary tale of how hubris and inhumanity can render even the most ambitious projects utterly repugnant.Rating: 0/10

I have been a longtime fan of Bethesda. Fallout 3, Skyrim, etc. Their games meant a lot to me. But I can’t stay silent about what’s happened these last few days — and I refuse to give another penny to a company that seems to be condoning or participating in something so vile.

What’s happened:

Charlie Kirk was assassinated on September 10, 2025, while speaking at Utah Valley University. Authorities are calling this a political assassination. 

In the wake of this, there have been extremely hurtful, cruel, and inflammatory reactions from people online, accusing him of racism, fascism, or worse. Some reactions seem to treat his murder as if it were justified. Whether or not you agree with his politics, this is dangerous territory. 

Most disturbingly, a Bethesda video clip was posted (on what appears to be their official account or closely connected account) that seems to mock the situation. The clip shows the lead character in Indiana Jones and the Great Circle petting a cat and saying, “You don’t care much about these fascists, do you?” after the assassination. That is deeply irresponsible. 

The post was later deleted, but deleting doesn’t erase the harm or the message being sent. Silence feels like consent. And for people like me who are now worried for their safety, being publicly smeared (called fascist or worse) could feel like a justification, for some, for violence.


Why I’m done:

A company should be able to separate its entertainment and politics, or at least handle political content responsibly. When an official account appears to mock a murder across ideological lines, that crosses a moral line.

I no longer feel safe supporting Bethesda. If they can tacitly support or make light of someone’s killing over their beliefs, then nothing feels off-limits.

Trust is broken. Respect is lost. Once you allow this sort of content (or response) from devs or associated with your brand, it changes the relationship.


Before this, I was willing to forgive or overlook small missteps. Not this time. Bethesda has shown that they are not just makers of games, but are willing to sign off on or allow extremely damaging, divisive, and possibly dangerous messaging. I will be boycotting anything connected to Bethesda from now on. I urge others who feel similarly to consider doing the same — sometimes money is the only language big companies understand.

Starfield – where do you even begin? This was meant to be the next era for Bethesda. It launched to warm reviews, but was later torn apart by both media and players. Once again, Bethesda has done what they’ve been doing for the past decade: delivering not a perfect game, but a controversial one – and Starfield is absolutely that.

It struggles with issues even Bethesda games haven’t suffered from as much before: loading screens between planets, atmospheres, space, and even houses. This is the most common criticism I hear about Starfield, and it’s not wrong – it can be tough to sit through. But once I started playing differently, only fast traveling from the cockpit and using the UI sparingly, I discovered another side of the game.

When the game forces you to walk through cities and actually explore the handcrafted environments, it becomes fascinating. From New Atlantis with its futuristic feel, to Akila City with its western vibes, and Neon which evokes Cyberpunk and Blade Runner – every location has its own soul. And when you slow down, you start to notice just how much handcrafted content the game hides around every corner.

Starfield is a sandbox. If you go in expecting to rush between quests (and fast travel everywhere) in search of a tightly scripted story, you’ll be disappointed. Starfield thrives when you create your own adventure and use a bit of imagination to fill in the gaps. It was never an easy game for Bethesda to market, but I’d argue they actually marketed it too broadly – and to the wrong audience.

And like all Bethesda games, mods are central. You don’t need them, but they let you shape the experience, either limiting or expanding features to fit your playstyle. If you’re looking for seamless spaceflight from system to planet, Starfield isn’t the game for you. But if you’re after a sandbox that offers interaction, world-building, and adventure in a spacefaring setting – then you might just be in the right place.

Writing is generally good, with the faction mission arcs being the highlight. Side content in my experience has the largest gradient in quality, from one off meaningless interaction to an intriguing plot arc. Gunplay is very satisfying, melee not so much.

User interface is the biggest complaint as well as the outpost and crew management side of things, all minimum viable products. Character progression is quite slow unless you optimise your difficulty settings for an xp boost and remember to sleep before leaving your ship.
