I wrote this in 2025 after seeing if anything in this hunk of junk has changed. Been playing Bethesda games since 2003, modding them since 2004. I say this to establish that I have nothing against Bethesda. I am, in fact, a big fan. I love the usual flavor, freedom and even the jankiness that comes with your standard Bethesda title. This one is different. This one lacks the charm. It could stand to lose half the content, half the price, focus on ship building and combat, and with a few mod-sized changes, be marketed as a space pirate simulator quite successfully. 

Why this game isn't good:

While ship building, combat, and similar aspects of the game are pretty great, the rest of the game is like trudging through a desert devoid of interest with added intermittent load times and transition animations. Seriously, average 5 minute game play experiences may include around 1-3 minutes of slow unskippable transitional animations, pestering long-winded-even-if-you-skip-every-line dialogue interruptions, and stuff like trying to figure out why your quest target won't interact with you. If you're not doing that, you're either building something or doing the same combat with the same enemies in the same bunker in 1 of like 4 biomes. 
The main game play is grindy and mostly unsatisfying. After a while, I had to use mods and use console commands to make it fun. The story seems like it was PURELY built around the fact that they want you to do basically the same thing again in NG+ like the story was SOOOO much fun the first time. Hey, you wanna play the game where the point of the game is to play it again but with sprinkles this time, be my guest. That's a weird loop. I don't care if some of the characters (that I didn't care about in the first place) act a little different, or if loot is in a different place, or if the tedious, pseudo-philosophical dialogue has a different flavor. NPC's are either hollow, flat characters or they're a cliche archetype who might as well be a cardboard cutout with a speakerphone attached-- very few compelling characters, but to give them credit, it seems well voice-acted. 
The amount of useful item diversity, including weapons, armor, etc. is seriously lacking considering you've got a large portion of a galaxy to draw from. You'd think there'd be regional variants on things, specializations and stuff, but instead, its usually like 5 base models of spacesuits that have slightly different stats that seem balanced by a live service game manager rather than built from the lore or whatever (seriously the stats on some of this stuff seems randomly assigned or to be "fair" and in doing so made everything feel cheap and unsatisfying and immersion-breaking. It's rare you'll get a nice, handy weapon, usually they're trash. Useful gun types are common, but they're still not great unless they're legendary, so even the good guns don't feel like they add to diversity, its just that you now have a real gun. It's like being thirsty while stranded a small boat on the ocean. Water, water, everywhere, and not a drop to drink. 
Vanilla game still experiences classic Bethesda soft-locks from unresponsive NPCs, quest targets not responding, and general CTD style catastrophes. 

The universe itself is pretty! At a glance. They did a mostly good job on pretty much anywhere you have to go for the main quest. All major settlements look great, even though they kinda feel like mostly empty or useless space. They're either too small, or really spread out but have a similar amount of interest. Most curious explorations of urban environments was pretty, but upon inspection becomes underwhelming. Everything looks really good, on the surface, but start to pay attention and it all looks like it was cut by laziness, cost or engine limitations. If you want to swim but can't afford a swimming pool, a wading pond isn't gonna cut it. Maybe they were trying to impress the neighbors. Procedurally generated worlds all feel like the same flavors of "ugh." Even when you find a landmark its pretty sad and underwhelming. 

It's not charming like Skyrim was, even on launch. Skip this one unless you really need to play all the Bethesda games or if you really like building and flying sci-fi spaceships. Some really good mod content exists for this game as of posting. check the reviews for shattered space dlc for more details there, haha!

TL:DR Yes its worth playing once but its replayabilty is soured by being forced.

Starfield is fun and engaging with a lot to offer solo players. Level 200+, unlocked and maxed all powers, stopped counting my Unity runs after 14. (screwed up and didn't unlock every power my first few runs) There are many worlds to explore and replay is fun, however there are some glaring issues with the core endgame mechanic.

To fully unlock and maximize your characters powers, you will need to go through unity no less than 10 times. This is a lot of forced replays just to achieve max power levels. But maxing out becomes about a 100 hour chore even with skipping tremendous amounts of content each unity run. This is separate from character leveling which is also a fairly heavy grind. It wouldn't be so bad if you could take a single ship through the unity. I understand why you can't and it makes sense in game. But there is a strong focus on ships, crew building, and customizing. You get a decent ship called the Starborn Guardian but it rapidly becomes Meh as each unity playthrough progresses. It is very clear, that a custom built ship is the absolute best way to go. However crafting an endgame ship takes time and effort to achieve because the parts are located behind missions and all across different vendors in the galaxy. Having a forced game cycle of rebuilding and destroying a ship that takes hours to construct is beyond obnoxious. 

It feels like the Unity gameplay/leveling mechanic is a terrible idea for an intricate spaceship building game. Or an intricate spaceship building mechanic is a terrible idea for a game with a mechanic like unity. I'm not spending an extra 20 hours per play through hunting out the best vehicle parts all across the galaxy because it turns into a hate filled chore. 

Starfield is beautiful, and empty. Much like the real universe. Which at times is exactly what you want. But there is so much empty on every one of its planets that exploration becomes tedious and unenjoyable. Especially after your 8th or 9th play through collecting/leveling powers.

Starfield is a fun game to play through one or two times but forcibly chokes itself out. Play it to just enjoy the universe and story woven. Otherwise the "over and over-ness" of unity will ruin it for you.

PS... 
That little squiggly button that disables achievements being one hit and done is problematic. Went a long time not getting achievements because of not noticing this. Once realized, out of shear achievement FOMO, loaded a previous save. Lost over 100 levels at the time. Don't have a fix or helpful suggestion, just wanted to say it's icing on stale cake.

The game has all the parts to be great- base building, tons of voice acted content, good visuals, exploration, botany, geology, gun and suit modding. You can even board ships and take them over!
HOWEVER: most of the gameplay loops are broken in some way, making you lose interest after putting too much time into the game, but also somehow not enough. 

Example: You can capture ships in space, but they are "unregistered" meaning you can't sell them until you register them. Then when you sell, you net like 2k credits. absurd. You should be able to go to a pirate station and get a randomly generated mission where you get your ship registered, or create forged credentials so you can pirate and sell ships for profit.

You can build bases and even mine and manufacture everything you need, including animals and plants. However, there's no sorting device that sends resources into a specific crate. Also the storage that links to your ship inventory is tiny and you can only use it to access what's actually in it-when it should give you access to all the linked storages in the settlement.
Basically, to create a functioning manufacturing base, you have to create some insane network of stations that's akin to a youtuber's minecraft computer- it's crazy frustrating. 

It needs some major QOL improvements designed by someone who has actually played the game.
If you like space, RPG and good gunplay, you will love this. It's definitely not without flaws, but since I love Bethesdas games and space sci-fi, I have a great time.

I had high hopes for Starfield but somehow Bethesda made a Universe of Possibilities into an incredibly shallow experience. I'll keep playing because the combat isn't too bad and there are some interesting ideas, but neither are as fully fleshed out as you'd expect a game with 10 years of development to have; mods can fix the combat AI being very dumb, but no mods exist (so far) that can help the story. There's an inbuilt reset button but they still refuse to let you make a mistake, outside of a couple (I can actually only think of one) side-quests the most won't even engage with. The game is the most on rails of any Bethesda game I've ever played and yet they expect you to do it 10 times to actually complete all the powers (shouts); it's not very fun and repeats itself even if you don't do the NG+, but if you just want a game that you can turn your brain off and coast it's alright for awhile... can't recommend it though.

I have been playing Starfield for a long time and so far my experience has been quite good. The game has very beautiful randomly generated landscapes. You can explore quite a bit and kind of get sucked into the beauty. The controls are quite good and it feels like Freelancer in space, however, I feel Freelancer had a lot better sound track and the environmental sounds in space were really cool. As for Starfield, if you like FPS and want to explore on planets and you want to fight in space, then it is great. As for the depth in space, it is quite shallow. Also, the game has a ton of bugs, for example, game objects bouncing around, NPCs getting stuck, items you placed in your home base falling into tables, etc... The game does play nicely and the story is interesting, but it is quite short and you then get stuck in a loop of universes as a member of the Starborn race. I would say the game has tons of potential, but it is not worth the $69.99. It is worth $19.99, not unless additional effort goes into making the game a long-term gem. However, I would not miss out playing Starfield though, since it may capture you like it did me but wait for a discount.

I also often people say the planet feel barren but when you on NG+ 5-6 you glad the planets dont have 100+ fauna and flora or you would spend days scanning one planet. 

I personally Love this game and recommend it for people who love space and the ability to explore all possible choices.

I don't agree with the overall opinion on the rating of the game, but I can understand a lot of the frustrations other players have. The planets feel dead most of the time unless there is a designed city/location - however if you go outside of the city the planet doesn't offer all that much in terms of exploration. I miss the handcrafted design of games like Oblivion, Skyrim, Fallout, etc. and that is where my biggest gripe is with the game.

The travel mechanic feels dull at times when comparing it to No Man's Sky (which may be unfair), but as that game is 9 years old - it's hard not to compare the space travel/exploration vs Starfield's loading screens.

However the game play is pretty solid, some of the story is really cool with Starborn and the endgame loop is interesting. I do enjoy the perk system and weapon combat but i would like to see more unique weapons and impactful legendaries such as with Fallout/Elder Scrolls unique gear.

Overall i'd probably throw it a 7. I still think it's enjoyable but it does need some improvement with the expansions.

super mid not worth the money

With over 1200 hours in Starfield, I can honestly say it’s the game I keep coming back to. The sheer variety of storylines and side quests continues to entertain me, even after completing the game 23 times. There’s always something new to discover, especially with Creations.

The gameplay is excellent across the board, whether deep in a firefight, piecing together a new ship design, or setting up an outpost on some far-off world. I also REALLY appreciate that the game isn’t filled with constant explicit language.

Another huge plus is the freedom of choice. Being able to shape the kind of character I want to run through is a big reason why the game never grows stale for me. Add to that the Creations system, expand the game with new quests, locations, or immersive tweaks like fuel requirements or ledgers and the replay value just keeps extending for me.

The only part I’ve avoided is Shattered Space. For me, it strayed from the tone that made the base game so enjoyable, forcing a character setup to launch the quest and leaning heavily into horror. It just didn’t feel like the same Starfield I’ve come to love. That said, I’m hopeful future DLC returns to the spirit of the core game.

I know Starfield has received its share of criticism, but to me it’s Bethesda’s best work to date. I may be in the minority, but I’m more than happy to stand by it. For me, it’s brilliant—and I’ll keep exploring its universe as long as it lets me.

Ah yes, Starfield, the game that promised a universe of endless exploration and delivered… entire galaxy’s worth of cargo holds filled with potatoes and stolen coffee mugs.

After spending hours naming my spaceship “USS Midlife Crisis,” I embarked on a grand journey across over 1,000 planets, 998 of which appear to have been handcrafted by a particularly uninspired algorithm with a fetish for rocks.

Gameplay:
It's like Skyrim... IN SPACE. Which means I spent most of my time crouch-walking behind Spacers and aliens, pickpocketing them, and launching them into low orbit with a poorly-timed shotgun blast. The combat feels tight, if by “tight” you mean “occasionally functional and almost never graceful.”

Inventory management is peak Bethesda  within 10 minutes of starting, I was encumbered by three space helmets, a dozen sandwiches, and a priceless alien artifact I forgot I picked up while looting someone's dresser for no reason.

Story:
You're a miner who touches a rock and suddenly becomes the Chosen One, which is very different from being the Dragonborn or The Courier or That Guy Who Took an Arrow to the Knee. The main plot is a philosophical sci-fi odyssey full of mystery, wonder, and the deep existential question: Why does everyone walk like they’re wearing invisible diapers?

Companions:
Your crew includes a man named Barrett who talks like your overly-friendly HR rep, and Sarah, who has all the charisma of a sentient IKEA instruction manual. Romance options exist, but if awkwardly flirting with polygonal coworkers is your thing, might I recommend real-life LinkedIn?

Exploration:
Todd Howard said you could land anywhere on any planet. He didn’t mention that most of them feel like dusty desktop wallpapers with gravity. Still, there’s a weird joy in touching down on a lifeless rock just to mine aluminum or as Americans say, “uh-LOO-mih-num” and immediately question all your decisions.

Bugs:
Yes, they’re still here. Glitches are a core feature of Bethesda’s charm. I once saw a pirate T-pose through my ship’s hull mid-dogfight and ascend into the stars like some kind of space prophet. It was beautiful. I cried.

Final Verdict:
If you love Skyrim, Fallout, and loading screens, Starfield is the space sandbox for you. Just don’t expect Mass Effect levels of depth, and maybe bring a podcast for when you're scanning space rocks for the sixth hour straight.

I was really looking forward to this game, and as soon as it was released, I bought it shortly after. But it turned out to be such a disappointment for me that I uninstalled it pretty quickly. Still, I gave it several more chances, but always ended up feeling the same, until the spring of 2025, when I decided to give it one more try.

This time, I let go of the urge to understand everything right away, and at some point, I crossed that psychological threshold in the playthrough that I hadn’t been able to before. I suddenly felt completely absorbed, captivated, I couldn’t put it down.

I realized that what had bothered me before was my own expectations. But now, I started to understand the story, I could relate to the characters, and an entire universe opened up before me. Planets and star systems were waiting to be explored.

I know some parts of the game are unnecessarily complex, and there’s a lot to keep track of. Not just the skill tree, but ship-building, faction dynamics, and even how different planetary populations react differently to your character. Still, all things considered, it was an incredible journey among the stars, and my heart was longing for a fresh start.

Unfortunately, I didn’t make it all the way to the end, as work took priority and the game had to be put on hold. According to my mission log, I only had one quest left, which I do regret. At this point, I’d only go back to see how it ends after the fact, since I had to stop the adventure back in June.

I bought this game when it first released.  I fell for the hype like most people did.  Skyrim in space?  Yes, please.  I played for maybe 30-40 hours and just kind of quit playing.  I forgot about this game for a long time, until I recently built a new computer and wanted to give it another chance.  Maybe I missed something?  Maybe I need to give it more time to see if it's worth playing?

I can say, now at 233 hours of game time, I'm fed up.  

This game has been out long enough for them to have fixed at least *some* of the bugs, but my lord, the bugs are still there.  Game-breaking, mission-ruining, absolutely exhausting bugs are everywhere.  Don't even think about trying bounty hunting.  Once you identify a bounty, you're done.  You can't do anything about them.  If you kill them, you fail.  If you incapacitate them, they lay there a while then get back up and fight.  If you leave and come back, it *might* reset them to non-hostile, but you still can't do anything.

Oh and the game crashes a LOT.  I'm officially quitting trying to get this game to be fun due to the last crash that randomly occured about 20 minutes after my last save.  There's never a reason, never a report, it just crashes.

If the other bad reviews for this game haven't quite done there job of convincing you to save your money, I hope mine does.  This game is a very, very unpolished turd that Bethesda seems to have quit on.
I am at two and a half hours in this game, and I just want that time back.

Story-(3/10)
Starfield does not have an amazing story or any thing super memorable but it's fun. 

Gameplay-(7/10)
Starfield plays like an upgraded Fallout 4 but it's still not anything impressive. It is fun to go around as a Space Cowboy. 

Characters-(3/10)
No one is really memorable outside of Andreja who is mostly loved by fans and Sarah who will nag you to death. Then you have the Hunter who is who you might become depending on how you play. Other than that, everyone else is mostly forgettable. 

Soundtrack-(8/10)
Typical Bethesda game, Great soundtrack. 

Game Length-(6/10).
I find the game a little short. The only thing that keeps me playing Starfield's NG+. With Starfield, NG+ is cannon to the story and a continuation of things. I have never seen this done in a game before. What's sad is the best part of the game is the end, which many players don't make it to because of the forgettable characters and story up until that point. Iv'e done NG+ over a dozen times and continue to do so. [spoiler] NG+ allows you to play the game again with the knowledge of your previous playthrough. Think of it like a Groundhog Day scenario. You are just reliving the same story over and over again [/spoiler]

Difficulty-(7/10)
Just like any other Bethesda game, Starfield is not difficult. It's simple combat and not much of a grind. But still really fun nonetheless. 

Grind-(NA/10)
Depends on your goal but you will be doing mostly questing and exploring. Everything is easy to acquire.

Graphics-(8/10).
The game has good graphics but most of the time you will not be blown away. 

Audio-(10/10)
No complaints and no issues. 

Price-(7/10)
I think the price is a bit steep for the content but on sale it's worth every penny. 

Bugs-(8/10)
Starfield is probably the most bug free Bethesda game. With that being said, they are still present. I guess thats part of the Bethesda charm at this point. 

Audience-
For a typical Open world enjoyer. The game is not a masterpiece but enjoyable none the less. 

Overall-(7/10)
Starfield is a fun experience but it will not blow you aways like Fallout New Vegas, Oblivion, or Skyrim. If it were not for NG+ I would not have as many hours as I do in Starfield but with it's current state, I have no regrets.

I realized I never left a review for this game!
So here goes.

Starfield... is the definition of modern game-slob. Everything to become great is there but nothing is designed in a way to have any depth.
You're constantly left with the feeling of 'that's it?'

Leveling is atrociously designed, gating content behind it non-stop. Want to not die all the time in space? Better ensure you've taken the license to fly a decent ship as otherwise you got exactly 0 options to survive when pirates actually come!
But no worries, there's loads of areas to explore, after all it's got over a thousand planets, right?
All of them are basically identical, more so then No Man's Sky in 1.0 was. I think 5 or so randomly generated meaningful places which repeat ad nauseum, with generic loot, generic enemies and generic nothingness inside.

So is the hand-crafted aspect better? The story? The side-quests?
No, not even remotely. Back in the times of Morrowind there were interesting unique scenarios. Starfield offers half-assed boring crap. The main story is really lackluster. There are no stakes at all. Side-missions are all pre-set solutions without proper choice... and if you got em? They have exactly zero meaning going forward, a miniscule change in what's displayed at best.

Ship building? Could've been great! But it's gated by myriads of nonsense, the majority has no meaning and the physics engine will throw around your decorations willy-nilly anyway so it'll stay fully generic.

The biggest variety the game offers is in food items... which are all looking interesting! And all do the exact same 'give back 5 health' thing so any meaning of variety is immediately thrown out the window.

Crafting materials are sorted into categories, instead of getting them you get random crap which has a category attached, making it nigh impossible to keep proper track.

Pinning stuff? Why should we keep track?

Changing locations? Better have 5 minutes of time at hand solely to do that since you'll go through several loading screens and unskippable animations.

Base building? Even if you unlock it you can simply buy everything you want from traders what you would need dozens of hours of barely functional menues to set up... and which then has no use-case anymore as that was already the end-line.

In total:

This game is shit. I'm not often saying this about a game, I usually point out the flaws to mention how something can be made better.... but this one? This had everything to be good... but nothing was finished.
It's simply one of the least worthwhile experiences on the gaming market, and for the still high price-tag of 70€ you're better off buying several trash-games which each offers 5 hours of fun for being trash then buying this 'AAA' game that shoves being beyond mediocre into your face from the start.

You hope it gets more after you start? No, it never does. The first 3 hours is what the whole game is, there is nothing more, you've seen all it has to offer, all other stuff is added on is solely the same thing in another package or side-mechanics which are unfinished.
This type of game-design should be considered a scam actually... sadly it is not.

I'll start with brutal honesty: it's a buggy mess, like all Bethesda games (specifically, my biggest bugs happened during Matters of the Hart, Brownout, and the beginning of the Freestar Ranger questline). When it first came out, I riffed on it endlessly without giving it a fair shake. After playing, however, I really enjoyed it! The writing had me hooked from the very start, and the New Game+ mechanic added a really fun element of surprise. Ship building is by far one of my favorite aspects of the game, and you'll find lots of fun ways to configure your ship. Though there are only 4 main/romanceable companions, I found all of them to have engaging storylines that made me enjoy bringing them on missions and completing each of theirs. Combat and movement feels smooth, though I will say I'm not a player of mainstream shooters. I would also recommend adjusting cursor/joystick sensitivity for optimal targeting. I especially enjoyed fights in zero g and felt Bethesda's engine really captured the "feel" of what it would be like to navigate areas with different gravitational fields.

TL;DR: if you're expecting to play this game like your average shooter, I would say this game isn't for you, but if you liked Bethesda's writing style, storylines, and combat in Skyrim and Fallout 4, I would recommend giving Starfield a shot.

The world, the writing and the lack of the Bethesda charm and character had me very disinterested in the game after my 100 hours of playtime. After seeing videos for a mod called Genesis i was incredibly interested in downloading the game and using the mod pack to explore a game that never was. Even with my renewed interest i was devastated to see the new TOS, that you are required to accept to play the game, removes all right to ownership of the game.

I spent my hard earned money, that i traded time away from my family for, to buy this game. Sacrificing my physical, mental and emotional well being in the name of capitalism, and the ruling class won't even let me own the digital copy of a game i bought.

I can't recommend this game or any other game that removes consumer rights and protections in the name of shareholders greed.

[h1] TL:DR Ticks many boxes [/h1]

In the beginning I played Space Invaders in the arcade. Years later I played Elite on a BBC B home computer in 1984.

Space. If it’s so big why are there griefers, pirates, killer aliens and loading screens everywhere?

Freelancer. Eve Online. Many versions of Elite. No Man’s Sky. FTL. Stellaris. X4. Space Rangers.

[b]To infinity and beyond[/b]

There’s no perfect Space game. They all have something missing. Something I would add.
Starfield might be the closest to my ideals, my needs. My desire to do whatever I want.

Let’s check some of the requirements/ attributes on the list:
[list]
[*]A universe to explore with an interesting back story, space, systems and planets
[*]Ships to buy or construct yourself. Hull, shields, fuel, cargo space, habitat modules, colour schemes
[*]Guns, armour, helmets, aid, lockpicking. Booster packs. Zero gravity spaces.
[*]Piracy, Bounty Hunting, Missions, Aliens, Landing on Planets
[*]Character Development, skills, relationships. Oxygen consumption.
[*]Shooter, looter, research, your own home base of ops
[*]Base building, home purchasing, companions, romance, parents, adoring fan
[/list]

[b]Bethesda[/b]
The first Beth game I played was called Gridiron back in 1986. 
However, they grabbed my soul through Arena, Daggerfall, Morrowind etc. 
It’s the freedom. The first-person perspective. To go wherever I want and do whatever I wanted. 
Starfield continues that path. 

***************
I land my ship on a huge platform in the middle of an ocean. It’s called Neon City. 
I cross the long bridge and enter the city. Talk to some people. Go through this door, climb some stairs. Left and right. Continue my mission. I look over the platform, the edge, and see my bloody ship far below. I swear I can jump down to it.
***************

[b]The Community[/b]
As with these games since MW, the players make the game better or help you play the way you want. Most developers don’t do this. In Oblivion I made a simple mod that made hand to hand combat more viable.

My fav mods in Starfield now:
a) one that allows you to register ships very cheaply so that piracy and selling ships becomes a real option
b) one that helps you locate a base building location with added materials and a guide

You want more guns, more ships, harder combat, more missions, instant character creation…

[b]To Infinity and Beyond[/b]

One of the problems with Oblivion, Skyrim etc is that there is a lot of content. You won’t see it all. But you can forge your path. For me, it’s hardly ever the main path.

575 hours into Starfield now I am appreciating it more. I notice things I never did before. I think the planets in systems move.

[b]Frustrations[/b]

Beth have fixed some of the probs such as loading screens and provided vehicles to promote travelling on planets. They have provided maps to prompt faster travelling within cities. 

Something is missing though. A reason to explore. 

In Fallout 4, Oblivion and Skyrim you knew if you headed out in a direction something will find you. Is that true in Starfield?

I would suggest something like F4 outpost development and building. The settlements. A storyline encouraging you to build and connect communities.

I would also add a proper trading system where merchant roleplaying/ mining was an option.

[b]Summary[/b]

Starfield is nearly there. Just a few more light years. Just one more system to jump into.

I don’t believe ship building was intended to be in the final game but someone high up must of realised the game was looking terrible and they added it in.

Beth. Listen. Adapt. Create and Improve.

As a big fan of open world exploring space settings, I really tried to love this game and played it quite a bit, but there are many issues that hold me back when I want to play and stop me from starting it again.

The Side Quests: Most sidequests are simple: retrieve this item, kill this pirate, or go through this generic dungeon and find XY. It's totally boring after you've played it for some time.

The Main Quests: The main story feels rushed and lacks depth. Quests start to get interesting but then abruptly end without payoff. The artifact hunting becomes tedious - it's the same formula repeated across different planets with minimal variation.

Exploration: Despite being set in space with 1000 planets, exploration feels hollow. Most planets are barren procedurally generated landscapes with copy-pasted points of interest. The constant loading screens between areas kill any sense of seamless space exploration I was hoping for.

Dont buy, wait for other titles in this genre to pop up.

I won't talk about how it looks or performs, because ultimatly, all that doesn't matter if the story and or gameplay isn't any good.

Starfield starts out like any open world Bethesda game: You're a nobody, chosen for greatness, sucked into an adventure and the first few hours all is fine. The universe feels vast, you get a cool spaceship that makes spaceship noises and the story seems interesting enough. After the initial discovery and wonder the game quickly becomes very bland and boring. 

For me, the crafting mechanism is useless and so overcomplicated that it's just not worth doing. Because of this inventory management boils down to constantly filtering out useless trash to avoid becoming overencumbered. 

The different weapon types, despite some nifty laser 'pew pew' effects don't really make that much difference or feel that exciting to use. 

It feels very much like they added stuff for the sake of having a lot of stuff rather than focusing on having a diverse amount of good stuff that impacts playstyle and gameplay options. The same goes for the sidemissions and the planets in general. 

Even the choises you make are basicly not that important; yes one person will give you more cash and the other one will throw in a fancy hat, whoopty doo. 

I just didn't care about what I was doing or why anymore and just felt like I was going through the motions playing the game more out of boredom rather than actual interest. Kinda like watching some dumb realty tv show on the tv while actually browsing my phone. As soon as you turn it of, you really don't remember what you actually did. Utterly forgettable. 

So in conclusion: In an age with new games coming out dayly, fighting for your precious and limited time on this planet, this one should not be concidered. This game would the oatmeal of games, if it had nutritional value. Maybe dlc can add something interesting down the line but with the writing team that made the main game, I wouldn't hold my breath.

+ you can role play as a space trucker - to make money as a hauler, or..

+++ have to edit - I forgot to add that you can also create your own outpost on any Planet !! - you can build and design to your hearts content and have your companions live with you.

you also have Quest Line of Main Story - you can ignore it or do it, lots of different faction you can join with countless of hours to sink into. its amazing.  sure this game may have added some controversial stuff, but just like in real life..  I IGNORE THEM, and thank god this game is not shoving anything in my face.

I've been gaming since Wolf3D and overall give Starfield a 7 out of 10.      I feel this game gets so much hate because of a lack of perspective.....

While I do agree with many that it was a mistake for them to use the same engine that was used to make Skyrim, however, players need to compare a fresh install of Skyrim vs Starfield.       It is stupid amazing how much they were able to push such a outdated engine....

Much of the hate towards this game comes from the loading screens.     I truly don't understand this complaint.     First, if your playing on a laptop, that's on you.   I don't care if it's a "gaming" laptop.   Second, I don't recall to much fuse over Skyrim and loading screens for Cities, Caves, Houses, Ect....    FarCry had a few loading screens, Half-Life had out of nowhere mid map loading screens..      

So why is this a issue for Starfield?    Because it's a bigger game.     The loading screens are a necessary evil for several reasons, one being to make sure as many computers can run the game and to make sure your computer doesn't exploded from trying to load huge amounts of data\textures.        Don't get me wrong, I do think they could remove some of them.

All the plants are boring?    Keep in mind that Bethesda wanted to be as real as possible.....    Every planet in our own Solar System, is nothing but a barren boring rock.   Also, based of the time frame of  game events, the settled systems don't have enough people total to fill every planet, so of course there aren't many points of interest to explore on every planet.

Yes the combat is a bit lacking but this game's main purpose is not a action game but role playing game.   As the player you got to put yourself in the shoes of the miner your playing.   Don't rush the main story, explore the side quests, even ones that don't seem important in anyway.   Almost all of them are connected to the main story in one way or another.

Overall I believe the main reason why it seems this game is dead is actually because of the modders.    

Everyone knows Bethesda games are made with the expectations that the modding community will step in and keep things going with a steady flood of improvements.     Unfortunately due to various reasons that caused a bad reception upon release day.    Many modders have turned away from the game which is a bit sad because after you install a few good known must have mods, you quickly see how this game could only get better. 

To counter some of the bad reviews for this game..     Mods can solve the following issues, UI, shipbuilding, player exp curve per level, combat damage numbers, remove the mind numbing temple puzzle that has to be done way to much, all game stats, common game bugs, NG+ improvements.....    No different from playing Skyrim and people aren't hating on that game that has some of the same issues as Starfield.

I have been playing Bethesda Game Studios games since Fallout 3 (2008) and ever since then their games have scratched an itch for freedom, exploration and self expression that very few games have ever done for me. Starfield is no different to me even while I do believe Bethesda bit off more than they can chew with this ambitious title it's clear to me a lot of thought and effort was put into it. 

Starfield is by no means perfect, there are some elements, big and small from their previous titles that are not present, yet there a lot of aspects improved (specifically many of the roleplay criticisms from Fallout 4). And there gameplay features unique to it that could have been handled better (primarily space travel and planet exploration). I will admit that despite my enjoyment of this game. However, despite those issues, there is a lot this game does offer that makes it's worthwhile and even unique.

There is a plethora of things I could say about this game. I put many many hours into it across three different characters, yet I only finished the main quest with one, one character built for a completionist playthrough and I have say I was very fulfilled, taken back and honestly swept with a lot of emotion with the journey this game will take you on if you just give a shot, take your time and use a bit of your imagination.

Worth the journey into the unknown.

On a surface level this game appeared to check a lot of my boxes.
Bethesda style RPG in space? Completing sci-fi quests while flying through space, travelling the unknown in the name of science and exploring the cosmos? Customizing spaceships and managing a crew? Shooting bad guys? Awesome.

I really wanted this game to be Fallout in space, so bad. And I think that helped ruin my experience because this is nothing like those games. It would seem stupid to compare this game with the 10+ year old Fallout 4, but it's not even fair for starfield to compete against it. And fallout 4 isn't even that good. I would love to compare starfield to FNV which is even older and better than FO4 but that game was not made by Bethesda.

Anyways, after 5 hours of gameplay here are my thoughts. I have formatted this review in sections to talk about the parts of the game I was most excited for, and how I was completely let down in every way possible.

[h3] Space Travel: Nonexistent. [/h3]

Piloting/flying the spaceship through space is useless, unrewarding and not engaging whatsoever. Honestly completely useless. I would have honestly preferred no spaceships/flying whatsoever compared to the joke of an experience you get playing starfield.

The way you travel between galaxies/star systems is via this annoying menu with multiple layers, where you pick a star system and then choose a planet in the star system, then press x and you are magically teleported into orbit there. Once you arrive in orbit you have to go BACK into the same menu, click on the planet AGAIN, and press x to land there. Sometimes when you arrive in orbit there will be a random event where you might have to fly around a little to engage in combat with another spaceship. This is the most opportunity you will get in terms of being able to fly the spaceship around.

[h3] Story/characters: Boring. [/h3]

Doesn't matter what class of character or what background you choose for yourself, your story always begins in the same place under the same circumstances. The premise of the story is that you have to find these pieces of metal that have zero connection to you. You just happened to be in the right place at the right time to find a piece of metal and now have to go on 1000 identical boring fetch-quests to get more. There is no personal connection for the story to kickstart your emotional investment or any real reason to be doing what you are doing in the game. The characters aren't written very well and the voice acting is passable but not stellar. You can tell voice lines were all recording separately with little to no direction because conversations between NPC's have these odd exchanges where they sound they are reading lines instead of reacting to the other character's statements. That kills any sort of immersion in the game.

Basically the entire game in a nutshell: Use the menu to travel to a nearby star system, use the menu to choose a planet, use the menu to land. watch a cutscene to land. Get out of the ship, shoot a couple of guys, collect your little metal shard at the end of a cave, then use a menu to fast travel back to your ship. Use another menu to take off, watch a cutscene, and travel back to your little base, use the menu again to land, and deliver your metal shard and engage in boring conversation with boring characters about stuff that doesn't concern you in any way. Do this about 100 times and you have completed the game. Wow.

[h3] Pros? Not enough [/h3]

Graphics are nice enough and the game appears to be well optimized. I don't have stuttering or framerate issues which is a very nice change to my typical bethesda experience. Gunplay is good enough. Lots of variety in weapons and customizations. I would want to mention the spaceship building/customization here but you never really get to use the thing, so what is the point of customizing it?

[h3] Digster's rating? [/h3] 

5/10.

If you really want to try it, buy it on sale. At least 50% off, preferably more. Not worth the AAA price tag.

I will most likely play a few more hours before giving up on this game, and will edit the review accordingly if anything changes.

If you buy this expecting Fallout/Skyrim in space, prepare to be disappointed. The combat feels off, the crafting system is convoluted, the perk system honestly just sucks, and the ship building feels limited to its true potential

Don't get me wrong it is a good game, but...

Bethesda, for me, will never reach the peak that was Morrowind, where at the start, your only connection is Jiub and they immediately drop you off at the docks alone. Suggesting that you explore the beautiful world they spent designing, on your own schedule. With no obligation or scripted ties to anyone. Even if you follow its main quest, they still push you multiple times to go your own way, see the world, and become apart of it.

Starfield, again for me, is too heavy handed without doing anything truly unique apart from telling an okay story with a fetch mechanic based progression similar to skyrim in a highly detailed environment with fancy materials based off a modded version of fallout. 

Big negative for me was the fact that it was also plagued with mass real time procedural generation (which sucks a continuity of life from a world making everything seem arbitrary) with very little options in terms of making a unique part of space your own. 

Despite 23 years since that 3D open world formula was established it was somehow lost to time by the people who established it with a game of the year award.

This game, however, felt like the player was only there for the developers ride. Not good.

Locking a lot of content behind what i personally would describe as: the worlds longest intro quest (Im still not sure if i unlocked everything) i feel intentionally discards the charm with something being open world. When you constrain the player to these narrow metaphorical hallways, especially when they are littered with npcs randomly handing you the equivalent of a leaflet just for walking in proximity of them, it robs you of the experience and ultimately frustrates people. Like trader opening dialogue one shots when you're only goal was to quickly sell items and move onto the next thing.

The ship design and actual piloting of your ship is a wonderful addition sitting next to older games that built out the foundations this game sits on, but i feel its incomplete without a complimenting fully fleshed outpost building system. The signs of what made the budget is clearest here and it was not the bells and whistles for base modules. It feels weirdly taunting to have to raid places you know you'll never be able to build because of that restriction. I could see it being a point of contention to hate the game for some.

Another point of contention (some might have) is with the character creator, the constant moving of the characters head and face during editing makes me wish this trend would die, it makes it impossible to view the edges of the face and is a constant source of frustration especially when you're limited to editing with  2-3 sliders that change poorly described regions of the face.

A minor gripe with animations, which I'm sure on controller this game handles just fine in 3rd person, on mouse and keyboard your character is ice skating if you move the mouse while moving. Not to mention the entire bone chain for the  middle torso to lower abdominal region is nearly static when turning and has little to no movement, until you strafe. It looks great on npc's but when your character is the main focus of the screen in 3rd person its hard not to notice. 

After all these complaints I'm sure whoever reads this far is wondering if there is anything i liked anything about the game.
Yes, There's a fair bit that i do like, but i don't think i would write anything at all if i didn't like the game.
After a few hours, it was boring and annoying (unfortunately too many to refund) and far too expensive.

With nearly 500 hours invested, I'm still finding myself genuinely surprised by the sheer amount of detail and effort that was put into this game.

I've never quite understood the harsh criticism the game has received. Since its release, it seems to have been met with mostly negative feedback, with some claiming it's "empty" or "lacks charm". From my experience, nothing could be further from the truth. Perhaps it's just me-or maybe expectations have shifted in a world where people want constant updates to stay entertained-but this game delivers in ways that truly matter.

Bethesda has given us the deep, emotionally grounded storytelling we loved in Fallout: New Vegas, 4 & 3. Combined with the intriguing POI reminiscent of Skyrim and other Elder Scrolls titles. Locations aren't just scenery; they tell stories without having to shout them, and the staggering attention to detail is what truly sets the game apart.

Starfield may not be everyone's cup of tea, and that's okay. But for me, it's exactly what I've always wanted from a Bethesda experience-(Bugs and all)-a game that rewards exploration, immersion, and curiosity at every turn.

I'm also excited to see what the modding community will continue to bring. Bethesda games always shine when fans get creative. Future updates and DLCs have the potential to make Starfield even richer, and i Can't wait to see the universe expand in ways we haven't even imagined yet.

I will say, upon RETURNING to Starfield after its release, I feel pretty confident recommending it.

They have added enough to the game that I feel it has improved, and maybe I'm a clown for thinking that, but Idk honk honk I guess.

The gameplay settings are pretty god dang expansive in a way that I love, meaning you can crank up and down a bunch of settings to match your preferred playstyle. For me, I made my damage and enemy damage SUPER high, and cranked up the medical conditions severity, so combat feels very like... tarkov-like. (Not exactly but you know what I mean) 

With my settings, if you get the drop on a group of spacers you can take them all out with a few well placed headshots, HOWEVER, if someone gets the drop on me, I'm screwed. Which is kinda fun, makes guns feel more lethal.

Anyways thats just one setting, there are a ton to tailor the general gameplay. There are also a lot of QOL things added, as well as just missing features that have been patched in:
- Area maps
- buggy-type vehicle for planet exploration
- can fast travel out of many locations you couldnt normally
- Area maps
- Ability to target mission locations in your ship hud to fast travel there instead of going to the menu (Not a fix to the fast travel issue, but SLIGHTLY more immersive I guess? idk)
- AREA MAPS

The big thing is honestly the settings menu, it kind of re-defined my relationship with the game if Im being honest.

I mean, you cant fix the writing issues, but I feel confident saying that this game is no longer a COMPLETE miss. And on sale, I recommend it.

The Great

The ship building game loop of:
1. Use resources to upgrade ship
2. Get resources faster with upgraded ship
3. Repeat
Is one that I really enjoy. The game Reassembly is a 2d version of that and it's the only game I've gotten 100% of achievements for. I was looking for excuses to keep playing.
The NASA Punk aesthetic. Some people didn't like I but I'm a fan of the UI style.


The Meh

Gunplay is okay, I guess. The gun upgrading systems didn't grab me like Oblivion or Skyrim did.


The Bad

- I had some major side quest get derailed by a merchant NPC spawning somewhere far away in the sky, instead of in his shop.
- So many characters are unkillable, despite the story being very very amenable to having all characters be expendable. This makes the stakes feel lower and lamer for no reason.
- "Open World" but linear af main quest. The era of linear story lines or even branching story lines in video games needs to die. If I want to experience one I'll read a book or watch a movie. We can do better. Give me Dwarf Fortress world generation and history simulation with dynamic dialogue, organic factions, and conflicts that arise from the opposing goals and incentives of those factions and NPCs.

Starfield is so close yet so far from being the perfect Space RPG. No Man's Sky is rooted all throughout this game, which is great. NMS is still king in the Space genre, however NMS is way more about exploration than anything else. I have always wanted a more realistic take on NMS that has much more depth in its combat, both on foot and in your ship. Starfield is sort of an answer to this, but its lacking so much in other areas that it really keeps this game from being as amazing as it really could be. Engine limitations have hindered the space experience, there is no traveling in space, no flying between planets, no flying into a planet's atmosphere and landing wherever you want. A lot of this really does impact the overall experience and it makes me incredibly sad because there is a lot here that I like.

Which is why I am recommending it. A lot of people may disagree here, which is fine, but this is just how I feel and maybe some of you trying to decide whether to get the game will feel. The aspects here that are good, are great - for the most part - this is the first Bethesda game that feels good and smooth, not that much jank, gunplay is their best yet (which isn't saying much). I really love the aesthetic they got going here, the cities feel unique and very fantasy-like but in the context of sci-fi. The worlds do look beautiful, you'll find a lot of screenshot worthy planets. The gameplay loop is fun for a bit, but it does get repetitive rather quickly, however it doesn't change the fact that it is still addicting. Theres always more things to get or upgrade, or add to your arsenal. I do wish there was more human enemy types however. Its crazy how Halo Combat Evolved, a 20+ year old game still has some of the best enemy variety and AI to this day, and no one seems to take notes. 

Anyways, if you're looking to try out a realistic take on NMS, set in a Bethesda RPG world, with all the good and bad that comes with that, give this a shot. Thankfully, this isn't really a game that NEEDS mods, in fact there really isn't much mod support for the game since it died off pretty quickly. But don't let the hate pull you away from a game that you'll probably enjoy. But definitely get it on sale, $70 for ANY game is way too much.

What I enjoyed in this game:

+ building character
+ exploring new places (until the are not new anymore, you know, copy/pasted)
+ killing enemies and hoarding loot to sell it
+ having crew and all this mass-effect-like romantic vibes
+ main story is _not_bad_

I really enjoy roaming on the planet: killing fauna, gathering resources (no idea what for), reaching PoI, exploring PoE, finding magazines... could do this for hours and I did it for many hours.. it's fun.

What I dislike:

- everything else.

A detailed list:

- leveling is too slow paces, quest rewards are pathetic, constant lack of skill points;
- space combat is a big, stupid, and not fun mess
- ship require too many skill points otherwise any encounter is a stress
- ship builder is ugly, messy ship components scattered over the galaxy or needed to be unlocked, poor UI
- non-rewarding ship-capturing mechanic. their sell price is pathetic, on-ship loot/combat is pathetic
- poor quests, all of them, running from one point to another, talking, sneaking, sometimes fighting.. booooring
- NPC models are very similar, I think I've seen 10 brothers of that police officer from New Atlantis
- the map is annoying, even after 200 hours I hit esc to close it and instead it switches to a higher level map ><
- lack of QoL EVERYWHERE, from inventory, where I can't just drink/eat something, but need to go through huge non-filterable list to a map, where you can't just visit city, no, you need to remember all systems, planets, stations and manually navigate
- lots of bugs, small bugs, big bugs, 2 years-lasting bugs, I am sure there will be lots of 10-years lasting bugs too
- inventory management is really annoying after a while, no way to prevent accidental move/sell, lots of garbage, it's very poor inventory, from UI to automating common operations
- VERY stupid research and craft system, locked behind obtaining skill, which can be obtained by crafting and spending previous skill points, you got it
- there are numerous of powers in game, yet no way to use more than few of them comfortable, nor a way to track which one is active.. how many times I used the wrong power? How many times I had to click 5 buttons to just use rarely used power???
- the power system is very repeatable, poorly rewarding and way too farmy for maxing (hell, you need to collect powers, playing that stupid catch spark mini-game 240 times over the course of 10 full galaxy resets!), most of us going to play this freeking game once at most, many don't even finish it, not sure where Bethesda find their naive game designers
- quests: too many dialogues overall and too little action
- slow nonskipable animation, opening air-locked door, sitting/standing up, clicking NPC and waiting until it turn/stands up/whatever, following NPC in MANY quests
-the universe is full of garbage, most of pickable items you don't ever need, WHY making them pickable/show them in scanner?
- scanner (your the only tool to highlight items in this "gray"-pallette universe, where everything is dim and hard to see) is buggy, doesn't highlight all items, many actions are disable while scanner is active, I hate it, but there is no other way. I wish Bethesda devs play Borderlands games once
- environmental protection get SO MUCH annoying very quickly, no way to recharge it, in several quests it breaks all the immersion by beeping, dealing damage, causing debuffs
- poor DLC on top 

.. I could continue for much longer telling BAD things about this game. Basically on any good thing comes in package with 9 bad ones. UI is bad and lacking, QoL is non existent (the only good thing, thanks god, is an ability to press button in quest log to instantly show destination on the map, without it game would be a total nightmare).

Overall, it’s a AAA game that started off with big ambitions, but then they began cutting pieces out, and a lot of unfinished, poorly polished stuff was left by the time release came around. Dialogues with two different voices, conflicting UI elements, weird controls. It could’ve been a good game with another 10 years of development. As it is, it turned out to be something confusing, strange mixture of Mass Effect, No Man's Sky (or similar), Fallout. Now I just want to finish the achievements and forget it like a bad dream. No Man’s Sky is an order of magnitude better.

[h1]A Bethesda Game in Space[/h1]
Look, this is a Bethesda game in space. If you're familiar with the formula of games like [b]Fallout[/b] or [b]Skyrim[/b], [b]Starfield[/b] will not come as a surprise. The result, in the context of a massive sci-fi universe, is exactly what should have been expected. And honestly, I think a lot of the criticism it received was unfair.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Best and Worst of the Sandbox[/h2]
This is a game best played when you slow it down, but the game itself can make that hard. It can feel a bit overwhelming, and you might easily get confused by the sheer number of quests available. It's hard to know what's a unique, hand-crafted experience and what is just a repeatable chore. The mission boards, constant radiant quests, and the act of just surveying a planet all blur together. If you get caught up in doing only those things, you will get bored quickly and miss the real strengths of the game.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Where It Truly Shines[/h2]
However, the game truly shines in its rich, immersive side quests and the smooth first-person shooting. The beautiful aesthetics and overall theme are fantastic, and if you're willing to be a deliberate explorer and seek out those quests, you'll find incredible stories that feel both personal and rewarding. This is where the game's open sandbox design truly pays off. [b]Starfield[/b] becomes what you make of it—an intimate journey or a simple life as a scavenger.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Honest Truth About its Faults[/h2]
The game isn't perfect, of course. The main story, particularly the concept of the Starborn, is quite weak and feels unattached from the rest of the game. Many of the main characters are poorly written or just straight-up dull, making it hard to care about them. The simple act of helping a random NPC in a side quest can often lead to a much more meaningful interaction and story. I also understand the frustration with loading screens, especially when compared to other sci-fi games. They can become frequent, but they are still very short (only 2-3 seconds) and something you come to expect from a Bethesda title.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]The Final Verdict[/h2]
For those of you wondering, this is how I play games. I’m someone who loves immersion and roleplaying. I get rid of most of the UI and don't chase the meta build or the best gear. With that in mind, I also believe that mods shouldn't justify if a game is good or not, but they have become a standard part of the [b]Bethesda[/b] experience. They can make the game feel more grounded and give you control over your own play experience.

The core of a great [b]Bethesda[/b] game is here: beautiful design, immersive first-person gameplay, and a huge sandbox. I don't care about a company's reputation or what people say online; at the end of the day, I care about what's in front of me and how it feels to play. If you want a similar feel to previous [b]Bethesda[/b] titles, I would recommend giving it a chance.

I played Starfield when it first came out and I had a lot of issues it like everyone else.  I reinstalled it in summer 2025 and it was much better this time around.  I even enjoyed Shattered Space DLC.  The game is very open in how you play.  You don't need to build outposts or custom ships to play the game, they just add to the fun.  There are plenty of legendary weapons so you don't have to pursue the crafting tree if you don't want to, but crafting is fun as well.   I recommend just jumping in the game and pursing the faction quests.  The best way to level a character and make money is to do mission board quests.  Don't start with outpost building or surveying planets in the beginning as it can be tedious and feel like work.

I tried to enjoy it, I really did... But it's like they took everything that made Skyrim and Fallout 4 good and said "Let's do NONE of that."

The story feels very lazy and generic, like it wasn't anywhere near the top of the priority list.
The outpost system is entirely optional and basically useless. You spend dozens upon dozens of hours building a complex trade and manufacturing network across the galaxy, and then you NG+ and it's all been entirely wasted with nothing to show for it.
The companions are somehow more annoying than previous Bethesda games. Constantly standing in doorways(which is particularly annoying in the tight, confined areas of ships/stations), companions feeling useless in combat, being extremely picky and judgmental about every decision you make(look at you, Sarah Morgan. Being upset that I stole from pirates because the object was marked as stealing), and just overall being unfun to travel with.
The ship customization also feels like a major afterthought. Like it was thrown together when they realized the game had no redeeming qualities and thought that maybe customizable ships would help.

Overall, the entire game feels like they put as little effort as possible into it with the hope that the modding community would keep it going like they have with Fallout 4 and Skyrim. Except they killed the modding community for Fallout with an unneeded and unwanted update. If you're comfortable with modding Bethesda games, and this game is on sale for $20 or less, I'd say it's worth it. Otherwise, stay far away from it. Bethesda has shown how lazy they've become and how reliant on the modding community they are to keep their games popular.

A flawed game that hits all the right points for me. Bethesda has previously seen improvements in exploration to the detriment (my personal opinion) of narrative and storytelling. What works for me is that Starfield bucks that trend. With some of the best integrated companions from Bethesda and a commitment to RPG dialogue, Starfield plays towards what I look for in games. Procedural generation works better for ambiance rather than exploration; however, with the right temperament and expectations, that can also be a positive. I understand some of the trepidation, but for me, Starfield has been well worth the time and money and makes me interested in the future developments

I really wanted to like this game, like really really wanted to.  I upgraded my desktop so I could play it.

And man, it's just so boring.  Sure the first like... 10 hours are fun, when everything is new.  Then you realize that every planet is basically the same, the people are flat, the environments unimaginative... I can only explore the same exact abandoned science facility on so many planets before I just don't care anymore.  And I mean exact same, same floor plan, same enemies.  The outpost system is clunky, and feels like an afterthought to justify having all the random junk in the game to pick up, and to have some crafting systems you'll never ever use.  The factions are boring, and uninspiring.  I might try to force myself to finish the story... But I don't think I care, the main story arch might be interesting but it's just so... slow....

There are some positives!
The random little stories you'll bump into randomly are so enjoyable, but the problem is that they're too spaced apart to really make it worth it.  I've quite enjoyed the spaceships, and space combat is fun.  I've also enjoyed the gun play, handles well.

Just spend your money and time on any other Bethesda game.

I have been a huge fan of Bethesda RPGs for decades, and this is a welcome addition to the library. I've had hundreds of hours of fun and plan to have hundreds more. I really dig the future of space-faring humanity setting, and absolutely love the ship building. This isn't some space-sim with orbital mechanics, nor is it an endless universe with aliens and black holes. Bethesda has done what they do best, and made another great RPG to play for hundreds of hours, My only gripe, is that they seemed to have given up on the fully-voiced protagonists. That was something I really enjoyed about Fallout 4, and in other RPGs like Mass Effect, too. Sometimes, my father and I would be playing FO4, gaming separately of course but in the same room, and it was kinda nice hearing the full dialog while we played, rather than the truncated other-half-of-the-conversation it sounds like now. A small gripe, because it only would've made the game a bit better; it is still great without it.

there are SO Many things to talk abt with this game but as a whole i do really enjoy it! ive loved spending hours exploring all of the different planets and generally i have really liked the different story lines within the game itself! i think that i enjoyed the crimson fleet storyline the best and i kinda wish that it was longer tbh

my main criticism with the game is that it feels kinda empty both in terms of the world itself and the characters that you meet. in comparison to other bethesda games i've spent large chunks of my life playing (cough cough skyrim), i didn't find myself excited to explore all of the different structures on all of the planets in hopes that i'd find a unique quest or layout to explore. i didn't really find myself overly attached to many of the characters that i met throughout my journey because they felt so empty and almost one note? i did find that i didn't really want to have any of the constellation members as a part of my crew because they would get angry with you if you did anything that they didnt agree with (theft, crime etc etc). you would think that the main characters having morals would make them more impactful or human, but because all of them felt the same way, it just felt more frustrating than anything if i wanted to roleplay as a morally grey character. i don't think that they were bad characters by any means, but that in combination with how flat a lot of other characters in the world felt made it feel less important to really talk to anyone or connect with them. 

i do really enjoy the game as it is and i appreciate the work that they've put into it because it really is just a stunning game and getting to explore space is SO COOL!!! it was probably my favourite part, especially when there would be the odd random event that made the galaxy feel more full of life. i think that i just wish that they didn't put so much effort into making the game as massive as it is only to leave it feeling kinda empty as a result. i would definitely recommend the game if you're a fan of exploration or seeing all of the different planets but if you find that a little tedious i would probably get this on sale or smth!

Holy fuck this game is trash. What happened to bethesda?

After spending an inordinate amount of time to fix visual glitches, a problem with it defaulting to fsr3, I discovered that the game is awful.

The UI is the worst I have ever encountered. Everything is a nested menu. Everything is button inputs instead of mouse clicking. No page has a reasonable quantity of information. Sorting functions literally do not work sometimes and you have to close and reopen inventory to use them. Storage containers do not function properly?

I would literally nuke all console manufacturers IRL if it meant games would stop with these FUCKING TRASH ASS MENU SYSTEMS.

And then there is the gameplay. It's mediocre gunplay. Mediocre movement. Bad navigation. More minecraft/survival game resource collection garbage.

Also the load screens. You have to fast travel (load) your ship, get into your ship (load), open the trash ass navigation map to travel to a new system (load), get scanned then land (load), use a train to get to the right part of the city (load), go in a building (load) and at no point is there any meaningful gameplay in between these meaningless check boxes.

It's too bad I bought this ages ago and then didn't get it off my to do list until months later. Can't get a refund now.

Exploring the Final Frontier: Starfield and the Art of Modding

Bethesda’s Starfield is an ambitious space-faring RPG that invites players to explore a vast galaxy, teeming with diverse planets, alien landscapes, and fascinating characters. As the studio’s first new IP in over two decades, it has captured the imagination of gamers eager to chart the stars and create their own stories among the stars.

A Universe Waiting to Be Explored

One of Starfield’s most striking features is its scale. Players can traverse hundreds of procedurally generated planets, each with unique terrain, climates, and resources. From arid desert worlds dotted with ancient ruins to icy planets with hidden subterranean oceans, the game delivers a rich sense of exploration. The freedom to land on virtually any planet, pilot customizable ships, and investigate uncharted locations gives players the feeling of genuine interstellar discovery.

Every planet hosts unique environmental challenges, resource opportunities, and potential encounters. Whether scavenging for valuable minerals, deciphering alien technologies, or interacting with local factions, exploration is both rewarding and immersive. The game’s attention to detail extends to its day-night cycles, atmospheric conditions, and dynamic ecosystems, making each world feel alive and distinct.

Characters That Shape Your Journey

The galaxy of Starfield is populated by a diverse cast of characters, from hardened space mercenaries to enigmatic scientists and traders. NPCs have their own motives, affiliations, and storylines, which can influence the player’s journey. Choosing alliances, navigating moral dilemmas, and engaging in dialogue choices all impact the narrative, offering multiple ways to experience the story.

Companions further enrich gameplay, providing unique skills, backstories, and sometimes comic relief. Whether forming strong friendships, rivalries, or even romances, characters make the galaxy feel personal and lived-in.

Modding: Expanding the Universe

Modding has long been a hallmark of Bethesda games, and Starfield is no exception. The game’s robust creation tools allow players to craft entirely new experiences, from cosmetic tweaks to expansive gameplay additions. Mods can enhance graphics, introduce new ships and planets, or even add gameplay mechanics like multiplayer functionality—a popular aspiration among the modding community.

Some notable modding possibilities include:

Planet and Biome Expansion: Players can create entirely new planets with custom terrains, flora, and alien lifeforms, expanding the galaxy beyond what’s in the base game.

Character and Faction Mods: Custom NPCs, factions, or even companion modifications allow players to enrich interactions and story depth.

Quality-of-Life Improvements: Mods can streamline inventory management, UI, and navigation, enhancing immersion and convenience.

Gameplay Mechanics: Advanced mods can introduce features like faster travel systems, enhanced combat mechanics, or entirely new mission types.

The modding community thrives on collaboration, sharing creations that continuously refresh the game for both veterans and newcomers. For those willing to dive into coding or asset creation, modding provides a creative outlet that can turn Starfield into a personalized universe.

Conclusion

Starfield combines the thrill of space exploration with rich storytelling, offering a galaxy filled with planets to discover and characters to meet. Its modding potential adds a layer of limitless creativity, allowing players not only to explore the stars but to reshape the universe itself. Whether you’re charting unknown worlds or creating new adventures through mods, Starfield invites you to make the cosmos your own.

The game is o.k. for what it is.  It's not trash, but then again it's not amazing either.  The thumbs down is because I couldn't recommend people buy the game without checking out both the positive and negative reviews of the game first.  Then decide for themselves whether or not they want to spend the money and give this game a spin.

I will say this it's not in the same league as Baldur's Gate 3, Witcher 3 or Kingdom Come Deliverance...not even close.  In fact I think Bethesda did a better job with Skyrim and Fallout. 

The stories in Starfield are somewhat interesting, but one of the things I look for in a game is replayability.  Right not it's it's kind of looking like a one-and-done kind of game to me.  As far as the NG+ feature...I heard someone say the juice ain't worth the squeeze, and I'm inclined to agree.  

As far as the spaceship dogfights go, well I come from an extensive EvE Online background.  So, what can I say.

UPDATE:  After spending more hours with this game,  I've changed my opinion somewhat.  I would recommend this game to those who might like this sort of game.  There's plenty to explore and do.  There are bugs and because of random times where the game freezes and locks up, you need to save often in order not to lose too much progress.  That typical with Bethesda games where they don't put enough effort into quality control and bug fixing.

I've enjoyed playing around with the ship building and outpost building features.  There are lots of interesting side quests to keep you busy,  and there is some amount of re-playability and build variety to the extent that I can say I've gotten my money's worth out of this game and I'll probably be spending more hours with the game.

FINAL COMMENTS
After 311 hours I've uninstalled the game.  Do I feel I got my money's worth.  Sure.  Was I impressed.  Not really.  The ship building and outpost building was more engaging than the main story.  Heck, some of the side quests were more engaging than the main story.  The only value companions brought to the game was their buffs as crew members on the ship, even that aspect was short lived.  I found it much more enjoyable to just travel alone without the same chatter repeating over and over.  Plus as companions, they contribute little and often get in the way.  

I didn't like that quests were automatically put into your quest list without giving you a choice.  At minimum it would have been nice to have a separate inactive quest tab that you could move them to.  This would eliminate a lot of clutter in your active quest tab.  

The ship combat was not impressive.  No skill required.  Just bump up the perk points, beef up your weapons and shield and you're golden.  But here I'm comparing the ship combat with EvE Online.  So that's probably not a fair comparison.

There really is not as much replayability as it might seem at first.  You can do almost everything with just one character regardless of the background or traits you chose.  Although it would have been nice if there was some sort of path to redemption for the player if they rejected SysDef's offer and sided with the Crimson Fleet where they had the ability to choose between SysDef and the Crimson Fleet after retrieving the legacy.

Will I play this game again?  If I do, it probably won't be for a long while.

I know.  I know.  479 hours played and a "thumbs down."  I get the contradiction.  Here's the thing: there are parts of this game that I love.  Building spaceships and bases is my crack.  Disabling and boarding an enemy ship, wiping out the crew, and adding it to your own fleet = *chef's kiss*

The problem is that most of the rest of the game feels like it was designed by my 14-year old self.  "What if we made a game that was Wing Commander + Doom?!"  The RPG elements feel largely superficial and the story is--with the exception of a few specific missions/quests--not worth your time.  Not once did the characters or plot elicit an emotional reaction from me.

If you want to play Spacecraft Engineer or SimBase, you'll find something to enjoy here.  If you want a deep, involving first-person RPG with robust mechanics, interesting characters, buildcrafting, and a memorable story, you should go play Cyberpunk.

[h1]🚀 [i]Starfield[/i] - Mixed Feelings Among the Stars[/h1]

[b]What I Played:[/b] Spent around 90 hours exploring the vast universe, completing quests, and encountering the same faces on different planets.

[b]The Good:[/b]
[list]
[*]The story had potential and kept me engaged throughout my playthrough.
[*]Exploration felt rewarding with unique planets to discover and environments to traverse.
[*]The game's soundtrack and sound design added immersion to the space-faring experience.
[*]Customizing my spaceship and upgrading gear provided a sense of progression and personalization.
[/list]

[b]The Bad:[/b]
[list]
[*]Repetitive quests became a common occurrence, leading to a feeling of monotony.
[*]Encountering the same faces for different characters broke the immersion and made interactions feel less unique.
[*]Some technical issues like bugs and glitches hindered gameplay enjoyment at times.
[*]The overall gameplay loop lacked innovation and felt familiar rather than groundbreaking.
[/list]

[b]Verdict:[/b] [b]Recommended with Reservations[/b] - While [i]Starfield[/i] offers a decent experience with its engaging story and exploration, the repetitive quests, technical issues, and lack of innovation hold it back from shining brightly in the vastness of space. If you're a fan of Bethesda Game Studios' previous works and enjoy RPGs set in space, this might be worth a try, but be prepared for some drawbacks along the way.
