The game is basically space fallout but with a less interesting story and even less interesting characters. The world building is not good. I have seen some reviewers, even critical reviewers, claim the world building is good. It is not. This is supposed to be a large part of the galaxy that has been explored, inhabited, for something like a couple hundred years. It amounts to 2,000 empty planets. 

Even the planets that have what should be large populations, major cities, are tiny insignificant and bland locales. The game is not a space exploration game. The planets have nothing of interest besides resources you need to gather that are never in one planet so youll be planet hopping across systems just to go through the tedious process of upgrading one of the many terrible weapons.

It is a fast travel and loading screen simulator. Often times when i play an MMO or multiplayer RPG game, i think "i wish this were a single player game". But with this game its the opposite. this would be a fantastic multiplayer game. But that is one of the many things Bethesda has been on record of definitely not doing. Along with all of their other "definite nos" when creating this game and responding to the feedback. They seem to love disappointing people and making the game as poorly as possible.

But this is nothing new. A lot of people have talked about this. But I have given this game a lot of hours without paying attention to the critics because I wanted to get an idea of it on my own before really paying attention to the same complaints I had.

So the game is worse than the fallout games in story, environment, etc. But that doesnt mean it is absolute trash. It still was entertaining enough. I also dont agree with people who claim a game must have 150-1000 hours of gameplay to make it worth the 60 dollar price tag. If you play for 60 hours, thats 1 dollar per hour. Is that really not worth it? Even if it is a disappointing experience, you still spent 60 hours for some reason. I recognize that, and because of that I really cannot say I regret playing it. It had aspects that are really cool and fun. Just because something isnt as good as something else doesnt mean it is worthless. I love the movie Alien and Aliens, and find Alien 3, 4 etc to be awful compared but i still enjoy them and will watch them all together every so many years when I binge the series again. Even the Alien VS Predator movies find their way in and those are pretty bad movies.

But Bethesda should not be making the equivalent of B movies when making their games. Starfield is not 1:1 the equivalent of Alien Vs Predator when looking at things that came before... but it is not much better.

I love it now that the modders have made it brilliant. And I hate that Bethesda gets rewarded by the work of the modders (due to people buying their game, and playing it only due to modders making it worth playing). But thats why we need to support indie game creators more. They are truly making interesting content.

If you really dont care that Bethesda made a subpar game and lied about what they were making prior to release, then buy it and get mods and youll probably enjoy it a lot. But the average gamer isnt going to install most of these mods. A lot of them may still like it.. especially if you didnt expect it to be what they said it would be prior to release.

The crafting and base building can seem tedious at first but once you get into it, it's rewarding for those who like to build and create. 100%ing the achievements did take a decent amount of time. Ground combat is percentage based so no matter how good your aim you'll still sometimes miss. Space combat is ok to needs improvement. Companions and story arcs are pretty generic. Ignore the Astral lounge as it's just a den of wokeness. Overall, I'd recommending on waiting for a good sale.

This will probably be the most negative positive review I've given. That's because I did *genuinely have fun* during most of the 400-plus hours I have in game. However, its flaws are just so glaring that I can't blame anyone who passes it by, and you're not really missing anything if you do.

First, the good. The visuals and soundtrack are spot-on. The atmosphere Bethesda wanted, they hit. The NASA and Space Age inspirations are there, and they are a joy to behold. This is probably the best "space-themed wallpaper maker" game there is, more than No Man's Sky or even my beloved Elite Dangerous. It's also the most stable Bethesda game I've played. In all my time, yes, it's crashed, but I never had a vital quest or item bug kill gameplay. There's definitely some fun to be had your initial forays into exploration, starship and outpost building, combat, and learning the lore of the setting. And there are some individual quests that are quite satisfying to solve.

But the longer you spend with it, the more the nagging flaws start to become. Some of it is technical -- the inventory/merchant UI is atrocious, and I was about eight hours in before I was looking for a mod to clean it up. The leveling, perks, and skills wildly vary in their applicability (and even clarity of what they do) relative to their cost. The starship combat tries to be engaging and tactical, but like the on-foot combat, tends to be very spongy towards your opponents unless you have overwhelming gear (or rebalance them in the settings), which brings me to a more overall point about what the game tries to be and what it actually is.

This isn't Skyrim in space, it's Borderlands wearing a thin skin of Original Series Star Trek. The fountain of arms and armor you're showered with and constantly expected to upgrade, the emphasis on gunfights versus any other gameplay, the fact that starships are basically glorified storage containers and loading screens, the lack of options and roleplaying to solve most quests, and the plot being a very loose excuse for it all is not really what I expected. There's such a lack of care for the setting Bethesda claims to have been building for 25(!) years. 21st-century ruins have the same computer technology as the 24th. Identically titled points of interest on opposite sides of the game map are built *fully* identically, down to data logs and half-eaten sandwiches, with only the enemies and contents of loot chests changing (and those still in identical locations). Main NPCs have little characterization and interactivity, with little of consequence besides arbitrary relationship values. A bit later in the main plot, when "temples" become available for exploration, the so-called puzzles within quickly become obviously meaningless and unchallenging, and it was after completing only a handful of those that I was on the lookout for a mod to auto-complete them. And it commits one of the worst sins for what claims to be a roleplaying game, in that the railroading in certain quests (including the main-plot ones) is as blatant as could be.

In retrospect, it all seems like it's done in service of the New Game Plus mechanic, but then that gets undermined by the fact that basically nothing matters in this setting because so little ever changes during a run, and then so little even potentially changes from run to run, that I wonder why they even bothered with having an NG+ option. So much of the game content can be seen in one or two runs that subsequent ones serve little purpose but building up your special powers (which are mostly useless until you have increased them significantly over multiple games) and character levels to access more perks. Starfield could have provided you with the opportunity to really impact the game world, but it doesn't. It could give you vast differences between runs to make it worthwhile to see what is out there, but it doesn't.

Overall, Starfield is a game that feels remarkably unconfident. It promises the galaxy, and it is fun to indulge that promise for a while, but it stands for nothing in its writing or gameplay. It asks questions but is tediously shy to even speculate on answers. It tells you in no uncertain terms to go out and explore, but gives you nothing to find. There's actually hints that maybe the right choice is *not* to continue wandering, but to stop and enjoy where you are, which is not inherently a bad message, but it clashes with everything the game purports to be about. It wants to emulate the best of science fiction, but won't commit to any compelling moral or narrative arcs to do so.

Is it worth the price of a case of good beer? Maybe, if you're in the mood for it, but it might end up being the kind of beer you take to a party and leave for someone else with different taste.

TLDR: Starfield is Outer Worlds (rpg in space) pretending to be Star Citizen (space sim).
Let's go through the steps of planetary travel in each of the three games:
OW: Enter ship (loading screen), select destination (loading screen), exit ship (loading screen).
SC: Walk onto ship, sit down, fly up, fly to destination, fly down & land, stand up, walk out of ship (no loading screens throughout process).
SF: Enter ship (loading screen), sit down, take off (loading screen), select destination while flying in space (loading screen), select landing point while flying in space (loading screen), stand up, exit ship (loading screen). Note: Starfield includes fast travel, which reduces the aforementioned five loading screens to one or two.
You'll notice that the only notable gameplay difference between OW and SF is spaceflight, but the number of travel steps is closer to SC. SC has done the work to make a space sim, so each step is naturally part of the experience; OW includes only the steps necessary to facilitate multiple distant game worlds; SF has strung together the individual events of planetary travel to give the illusion of a space sim, without those steps being required by the overall process. 
I'm still recommending the game because it's fun as-is, and it has some great aspects - the graphics look great, the stories & characters are servicably interesting, and shipbuilding is mostly really cool. If you like Bethesda games, it's definitely worth a try.

Oh my goodness, where do I even start? This game is very forgettable. The hype surrounding it was incredible, and I threw myself into it with open arms. At the time, though, my PC had trouble running it, and I ultimately dropped it because of that. Over the years, I lost sight of it, until just recently when I had an itch to play again—not sure why exactly.

The gameplay is mindless to its core: fetch-quest main missions, a hodgepodge of side quests, and "activities" that NPCs randomly add to your quest log. The side content is ultimately a distraction from how empty and soulless the entire game is. The developers obviously put some effort into the main cities, but past that, the procedurally generated content is positively bland in every aspect.

This time around, I decided to only play the main story missions as I couldn't bear the brain-dead content. The story is somewhat interesting to an extent but falls flat. Plus, I couldn't even finish the story because it led to an unskippable ship combat battle with high-level enemies. The ship combat is truly atrocious in this game already, and a 50-level difference just makes it impossible. But I cannot fathom spending any extra time leveling up for that. So I'm stopping there.

What a waste of money and time this game was. You'd be better off playing The Outer Worlds (seriously, even better than this) for a space travel story, or No Man's Sky for space exploration instead. Those two games would fill in any shortcomings Starfield has.

But at the end of the day, if you're looking for a first-time experience of Starfield for its purely quest-running simulator structure and no real substance, grab it on a heavy sale. $20 is the maximum I'd pay for it if I could have a do-over.

I genuinely love Starfield. The world-building, the freedom, the ships, the outposts  it’s everything I wanted in a Bethesda space RPG. I’ve sunk hundreds of hours into one character, pushing them well beyond level 300, and I still find new things to do.
But here’s the problem: Bethesda designed Starfield as a long-haul game, not a short replayable one.
Outposts are built to expand, link resources, and grow over time.
Ship building is a massive time investment, meant to evolve with your character.
The whole premise is that your universe grows with you.
And yet… the engine can’t sustain it.
Without a proper save file cleaner, the game slowly chokes itself with leftover data  ghost scripts, orphaned quests, broken references. Eventually your once-great save risks crashing, bloating, or stuttering until you’re told the only “solution” is to restart.
Restarting is fine in Skyrim or Fallout where each playthrough can feel fresh. But in Starfield? Restarting means deleting years of investment in outposts, ships, and character progression. That’s not replay value  that’s punishment for long-term players.
Yes, modders have stepped in with experimental save cleaners, but this should not be left to unpaid volunteers. Bethesda knows this problem has existed since Skyrim. If Starfield is truly meant to be “a game you can play forever,” then we need official tools to keep forever saves stable.

🚀 Starfield Review — The Best Space Sim Out… But It’s Lonely at the Top

If you’ve ever stared at the stars and thought,
“I want to go there,”
Starfield says,
“Cool. Pack your gear. Let’s go.”

And it delivers.

Starfield isn’t just a game — it’s a galaxy. A vast, handcrafted constellation of planets, secrets, factions, starships, and strange anomalies that suck you in and refuse to let go.

But after a few hundred hours of charting the stars solo, one truth becomes clear:

This game was built for multiplayer… it just doesn’t have it.

Yet.

🌌 What It Gets Right (And It Gets a LOT Right)

Ship customization that turns every cockpit into a home.

Planetary exploration that feels genuinely mysterious and rewarding.

Gunplay that’s smooth and weighty — finally, Bethesda nailed it.

Dialogue and storylines that actually pull you in (Crimson Fleet, anyone?).

And the soundtrack? Cinematic perfection.

This isn’t No Man’s Sky.
This isn’t Elite Dangerous.
This is something else entirely — a Bethesda RPG first, space sim second, and an ambitious love letter to science fiction.

You can mine, fight, romance, steal, build, upgrade, smuggle, and scan until your ship's cargo bay is full of rare elements and ethical gray areas.

It’s fun. It’s deep. It’s massive.

And it feels like a real space odyssey.

🤝 But It Needs One More Thing: Us

There’s a moment — after you’ve built your dream ship, colonized a few outposts, made questionable moral decisions, and collected alien artifacts — where you sit in your captain’s chair and realize…

“I wish my friends could see this.”

Starfield is begging for co-op.

Just a two-player system would change the entire experience:

Co-piloting missions.

Base-building with friends.

Dual-ship PvE raids.

Shared exploration logs.

A reason to revisit planets and stories together.

Imagine crewing your custom frigate with your real friends, watching one scan for anomalies while another takes the helm and a third jumps into a spacewalk. The potential is right there. It just hasn’t been unlocked.

🛰️ Still the Best Solo Space Sim in the Galaxy

Don’t get me wrong — even without multiplayer, this is the most complete, immersive single-player space sim on the market right now.

But that’s the thing:
It’s almost too big to experience alone.

Bethesda built a galaxy worth sharing.
Now we’re just hoping they let us.

Final Verdict:
🌠 9/10 — “A breathtaking solo voyage through the stars… now give us a crew.”

Starfield is majestic, ambitious, and incredibly polished for a game of this scale. It sets a new bar for what a space sim can feel like when storytelling, combat, and freedom collide.

But if it ever adds multiplayer?

Game over.
This becomes the definitive space experience — full stop.

Until then, I’ll keep flying solo.

But I’ll keep hoping.

This is some C- work from Bethesda.  Still - i'd recommend it to fans of Bethesda products who like to MOD to raise the product quality.  In a few hours I made my copy into a STAR WARS game with KOTOR music-jedi skills, armor ships, quests and props, which Rocks.  But Out of the box "as is" - this is a deeply flawed product.  The 3d avatars are complex and pretty models, but animated horribly with overly expressive and clumsy facial animations for speech and emotion that put them on par with muppets.   The "random" dungeon encounters scattered about are actually the exact same pre-built 12 levels or so that are recycled like counter strike levels with weak and dumb bots as opponents.  Boring.   The actual missions - some are complex and invested designs, and some are stupid errands and busy work for XP.  A lot of the game mechanics here are broken as hell..  Pickpocketing/stealth and the like - all busted up.   Skills are also badly designed with Skyrim and Fallout 4 having better skill tech trees and crafting.   Space travel occurs everywhere - and its all just blank 'screen loading' fast travel that takes time.  The UI Sucks - worst i've ever seen acutally - slow and with hot key buttons recycled depending on what 'mode' you're in.  Example -Hot Key "E" Activates targeting while flying, or could lock on to an enemy, or look or make you get up and walk away from you ship controls leaving your ship with no pilot in the middle of combat.  The UI is super slow too - taking you out of combat. and you have to go through many pages of UI to be in the right mode to reuse a hot key.  ugh -So its up to you mod it till it don't suck so much.  Unfortunately the game is very slow.  Slow loading - lots of 'fast travel' and the space ships are only really used for combat in orbit.   Space ship design is all the same "SPACE 1999" looking and the space suits are all ugly fishbowl designs... very little 'coolness' found there..  So you can try to mod that to make it less dorky.    All and all - there is more of the 'bad' Bethesda is infamous for, and less of the 'good' they are also famous for.   However they do have a mod community to save them from the fire.  With that saftey net, the game is salvageable.    As much as I hate things about it - i'm playing the heck outta it too.  So i still recommend it if you're a fan of bethesda products.

Good

!!!PLEASE DON'T REPEAT MY MISTAKES!!! - don't just blindly trust all the nagative talk about this game. I fell for that trap myself and it was a huge mistake. 

People who judge games by comparing it to gta or rdr2 and shooting the water for 5 minutes to see if it's splashes are physically accurate - ngl, you are retarded. This same fucking thing happened to Cyberpunk before. 
If you are expecting Starfield to be a space sim like Star Citizen + to have stealth like in Deus Ex + to be a narrative rpg like Baldur's Gate 3 AND to have a realistic physics and NPCs like RDR2 -  you are setting yourself for disappointment bacause no game can do all of those things together, it's just impossible. 

But Starfield does so many things at the same time that no other game does.  It has great stories and questlines with different outcome depending on your choices and factions that you can find or unintentionally miss; it has a really well thought out lore; it has an enormous world that just has so much in it - it's insane, the amount of small details, hidden things or funny encounters is staggering. It has an amazing outpost system, really well thought-out ship builder, amazing Hand-crafted cities and locations, you'll have companions with their own smissions and quest lines (you can even marry them!), the art design is gorgeous, your character's perks actually influence gameplay, the UI is great (NASA style badges as the art for perks is so creative), ther's a contraband system, there's piracy, there's bounty hunting. It's simply so engaging just playing it and be constantly disctracted by another interesting thing after another so you'll just find yourself at 5 AM in the morning completing another task that you set for yourself. 

The dialogues are actually good this time in a Bethesda game. Your perks, background and traits can lead to a different outcome, personally I was surprised that I can actually role play in a game from Todd Howard. 

The complaints regarding loading screens are just unjustified. There are loading screens BUT did you actually see how much stuff is in this game's  locations? I mean ALL the small objects are interactable and have a physical 3D model and there are a lot of obects here. It's a necessary compromise to have loading screens. It would definately be better without them but is it fair to ask AND the insane amount of physical objects AND to have no loading screens? If you think yes - then tell me what game has this two combined? 

Personally - it's my favourite bethesda game, I loved every hour and I really recommend everyone just to try it themselves, it just might be your next favourite game.

The key to enjoying this game is realising that you have the ability to get lost.   Unlike games like Skyrim, it doesn't hand them to you on a plate.  Also you are unlikely to stuble on things to the same extent as skyrim, so you'll have to put in time an effort to explore.
Its not terrible, certainly not as good as Fallout\ Elder Scrolls...

It's the writing and dialog that I just can't take seriously.  It always rubs me the wrong way when I hear it.  

The game has so much potential, the world building is good, character creation is spot on, combat is polished and feels nice, making your own ship and participating in many space battles feels epic, the premise of 3 split main factions (United Colonies, Freestar Collective, and House Va'ruun) with some interesting side factions like Crimson Fleet, Ecliptic Mercs, Spacers, with cool corporations like Ryujin Industries, Stroud Eklund, Deimos and more, this has potential.  

What ruins it for me, is the shallow sterile writing and interactions that plague this game.  I don't want to see some 6th grader class ask me stupid questions in space, some grandma offering me soup, people being PC and being inclusive only for the purpose to gather a wider audience.  What I want is Depth. I don't mind being PC and inclusive but holy hell... make it feel right. Not just there to say it's there. I want well written characters, not characters that have me wishing there was a mod to shut them up.  the game could be so much more than what it is.  

I want the Crimson Fleet to be disturbing and crazy, I want House Va'ruun to be like the Imperium of Man with how fanatical they are and how they will kill anyone who commits heresy.  Make the Freestar collective more like the series Firefly and movie Serenity.  Make the UC like this pristine icon from the outside but deeply corrupt and greedy when you look deeper, and I want characters with convincing writing and depth to them where they have actual character and interesting mannerisms and for god sakes give me a companion that doesn't constantly gripe about me picking up too much stuff! 

TLDR:  Great universe and gameplay (Combat, Space Combat), sterile weak dialogs and writing of side characters that gives no real character and that rubs me the wrong way.

its your no mans sky wanna be without other alien races and languages its like todd thought that fallout 4 and skyrim would be great to take elements from those 2 games and combine it with no mans sky for $20 more then no mans sky with like roughly 70-80 weapons you can use in this game

I've tried to love to this game for almost 50 hours. But i can not stand anymore. MIXED review is the proper assessment of this game. There are a lot of great things in this game: ship builder, outpost building, manufacturing, excellent faction stories. Like REALLY good stories. This game is one of the best scifi themed games. But all of these pointless because game systems are badly interconnected. You have the best ship builder game, but space exploration and space battles are meh. So your ideas and vision of the perfect ship wont matter that much. There are good outpost and industry systems, but the whole usefulness of it is just plain money printing which you wont need anyway. The story lines. Yeah, stories is extremely good and this game has a lore heavy as we used to see from bethesda games. The side stories alone carrying this game. But, it is just not enough for me because i need to go through bad UI and load screens to get things done. This is simply not uneven story pacing due to technical limitations. 
Yes, and then there are technical issues. I really struggled to put all the technical things in place to have a smooth playthrough. TBH, technical side of things is just not acceptable in the modern game industry. 
Overall, this game is just a sort of good wrapper but bad filling. 
Still, ill keep my eye on the development and future updates and have a plan to give it another shot because there are some things that are just so incredibly good.
TBH, leaving this game a downvote is just a sad moment for me. :(

They could just mimicked their success in Fallout 4 but somehow every system in this one is inferior. 
Legendary perks are as interesting as room temperature water.  explosive rounds (and many other perks) are now rng based, making the combat experience very inconsistent. 
Outpost (settlement) system is completely pointless and ridiculous time consuming. I envisioned I could be self dependent with all the resources my outposts produce but by the time I can build high level materials extractors, I do not need those materials anymore. So what are the points? And the outpost link system is utterly dreadful. In Fallout 4 I can just make a link and call it a day. Resources from all settlements can flow into my main base and I can enjoy a life of abundance. Now I can only link 3 outposts to my main base. So I need to make a map about the optimal links before deciding where to build. You are telling me that giant landing post cannot be shared by two ships and each ship needs their own? No wonder people in this world is fighting for scraps. Their basic infrastructure costs more than their society can produce. 
Just complaining makes me tired. It is my fault for expecting a miracle when literally everyone says it's a bad game. I regret ever meet this game in the first place.
Interesting story. Decent replayability. Id give it a 3.5 or 4 out of 5
this game is such a wast of fucking time, the ending just says LOL play the game again with no to barely any changes and everything you did doesnt fucking matter

It pains me to make this a negative review, but despite this game being mediocre, I can't bring myself to mark it as worth playing. 

I love Bethesda Games. I've been playing their titles since Morrowind on the original Xbox and this was the first game that didn't click with me. Fallout 4 didn't keep my attention as well as Skyrim, Oblivion, or Fallout 3 did, but this was a new level of disconnect. It is a good to great looking game with some pretty decent combat but everything else just falls immensely flat. 

The singular most important aspect of this style of game is missing - exploration. Which is astonishing given how absolutely huge the gameworld is. Thousands of planets that would take thousands of hours to see the entirety of. But they hod nothing of value aside from a handful of copy pasted points of interest and randomly generated terrain. Exploring boils down to visiting a new planet with slightly different foliage and colors than the last one, setting down near a building with almost the exact same layout as the previous one, only to find randomly generated loot that either has no use or no personality. I don't care to explore any of the thousands of worlds  because I know that there will be nothing worth searching for. Even the handcrafted locations like cities or areas made for missions feel like they don't have anything worth searching for. If all of the loot is randomly generated (or at least feels like it), then why would I even both trying to search for it if I'm just as likely to find it in a store?

Another huge issue with the game is a lack of immersion that largely stems from one place: Loading screens. Enter your ship? Loading screen. Sit in your seat and take off? Loading screen. Fast travel to another planet? Loading screen. Land on a new planet? Loading screen. Exit your ship? Loading screen. I am constantly made aware that I am playing a video game. At least in their previous titles like Skyrim or Fallout 4, the only real loading screens you would see would be while entering or exiting buildings. You could spend hundreds of hours in the open hub aspect of the world and never see a loading screen, but since there are 1000's of planets here, there are thousands more loading screens. 

But it's real cardinal sin is that it is just boring. 

Combat is a step up from their previous games but still nothing to really write home about. The story is equally as inoffensive with no real drive. You can tell that they really learned from the previous games by basically making the tutorial levels only take about 10 minutes but I was not hooked by the story at all. Most of the missions are standard RPG quests about fetching an item or talking to a person so you can shoot their friends in the face. There are very few missions that do anything remotely interesting and many of them are relegated to side quests. I feel like it's impossible to say "No" in certain scenarios, where characters will just railroad you towards taking the missions despite your refusal. I also feel like many of my dialogue choices have no effect on the outcome of the mission or the story so I often question why they even let me choose responses to begin with. 

The art style on the other hand is absolutely fantastic. They obviously took a lot of inspiration from real life and sci-fi designs from real NASA design documents to Alien, to Dead Space, Star Wars, Blade Runner, Star Trek, the list goes on and on. And yet, it feel cohesive like everything fits together without feeling out of place. There is definitely some inconsistency with how much attention certain locations get. Obviously story locations get more attention and care put in their item placement and set dressing, but it feels like everything else is just randomly generated. If a quest marker doesn't take you there, it felt like it was more than likely never even given a second glance. 

I could go on and on. Every now and again I feel the itch to give it another try. Maybe I missed something or maybe this time it will click for me. But it never does. This is my fourth attempt in the past 2 years and I feel like I don't need to see anymore after only playing for 3 hours. 

And no, no amount of mods fixes it either. Turning it into a Star Wars game just made me almost fall asleep while flying a Naboo Starfighter. There is no amount of novelty that can fix mediocrity.

Recieved this as a gift

This game has been out since Sep 6, 2023. 710 days have passed and this game runs just as poorly as the original complaints I've seen. I have a pretty good system, not the best, but it's definitely not the worst by any means and this game still runs like it's in a beta. 

I think the game play is alright, I'd enjoy it more without the unending stuttering and audio drops. 

The story so far is extraordinarily basic. Very basic things don't make sense, until you realize they're made that way just to have a tutorial or to progress the story, not because it's what any person, crew, or life-form would actually do.  

The graphics are pretty cool, until you realize that so many assets are just the exact same thing. All the solar panels are the same. All the Outposts look the same, All the people share soulless eyes. I haven't seen anything that has really wow'd me yet honestly and I don't really think I will as I play more of this.

This is one of the games where I'd normally come back in a few years and see if they fixed stuff. But I just got it and it's already been almost 2 years since it released. I don't think things are going to get fixed.
Put alot of time into this game since it was released, and honestly not much more that i can say that hasnt already been said except not even mods were able to save this game.

This is as honest a review as I can get for this game. Just gonna keep it short and sweet. Is it a good game in some aspects? Yes. Ship building was a cool thing to play with, as it remains simplistic and not too overly complicated. But everything else is just mediocre. I unfortunately bought into the hype and pre-ordered the game + ultimate edition months before it's release. During my time with the game during the few day early access period, I did enjoy quite a bit of the game, and that's what Starfield does do well, is makes you think you've got a lot of depth to the game, when really, once you dig into that apple pie, you learn that most of the pie is 99.9% crust, and 0.1% filling. I really did enjoy the new character customization options  such as pronoun control and even a few in depth options like walking style and I was hyped for the whole traits and backgrounds system, but it really ended up all falling flat for me. It took Bethesda nearly a full year to release mod support, and by then, the game was dead in the water. Shattered Space came and went, and at least for me, the modding community has nothing interesting to offer to keep me interested in the game. Take this as a lesson. Never pre-order a game out of hype. Especially never Bethesda. Nostalgia can be a drug. If you're looking for a good spaceship simulator, go to Elite Dangerous. You want RPG elements with modern-ish graphics? Fallout 4 has infinitely more content and even a thriving modding community for you that is sure to give you HUNDREDS of more hours of actual enjoyment than Starfield, while being cheaper. I just cannot recommend this game in it's current state.
full of surprises. many cool features. do recommend

Yes there is a tiny bit of the world which is not random and regenerative but the majority of the planets are completly pointless. This game has many problems, but chief among them are: it doesn't feel like you're actually exploring space, and it has no character or personality whatsoever.

Your ship might as well not even exist, because you can't fly it anywhere except around the immediate orbit of planets. When you go to different planets, you are clicking dots on a star map and then you basically teleport there after a loading screen. It just feels like a bunch of disconnected areas. Ship combat exists, but it's not really any fun.

Bland is the best way to describe the content. The game feels very PG rated, and all the characters seem like they were written for the Disney channel. Even the "seedy" town of Neon feels extremely tame when compared to something like Night City from Cyberpunk.

I could write a much more in depth review of all the other issues, but there isn't really any point because those flaws alone kill my interest in it. There are plenty of worse games, but there's also no reason to recommend playing this game, at any price really.

6.5/10. I tried and failed to like this game. 

This is a classic Bethesda experience, for better or worse. The story is fifteen minutes of content spread across 100+ hours. The companions WILL just begin sprinting in a random direction upon entering any shop. The NPC models WILL warp into body horror as they try to speak to you with limbs sticking out of walls, heads twisted at 180 degrees, etc. 90% of the skill tree is completely worthless. They even added a jetpack in an attempt to streamline the process of jumping up the side of a mountain.

I haven't enjoyed the Elder Scrolls games, but as a fan of both the Fallout series and space exploration games in general, I had high hopes for this one. I ended up just missing all the other games this should've emulated. If you want fulfilling space/planetary exploration, play No Man's Sky. If you want a satisfying spacefaring story or compelling crewmates, play Mass Effect. If you want a collectathon, play Super Mario Odyssey. 

Narratively, this game is the usual humdrum process of showing up somewhere, immediately being told that you're the most important person who ever existed for some half-baked reason, and then getting booted out to door to solve everyone's problems. There's very rarely any personal connection to be made with these quests. Mostly it just feels like driving for GrubHub: point A, grab item, point B. The main quest itself is that you're looking for rocks, but don't worry - they're very inportant rocks. And when you get to the super-special thrilling post-game content... you're still looking for rocks. Groundbreaking writing here and not all derivative.

This game is a failure when it "works", but don't be fooled - it's still got plenty of game-breaking bugs. For one example, after getting amped up to run the Red Mile (a kind of challenge gauntlet), my game immediately crashed upon first setting foot on the path. It did this somewhat consistently upon several repeat attempts.

For a second example, in a certain late game mission, my quest marker led me to a dead-end. I later learned that the NPC I needed to speak to in order to proceed with the mission no longer existed. (His day off, I guess.) I was (thankfully?) able to proceed through the mission by using an upgrade skill to manipulating a guard into opening the door for me. You may ask, "Why not just pickpocket the key from the guard?" I tried. The guard had no key in his inventory, but was able to open the door anyway. Thanks, Bethesda. 

The game isn't atrocious. I had fun with the ship-building, and they did provide the perfunctory funny robot companion. Starfield got a couple points out of me for nostalgia alone, but after 80+ hours I'm tired of trying to force some fun out of it.

When i saw this game i thought i was going to love it. But now 2 YEARS later I've come back to give my 2 cents. it was so forgettable i forgot to put up a review, don't buy it save your wallet the pain.

Pro: Hard sci-fi space opera with the Bethsoft formula

Con: Menus are cumbersome and planet exploration is lacking that skyrim sense of adventure. 

If you love hard sci-fi and love Bethsoft games, this game is for you. solid 8/10

After putting as many hours as I have, this game just feels like a Fallout 4 skin. Obviously, it is because it is the same engine with worse performance. This just feels disappointing; there just is nothing rewarding with engaging with any of the games mechanics once you breach the 20 hours mark or so. 

You keep playing because you hope there is more since the galaxy is so 'vast', but it literally just devolves into copy/paste areas with zero variation filled with loot that just becomes garbage to dismantle. This game would have been better off just being one solar system, consolidating all the planets with hand crafted areas into it, and then focusing all resources on building out those planets with more hand crafted places and possibly stitching it with some procedural generated areas. There is just no sense of exploration in this game after you see just how quickly the same tricks are played....you end up exploring the exact same 3 or 4 places over and over again.

Bethesda insists they have done no wrong and this game is amazing and disagree entirely with the user ratings, so it is clear they are compromised by their own ego either throughout the entire studio or simply leadership (Todd Howard specifically). This game will never be good and with the back to back bad releases all facing similar issues (Fallout 4, 76, Starfield) I do think this studio is over and done with.

I liked the game up until you are forced to steal the artifact from Petrov.  I'm sure there is some deeper meaning to the quest, but I hated it so much that I immediately quit and uninstalled.  That's on me though. 
 Aside from that, I don't see why this game gets so much hate.

I had began the game at its release, and the only reason I wanted the game was for the takeoff and the extremely long and fun exploration, which both are not really in the game, so the two things I got it for weren't there. The only fun part of it was attacking bases and getting stronger guns for the fighting npc's to use.
i wish i played sooner
Offers what feels like maybe 5% of the content and depth as any previous Bethesda game, hasn't improved meaningfully more than a year later.

You know what I actually like this game. It's just a fun open world slop type game. The marketing for games like these always ruins people's expectations for what they are going to be. While that is cringe, the game itself should be judged by its own merit. If you like the shoot guy, loot thing, and explore loop then its probably going to be entertaining. I actually think it does that loop better than some others. Just buy it on sale.

I think Starfield got an unfair bad rep here. The game is, from where I'm sitting, "Bethesda game universe but the main point is to poke around and do whatever", which frankly is EXACTLY what I hoped it'd be. I grant it's not a game for anyone who isn't used to finding their fun without direction sometimes, but for anyone who does? Well worth it.

I put off getting this game until some patches and updates came out for it (Bethesda classic imperfections) and it was well worth the purchase! There's so much to do and customize that it's almost too much lol. I highly recommend it.
its Fallout in space. Its a Bethesda ass Bethesda game. You know if you like it, you know what you are getting.

This game has potential. But the negatives are just overwhelming. 
The elder scrolls and fallout series are both based around the idea of exploring an interesting world. Starfield is absolutly not. The World feels extreamly empty. Generally you are not rewarded for exploration. if you want to explore some waypoint on the map, you are generally "Rewarded" with walking minutes through empty worlds, without any interesting locations, just to fight the same enemies. 

There are only very few enemies in the game. So there is NO variety and combat is fun, but very repetetive. 
Skyrim and Fallout generally reward the player to explore the world, Starfield does not. From the mid game on, you will travel everywhere  by fast travel. But also the Fast travel funcion is restricted, just so that you have to "jump from Star-System to Star-System", and watch the animation again. 

Also why is the landing, docking and take off animations not skipable? you are going to see hundreds, or even more of the same animations. The sound of your engine during Take off really got burned into my ears. 

Also, whay do computers sound exactly the same as they did in Fallout? sholdnt the sound like "more modern"?

And the Plot. Oh my god. I dont know what happened there. But the Plot is full of extremly unbelievable characters. 
In the first five minutes: You are an minter on some unimportant planet. You are an nobody. After some events, there arrives an explorer, who just gives you his space ship!? What? Why on earth would somebody give his spaceship to some nodbody he just met one minute ago? You would never give yours car to somebody you just met, even if that person was involved in some extraordinary event. 

Later the Plot stays equally ludacris. I am not talking about the events of the story, but rather the actions, and reactions of the characters. I have never seen such unbeliveable characters. I genuinly breaks immersion and made me laugh. Laughing not because of some joke, but laughing in disbelive about the writing. 

For the money they charge, i expect more.
-Graphics: OK
-Sound: OK, but many recycled Fallout sounds
-Story: Absolutly attrocious. Realy really dog shit.

Like many games of the modern era that make big promises: This one drops the ball on almost all of them. I know that, you know that, whatever redeeming qualities this game might have are dropped by how much of the games problems need to be modded out instead of just being fixed or patched. My reasons?

1. Prejudiced against Hoarders. I am one of those gamers that grew up on The Elder Scrolls, and the philosophy of TAKE LITERALLY EVERYTHING  YOU CAN is ingrained in my DNA at this point. This makes any game that has mountains of loot but extremely limited storage ability when you can have a base of some kind actively stress inducing. 0/10 for that.

2. Outpost Building. Something which seems to be a theme in Bethesda Open World Games of late, the outpost building in this game is like a really badly imported version of the outpost building in Fallout 76, which is itself a really terrible imported version of the settlement building in Fallout 4. An extremely small limit to defences (Seriously, 6 turrets?), no vanilla way to build a decent looking settlement with things like walls, foundations, etc, Hostile life forms constantly spawning in the middle of the base and therefore (just like Fallout 4's biggest pet peeve for me, bypassing solid defences) causing huge problems as I try to kill them, and my need to build MASSIVE STACKS OF STORAGE CONTAINERS (See point one, I am a hoarder in video games) make the Vanilla experience with Outposts tedious for someone like me that likes to make nice looking settlements. 

3. NEEDING to mod the game for it to be playable. I literally, in order to actually keep playing the game, had to mode the thing. I encountered game-breaking bugs (that I think still haven't been fixed, I wouldn't know, I haven't even had the game installed in ages), such as my ship regularly deleting itself at landing ports, other setpieces/ships being fused with my own and therefore making combat/flight/looking at the game impossible. These needed Console Commands to repair, but if you use the console it disables Achievements, etc, etc... LAUNCH YOUR GAMES COMPLETE BETHESDA.

4. Ship Building/Corridor Spaghetti. In order to make the large Mobile Base/home that I like to build for my Single Player RPG games where such an option is possible, it took over 8 hours. EIGHT ACTUAL HOURS. The reason? Corridor connections are entirely randomly generated by the in-game AI. Which means you get labyrinths that make absolutely no sense instead of a well thought out and nice ship interior that makes no sense whatsoever. You have to painstakingly ensure that wherever you want doors you have FORCED the game to make those connections through numerous tips and tricks, etc. Having to run around to every different supplier instead of just being able to access everything from your Outpost/Home Base landing pad is a form of tedium that we could have done away with. I guarantee that any company in space that sells parts/products would be more than happy to charge increased prices for delivery to remote systems using private couriers/shipping. Honestly I think this was the biggest thing that pissed me off...

Didn't even finish the main storyline. I went back to playing Stardew Valley instead. If you don't have this game, don't bother unless all you want to do is build a quick ship and do all the quests as opposed to building a Character Story.
Outstanding game.

I initially rated the game 5/10, but after playing more of the main story and side missions I give it 2/10. I think it's the worst quest design I've ever seen. It's the "poop quests in old WoW were more entertaining" level of bad. 

There are some of things that Starfield does well: combat, ship & space travel stuff (I didn't even hate the loading screens that much) and audio design. Suit, gun and ship models looks fantastic. There was a couple of really fun quests - I did like the Trackers faction one, where you get to fight a bunch of enemies in zero gravity. 

Starfield's biggest sins are:
1.  Horrible quest design - 90% of the quests are fetch and "follow a very slow npc for 5 minutes to receive yet another fetch quest" kind of quests. The fetch quests will take all across the Universe too, which mostly just means a lot of loading screens. There's also an unholy number of quests overall - your log is going to be a total mess. I also absolutely loathe the fact that you can't refuse/drop quests. 
The biggest offender, though, are the power collecting quests, which go like this: go to the temple, which is in the middle of yet another barren planet, find a door, unlock the door, float around the room catching glowy stuff for about 2 mins, get the power, fight a guy outside of the temple. Rinse and repeat 10 more times! I did two of those and decided I needed to stop wasting my time with Starfield.

2. Truly atrocious NPC models. They look like the belong in 2005. There are plenty of AA companies out there that are doing a much better job with much more limited budgets, so what is exactly Bethesda's excuse? 

3. Writing - I just couldn't bring myself to care for any of the characters or stories.
No perfect, but well worth your time to play.  A very good game.

This is going to be one of the most painful reviews I've done. I have, regrettably, 300+ hours in this game. For the love of god, don't do that to yourself. I am clearly NOT WELL and easily susceptible to delusions. I tried so hard to believe I was playing a good game in those 300 hours. At first I thought it was misunderstood. Then I thought it was uniquely for me. Then I thought it had potential, and that I could fix it, so I downloaded the creation kit. Then I finally beat the game, and it hit me, this wasn't good. 

It's issues:
1. Plots bad. Quite boring and stale. Being "starborn" is so absurd I can't believe it's real. The ending twists and reveals are lackluster or eye-roll worthy. About the only interesting reveal was what happened to Earth and that's mildly interesting.
2. Some of the side quest lines are interesting like the Crimson Fleet and UC Vanguard but they still feel held back a bit. The other side quests just lack meat to their stories. 
3. I think a lot of the world building and aesthetics are decently handled, but just not in depth enough, especially given this is the first entry in a new, original IP.
4. Exploration is absolutely killed. I know I'm beating a dead horse here but the random points of interest on a randomly generated square of land is not fun, and the vehicles they added barely helped. 
5. Space is practically pointless considering you can't fly to different planets, everything is fast travel essentially. As a result, the cool ship customization ultimately feels a little pointless. 
6. Underwhelming main cities. New Atlantis is impressive for Bethesda but is unbelievable as a CAPITOL CITY for the majority of what is left of humanity. I literally drew up plans for an expanded New Atlantis because I just wanted it to be good SO BAD. Neon makes sense size wise but i still feel it should be much bigger or at the least not split up with loading screens. And Akila City is just kind of pathetic. Could've had a bunch of smaller towns outside of it giving it kind of a mini Skyrim feel to match it's Whiterun feel. 

And so many other minor things that just add up. It's a shame because i thoroughly enjoy it's semi-grounded approach to future space travel and aesthetic. I really like the ship building but i am the type of person that spent time in the gummy ship editor in KH I am not normal. Base building is similarly fine, I'm just definitely willing to put up with bad base building because I enjoy it so much. I like the design of the ship parts and interiors and the lore and purpose of all of the different ship manufacturers.

But most importantly, the reason I kept playing is i LOVE space. I love the idea of space travel and I like that this fictional vision was near future instead of waaaay in the future. I was so locked in on the idea that I could design my ship, interior layout and exterior, decorate it, fly it (barely), and fight with it. It's like Star Citizen, but i can customize my ship. It's like No Man's Sky, but I can customize and walk around my ship. Except it's not like those games all. This game has the one thing those 2 games lack, an actual story, and it's not even good. At least it's SOMETHING compared to those games, and if I could have the perfect mixture of those 3 games, I'd probably never play anything else again.

But this is NOT. THAT. GAME. 

This is what feels like the final nail in the coffin for Bethesda. Conceptually flawed, this seems unsalvageable. Creation Kit modders seem to want nothing to do with it, except the ones utilizing the creation club, which is going to cost you even more money. Bethesda publishing their own stuff on there at the cost of MORE MONEY when the game is horrendously lackluster on launch is such a kick in the nuts. I have yet to play the actual DLC expansion, but I hear it's not helping very much. I don't think this game can pull a No Man's Sky, no matter how badly I wanted it to. 

3/10

This is a pretty interesting situation where I find myself wanting to play more of the game, but also running into bad writing and atrocious AI so often that I'm considering throwing out my 40 hour character to restart using an unarmed build with an AI mod installed.

This is your typical Bethesda writing, think Fallout 4 style nonsense. There's a quest where you need to get a thing to go to a place, and there is an important security-related person who has the thing you need to get in. This person doesn't know you, you're not disguised, you are just a random stranger. 
Do you:

A. Pickpocket the item? 
B. Steal it from their room? 
C. Blackmail them to get it?
D. None of the above?

It's D. You just, persuade them. "I think we'd both like this to work out" to paraphrase one of the persuasion options. ??? This person who is responsible for keeping the doohickey safe has no clue who I am, why am I even able to attempt to persuade them to give it to me in this context??? There's no reason they would even consider this, if there was any care put into writing their dialogue. Truly one of the most Fallout 4 meme compilation worthy interactions I've ever seen.

As for the AI, I went on a mission to assault a pirate settlement. Killed some dudes in combat, broke in, stole the thingy I needed to steal, and afterward I was ambushed leaving the facility. Cool!

Except the 4 Sharpshooter AI enemies ran all the way down the hill on the opposite side of the settlement and took cover behind rocks that were like.. 500 meters away from any chance to shoot me. So I hunter them all down, one by one, took about 4 minutes to kill the 4 dudes. Just such a weird tedious combat encounter. Broke into a space station, started shooting guys. There's like 14 enemies in the station, but I'm only ever fighting like 3 at a time, the other 11 can't hear my unsuppressed gunshots or grenades going off around the corner? Convenient for stealth gameplay I guess, but I wanted a firefight

Anyway, the game is like... 
6/10 as far as compelling me to complete the story goes.
2/10 combat AI.
4/10 writing.

Womp womp. Don't buy it full price, probably, I dunno I'm not your mom.
Feels hollow and empty.

Please buy on a discount.

As with other bethesda games, the game starts off really interesting then it gets really slate.

What keeps this game alive are the mods. I had to install "cheat" mods to enjoy this game. Some of the "cheat" mods I installed are mods that grant more credits, XP, unlocks and better loot. Without those cheat mods, you will be forever grinding and this takes away all the fun.

Also, I had to cheat to survive space dogfights. I had to design my ship such that it looks like a flying abomination. It basically looks at Christmas candy bar. The center mass is designed to be hollow for me survive space dogfights.

Even with the weak story, I really enjoy disintegrating enemies and turning them to gory paste.

My rating for this game would be 5.3/10 without mods. With mods, I would give it a 6.4/10.

id give it a 3.5/5 itd be better if modding wasnt limited by bethesda greed. also the plot has a couple holes and some of the side quests are missing some actual story. just a lot of fetch type quest and go here quest. and theres basically no reward for surveying planets. desperately needs some animation work and better scripting.
Overall decent game, has the same feeling as other Bethesda games. Main story line is meh, but other there is plenty of other content to keep you busy.

Most of my time spent playing the game has been in the Game Pass version, but  I absolutely love Starfield. The more I play it, the more I love it. When Starfield was first released it was widely believed that the best thing to do was to finish the main story to gain access to new game plus features, so thats exactly what I did. 


However, upon doing a little research, I discovered that I cheated myself out of all that the game had to offer, so I started a brand new game. 

The amazing thing is, for most of this time I’ve had absolutely no interest in finishing the game. Now mods are available and that feeling of not being interested in completing the main story has only increased.

However, as a person that loves Starfield and everything about it, It does feel kind of strange that I have yet to experience new game plus, so my genius idea to solve that problem was to buy Starfield on another platform, which is the steam platform. 

But this is also good because Steam players get the red carpet treatment when it comes to video games. For example, Steam players are allowed access to any new content that Bethesda releases approximately two weeks before everyone else, including PC players like myself who purchased the game through Microsoft…which is kinda weird, but such is the power of Steam due to their dominant position in the industry.

Starfield is so rich with things to do it really can be overwhelming. If you’re looking for a game that will mainline you through the games main story and side quests with unavoidable action scenes and violent encounters with creatures and human NPCs, Starfield isn’t that game. 

For that, I would suggest Mass Effect, which I often still play even today.

In Starfield, you reach a point where you can play the game for countless hours without even touching the main story. In fact, you could have an encounter with an NPC that could change the result of other side quest. 

Some category of side quest may seem mundane, but the intention of those side quest is to introduce you to locations in the game that you may otherwise never experience. For example, you may deliver a bottle of wine to someone on a space station. But while visiting that station you may encounter an NPC who needs help with one thing or another. 

You can join a number of factions that offer a plethora of missions and task to tackle. For example, after knocking out numerous missions for the mysterious Ryujin Industries I was summoned back to Ryujin towers to be informed that my performance was so impressive that I’ve received a promotion and my own office, equipped with my very own mission board terminal.

But honestly, you can spend hours in Starfield playing its research and crafting system. You could have so much cargo coming in and out of your outpost it can begin to sound like a major metropolitan airport. 

I absolutely love the research and crafting process in Starfield. Starfield has a ton of nice armor and weapons but it means nothing if you can’t upgrade them. 

Experiencing the difference and effectiveness of your weapons and armor after upgrading them is very satisfying, especially when you’re playing on very hard difficulty. It really makes a difference. 

I also love the way the ship combat is designed…the way it gives you the choice, provided your ship has the right weapons, to either completely destroy the ship, or to simply damage the engines, allowing the player to board the ship to loot it, or takeover the entire ship. 

After doing so, you could either sell it or put it in your personal ship lineup. 

I also love it when enemy ships are pursuing you aggressively and hitting you with a barrage of missiles. You really feel the heat of the enemies pursuit and their determination to destroy you. 

And Bethesda didn’t cut corners in this area. While being aggressively pursued by a few enemy ships, just out of curiosity, I once went into photo mode to see what was going on outside of my ship as I was attempting to get away. 

The outpost building is amazing. There is nothing else like it in any other space game.

After 421 hours, I finished my first playthrough. I explored so much, scouring the Milky Way for as much content as I could find, and even having completed so much of the story and the side missions, I was still hesitant to let it come to and end. 

It is shocking to me how mixed the reviews are. So much thought has gone into the game. There are differences between this and the other Bethesda games, but I find that it is usually pretty beneficial for every game to not be, you know, the exact same game. Starfield contains so much depth and beauty to the world; the designs of the cities, the scenery from so many of the planets. Even the barren rocky moons that so many people complain about; listening to this fantastic score while sitting in a crater-speckled valley as the sun rises over the horizon and casts long shadows over the mottled landscape was a truly pleasant experience for me. 

I won't pretend it was a flawless experience. There are systems layered on systems layered on systems. I have a liquid-cooled PC, and had to replace sections of tubing that had warped or cracked from the stress of running so hot for so long whole playing the game a half dozen times or so. It crashed at least once per play session. The inventory and resource management system is so janky that not only was it frustrating, but they added a button to "transfer all resources" and it was a 50/50 chance that this button would not only crash the game, but the computer itself. That said, this was also the crunchiest any bethesda game has been. The act of spending your meager upgrade points means going through a collegiate process (oh, you want a 300-level skill? Sorry, you need to spend at least 2 more point-hours in 100 or 200-level courses before you have the science background to handle that skill. You want to improve your Botany level? Looks like you have not yet finished the assignment from your last Botany class, to demonstrate you actually learned the skills you were shown). As someone who loves a road-trip, an experience where you have vast expanses of nothing, dotted with small settlements peopled with strangers whose names you don't know, and who may need help, or may outright hate you; that isn't just feel accurate to Space travel, it feels accurate to driving across most of the country. And then every once in a while, there is a vibrant, unique, packed city filled with people and stores and things to do. It just feels good. 

Fortunately, the New Game+ is baked into the story itself, so I did just keep right on playing. 13 hours into a new game, and so far I am finding so much new dialogue, a lot of new experiences. However imperfect it may be, this game is unlike anything I have ever played. So much thought, love, and detail went into making an experience that fits me so well that after all these hours, I still don't really want to leave.

The game doesn't do space exploration very well and that is a shame. It is, however, a fun ARPG with better role play features than other Bethesda games, and there is quite a bit to have with the game. 

If you're looking for a good space game with loads to do in your ship and in space, this isn't the game for you apart from some decent space combat. 

If you're looking for a fun action RPG where you can create your own story in a space setting, try different approaches to different scenarios and immerse yourself in your character, on the other hand, this is definitely it!

Yes it doesn't have seamless transitions like nms, that's true, but I really don't think it is that important after playing for tens or hundreds of hours. 
I find it quite ironic in myself that I tend to enjoy games that are criticized by tons of people more than those with a huge positive fanbase, but in my opinion, this is a great space game. It has been ages since a game have hooked me up this much. I don't care about what other people say, but if a game has what I want, I'm in.

Technical:
-A little unoptimised and the game save can get bloated within only a couple hundred hours (increases loading time)
-Most stable Bethesda game. Ignore those viral "clips" of the game. Dig deeper and you'll find that those are out-of-context clips from people messing around with console commands

Story:
-It's alright. Think of a space sci-fi movie trope and Starfield will probably fit any of them, with a space fantasy-esque twist in the middle
-Though it has RPG elements and choices do matter, it doesn't seem to be the main focus as the writing is a bit flat and outdated

Gameplay:
-Combat is better than one would expect out of a game like this. You can take it slow and fire potshots from cover or you can charge in, use sword and magic to manipulate the entire battlefield and fulfil that Jedi (or Sith) fantasy
-Dialogue choices are quite good and cover most moral stances, allowing us to roleplay as good/ evil as we want
-Ship and base building in this game are great. It's easy enough for someone new to it to make something viable for even endgame gameplay but also allows plenty of freedom for those who are interested in making complex designs

The current modding scene is dead. Bethesda now only allows achievements on certain Creations from their store which upset the modding community because they felt it unfairly incentivised Creations over the free mods. This is a case of "biting the hand that feeds." Bethesda's games have long been the supported by modders providing free mods keeping player interest alive for years and allowing for continued sales. Rather than being grateful and continuing this symbiotic relationship Bethesda decided they wanted a bigger piece of the pie and are monetizing the free labor of their community directly now.

I am sure they would argue that now that modders are also making money, what is wrong with that? The issue is two fold. First, Creations add a pay wall to a previously free feature. Part of what made mods great was the ability to endlessly change the game you were playing. You could find cool looking mods try them out and if you didn't like them it was no loss and you could try something else. Some of these Creations are quite expensive and they are all priced with fake digital currency to obfuscate their cost (a dark practice on its own) and it should be obvious why this greatly harms the modding experience. Modding has always been collaborative endeavor, if the people making the mods aren't able to freely play around with mods they lose interest in the game and stop making mods.

The second issue with this excuse is that modders were already making money. The Nexus, the main site everyone uses for modding, has a point redemption system that allowed modders to get some compensation through donations. They also could get donations from other platforms like Patreon or Ko-fi. Bethesda sticking their finger in the pie has complicated things.

Finally don't think for a second that restricting achievements to certain approved mods is for the players. It was never an issue with previous games. This is 100% a ploy to give them more control over the modding scene and to try and force more modders to their platform so they can make money off free labor.

I played Starfield on release on my Xbox, and playing on Steam rightnow. After going through it, I honestly don't understand all the hate it gets. Sure, the game isn't perfect. there’s valid criticism when it comes to the procedural generation of planets but overall, I think Bethesda did a great job, especially with the ship building mechanics and the Starborn storyline. One thing that really disappointed me, though, was the lack of real conflict between the factions. The game constantly references dramatic wars in the past, but unfortunately, none of that tension really plays out during your time in the game. It felt like a missed opportunity they could've built an awesome Cold War style arc between the factions, which would’ve added a lot of depth to the world.

That said, I still think Starfield did a better job than Fallout 4 in several areas. It’s definitely not a flawless game, but it doesn't deserve the level of hate it’s gotten. It feels like a lot of people just jumped on the hate train because that’s kind of how things are these days.

I always wonder how Bethesda will push the envelope when it comes to scummy monetization, and their intent with the whole 'creations' paid mods system became clear as day with Starfield.

It's quite obvious they have cut a lot of content from the game, in order to sell the content piecemeal as creations. So a system they claimed was created to help modders make money from fixing their broken games, was really just created to nickle and dime their players even more.

One example is The Tracker's Alliance faction mission that pops up in your mission log. It's presented like all the other faction missions, so you assume it's going to be another interesting and substantial questline to experience. Only when you finish the first mission you realize you have to purchase the rest of the missions through creations. It's quite obvious it was something originally meant to be completeable in the base game, being the only 'Bounty Hunting' type faction line.

I wouldn't be surprised if in TES VI they lock The Dark Brotherhood or Thieves Guild questlines behind creations as well.

I went into Starfield thinking I’d be the main character, a spacefaring Sigma with infinite rizz, exploring galaxies, pulling alien baddies, and discovering untold wonders. Instead, Todd hit me with the ol’ “It just works” in 4K disappointment.

The planets? More empty than my DMs. I’ve seen Minecraft superflat worlds with more personality. Every time I landed on a new world, I half-expected a Skibidi Toilet to pop up just to give it some life.

The gunplay? Mid. The ships? Yeah, you can build ‘em, but they handle like a brick in zero gravity. And the NPCs? More dead inside than me after watching 300 hours of Ohio memes. I tried to flirt with one, and they gave me dialogue that felt like it came from ChatGPT with a bad Wi-Fi connection. Zero rizz. Negative rizz.

Loading screens? Bro, I’ve seen shorter wait times at McDonald’s ice cream machines. And don’t get me started on the “exploration” — I walked five minutes on one planet and hit an invisible wall. I guess the real “open world” was the friends we didn’t make along the way.

Todd, my man, you promised me space Skyrim. What I got was a PowerPoint presentation on loneliness.

Verdict: Skibidi dop dop dop yes yes yes to uninstall.

Starfield Review: 146 Hours Later and I’ve Ascended Into a Buggy, Glorious Space Nerd

At hour one of Starfield, I thought, “Wow, this could be Skyrim in space!”
At hour 146, I’ve accepted that it’s actually Excel in space, with a faint hint of lore, a sprinkle of combat, and more menu navigation than a 2007 DVD main screen.

Let’s talk about the “vision” here. Todd Howard told us we could “go anywhere.” What he meant was, “You can fast travel to a loading screen, and then fast travel to a slightly different loading screen, and then land on a planet with nothing on it but a rock, six angry space ticks, and a weirdly placed bench.”

Every new planet is like opening a mystery box filled with absolutely nothing. A barren hellscape with the personality of wet cardboard. But somehow,,somehow..I keep going. Because deep down, I am a Starborn. A glowing, cosmic PowerPoint presentation of a person who has now New Game Plus-ed into a full-blown space wizard with a cape and a superiority complex.

And I love it.

The story? Meh. Space politics, cults, multiverse..you know, the usual Thursday night stuff. Honestly, I wasn’t paying attention after I figured out I could throw people across the room with gravity powers like a space Gandalf on pre-workout.

But let's not forget the real magic of Starfield: the ships. Not flying them, no. That would be fun. Instead, building them. For hours. Toggling between modules like a space IKEA engineer who lost the will to live, only to end up with a ship shaped like a toilet that barely flies and somehow weighs more than a neutron star. But you keep doing it. Why? Because your brain is broken and Todd Howard’s got you hooked on virtual clutter and crafting tables.

Speaking of Todd:
Oh, Todd. You magnificent liar. You said there were a thousand planets. You didn’t say 998 of them were procedurally generated deserts with one sad space bear and a half-buried science outpost. At least No Man’s Sky had the decency to admit it was a vibe generator. You? You gave me “NASA-core” aesthetics and said, “This is the future. It’s beige and joyless.”

But here’s the twist. Despite the jank, the bugs, the lifeless planets, the completely baffling UI that requires a PhD in sadness--I’m obsessed. I’ve become the dork I used to mock. I’m walking around in a flowing Starborn cape, muttering about the Unity and acting like I’m some kind of space messiah while looting toilets for credits.

I have spreadsheets for cargo weight. I’ve argued with Vasco like he’s a real person. I’ve shot a pirate in the face because he insulted my ship layout. I am not well.

So yeah, Bethesda, you got me again. Just like you did with Skyrim, Fallout 4, and my childhood. Starfield is a mess, but it’s my mess. A beautiful, sprawling, bug-ridden galactic sandbox where I can pretend I’m important while yelling "I AM STARBORN" at the TV in my pajamas.

Final Verdict: 6/10 for the game. 12/10 for the Starborn cosplay lifestyle. Thanks Todd, you space goblin.
Amazing Graphics, game play and options which keep you engaged for Weeks. Highly recommended.

The Jury is still out on the game, and first impressions are mixed. I'm giving it a thumbs up, but that's subject to change with more play.

The game does have more things to do than "No Man's Sky", but it's ship play is worse, however unlike the latter you can mod your ship, which is a cool feature, and the locations are so much better. I like NMS's play, but damn it got boring fast, and was exceptionally repetitive.  We'll see how Starfield holds up. It does haves 2 major detractors thus far, it lags badly, even on a robust modern system... and that's with the game settings turned down and dynamic resolution turned off. Reminds me of a bad internet connection. I did try it on a system with the minimum requirements and it was obviously worse, until you got into combat with multiple enemy and it became unplayable. The second is the menu system. It's way too convoluted. Some designers really need a lesson in the "KISS" principle. Being it's a Bethesda game, I suppose any fixes will have to come from the MOD community, or not at all.
