Well, the lag problem was 100% due to having installed it on an my second drive which was not an SSD. I rectified that problem by upgrading the drive and all the lag went away and all the scenes load much, much faster now. It even allowed me to turn up the graphic setting back to Ultra. Amazing the difference  between the 2 drive types for game speed. 

After 80+ hours of play, I'm enjoying it, but truthfully there isn't any better than the classic games like Fallout or Skyrim, which are much, much older games. If anything the continual jumping into a ship to go here, there, and everywhere makes it worse. The NPC's are a little better, but the enemy are just raiders in space suits. Except for the cities and bases, the planets themselves are so bad I long for the beauty of Skyrim.

The base building is kind of a joke. In other Bethesda game you could buy prebuilt modules for purchased homes, this one doesn't do that. You hand build everything from an oddly designed list of items, that really doesn't have anything in it. I suppose the modding community will rectify that. The ship building, which is probably the one standout feature, is also lackluster and convoluted. You can't really tell what you're upgrading, or buying, as you have to buy it to look inside. Then it sort of just places portals, ladders, and stuff where it wants to, giving you "zero" options to move things around. This could have been done so much better. 

The plant-side interaction and base building is pretty much a waste of time. Unlike NMS where you have a lot of choices for base building, vehicle types, and diverse planet types, Starfield is rather blah. The planets are mostly the same with different atmospheres. There may be better vehicles further in the game, but thus far the "moon rover" is a joke. It's like trying to drive around in a vehicle with beach ball tires. Which considering the lousy job they did building environments that are overly, and consistently, strewn with large boulders everywhere, the only way you can get around is bouncing off everything, or bouncing over it. It's more akin to playing a Super Mario brother go-cart racing sim. It really detracts from the type of game you were hoping to play. In that aspect, and actually flying a spaceship, No Man's Sky has Starfield beat by a million light years. 

As for things to do, I'll never really understand the overall concept of continual re-spawning of enemies in the same locations. There's only so many times you will want to attack the same place over and over, just to grab some loot. I think it would be better to either conquer the universe, or free it, and gathering loot and upgrading is a reward for doing it. Spend more time in building quality environments where people will want to spend time in them, instead of just procedural generated bland nothingness. Set most of the stores on each planet, Then you have an entire universe to expand into. You're not surviving, your not expanding, and you're not really exploring, which is what a space game should really be about. That is of course my opinion, but if each plant were it's own DLC, there could be a lot of fun, and money to be had. 

That is also where NMS failed. At some point it's all just repetitious blah. There's no reason to explore when there is nothing to really see, and there's no reason to fight when there's nothing to be gained, or lost. At some point it's really just a more in-depth arcade game, with occasional stories thrown in to break up the monotony. 

You'd think that after all these years, someone at Bethesda would look at what the MOD community is doing, and what the player base is saying, besides just their testing and control groups. There's a wealth of information to be gained, but you have to seek it out, and stay away from the Microsoft mindset of thinking you, and only you, know what's best for everyone else. Are you looking, are you listening?... or are you just patting each other on the back and "sniffing your own farts" -  A South Park reference. 

Does any of this mean the game isn't worth playing, no, absolutely not. It has it's fun side, and I've spent many hours proving it to myself, but it could have been better, and it's certainly not worth the hype or the price tag. They really could have made this something, but with poor base building, mediocre ship building, horrible planet-side interaction and ship flying simulation, it's just a 5

Oh, and one thing to add, they really need to fix the NPC continually blocking the damn doorways and cramped aisle-ways.  That has been an issue in all their games. I realize that the NPC are supposed to act like real humans, but is it necessary to make them act like woman at a grocery store?

///Update part 2///
A lot more time into it and my original comments still hold true. I did however download some mods as the base game is well... not the greatest, especially that stupid rover. A modded vehicle made planet movement tolerable, although the maps are all pretty much repetitive junk. They really need to focus on each planet as a DLC. Again this game could really be something if someone had a brain.

Great visuals could use some online game play but nice narrative and space game play

Unfortunatly, Starfield lost what made others Bethesda's Open world so good. A living and interesting map.
In those previous titles, maps were engineered in a way that made players wander around. Quest asks you to go from point A to point B. But since you've not visited point B yet, you can't fast travel, so you have to walk there. And that's when the magic happens. You were bound to stumble on something : a new location to explore, a dungeon, a new questline or an NPC companion.

In Starfield however, since you're going from planets to planets, and they are not physically linked, fast travel is available from the start and actually your only option to get from A to B. So you end up in an awful gameloop of fast travel, talk to npc, fast travel, shoot npc, fast travel talk to npc. Over and over again. No wandering, no feeling of discovery nor exploration which is terrible for a game which story line revolve around space exploration...
Even if you try to force exploration in your game by going to random planets and explore, they feel empty because they are randomly generated from a very limited number of assets. The few locations that are handcrafted (the major cities) actually do feel quite intersting but unfortunatly they are too small.
On top of that the game is quite outdated technologically and the player choices do feel inconsequential a lot of the time. Most dialogues option resumes to yes, yes but being smurk, no, leave conversation.
Overall the main issues this game has comes from it's design and are not something that can be fixed really unfortunatly.
Let's just hope that bethesda will learn from this massive mistake and come back to handcrafting the map of TES VI

I did like some aspects of this game. The story picks up about halfway through the main quest, but fizzles out in the end. Ground combat was fun. That's about it.

Base building is unnecessary and tedious. Space combat is clunky and difficult (get good I guess). Looting seems like a main piece of gameplay but also not required at all. Dialogue is at times very poorly written, and the way the scene jumps between characters has incredible amounts of jank. 

All in all I think I enjoyed a single quest. Way too much content, too much bloat, no focus on quality. After 10 hours I raced through the rest of the main quest just to see how it ends, and was disappointed with that too. I will not be playing again.

[hr]
Starfield is an "Open World" space game that mixes gameplay between Fallout 4 and TES: Skyrim in terms of powers. I knew what I was getting into as Bethesda is known for their portfolio of bugs and "It just works" attitude. The marketing of this game was promoted as "NASA-Punk", which initially caught my interest. Unfortunately, I was not expecting that this game would completely change my view in a negative way towards Bethesda and Microsoft in the video game industry.

Let's start with the game engine itself. It uses Creation Engine 2, an "upgraded" version of Creation Engine. This engine really gave mod developers a strong footing in their hobby and the modding community in general. I myself developed several mods in the graphics department for Fallout 4 and Skyrim and studied the engine in terms of graphical perspective. While that is a positive, the engine is extremely outdated technical wise, and based on what I've seen on this game and the promotion of version 2, I see the opposite of an "upgrade". And to my understanding, they keep using this engine in hopes of modders to fix and give the mod popularity treatment, which is not a professional move.

[hr]
[b]Here are my problems with this game:[/b]

[olist]
[*]The majority of this game is loading screens - entering a building, entering your ship, entering an elevator, literal movement leads to loading screens which completely eliminates the "Open World" aspect of the game. Not good for showcasing the Creation Engine 2's "upgrade".

[*]Graphical quality and models are horrible, even at high graphical preset. I doubt the graphical and model departments even cleaned up and optimized their work. Bad model render and low resolution textures and sometimes seams in some aspects. Also, majority of the graphics are behind under filters, the colors feel washed out in some areas which does not give a good presentation in some scenarios, specifically interiors and dungeons. Again, not good for showcasing the Creation Engine 2's "upgrade".

[*]General unoptimization and bugs that are even worse than Bethesda's previous works. Again, not good for showcasing the Creation Engine 2's "upgrade".

[*]It is interesting to land on a planet which generates new land each time. However, the POIs are very limited and overall feel empty on majority of the planets. You would figure that with the lore technology humanity has gained, you would see some interesting events. Again, not good for showcasing the Creation Engine 2's "upgrade".

[*]Game Design is literally broken or doesn't exist. The skill tree does not make sense gameplay wise.

Example #1: In order to upgrade your lockpicking skill, you have to lockpick a level above your current level, but the game will not let you challenge a higher level of what you are currently at. How are you supposed to improve your skills with this gameplay design?

Example #2: The game states that you can be a pirate and smuggle goods, but there is absolutely no way to smuggle. Every time you enter a civilized star system, the authorities will automatically scan your cargo without giving you options or strategies to by-pass it. To summarize, there is no way to be a pirate.
(Edit: Upon researching, there are some ship upgrades that will lower the chance of getting spotted. While at least its better than nothing, but for a AAA game this is not a good solution.)

[*]The story and character writing are absolutely horrible and uninspiring. None of the characters are interesting or engaging. The characters you meet keeps on trauma dumping and are extremely judgmental towards you and the actions you commit. To put it short; you can not win with them. Also, the factions literally feel the same with different hues of colors, all working for the same goal but with different wordplay.

[*]The game is rated M for Mature. However, this game does not deserve that rating at all. This deserves Everyone 10+ at best. All the things I have seen and heard in this game are sanitized to the point where I feel like I am playing "Hello Kitty Barbie Tea Party Space Adventure".
[/olist]

[hr]
Overall, I am extremely disappointed in this game that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. I really love the concept of NASA-Punk, but Starfield is an F-rated execution. Bethesda/Microsoft bent the knee to a certain audience which I believe does not exist nor is targeted to the right audience in both customer's and developer's point of view, which ultimately led to execution of poor and not thought-out ideas, especially on storytelling, which is a major flaw on Bethesda's portfolio. This does not give me faith in their future works.

Before the release, I was sceptical but excited.

The dream died during my first session. It should be a criminal offence, for a studio responsible for titles like Skyrim and Fallout to release...this. An inch-shallow puddle, with outdated graphics, practically non-existent narrative and laughably poor mechanics. This is an affront to every single Bethesda supporter.

I don't know where to start and I'm not really keen on saying too much. There are exhaustive reviews telling you everything you need to know about this...whatever this is.

If I didn't know better, I would've believed it's a parody. It's like Inception and Minority Report had an IVF baby, delivered by a doctor with the diploma from Temu. You wake up from one loading screen only to find yourself inside another, and the amount of screens, tabs, submenus you need to go through in order to complete a single task is, for all practical purposes, always +1.

The worst part, to me personally, is the visual side of the game. Everything looks disinfected and plastic. The last-gen lighting is atrocious. There's no perceivable depth in any location you go to. Everything is popping in your face, and sharp, crystal clear contours and colours slap you on the face like you were tripping on something. NPCs look like mannequins and behave like androids. The facial animation is so bad I would pay to have an option to turn it off entirely.

Save your time, save your money, respect your mental health.

Most recent update to this game has made it unplayable.  Nothing works, it crashes at the tutorial, and every update they've put out this last year has broken the game.  I'm throwing in the towel on getting this game to work.  The memory leak from last year that causes this game to not release system resources until it crashes is still here and unfixed and there's no mod to fix it either.  It does not help, by the way, that there's a strictly enforced policy of toxic positivity in the feedback forums (you get banned for even the most innocuous criticism).

This is a turd that Bethesda simply cannot polish no matter what they do.

Well I put some time into the game a while back and was hoping for some recent updates or changes. 
This is completely terrible. 

If you are looking for this type of game with space involved go play Outworlds. Then wait for the 2nd one to come out and it will still be better than this. 
I really wanted a full fleshed games. Not the same "Dungeons" repeated with the same enemies and lack of weaponry.

So, spoiler alert... of sorts... this game and its actual storyline is literally designed around the NewGame+ ('NG+') mechanic - a form of 'prestige' progression where, in order to progress the actual storyline, you have to 'start over' multiple times and every time with only your XP and personal skill points/learned abilities from the previous game... no stuff, no ships (spoiler: [spoiler]except for one [/spoiler]), no records of exploration, no previous quest progress.  The whole thing is lazily hand-waved away (almost bordering 4th-wall-breaking) by in-universe techno-babble - and the explanation itself isn't even that compelling... again, pretty lazy. Wouldn't be so bad if it was only one apsect of many in the game - but it's the whole crux of the game and plot.

ALL of the effort of a single playthrough (easily 100s of hours) of exploration, questing, building a home base for yourself, building comraderie with your companions - everything that would appeal to most players  - is completely pointless as none of it actually has any mechanism that allows any of the benefit of that time spent to be carried forward into future progression.  The only thing that you can carry forward, is a single main-story quest, and the hours upon hours of XP earned though what is, at best, a mediocre combat system that can be easily 'cheesed' to make the player OP 99% of the time.  This was a deliberate decision by the game creators, that had the unfortunate side-effect of rendering 90% of what is already over-promised/un-delivered 'full-yet-still-somehow-empty' content in the game utterly pointless.... questing, exploration, socializing, advancements of most kinds... pointless if a player intends on seeing the actual storyline to its conclusion.

The combat system, itself, is not terrible per se, it's just that it is literally the only thing that matters for 'progression' - and that one mechanic, on its own, is not enough to carry the game by ANY stretch of the imagination; as all of the other mechanisms for earning player XP (which, again, is the only thing carried forward to new games) have been nerfed through the ground by the Devs multiple times since the game release, forcing players who legitimately want to experience the actual content of the game (such as it is) to be punished for 'wasting' time on mechanics that offer nothing of value to actual game progression. Sure, if you want to play casually and never start a new game after your current playthrough, you can build-out and explore to your heart's content, but you're literally missing out on the Main Storyline. 

Should you choose to finally pursue that main story, be prepared to give up EVERYTHING you've done in a single game - and not in a fun way.  The tradeoff of this 'forced' NewGame+ mechanic is just objectively bad and very poorly implemented by the game creators - which wouldn't be so bad if the actual storyline wasn't so... flat and uninspired.

StarField has consistently been a game where there is SO MUCH potential in the gameworld that has been created - but bone-headed and extremely short-sighted decisionmaking on the part of the initial game creators (and now also the current Devs) have rendered what should have been an exceptional era-defining title into an excercise in tedium; tedium made all the worse in that 90% of it doesn't matter since you can't carry it forward, and the 10% that does carry forward is simply not compelling enough to justify the rest.

Starfield is two different game archetypes rolled into one... unfortunately, the two archetypes are fundamentally incompatible with one another. All the execs who signed off on trying to blend the two genres together should be taken out back and horse-whipped - whichever game archetype you choose to play through, you will only be playing 'half' the game at any one time - and be fundamentally cutoff from the other half, which makes trying to play both at once all the more painful. I personally prefer the 'open world ARPG you can play for 100s of hours' aspect of the game over the 'grind the prestige system' (aka NG+) over and over for advancement and the [i][b]chance[/b][/i] (not guaranteed) to get differences or changes in each new univers... erm... NewGame+ run.

[i]Disclaimer: I got this title for free a few days before launch because it came bundled with an AMD GPU I was already planning on purchasing - the free game came as a surprise. I wasn't planning on purchasing regularly, but I thought I would give it a try since it was Bethesda.... needless to say, it's been quite the disappointment.[/i]

the $60 pricetag is... not worth it.  If it gets a steep discount (50% or more) in the future, then I could suggest picking up the title, just so that players can experience that first playthrough and all the gameworld has to offer to a first-time player.  Unfortunately, players need to know that they will be missing out on the resolution of the main storyline should they choose not to allow themselves to be 'penalized' by the making use of the NG+ mechanic that forces the loss of ALL previous gametime invested in the game, except the combat XP.

I would not recommend purchasing the DLC... at all... ever.  It doesn't add enough to justify ANY pricetag, and paid DLC for a game so filled with wasted potential does not really deserve to be rewarded with additional $.


[i][b]REVIEW UPDATE:[/b]  The devs of the game (Finally!) ended up streamlining the add-on functions of the game, so that players did not have to rely on 3rd party Add-On managers (like Nexus Mods, etc).  Unfortunately, even though most of the addons are literally ONLY COSMETIC and do not affect actual gameplay in any way, any addons that a player installs (except a few select in-house addons) will disable achievement progress unless those addons are PAID versions.  Literally the exact same addons, with no code changes, are forced (by the Devs) to become paid addons that ask for real life $$ (so that the Devs get a % cut of that purchase) and suddenly become 'achievement-friendly' when installed despite the aforementioned no need to actually change the code itself.  This had quite the chilling effect on the addon development community, and as such there are a lot of abandoned addons out there now because of that decision (and the fact that the game is just not that great to begin with, despite its immense potential).  If you don't care about achievements, then it's probably no big deal - but if you're someone who already struggles with accepting games with NewGame+/Prestige mechanics like this, then the loss of achievement progress over added COSMETICS will likely make that pill all the harder to swallow[/i]

I spent 30 hours on this game and completed the main quest. 95% of it was "go get this" or "go kill this". Horrible writing via several outsourced studios. 

Dialogue, I'm not exaggerating, couldn't be anything less than a 6th grader's doing. I wouldn't believe any studio employee that told me AI wasn't used for most of the cringey/boring/childish characters and dialogue choices. Companions constantly interrupt you to talk about moronic things like "how they fit in" or "my kid keeps leaving her tools out" despite literally spending hours ravaging through other people. It just doesn't make any sense. Poor writing.

Graphics are on par with other games I played 10 years ago. That's all I got for that. They're not great. They're not horrible. Outdated.

The game they supposedly spent "10 years on" is no less than a space set Fallout 4, minus interesting world immersion. They somehow thought just jamming a map full of random planets and fetch quests/kill orders was going to be up to par with Fallout and TES. Shitty plot, shitty FPS combat, shitty ship combat,  shitty world immersion, and overall just an embarrassment. This studio developed Skyrim 14+ years ago, and I'm pretty sure I'm gonna hold off on TES6 if this is the path BGS is going down. This is clearly a cash grab void of artistic writing or effort in general and is a testament to a studio at the end of their road.

Now to be fair, a few main story quests were interesting, and I won't spoil them. The UC/Crimson Fleet faction questline was interesting. Ship building and configuring is fun, although it takes a while before you can really get into it (which is understandable in terms of pacing the game).

I spent $60 on this game and I strongly recommend not making the same mistake in this economy.

Hundreds of planets and, honestly, what is even there to see? Same dungeons, same biomes, same enemies. Starfield is a mile-wide puddle that boldly goes against Bethesda's greatest strength, a seamless, hand-crafted open world. Instead, we get procedurally generated landscapes with identical experiences. 

I want to climb that mountain, Todd, but only if someone put it there.

Just overall highly meh.

The people at Besthesda now rely on past successes and think that they don't have to improve on their game design (or on their engine for that matter) ever again. The graphics can't compete with other games in the genre that are older than it (Cyberpunk, Red dead Redemption 2), the story is uninspired slop, the sidequests and stories even more so. There are a few nice stories and encounters here and there but not nearly enough to make the massive world feel alive and entertaining.

The Gameplay is just copy-pasted from Fallout 4. There is nothing else to be said.

And on top of that they still haven't removed all those goddamn loading screens. The amount of loading screens in Fallout 4 was already bad enough (compared to the Witcher 3, which was released in the same year), but somehow they actually managed to make it WORSE in this game. Step into your ship - Loading screen - Take off - Loading screen - Fly to another system - Loading screen - Fly to a planet within that system - Loading screen - Land on that planet - Loading screen - Enter a Building on that planet - Loading screen. On an average bounty hunt mission I see more loading screens than enemies. How is that fun?

If you just want to play Fallout with some new paint slapped on it go ahead and buy this game. But you still shouldn't expect to be amazed by anything you experience in this game. It is all just soo meh.

EDIT: to get rid of the stuttering and audio desync try installing it on your boot drive, that worked for me!

Starfield — A Galactic Disappointment

I bought Starfield at full price on release, hoping for the groundbreaking space epic the marketing promised. Instead, what I got feels like a relic from the early 2010s. The game is poorly optimized that break any sense of immersion.

The “vast, customizable, endlessly fun” experience Bethesda hyped up is just marketing smoke. The worlds feel empty and repetitive, the quests are predictable, and the exploration loop becomes stale within hours. It’s less like stepping into a living galaxy and more like wandering through copy pasted environments that forgot to evolve past last decade’s design.

The only thing that meets 2025s current standards is the gunplay, but that just passes the bar by only a bit.

For the price and promises, this feels more like a bait-and-switch than a next-gen space adventure.
Overall I like it. It's fun.

Leave it to community as you always did ffs.

This game was a large-scale endeavor that was ultimately abandoned.

Although spacecraft were created, they lacked the ability to fly. The use of teleportation rendered the spacecraft redundant, as planets were merely standalone instances that couldn't be accessed by flying to or within them.

It featured the most extensive handcrafted instances, yet these were diluted amidst the vastness of the cosmos. The developers didn't differentiate between manually crafted and procedurally generated content, making it hard to fathom the time and luck required to encounter them.

Nonetheless, it's an irreplaceable title, offering gameplay and storylines unmatched by Star Citizen, and landscapes in a realistic style that No Man's Sky cannot achieve. It's suited for a traveler rich in time, who wants to leisurely enjoy interstellar journeys and explore the unknown.

Its experience is indeed difficult to evaluate, but ultimately it will be discovered by a group of players who appreciate its unique qualities, as there truly isn't another game that can replace it at present.

Despite the odd controversy over this game, I think its one of the best space exploration games that manages to stay relatively grounded compared to more science fantasy genres. Feels heavily inspired by NASA-punk themed IPs such as the movie Interstellar. Give it a shot and don't judge it based on sensationalist controversy generated by game journalists.

Starfield is one of those games that I really want to love.

I'm a big fan of Bethesda's work, first being introduced to them through Morrowind. But Starfield is the first game from Bethesda that I can't recommend, and I keep trying to find that same feeling Morrowind gave me.

Starfield has a lot going for it. Ship battles and customization can be fun. The same kind of Fallout-esque first person shooter style fun with a lot of loot to sort through. By all accounts this SHOULD be a hit.

The issues where this games struggles, and where I see several space type games failing, is the transition between space and planets. So much of this game is loading screens because you load to travel to a planet, you load to land, you briefly load to get out of your ship, and if you're real lucky, you'll load again to enter a building. And then you'll spend a brief time in that area and end up doing that all again just to sell off your loot.

While I get the attempt to make a more realistic space game, I'm furious that every person you speak with is human... if you're going to make a space game without aliens, you need to make me care about the different factions in the story, and to be honest, they're pretty lame. The only faction that made me care was the UC sysdef, and that's because I really want to kill their leader everytime I accidentally get caught with contraband I didn't even know was on this ship I'm trying to register...

Setting up outposts, researching, making weapon and armor mods, these should all be less painful systems. I try my best to utilize those systems because that's such a big chunk of getting the weapons you want, but it is such a time suck.

EDIT: Another point I thought of that absolutely drives me crazy is how the best stories in this game are the things you heard about that happened in the past, or that you find through writing. I understand that lore and world building is a key point for Bethesda games, but if you're offering me the choice between a time where I have to listen to an ultra-wealthy man and a priest argue about whether a space rock was sent from god or not, or a time where there are interplanetary battles taking place with xenowarfare and mechs, I'm going to choose the latter... there are also so many points in the game where they could have leaned further into the space horror or cosmic horror of the game, and they don't. Basically what I'm saying is this is the unseasoned chicken of games, and I know for a fact there's a whole spice rack that could have been used...

----SPOILERS BELOW!!!!----

While I love the endgame idea of kind of restarting the whole thing from the beginning, and letting you choose how you approach that restart, there's not enough in the game to make me care about that.

Ultimately, I'll keep coming back to this game from time to time, but it'll never be quite what I'm looking for.

Starfield is an open-world game following the same familiar formula as other Bethesda games. Interactive NPC followers, shops, resource management, outpost building, character customization, skill specialization, leveled lists, etc. 

However, Starfield builds upon these staples with procedural world terrain generation as well as the unique-to-Starfield (for Bethesda) space exploration and starship builder. There is a good amount of complexity in outpost management, weapon/armor/ability customization, and starship building/management, and you will definitely find yourself short on time to complete everything you want long before you run out of customizations to complete. There are the usual supply of abundant main and side quests to immerse yourself in the various factions and character stories of the game, including purchasing home sites at some locations which can also be customized with furnishings inside. 

Unfortunately, there is a short supply activities to enjoy outside of quest lines and resource management tasks available in the game. So those without the motivation to conquer complexity may quickly run out of reasons to play after completing quest lines. 

The combat becomes pretty redundant quickly as the NPC enemies are overly-scripted in combat, including in space (enemies are immovable rubber-banding objects that aren't tethered to any type of physics and have scripted movements until defeated, at which point they become rag doll objects you can push around).

There is a good variety of alien lifeforms to discover and combat in the game, providing the most thrilling combat experiences in the game (Think a hammerhead shark and a T-Rex mix chasing you through a forest!). They greatly outshine all other combat situations (human and starship) and feel the most immersive without question.

General NPC dialogue is enough to feel slight immersion in and out of combat, so long as you don't spend too much time talking to them (you will start to notice the slim variety of voices and lines). 

Companions are useful in combat and while exploring planets, but feel incredibly lackluster in character development (there are literally no activities unique to them outside of scripted dialogue backstories and relationship satisfaction metrics that affect dialogue with the player character). Companions surely shine their best as carefully assigned starship crew when combat arises (they provide many awesome benefits to your ship's capabilities that are unattainable without them). 

All-in-all this game is a homage to players who yearned for expansive worlds that technology could not yet provide in the old days, and to lovers of single player self-paced story-telling and character progression you can pick up and play as much or as little as you like when you have time. Yet Starfield will struggle to satisfy modern gamers who seek content variety, online play and mod support. 

Not the best open world game out there (I even prefer Fallout 4 in many ways over it), but it is certainly one of the largest to explore. 

Not a lot of immersion or control of star ships other than very basic combat in planetary orbit and shipbuilding itself, but enough customization variety to create a semi-believable star ship ownership experience. 

Character appearance customization is one of the highlights, although clothing choices are easily among the worst I have ever experienced in a game. So you'll enjoy making your character, so long as you don't mind dressing them like an NPC afterwards. 

Bethesda has given us our first land vehicle (and it is MUCH appreciated!), but it tries to be a Mass Effect Mako without approaching the same combat effectiveness. It will make your planetary travels MUCH faster, but provides literally no other usable benefits (the one weapon it has does just enough damage to aggro enemies). 

This game feels VERY dumbed down and excels at nothing to create a neutrally-consistent experience for everyone. Unfortunately that consistency quickly becomes repetition and monotony during extended play. 

The quests are rich in backstory, though the activities are repetitive (go here, kill this). There is unfortunately no strategy or problem solving outside of Digipicks (lock-picking) due to the scripted combat movements of enemy NPC (they literally just rubber band in combat and possess no physics until defeated). Even in tasks where you are given the opportunity to choose between stealth or brute force (such as bounty hunter quests), the choice is really just a scripted dialogue choice that is specific to scripted quest line situations only (like unique one-time bounty targets). Every open world repeatable quest is simply shoot and kill. Even if you disarm enemies with non-lethal EM weapons, they won't allow you to take them as a prisoner. The only effective use of EM weapons is to neutralize native lifeforms to harvest (which provides no benefit over killing them outright and then harvesting them) and the very scripted mission in New Atlantis where you must not kill any hostile citizens. 

I love the game, but it feels very rushed out or stripped down regarding content enrichment. It is very well-polished and gorgeous though. 

I rate story development 7/10 for rich dialogue, numerous cutscenes specific to your choices in the game, and generous experience gains from quests, but lack of mission variety, unique quest rewards and overly-basic companion interactions.

I rate combat 4/10 for cool weapon customization, but scripted enemy combat movements, rubber banding and lack of weapon variety (no rockets, no special kill visuals, no grappling, no melee combat outside of single-slashing with blade) causing combat to become boring very quickly.

I rate exploration 6/10 for immense landscapes, unique procedurally generated maps, cool diversity of biomes and huge variety of creatures, but no aquatic or submerged exploration (the surface swimming is more of an insult as it kills you on almost all planets), no activities outside of scripted quest lines, copy and pasted locations and a lack of variety in location diversity (often putting lush tropical oasis in the middle of frozen biomes or placing frozen icebergs in the middle of a completely arid desert biome as copium)

I rate outpost/starship building and management 7/10 for immensely detailed customization, complex mechanics, freedom of choice, and facility progression tied seamlessly to character progression and build, lacking meaningful activities with other characters, and limited control of active base/ship functions (you can't "fly" your starship wherever you'd like, most instances are replaced with a copy and pasted take-off/landing cutscene.  

My overall rating of the game is 6/10. It is a replayable open-world shooter with an emphasis on base-building and resource management. But it does not reward extended play once you have completed quest content.

I've spent over 700 hours on Starfield, and I've unlocked every achievement. Starfield is a game I enjoy playing, but it has issues making sense. It feels like two different games: the enjoyable and addictive Bethesda gameplay loop, and a world that seems like it was created by a group, where each piece of lore contradicts the others.

I loved the shipbuilding mechanic; it's one of the best parts of the game. For a game with exploration as a main selling point, it's not engaging, and the rewards are not there. Scanning planets for slates, that's it.

I do not mind the procedural generation and the POIs, but the repetitiveness of them will bore you. Environmental storytelling was missing; the only POI I remember with this was the pirate base on Kreet. Why is there a research lab on this planet? Why did the Ecliptic raid this mine? Why is a group of scientists here? What are they researching?

Combat is good; I'm not a fan of fast-paced shooters, so for me, it's good and enjoyable. It must have been nice to have more variety of weapons, though.

NPCs will forget who you are, even if you met them before (looking at you, Admiral Logan).

This is a problem similar to Skyrim. You can be a pilot for the UC Vanguard (even one of the founders of UC's new division), a Freestar Ranger, and a member of the Crimson Fleet pirates—all at the same time, with no one batting an eye. There's no faction reputation system that makes your choices feel like they matter. This completely breaks the immersion and makes the galaxy feel like a theme park, where you can ride every ride without any repercussions. I would prefer they took Fallout 4's faction implementation over what we have now.

Shattered Space DLC is mediocre. Why make being a member of House Varuun mandatory? They should have made it optional. The questline and story are interesting, revealing some mysteries, but it's not enough. Only played the DLC for the achievement and never touched it again.

NG+ gives players another avenue of choices without starting a new character every time, which is a huge plus for me.

I stayed away from this game for a long time due to the negativity surrounding it. After giving it a go, I actually find it really immersive. Yeah the planets can be copy and paste sometimes, but following the questlines I found myself able to explore really well put together settlements, talk to a lot of NPC's and pick up some quests, find some bounty targets.. the questlines are really good too, each one takes you to at least 2 or 3 'dungeons' if you will, full of enemies and glorious loot. I'm really enjoying the game, I've had barely any performance issues, just one crash in 33 hours, and it really does look incredible. Bethesda didn't deserve the hate for this game, and if they release more dlc and further updates, this game will be such an underrated gem. Skyrim will always breathe down Bethesda's necks and cause enormous expectations from the fans, I think Starfield deserves a chance to be beside Fallout and the Elder Scrolls, 100 percent.

I’m giving Starfield an 8/10 as it is a good game, but not GOTY.  It’s similar to Elder Scrolls or Fallout except it is focused on space travel and exploration.  It does a lot of things well, and others leave you scratching your head as to why the developers implemented some mechanics the way they did.

My main complaint is that space ships are controlled using a mouse and keyboard or a console style controller.  There is no native joystick/HOTAS support.  Some folks defend this oversight by stating Starfield is not a space sim, yet a good deal of your time will be spent in your ship flying around and fighting “in space”.  I hope to see joystick support added in a future patch (hint, hint).

The main storyline has you unraveling a mystery that takes you all over the known galaxy in which there are 120-star systems and 1700 planets to visit.   Several of the systems are colonized and controlled by different factions; some friendly and of course many systems are controlled by outlaws and pirates.  You can jump to the different systems using your Grav drive then scan the planets and moons to see their topographical layout including different regional biomes.  Biomes support different flora (plants), fauna (life forms), and resources.  You may have to travel to several different biomes to scan an entire planet.  Scanned planet and system data can be turned in to different NPCs or sold for credits to vendors.

Different planets and moons will have various gravity, atmosphere, and points of Interest (POI).  Some of the POIs are mission related and others are randomly generated for you to go scan or explore.  (They are kind of like camps and dungeons in other Bethesda games.)  During the games initial release, you had to walk/run from your ship to these scattered POIs.  Now there are vehicles you can use to drive or fly to get there faster.

There is the main story line, faction missions, activity missions, miscellaneous and random missions that just pop up.  Bethesda implemented random “radiant” quests (called missions here) in previous games.  For instance, you can pop into a system and a researcher may hail you and ask if you have any resources they can trade for.  You could find a ship on a planet and the pilot is working on it because it broke down causing them to make a forced landing.  There are also mission boards you can visit to pick up various random missions.  So, there is always something to do.

The voice acting is well done and NPC facial animations express emotion which helps with immersion.   As with other Bethesda titles, there are NPCs that mill around and travel from place to place, and static NPCs that are vendors and related to the many available missions.

The ground combat AI is “OK” as NPCs will take cover, step out from cover to shoot at you, and throw grenades.  But, depending on how realistic you like things, it could be considered too easy.  For instance, NPCs in installations will fight you until they are dead, but since they never set off an alarm, none of the other NPCs in the same installation will come to their aid.  Also, the sneak mechanic is kind of broken as all you have to do is wait a while and the NPCs figure you have run off and they will then go back to what they were doing, even walking past their dead companions lying on the ground.  There are several AI mods that improve NPC combat that makes it much more challenging.

Ship space combat is also just OK.  Ships warp in and you’ll be engaged in battle in which you can either just shoot through their shields and hull to destroy them, or lock onto a single ship, then select from different sub systems such as weapons, shields, engines, or Grav drive to take out individually.  Taking out a ships Grav drive prevents it from escaping, while taking out their engines lets you dock and board the ship.  Once inside you can kill the crew and take over the ship, adding it to your fleet.

There are a lot of different weapon types to choose from including sniper rifles, shotguns, pistols, grenade launchers, miniguns, and melee weapons.  You can improve weapons and suits at crafting benches (after unlocking the appropriate skills) and some weapons and suits come with special perks such as increasing weapon fire rate, or a suits protection against energy weapons.

There are various crafting skills and benches.  You can craft basic items, but will need to spend skill points into the crafting skills in order to make better quality weapon and suits.

Ship building is modular.  There are 3 classes of ships, based on reactor size, and you can buy, sell, build and modify to your hearts content.  Mostly.  There is a cap of 10 ships you can own.

The skill system is vast, with 5 different area covering personal improvement, research, combat, exploration, and ship systems.  Unfortunately, there are way more skills than you will ever have enough skill points to unlock unless you get to level 300 or so.  So, you have several choices… decide on a limited “build” that you put those precious points into, leaving you unable to do other things, use a mod to increase the number of skill points gained per level (I find 3 per level is about right), or use the console command to give yourself points or skills.  Many will say the last two options are cheats, and rightfully so, but I play games for enjoyment not frustration.

You can build outposts on planets and moons, place various HABs (habitat enclosures), resource extractors, and outpost defenses.  Outposts are similar to settlements in Fallout.  This is where you can collect raw materials for crafting or create a home out among the stars.

Completing the main storyline can create quite a dilemma for you as it offers some (game) life altering choices.  I’m not going to add spoilers, so if you want to know, go do an online search for it or just play though the game. 

As with other Bethesda games, StarField is better with mods.  You can find good ones, both free and paid ones, in the in game Creations section.  There are also a lot at Starfield Nexus.  I run about 175 mods that actually make the game harder (more realistic) than cheaty.  For instance, NO fast travel, Medkits, digipicks and ammo all have weight instead of 0.00, food doesn't provide instant healing but crafted food provides better buffs than packaged foods, Grav jumps require Real Fuel (Helium-3).  There are some that give you an edge like extracting and installing mods on guns and weapons.  But, again, that is something you would expect could and should exist.  

TLDR;  Vanilla Starfield is an 8/10.  With mods, it easily becomes 9.9/10 (still needs joystick support) and one of the most enjoyable games I’ve ever played, including Skyrim.

PS.. I noticed a little star that says my review is not considered in the overall Positive/Negative survey count because I activated StarField with a Steam Key.  That is BS.  I bought the $300 constellation package and HAD to register it with a key code.  So if you can't already tell from my review +1 to POSITIVE.

This is a Bethesda game, so if you've played other Bethesda games (Skyrim, Fallout 4, etc.), you'll have a rough idea of what to expect.

But this is a game set in space. Space is a yawning black void of seemingly infinite nothingness, and Bethesda have accurately captured this ambience by making it more boring than a party political broadcast from Gordon Boring, Minister of Boring, from the Boring Party.

Just so you know, I'm not a member of the Todd Howard hate-boner club. I've spent huge chunks of my adult life scampering through Skyrim's frosty environs and throwing small nuclear bombs at people in Fallout's Commonwealth. I love nothing more than a good Bethesda open-world explorathon, but this game... Dear Lord, what were they thinking?!

Initially, I was enthused. I was anticipating great things. I was prepared to be gobsmacked. And because I'm an easily-impressed simpleton at the best of times, I kept waiting for interesting stuff to happen. For those "Ooooh! What's in here?" moments you expect from a Bethesda game. Instead I spent a lot of time wandering around like a confused pensioner, wondering what I was supposed to do next, cursing the horrible user interface, and hoping something cool would be over the next ridge. Or the one after that. Or the one after that. But there was never anything cool. Just another vast expanse of AI-generated slop with the same copy/paste factory, or cave, or mining outpost, populated by the same generic "bad men with guns" or "helpless colonists" or "angry robots".

Starfield is a game that makes you wish you were playing something other than Starfield. Sometimes I'd get so bored I'd get up and do household chores rather than keep playing. I have a pathological hatred of household chores, but given the choice, I'd go do laundry or vacuum the stairwell than spend another hour shuffling despondently across a dreary, rock-strewn plateau waiting for some guy in a spacesuit to start shooting at me for the 57th time. (Or I'd just play Fallout 4 instead.)

It's not all bad. The main quest, though slow to start, is pretty engaging once it gathers momentum. Likewise, the faction and major side quests. The game certainly looks nice. It's stuffed to the gunnels with the usual Bethesda jank -- NPCs getting stuck on the scenery, inanimate objects rocketing around the room because the physics system has imploded, and occasionally you'll exit your ship only to load in trapped beneath the boarding ramp, fast travel being your only means of escape. The voice actors all put in a solid performance, the combat mechanics are by no means revolutionary, but they're at least as good as Fallout 4, and the music's suitably pleasant. It's when you wander off the beaten path and look for extraneous things to do that it all falls sideways over a cliff. And for a Bethesda game, this is the kiss of death.

Bethesda nerds play Bethesda games because we love the freedom to go wherever we want, whenever we want, and do pretty much whatever we want when we get there. Both Skyrim and Fallout 4 gave us a hand-crafted world, densely packed with hand-crafted locations, full of interesting characters or at the very least, some environmental story-telling. NPCs, notes, computer log entries, they all worked together to give us a sense of these locations being actual places, existing for actual reasons, and within them we were given meaningful things to do. (Radiant quests have always been a nice idea in theory, but considerably less engaging in practice, so let's not talk about those right now.)

Starfield gives you endless torrents of procedurally-generated dog-water to wade through, and almost all of it is mind-numbingly dull. I get that space is like, really big and stuff, and hand-crafting entire solar systems would likely mean the game wouldn't have a release date before the year 2058, but some kind of compromise would have been nice. Maybe if Bethesda had reined in the ambition a little bit, choosing instead to work on a smaller, more curated experience.

Seriously, is anyone really interested in 500 planets if they know 450 of them have been crapped out by Chat-GPT? This stuff was boring back when the first Mass Effect game was released. Driving the Mako (which handled as though it was made of balsa wood and helium) around the surface of Generic Planet #839 in search of Salarian relics was utterly monotonous, and Starfield's rendition of the same repetitive nonsense is just as insufferable. Please don't make me pilot a vehicle that is possessed by demons across interminable miles of nothing. It's the opposite of fun and it will make me hate your game. (And if you make me walk, I will place a curse upon your entire bloodline lasting until the heat-death of the universe.)

But, but, but... space battles?! Space travel boils down to "clickety-clickety-clickety-WOOSH!", and interstellar combat is basically, "Oh no! Pirates!", followed by roughly three minutes of "shooty-shooty-blam-blam-BOOM!" Then, because you need to use your grav-drive to jump to another star system, it's more "clickety-clickety-clickety-WOOSH!" However, if you need to land on the planet, it's a variation of "clickety-clickety-clickety-WOOSH!", followed by a brief cutscene, after which you wander aimlessly like a clinically-depressed homeless person across a boring landscape (it might be verdant green, or cobalt blue, or soiled-undergarments brown, but it's always boring), then you have a chat with someone deeply forgettable, briefly participate in some anticlimactic "pew-pew-pew!", then "clickety-clickety-clickety-WOOSH!" back to the cold, uncaring vacuum of space. Rinse and repeat until you can feel your soul actively trying to escape your body.

I so wanted this game to be good. But it's not. It's a steaming wheelbarrow-load of wasted potential. Bethesda are better than this. Buy it if it's on sale, and only if the discount is seriously hefty. Otherwise, there are far better ways to waste the remaining sad, purposeless moments of your sorry existence. Try vacuuming the stairwell. It's loads of fun. Honest.
It's just not good. A sad forgetful boring game from BGS.

So I've got a 80 hours in the ship builder and maybe the other 30 in actual gameplay, even less for main/side quests. I used the console to get cash to build ships, fight me. 

It's boring & having a loading screen between planets & no in atmo flight makes pretty much everything I've done in the ship builder feel like a complete waste of time. No challenge from the AI ships after a point, heck I don't even know if there ever really was. It's not like they can really evade or pop countermeasures. 

The reason I ended up using the console to get cash vs. playing the game is because the story content is so unbelievably boring that even when the game tried to convey real stakes to me by making me pick a character to let die, I almost skipped past the option, that's how checked out I already was. 

I don't know what bethesda expected to happen here, & what's worse is that the nasa-punk style of everything is actually very cool in my opinion. This is one of the main reasons I like films like Sunshine or Interstellar over something like star wars; it's raw & analog feeling making the tech feel realistic. 

Bethesda needs to adopt a new design philosophy & really start taking some risks. Allow players to do things that change their play throughs in meaningful ways. Let us screw up, don't give us a paper choice so we don't risk missing something. Handholding players is only going to turn people off in my experience, see Destiny 2 for example. 

Who even plays that game besides streamers these days? That game is only interesting when playing non-matchmade content, otherwise it actually puts me to sleep with how easy & simplistic everything is.  

Their excuse is the same as bethesda's; they favor the engine they know. 

Well, it's time to make a change particularly around the AI in these games, the grunts in Halo have more survival instincts than the empty headed lot in Starfield. Seriously, at least the grunts know to kill themselves (and the player in the process) when the chips are down.

There was a time where Bethesda had minimal to no competition, however these days the only things that really set them apart is the scope & scale of their worlds. You can still pick up almost every item & walk until you pretty much can't anymore.  

However, that exploration is extremely hollow in starfield; outside of a few trash mobs & a structure or two there really isn't anything meaningful to find on those planets aside from a couple of good views.

I still come back every once in a while to tinker with a ship or walk around the moon, earth whatever feels cool & yet after a few minutes I'm like "why am I playing this?" & simply uninstall the game. 

Do not ever pay full price for this game, plenty of better games exist at much lower price points. If you want to try it; get game pass like I should have.

Better games: 
Cyberpunk 2077 
Everspace 2 - it's in space too 
No Man's Sky 
X4
Dune Awaking 

Literally anything else please I'm begging you, take your finger off the add to cart button NOW BEFORE IT'S TOO LATE!!!!

It's a Bethesda game and people seem to have forgotten that. I like reality more than idealism. Should Bethesda get away with making shells of good games to let modders fill in the gaps? Probably not, but they do. However if you know this going in, this game is honestly amazing. I praise modders as much as Bethesda but it really does feel like they work hand in glove. 

Is it perfect, no. Is it great? I think so. This isn't a space sim but does enough space sim lite stuff that it works for me (with mods). I think most people couldn't actually tell you wtf Skyrim is like without mods, I certainly can't recall. I don't see why people assume this is any different. However I will say that this game, unmodded, is significantly better than Skyrim was on its own. I really liked Skyrim too.

Worth noting that I'm well aware of what Bethesda is like so I purposely left it years for modders to do their thing and only played with it heavily modded. Just for transparency. However, for me personally, I've been loving it. Literally paused an awesome moment in one of the faction quests to write this because god knows it needs some love on here too.

I bought this game on sale... and I still think I overpaid. 

This is game is pretty much "promises" and "potential" but it's all mediocre or simply feature incomplete. 

First off the RPG elements in this game are atrocious. I will give an example :

I was sent to recover a pilot and a ship from Eclipse merc's. Upon docking to the ship I persuaded the merc leader to let go off the pilot which he did agreed on. NOW here's where the RPG falls apart. I had a choice to shoot them after freeing the pilot but I was outnumbered and didn't have good guns... so I thought to myself I can just blast their ship and take remains of the cargo ! NOPE. The ship is a PROTECTED NPC. That's right the game has NPC's you CAN'T KILL because of "story" reasons smh. 

Sadly there is WAY more immersion breaking "choices" that can't be made or simply the game won't let you play as the bad guy. 

The COMPANIONS you get are all bad. I miss my old crew from Mass Effect 2. They had style, personality and quest lines. Whereas companions you get in starfield are... just bland. Boring and annoying. 

Space exploration is pretty much - LOADING SCREENS with occasional space battles. Even then the controls are clunky ( it's like the Dev's never played Ever Space 2 ? ).

In the future all NPC civilians will be fat, ugly and have a plastic surgery on their face. Seriously person who designed them should be ashamed. 

Combat is servicable BUT STEALTH is broken! Enemies can see you through walls, your companions can trigger the combat ( at least the big robot buddy got me in trouble way too many times! ) and Perk tree requires some dumb challenges to complete?! WHY? I still have to put a PERK POINT IN IT so WHY SHOULD I DO DUMB CHALLENGES ? 

There is severe lack of tension and horror in the game about the SPACE... they really dropped the ball here. Bland fetch quests aside from few and back to loading screens. 

There is more to say but I don't want to end in the negative note...

I enjoyed the spaceship design, fantastic armour and weapon designs and overall aesthetic of indoor and outdoor locations is great. 

The game has it's moments but that's about it. It never gets EPIC like Mass Effect... never reaches it's potential... it's such a waste. Buy it on 75% sale...


EDIT 1 : Writing and choices are atrocious ! I could never roleplay as a badass Renegade ( like Shepherd from ME 2 ). Joined Crimson Fleet pirates only to be disrespected constantly, underpaid and had no WAY TO SHOOT them because of protected NPC and Questlines. Screw this. I can't even talk back or refuse to do certain things because THERE IS NO OTHER OPTIONS. Bethesda didn't code it. 

Also WHY oh WHY most people IMPORTANT NPC's are FEMALE? Seriously. CEO's, security, army operatives... you name it. Whereas white males often are often presented as goofy and incompetent. 

I really regret buying this game. This is beyond let down. NOT EVEN MODS CAN FIX IT because a lot of mods are OUTDATED or simply modding community mostly gave up. I can see why.

I think a lot of the reviews for this game were misleading. What I'll say is this: It's not worth $100 with the DLC or even $70 for the base game. But, if you buy it on sale or you're a hardcore fan already dead-set on buying it, it's not bad. The outpost system is a bit weird and hard to get the hang of, and certain cities feel emptier and less lively than others, but the voice acting is amazing, the 4 romanceable companions have real depth and likeable personalities, and the graphics are good. I've almost finished the main quest at this point, and I'm finding the game very fun to play.

It is actually pretty amazing. I think the criticizing camp stepped a bit over the line. Sure ... the cities could haven been more diverse, livelier, the clubs could have been grittier, they could have tweaked the procedural system so that exact copies would not be generated. but all in all the deeper, even a tiny bit more high brow and realistic edge and perspective this game brings and also the off humour. I really like it and I think the next DLC will bring it home ...

I have almost 100 hrs invested in Starfield and I have enjoyed it quite a bit. I feel maybe people have too many expectations for this game and aren't taking the time to see it for what it is. Yes there are a few things that aren't polished and perfect, however the giant sandbox that it is can indeed be quite fun. Relax and enjoy.

This game was kind of boring. The story was not interesting? The characters don't feel very compelling. This game doesn't really allow you to play the bad guy. There aren't a wide selection of choices that allow for a bad guy play through. There's a memorable instance where you can betray a faction but the NPC's are invincible so that quest line if you choose the bad route is basically unplayable. There are several invincible NPC's. If you choose bad choices you're companions will all hate that. There is no grey or evil morality support in the game. If you make bad choices your companions WILL find out even if they weren't with you when you did evil. The auto generated content is so boring. Sure there are hundreds of planets but only a hand full with prefabs that are actually interesting to explore. You can explore planets with nothing on them for hours and its just generally boring. Even building out a settlement for resources is not interesting. 

The one pro I will grant Starfield for all its lack of content at least its a functional game. This may be Bethesda's most functional game with the least amount of bugs. There are a few game mechanics that really feel it's the most elevated compared to other Bethesda games. If you like Bethesda games you might enjoy this game initially. I just wish the story didn't feel like dragging your feet in cement. I hear the game play and story gets better in late game but I just can't force myself to play this game anymore. 

I really want to like this game because it is an improvement in visuals, game mechanics, combat and a real clean up of bugs that Bethesda games are known for. Its almost like they heard their audience and tried to appease us but the killed the things that made their games fun to play regardless of the flaws in them. There's just no real story telling elements.

Maybe one day whenever I have so much free time its boring I might comeback just to get my money's worth. But I haven't touched this game since Oct 2023. It is August 2025 and this game hasn't been a thought to me in the time since. Really lost my faith in the game studio since this game and I will be so much more hesitant to get any other Bethesda game going forward.

It's a typical Bethesda game for the most part, so you know what to expect. However, exploration is lackluster due to the planets being so empty and not diverse enough, and the game offers plenty of opportunities for exploration. Regardless, for most players, it'll probably take a while before you get bored of exploration. I'd say there's 20-30 hours of good fun to be had here, maybe less, maybe more, depending on your tastes. It probably won't be enough to play through the story unless you rush through it. Regardless, if you enjoy Bethesda's games, you can definitely have fun in Starfield too, only probably not as long as in Bethesda's other games. If this was the only part, I'd recommend the game with reservations, but there's more.

The game has New Game+. I don't usually take advantage of NG+, because I have only a limited amount of time, and few games deserve my time for a replay. However, in Starfield, it's essentially written into the story, compelling you to start NG+ if you want to feel like you've truly completed the game. Yes, not everyone is going to feel that need, but for me, it was compelling enough that I started NG+. The issue with this, of course, is that your dozens of hours of settling in the world go down the drain, and you start all over again. It makes getting attached to anything harder than it should be. I can appreciate the writing, but what it means for the game is that the whole game becomes hollow. It's like pulling the rug after you've completed the game.

I definitely had my fun, boring bits aside, but there probably won't be much attachment or really caring about anything in the game if I ever come back. I'm glad I got the game for 'free' with a new GPU when it was released and didn't have to pay for it. If you can overcome the shortcomings though, it's worth a bit for sure.

I am conflicted. When I'm actually playing the game part of the game I'm having the time of my life. Out of all of the Bethesda games the gun play is the best they've done. 

Pros:
- The guns animations and design don't always make sense logically but they FEEL good. 
- I really like the general aesthetic of the game as well and I think they did a really good job with it. 
- Scouring every nook and cranny looking for loot to grab and probably sell is really great and the interior environments are all incredibly well detailed. 
- The ship building is great, tho I do find some of the pieces don't really look that nice when put together.
- The actual asset detail is incredible, I know a lot of people talk shit about the graphics and I will name a few complaints in the cons, but overall most of the assets and interior environments actually look really good (too many people just play with brightness cranked so high everything is washed out)
- I might be in the minority, but I really do like the progression system. Mostly because it's like fallout and Skyrim progression had a baby. I never loved Fallout's because every perk had some kind of perk point prerequisite which became a time sync to grind levels, and I never loved Skyrim's for the same reason but different. In Skyrim it became a time sync where you basically were required to cheese a skill level just to get some decent perks. I like Starfield's because rather than a specific skill level to unlock a perk, you have a specific objective. I like that. I understand that might be an unpopular opinion, but I like having to "unlock" my perks with an objective rather than just points.

Cons
- The menus... the menus... the menus... there are soooooo many menus you have to go through and click on just to travel from one planet, to another, and then from that planet another menu to land on the surface. It's just 5 too many clicks in my opinion and really kills any solid grind sesh that requires moving around a lot of different planets.
- The UI to this day (8/4/2025) is locked at 30fps and that really sucks
- The graphics are great mostly, BUUUUT, the graphics on exterior environments such as the proceduarlly generated landscape on most planets suuuuuck graphically. Apart from showcase landscapes such as the very first one you travel to in game, they are all extremely repetitive and the foliage can appear kind of muddy (not brown but like blurry)

Middle Ground
- The loading screens going in and out of buildings don't actually bother me that much. I have an m.2 so they load extremely fast though obviously it'd be better if I could just open a door and boom, I'm there. It's just not as encumbering as the Skyrim or Fallout 4 days. The only loading screen problem I have is what I mentioned in the cons about how many menus you have to click through to get from one planet to another. 

Overall I really loved playing Starfield, beat it a couple times before I burned out because of all of the fast travel sub-menus for simple travel.
I like this game a lot
Fallout in space? yes... good/great? yes... Life changing? no

[h1]Bethesda Gave Me the Stars… Then took away the sky [/h1]

I was walking in New Atlantis, just there wandering, alone, thinking about how this city looks big but feels small at the same time, that's where I stumbled upon it, 'TerraBrew' i went there, maybe to get some latte or just black coffee with no sugar, the employees were arguing with someone, so i thought I'd help myself, went to one of the tables, and took a sip from the latte left there, the next thing i knew is UC security all over the place, weapons all drawn at me, and they telling me that i am under arrest, I thought okay, maybe I'd pay a fine or get a lawyer or something, but nooooo. Blackout, i wake up in jail, somewhere in space, and Commander Ikande is there telling me that I have the qualifications to work for space government (i really wish getting a job in real life was this easy) and infiltrate the Crimson fleet as a spy. This where I realized that Bethesda don't make games, they make fever dreams with budget.
And that's basically Starfield, a Space RPG in space, where logic is optional and your ship is real but your freedom is mostly a 'Suggestion'.

You see a planet there, you like it? you think am gonna fly there and live the space exploration dream, Nope, you basically open a menu, go to map, then get out of planet click again to get out of system, click on that system to enter, click on that planet to travel to, and maybe you start to think this is it... but again nope... loading screen appears. you reach that planet and now times to land and yes you guessed it again, open that google map thing and click where to land and again loading SCREEN, you think OK at least i will fly inside the planet exploring and all, but again no, you only land and walk from there, and even if you want to change the spot you landed at, you again open map and click on different spot and land, A PROCESS THAT KILLS THE IMMERSION!!!! OF YOUR EXPERIENCE.
 It feels like if i gave you a Lamborghini car, you set there very happy, can't believe yourself. Now let's have a ride, but nope the steering wheel is locked instead am gonna show you [b]A POWERPOINT SLIDESHOW OF YOUR DREAMS BEING SHATTERED!.[/b] They build an entire galaxy then taped a fast travel system to it, and called it immersive, it's a very disappointing experience that has zero seamless space to planet flighting, it completely ruins the space exploration experience and every time you get that excitement feeling it just gets shutdown by that process.

Now to be fair there's always the bad and good, and Oh boy, this game makes up for those dream shattering moments in some way.

[h3]SHIP BUILDING:[/h3]
This is the best thing in the game, it feels like Lego but for adults with interior design trauma, you want to build a war machine?? yeah you can. you would like a comfy mobile home? or maybe an IKEA showroom that you can decorate and make it yours, yes you can do all that(You can even put a toilet with toilet paper in the cockpit, for some reason). this is something I've put many hours into and every time i feel to do more and more building non stop, it's therapy.

[h3]World details:[/h3]
I’ve never seen a game in my life that is this detailed. Bethesda’s art team went feral, every single item, sandwich, object, every lab or deserted outpost there are details everywhere, in every corner around the galaxy. I think someone personally hand placed them during a 3 AM breakdown. i am amazed, Many times I would just walk around, staring at objects like a creep, because the level of detail is insane. you can tell someone’s soul went into decorating these spaces. Heck, there’s more storytelling in an open closet or lab than in the story itself. BUT.... then you leave those handcrafted areas and land on a random moon or a planet, and the magic is just gone, yes there are breathtaking views and very cool alien skies, but the details are gone, it's just an empty copy pasted layout on every planet to the point where exploring becomes very boring and has no value, i do understand that this is what space in reality would look like, empty and vast but still, we need something to keep the player engaged, not to find abandoned facility with the same layout on all moons and planets.

[h3]Story:[/h3]
yeah the main story is there, you touch some rock, see a vision, float a bit, tbh i didn't care, it felt as if they were trying to be deep and mysterious, but to me it felt shallow and forgettable, However...all the real magic went into the side quest, especially the faction storylines, those are where the game comes alive, I've enjoyed all of them, they'er not top tier, but they are solid enough to keep you engaged and interested.

[h3]Companions:[/h3]
I was never this disappointed with this kind of companions. It was a disastrous experience. They don’t feel like your companions, they feel like some company HR interns but in space. you commit a very tiny mistake and they’re like, “I don’t think that aligns with our mission values” Especially Sarah Morgan. I HATE YOU.
Sometimes they feel very dumb. for example, Andreja will keep asking me, “Can we talk for a moment?” while I am engaging in combat and fighting for my life, and it happened not one time or two, but many times, at the end i just preferred to travel alone with no companions.

[h3]Gameplay:[/h3]
I'd say it's okay, typical Bethesda gameplay, I did really enjoy the guns in this game, the combat and shooting mechanics where okay i guess, also the ship battles where fun sometimes, the most fun time i had is when i hijacked others ship and enter them and steal the ship and kill all it's crew. also there are many guns in this game, i loved them, they are detailed, you can customize them, put a silencer, but for nothing since the stealth in this game is garbage. 

[h3]Photomode:[/h3]
I am really amazed here. While nothing particularly special, the game is damn pretty that you could accidentally create a masterpiece. there’s so much to capture, alien moons, space sunsets, giant gas planets, it’s a straight desktop wallpaper factory, the depth of field is also really good in this game.

finally i would rate this game a 6/10 for building a dream world and hold it all together with loading screens, 10/10 for ship building alone, maybe 8/10 for that coffee theft to spy career shift, AND -999 FOR PRETENDING FAST TRAVEL IS THE SAME AS FLYING!!!

Dear Bethesda,
You made something huge. Something packed with tons of details, art, ambition, and almost feels handcrafted (the planets are not though). But then you sat me down and said:
“You see that planet? You can’t actually go there. But here’s a loading screen.”

You gave me a spaceship and told me I could explore the stars...
Then made me teleport every single time and open that damn Google Maps in space.

You handed me the keys to a galaxy,
and then locked the steering wheel.

WHY?

We didn’t want loading screens.
We wanted to feel control.
I wanted to feel the journey.
To live like the real thing.

I would say only buy this game if you really enjoy space, or you are just like me who like to stare maybe for long times, at objects, views, spaceship interior, or love to take screenshots, because photomode is decent. it's not worth full price unless you truly understand what you are getting. tbh there's much more to talk about but i feel this is enough for now.

Both of these bugs are generally harmless in a single player game. Meanwhile, theres still a bug in the game that causes Temples to not spawn. This is a core mechanic of the game that still hasnt been fixed and can be considered game-breaking. The list goes on and on. The game feels like a lot of potential and broken promises. Despite buying it on sale, I kinda feel like I want to return the game and get a refund. Ps. Lets not overlook the paid mods! Basically anything is permissible IF you pay for it, achievements arent disabled. IF you run a free mod that does the same thing the achievements are disabled. I really want to like and enjoy this game but get the impression that Bethesda doesnt want people to like or enjoy it considering the 'fixes' theyve implemented while ignoring the bugs that need fixing.

This game received a lot of hate (and continues to do so), but I'd urge anyone to ignore that and to judge the game for themselves.

Is it perfect? Of course not - it's ultimately a Bethesda creation engine game, which comes with loads of positive as well as loads of negatives. However, anyone who is familiar with the engine and their other games will feel right at home.

The game has loads of difficulty options which can be tweaked to your liking in a granular way, including things like carry capacity, how much money vendors have, damage done and taken, etc. You can pretty much tailor the difficulty to your liking and make it as hard or as easy as you desire.

The story is fine - the factions are fun and the world itself has enough going for it to keep you busy for many hours. The NG+ mechanics, without spoiling anything, enable multiple play-throughs and add something new during those.

Ship customisation is great, outpost building I haven't interacted with but seems to have some depth to it too.

But honestly, the most important thing for me: The game is *fun*. I feel people forget that this is what games are about and criticise games for graphics, animations or gameplay aspects whilst praising games which have far less depth or are just not anywhere near as much fun to play.

Will you love it? No idea - but if you enjoy Bethesda games and want a more 'near future' NASA-punk style space game, it's hard to go wrong with this one. You'll get plenty of enjoyable hours out of it for your investment.
