Absolutely fricking amazing! As someone with >5k hours each in Skyrim, FO4, FNV and FO3, this game follows and improves upon the Bethesda RPG open-world model. And like those earlier legendary titles, Starfield is still fairly early in its development cycle, with only one DLC so far released, and the modding community only just getting involved. 

Starfield game reviews have also somewhat tracked those earlier titles. Fallout New Vegas, for example was initially panned--but is now a fan favorite, considered by some (myself included) to be one of their best ever titles.  

Does Starfield have bugs? Quirky and/or maddening mechanics? Yes, and yes. But so does EVERY other Bethesda title I love, especially Skyrim and FO4. Misleading and/or incorrect quest markers, and the Ship Builder interface are the chief culprits plaguing Starfield. Until either the Devs--or the modding community--sort them out, they'll continue to be the biggest downside to the game. To be fair, putting the time in to learn exactly how these quirky features work has made them much, much more manageable. 

I'm 133 hours in and utterly impressed with the main quest missions I've played so far. The Vanguard, Rangers, and Crimson Fleet questlines were a total blast. The attention to detail of starship and building interiors is far more refined than in even heavily modded FO4. In conclusion. great game, that in a few years will be considered one of Bethesda's best ever.

Starfield is a great exploration, Sci-fi sandbox looter shooter universe that gives you a PLETHORA of not just quests, but each type of quest, ranging from scientific exploration and pioneering to killing some dude or ship for money, to stealth missions requiring the utmost control of your fingers and awareness. It has SO much to offer in the realm of roleplay and really lets you piecemeal your charterer together and flesh out your own story and some cool adventures. creations is just mods with a price tag and I will say that to my dying days but does add some things that fit the themes of starfield. Bethesda has a massive community and most of them geek out about the stories that are placed before them, starfield, despite is MASSIVE short comings is still a great story. Shortcomings? yes, they are glaring and massive, for a supposed ERA DEFINING title, its weaksauce compared to already massive Sci-Fi game titles out there and the reasoning? bugs and gamebreaking problems, NOT a feature just to say. People across the board have issues or take issue with TONS of bugs, such as getting locked into NPC convos, quest triggers getting stuck, game crashing after random high visual intensity scenes or just outright hardlocking after your to good at the game randomly have a quest item you shouldnt have yet. these are just a few examples. Its like one of the devs spilled some soda into the code and its just sticking the keys together and attracting more bugs. I understand that the development cycle for games this big have some serious time constraints and bug fixing is not priority #1, they have already run up the bag, gotten people to buy it and cashed out, hoping to also get small returns by having dlc and creation club sell. Meanwhile, idiots like me who invested in this game heavily at the time see no way out, its either a finacial loss or forge ahead and hope it gets better. I cant get my money back cause had it so long and and even then people will ask "well if you hate it, why do you still play it?" if you buy a car and immediatly know its garbage but dont have the funds for another car, do you park it and never drive it? no, you dont, you start it everyday with a hope and a prayer that today it doesnt blow out. same thing, I put to much time, energy and money into it. I will continue to forge ahead and maybe try what the community recommends and get 3rd party fixes (IE: dlss mod or optomizations). Yes I believe that companies this big should release a great product, no I didn't try fixes yet because wanted to stay vanilla  because, Im lazy. long story short, invest in the community, not the company.

This game, even after so many hours, just feels empty. The only aspect of this game that really sucked me in was the shipbuilding (an amazingly designed system with a few hiccups). The story? Lame and disjointed. The worldbuilding? Nonexistent compared to TES or Fallout. The gameplay? It was fine but not a huge improvement over anything else Bethesda has made. The RPG elements? Horrid. The dialogue? Awful. The graphics? A horribly mixed bag with some elements (like space) looking beautiful with others (the NPCs in cities) looking terrible. Map design and exploration? Cities are just as small as ever and the world feels empty and devoid of reasons to explore. Everything is procedural generation and I found ONE interesting quest on a random planet. If you like endless repeated dungeons across planets that are supposed to be barren yet have dozens of abandoned outposts with a maddeningly poorly written story and world with no depth, this game is for you. If you like quality, go elsewhere in Bethesda's catalog or just anywhere else on Steam. I regret my purchase.

I wrote a several pages long review for myself; this is the absolute barebones version.

--This is - not - a space exploration game. That notion is false. YouTubers and many reviewers refuse to acknowledge this fact. They promoted the game the wrong way. Starfield is (just) a single-player, open-world game in which you happen to use a ship to get to your quest destination - that’s it.

--Like several other open-world games, Starfield severely limits your XP, credits, and possibly rare resource intake (forcing you into New Game+). Much like AC: Valhalla (even with everything boosted to +75%) your XP gain is abysmal. This is done very deliberately.

--The XP crafting guides on YouTube from a year ago are now heavily nerfed and no longer work.
I crafted countless "Red Trench", for example, to gain XP instead (and used console commands to acquire the materials).

Killing certain enemies or animals still grants good XP, and there are XP farming guides out there.
However, 90% of quests give very little XP - you're basically doing them for the story.
Don’t expect amazing weapon rewards either as it should’ve been. (with maybe one or two exceptions) 

--If you do not want, or like, to play with mods, I absolutely cannot recommend this game.

(Real effort and expertise, have ensured that you don't gain progess at, what is in my view, an acceptable rate.)

--I focus on the story, conversations, gameplay, and missions. 
If you lack the patience to read or absorb what you're doing, and just want to casually play, skip this one.

--I was in full rebel mode, determined to deliver a positive review for about 80% of the game - I loved it.
Not having to deal with credits, carry weight, XP, or resources, and just doing the cool stuff like building your own starship, becoming a pirate, saving the government, exposing corruption, and engaging in corporate espionage.

--My will to continue however dropped sharply near the end, when I started the main questline.
At its core, it's an ad infinitum rat race. They lead you toward something divine, but you're really just confronted with hubris. Calling this lackluster is an understatement. Starfield is a game that demands - or funnels you toward - replaying it. (Again & again.)

--The main quests give you 'starborn' powers. A handful are somewhat useful but certainly not needed. 
And to reach the max rank (10) legitimately of each individual power (24 in total), you need to replay the main story ten times... Yeah, that's never going to happen.

(So basically every time you replay the game, you can add 1 point to an existing power, up to 10. - more range, dmg, lower cooldown, etc.)

--In most single-player games, people wish for New Game+. 
This is, no joke, the first game I’ve ever encountered where you actively don’t want it.
Worst of all: you can't take your very carefully crafted ship, weapons, or armor with you.

All my weapons and spacesuits are custom crafted with handpicked perks.
--Some complain about "bullet sponge" enemies - that's false.

What they should say is that your talents (and thus your XP gains) 
- not just weapons, or their perks - mostly determine your damage output.

You’ll deal very high damage with:
- Semi-auto, silenced weapons
- Always being crouched/invisible (to initiate sneak attacks)
- Talents like Stealth, Concealment, Sharpshooting, Armor Penetration, and Marksmanship

The problem? Crouch-walking speed is horrendously slow, so legit players avoid stealth entirely and just use Mag or Va'ruun weapons. (I used a mod to increase crouch-walk speed to stay mobile in combat.)

With this setup, nearly everything dies instantly - even from an advanced, silenced, old earth, 1911 pistol or a silenced (Hard Target) sniper for example. The rest is gravy.

Semi auto weapons, burst included, gain more crit chance and this, with crit damage talents, deal most of your damage when multiplied by 5x through sneak attacks.

Very basic, but requires around... level 130 to have a comfortable amount of talents to enjoy the game on Extreme, with a variety of weapons, and all necessary ship talents, etc.

Alternatively, the Va'ruun Inflictor and (DLC) Longfang are also top-tier, even without legendary effects. (Sneak attacks still reign supreme though.)
An Inflictor with One Inch Punch is roughly equal to a non-perked, advanced Longfang.
They clearly made them very strong to incentivize DLC purchases - a common tactic nowadays.

--Most companions are useless (you’re much stronger with the Isolation talent) and constantly judge your every move. If there was an option to throw Sarah out the airlock, I’d have done it.
Gamers don’t play to be berated like children - and the conversation options to stand up for yourself are extremely weak.

Basically, you’ll get a ton of condescending feedback, and while I have thick skin, the fact that you are treated like a petulant child ripe for scolding - is where I draw the line.

Jessamine is probably my favorite, she's down for whatever, but she has weak ship talents and can’t be romanced. Sam Coe is voiced by the legendary Elias Toufexis (Deus Ex: HR/MD), which was a real highlight.

There’s also a Russian character - name, voice, accent - who doesn’t look Russian at all. (I’m sure you understand what I mean.) It’s blatantly obvious that an outside force came in very late during development and decided certain quotas hadn’t been met.

Why I'm not giving a negative review:
*As someone who enjoys single-player, open-world games, Starfield is not without merit.
200 hours for a single player game, while bypassing almost all the timegating nonsense is good value in my book.

*I grew up playing the original RollerCoaster Tycoon, so building was one of my earliest gaming joys.
In Starfield, you can build your own outposts and ships - and there’s nothing else quite like it. (That I know of.)

*I really like the music.

*I’m not very familiar with earlier Bethesda games. (They did publish Dishonored 1 & 2, but that’s about it.)

Valid criticism:
* The eyes look horrendous. It's so horribly done, I just look at the subtitles. 
There're mods that fix this but I don't want to install too many on my potato PC.

I read a comment that said, very roughly:
"You walk through a museum detailing the history of the Settled Systems and a major galactic war - yet the planets you visit are barren and lifeless."

That’s exactly it. In an ideal world, Bethesda would’ve scrapped the main story and all the Starborn nonsense (which started off intriguing, until you actually meet them and realize the 'divine' endgame is just a repetitive rat race).

Instead, they could’ve focused on you being a simple grunt in a brutal war with mechs and xenos, fighting against impossible odds! 

Or even make two games in one: in which you choose between the UC or the Freestar Collective, with entirely different stories depending on your choice. (make a real new game + experience.)

In short, they could’ve gone in dozens of better directions - none of which involved chasing artifacts for no apparent reason, just to gain more powers you don’t even need.

All in all, I'm at 180 hours in now, nearing the end - with mods. 
Without mods, it could easily be double this, just for 1 full playthrough.
There's value here. 

Best of luck!

Mods I used:
- Zero Weight 
- Richer vendors (x10)
- Stealth Run
- Minimum Level 100 (to keep enemies at 100% your level)
- Varuun X (for black, hooded clothing.)
- Console commands for resources, and to add specific weapon & armor perks.
(One Inch Punch, Shattering, Double Magazine, Camouflage early on, etc.)

Listen we all know BGS might have botched the game and they are utilizing micro transactions and relying on the modding community to keep this game afloat. That does not take away from the fact that if you like the standard BGS game architecture and standard of play that accompanies that then this game is for you. Its not polished but the same could be said for Skyrim and fall out even for today. Both which play the same in my opinion with their own respectable differences. Procedural poi and the copy and paste of the worlds can be annoying but with some simple creation club "free" mods or your run of the mill nexus mods can really lift this game into the next level. I often find myself playing Skyrim or fallout and itching to hop back on Starfield just because those games feel like they are missing something that this game offers more of. I do recommend this game. It offers hours of fun and hours of bugs. Thats just how BGS games go. Most notably interesting is the ship building I find myself spending hours making new ships just to delete them an hour later and make another one. Its literally a mobile base and with a couple mods to make space more dangerous and interesting things can be pretty fun. 

Should BGS have put more into this game before launch. Absolutely. Plain and simple yes, but what they delivered on is another run of the mill Bethesda game which will ultimately be carried into the future by its community.

Starfield is a never ending battle between yourself and sleep, in almost every metric it is either extremely bland, or such a step down when compared to its counterparts that it's almost an insult to the industry. After several attempts and subsequent uninstalls I have given up trying to beat the main story, it is quite literally so vapid, bland and endless that it becomes impossible to have any semblance of fun whatsoever. The quests are repetitive and boring, the characters are generic husks of human beings, and it has a story so forgettable I can barely even remember the plot. The gunplay and ship combat is some of the worst of its kind, with ship combat especially being something I actively avoided at all cost. Fast travel in general is a sea of loading screens, oftentimes needing at least 4 or 5 to get where you need to go. This is certainly one of the worst projects Bethesda has ever put out, standing right alongside Fallout 76, a game that was basically unplayable at launch. If you are thinking about purchasing this title, I would implore you to please save your time and money, and get basically any other open world game out at the moment. You would have more luck winning the lottery three times in a row, than ever getting to the end of Starfield and feeling satisfied with your time. An absolute disgrace to what an open world story game is supposed to be.

I've played many other Bethesda games, and it feels like this had an even worse direction than their online cash-grab games of recent years. Bethesda is known for dense, populated, single-player story-oriented, discovery-centered, dangerous, wacky worlds. This game was none of those things. 98 % done, missing level 100(50+ hours is outpost building. Changed my review a few times. I really like this game. I had a great time playing this game, exploring, battles, weapons, space armor, building outposts and spaceships etc. Huge open world game, like very huge. Been a while since I played(I bought expansion and started playing again), I see they fixed many bugs and they added cars to explore planets! Great.
Not many games where I can play 4+ hours straight without getting the slightest bored, really impressive, lol. This game is great for anyone that likes singleplayer open world games(and in this case space/the universe too). I very much recommend it, if you like that. 

Now, I primarily mention some bad game designs/lacking QoL(quality of life), because most of the game is great, easier to mention the bad things:
- You cannot stash minerals/ores/stuff and access it everywhere, except in your spaceship with limited space. This is so annoying, like really QoL bad design. You have to move materials and such around all the time and it sucks, until your ships cargo hold is huge. Storage system makes outpost building(which I guess the game was meant to be about, observing all the outpost talents etc., but then again not really with the NG+ system, losing everything anyway etc.). You MUST have a ship with large cargo hold, making the spaceship fighting pretty bad, then you must change your ship to a battleship etc. and I do not really trust the game to keep my stuff in my spaceship either, if I change ship etc.
- Mining, why spend time farming ores on planets, when I can just buy them in stores cheap? If they had to actually give you the feeling, that you must collect ressources, they should probably not add vendors selling them for nothing? Either selling them for very high prices or not at all(hard to get items), and allowing the player to sell them too for decent money? With this design the ressource mining and scanning planets is totally pointless? Only thing you really need is aluminium, iron and some lead, copper. Had been better imo, if you actually had to mine the stuff yourself on different planets, and then some really rare ores on planets that are hard to survive on("extreme enviroment" - reason to get this skill too btw), large carnivores, heat, acid etc.? And what is the point in building the outpost extractions, when you can just buy ressources, surely you need an outpost to farm alu, iron, titanium and lead(most used materials). It's an open world RPG exploration game right? The planets, their ressources and building outposts were supposed to be big? The idea imo should be, that you must mine to build and craft gear? Would had made more sense, reason to explore and do these things, reason to pick certain skills? The mining missions/objectives would also make more sense, "outpost business". 
 - The gear/item menu etc. is pretty bad to navigate in? Is there even a way to see if some item is an upgrade for my companion? As I see it, if you stay and play in just normal game, I guess companions and  leadership works, but if you rush NG+ you would go for isolation trait - because you don't need to pick up a thing other than weapons and ammo. Strange designs imo, as if the game goes against it's own game genre, it's own skill designs, all the "sidestuff" in their game? I mean RPG is about collecting stuff, finding stuff, play your way. There is no way to search for an item either. And we have like thousands of items around in different places due to not having one chest where we can store everything. I think it's fair to ask why there are so many items, if you take "aid", there are several items with almost the same effect etc.? Different food is great for designing the outpost etc.(only looks). The game is also very easy due to pretty op aid items? Boost in damage, resistances, speed etc. 
- Outpost building, the "connecting stuff"(cargo link) is quite hard to navigate/master, quite poor design? Outposts can be quite bugged too, sometimes you can load and some parts of the outpost is gone, then go somewhere else and come back and the stuff is back, plants sometimes bugs into the inside of your outpost(still there). Then gone again later on. Pretty annoying when the idea in the game is about building outposts. I made my own outpost mansion/palace, great "Hollywood view" from a mountain, really put some hours into it. I had lots of fun building/designing my main outpost, think I spend 50 + hours or so lol(I also enjoyed building in Fallout etc.), putting all my collected items on display, designing my outpost etc. I like building stuff in games. Also no option to build some "universal" chest that regardless of outpost and place could allow us to store stuff with unlimited space(outpost linked chest)? QoL stuff, why not? It's a singleplayer game? Not even some option in talent points. The storage system is so annoying, Jesus. 
- I also wish the dev's had made half as many planets and then focused on making them better instead of making many "poor"/fill designed planets without much purpose, Fewer planets with increased design quality, rather than quantity(a bit like the 8,2 billion humans on Planet Earth, hehe)? 
- New game plus - it annoys me, that I lose everything in new game plus? I lose my 50 + hours designed outposts, my designed ship!? I can understand the logic/idea in it, but then in start tell me this?(It's hard to reach level 100 without NG+? Even though sources on the internet asserts it's possible. Would be nice, if there was an option to lock one outpost and one spaceship into new game plus at least? Please tell me this design in start, character creation screen? - So I can wait for second or third playthrough to spend 50 + hours building my stuff, collecting items from planets?  I spend a lot of time making a really nice outpost and now my ship. Losing it? Why? Losing 50+ hours of my life? It's a game. I personally didn't use the powers much(except expansion now)? The game is pretty easy already? Yet the new game plus stuff is based around getting power ups, as far as I can tell? You become like some "quantum god being" or something. So I tried NG+(to reach level 100), enemies are not harder, does not scale level etc. lol, meeting many level 5 as lvl 71 etc. Terrible designs, really. 

Other:
- First time I played Starfield, we could not design the inside of our spaceship, this I found so annoying and bad since it's our only real home base due to the lacking/bag storage system in Starfield. We now can in newer patch. Great QoL update, same about the car. 
- Outpost and several other talents are annoying and pointless due to NG+ design? 
- I do miss "Dogmeat"(Fallout) as a companion :P, where is he? My best good boy....
- You can romance in the game, more or less whoever you want(I think), if that is your thing. I went with Sarah. You wouldn't think so, but she is a wild cat, not boring at all ;)
- Would be cool if we could upload images and add them as posters to our outposts?
- We need better menu/item overview etc. Why can we even see all these cards/keys in misc when we cannot do anything with them anyway? Remove them to some key pocket thing?
- We should be able to spawn the car and somewhat be able to harvest from it imo? I do see some problems, since you can fast travel to your ship even when overloaded from car. 
- Would be nice with a tmogger btw, to change our char etc.
- Graphics are very great, stunning! My PC is pretty bad, even on low it's great(Anyway, who can honestly upgrade their PC's every year? - Not to mention climate etc.) 
Combat is great imo. 
Voicing is great, but faces are a bit stiff at times, mimic is poor(it's better in Shattered space).

I would say, it is a great game/entertaining, even though the game is lacking some QoL, I give the game 9,3/10.  I think this massive open world game deserves 9,3, yeah, it's fair.

While it could be summed up as "Oblivion/Skyrim/Fallout...but in space," there is a deeper level of engagement with the player.
While it's not perfect, Starfield has definitely captured my attention as an interactive story with a dense galaxy sized nebula of stories, quests, economics, and character development.
While there are some heavy-handed "these are the baddies" elements that slightly detract from my immersion into the universe, there are some nice nuanced factions and even characters within factions that nicely represent those bits of inconvenient reality one runs into during the course of life.
I appreciate the numerous patches addressing bugs, adding features, and QoL improvements.

A specific gripe (that might be resolved already from a mod, perhaps?) pertains to the ship design mechanic: I wish "module not connected" errors would highlight or flash which parts are disconnected, as I have repeatedly experienced things such as a small shield module that were left unattached once the part supporting it was changed or moved, but is not readily apparent that it's to blame for the error.

I am only on my first playthrough, and while I'm not nearly as far down the skills tree as I'd like to be yet, at level 25, I don't feel that I'm pigeonholed into numb grinding activities in order to get over a particular hurdle in my progression. There seems to always be something else you can explore or invest in to make the time you play return the level of enjoyment you expect. This game has been a good value for the money.

I do recommend that players are mindful of all the little touches the developers have put in every square meter of the environment. It's easy to become fixated on mission completion and totally miss the 'mise en scene' of a station, outpost, or ship which tells a much deeper story than the character interactions (whether through persuasion, plot exposition, or their untimely demise) you may experience. Sometimes the little things - such as which hands of cards were  dealt out on a table - can give you insights into important elements of the characters and story you are encountering.

I realized I had never reviewed this game. Really the word for it is "meh". "2000 planets", "futuristic weapons", "multiverse theory", "space flight", "ship building". They're all sort of 'there', but in the most basic form that'd allow them to market those terms without sounding like false advertising.

The gameplay proposes interesting stuff like armor and weapon perks along with randomized loot, which on paper should make for a fun game, but in reality they didn't make a single perk interesting, or crucial, much less over-powered. Rather than tiered weapons and noticeable upgrades along loot rarities, you just get a slop fill of meh weapons with meh upgrades that allows you to try everything without missing out, but also means everything is mostly samey. Finally, if you ever feel like pursuing a particularly nice legendary effect combo? You'll never get it unless you're stupidly lucky.

Combat AI is exceedingly dumb, sad even. What little entertainment there is in finding good guns and armor is made completely irrelevant by enemies that don't even try to survive. It also means that you kill a guy with a weapon, and when you loot him it gets turned into a randomized enchanted weapon that the npc was clearly NOT using against you.

Planets are not even that varied, so it's irrelevant to have 2000 empty balls of procgen wasteland when 10 would work fine for the main quest and most secondaries as well. Outpost building on them can be kinda nice, but there's no variety to structures or furniture, and thanks to traders it is made completely skippable.

The story is forgettable at best. It's Skyrim in space with a few somewhat interesting multiverse stuff dispersed in that you never really get to properly probe, question or experience between the busy work of loading screens required to travel from place to place, and if you get to questioning too much? Well, they didn't go that deep.

The only thing this game kinda tries at, is being a legally distinct "bethesda game" that can't be compared to Fallout or Skyrim... and even in that it falls short.
Shallow, unfinished, fakes depth and mechanics at every corner. Not even the mods can salvage this wreck.

I have played most Bethesda games from oblivion and fallout 3 to Skyrim, fallout 76 and I have found some enjoyment in them even if the games are anything but flawless, however this game was one of the least enjoyable gaming experiences I ever had (in recent times), I can not speak for everyone who has played this game but the first time I started this game personally it just looked so...ugly, not that Bethesda games are graphically masterpieces especially in NPCs and character design but this, just felt the worst, like they were trying to make characters look realistic but also somehow kept the usually look of Bethesda characters and it looks really bad IMO, my biggest issue with the game was the sheer frame rate drop when I entered New Atlantis my frames dropped to an unplayable degree, it took me awhile to actually fix it and also look good at the same time but I was able to accomplish it,eventually. Some other problems I have with the game are most of the spacesuits and weapon designs and variety, apart from the UC Vanguard sentinel spacesuit and UC Vanguard spacesuit i found the other suits, kinda not very appealing looking for a game set in well, space, when I first played and I was on the first mission "one small step" and at the part with the crimson fleet captain, the minute I saw him I thought "he has such cool armor, I wish I could get that" and to my disappointment albeit not surprise, he doesn't drop it, instead I got some ax that was better than the one I was already using, which brings me to my other point about the weapons, yes I do think many of the guns in this game look like very chunky and ugly designs, they do not bother me that much as I did think the gun play of this game was not horrible, BUT my biggest issue was the absolute gutting of melee weapons in this game, I always loved to play many of Bethesda games (more specifically fallout) with melee only, as I found it way more fun to wack enemies then shoot them, but in this game, instead of having a few unique melee weapons,we got 9 and they are all bladed, no blunt weapons, no cool sci-fi type of melee weapons, just 9 bladed weapons and that frustrates me so much,and the story of this game just felt so...Unengaging, I just did not care about it, I didn't care the characters I couldn't get behind any of it, which when I first started playing this game, felt strange as I was able to engage and enjoy most other Bethesda game stories, even Fallout 4 as much as I didn't enjoy the game,but this story just felt...lifeless in a way I can't explain.

This game deserves a thumbs down simply because it exists. it could be better it could be worse, its not great not even good, it's blasé. I don't hate the game, I don't love the game, I've played it, enjoyed some elements, but was ultimately bored. And then I beat it, and well if you haven't had one play through because you got bored, then beating it will be like being stuck in hell.

1745 hours played.

Numbers like this are what people like Todd exclaim first and foremost about how their games are played, as an exclamation of excellence. It is held up like a trophy, “revel in our success”.

In this case however, instead of playing it for some kind of enjoyment, I racked up those hours trying to find the justification for Bethesda releasing this game at all.

Coming down the elevator and entering the cinematic at the start of the game, I was holding onto years of anticipation for this release, but also the lessons learned through 40+ years and 10K+ hours of ....Bethesda.
During that opening cinematic, I witnessed one of the VERY few "real" conversations that I would experience during the entire playthrough, but I did not know that at the time, all  I was thinking of was my doubts about the improved graphics being able to hold up knowing what I do about the engine driving the system I was about to take a long ride in.

Upon release of my character, I rushed to the games UI, and my heart sank. What is this?
The SAME old clunky and outdated UI? And why was it even slower than previous games?
A tiny ember emerged right then, but I  pushed forward, spurred on by the thousands of hours of "dedication?" to Bethesda's previous titles.

My next step was being told by the supervisor and as a brand-new miner, that I was going to be the one responsible to proceed into the next area and to obtain some unknown and possibly dangerous item. 
For clarity, since the start of the game and up until that moment, I had just spent 9 minutes being lectured about safety, responsibility, and the importance of working together. So much for immersion eh?
This is Starfield. Written by people who apparently have no real-world experience and as such, simply have no idea how to emulate how a person would think, act, or communicate let alone build a world real enough to keep you inside of.

WIthin 20 minutes into the game, my random "Joe" just got handed a ship and was told: 
"fly.. be free"....like a child. Now I have a ship and have accomplished... nothing.

I played the first hour with that small ember turning into a hot coal as my brain tried to reconcile how ridiculous the "story" I was being presented with was, and a growing dislike for the games main companions. By hour 50, I wanted nothing to do with Constellation at all, and in retrospect, I think the game would have been much better without it. Just a world where you start as that miner and develop into something from there, supported by interesting questing and progression, but surely not "Skyrim in space". 

I spent the next 475 hours ensuring that I had explored every single element of the game. Every possible interaction, every planet, every scenario. I cannot stress to you enough how boring and tedious this became, but I was documenting everything along the way.  

The next 1200 hours was spent trying to "fix" what parts of the game I could. Tearing into the games actual bones made me come to the same conclusion of many (most?) of my fellow mod makers.  The game simply was not worth working with, and the stretched engine is a mess. I suspect major changes coming from Microsoft above soon regarding the Creation Kit.
Most of us quit, but some stayed, instead agreeing to follow the dangling carrot that is the mod store.

The dream of Bethesda handing us the bones to a "modder's paradise", a universe to do with as we could, was instead manipulated into method to generate cash from people formerly fixing their games for free. All brought to you by the originator of the plague that is microtransactions that has now spread worldwide to be the norm.
Although there is a very well-known saying among the community "Beth makes games so that modder's can fix them", in this case there is no fixing Starfield. No matter your skill, you cannot erase the stain of the games main story and its beyond irritating attempt at world-building. 

I finally quit the day they released the “buggy”, a vehicle with no storage, to bounce off things with for 20 minutes before never being used again in the mess of procedural generation  
10 minutes after that patch, I was done. The X-pac was paid for but never played. I thank myself for that decision.

Many others have noted how incredibly shallow and simply boring this game is, so I need not go further than confirm my wholehearted agreement beyond what has already been stated here in these reviews SO. MANY. TIMES.

Here are some things that perhaps others have not noted, or my case really burned my a**:

1. It's simply a downgrade compared to most developers in regards to innovation. Systems may have been imagined, but they were never implemented to the point of being useful.
2. There is NO FUNCTIONAL ECONOMY in Starfield.
3. The score/music sucks, begins to grind at you, and since there is...
4. NO radio? no real comm's? WTF? really? How many fast-travel and loadscreen issues could have been fixed with a simple comms device? Let alone some real tech.
5. There is NO SCIENCE or SPACE in this game about science... and space.
6.Its disgustingly "safe", politically correct, and generic. A masterclass in no chances were taken. This is the main reason why the quests are simply boring, there is no flavor to be had.
7. Whoever signed off on the clothing should be fired immediately.
8. Your "Ship" is nothing more than a settlement (think previous games) that LOOKS like a ship, but in this case you transport it via load screen from location to location. 
Actually flying in this game would let you actually see how bad the procedurally generated terrain actually is. And the next issue is the reason:
9. Tell me, how many rivers have you seen in Starfield?
Anyone can easily see with a good jetpack, let alone by simply using console commands to "fly" up and take a good look around at how lazy the terrain generation and object placement is. While doing so, make sure you track your framerate and you will know exactly why flying around planets was never implemented. (and never should be with this engine)
10. The character creator is simply lazy. A shallow step up at best for Beth, but bad compared to all other AAA studios. Even the best face modelers find it nearly impossible to create anything but a mediocre mess of a face in Starfield. It's no wonder the NPC's look so horribly bad. 
11. Combat barely improved (Gunplay, and only thanks only to id software for sure) but Bethesda still has not learned to code a character that wont get stuck on a stone let alone actually move or god forbid CLIMB like a game from 2025. Go play a game like Horizon ZD or FW and experience it's movement and combat then tell me Starfield's gameplay is up-to-date, acceptable, or even improved from previous titles with a straight face. You just cant. A jetpack does not make up for that.
12. Starfield's melee is a joke. I get that they "had" to put it in the game, but no effort or thought was put behind it because Bethesda STILL insists on the use of inflating enemy health pools as you level, a tactic that should have been put to full rest 20 years ago. 


After all this if you still decide to play Starfield for the first time, I would suggest the following:

1. Mainline the games "story" while doing everything you can to not look at the NPC's.

3. Do NOT fall into the trap that is the online "store" of "mods" for this game, as it is the ONLY reason Starfield exists. Please do not contribute to the problem.
4. When you play, do so inebriated so that your mind will have at least some chance to enable whatever suspension of logic and taste as is possible

I'll start with this. Amazing modability! (assuming you have the patience). Without mods? Rarely crashes, though you'd have to be actively trying to make it crash. However, with mods, it can either run incredibly smoothly or crash every two minutes. From my experience, this depends on both your hardware and your modding capabilities.

Without mods, though, I can say that the game gets rather dull after maybe your 5th or 6th NG+. There are subtle changes in these playthroughs, such as your crew being children in one NG+ or meeting yourself and having your past character join the crew. However, I personally spent at least 400 hours simply customizing and building ships. While vanilla ship-building can feel limiting after some time, using mods to add custom pieces and parts, and removing these limitations, almost makes the game feel truly endless.

While I mentioned it can get dull after a few NG+ runs, with mods, I’ve added in quests, new homes to decorate, and I’ve even used the Star Wars: Genesis mod collection to transform Starfield into an entirely new game. It’s far from perfect, but it has kept the game from becoming stale as I’ve played.

Don’t let other RPG titles, such as Baldur’s Gate and Dragon’s Dogma, deter you from this game, even though they are incredible in their own right. Starfield has that Bethesda charm that few games can match. Beneath the bugs, crashes, and randomness, there’s a story that’s both unique and time-consuming, with nice side quests to keep you busy.

When approaching a game like this, you have to keep in mind Bethesda’s past titles, such as Fallout 4 and The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim, games that were also riddled with bugs and crashes, but today have become the foundation of the modding community. These are games that almost every PC player downloads the second they can, eager to push the limits of modding. Entire communities have dedicated themselves to turning these games into entirely new experiences, simply by using their engines. Fallout: London is a prime example.

Do not just take my word for it; I urge you to read at least five more reviews after this one. A game like this will require both time and patience. It’s fun in its vanilla state, but it can become legendary once you’ve taken the time to curate a mod list suited to your tastes—transforming a simple work of art into a masterpiece.

I liked the Nasa-punk idea. Loved textures and environment elements. I also liked the environmental storytelling very much. Wish the game had Oblivion or Skyrim level-up and upgrade systems. Despite a great number of minuses, I cannot say I disliked it or was irritated by it. The ideas behind Starfield are so much more than the end product. I bought advanced access because some YouTubers I trusted said that it was Skyrim in Space.

I no longer trust those YouTubers.

Like everyone said, it's got a slow start, but things click a couple of dozen hours in- and it's a good feeling.  But in retrospect, I realize that a lot of the good feeling was anticipation for payoffs that never came.

I think Starfield game has several good game systems.  I enjoyed tinkering with my guns and building powerful spaceships.  I enjoyed completing challenges to unlock skill purchases.  I'm not a FPS connoisseur, so the gunplay was fun enough for me.  Spaceship combat was subpar, but seeing your custom ship elevated it.  I know the NASA-punk art style was controversial, but I found it novel and enjoyed it (especially once I got the not-Doom-Slayer suit).

The main story has a number of good ideas, too.  But in the main story, and in the characters- and in the dialogue- and in the quests- the execution /consistently/ fell apart.

Dialogue was terrible Millenial writing.  The cast were vomited straight out of DEI consulting pamphlets.  The companions range from repulsive to obnoxious to pretty but bland.  And perhaps most egregiously, in quest after quest, the game blocks you from doing the thing the player naturally wants to do.  The achievement of every quest had the good feeling stolen by stupidity and railroading.  

In short, everything that gives /meaning/ to your striving- helping characters you care about in a believable setting- was a letdown, time after time.

I found myself emotionally detaching from all the stupid turns of dialogue and story, gritting my teeth and holding out for "the good part".  Once I realized that I had seen the best the game had to offer, and there was no "good part", the fun gameplay systems didn't matter anymore.

:TLDR: It may seem good but this is trash and bethesda should be ashamed.: the review: For everything I love about this game. It usually has something going on that just makes me go really, really Mr Howard. It was under cooked on launch and putting it in the patch microwave just made it chewier. Sure its well seasoned but the meat was raw now its just grey and chew. This game has a main story that honestly I couldn't give to squirts about least motivation. All of these perks to choose from and only so many dialogue options related to them also speech is worthless in this game as its a basically sums up to a quick match check not me choosing the dialogue that sounds the best. Again it has good RPG mechanics, but doesn't use them nearly enough. I'm gonna skip over the empty moons of this universe as its the common complaint. The new rover they added sucks. Its moves slow it is unfun to drive it can't make up its mind between halo style steering and traditional WASD steers (but like a strafe) the mouse steers it more for some reason. Did i mention it lacks traction a slight inclines but on the same planet will drive up a freaking cliff face without issue. The guns though work do suck. I think bethesda just likes making gun designs to rile up gun nerds at this point. if so top kek ya got me. that being said weapons go like this find something you like use it eventually find the advanced beowulf never ever use anything else because 7.77mm is everywhere in the galaxy (ammo is not a complaint thats one of the good things in this game a lot of games make me ask why did this guy only have 4 bullets on him i shot him in the head from behind where did his ammo go?) Combat is one of those things that are a mixed bag did you like fallout 4 good youll like the gun play in this its pretty much that but a bit more up to date. Pros:
The companion stories, writing, and VA are very good, some of the best in the genre.

The minority of the individual missions are fun and creative.

It is huge, and there is technically a metric ton of content.

It is visually stunning. 

Cons:
The UI sucks. Had to be modded. Speccing into many of the option means you'll spend a ton of time in menus, and the menus weren't made to spend a ton of time in them. 

The game seems to assume that you will play it for at least 120 hours, so it has a ton of content. Problem is, most of that content is not compelling, especially to do repeatedly. 

The worldbuilding is borderline nonsensical, and constantly undermines itself by having elements that remind you it is a game at all turns. 

It's far too buggy for a game of its budget. Encountered one game-breaking bug and one massive loss of inventory in just one playthrough. 

Verdict:
If you love Bethesda games and play them almost exclusively, you'll probably get a lot out of this. However, if you don't have all the time in the world, you're better off playing things like BG3, Cyberpunk, Outer Worlds, or one of the older Bethesda games again.

Unfortunately, the game is really not much more than an empty shell. Everything is somehow just a facade of what you imagine you want to see. 
Nothing in this game carries weight or feels meaningful. It's like watching a movie and not being able to remember any moments afterwards.

This game has seen its fair amount of hate and disinterest but I think this game is an interesting and somewhat unique experience. I see a lot of people compare this game to no mans sky or any other space games and I think this is a bad example to use. Starfield is not No Mans Sky. Starfield focuses more in story and dialogue with certain aspects sprinkled in like: Bounty hunting/other guild work, ship building, and random encounter you might find in space. This is a good space game, however, it is not the best and doesn't come close to others. While I praise the story there are lots of things this game could've done better. Starting with music, while fallout or the elder scrolls have iconic and thematic music pieces, with Starfield it is the opposite. Along with comparisons to fallout or the elder scrolls I think that those games do a good job at making you feel important in those worlds but in Starfield you are just a random to everyone and you also don't even become important in guilds. I think a good fix for that could've been an interstellar newsletter or something of the sort. Next, exploration. A lot of people have complained about this and I can only agree when comparing to no mans sky. Planets are not different, and if they are its very minor differences. This, along with relatively flat terrain on every single planet makes for a very boring exploring experience. One fair criticism I think is the use of planets. While No Mans Sky basically requires you to gather supplies from planets, which gives them a good reason to be explore, Starfield gives you no reason to explore and no reason to invest in the things that do require gathering supplies. I also do not really like the realistic NASA type asthetic with the film grain and bland coloring. I see the vision but it does not work well and especially when you look at other space games. I think if this game had the same ideas(Story, ship building, skill upgrade system, random encounters, combat system) but different aesthetic and elements this game would be seen in a better light.

Starfield is yet another example of developers believing that all they have to do is make any kind of first person shooter game (even a more polished shooter… with jetpacks), and people will be too excited and/or inexperienced to realize what the title is lacking, for such an exorbitant price. The delivered experience capitalizes gameplay elements that players have already had in other games, while not meeting the expectations of what the game promised to do differently.

I have been a Bethesda games fan for a long time. I played my first RPG with oblivion, Fallout 3 opened my eyes to what a first person shooter could be, and New Vegas opened my eyes to the depth that could be achieved when video games combined storytelling and gameplay correctly. After playing through Skyrim thoroughly, I got my first gaming PC and started learning modding so I could make the game my own, like many others have. Fallout 4 was an even better education, and it was the modding communities that took it from being a good game, to an amazing sandbox experience that still continues to grow like Skyrim’s player base. The education I got expanded to help me understand more about file structure and how games work, and the communities I interacted with have been the life blood that has kept me and other players coming back. The experience and the people improving it, have been such a big impact to me personally. I am truly grateful to be a part of that rich history and the people who have helped shape it.

Make no mistake, Bethesda has built up their business on the backs of players creating these types of fixes: the players have not only been their testers and source of feedback; they have been the source of inspiration for original content that people actually want. More importantly they have created the script fixes and community updates that have helped Bethesda games work the way they were marketed to work.

It is for these reasons that I am deeply discouraged and like many others have communicated… deeply disappointed, that Bethesda has chosen to capitalize on a tremendous opportunity for future player creativity, by adopting the "nickel and dime” approach to their newest releases as the corner-stone of their business model. The inherent lack of any real story in a game that amounts to “fast travel artifact fetching”, is just the surface of what is disappointing about this game. Past the OCD ship building, the experience becomes more and more watered down the further into the game you get.

It would have been different if Starfield had a slightly rushed or arguably unfinished main quest, but even the unpolished ending of Fallout 4 was still made less painful by the modding communities that made comprehensive fixes to the story and built up the world the way it needed to be. As inspiring as it may be for some to hear ol’ Todd wax philosophical about storytelling, Starfield delivers even less on the creation of rich story telling than Peter Dinklage trying his best to make the writing in his final GoT speech sound authentically believable. There is sadly not enough of a story in this game to create a corresponding fix to make it have any real depth:

Bethesda created a plot that plays like a frustrating grindy loop (quite literally), with travel elements that are boring, sidequests that are forgettable, loot that is uninspiring and less and less unique, interactions and relationships that are bland, and enemy bases with layouts that defy logic while needlessly having players travel from one puzzled corner to the next… just to flip a switch. It’s like Bethesda put in the proper amount of time into the project to polish it, and instead spent the time working really hard to give us the illusion of depth.

As a result of Bethesda’s decision to control the modding experience for Creation content that was once free, mod creators are now no longer making content for ANY platform. Forget new skins, armor, and ship additions… where are the bug fixes?! Where are mods that limit background static, help menus load faster, or make details of gameplay function without the occasional glitch or cause your whole game to crash? No one experiencing known issues in-game is creating fixes, because their mods are more highly scrutinized by Bethesda’s need to put a dollar amount on mods.

And so, the most advanced Bethesda game to date (now more than two years after its release), is completely dry of any compelling new content, as the developers assumed players would continue to create the experience after its release.

Bethesda is not the first to take the easy road of appealing to newer players who don’t know they are overpaying for content, but it is still sad to see Bethesda leaning into these kinds of mistakes on this release, instead of learning from them. Bethesda has already made their money back on this title, and they have achieved this in part at the expense of distancing themselves from the player base that made them their fortune.

So incredibly middle of the road that I don't know whether it's a good or bad game. Also, LOADING SCREENS, I hope you love them because I swear half the game is just loading screens. So much content in Starfield but it's mostly just meh. I've waited forever for the game to be fixed and instead it was abandoned, I preordered a collector's edition I was so sold and instead it's one of my least enjoyed games in years, wasn't even worth playing. I don't know anyone who likes it, it's genuinely rare for me to not enjoy a game as my standards are super low.

StarField was over-hyped for sure!! However, it's not a bad game. So let's talk about that.

What Do I think of starfield:
It's an OK game, with great art style, great verity of guns and armor to collect and combine for a verity of play styles, the story is OK, faction stories and missions are fun. And the general game play feels great, space ship controls are basic, ship combat is simple and easy to manage granted you have the right equipment to deal with whoever is attacking you. 

The big problem with the game is for me 3 main things. 
1. While I really enjoy some of the game play aspects, I think the procedural generation is a big letdown and not because it's there, but because it makes the world feel small. You don't choose where to land exactly as it will just land you in the general area you selected. When you land, there is a mission or some random location, but outside of that there is nothing else really. So you just go do your mission and if you don't see anything in the distance you just go to your ship and fly off. It does not provide any incentive to explore outside of the handcrafted mission areas which is a real shame, as the feeling of adventure is largely derived from being interested to travel and search for some adventure, loot, quest, etc But there is none of that here.

2. the economy being so tedious where you can only sell a couple of things before the vendor runs out of money, you just wait in a chair in front of them and you can sell things again! This is not Skyrim and there is really no need to have us wait multiple times just to sell of the stuff we looted during a single mission. We have ships that can fly to other planets at will! but a vendor cannot buy multiple armor pieces from me without being bankrupt??

3. Bugs, unfinished game systems, missing maps etc when the game was launched. Even now that most of these have been resolved, it did impact my experience as I needed to reload saves multiples times due to quests not working, Pirate ship getting stuck with me on it and pirates disappearing causing me not being able to simply walk of the ramp. Base building which is very strange and does not feel good to actually interact with outside of simply needing to. Not being helped by the fact that again you can't really choose where to land exactly and it becomes a luck thing if you will find the things you are looking for or just have to retry a couple of times to get a location that is somewhat decent. 
All of these combined are things that did impact my enjoyment regularly.

I did not mention the ship building, as I personally don't think it adds much to the game. You can buy decent ships when you get some money. And you don't actually fly your ship all that much (I know!) you only fly in a procedural generated area when you are animated into space. You either run into some encounter (friendly or not) and just open the map to auto navigate to your destination (Yes, this game will have you go through 5 loading screens one after the other very regularly and I simply put up with it as the wait is not long)


Overall, if you like the premise of Starfield, you like the art style and decent gun play, you like the space setting and are in to experience a space faring story. You will enjoy this game especially after most of the bugs have gotten fixed.
However! don't expect this to be a grand adventure like previous Bethesda games. This is more a game you will play, get through the story and do whatever faction/side quests you find interesting. And when you are done you won't feel the need to jump back into the game as it does not have anything to offer that you have not already seen/done enough off.
There is no point to go on random exploration, no point in just going your own way and running into adventure as that is simply not the experience Starfield is shooting for (or it failed massively if that was the case :D ).
Even the DLC they released is so minimal in content that I would not even consider buying it at any price. I'm simply done with StarField and looking back, I think this game should be about 30% cheaper. Because at full price I don't think it's worth it.

Now on a separate note! If you want to play a game that will knock your socks off. Also based in space, with better combat, better story (you will have to put in some time though), Better guns, better gear (no competition even), more customization, better ship combat, and is Free! Try WarFrame (welcome Tenno!). Oh and! don't watch any endgame tutorials/videos!! really!! You will only need them after 200+ hours of game play. Maybe even more! But they might give a very wrong impression of the game! Don't say I did not warn you.
Although it's not what we were promised, it's still a very good game

As a big Bethesda fan, I have to say I was disappointed. I came to this game on day one of release after hyping myself up with Skyrim, The Outer Worlds and No Mans Sky all of which should have been decimated by the level we expect from a big developer like Bethesda. This game was just, not it. Here are some pros and cons.

Pros:
Beautiful new world to traverse
An interesting main quest
Custom ships and outpost building

Cons:
5 loading screens to get anywhere
Completely overloaded with fetch quests (with the above, you can see how this is an issue.
New game plus only has one slight change to the original main story. Either complete the game and immediately start over or never complete the game.
Glitches everywhere!
You need material to build your outposts but the material weighs so much it takes eons and a lot of frustration to create a single space

This is just a few but they were enough to turn me away. I fought through a full play through and then waited until now (almost 2 years later) to go through new game plus but was left bored and uninterested. Instead, I'll just play Skyrim and the new Oblivion Remastered instead.

I love this game. Does it live up to a truly expansive immsersive universe? Not fully, but that's a difficult task. Outpost building and management leaves a lot to be desired, and the ship crew experience could be much more immersive than it is. but overall, it's an immersive and impressive game. Fallout in space.

Bethesda didn't learn anything from the launch of No Man's Sky, they've created a universe which is as wide as an ocean but as deep as a puddle. 

- Outside of the core cities, towns and story locations, every planet just feels like a featureless rock hurtling through space. 
- The main story feels uninspired and linear, same with the core NPCs, I'd rather roam aimlessly on a dozen barren wastelands than do a story mission. 
- Although ships are fun to create and customise, they feel functionally useless.
- Fast Travel everything 
- Once you've been in one gunfight, you've been in them all.
- The in-game visuals are not impressive enough to justify how badly it runs on good hardware. The Creation Engine is a relic of a time when Bethesda were on top of the world, its time for something new. 

I don't know how the development of ES6 is going, but if Bethesda are using the same tools, development philosophy and Director as Starfield, they should consider starting over.

I have about 5000 hours  in Morrowind. Countless hours in Oblivion, Fallout 3, Fallout New Vegas, and Skyrim. I bought each of those around 4x on different consoles and platforms, mostly Xbox. 
Starfield is a game without a soul. Can you get 200 hours out of it? Sure. Is it better with mods? Probably. Is it worth full price? No. Bethesda fell way off. Starfield is 20% of the quality of previous games. Most of the hours I spent in game was tinkering with starship builds and hunting for free ships. It got old after a while. You can only see the same 3 POIs on every planet so many times before you question whether your time is more valuable playing something else. This is procedural generation at it's worst. The NPCs look like abominations. They look like what Aliens would draw if you asked them to draw a human. Insane levels of uncanny valley. The biggest immersion breaking aspect of this game is the random temples that you are supposed to loot over and over, created by unknown aliens and somehow unknown to all of humanity except that they are everywhere. There are so many things in this game that will destroy your immersion. Everything has censorship and training wheels. Bethesda is a company long past it's prime, and I doubt they have the ability to design what they did in the past.

A new game from Betatesta, crazy. Let's see. Ah, crap... I completely fell for you rascals. Starfield isn't a game, it's a modding platform that offers dubious talent the opportunity to offer their "creations."
It's good for recruiting new talent who will hopefully work on Elder Scrolls 6 or something similar. The rest is exactly that:
A framework, modular, flexible, and typical of Bethesda: years behind all current technical capabilities. Based on the reviews, I also have to realize: These developers are largely past their prime; I don't want to have to pay 70+ DLV+DLC+DLC+DoubleD+Micromade to get my game complete or even: bug-free; better: as described.
But I'm also incredibly happy to occasionally squint at the sales figures. The idea of making money with currency for crap is finally dying out, great. Welcome to the future! Without Starfield or anything similarly inferior in our lives, we can confidently set off into the sea of stars (Starfield—starfield, that sounds so typically tiny, so powerless: all of Bethesda.) There, where trials await us that cannot be solved with inferior software or circumvented with sloppy programming for the purpose of (profit) maximization.

I'm also very glad that I still have some time to watch another of the "old" (meaning: antiquated) software companies, dependent on the consumer (from the publishers' perspective, we are consumers, neither customers nor players, and absolutely not owners of the games), crumble. However, I feel very sorry for the purchasing power that has found its destination here.
I'll bet anything: with that money, the smarter Steam users could have easily created their own IP, with space in the game and stars, not crammed into tiny, eternally identical maps with endlessly identical flora and fauna (if they even exist), textured enemies, and everything up to the ugly sound in endless procedurally generated x1000, because the game has 1000 planets, which is a lie: There are no planets in the game; they're just small maps with minimal content, because the engine is outdated and no (Beth) developer is interested in making something new (in this case, more like something old: delivering a good game). The next... "cool DLC" urgently needs to be released, otherwise the immersion (great keyword: immersion...) won't be right, because: the acrylic hooves won't keep their feet on the ground.
Be brave, you wonderful, young developers. You prove every day what you're capable of when you're not forced into a box.

I want to update this review after I finished the main quest, which I did now.

I still recommend this game, although I want to highlight some things:

- the game is not Fallout/Skyrim in space. It's more of an open world RPG
- building has no added value. In Fallout4 I used to build giant settlements, hours of work, designing and extending. Here I built one or 2 outposts but the building system is counter-intuitive and not needed
- once you have a nice spaceship, with enough storage, you are good
- companions are useless. I walked with Dani Garcia for a long time, there was no interaction. But at some point I was at Constellation I got like 5+ optional companions. I walked with Sam Coe for some time, but I never got to the highest affinity level. 
- companion stories are boring, uncompelling
- the game is beautiful, so much to do and see, but many places I never went to, the galaxy is just too big to visit every corner
- also maps were too big, there was a clear path to the next target, but I saw huge extra places I could go to, but I was not encouraged to do so 
- in Fallout4, I extensively modded weapons/armor etc, but here I modded absolutely nothing. Modding/crafting is not needed at all for the game. 
- the skill system is too big. I became level 40 when ending the main quest, but the only skills I used are weapons, lock-picking, carry weight, persuasion and some ship skill (shields, targeting). The rest of the skill are overkill IMO 
- too many weapon types, in the end I always used only Maelstrom and Grendel, and then upgrading each time when I got a better version


In the end, still a nice game. I still need to start shattered space.

Of course! Here is a revised and improved version of your Starfield review, correcting the errors and organizing your points for better clarity. This is ready to be posted.

A Great One-Time Journey, A Flawed Forever Game
I want to start by saying that my first playthrough of Starfield was a great experience. I am a completionist, and I loved how many side quests there were to get lost in. The game is incredibly complex, with deep systems for ship and outpost building that seem designed for multiple playthroughs. For that first journey, I spent countless hours and had a lot of fun.

However, this is where the game catastrophically fails. The core game balance is completely broken.

On my second playthrough, just three hours in, I lost all motivation to continue. The gameplay loop became a tedious chore. Every visit to a city involved running from shop to shop, selling enough gear to completely empty every vendor's bank account. After that, my only options were to find a bed, wait 24 hours for the shops to get more money, and then repeat the process. There is no logic or fun in this.

The problem is that the game's economy does not scale with your level. High-level items are worth more than all the vendors in an entire city have combined. With a few good skills, you can make money so easily that it ruins any sense of challenge or progression. It feels like this core issue has been abandoned, as there have been no fixes for such a simple but game-breaking problem.

Conclusion:

I recommend playing Starfield for one, single playthrough. It is a fun and massive game that is worth the time for that initial adventure. However, I will not be purchasing the DLC. Core economic fixes like this should be part of the base game, not something we have to hope for in paid content.

It's truly a shame that such a great idea with so much potential falls apart because of a simple lack of balance, which completely kills the replayability it was clearly built for.

I wished the weapon/suits/crafting modifications was similified - but again that is a normal Behesda game.

The story is fun, the mechanics are well designed.  I don't say this often but I'm not sure I even need a mod to help make this game fun.

I don't know where to begin.
I watched the showcase back in the summer of '23, and preordered the most expensive version of the game like an idiot. I was so damn hyped and love BGS and space. My first playthrough was roughly 20 hours and I beat the game 2 days after it came out in early access. I loved it, although it was a nightmare to get it to run at 60 on my gtx 1660 ti lol (still isn't optimized well). The story is really nice and the ending and the whole way they handled NG+ is creative. But that's it.
Starfield is a game that checks the boxes. It looks nicer than other BGS games, has very polished gunplay, and you can get some cool choices to make. However, it does all of these just to the bare minimum. Maybe I expected too much, but this game was just kind of underwhelming. After the novelty wore off, I didn't want to do more. Space was underwhelming, planets were all so similar, and story didn't capture a feeling in me that made me need to experience it again. 
Starfield 2 years later is unfortunately the same. They added a car, fixed some bugs, and Shattered Space came out. And yet I never felt the need to play it. Unfortunately, Starfield is just aggressively mid. It's not bad but it is just a game. It isn't the groundbreaking new Bethesda IP we all wanted, but it's not the nail in the coffin for Bethesda. It's just kinda like a B tier restaurant that isn't bad but you wouldn't eat there again.

Even after 86 hours, I am still thoroughly enjoying Starfield. It takes elements of Bethesda's style of RPGs and mixes them with core elements of Star Citizen, No Man's Sky, Mass Effect and other games to create an enjoyable space RPG experience. 

The core elements it borrows from those other games aren't done as well as they're done in the other games, but they give Starfield so much more to do overall than any of them individually. It doesn't have the same level of heart and storytelling that Mass Effect has, but it does have a sense of exploration, discovery and open world elements that Mass Effect lacks while capturing good action RPG gameplay. It's got a realistic sense of scale but doesn't have seamless transitions and superior planetary tech like Star Citizen. It feels so much more alive than Star Citizen due to the characters, story elements and flavor added even to side quests and missions. No Man's Sky captures a truly endless universe and does so with plenty of variety but lacks the realism that Starfield still manages to capture. Outpost building in Starfield lacks some of the variety compared to No Man's Sky but ship building in Starfield feels very satisfying. There are a lot of other elements you could compare, but the pattern essentially continues in the same way.

While there are plenty of disappointing, under-cooked elements, I think ultimately systems in Starfield that are "good enough" are often faulted for not being excellent like there are in other games. Starfield is very much a jack of all trades but master of none. By far the biggest disappointment in the game is the fact that, apart from initial bug fixes and QoL improvements, Bethesda seems to have abandoned the game. A little more polish could have improved the disappointing elements and made some of the things that were done well enough to become legitimately good. There's a lot of potential here and I hope that this game can be revived.

Regardless of the disappointments, this is still a fun game as is and I will continue to thoroughly enjoy it for many hours to come.

Starfield is one of the most disappointing games I've played. I love the idea of a rich space RPG where you pilot a starship, explore a galaxy, and get involved in the politics and intrigue of all the civilizations you discover out there.

But Starfield so poorly executes on that vision, both technically and in terms of the game's design, that it just boggles my mind as to how a game company with the resources of Bethesda, with the same talent that created Fallout 4 and Skyrim, could create such a disaster. 

--

The pacing of the game is entirely off. They begin by dumping you into a huge city filled with more than a dozen quests that all end up being boring fetch missions and exposition dumps. I kept hoping the next quest would be interesting. But no, the next one was just the same as the last. No intrigue, no choice, no way to express my character, no different outcome based on my choices. Heck, even my starting traits mattered little. I'm not sure why these quests are here; if you aren't going to lead with your strongest quests, I'm not sure why you'd begin by placing your players there.

There's no sense of discovery as in Fallout or Skyrim, as many others have written about. You teleport from POI to POI, all separated by loading screens, rather than piloting your own ship. No Man Sky figured out how to do it, why can't Starfield?

There is an annoying stutter on my machine, even though I have an extremely high-end rig. Though, the textures are high-resolution and the art design is beautiful.

Crafting is overwhelming. There are an intimidating number of inputs to crafting, all slightly different in confusing ways. Like, I wanted to get into cooking, but I couldn't find any bread - a required input. I bought items that sounded like bread, but they aren't valid inputs. I visited several stores looking for bread, and wasn't able to find one. I don't understand.

There's a lack of game design polish everywhere. I've mentioned crafting already, but let's take pick pocketing: There's no pickpocket minigame. You just walk up to someone and see an HTML pop-up menu. Just click the item you want to take. How boring.

Menus feel designed for consoles, I guess, and have far too many clicks to get what you want out of them. Real estate is wasted on close-ups of items, for some reason.

--

Nothing feels like it works together. It seems obvious to me that they hired an army of artists to make tons of different items, a ton of writers to come up with a ton of small, meaningless quests, an army of level designers and environment artists to make tons of cities and caves and interiors, a few game designers to separately craft the trait systems, combat systems, crafting systems, spaceship systems, outpost systems. And then they sort of smashed everything together. What we get at the end just doesn't work together, and all sort of sucks as a result.

But I was fine with that. Whatever. It's janky, okay? It's too big? It's a little stuttery? Fine. Whatever. I was okay with all that. It's a huge space game, but I love space. I'll deal.

What broke me, dear reader, was a stupid side quest to go to a supposedly dangerous cave that claimed dozens of lives on Mars and pick up a precious rock, the Heart of Mars, that was worth thousands. The quest giver strongly emphasized how haunted and dangerous this place was.

Reader, there was nothing interesting about the cave I teleported to. Nothing happened when I walked in. No enemies. No environmental hazard. No puzzle. It was just a cave. 

But what broke me and made me write this review wasn't the terrible quest, it was this: I couldn't pick up the Heart of Mars itself. The quest was bugged.

I google it, and discover posts from 2 years ago saying how this quest is broken, and you need to use a console command to clip through the ground and grab it from under the ground. Oh, and doing that disables achievements. Unless you download a mod.

Best of all, I see a developer post saying it was fixed, two years ago.

Dear reader, it definitely isn't fixed. And it probably won't ever be fixed.

--

It is the final stage of post modernism where society strips itself of humanity and embraces nihilisism so it can reach for the star for reasons.  It is odd to go into a room and scan the characters, only to know what role they play and what they will say, provided you still want to listen to the committee/AI generated dialog.

The UI feels like a South Korean MMO from about 2005, minimal, drab, yet still hard to read.  What makes it bad is that the player will find themselves in the menus a lot.  Go Murder Hobo then spend 5 minutes managing inventory and plotting the fast travel.  Want to base build, same deal.  

The most interesting thing about this game is it the first game I ever played that expresses its Agile subcommittees work so overtly.  In going from one subcommittees' work to another, there is a marked change in everything from what needs clicking to how to complete an action.   Each part from flying to conversations is a completely different mini-game.

All mods are purchased through micro transactions.    I will not spend more money on a 2 year old game.   they just thought they could capitalize on the work of others.  Not a fan.

All I can say is: disappointed. 

My main issue is that they have claimed it's a 'huge universe' simply because they have a bunch of planets you can land on. But the catch is, it's all procedurally generated. You can land on one planet, and encounter the exact same fauna/flora as you did on a planet on the other side of the universe. The creatures and plants will have totally different names to the carbon copies you encountered before. 

You will then land on that same planet at a later date, and the whole lay out will be completely different. 

And there are seemingly randomly placed structures on moons, again procedurally generated. The lack of continuity is a huge flaw. The buildings again. carbon copies of other buildings you've explored. 

MORE PLANETS does NOT EQUAL high quality gameplay.

We would value less planets but with fixed, non randomly generated locations that actually have flavour and a proper story around them. It feels totally soulless and I haven't even bothered finishing a full playthrough because the immersion breaking is just not acceptable for an RPG game.
