Remember when Starfield was supposed to be the next big thing? A vast living universe where you could lose yourself in adventure? Turns out “adventure” meant clicking through five menus just to see a glorified JPEG of a planet before being dumped into another recycled outpost.

Fast forward to now, and Bethesda’s approach to post-launch support is basically, “If we don’t talk about it, maybe you’ll forget it exists.” No major updates since late 2024, no transparency, no meaningful communication, just PR fluff about “exciting things in the future” while the player base bleeds out from boredom.

Even the modders, Bethesda’s historical unpaid game-fixers have collectively noped out. The community patch? Dead. Modding scene? A wasteland. Most have moved on to literally anything else because, shocker, fixing a fundamentally hollow game isn’t fun.

Bethesda promised “NASA punk,” we got Menu Simulator 2023. They promised meaningful exploration, we got barren planets sprinkled with the same four prefab buildings and the thrill of back-to-back loading screens. And now, they’ve gone full stealth mode, zero updates, missing DLCs, and a player community that looks more like a ghost town than a thriving galaxy.

I enjoyed my time with this game, But let's be honest, at this point, Starfield feels like a corpse Bethesda forgot to bury. And judging by their silence? They’re fine letting it rot.

I've played this game twice - once at launch where I completed the main quest and most faction quests and again recently, a few years after my first run. Both times playing the game, rather than having fun, it just made me want to play Fallout NV or Fallout 4, because both of those games were far better than this one, and all Starfield does is tickle an itch I can't scratch unless I stop playing it in favor of an actually good Bethesda game.

This was, and still very much is, a very disappointing game that will probably leave you unsatisfied and wishing for something more if your'e anything like me.

It's a Bethesda Game Studios game, indeed, but don't think too hard about it. The main hallmarks are all here, and the worldbuilding is interesting enough, but take this one on with an open mind. Let it take you on the ride it wants to take you on and have a little bit of fun with it along the way. There are tons of gameplay systems to engage with, but none are groundbreaking or the trend-setter that's going to dominate game design for the next 5 years. Instead, slow down to really experience the good stuff. Fly by the meh, and savor the time spent in this fascinating setting. 

That's the best part, in fact. Not to regurgitate Todd's divine sermons, but I actually really love the term "NASA-Punk" that he used to describe the theme and setting. It's unique, fun to engage with, and I genuinely love that theme for this game. It's what keeps me coming back to this and other BGS titles.

This game is beyond good.  I don't understand or haven't experienced the things in the negative reviews.  I have been playing 28.5 hours and so far, prefer this game over the Fallout games.  This game is massive.  It is a little hard to review without leaving something out.  I've had to watch videos about how to mine resources and build ships because those systems are fairly intricate, considering these are optional side activities.  They seem certainly worth pursuing though.

The story, the factions, the quests and interactions with NPCs, no complaints here.  Not that I remember each quest from other Bethesda games, but these so far have found what NPCs have to say interesting enough and I usually accept their side quests which often have me going to a new planet.  Plus give me them credits!  I usually bring a companion they are great for extra storage and being bullet sponges.  I am curious what happens, if anything, if I keep flirting with Sarah.

Building and resources, and customization - wow.  I haven't really started doing anything with my ship, but I watched videos and looked at some ship parts in the game.  You can pretty much design what your ship looks using parts from different in game ship part manufacturers, inside and out.  I want to get a bigger ship so I can have room for work benches.  I heard you can assign a crew to certain jobs, but I haven't learned how that works yet.  The resource gathering, seems pretty good but I haven't gotten very far.  It seems like it could get complex if you start gathering from multiple locations and want to tie them all together.  You can also assign NPCs to stuff you build here according to tutorial videos.  I never cared for base building in fallout 4 but I will be trying this.

The skill tree, also no complaints.  It does take time to level up which can be a little agonizing since a lot of these skills effect your resource gathering or building, and research and gun upgrades.  But just another reason to keep playing.  That said, this game has a huge lifetime.  I will be playing this for years probably* just to see what I can unlock or fly to.

Some the Karins out there may have complained about planets not having enough variety, but I haven't really noticed.  I mean most planets should be empty right, that's as much as we know about space.  There are so many star systems in this game.  Most I can't go to right now or just haven't yet.  I think there are literally a thousand plus planets.  I have landed on some planets and gone into a build that turned out to be identical to another building on a different planet.  I am not going to give the game an over thumbs down for that.  It doesn't ruin game play it just dulls that part of exploration.  Nobody is forcing your hand.  Seriously - the game would be a terabyte and probably never release if they couldn't reuse some assets.  I give the Devs credit for making so many systems and making going to them fun.  It's pretty amazing you can pick any section of the planet to land on, not just marked outposts. I guess this is on the newer side, but having a vehicle in your ship is an awesome addition!  

This game graphically is very good and there is a ton to do.  It has kept me up later then I would like to stay up.  Super fun, good frame rates (rtx 4070)...I don't know.  I love it, and feel people fine one thing they don't like and then only talk about that.

Bethesda game with no story, no exploration and nonsense worldbuilding. A space game without space or space travel. Join a guild of explorers who supposedly have been active for generations, who have not explored a single thing, walk 50m from their front door in the largest human settlement in the galaxy and you're in completely unmapped territory with completely unknown fauna you can scan for no reason. Visit farmers who live on airless moons, where nothing grows, orbiting verdant green planets where no one lives. Visit small settlements with a handful of buildings that are supposedly humanity's largest remaining cities. See the same dungeon, cave or base over and over again after walking fort ten minutes across a flat dull uninspired square of terrain with nothing to see or do. Build a spaceship for no reason since travel is just a click on a map, no space travel necessary.

Even if you get Starfield for free, get a refund.

Enthralling, immersive and fun

The game has a lot of the classic Bethesda elements.  If you've played Fallout and Elder Scrolls, you'll be pretty familiar with this game's systems.  The gun play is crisp and tactile, and is a massive step up from the Fallout games.  The crafting system can be deep, although many might consider it too much work to get all of the ingredients together to make it worthwhile, when purchasing the final product from vendors does the trick just fine.  

This is due in part to there being so many ingredients, but the Outpost system, while also deep, can largely be ignored.  Until they make some changes to the way Cargo Links work and give players the ability to dedicate a certain amount of cargo space to specific items or item types, the inter-outpost connectivity systems can be almost too convoluted to be worth the time.  I've set up my fair share of fully decorated and technically productive outposts, but then I end up mostly using it just for the launch pad to have access to all the ship modules.  

Most of the negativity I've seen online stems from both the lack of seamless transitions from ground-to-orbit or from planet-to-planet, and the frequent loading screens (doors and buildings) even when exploring on the ground.  While I can understand where that feedback is coming from with other space games from other developers having those features, after re-watching all of the promotional material from before launch, Bethesda never actually stated the game would be seamless: they simply didn't take to social media to curtail the rampant speculation when fans started theorizing about it prior to launch.  By not addressing that and instead remaining silent about it after the Starfield Direct, I personally think Bethesda failed to properly set player expectations for how these systems would function, which led to the disappointment of many fans who were expecting Elite Dangerous or No Man's Sky, and subsequently much of the negativity surrounding the game.

The quest system is familiar, with main, faction, side, and activity/misc quests.  I've seen a lot of criticism about the game having bad writing, and while not every side or faction quest will blow you away with twists and turns or deep narratives, there are PLENTY of quests in all 4 of those categories that WILL do exactly that; consider the disparity in quality between something like the Thieves Guild quest line and the Civil War quest line in Skyrim, for example.  All I'll say, is do yourself a favour and play through the Crimson Fleet and the UC Vanguard quest lines.

My main gripe with the game is that the dungeons in Bethesda's other games have typically been rich in environmental storytelling, and while that's mostly the case in this game with each POI having it's own minor story to tell through terminal entries, notes, and/or audio logs, an issue you'll never run into with Fallout or Elder Scrolls is running into the exact same dungeon with the exact same environmental storytelling on 4 times on 3 different planets in one night.  All that being said, I don't think this completely ruins the game, though it can be immersion breaking at times.  The feeling of freedom you get from being able to check out that abandoned space station, that derelict ship, that named destination on a planet, coming across a random encounter after a Grav Jump, finding a spacer ship touched down on a planet, board it, and have it take off with you still inside is worth occasionally stumbling across the same POI that you did 20 min ago.  Maybe not every POI is going to be a new experience, but any of them COULD be.

On a more positive note, ship building is an absolute standout.  It offers unparalleled customization, letting you design everything from fighters to freighters. Any module you add to your ship, with the exception of the Structural modules, are not only cosmetic, but also impact performance or provide some function, like a control room providing greater crew capacity, or a living space module allowing for passengers.  The shipbuilding system is deep and can be a lot to learn at the beginning, but it's actually pretty intuitive and lets the player make a truly unique home base that they can take everywhere they go.  While you may not be able to seamlessly fly between planets, the ship combat is incredibly fluid and satisfying.  I never thought Bethesda would make vehicles with their engine, let alone vehicles that feel like they're flying (even if that's not what's actually happening behind the scenes,) but whatever magic they used to pull this off with the Creation engine... It just works.  Boosting, thruster maneuvering, distributing power, destroying and looting debris or disabling and boarding to fight the NPCs directly, commandeering the ship for yourself afterwards or simply making off with its cargo once everyone inside is dead; I genuinely think this game nails space combat, and fulfills the spacer/pirate fantasy more justice than any other game in the genre.  Total freedom.

Overall, the game isn't perfect, but I don't think any Bethesda game ever has been.  If you're a fan of past Bethesda games and haven't tried this one or are on the fence because of all the negativity and backlash online, I recommend giving it a go for yourself.  I've wanted a game like this for YEARS, and while NMS and Elite Dangerous came close, they couldn't quite scratch the itch I had.  Space exploration, ship combat, crisp shooter mechanics, exploration, AND actual stories and quests all rolled into one game.  I've had a blast for the whole 600 hours I've played so far.

It didn't have fallout's charm, it didn't have skyrim's adventure, the story certainly wasn't as compelling as mass effect. It wasn't bad, it just need a little more to it. Coupled with the fact that it seems like Bethesda has abandoned it just makes the whole thing a bit of a disappointment.

Immersion is where Starfield earns its badge. The sense of scale is massive. You’re not just traveling planet to planet — you’re carving your legend across the galaxy. Between planetary scanning, mining resources, recruiting crew, or sweet-talking your way through politics, the game lets you live in its world.

It’s not always fast-paced, but it’s thick with detail. And when you’re sitting in the cockpit watching a sunrise over an alien world, it hits you.

Okay, let’s be honest — not everything is zero-grav gold.

Menus are a little clunky. Some planets are empty by design, which can feel like procedural filler. And fast travel can break immersion if you’re expecting seamless No Man’s Sky-style transitions.

But none of that overshadows the core experience — it just occasionally pokes you like a creaky door in an otherwise killer star ship. Combat is tight — more Fallout 4 than Skyrim, with weighty weapons, jet packs, and the occasional zero-G shootout that makes you feel like a bullet ballet dancer.

Ship combat? Chef’s kiss. If you ever dreamed of being Han Solo with a more questionable moral compass, customizing your own gunship and taking down pirates is your jam.

The RPG elements are deeper than you’d think: pick-pocketing, persuasion, science, stealth... it's all there, and your build matters.

It is bold, enormous, and undeniably Bethesda. It’s not a revolution, but it’s an evolution — a love letter to space, exploration, and the kind of freedom only video games can offer.

If you’re the kind of player who likes getting lost in a universe and writing your own story among the stars, this one’s for you.

This is one of the most mismanaged games I have come across. If you look at Fallout 4, it was released on 11/10/2015. 3 months later they announced 6 DLC's as well as dates it would be released. By 8/29/2016 all 6 DLC's were released.  That's less than a year. 

Starfield was released on 9/6/2023. It is just short of two years after release and there has been 2 updates. One that introduced new maps and a vehicle. The second an expansion that was underwhelming to say the least. During these almost 2 years there are bugs from both launch of the game as well as the DLC that have yet to be fixed. To get any new content you have to buy mods. There is no guarantee the mods will work and you have to worry about things like load order.  Even Bethesda themselves are selling content as mods. How they can justify asking players to pay an additional $10 for 2 missions is beyond me. 

Don't waste your money. Bethesda isn't supporting the game. The game and DLC/paid mods will end up costing you over $100 USD.

In short, the game shows everything that is wrong with Bethesda and why you should take the money you are going to spend here, and spend it on some small indie games.

I'm not looking to bash this game, I believe there were many people who worked on it that wanted to make a great game.  
For me, (40+ hours in), I am struggling to continue.  If you've played other Bethesda RPGs, you'll know what to expect.  Passable writing, center framed NPCs droning on about something, obvious skill trees/leveling, bloat quests, passable combat.  The thing that constantly brought me back to Bethesda, (Morrowind, Oblivion, Fallout 3, 4, Skyrim), was the exploration of the worlds.  Starfield lacks that, and it hurts the overall design.  The planets and environments don't pull me in.  I don't feel compelled to explore or level my character.  I've rolled my eyes at multiple story beats.  Obvious Bethesda tried and tired story beats.  
I'm so glad I have a fast PC because man, the NUMBER of loading screens.  6 to go from one location to another, jeez!  And there is this weird sluggish progression and economy that feeeeeeels like it was meant to be a live service game.  I might be way off on that point.  
Anyway, if you have any interest in this game, consider a sale.  It's definitely the best looking in-house Bethesda game, that's about it though.  Hope this review helps.

I decided to play Starfield on Xbox for Windows first, because it was free with my subscription, and I could see whether I liked it before buying. Yes, you'll have to buy the base game if you want to enjoy DLCs in future.

I read a number of reviews that give Starfield a mediocre score. If so, I would agree that it would be too expensive and give it a miss for a while.

I found that, as I liked Fallout 4, I also found Starfield to be quite a nice game. Very similar to Fallout 4 in many aspects, but different enough to warrant the investment of my hard-earned cash. The playing field is very much bigger for a start. The mechanics of movement, firing, etc., are very familiar. It is very much a Bethesda game.
 
On Xbox for Windows I found the game was quite jerky, with lots of waiting between cut-scenes, door openings, and so on.  I often found myself very frustrated and annoyed when, on meeting a new opponent and pressing fire, the PC stopped while loading the next bit of code. Then all of a sudden my PC would come to life and disorient me. Vocals also caused a big stalling on the Xbox for Windows version.

Not so on Steam. On Steam, Starfield is much smoother and more fluid. I have yet to experience the same freezing when firing at a new opponent. There is some delay of starting a speech scene, but I think that is n worse than in Fallout 4, and I can live with it.

I have a few other space shoot-em-ups, but Starfield is the most satisfying for me. I like that it has some of Bethesda's quirky animations - people walking in front of you as you're engaged in a shoot out, NPCs moving to and fro for no apparent reason, and your companion always getting under your feet.

Also, at the moment, at least, the Steam version has the best, and easiest to install, mods. However, as with Fallout 4, installing some mods in Starfield may affect your ability to progress in the game. For the moment I'm happy to play the vanilla game and enjoy a familiar yet, strange and new gaming environment.

Oh. And I paid for Starfield with my own cash - although, I did find a discount code and saved quite a bit. Saving now for the 1st DLC, which, again, has had disappointing reviews. We'll soon see about that. C'mon Bethesda and Steam how about a 50% discount?

On a technical standpoint, this is Bethesda's most impressive work. It's visually stunning and it's definitely the least janky game they have released so far. It's surprisingly well optimized running at 4k on a 4070ti I had 90-120 fps with no stutter and loading times were crazy fast so hats off to them for that. 

Story is a big old meh. Forgettable characters, repetitive content, weird quest design choices at times, but it was still enjoyable enough that I didn't need to force myself to finish it, I genuinely wanted to see it through.
Faction questlines were the most fun I had during my time on this game.

Gunplay is very solid, grounded and it feels great. Lots of weapons to use, decent gun modding.

This a not a space exploration game. This is not fallout or skyrim in space. It has that Bethesda game feeling, but it will never be what their other IP's are. Don't compare too much, don't expect too much, go in with an open mind and enjoy it for what it is.

Overall I'd give it a solid 7/10 and I'd recommend to buy it on sale.

The most mixed of bags. Fun, with good ideas, but deeply flawed. The very definition of wasted potential.

Starfield is, in essence, Fallout 4 taken to an extreme. The parts that worked are improved and expanded, while all the bad stuff is further neglected.

The gunplay is great, improved from already good system in Fallout 4. Dedicated grenade and bash buttons are very welcome, everything's more responsive and visually satisfying. There's also spaceship combat now, complete with boardings. You also have a drivable vehicle with a turret. Outposts are [i]fine[/i], resource gathering is more focused on outpost extractors and mining with a laser, but you can also do asteroid mining with your ship. There's a lot of POIs to explore and shoot through, so the looter-shooter aspect is definitely at it's best here.

On the other hand, the setting is bland and generic. There are some very cool elements, but they never really go anywhere. It's like they wanted to go full NASA-punk, which would be a cool and unique aesthethic, but abandoned the idea to give us Generic Sci-Fi Universe #44325. The factions and characters are forgettable, quests are boring with the exception of a few standouts, and the roleplaying potential is very shallow.

And then we come to the main reason behind the negative review - modding. Starfield fully integrates Bethesda's "Creation Club", allowing anyone to upload their mods to be purchased for "creation credits". A 500 pack of credits costs around 5$, and cheapest mods will run you 100 CC. I don't think I have to tell you that this was a horrible idea that hit the final nail in this game's coffin. Buying a mod for $1 sucks if you find out you didn't like it, or it's buggy, or it conflicts with your other mods, or it's outdated, or it bricked your save. And it will get expensive VERY QUICKLY, as many people consider a modlist of 100 individual mods to be "very lightweight", with some modlists hitting THOUSANDS, with many times that being testing of mods that didn't make the final cut. And that doesn't even touch upon lack of support for external tools, like MO2, BodySlide, DynDOLOD, xEdit, and many, many other essentials.

And if you look at NexusMods for Starfield, you'll see what it led to - a barren wasteland. Many mod authors who even started modding the game in the first place have already given up. The game has so many great systems that could make it the ultimate modding platform, like the procedurally generated planets, NG+, shipbuilding, drivable vehicles, and so much more. But none of that matters when there's no mods. Unless you want $1 weapon skin packs or player homes, there's NOTHING.

Ultimately, Starfield is a fun game for a few hours of looting and shooting. It's not a deep RPG, it's not a full-featured space sim, it's not a [i]great game[/i] - and because of Bethesda's vile murder of the modding scene, it never will be.

I recently saw that the last time I played Starfield was October of 2023. Since then there have been a handful of updates, several of them large, and none of them really offering anything that stands out and says "come play me again."

In fact every time I sit down and think "maybe I'll play through Starfield again," by the time I boot up Steam and am ready to click 'play' I waver and instead boot up Fallout 4 or even Skyrim again for another run through. Both of those games have advantages over Starfield including familiarity and the vast modding community of Skyrim as well as a much more fleshed out and robust gameplay system in Fallout 4

It's not that Starfield is bad, it's just that it isn't... well... all that fun. The base building is mediocre and absolutely pointless, whereas in Fallout 4 at least if I do things right settlers will arrive on their own and populate my settlements and I can establish ways to earn money or set up businesses to sell and buy items, and it seems like there are a hundred different play styles I can utilize through the perk tree. Whereas in Starfield it feels like half of the perk tree is mostly just useless even if I want to try something different

And ultimately the thing that will always leave a sour taste in my mouth concerning Starfield are the procedurally generated planets. Once you've trekked through a handful of planets and seen the dozen or so outpost styles the game has then you've basically seen everything Starfield has to offer. Sure there are unlimited planets or whatever, but ultimately those "unlimited" planets are all the exact same in the end

Basically if you go to Planet A and see Outpost Layout H, then later on you go to Planet Z and it happens to have Outpost Layout H, then you'll get the exact same story on a completely different planet. If OLH has a story where scientists were attacked by scary monsters and in room 1 you find a tape where Mr. Johnson gives his account of the monsters swarming them, you'll find the literal exact same tape on two different planets with the same Mr. Johnson tape in the exact same area

It was lazy design and means this "vast" game really isn't as big as the developers claim. I know Bethesda wanted to make Starfield the next big property but it sure doesn't seem like that's the case. 

To be nice to the game I will say the Spaceship creation is fairly in-depth, though the UI leaves a lot to be desired and it doesn't exactly explain things well. The game also looks beautiful, and the story is fine and enjoyable enough to run through once. But yet again even after typing up this review and convincing myself I should play through one more time, I find myself thinking Fallout 4 might be a little more fun to trek through

Starfield is a solid space RPG with that familiar Bethesda touch — large open areas, plenty of freedom, and lots of systems to explore at your own pace. The main story is decent, side quests are often more engaging, and the overall atmosphere of space exploration feels immersive. The gameplay loop is relaxing: land on a planet, explore, complete missions, manage gear, and move on. Ship building and combat are pretty enjoyable once you get into them, though the UI could be more intuitive at times. Technically the game runs okay, and while there are some bugs and rough edges, nothing game-breaking.
Starfield may not blow your mind from the start, but it quietly grows on you — and if space RPGs are your thing, it’s absolutely worth playing.

Starfield is a game that was designed for endless game play, not to tell a story. As of writing this review I have 183 hours and I intend to put many more into it, however I can not recommend this title for reason that it is a puddle advertised as an ocean. Without getting into spoilers, late game there are many many actions that you can take which should lead to you experiencing some sort of consequence but that never happens. The world feels static and unchanging no matter what actions you take.

Graphics are great, sure, but that’s about it. The game feels stale, and I actually got a headache from how boring it was. The AI characters look lifeless and awkward hard to believe this is what they came up with after a decade of development.

I’m glad I only paid $35, because this game definitely isn’t worth full price. The UI and inventory system are a mess, and keeping up with upgrades and mechanics feels more like doing chores than having fun. It’s poorly organized compared to other modern RPGs.

Ship combat? Mediocre at best. The whole experience just feels... hollow. I found myself not caring about the story at all it’s just bland, like background noise.

Sad to say, but Starfield is more talk than substance. If this is what 10 years gets you, maybe it’s time to rethink the formula.

Then there’s the dialogue options of pointlessness. Why are these always a thing in Bethesda games?! And why so many useless options? Well, since I tortured myself “playing” for too long to get a refund, I guess I’ll have to check out the MOD scene. We’ll have to see if MODs can rescue the steaming pile of garbage, like all of the other Bethesda games before it.

This is such a disappointment. Bethesda is a shell of it's former self. There have been far too many absolutely stellar singleplayer RPGs released in the last half decade that make some of the design choices in this title stick out like a sore thumb in 2025. 

I distinctly remember that the first three times I tried to "do" something in the game I got completely stonewalled by it. I tried to steal the spaceship the game gives you for free 5 minutes later, nope. I tried to LEAVE MY SHIP TO GO OUTSIDE IN A SPACE GAME to visit a SPACE STATION, nope. I literally thought my game was bugged, how on earth are you not able to explore stuff in space in a SPACE GAME. And I tried to land just outside of one of the major cities and see what was there, apparently empty nothingness until you hit an invisible wall. What a tragedy. If I was a developer and I knew I wasted 6+ years of my life on this heap of junk instead of something good I would start looking for another developer that better utilizes my abilities.

People gave up on this game too quickly. Yeah, the marketing was misleading, and the early game is painfully slow New Atlantis feels like a padded tutorial. But once you push through that and start exploring properly, Starfield opens up into something special.

It’s not a perfect game. The loading screens are too frequent, the outdated engine shows its age, and the fan-made Turkish translation (which relies heavily on AI) is a mess wish there was official TR language support.
But the universe is rich, the lore is deep, and the ship customization? Cherry on top. I found myself caring more than I expected crewing my ship, roleplaying my own little sci-fi story.

This isn’t the next Skyrim. But it might be the first true open-universe ARPG, and for that, I kind of love it.
If you’re into space, story, and a bit of Bethesda jank, go for it.

This game is very different to other BGS games but it is very good, especially if you are already a fan of the space / scifi genre. Only issues are some of the loading screens and low fps in big cities but other than those small issues its a great game, one of Bethesda's best imo.

Some fun to be had, but very disappointing as far as an open world space rpg goes. Some cool moments on your first playthrough, but shockingly short. 

Sidequests are very limited with no replay value. 
Large open spaces filled with procedurally generated nothing. 

Main issue is the story, 
the writing is bafflingly bad, from the characters to the story arc. It felt like there were some good ideas, but they never got implemented or were work-shopped out somewhere along the creation process. Characters are hollow simulacrums who exist purely to move the story along and will never once make you believe they are real thinking people. The main story hints at something grand, but then ends. It pretends to have more replay-ability but it's a lie. 

The entire game sortof has a Carl Sagan-esc 'wonder for wonders sake' feel. "There is no story, and isn't that an amazing story?" and it falls completely flat. 

Remember Mass Effect 3? Getting to the end and thinking "Ok, this hologram is clearly lying to me and this is some sort of reaper mind-trick. How do I get out of it?" and then finding out that no... this is actually the story and the intended end. Starfield's story is like that. 

I love Bethesda games, and I'm sad to see this game in the state it's in. Hopefully this is not indicative of future products from this company and they can get back to making great games that will be loved for generations.

Personally, I think this is an excellent game.  If you are looking for a game where you spend most of the time doing space exploration, then this is not for you.  This is a very story driven game and along the way, if you speak to the right people, additional tasks and quests can be added if you accept them.  You can join various factions and earn through missionary jobs.

The controversy over woke is nonsense.  You have a single option during your character selection of becoming a he/him/them.  That is it!  That single thing is stopping people playing the game.  There is the opportunities later in the game to become romantically involved with your main partner in the quests (male or female, your choice) but you can also choose to stay friends or even just work colleagues.

There are a limited range of planet designs so do not expect every planet to be different.  The main story planets are unique but the others are fairly barren save for some outposts with some people to fight with and a few other discoveries.

There is an excellent modding community with excellent additional weapons, outfits and even missions.  You do have to purchase credits in the Creations store which has been controversial but to be honest if you choose your content wisely you can get some good additional content for not much money.

Basically, if you are looking for a high octane space explorer then this is not for you.  If you want a game that you can spend your down time on and follow a good story then this is worth a shot.
Just a damn shame. This is what happens when you let Michael Scott be your creative visionary for your 400 million dollar game, should've stayed in the chess club!   F-

Starfield is a space sandbox where I can get to build ships, plan supply chains, and fight space pirates.  Companions, factions, and the sheer amount of systems to tinker with keep things interesting, but be ready for some of Bethesda’s trademark jank: AI glitches, occasional bugs, and a few design quirks that can trip you up if you love fine detail like I do.

Even with its rough edges, Starfield has given me a sci-fi adventure that lets me play my way, whether I want to roleplay a Freestar Ranger, build the biggest cargo hauler, or live in a survival base on a frozen rock. I appreciate that freedom more than anything.

Took me 3 times of trying to get into this game. Once you finally through the initial overwhelming start the game has a huge amount of good content and is genuinely fun to play.

It may not have the best base building, or the best space combat, or the best quest lines, or the best procedural generated content, but has all that plus great ship building, something I've always wanted in a game, so overall it is still a great game.

This is one of those rare games where I had to go with "No" because it's just meh. The gunplay is fine. Space battles are fine. The main story is fine. The worlds, however, are lackluster. The RNG they used to generate the worlds has about 20 or so buildings, so you'll end up exploring the same ones multiple times. A few are genuinely fun and well designed, but you start getting to where you can run through them in a few minutes. And then run on the planet for another 5 minutes looking to get to the next building.

Running on Low-G planets is enjoyable. Watching the enemies ragdoll in 0.1 G is funny for a while. And then you wish they would hurry and fall down to the ground so you can loot them.

The main story is blah. It's fine, but nothing really gets answered. You never find out the answers to the artifacts. You end up basically just undoing all the good you did when you move on. It's both optimistic and intensely nihilistic at the same time.

The side stories and faction quests are all interesting and fun. Shame the worlds couldn't be as well.

The characters do their "Stare at you blankly while they talk" thing that Bethesda games do. There are definitely bugs in a game this size, but I didn't come across any that were game breaking.

The adage, "An inch deep but a mile wide" fits this game perfectly. If you're looking for a sci-fi bethesda game, this'll scratch that itch. Just don't go looking for anything too deep from it.

If you're looking at the mixed/negative reviews, know this, I'm a decent way in the game and after each main quest you receive an achievement. After this last achievement, I noticed only 29% of players have received it meaning a majority of the haters for this game, haven't even dipped into the story or where things really pick up. Which also means a lot of people are just predisposed to hating on the game without giving it a chance or playing it through. Take it with a grain, but here is my review.

As someone who played at launch with over 150 hours on Xbox, I can clarify there's quite a bit to address here especially in recent times.

I have been playing Bethesda games since Fallout 3 around 2009 and have completed all titles stories. What sets this game apart from all of them has not only been the atmosphere, but the story itself. I know people say it's "forgettable" but honestly I've come to realize those people probably have never questioned the universe outside of religious aspects and more scientifically. This game does exactly that and if I were to TLDR the story without any spoilers, think the movie "Interstellar". Not to rip on Fallout or anything but to me it's the same song different dance in terms of a baby being involved whether it's you or your own, or being shot in the head and somehow waking up, they all just feel the same and honestly I found those stories much more forgettable because they relied so heavily on the "believably sane" option that could relate to almost anyone. What this story is, is much more, it can be applied to our universe and actually help us understand some of the great theories this universe has to offer. It's definitely a more hypothetical realistic approach which is risky knowing people would either love it or hate it, but I thought it was worth mentioning because even Elder Scrolls games we look at and immediately know it's fantasy, although with this title, you wonder if there is actual truth being told to a degree and really makes you wonder. It literally made me feel like a kid again with the amount of excitement this game still brings me.

Playing this game just coming out of a nasty marriage, extended months in rehab and mental in-patient stay's come to find out I'm disabled from schizoaffective, this was the first video game that actually held my attention in almost a decade and what has brought me back to gaming. I know there's also talk about POI's which I whole heartedly agree with. If you don't know, randomly procedural generated worlds are created each time you land somewhere on a planet, it doesn't matter how close you land to the previous landing, it will be entirely different yet consist of the same POI's just set out differently literally in a copy/paste fashion... On every planet. It took me 100 hours to figure this out and once I did, I slowly stopped playing the game and waited for a "fix" to this yet never was fixed. 

From what I can tell so far coming back to this game almost two years later, is that I kept getting this itch to play a Bethesda title, and re-dipped my feet in each one, yet it wasn't scratched. That I valued the story so much more in Starfield than the actual exploration and a lot of people do not understand the reason why there are so many loading screens, it has to do with the fact that each time you load into a different section of the game, it saves whatever tangible objects location is so that it will be exactly was as you left it. Meaning if I dropped a pear on one planet and decided a week later, in game or real life, to go back to where I put that pear, it would still be there. So with that being said, it explains the all the loading and helped me be more forgiving on the experience after learning this.

After many day's hovering over the purchase button for this game during the summer steam sale debating if I wanted to come back to this game knowing I NG+10 times in my Xbox playthorughs, that I would probably be sick of it by now. Although getting through the intro and seeing the constellation again, feeling the excitement of this being the beginning of a non NG+ playthrough hit home and took me back to the magical days of launch and the start to my journey as a father, a single father, and one that had to learn to live with a diagnosis. This game helped keep me stable until I went back into psychosis for three months last summer and was the only game I consistently felt like I looked forward to playing when times were rough. It literally kept me sane.

Buying the game again and replaying it knowing the outcomes to every questline, end game material, I actually am overwhelmed with joy to know I get to re-experience all of this because of how magical every moment of this story felt.

Yes it's very PG but you're in a group of fricken scientists, not gonks and chooms in cyberpunk (a game that was heavily compared to at launch). The PG aspect was actually a breath of fresh air because I went from a life of not having a single soul I could trust and only seeing people's worst sides, to something that reintroduced me to what "normal" and friendly people are mostly like. It retaught me morals in a way.

Needless to say, I'm rambling at this point. Basically what I'm trying to say is if you're looking for space exploration, go for No Man's Sky or Elite Dangerous, or even Starcitizen. If you're looking for engagement and progression, go for Starfield's story and if you're a big science geek like myself, you'll probably actually love the game. I've never played every questline in any other Bethesda title, although this is the first I actually enjoyed doing.

Lastly, just keep in mind what I said about copy/paste POI's and the same ones on different planets. Focus on the story, story lines, etc and when you get to end game, all i'm going to say is you haven't seen this in gaming before. Get it on sale or try it on Gamepass if you have it. But nothing has boggled my brain as much as this game and is the closest I can relate anything to being on the "Interstellar" level of questioning you will have by the end of this game.

Todd Howard and Bethesda, please don't abandon this game or series, there is still so much potential still here. Despite the absolute flaws, this is the only game I've ever actually purchased merch for.

If you go this far in my review and plan on getting it, I really hope you enjoy as much as I did, and currently am again. This one hit's different. :)

Well I won't be laying this confusing piece of ***.  The graphics are amazing but they have made this too complicated.  I've played several other Bethesda games without difficulty, but this one has really tried my patience.  Sigh

I honestly don't know why Starfield has gotten such a bad rep. Is it an amazing game with an unforgettable story? No. But let's be realistic, it's a Bethesda game. We're not playing it for a life-changing narrative, we're playing it because it's fun. It's extremely similar to FO4, and I'm hard pressed to think of issues with this game that aren't present in FO4 as well. 

I'm a big sci-fi fan, and the role-playing aspect to this game definitely scratches an itch. The ship customization is fun, the character skill trees feel well-rounded and tailored to your game-play style (think of a mix between the fallout perk system and morrow wind's skill upgrades, in which you have to actually do the skill in order to level it up). Recent upgrades such as better local maps and adding earthbound vehicles have also been a huge improvement. The character models are pretty good too. 

Complaints about the emptiness of Starfield's world are sort of lost on me -- the plot will take you to interesting and varied locations. Landing on a random moon and expecting something other than moon dust is just not how this game is structured - there will be desolate, empty areas and there will be areas teeming with life/danger. You have the chance to explore both, and following along with the plot will take you to both. The varied gravity and assistance of a jet pack have also made for a unique play style that's really fun. The combat system is... fine. If you've been spoiled by games like Elden Ring, you will probably find it lackluster. I find the exploration aspect a lot more interesting than its combat. It's very typical Bethesda, but the upside is that there is a massive amount of difficulty customization that provides a fix for monotony.

The settlement system is lacking and feels like an afterthought. I would have really enjoyed something closer to fallout 4's system of building. Resource extraction had a chance to be meaningful, but it just feels useless in the game play itself -- not a great way to make money, and with not-very-interesting results. I love base-building but I've honestly skipped it in this game because there's just not much to do there.

There are some really memorable quests, and some quests that are fairly dumb/repetitive (honestly, reminding me a bit of Skyrim - a lot of lost potential in certain narratives and a lot of surprising content in others). The companions are fine, I found myself neither loving nor hating them; the factions also have a really decent history, but I did wish that there was more consequence for choosing to support one group over the other. The game allows you to be MANY things at once, and while that can be fun for having a lot of content in a single save, it can also make your choices feel inconsequential. 

So overall? It's fine! It's honestly a lot of fun if you're looking for a roleplay-focused space adventure. I don't regret my purchase, but I also wouldn't nominate it for any big prizes. Most of my defense for Starfield is out of surprise for how much people dislike it. I bought it on a whim expecting the worst, and actually had a pretty good time with it. If you go in with metered expectations, you'll probably have a similar experience.

I'm having a great time! I love exploring the galaxy with my crew and I am absolutely addicted to designing ships. I love running my outposts like businesses that support my expensive ship design habit. Scavenging for items to decorate my ships and outposts is also a super rewarding time-sink. I take and stash every alien egg I find in crates overflowing with their like from other planets. Over a thousand hours in-game at this point... I feel like I've just started.
nice open world, space exploring, fighting pirates (or joining them), there are a lot of good stories in side missions as well.

I'm surprised that I'm not mad at this game. I avoided it during release because I remember what Bethesda puts out, but I was hankering for some RPG gameplay regardless, so I picked it up.

There are genuinely cool moments. The big ticket fights with Terrormorphs stand out for me and with a little more fleshing out I honestly believe we could've seen Terrormorphs become a new icon of fiction, or at least gaming. 

Likewise, when you get it to work right, starship fights are pretty fun, as are micro-grav shootouts. It's clear that some effort was put into this game.

Emphasis on some, however...

This is a game that was worked on for the better part of a decade? I can't imagine what was left on the cutting room floor...

Factions, history, motivations...every aspect of world building is broken and only makes less sense the more you learn of it. I could go into detail, but there are video essays on the matter and, besides, it's basically every aspect of the game at this point, so please believe me.

Gameplay that is, at best, adequate. It doesn't stand out in any fashion, but it's just a reskin of everything we've seen from Bethesda for like 20 years now. I know I'm not breaking new ground saying this, but it is astounding the levels this company went to just spin its wheels and still manage to sound like it huff its own farts in press releases.

That's my biggest take from my time with the game, ultimately. Bethesda didn't take the time to humble itself. It didn't care how all aspects of the game worked together while the writers were clearly not talking to each other in either the story or quest departments.

Those are pretty big issues in a game about combat and roleplaying and I don't understand how a company that does nothing but that can manage to be so bad at it. Sure I had some fun, but it was mostly despite the game, not because of it.

I'm glad I experienced this, because one way or another it will be a landmark moment. I like what Bethesda can do, honest. I hope that this is their wake up call to go back to basics and focus on the fundamentals of the games they themselves make.

If you're going to make a shooter, make the shooting fun.

If you're going to make a story driven game, make the story engaging.

If you're going to make an RPG, make progression meaningful.

I wouldn't recommend Starfield. I only played it as RPG fast food. I was hungry and it was there. Yet, if this is the game the makes the developer step back and rethink how they make games, I'll be glad for it's existence. Though I doubt I'll ever touch this, again...

After spending over 200 hours on Steam and another 100+ on Xbox Game Pass, I can confidently say Starfield is a good game!

The faction quests and designing my starship are easily my favorite parts. I’ve literally had to set alarms to stop myself from spending too much time upgrading my ship — it's that addictive. I also really appreciate how the traits and backgrounds influence dialogue. That’s a fresh addition for a Bethesda game and a step in a really exciting direction. 

That said, exploration can feel a bit empty at times. Surveying and cataloging creatures isn’t really my thing, but if that's the kind of roleplay you enjoy, there’s definitely something there for you.

I don’t think it makes sense to spend hundreds of hours in a game and walk away saying, “It’s alright.” Some characters are deeply fleshed out, others are more background — but that’s par for the course in a game of this scale.

Overall, Starfield is a solid game. I’m really curious to see how Bethesda builds on its strengths in their next title.

I will never understand why people shat on this game the way they did. Sure, it has some flaws. But overall, it is such a fun game. 
Pro's
-I love the vast worlds and making outposts. Tweaking everything so I can make supply lines and ways to make credits. 
-The story is new and interesting. The concept is mind bendingly complex. There are so many different branches the story could take in the future and that excites me. 
-Ship building to make my own spaceship and decorating it.
-Some of the quests have actually made me emotional.
-I still discover new things on new playthroughs.
-The background and traits help me feel like I am really in character.
-Chunks. Period.
-The views are stunning. I love going to other planets and moons as if it were real life. Exploring and seeing different stars or how the sky looks on each and every celestial body. 
-The times being correct on each place you visit. And it is relative to the rest of the universe. I think that was really cool. 

Con's 
-Crowds look like sims townies but worse. 
-The lipsync gives the uncanny valley effect. I cannot stand how they move their mouths. Looks hella weird.
-The BLOAT on the saves. I have never had a game autosave so much. I even turned off the autosave except for once per hour on pause. And it still saves more than I want. 
-The LOADING SCREENS. There are WAY too many. Docking and undocking really could be less time consuming.
-It's almost impossible to be a "bad guy." I wish there were more endings, more shady characters and just more bad guy stuff!! There isn't really a morally gray character in this. It's either good or bad. If Delgado was a romance companion, THAT would have been awesome! 
-Nothing in this game is fem or masc. It's all so androgynous. Am I saying having those options is a bad thing? No. But it is too gender neutral. I love feminine clothing and armor. And the selection for that is just near to nothing.
-Lastly, I wish there were actually choices to change the story line, as a whole. There is really only one end and one beginning. Yes, the story is fun and exciting. But compared to games like BG3, it just makes it difficult to make any REAL game altering choices. 

Overall, the gameplay is fun and adventurous. I enjoy it very much. There are ALWAYS going to be flaws with any game. I give it a 7.5/10.

Some people might not like it, but I love games that let you explore and choose how to approach missions. I already have 7 hours and i've only just arrived at the first "citadel" type structure. I can tell i'll be spending hours just exploring and even more time completing sidequests.

I like the character creation choices, ship building, outpost building and to build so many in diverse places, along with the missions and overall game play. This is my favorite game. It's good to be back at it. I could not play it for months (tech difficulties). Bethesda has a lot of upgrades that have made this even better.

Finished Starfield and all I got was a galaxy full of loading screens, boring planets, and NPCs with the emotional range of drywall.

Tried a stealth mission—had to steal a key item. Opened the case: empty. Turns out patching the game broke my old save. Bethesda innovating by letting you roleplay as a confused thief.

Exploration? Feels like Google Maps with extra steps.

Would rather get sucked into a black hole than reload that save again.

Not sure this game deserves all the hate, I've really enjoyed a little adventure in space. SO much to explore and so many quests, Ship combat is satisfying and ship building is so much fun. I particularly like the ship power levels and how you can increase power to shields or weapons etc.

This game is just boring. I thought coming back would be fun, that mods would do what the developers failed at. It didn't, even the mod side of things is an empty pit of disappointment. If you want to have a fun space game that feeds you content Mass Effect 1-3 aged like fine wine. This, this aged like toilet water.

By itself, it's an okay game. Don't get me wrong, it has so many things wrong with it from questionable design choices to a very boring and uninteresting story. But even still it's a very interesting concept that I'm surprised Bethesda was able to make work. Although most of the games "entertainment" comes from modding the shit out of it. I wouldn't justify spending $70 on this. Get it on sale, or don't get it at all.

I don't normally write reviews for games, but I feel compelled to express just how much fun I am having with this game. It's not perfect. I have critiques. But regardless of those criticisms, every morning since I bought it I have woken up wanting to play it more, explore its world, and indulge in its amazing NASApunk aesthetic. Video games are a kind of magic, and this one captures that sentiment more than most.

Although the game has some issue, overall I like it and am not sure why the vast majority of players seem to hate this game. Perhaps they were expecting a space sim like Elite or the X series, but instead they got an RPG. The game is like a mix of Alien: Isolation and Deus Ex: Human Revolution with smattering of Mass Effect and No Man's Sky thrown in. Of course it is a Bethesda RPG, so just like Skyrim, it requires several mods to address the shortcomings. And it does have some weird performance anomalies. I have a mid-range system and will normally get 40-50 FPS on low-medium settings (which still looks good btw) but sometimes the game will just randomly drop to 8-10 FPS and look like crap. I can usually fix this by going into my inventory or talking to an NPC, but not always. I am running several mods and don't really know if this happens in vanilla. Another issue is the seemingly deliberate bland-looking NPCs that populate the game. The character creator has a lot of variety and allows for some great-looking characters, but some of the NPCs (mostly the generic "crowd" people wandering around the populated areas) seem to have been deliberately made to look, well, ugly. The other thing that is kind of mediocre is the dialog and overall pacing of the conversations. But I thought the exact same of the dialog in Skyrim and Oblivion. So don't expect the wit of Mass Effect 1-3 (IMO, Mass Effect Andromeda also had some lackluster dialog). The over-arching story-line seems to be a mashup of Skyrim, Mass Effect Andromeda, and No Man's Sky. It hasn't yet given me the "wow" factor and I don't know if it ever will. All of this being said, I hope Bethesda does not abandon this game (if they haven't already).

This game is what Fallout 4 was to Skyrim. It is a backward evolution of all the story and world structure, mechanics and quest design from the previous games, to a point where all that is left is a watered down spectacle theme park that strings out mildly engaging moments across as much gratification delay as it possibly can.

Ignoring all the technical issues with the game, Starfield presents story tropes that are nowadays overdone and mashes them with their old cliche Dragonborn-learn-shout kind of gameplay loop. It's not necessarily the worst idea in the world, as it worked pretty well in Skyrim and we lacked a similar feeling in Fallout 4, but Starfield they did it in the most cringey way possible, and when you come across it, it's rather blatant and eye-roll worthy. The narrative is lowkey and the dialogue is wooden, and there's next to no interplay with animations or music employed to enhance the emotions of particular encounters, making the whole activity of making choices and talking to characters a chore.

Settlement building makes a return, but is rather pointless other than to fill a checkbox of mechanics to put in an otherwise empty game. Any purpose the mechanic serves is overshadowed by other mechanics - you don't need to setup automated mining, for you can just run around a planet with a laser drill for a few minutes and find the resources you need, or buy it at a vendor, if they even have enough money or items for a worthwhile trade. They added a whole spaceship building system, but they implemented just the bare minimum, not thinking about what players would actually want to do with their ships - you can place room modules of various shapes, sizes and types, but you can't really decide where you want doors between them to be (apparently you sort of can but it's 50/50). You also can't place furniture in your ship like you would in a settlement or house as the interiors are pre-modelled.

The sound design and music of this game is perhaps poor if you've heard everything from Fallout 4. I'm unsure if it was the creative direction or due to the range of the composer, but the music in this game just sounds like more Fallout 4, rather than its own thing, other than a few 'theme' pieces. There were many times that I was looting an interior cell and heard some music and felt like I was getting flashbacks to looting train stations and bathrooms in Fallout 4 that I had to step back and do a double take. There are also a lot of reused sound effects in this game from both Fallout 4 and Skyrim, which is really jarring when you're familiar with both games and noticing it pulls you out of the experience.

Taking the lazy route, Bethesda decided to maintain the current cell-based structure of their famous Creation Engine and didn't even bother to innovate upon its world streaming capabilities, leaving a size-limited playing field with a rather unimmersive invisible wall at its edges of the procedurally generated planetsides that forces you to turn around or leave the planet and pick another arbitrary spot to land on. This wouldn't be so bad if the new (and admittedly impressive) terrain-blending feature of the procedural world generator had been given enough hand-authored POIs to actually distribute on the planets, but Bethesda only decided to make a couple dozen different structure types and called it a day. Not even adding new POIs through post-launch updates or even sprinkling some smaller DLCs were on Bethesda's plate.

I would not recommend this game. Even on a sale, you'd be better off watching some YouTube gameplay for a couple of hours and you'll have seen almost everything this game has to offer. And that really hurts me to say, because I love Skyrim so much (still mod it to death to this day, 7500+ mods and counting), so much so that I pre-ordered the Premium offer for Starfield. I gave Bethesda the benefit of the doubt that Fallout 4's downgrade from Skyrim was just a misfire, and that Fallout 76 was the 'experiment', but Starfield truly was the disappointment of the decade for me.

I like it but it's the most "chill" kind of game that bethesda has ever made. Though a lot of reliance on procedural generation, lack of attention that certain places got and other problems with the core of the game make it sometimes feel kind of empty, it honestly really just feels like Oblivion if it was made nowadays. A lot of people expected it to be a "Skyrim in space", while it's straight up a "Fallout 4 + Oblivion with a No Man's Sky sauce". Overall it's an okay 7/10 game, it's not great but it's also not as bad as many people say. If you want to watch a good review then watch either "PatricianTV's" very short 8 hour retrospective or the excruciatingly long 14 minute one by "Forgive me i'm left handed".

Game had good concepts and mechanics, and it had many storylines that had me invested with satisfying endings.

This aside, the game also does feel very haphazardly put together with long loading times and constant lag, and many factions and features that are blatantly unfinished. 

Overall, I still recommend the game and Bethesda's laziness was the only thing that stopped it from being a 10/10 game.

Starfield delivers an expansive, immersive space-faring RPG that both longtime Bethesda fans and newcomers will find hard to put down. Here’s a breakdown of what makes it shine—and a couple of areas where there’s room for improvement:

Storyline
From your humble beginnings as a member of Constellation—the last group of space explorers—Starfield weaves a narrative that’s both grand in scope and surprisingly personal. The main quest chain takes you across meticulously crafted planets, through political intrigues between the United Colonies and Freestar Collective, and into uncharted mysteries lurking beyond known space. Subplots involving mercenary work, corporate espionage, and archaeological digs add layers of depth that keep you invested in your character’s journey.

Gameplay
At its core, Starfield nails that signature Bethesda blend of freedom and emergent storytelling. Whether you’re negotiating with a space station’s governor, sneaking through an abandoned facility, or dogfighting Bandit ships in zero-G, the game consistently rewards creative solutions. Ship customization feels robust without being overwhelming—you can swap components, upgrade weapons, and even paint your vessel to your heart’s content. Ground combat takes inspiration from modern FPS design, with satisfying gunplay and the occasional strategic pause to manage health and special abilities.

Adventure & Exploration
Exploration is Starfield’s beating heart. With over 1,000 star systems and more than 100 explorable planets, you’ll encounter everything from lush alien jungles to rusting industrial wastelands. Random encounters—like distress signals, ancient ruins, or pirate ambushes—mean that even a routine supply run can turn into a memorable side quest. Scanning planets for resources, cataloging alien flora and fauna, and establishing outposts all feed your sense of discovery.

Downsides
No game is perfect, and Starfield’s two most noticeable rough spots are outpost development and game balance early on. Building and managing outposts is a neat idea in theory, but the interface can be clunky, and resource logistics quickly become tedious unless you’re deeply committed to base-building. Additionally, some weapon mods and powerful gear unlock far too early, making certain firefights feel trivial—and robbing the midgame of its challenge.

Balancing with Mods
Thankfully, the vibrant modding community has already stepped in to smooth those edges. Balance-overhaul mods adjust weapon and enemy scaling, ensuring that you’re never steamrolling every encounter simply because you picked up a Legendary Plasma Rifle on your first planet. Other quality‑of‑life mods refine the outpost UI, streamline resource transfers, and even expand building options.

I really wanted to like this game, and when I beat the game I just felt empty. While I had fun with the combat and ship building, you can only explore the same, reused location on a totally different planet so many times.

• Over 90% of planets you explore are dead and for the most part not worth exploring. (Was it so dead and empty so you could build settlements to make it "feel" more alive? Was that the plan?)

• Leveling skills is a chore and not fun. 

• The main companions are trash and EVERY single one of the has an issue if you're evil or chose the more aggressive options. Always complaining about every little thing you do. Best thing you can do with them, leave them behind if you don't want to be nagged for everything you do. I REALLY wanted to do a Hunter playthough, but no, all companions are protected. There was a twist half way through the game where something happens to the one you spent the most time with and I couldn't care less. 

• The Hunter, honestly the best character in the game and the correct character to side with when you can.

• The "Powers". They're trash and can only be upgraded through many playthoughs. You can play but never need to use them due to how weak they are at the start. These only become useful if you plan to play through the game multiple times. 

• The ship building is fun and I really enjoyed it. Ship combat, once you have a decent ship is also really fun. Though at some point you can just sit there and destroy everything on screen with the upgrades and weapons.

• IT IS NOT worth doing a second playthrough if you have weapons and ships you liked, as you lose EVERYTHING when you start a new game+, with no way of saving ship blueprints for easy building or a weapons cache that can save at least a few of them. 9 times out of 10 the items it starts you with will be worse than your current gear and ship, which is a huge loss. 

• When they updated it to add the Creation Club stuff, it shows I have the DLC, I can't access it no matter what I do. Also, every single one of my files have been marked as modded, even though I never used any mod or outside tool as I was achievement hunting at the time, so achievements are locked, even on my oldest save which was done back at the start of the game AND when I tried to make a new game.

• They added a buggy so you can now explore the barren planets faster... Yay?

• For a game that takes place in SPACE, there is very few alien species, all of which are some sort of wildlife. Your main foes will be other humans... in a space game. Honestly this could have taken place in the would of Fallout and I won't question it. (HECK, at least Fallout had ALIENS!) 

This game sadly just is not worth it.

[h1]The game is as wide as an ocean, but shallow as a puddle.[/h1]
     [h3]Closer to a tech demo than an actual game.[/h3]
[b]Positives[/b]
-Gunplay is smooth and plays like a typical generic FPS game from 10 or 15 years ago.
-Ship customization is a highlight, your ship is effectively your home and where you will spend a lot of time.
-A lot of miscellaneous items have detailed models that can be fun to look at once or twice.

[b]Negatives[/b]
- A Solid State Drive is a requirement, if you do not have a Solid State Drive, this game will literally break in the weirdest and most unfun ways possible.

-There is little to no lore. Leaving you with very little to actually imagine or interact with in any meaningful or interesting way. This game is basically just a FPS sandbox for you to fight generic space pirates in.

-The story is barely there, with the grand arching narrative being: [spoiler]Getting to New Game Plus so you can then immediately speedrun to New Game Plus again.[/spoiler]

-The game disincentivizes you from playing as a pirate, thief, or smuggler by putting you into extreme amounts of XP debt, effectively bricking your character's progression by requiring you to grind hundreds of thousands of points to be able to even consider leveling up again.

-Settlements are genuinely a waste of time and require way to much grinding, resource gathering, credits, and time to actually make it worth doing. It is quite literally easier to just go and buy whatever resources you need for crafting from NPC vendors. [spoiler]Also new game plus completely erases your settlements, so save yourself the trouble and do not bother interacting with this mechanic.[/spoiler]

-Major spoiler: [spoiler] The entire goal of the game being to get to New Game Plus effectively robs the story, characters, and actions of the player of any and all weight, making it very difficult to remain immersed or invested in the borderline non-existent story of the game to begin with.[/spoiler]

The world of Starfield is one that feels very barren and desolate. With very little story, with very little lore, with things that could remotely be considered being living breathing settlements being far and few between.

Starfield is little more than a sandbox FPS "RPG" with a story shoe horned in because hard-grinding XP by running around as a murder hobo killing generic space pirates for the sole purpose of leveling up and getting a perk that lets you do 2.5% more damage with pistols is not a very good long-term motivator.

Ship building is cool and ship combat can be entertaining, ultimately your ship is effectively your primary home and where you will spend a lot of time just crafting, doing inventory management, and flying to new planets to repeat your murder hobo routine until you can manage to level up again. It can be genuinely enjoyable trying to customize and make your ship your own. [spoiler]Unfortunately the new game plus feature makes it pointless to actually invest any significant time or resources into this.[/spoiler]

Just started up again this week. New character, bunch of new mods. Mostly clothing/spacesuits, weapons, immersion and quality of life stuff. Oh, and the biggest deal ever: DISABLING ALL TEMPLE BS! Mod that just has you walk in and it's done! Erased the dumbest part of the game for me. 

Now I'm actually having fun. Doing sidequests and faction missions. So far, I'm finding these to be the most interesting and fun of any Bethesda game. It ain't perfect, no Bethesda game is. But I'm having that role-playing, wanderlust type of fun and it just so happens to have pretty good gunplay, fun spaceship combat, ship building that could be it's own $10 game. Have yet to touch outposts, but on NG+ #1 and gonna get into it on this playthrough. I really like the choice they give you when you start a NG+, refreshing.

ok so first things first this is my setup
AMD Ryzen 5 2600 and a
nividia Geforce GTX 1650

now performance issues on a 5 year old setup, the game goes from 30 ish fps in the first 2 missions to 5-7 in new atlantis
all the textures are blurry and with no options for texture quality only VFX and lighting options, i'm guessing my now potato PC is trying to render 4k textures on high poly models, you also can't turn of reflections or ssao to try and save some Vram. 

I find what little story i experienced to be rushed and stupid. you start as a miner on your second day of work. within 5 minutes you find a macguffin star chart crystal witch gives you a vision, when you wake up some dude shows up says your special for seeing a vision gives you his ship and sends you on your way, all of this happens in like 15 minutes of gameplay.

I'm genuinely baffled the game is in this state 2 years after it came out, no official performance texture pack, basically nothing in the way of settings, did they not learn from cyber punk that building your game around high textures and resource intensive effects is a recipe for commercial failure.

I'm extremely pleased and glad I waited a while to get it. It runs well for me. I love the style of Sci Fi that they went for, it feels somewhat based in a reality. Full of color and excellent sound design, very clean and proper. It's fairly mature in it's writing and voice acting - something I appreciate massively. I can't say it is for everyone, but it is for me. I'm happy.
