Starfield is different from other Bethesda games, here you have a universe to explore. 
This game is not a shooter or follow the quests and the game is over. 
The main story is only a small part of the game. 
I have 442 hours in the game and I have not started the main story yet. 
Starfield is an exploration game, you stop on planets to see the stars and think about how small you are and humanity will really succeed one day. 
You can build ships. Explore cities. Each city has quests that concern the history of the city. 
Many planets have smaller cities with missions that send you around space to explore. 
If you are a fan of shooters or Fantasy stories like Elder Scrolls do not play this game. 
If you like space, exploring planets and enjoying the breathtaking view, empathizing with your character, deciding to be good or bad, a mercenary, a bounty hunter, a pirate or even just an explorer of the universe. 
Then there are stupid people who play the main story at fast speed and then: oh what a shitty game...... brainless person, do you know that to finish Starfield you have to do 11 a new game +? because every new beginning the universe is completely different? 
To the heaters who open their mouths without ever having played 1 Minute: go play with Lego, if you are capable or you have to whine there too.

TLDR; vanilla Starfield 6/10, modded Starfield 8/10 a flawed and sometimes boring game, that has a magic that grabs onto a few

After putting over 300 hours on this game figured I'd buy the steam version. To be honest it's a flawed game, but there is still a magic in there. That sentence is considering mods, as for the vanilla experience it's just way too under baked. Mods make this a worthwhile experience, and along with some creations like Watchtower it really brings the experience closer to what it should have been. 

The biggest flaws would be a lack of planet to planet space exploration, I personally don't think atmosphere flight matters or would change the core experience whereas being able to fly from planet to planet in a single star system with encounters such as derelict ships or fleet battles occurring as you fly would have enriched the gameplay flow. That's not what this game is though, it has alot of loading screens but if you have a good system they're basically negligible being under 1-2 seconds with more improvements to GPUs and the such if you choose to hold off on playing this, the experience will only get better with time when you choose to upgrade. For the average person though this won't apply, you'll most likely deal with 5-10 second loading screens back to back all within moments of each other, completely changing the experience from something that's hardly noticeable to something that completely ruins the game for you. 

The POI system also is terrible in the vanilla experience. The biggest issue with it is the lack of variety and an absolute NEED for a larger pool of choices to draw from for this type of game. You'll encounter POIs from the main quest while you're out exploring, or repeats of the same one right next to each other. The only way around this is with mods, which completely improves the experience but is a critical flaw of the game. There will be long periods of time where you're playing this game and essentially doing chore work, such as looting a dungeon can take you 15+ minutes just slowly scanning the room for loot. 

The repeatable radiant quests are braindead, simple, and usually only one step that tend to consist of you going through several loading screens to kill a single enemy, or loot a specific chest. A common theme with this game is that mods greatly improve this experience, mods that increase the payout for these quests, or even add more depth to them. Too many of the systems feel barebones such as the food/drink survival system that are improved with mods. Mods, mods, mods. You get the picture yet? 

With all the criticism I've brought up I still really enjoy playing this game. It has an interesting endgame, it feels like that's when everything really begins. Jumping through the NG+ multiple times, starting from nothing, and trying to build it all back up again is super fun especially with hardcore mechanics added to the experience with mods. Having to manage your fuel, crew morale, etc, adds layers to the systems that makes it a more rewarding experience, while making radiant missions more important when every credit has more worth to it. Plus with paid creations people are making new content at higher quality. 

Unfortunately that's just the name of the game now, I know there are still deniers thinking it won't be in ES6 but that's how Starfield stays fresh. New content coming from mods and creations. So if I ask myself do I think Starfield is worth $70? No. Not the base vanilla game atleast. Do I think Starfield + Shattered Space + Watchtower + mods + free creations is worth $70? Yes. The modded experience is definitely worth it, but it comes with many caveats and it'll be up to your subjective opinion on the story and world building. 

For me it's alot of good ideas but poor execution. Most of the interesting stuff in the lore happened in the past, and the time period in which you play is relatively at "peace" which makes things less tense and lack of conflict in the story. Though I personally find the metanarrative stuff with the NG+ very fascinating to think about. 

I know I said a lot to basically say nothing, but Starfield is an incredibly well made but boring game in it's base form that comes alive when heavily modded and with more content. To make Starfield probably the best space RPG in my opinion is to just add more variety to the POI system, make it more modular and randomized (enemies, loot placement, room layout, etc) and make space exploration more fleshed out. If there are a pool of 90 POIs the game pulls from, it realistically needs to be something like 200 POIs that can be further randomized to make it feel like a truly huge 1000+ planets game world. 

Basically this is Bethesda's modern attempt at Daggerfall, and I personally really like Daggerfall! I started playing Bethesda games with Oblivion and went backwards to Daggerfall and grew a deep appreciation for it but there's just not enough content that's required to live up to it's potential. That same sentence rings true for Starfield. Regardless, there is a magic in exploring, looting, building outposts, hunting down bounties, or whatever. I personally have more desire to play this than Fallout 4 because the RPG mechanics are deeper, even if they're not that crazy deep.

Barfield

When I first jumped into Starfield, I'll be honest – it was a bit of a struggle. The sheer number of game mechanics felt overwhelming, and it took me several hours to really start liking the game. I was slogging through the initial quests, trying to wrap my head around everything, and wondering if this game was truly for me.

Then something clicked. I decided to wander off from the main story, and that's when the real fun began. I stumbled upon the Space Ranger storyline, and suddenly, the galaxy opened up. This side questline truly showcased what Starfield can be, and it completely changed my perspective.

Now, 30 hours in, I'm absolutely hooked. Sure, it's not perfect – I've encountered some minor bugs here and there, and the visuals can sometimes look a bit washed out, especially in caves. But these minor gripes are easily overshadowed by the sheer enjoyment I'm getting.

The side storylines are fantastic, offering so much depth and variety beyond the main quest. And both the ground and space combat are incredibly fun and engaging. Exploring new planets, building my ship, and getting lost in the various factions has been an absolute blast.

If you're finding the initial hours a bit tough, I urge you to push through. Take a break from the main quest, explore, and find your own adventure – you might just find yourself as captivated as I am!

I recommend the game, but understanding what changed compared to prior Bethesda open world titles is key. The biggest change and most serious let down for me is that the diverse, unique and detailed level design and world building is gone. It is replaced by number generators and copy-paste design on all fronts. This approach affects everything, including points of interest, towns, NPCs, quests and character development. The high point for me is that despite the design-by-committee approach, it is also clear that the team tried to rise above that in many ways and worked hard to create an enormous amount of content. I would just like them to use a quality-above-quantity approach next time. About the writing, although the main quest is about at the level of high school fanfiction, I will say that the faction quests are very worthwhile. I did not have any real technical issues while playing.
The game is great. There are a couple things I wish it had like dismemberment and other features, but it is still enjoyable and fun.
I don't know why everyone hates this game. I dig it, and think that it's fun.

[h1]Bethesda’s long-awaited space epic, delivered, alright... straight into mediocrity.[/h1]

Buried under a galaxy of loading screens, carbon-copy outposts, and NPCs with the emotional range of a screensaver lies Bethesda’s grand illusion of exploration. The ships take off but the wonder never does.

Exploring Starfield’s planets feels like navigating a PowerPoint deck. The dialogue system tries to branch but mostly stutters, and the inventory micromanagement deserves its own MBA course.

Sure, it’s massive. Sure, it’s in space. But when every planet blurs into the next, all that scale just amplifies the emptiness.

Starfield is a good game. Hear me out..

Is the game a eye-candy showcase of what is possible for modern systems? No, but it is still quite awe-inspiring if you are the type of person who looks up into the sky on a clear night in life wondering whats out there.

Is the story or side stories the best of a generation or MUST SEE content? Well no, but the main story and faction quests are generally above average. The idea is unique and is certainly worth playing through. 

I believe Starfield is a good game; If it had released back in 2019 perhaps 2020 I think it would be considered a great game. My criticism may seem counter-intuitive for a recommendation, but I do strongly feel the game is worth playing if you enjoy RPGs, Space, or the Bethesda formula. 

I will however say that creation club has been and always will be a practice that should have never existed. It is extremely controversial to sell minor changes to the game or tiny additions for currency. We do not even need to dive into my thoughts on paid mods. But use your consumer due diligence and decide if that is something you are willing to incentivize the industry doing by voting with your wallet in the creation club store. 

TLDR: I highly recommend Starfield on two basic principles. You can find it at a decent discount from MSRP, and you stay away from paid creation club content.

All the best mechanics/features of Skyrim, Fallout series, No Man's Sky, etc., plus new and improved features and mechanics, upgraded graphics -- companions to accompany you and help with fighting, repairing your ship, defending your outposts and if you want you can even marry/romance them.

There are many factions, major and minor, and your notoriety affects your dealings with the factions.  Gain favor with one faction and you may find that another faction disapproves of your actions.  Your companions also have opinions about your in-game actions...just because they are a member of your crew does not mean they will approve of everything you do.

Snow-globes are the collectibles in this game, in comparison to the 'bobble-heads' of Fallout.  Collecting them all enables you to get special spacesuit, helmet and pack (a set).   As with previous Bethesda games this one is filled with things to find and discover...or you can just focus on completing quests and leveling up your character and rush pass it all and not even know it was there.

You can build outposts, connect them together such that cargo ships transfer resources from one to another -- think of multiple sites mining resources and shipping them to other outposts set-up for manufacturing.  The crafting, and building, are dependent on your researching (unlocking) higher tier buildings and equipment.  Outposts can be connected/linked together on the same planet or even in separate star-systems.  It's your choice -- make an empire spanning many star-systems, and linked together, or just one outpost somewhere with a great view to store your loot and recuperate...it can be as simple or complex as you want to make it.

They've taken all the good things from the games I mentioned above, made them better, and created something new -- it is a great game, and will give you many, many hours of entertainment.

[b][h3]Credits to IGN for this Starfield review.[/h3]

I feel like I’m the kind of person Starfield was made for. I loved Bethesda’s last single-player RPG, Fallout 4 (maybe a bit too much), and there’s nothing I like more than a sci-fi universe with spaceships, lasers, and political intrigue flying every which way. And yet, a dozen hours into Starfield, I was feeling lost in space. Things never went too far off course while I was flying my rinkydink little ship around chasing down mysterious artifacts and war criminals with a damn fine crew of companions at my side, but man did Starfield make me work hard to get through that opening stretch. Even when it mostly righted the ship and I was loving the story, sidequests, and launching boarding parties on enemy ships, there were still too many problems that constantly popped up, forcing me to curb my excitement. It’s a bit like Starfield’s own elaborate shipbuilder tool: even though you can slap a bunch of high-end parts together and it will technically fly, sometimes it’s just not the best fit.

I would expect no less: Bethesda has built out a sprawling universe with detailed lore in which humanity has left Earth behind and colonized the galaxy, but hasn’t made first contact with sentient aliens as of the 24th century. It’s chock-full of backstory about wars between its three major factions, run-ins with mysterious space deathclaws called terrormorphs, pirates, and an immense amount more. I wouldn’t call a lot of it especially distinctive – it’s a setting that’s reminiscent of The Expanse, Firefly, and Starship Troopers, full of references to every sci-fi movie from Aliens to Blade Runner, and of course Interstellar. There’s even a fair bit of Indiana Jones influence as it sends you on a treasure hunt to collect mysterious artifacts. In fact, there’s a significant similarity to what Obsidian created for 2019’s The Outer Worlds. But it’s so densely packed in, with more stories around every corner, that I found it easy to get invested in it – once I learned the difference between the United Colonies and the Freestar Collective.

Creating your character is a matter of picking a background story for them that comes with a set of skills and traits, as well as up to three modifiers. It’s always a bit tough to choose this on your first playthrough, since you don’t really know what you’re getting into and there’s no respecing allowed, but none of them is dramatic enough to really hinder you. Some – like the one where your parents are alive and well (if you don’t pick this they just never come up), or the one where a crazed fan follows you around – sound like they’ll be fun to experiment with later, which adds a sense of replayability.

After that, while everyone starts out in the same mining camp and touches the same space magic that sets off a trippy 2001: A Space Odyssey-style vision, Starfield is an immense game that will send you off in all kinds of different directions once it hands you the keys to your first spaceship. It’s to the point where talking to others who played alongside me left us all bewildered and asking questions like:

“Wait, what do you mean you don’t know who the Vanguard are?”


“How did you not meet this person?”


“How are you crafting those weapon mods already?”


“Wow, you didn’t unlock [REDACTED] until level 20?”


“What the heck even is a Va’Ruun?”


“You met who in a bar?”


“Where did you find that ship?”[/b]

Where to even start. 

I have well over 3500 hours in fallout 4. I am an experienced modder (LittleWolf99 on Nexus) in that particular game and have a good understanding of how Bethesda's games work. 

This game is Horrible. I do not say this lightly. I have an extremely high tolerance for Bethesda's Species of bugs and Bad story telling but this game takes the cake, throws it on the floor, and dances on in. 

Problem #1 and the only reason im not going to press on. I have a weaker system (AMD 3600 with a GTX1080) nothing speical but i have always been able to play in 1440p usually with high or max settings in every game I play (#1 being FO4 i have it beyond maxxed. Also, Cyberpunk at 1440p medium, GTa 5 Maxxed, Red Dead 2 1440p medium and high plus countless other "AAA" quality tier games, This is the ONLY game i can not get to run in 1440p at more than 15-20fps.

The settings are fundamentally broken. you have to choose between full screen but maximum resolution (i use a 4k Monitor) or your game will not be full screen no matter what you do. This is Plain unacceptable. These are basic settings every game under the sun should have and this game does not have functioning Display settings. WOW.

Next up, the story. Its dog water. If you need specifics watch ANY Youtube video on it. I can stomach it, but most cant and shouldnt.

The mechanics, they all feel wrong. This is coming from recently spending 200+ hours In Elite Dangerous and even the FPS mechanics in that game feel WAAAAY better and I dont personally like them either.

This game seems like its got decent bones. Maybe if modders stripped the entire main story and made the game more of a sandbox it might be more fun but even then im not sure the game has the tools to build actual enjoyable game loops without a MASSIVE rework that would warrent a standalone new game no shackled by an aging game engine and a profit hungry shell of a formally Great game developer.

With the Summer Sale coming soon, I figured I should leave a review prior to this game possibly going on sale. I can't recommend this game. It feels weird to say that as I've put 120 hours into the game, and I felt like I was having fun while I played it. But at the end of it all, looking back, I've drawn the conclusion that I was having fun because I WANTED to enjoy it. Not because I WAS enjoying it. If you're looking to get into the world of Bethesda games, I believe Fallout 4 is probably their best experience, and if that setting doesn't attract you, Skyrim is also a choice. If you're more attracted to the Space RPG aspect of Starfield, I'd recommend Mass Effect. All 3 of those games are likely on sale for a fair price. And all 3 of those games offer a better experience, in my opinion, than Starfield.

What it does well, does in no way outweigh the intense mediocrity that is the rest of the game. The exploration is not fun, if you can consider it present. You fast travel to planets, to fast travel to the surface, which is just a large, vastly empty zone, filled with things that you'll have seen in your first 5 planets. During your time exploring, the feature you'll get most acclimated to are the loading screens. This offers a great reason to practice with the Photo Mode as screenshots can show up as loading screens (not a complaint, actually nice). The combat is serviceable. The RPG elements are a step in the right direction with character backgrounds and traits, as well as skill based dialogue checks making a return. Visually pleasant. I didn't get an uncanny feeling, though going forward a more stylized focus would help. Starfield, I believe can not be salvaged. I think the world can be used again, and hopefully to greater success. But no amount of updates or mods can fix this fundamentally unfun game.

This is such a weird one.  It's like for ever step forward there's one or two steps backwards.
* The ship building and combat is pretty cool, but tying unlocks to a mix of player level, missions, perks and location just makes it kind of confusing to build the ship you want to.
* The level up system is a cool evolution from Fallout 4 - having challenges to make you use the skill the way you do in Skyrim is a great blend of the two systems.  Melee combat is worst than either Skyrim or Fallout 4, and a bunch of the skills aren't really worth engaging with.
* Like Stealth.  It doesn't seem to ever work - you can be alone in a room with a closed door and have a fully clear room between you and anyone else and it'll still say you're detected (and that's with max Stealth perks).
* Crafting is kind of pointless because weapons are inexplicably levelled - you put a bunch of mods into a pistol just to find an identical one that does more damage because you just hit level 20.  Better of regularly replacing weapons with loot as you level.
* The jetpack feels good, and the variety of planetary biomes, gravity and features is cool, but there's no reason to actually explore planets.
* The space powers are mostly worse versions of Dragon Shouts, so I ended up using nothing but the life sensing one.
* Outposts are such a massive step backwards from the Settlement building system they sprang out of.

If there's anything i learned from Starfield, it's to never purchase a full prized game at launch.

At launch the performance was atrocious, and after two years of waiting for updates and upgrading my PC, only now it's somewhat bearable. Occasional freezing does still occur both indoors and outdoors, despite being installed on an SSD.

After 18 hours, most of which were spent trying to get the damn thing to work, i haven't had the chance to actually get to play it aside from a few quests and seeing New Atlantis at an astonishing 20 FPS. Haven't gotten very far in exploring  but most of the worlds i have visited are exactly the same, barren and lifeless with an outpost or two.

To put it briefly, the game is boring and lackluster.

Personally my biggest problem with the game is that the player is treated like a hero from some vague prophecy. If this was a fantasy setting i might be able to look past it, One day you're a dusty miner working for minimum wage at the edge of space and suddenly you're given a ship and expected to know how to use it. How does Barrett know im not just going to sell it and spend the credits at some seedy establishment on hookers and booze?

Final assessment: Don't bother.

After years of hype, Starfield finally landed as Bethesda’s first brand-new universe in over two decades, promising an epic space-faring RPG with the studio’s trademark freedom and storytelling.

The result? A sprawling, ambitious journey through the stars that mostly delivers on exploration and scope, but occasionally stumbles under the weight of its own vastness and some rough edges inherited from Bethesda’s classic open-world formula.

Set in the 24th century, Starfield invites players to become a member of the “Constellation,” a group of space explorers chasing mysteries among over 100 star systems and hundreds of procedurally and hand-crafted planets.

The narrative centers around a conspiracy tied to ancient alien technology and interstellar politics—a classic sci-fi trope with some surprisingly nuanced moments and memorable characters. The voice acting and writing show real care, making you invested in your crew and missions.

While the main story isn’t revolutionary, it’s a solid foundation layered with countless side quests, faction rivalries, and world-building details that encourage curiosity.

Exploration is Starfield’s heart and soul. Flying between planets and landing on diverse worlds feels thrilling. The planetary surfaces vary from lush forests to barren wastelands, alien deserts, and ice-covered moons.

Planets often feature hidden caves, outposts, ancient ruins, and resource nodes to discover. Mining and crafting are surprisingly deep, letting you gather materials for ship upgrades, base building, and trading.

However, not all planets feel equally alive. Some can get repetitive, especially with similar flora, fauna, or quests scattered across them. The procedural generation is impressive but sometimes lacks the handcrafted polish of Bethesda’s terrestrial environments.

Piloting your spaceship between stars is a highlight. The cockpit UI is intuitive, and space travel has a satisfying sense of scale and momentum. Ship customization is extensive—you can upgrade weapons, engines, shields, and interior modules.

Combat comes in two flavors: on-foot and space battles. On-foot gunplay is serviceable—solid but not groundbreaking—with a mix of firearms, grenades, and gadgets. Space combat is more tactical and can be intense, especially during faction skirmishes.

Still, combat encounters occasionally feel repetitive, and enemy AI can be predictable.

Character progression is classic Bethesda RPG: a skill and perk system offering flexibility to create everything from stealthy explorers to heavy combat specialists.

Ship and base-building add layers of personalization. Your starship truly feels like home as you upgrade and customize it, while your outposts act as strategic hubs.

The crafting system is robust but can sometimes feel grindy, especially early on, as resource gathering becomes a frequent chore.

Graphically, Starfield is impressive with detailed planetary vistas, sleek ship designs, and atmospheric lighting. Spacewalks and planetary landings feel immersive.

Performance-wise, it’s mostly smooth on PC and current-gen consoles, though occasional bugs and frame dips persist—Bethesda staples that are likely to improve with patches.

Room to Grow:
-Planet variety can feel uneven after dozens of hours
-Side quests sometimes lack depth, feeling like busywork
-Combat mechanics are solid but not innovative
-Bugs and glitches—some humorous, some frustrating—still occur
-Multiplayer or co-op features are absent, which some players hoped for

Starfield is a bold, sprawling RPG that captures the thrill of space exploration with the familiar warmth of Bethesda’s storytelling and world-building. While it doesn’t revolutionize the genre, it offers a massive sandbox full of discovery, customization, and quiet moments under alien skies.

For fans of sci-fi RPGs and open-world adventures, Starfield is a must-play—even if it’s not without flaws. It’s a stellar launchpad for Bethesda’s vision of the future, with exciting potential for expansions and updates.

Pros:
-Vast, explorable star systems and planets
-Deep ship customization and space travel mechanics
-Engaging factions and story threads
-Robust character and base-building systems
-Beautiful vistas and immersive sci-fi atmosphere

Cons:
-Planetary environments can feel repetitive
-Combat and quests occasionally stale
-Bugs and performance hiccups remain
-Lack of multiplayer/co-op
-Crafting can become grind-heavy

Starfield invites you to chase the stars, explore the unknown, and carve your own cosmic legend. It’s not perfect, but it’s a thrilling new frontier worth charting.

Rating: 8/10

Bethesda shot me in the back of the head and then threw me into a cave and trapped me there for days. Then when I went to the hospital they stomped on my stomach and shoved down 20 quarterpounders into me and then crushed my esophagus. I had surgery and they pulled out my beating heart with their bare hands just to taunt me. Then I nearly escaped the hospital and realized it was a trap and they wrapped me up in cloth and punched and pulled out my pancreas then sent me into the empty void of space after I played Starfield.

💀 “Starfield is like getting catfished by NASA.” 💀

Let me tell you something, Bethesda pulled a drive-by on my imagination. They showed up like, "Yo dawg, you like space? You like RPGs? You wanna explore a thousand planets and be whoever you wanna be?"
And I was like, “HELL YEAH.”
Then I played it...
And now I’m in therapy.

This game is emptier than a TSA bin at a nudist colony. You walk around these so-called “planets” and they got nothing going on. They got one rock, two shrubs, and a cave you’ve already been in... twelve times. It’s like they copy-pasted sadness across the galaxy. If loneliness had a texture, Starfield would be the blueprint.

The gunplay? Man… it feels like your weapons are shooting regret. Pew pew pew—did I just fire a Nerf dart or a career-ending decision? The laser rifles feel like those little dollar store keychain flashlights. The combat is so mid, I started trying to negotiate with pirates just to feel something.

And don’t get me started on the dialogue. These NPCs talk like they’re running for space congress. “We must consider the ramifications of...”
Man, shut up and pass me a quest!
I’ve had deeper conversations with my microwave. At least it lets me know when it’s done.

Ship design? Okay, okay—I'll give them that. It's fun. But it's like Bethesda gave you a beautiful LEGO spaceship and said, “Aight, now park it forever and never use it for anything cool. You don’t fly—you fast travel.”
What kind of space game punks out of actual space travel?! This ain’t No Man’s Sky, it’s No Damn Game.

And the companions? Bruh. They got the charisma of DMV employees on Ambien. Every time I said something remotely spicy, Sarah Morgan’s like, “I’m disappointed in you.” Girl, I’m disappointed in YOU—for thinking this was gonna be fun.

Bethesda promised us the stars. Instead, they handed us a galaxy-sized PowerPoint presentation about missed opportunities. You know it’s bad when modders got more passion for this universe than the developers did.

Final Verdict:
I came for “Skyrim in Space.”
I got “PowerPoint in a vacuum.”

After playing nearly 100 hours, Starfield is a fantastic game. It has the RPG elements that are as good as Skyrim's and even better. There are more consequence options, decide whoever you want to be through the class system and the game provided me 3 ways to play this game. Either I remain in the universe as a home like the Pilgrim, travel through the multiverse to protect the Unity like the Emissary, or become a power hungry cosmic force like the Hunter.

 There is even more role playing aspects to choose from that are outside the main missions like becoming an independent settler, a  bounty hunter, a corporate spy, or even a gangster in the Neon drug trade. This is truly a type of Skyrim in Space which the story is never the destination, it is the journey. Highly recommend anyone to play this game and see for yourself.

Might well be the worst space game I've ever played.  Definitely the worst Bethesda game.  The story is uninspired and boring. There is absolutely nothing that makes me care at all about the main character.  The fact that I can't FLY in space from planet to planet, but can only fast travel...is beyond comprehension considering the game is called STARFIELD.   Genuinely the biggest disappointment I've experienced in the 30+ years I've been gaming.

For me, the game is almost there. It has all the pieces for a great game but the way its designed as a collation of internal small cells that you have to use menus to travel to is so jarring and immersion breaking.

In Starfield you can't get anywhere without opening a map selecting a location and holding fast travel. And the map is super clunky between ground, orbit, system and galaxy. Youre constantly cycling through them to get to the one you need.

In Skyrim you could get from Riften to Solitude by just pointing in that direction and holding "W" with encounters and towns on the way. This is the same with every Bethesda games. With a space game. I feel like this experience is even more critical and yet starfield is the only game where you can't do that.

Also, The pipboy in fallout allowed you to look at the map without breaking immersion. I don't know why they didn't carry that over here.

It's such a shame, because its almost there.

[Edit] I have now clocked 133 hours because I am addicted to ship building.  Starfield is not what I wanted it to be, but its fun in a way I wasn't expecting.

This game failed in the usual way when an ambitious project has its time line controlled by the publisher. The beta was a disaster when players couldn't figure out the complex resource and fuel management systems and rather than build out an early-game tutorial, they simply created an unlimited fuel system, ruined the economy, ruined the point of doing most things or being most kinds of characters. The rush to release made the game into a pointless repetitive mess. Identical bases with random baddies on meaningless planets. Many temples each of which contains the same non-puzzle. Clearly this was a place-holder and nobody was willing to spend the time to finish it. This had the potential to be a truly great genre-defining game, but the rush to publish completely irreparably ruined it.

This game is similar to edging or being blue-balled. It feels like being stuck in a perpetual state of "almost there."
Pros:

Cons:
- The Story and premise (The absolute definition of bland and generic)
- Dialogue (not a single line of dialogue felt natural or meaningful)
- Characters (Generic and forgettable)
- Loading screen upon loading screen
- Exploration was infuriatingly boring (1000 procedurally generated planets that all felt the exact same with what seemed like only 5 possible POI's

With all of that said, it has awesome aspects that are just outshined by filler and poorly-executed concepts that were great on paper. It's not flawless and not perfect, but I'm close to 600 hours and still playing on and off. The key here is managed expectations. It's easy to compare this to something like No Man's Sky or something along those lines, but this is a Bethesda game through and through. The closer comparison, in my opinion, is something like Fallout in space. Obviously not a 1 to 1 comparison, but still much more accurate than No Man's Sky, I think. Are there a lot of loading screens? Yes, but if you're a Bethesda fan, this ain't your first rodeo. If you've never played a Bethesda open-world RPG, the mechanics may sometimes feel slightly dated (although, I think that jet packs mixed with mantling and combat slides, have made combat feel much more fresh). If you've never enjoyed Bethesda's take on RPGs, this won't change your mind. However, if you ARE a Bethesda open-world RPG fan. If you have loved sinking your time in the Elder Scrolls Oblivion or Skyrim or if you've enjoyed the Fallout games since Bethesda has taken over, you most likely will enjoy this game. Just keep an open mind, although I've drawn comparisons to Oblivion, Skyrim and Fallout, this is not those games but the DNA is most certainly there. I hope this helps someone gain a realistic expectation for this product, before purchasing it. 

If you love it, please do so gracefully, no need to jump down anyone's throat for disliking or even hating something.

If you hate it, live and let live, and move on. They're not all gonna be winners, but no need to hate on those who enjoy it.

I see a lot of "controversy" over this game which often devolves into gaming philosophy pissing contests. We're all humans in this together, trying to find escapism in an increasingly demanding world. Let's stop the tribalism and enjoy what we all individually enjoy. Things are always more pleasant this way, in my opinion anyway.  

Hope this helps in some way!

I had so many prejudices against this game, and I sided with many that were bashing against it online,  even though I never played it, and just judged from what I saw in videos and reviews. -  Also  from experience of Bethesda games.

Now I played a bit, and I can now wholeheartely honestly say, I don't recommend it.

The skill-system is inferior to any Bethesda game. They tried something different, and failed.
Same with character creation.

Walking speed is still immensively  slower than those of NPCs,  so you either have to switch between walking and running, or you just ran around in circles or  wait for NPCs if you have to "follow" them.

Initiating conversations is extremly annoying, because it you constantly have to wait for the conversation to actually start, sometimes feels like  5-10 seconds... that way too long.

Persuasion is some random untransparent feature, as you get green, yellow and red options, showing the difficulty to success, but how high the chances actually are? Nobody knows. You'll find people online complaining how they fail and succeed green and red options about the same, while red options give you  more  points to the  overall persuasion challenge's points.

And while the idea might be not too bad, it also depends on HOW you argue in those pesuasion  options,  so you can either manage to skip some questionable quest objectives,  or you can just get better rewards, but that's not necessarily clear when you  pick those options,  which is why the implementation of that idea is just so immensively bad.

Companions dislike hearing you agreeing to do something they don't like, even if you don't actually follow through, OR if you  can only presuade them to  skip that part AFTER you agreed. So, if you wanna  finish the quest, without doing dubious stuff, you first have to agree to do  it and then persuade your questgiver to forget about it, but that initial agreement already grants you some negative points from your companion. Thank you bethesda for that brilliant design.

You also get A LOT of junk.  Junk  that you can't disamble, but you can sell. Problem is, lockpicks (digipicks) are also under junk, or as the game  calls it "misc" items. And so are extremly rare items called Astra, which  you can trade in  at a special store for rewards (haven't found that yet). Meanwhile Ressources are what's needed to craft things, and you  can either buy them, or grab them "off the floor" just like any  other  junk item. - Why am I so annoyed by this? Because with already 2 actually VALUABLE items sitting in the same category as actual junk, makes me question: What other valuable items are there, and how many  of them did I already sell? And why can't we dismantle some  materialis like in Fallout? 
There's special wire listed as ressource, and there's junk wire listed as misc, why can't i  dismantle junk wire  to specific ressources?

Oh, and I  don't know  what they thought when they worked on  the face animations, because A: they often don't fit with the acutal dialogue  and B: there expressions are often SO FREAKING CREEPY.

That's  it for now.  I could probably think of many more things I  don't like about this game, and very few things I like so far. I'm  just 12hours in, so I'm gonna keep playing for some more, so I get something out of it for  what I paid.

And who knows, maybe I'll find something that's so  great, it  changes  my whole opinion about the game?

It feels weird to leave a negative review after 138 hours of play time. But ultimately, I was disappointed. For a good 30 hours or so, I admit I was entertained. But the story was ultimately unsatisfying, and while the new game + experience was interesting, it just left me chasing completion and doing repetitive tasks for another 108 hours until I finally realized "Why am I even doing this?". Because it's an interesting progression system but by the time it feels satisfying, there's just nothing to do anymore that you haven't already done 100 times. 
Base building looks like fun but is also ultimately pointless. It gave me the same feeling of "Why am I even doing this?".
So in the end, even after 138 hours played, if the overall feeling is disappointment in the story and the gameplay, all I can do is give it a thumbs down.
Ship designing is fun, though. I probably spent 40 hours just building ships. But, that's not enough, is it?

I pre-ordered the game and played it at launch. It was .. less than satisfactory. I didn't refund, I got enough gameplay out of it for my money. But it was a define thumb down.

So I put the game aside with a solid 'meh' score and forgot about it until recently, when I got a new gaming rig and wanted to see how good it looks on high end hardware.

And.. It feels good. With mods far better than it did at launch. It's still buggy in places (cmon, it's a Bethesda game), but it's more enjoyable now. QOL improvements matter. And exploring planets can be yield vistas so pretty it brings a tear to your eye.

I'm upgrading my score to thumbs up, if you give yourself a chance to get lost in it you'll definitely like it.
But for the love of Ted, get mods.

I really enjoy Starfield and can recommend it overall, but there are still a few things that bother me even now.

First, the positives: the graphics are great and there are a lot of good options you can tweak. One thing I immediately appreciated was being able to adjust the conversation camera. Seeing characters only from the front all the time felt awkward, but thankfully you can change this to make dialogues feel more natural.

There’s a huge number of planets, POIs, quests and things to explore. The shipbuilding system is fantastic, I’ve sunk many, many hours into designing different ships, which is easily one of my favorite parts of the game. The faction questlines are also really well done and very engaging.

Now for the negatives: I’m still not sure if there’s much point in building bases on planets. There’s no proper builder, you can’t align objects well and everything ends up looking crooked. Apart from gathering some resources (which you don’t really need much anyway), building outposts doesn’t feel very rewarding.

Romance options start out interesting but quickly fall flat. There’s no real way to spend time with your partner after finishing their questlines and they tend to be a bit too "perfect", make one decision they dislike and your relationship takes a big hit.

One thing that disappointed me was the planetary exploration. Initially, it sounded like there would be a lot of variety, but in practice, many of the buildings are copy-pasted. While playing through the main story you see cool, unique locations... but when you start exploring planets, the scattered buildings look exactly the same, with identical layouts and loot spots (just different loot). It gets repetitive fast and for a game that promised "procedurally generated POIs," it’s a bit of a letdown when they’re just recycled interiors.

Another big negative for me is Bethesda’s new monetization. Charging 1000 credits (10€ or more) for a single questline in the Creations store is just not okay, I refuse to buy them at that price. A few euros might be fine, but this feels like an obvious cash grab.

I haven’t finished the new DLC yet, I only just started it, but I’ll definitely play through it at some point.

All in all, I’d rate the game around 7/10. It’s good for at least one full playthrough. New Game Plus is also not that exciting, you lose everything, and while some parameters can change, it’s not really enough to make repeat playthroughs feel fresh.

In the end, it’s a good game, I’m glad I played it, but there’s a lot of room for improvement.

I’ve got Fallout tattoos on my body and emotional scars from Fallout 76 in my soul. 

So when Starfield was announced — like everyone else — I strapped myself in for a wait that felt longer than an intergalactic load screen on a rusty Xbox One. 

Bethesda’s reputation for delivering genre-defining, bug-riddled masterpieces precedes it, and as someone who has worshipped at the altar of Vault-Tec, I was cautiously optimistic. And by "cautiously optimistic," I mean obsessively refreshing news feeds for five years and whispering, "Please don’t be 76 in space."

And you know what? They pulled it off.

Starfield is vast. Like, existential-crisis inducing vast. The space environments? Breathtaking. Sometimes I’d just float in orbit, staring at a digital gas giant like I was trying to feel something again. The ship customisation? Absolutely addictive. I lost hours tinkering with engines and modules when I should have been saving the galaxy or at least stealing sandwiches from NPCs.

The storytelling hits the sweet spot. Bethesda does its best when it leans into mystery and moral ambiguity, and Starfield has both in spades. It’s not perfec, few Bethesda games are, but it delivers where it counts: rich world-building, satisfying exploration, and that weird feeling that even the most mundane side quest somehow matters.

There’s still that familiar Bethesda jank (hello, NPCs who walk through walls like ghosts with unfinished business), but it almost feels comforting at this point. Like, if your companion didn’t get stuck in a doorway mid-monologue, would it even be a Bethesda game?

So yeah, Starfield won me over. It’s not the second coming of Skyrim, but it’s a damn fine space epic. It's flawed. It’s ambitious. It's got soul. And after the slow-motion trainwreck that was Fallout 76, it feels like coming home… to a home that happens to be orbiting a planet with space pirates, alien artifacts, and at least six factions trying to recruit you within your first hour of gameplay.

Final score: 8.9 out of 10 stimpaks repurposed as fuel injectors.

Would definitely board again.

I've had some time to digest this one. I did everything, put it down for a while, then came back to it for second taste. The short answer is, it's just okay. At some points it even qualifies as good. But It's rarely great, and too frequently bad. The amount of missed potential here is staggering.

We'll start with what I liked: It's a new adventure, and in the opening chapter it does a great job at building a sense that you have an enormous galaxy to explore before you and this is a universe that is both highly technologically advanced and still a rugged frontier. Your first quest shows you the scale and grandeur the game engine is capable of. The bespoke, non-procedural generated story locations are unique and life-like. There's even a glimmer of something mysterious and special when you get some cool new space magic

Then the bad: Everything else. At the risk of sounding cliche, the universe here is as vast as the ocean, and as deep as a puddle. The "1000 planets" touted so highly might as well be 4; the flat barren one, the jungle one, the snow one, and Australia. The variations are so trivial that each could barely hold my attention long enough to complete whatever fetch quest I came for. A meager handful of flora and fauna to scan and "catalog" that bare an incredible similarity to the last planet, and the one before that, etc. And the same could be said of the points of interest. About the third time I wandered through the same cryo-facility with the same corpses, same loot, same enemies, and same notes with the same names, just on a different planet, I realized that I hit the limit on the exploration aspect of the game.

And then I was robbed of the sense of adventure the opening chapter promised. Everywhere I went, somebody had been there. The surface of every planet is littered with abandoned structures and homesteads, or the remains of corporate industrialism. From a narrative perspective it drives me right out of the immersion. The presence of mysterious alien ruins unknown to mankind a short walk from the local space-Waffle House while random ships fly overhead of what should be an uncharted, virgin world destroys any of the mystery of discovering them in the first place. And a sense of mystery is only satisfying if there are breadcrumbs along the way to hint at a purpose to it. They just dump all this mysterious alien-looking nonsense everywhere and then never explain any of it. Then I see why all those buildings everywhere are abandoned: they got bored and left.

Then there's the combat. The game goes into great detail to build a world where a great war has recently concluded, and all the cool death rays, robo-mechs, bio-weapons, and other portable war-crimes that definitely exist in this universe have been conveniently outlawed and locked away by space-NATO. And what do they do with this sprawling arsenal of Chekhov's guns? They only fire the lamest one of them. No boss fights against towering mechs, no illegal weapons to smuggle past authorities on or off worlds to give you an ethically questionable leg-up on the scum of the galaxy. Just goofy looking guns, knives, and some mediocre gunplay with uninspired workbench mods. Only this game can make lasers boring. Blasting an enemy ship to pieces with laser cannons and missiles should be fun. Instead, it's a contest to see who has the more shield points while you spam all your weapons into one of the, at most, 3 enemies in front of you. Even the space magic is boring. They were literally given license to throw the laws of physics out the window and come up with something exciting, and the best they could do was "Fus Ro Da, but in space". And the same fly-through-the-rings puzzle every single time. TOTK had 104 unique shrine puzzles, and this game only has one. This review is already long enough, but we have to address the worst thing of all, the companions.

Your companions are perhaps the biggest missed opportunity of them all. They all have the same likes and dislikes, a choice to please one is likely a choice to please them all. To their credit, none of them are psychopaths. They won't gleefully join you in committing acts of terror, and rightfully so. It wouldn't make any sense to play this game as if it were a live GTA server. But there is no nuance. Every one of them is an upstanding member of society with no desire to disrupt anything around them. Even the one that used to be a criminal will bug out on you if you do some actual crime. If they were different flavors of ice cream, they would all be vanilla. I didn't find myself attached to any of them, and their various involvements in any events of the game didn't elicit much of an emotional response from me. [Sarah Morgan disliked that]

The game is mechanically sound and well polished from technical standpoint. But I could go on and on about specific plot points, character interactions (or lack thereof), and world building ideas that just missed the mark and could have been so, so much more. This game is worth about $25, tops. I advise you only buy it if it ever goes on sale, and for no more than that.

Note: I played on the Steam Deck. Works without issue other than some sound crackling after using the power button to pause play a few times. 

Quick Summary: There is a good game in here but unfortunately you can play it wrong (as I did originally). Yes you shouldn’t be able to play a game wrong but play it right and space RPG fun can be had. 

Long Version: Playing the game wrong > You can’t play this game (in my opinion) like No Mans Sky or Skyrim. Scanning stuff gets dull & repetitive (no real variety of life). You can’t wander around & do your own thing; space is too big compared to a region on a planet for a game map. 

*** The internet has new game tips but as my review / tips to get the best from the game ***

Story: Play the main story to at least > Into the Unknown > Minor not a real spoiler, you get a Skyrim type dragon shout. After this enemies start popping up Level 30. You can beat them but it drains resources, so now switch to the faction story lines. 

Travel: Other than the map telling you the difficulty of the star system (it says Level 10, 20, 50 etc. etc.) it should be avoided. Jump from place to place using the mission menu and > Set Location for mission. It’s faster and drops you immediately where you need to be. 
Next Up: Do the ranger missions next, you should scale as needed. If you don’t want trophies, steal the Watchdog ship during a mission. Nobody cares and it’s a strong fighter for early play. (you need to use the console ~ commands)

At the end of the rangers, you get a cool ship and now you are ready to do the main story or wander about. 
However > wonder via specific missions you like the sound of rather than just wander as mentioned above. Basically, any other location on a planet outside of the mission objective is just repetitive filler. Save time, go to the next mission & have more fun/story.  

Now What: Once you have done main story & rangers you should be knocking level 30. Finish the main story or do other side stories. You should be established enough to understand the game by now. 
Companions: You can’t be a lone wolf. Take companions & fill them with resources, some to keep and some to sell. Transfer everything to the ship regularly to free up you and the companion for more looting until the shops replenish their money. 

Base Skills: Honestly the only two base skills that I found worth picking at the character build was lock picking & persuasion. Everything else just works itself out during the game. Those 2 skills give you a better start. 

End Summary: Once your character is established. Playing the missions rather than wondering takes you to some fantastic places & stories. 
Neon is a fabulous cyberpunk space city. It must look fantastic on high end PCs. 
The ship that took generations to arrive at a planet only to find out that humans that left Earth later than them arrived hundreds of years first is thought provoking mission. 
The historical people clone world is bizarre & a good stupid fun break off for coming the beat and track. 

…and those are the ones I’ve found so far. 

Have Fun

Nearly 100 hours of Starfield between two campaigns, one at launch and another starting 2 weeks ago. 

I think I'm a bit jaded when it comes to this game because, on one hand, it's very evident that the folks at Bethesda really did pour THOUSANDS of hours into creating this game only for it to get scathing reviews, but on the other, they somewhat did it to themselves by advertising it as "Skyrim in space" when it definitely is not that. I think Starfield plays the most like FO4 out of any other game, probably with a mixture of No Man's Sky. Is that a bad thing? Well, I'm giving it a positive recommendation because NMS is one of my favorite games of all time and I am a sucker for space games, but not because it is Skyrim in space. 

Starfield is one of those games where it either moves really fast for you, or really slow early on and the inverse generally happens by the time you reach 15 hours. Then around 30 the decision is subconsciously made in your mind about whether you are having fun. My first playthrough, I played for about 40 hours with the first 10 being incredibly dull, but after discovering a few neat POIs, I ended up getting completely pulled into the world. However, after a million loading screens and repeated locations, I just never launched the game again until very recently.

All of this sounds strange and slightly negative, but I think Starfield offers a blend of different game(s) mechanics that cannot be fully replecated anywhere else. I love the fact that while it is a complete sandbox, you are also able to play in a very linear sense. Completing quests over and over without regard to creating an outpost (which you don't have to), scanning an entire planet (which you don't have to) or creating your own ships from scratch (which you don't have to). Some days, I would hop onto my save to work on some of my outposts and ships, while others I would complete two major faction quest lines in a day, and during my interstellar travels, would accidentally get 4 more quests that I could start. This feedback loop is incredibly satisfying and keeps me launching the game. 

People's complaints about the game are largely valid, with Starfield having a lot of loading screens, repetitive POIs and too PG of a setting to truly RP. But with a few potential updates or DLC, expansion on outpost building, and a few mods, this game truly opens up and becomes something that I not only enjoy, but recommend.

I've spent a significant amount of time exploring the vast expanse in Bethesda's latest sci-fi game. While it's clear that the developers have put a lot of effort into creating an immersive experience, I found myself wanting more. Just a note, I haven't messed around with the mods and only stuck to the original game. Overall it's worth playing despite all the negative reviews. I had fun playing it and I bet you will too.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
+ Stunning visuals: The game's visuals are stunning, with detailed character models, environments, and special effects that make for an immersive experience.
+ Lots of side quests.
+ Amazing sound effects and quality, both in game and voice-overs.
+ Great animation quality.
+ Awesome main story: [spoiler] Even NASA is involved. [/spoiler]
+ Immersive Setting: Starfield's universe is rich in lore and history, with a complex web of factions, governments, and alien species that add depth to the game's narrative.
+ Exploration. The game's open-world design allows for seamless travel between planets, each with its unique atmosphere, geology, and ecosystem.
+ Ship building is awesome!: Love completing some quests to get ship blueprints and experimenting with new designs. The models not only have different looks but act as functional parts that you can walk through and experience. (Some of the parts you can walk through).


[h1] Cons [/h1]
- Too many loading screens: It's not like I have a slow computer, In fact, I have pretty much the best you can get when it comes to PC hardware. The game seems to have loading screens for scenes that don't need them.
- Storyline: While engaging in parts, the game's storyline can feel disjointed and lacks the cohesion of previous Bethesda games. The main quest is often overshadowed by repetitive side quests that fail to contribute much to the overall narrative.
- Underdeveloped Features: Some features, such as ship-to-ship combat and diplomacy, feel underdeveloped or unpolished, detracting from the overall experience.

[h1] Verdict [/h1]
I give this game: 3/5
[h1] ★★★ [/h1]
[b] Worth Playing [/b]
this is just slop i slurp

Starfield is not a bad game at all - but it feels like a game that should have released around the time Skyrim did (for the first time, anyway). That doesn't make the game unplayable in anyway - I still return to Skyrim from time to time, so that would be a crazy claim, but it is basically highly unimpressive for a title that's come out so much later. 

The world feels too small, people are all to fast to pawn off seemingly meaningless tasks upon you, every NPC has NPC syndrome from TES and the space exploration grind is too time consuming for what you get out of it. 

It feels like the game tried to do too many things at the same time, and failed to do any of them well. 

I've still enjoyed what I've seen so far, but I can understand why it's had some negative reviews.

I honestly reached a point in my save where I genuinely cannot progress, and I don't really care. I'm not going to beat a dead horse, especially so long after the game's release, but damn, I regret spending so much money on this game. I wish it was the game they all said it would be.

Maybe next time, Bethesda?
Shipbuilding is good, but there's nothing to do you with your ship, everything else is awful.

Even  after playing it through a number of times already, I still find things I've never seen before time and time again. This is a hard one to put down and has come SO far from when it first came out. Highly recommended!

Honestly, this game doesn’t deserve the hate it gets. People are just mad that they got this and not another Elder Scrolls game. That being said, don’t go in expecting the same old thing from Bethesda. This is different, I don’t really understand why people don’t like the fact it’s different. Gameplay, storyline and visuals are all fairly different to other titles. It’s a solid 8/10 in my opinion.

Update: not all issues I have had with this game are Bethesda/Creation issues. After hours of troubleshooting most corrupted games were due to MS One drive.. Per advise, I disabled and uninstalled my One drive before installing this game. However, Steam will continue to  use the folder and save your Starfield data there. I had to re-install one drive and export my games. Then  uninstall One drive. and re-install Steam and Starfield so it would save local. That fixed my saved game corruption.

It's pretty bad.  So, adventuring around, a lot of the areas I'm in seem... identical.  I've encountered several different enemy factions, ah, who all appear to be the same, but aren't.  There's no intelligent aliens?  Just like, space creatures.  Neat.  Sarah, who you get stuck with early on because of a plot point for an early quest line, gets literally stuck on every surface, spasming around.  You'll have a seizure if you try and talk to her b/c the screen spasms around like crazy when it shows dialog choices.  So, don't do that.  You can carry very little loot, but everything is lootable.  That's just annoying.  Presumably, that can be enhanced with perks.  But it's such a grind, even early on, to unlock perks.  And for whatever reason, Bethesda didn't think that a local map was necessary.  And in the couple of years since release and, I assume, listening to people bitch about it, they still haven't patched that in.  Huge areas, no fucking clue where I am.  I can deal with a lot, when I'm not lost.  But, this is the tipping point for me.  I won't be bored and lost.  And it all looks the same, so GL with landmarks.  If I open the map it shows the planet I'm on, then zooms out, all the way to where I am in the galaxy, but it can't pinpoint any closer than "you're on this planet."  Shameful.  Skip this one.  Don't wait for a sale to "give it a shot."  Just don't bother.  If you have the itch for a game like this, Outer Worlds 1 is probably on sale somewhere.  It has much better writing and is much more interesting, if simplified.  But honestly, Starfield gets lost in itself and has no direction.  So, simple isn't a bad thing, when well executed.  

TLDR: skip Starfield entirely, never look back; maybe play Outer Worlds instead.

My standards for video games are relatively low (heck, I even like battlefield 2042), but man is this game complete garbage. It is so incredibly rare for me to dislike a game, and I almost never leave a bad review on any game. So the fact I am giving a thumbs down is a testament to how awful this game truly is. I pre-ordered the game and I was super super excited. The product I received was subpar at best, and horrendous at worst. The game was filled with glitches, making it nearly unplayable. When the game wasn't being a buggy mess, the content was below average. Quests in the game felt like a chore, every NPC felt super lifeless, and the story was a forgettable slop. I literally forced myself to play it, primarily due to sunk cost fallacy, and also because I thought at some point there would be a hidden gem in this steaming pile of poop. Well turns out even after 74 hours on the game, it NEVER gets better. It remains the same repetitive game that it started off as. I do NOT recommend this game to anyone, and there's a reason why it has mixed reviews on steam. I wouldn't even play this crap for free.

I really wanted to love Starfield. But the more time I spent with it, the more it became clear: this game has already aged poorly.

The biggest immersion killer? Loading screens. Everywhere. Walk into a building? Loading screen. Board your ship? Loading screen. Land on a planet? You guessed it. Other games have found creative ways to disguise them—Starfield gives you a static wallpaper. It absolutely breaks the flow of exploration and constantly reminds you you're playing a game stitched together by menus.

Then there's the companions and characters—bland, shallow, unmemorable. They lack depth and personality, and I never felt attached to any of them. The factions? Barely interact. You’d expect dynamic political tension or interesting inter-faction quests—what you get instead is largely siloed storylines that rarely overlap.

The main quest is another huge issue. The design seems almost to encourage players to rush through to New Game Plus (NG+). But if you take that bait, you’ll likely regret it, especially once you realize what happens to the world you leave behind. There’s a real sense of lost potential here, where meaningful progression is replaced by a hollow loop.

The planets and environments are visually decent at first glance but feel fake and lifeless the more you explore. Recycled points of interest, repeated base layouts, generic caves... it becomes a chore. There’s no joy in landing on a new moon just to find the same exact outpost you cleared three planets ago. There are no meaningful landmarks, no places that spark curiosity or make you want to revisit them—nothing like Skyrim’s iconic spots that felt alive and worth exploring.

Bottom line: Starfield lacks soul. It doesn’t immerse you in its universe—it reminds you you’re stuck in a cycle of loading screens, shallow characters, and copy-pasted content. I didn’t feel like I belonged in this universe. I just felt like I was checking boxes.

If you’re hoping for the next Skyrim in space, lower your expectations significantly.

Starfield — 608.8 h played  
Score: 7 / 10

A space-sandbox brimming with top-tier character progression and a brilliant ship builder—yet weighed down by copy-paste planets, too few questlines, and an outpost system that feels half-formed.

ANALYTICAL HIGHLIGHTS  
• **Leveling system (standout)** — Perks gated by challenges keep every skill investment meaningful; respecs, weapon specializations, and difficulty sliders combine for endless buildcraft.  
• **Ship builder excellence** — Snap grids, diverse modules, and flight-model trade-offs make designing haulers, gunboats, or smugglers genuinely creative. It’s the game’s signature toy box.  
• **Quest quality** — Faction arcs and miscellaneous jobs are well-written and cinematic while they last; individual missions rival Bethesda’s best set pieces.  
• **Modding runway** — Early quest packs (Dark Universe, Silent Dominion) and the newly released Creation Kit show a community already filling content gaps.

CRITICAL SHORTCOMINGS  
• **Procedural planets** — Reused tile sets, empty biomes, and repeated POIs turn exploration into déjà vu; easily the weakest procedural generation Bethesda has shipped.  
• **Quest drought** — Quality is high, but quantity is not. The game needs **three times** the quest chains to feel fully developed.  
• **Outpost building** — Interface is smooth, but outputs don’t matter; resources rarely gate progress and no real economy ties into the broader game loop.  
• **Companions & main story** — Core crew feel thin, and the multiverse-flavoured main plot never lands the emotional punch of earlier Bethesda epics.  
• **Performance** — Even on a Core i7-11700K / RTX 3090, New Atlantis can dip under 60 fps; CPU constraints persist.

FINAL ASSESSMENT  
Starfield excels at character builds and custom ships, but its procedural planets, sparse quest count, and underutilised outposts leave it feeling like an Early-Access framework. If you’re willing to lean on mods and trust that future DLC will triple the quest content, there’s a stellar sandbox here. If not, you may want to keep the grav drive in standby until Bethesda and the mod community flesh out the universe.

Starfield is about the journey rather than the destination. It is like life itself that way, but you, as your character, are central to the major events of the galaxy. It offers its own mystical destiny, and provides ample opportunity to explore your own ethos as you make your decisions and fight for what you feel is right. There are major factions of various political factions Liberal, Conservative, Federal, Libertarian and Anarchic. You can play as a champion of the people or a violent criminal, all with a very good expansive combat system. Crafting is fully developed, rewarding, flexible, and also avoidable if it isn't what you wish to invest your play into. I have over 1200 hours into it and am still playing.

虽然网上以及玩家群体一直在喷星空，但是多玩几部其他游戏厂商的开放世界游戏才能体验到B社开放世界的伟大之处，世界观的塑造以及探索，虽然有线性流程的主线任务，但是相比于其他游戏更加“开放”，每一款游戏都像是自己的第二人生。
优：
1. 与其他B社游戏一样的沉浸感，在太空中的第二人生。
2. 室内贴图以及建模都很精美，画质相比之前的B社作品有了质的飞跃。
3. 系统多样，多种战斗流派、潜行、哨站建造、飞船建造等，如果全部认真玩的话一定是个时间杀手。
缺：
1. 神殿超能力获取过程太过无聊，每次都是相同的步骤，并且最后也没有几个可以用的超能力。
2. 抛弃了所见即所得的设定，个人很讨厌在单机里加入刷刷刷的机制。
3. RPG设定相比前作出现了退步，尤其是部分很重要的能力初始状态下尽然不会。

The game has that classic Bethesda feel, but it misses the mark in some areas. The DLC shows more of what Bethesda can do with a space setting, but even without it, the base game is super fun — especially with mods. I’ve played a good amount, and there’s still plenty to do.

Main story is shallow, feels like recycled Skyrim. Other interactions are somewhat more interesting that Skyrim or Fallout, but bar was rather low. Persuasion is utter nonsense - you get few random lines from a pool and it's perfectly possible that you will not get the ones you need to succeed.

Has some good points but mostly falls short of what you'd expect from a Bethesda RPG. This game embodies the phrase "A mile wide, but an inch deep. Its really hard to be immersed in the game after exploring the same POI with the same exact loot and notes 15 times.

This pain me to say as I've been a Bethesda fan for years, since Skyrim came out, I felt they were slowly falling off, with games each times less and less profound, with quests more and more dumbed down, but Starfield get the cake of what not to do. 

I will start with what's good in the game because there's so much bad I will need time to write.

1. The ship building is fun and something I always want to engage with, but it's way too hard to do and take so much time because the interface and the mechanic of it is just not intuitive. I want this back in a Starfield 2 potentially.

2. The weapons are the best guns Bethesda ever done, it's by far not perfect, but gunplay is serviceable it's fine.

3. Some quests are great

4. Space is just cool


Now what's bad and I trully hated.

1. The Quests, as I said some quests are great, the rest is just awfull
2. The exploration. There's nothing I hate more than getting to a barren planet, and walking or using the vehicule to reach a rock with nothing at all and that's it and if I take 4 more hours on that planet just walking, driving to various POI what will I see ? Nothing of substance, I won't find some random quest, I will shoot a few guys, get a bit of materials and that's about it.
3. The cities, they are just awfully designed, the main city is the worst of the bunch there's 0 feel of grandeur and it's just poorly agenced, the fact the city is shallow but there's loading screens to get from A to B if you wanna take the trams is awfull. Witcher 3 done great cities years before starfield and that while making it fun to walk around without the need of loading screens.
4. The Ships space combats and overall the space exploration with the ships. This feels insane to me to know they had the possibility to make a space game, and space is just an after thought. Nothing to do in space outside, random encounters and space stations, nothing. The combats are awfull with the micro gestion of shield, weapons, it could be fun the way it's handled with keys or controller is just awfull. There's no enjoyement out of the space fights and most of the time it's, wait for auto-lock, spam, win or lose. 

And this is without even mentionning the choice to add loading screens to enter your ship, to get on a lader to get to the cockpit, then wait for a cinematic to sit on the cockpit, then hold a key to finally take off, then watch the ship take off, then loading screen, then you're tped in space, then you gotta open your map, navigate where you wanna go, then make sure you correctly added power to the astromotors, and then wait for another cinematic, and then another loading screen.

I am not joking when I say I can spent 3 minutes, just to freaking take-off and get where I want to and that with 0 fun, not a single second of engaging gameplay.

THIS is just the worst of the worst in the game. 

Imagine what we could've if they cared about space exploration, done less planets ( which are barren anyway ) and make it so you could get from planet, to space, without loadings and just playing or hiding the loadings like in Star Wars outlaws.

5. Loots, waste of time, nothing is engaging, you'll find most of your stuff on people you kill with pretty much 0 reasons to loot around outside of a few things.

6. The feeling of being betrayed. I installed this game over 10 times, I've really tried to enjoy it, multiples times, with mods or not, but I just cannot, this uninstall might be the last.
Very good game, felt a little empty.

Starfield doesnt deserve the hate it gets. First of all, the graphics are amazing. Sceneries and landscapes are so beautiful, and they change with different times on planets. Main storyline is actually nice, sometimes breathtaking and sometimes heartbreaking. Many sidequests are just pick this, kill that, go there. But the other half, is completely different, they are deep, devs actually cared about them and they are very enjoyable. Yes, most planets are empty with some stations, little sidequests, enemy bases, caves and they are proceduraly generated. But, you dont have to go to every single planet, 10% of them have life, means over 100 planets there have life, which, IMO is great enough. I dont care what anybody else says. Its great game and if you give it time, not just rush through  campaign and some side quests, but play slow and play NG+, you will discover many dialogues and many options how to actually change your progress.
It holds up to its price.

I have been a fan of Bethesda RPGs since Morrowind. I have played Morrowind, Oblivion, Skyrim, Fallout 3, and Fallout 4. I can honestly say I didn't enjoy every minute of every game but then again nothing is perfect. I particularly disliked the system changes between installments. Morrowind and Oblivion generally shared the same skill system. Fallout 3 did a great job of implementing the SPECIAL system from Fallout 1 & 2. Skyrim and Fallout 4 majorly regressed from their previous games. I understand the reason why even if I don't agree with it: simpler games sell to a wider audience which means more profits for the shareholders. The same goes for Starfield.

Here is what I think happened: the developers saw the success of No Man's Sky and decided to make their own version. The problem is that No Man's Sky is a game with an entire galaxy to explore but nothing to find. Let me explain in Starfield terms. You leave the first planet but you can't grav jump so you have to land somewhere in system to get fuel. You land on the planet and there are a few places to explore. Having played previous Bethesda games, you might be impressed at this point: looking at the galaxy map reveals over 100 star systems. Herein lies the problem: the vast majority of those star systems contain planets with nothing to find. Occasionally, you might find a dev designed dungeon but most of the time its cookie cutter dungeons with nameless enemies and random loot. Furthermore, most of the time star systems have 5+ planets with moons. In order to fully explore a star system, you must land on each planet and scan some rocks and creature creator monsters. I'm glad they didn't add a "fully survey every star system" achievement. I would still be scanning. Did they really need to created a galaxy with 100+ star systems? Who played this game for 15 minutes and said "Looks good. Ship it"? The core gameplay loop is this: land on planet, scan rocks, scan monsters, fast travel to ship, fast travel to planet, watch takeoff cutscene, fight pirates in order, land on planet, watch landing cutscene, rinse and repeat. This is not fun! This is work!

Two more small gripes: the outpost system seems worthless (a lame attempt to add the settlement system into the game) and space combat seems a bit under cooked.

Here is why I'm sad: there is a good game to be found in Starfield. I can honestly say I had fun with most of the scripted story missions especially Ryujin and the Crimson Fleet. Here is how I would redesign Starfield: copy elements from Mass Effect 2 and The Outer Worlds. Mass Effect 2 allowed you to scan planets for resources. This would avoid the Starfield problem of landing on hundreds of moons with the same 2 or 3 resources. The Outer Worlds is closer to a traditional Bethesda experience with multiple planets and each planet is a dev designed map with explorable places. With a few less planets and more purposeful dungeon design, Starfield would have been great and probably one of my favorite games. Instead, I am telling those who intend to play: don't stray off the path, there is nothing to find.

Also there are still stupid bugs 2 years after launch.

If you thought PC gaming meant instant loading, think again. Starfield is here to prove you wrong. Every time you step into a building or jump to a new planet, prepare for the longest loading screen marathon you’ve ever seen.

I spent more time staring at loading bars than actually exploring space. It’s like Bethesda wanted to see how many snacks I could eat between loads. My SSD was working overtime, but even that couldn’t save me from the endless waits.

The game has some cool stuff, but these loading times seriously kill the flow. It’s almost like the real game is waiting… and waiting… and waiting.

If you want to test your patience and perfect your loading screen meditation skills, Starfield is your go to.
