Starfield is a massive sci-fi RPG where you play as a space explorer in the year 2330. After a mining accident sets you on a mysterious path, you join Constellation, a group hunting for strange artifacts tied to the secrets of the universe. From there you chart your own journey across over 1,000 planets, taking on faction missions, building ships and outposts, fighting pirates and shaping your place in a galaxy full of opportunity and danger. It is a game about exploration, freedom and carving out your own legend among the stars.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3495028307

[b]First, let's get real: Starfield isnt perfect.[/b] Loading screens when warping between planets or entering cities will pull you out of the moment. Procedural generation means some planets can feel like vast empty spaces which dampens the sense of discovery. The majestic [spoiler]temples[/spoiler] ended up feeling like a copy-paste job, which came across as a pretty lazy bit on Bethesda's end. And my personal biggest let down: The universe is packed with human colonies, pirate factions and mysterious ruins, but if you were hoping to have deep conversations with alien civilizations or forge alliances with creatures from another star system, you will not find that here. [b]WHYYY BETHESDA?![/b] The alien life you do encounter is mostly wild and hostile, more space critter than cosmic allies. For a game about exploring the vast unknown, for me, this felt like a missed opportunity.

[i]But still, there's something here.[/i]

Starfield is built as a sandbox to lose yourself in. Its sheer scale lets you chart your own path, crafting ships, surveys, setting up outposts or weaving through a gang undercover mission that rivals cinematic heists. One thing that kept Starfield really fun is it's main questline and the faction storylines. If youd ask me, these are the real stars of the show, packed with exciting missions and unexpected twists that make you want to keep pushing deeper into the galaxy. Whether youre sneaking through the shadows with the Crimson Fleet or navigating corporate intrigue with Ryujin Industries, these arcs feel hand-crafted and full of life. The main story itself eventually dives into some wild sci‑fi ideas that make you stop and think, adding a nice sense of wonder and payoff for the journey. Of course, not every part of the galaxy glitters. Some side quests are more like space debris floating between planets and often feeling like basic errands. You will find the occasional gem, but a lot of them blur together and lack the charm of the main arcs.

At its core, Starfield is a galaxy sized canvas that invites you to chart your own path. It may wobble through some asteroid fields with repetitive side content and occasional jank, but when you are deep in a great faction storyline or piloting your custom starship through the stars, it absolutely shines. For anyone who loves crafting a personal space saga and losing themselves in a vast universe, this is one spaceship worth boarding.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3495336155

[b]Recommended![/b] It may not be a flawless supernova, but it glimmers with potential. I'd say: Focus on the hand-crafted parts of the game, the main quest and the faction quests. Forget about the No Man Sky's kinda procedural generated crap. You'll most likely feel disappointed walking on the vast empty planets and seeing repeated copy paste 'dungeons' and 'caves'. And if you're enjoying the game, get yourself [i]Shattered Space DLC[/i] at a discount.

[b]Recommended Creation / mini DLC[/b]
While there is only one official DLC at the time of this review, I have to say that even though I am not a fan of paying for mods, some of the community creations out there feel like mini DLCs themselves and genuinely add a lot to the game. I highly recommend getting [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_AUNVb3Jvyo][b]Watchtower: Orbital.Strike\\Fleet.Command[/b][/url] [i](achievements still work)[/i].

Imagine it's Saturday. You want to unwind from work and do something different... Your friends, family and loved ones want your attention.... but an NPC wants you to fetch a Terrabrew Cuppacino or 5000 Argon for them in return for nothing... If you want to do menial tasks in an empty environment while neglecting the potential to live a real and probably more exiting life, then this game is for you... Even the main story line is simply fetching identical objects and playing them on a spinny table only for the NPCs the spurt short bits of low level scifi jargon. It's empty, its repetitive, it reuses tropes from oblivion, FO4 and skyrim but to a more pedestrian and hollow effect... it wants to be modded and bethesda needs you too... so thay can profit. I am both a space game enthusiast and a Bethesda game enjoyer. I do mental gymnastics and carefully planned runs to make games like Skyrim and Fallout 4 actually make sense and be immersive. It's not easy but it's possible. Not here. I bought the overpriced deluxe edition to play this game early. I played thorough everything the game has to offer and the DLC to boot. I am fucking desperate for more of these types of games, but even with the benefit of being able to look back at it and just remember the good parts, it just wasn't very good.

There are a lot of valid complaints about technical aspects, the world, the loading screen, etc., but for me the most egregious flaw is the quests and dialogue. There aren't just a handful of bad quests. There aren't even a handful of good quests. [i]Every[/i] single quest is noticeably, objectively bad. Every interaction with another "human" in this game feels almost deliberately fake and artificial. I've seen it described as bland, but it's worse than that. A bland but believable setting with boring but logical quests would be a [i]major[/i] step up from what this game actually is. If you give this game a honest chance and try to immerse yourself, you will only find yourself punished. The basic setting, every quest, every faction and [i]especially[/i] the main story is just fundamentally flawed. Mods cannot salvage this. The DLC could not salvage this. The most generous thing I can say about it is that it had some good ideas, but it's like it was handled by a studio that doesn't really have experience making games and they fumbled the implementation big time.

The game is not enjoyable for its story, its quests, its locations, its exploration or its factions. The gameplay is half decent and that is it. If you want a game purely for the gameplay there are far better options. If you want an open world Bethesda-like with the same gameplay, play Fallout 4. If you want a half-serious clunky inconsistent space adventure with terrible space battles and janky NPCs, play the Mothership Zeta DLC for Fallout 3.

I really wanted to like this game, i tried, a space games most important thing is exploration, and this is by far one of the worst exploration games I've ever played, and there's so much loading screens in this game that it completely takes you out of the experience and ruins immersion. 

Now I don't want to hear "sWiTcH tO uE5!!!" they could've pulled this off in the creation engine if they really tried, they had so many devs and partners that worked on this game that they weren't all on the same page to complete this task, in other words, they had to meet a deadline.

I love Bethesda, I really do, I've put countless hours in there games and this really makes me fear for their future. 

I really hope ES6 is good, all we can do is hope Bethesda looks back to their traditional ways going into ES6, I don't know about you but i'm not counting on it.

Played at launch and now again in 2025. Firstly, this game has really improved. So I'll focus on the now. 

2nd. This game plays perfectly fine on steam deck at this point. I primarily play on deck at this point and never feel like I need to go to my pc for any feature. Yes frames drop when you enter populated places but it can be played through fine. 

3rd. Creations and mods make this game much fuller. Also star wars mods will make this game the best star wars game out currently lol. 

4th. This game has some of the best pieces of skyrim and fallout mechanics. Fallout 4 style crafting. Outposts are not like settlements though. The side quests and main quests are very much like skyrim. After a point you can ignore the main quest and just do what ever. It's very fulfilling to go on your own adventure hit a poi and launch a side quest after landing. 

5th. The ship builder is one of the biggest and best features in this game. It feels very satisfying getting all the pieces to fit how you like. And now you can decorate the interior as well which makes it even better. Very intricate and fun to play around. 

All around a good game to sink your time in.

Here's a brief rundown of some facts and opinions based on my gameplay so far:
- Gameplay is smooth on High Settings, and I have a 5-year-old PC
- The world is beautifully-crafted, though some consider it a little empty
- In true Bethesda fashion, the NPCs are a little janky, but they have a lot of personality
- Ship mechanics aren't over-the-top, nor are they too simple to be boring. There is some strategy!
- Character Backgrounds are unique, but I don't think they make a huge difference
- Typical Bethesda formula of clearing out bandi- wait, this isn't Skyrim.
- The quests outside of the main one are worthwhile. I haven't explored all of the factions yet, but I am seriously enjoying the UC Vanguard questline
- Dialogue choices probably don't change how you would actually handle situations, but there is merit to the persuasion system if you choose to play a high-charisma character
If you like Elder Scrolls or Fallout, you will love this game.

I know that this, in many people's eyes is a mediocre one, a disappointment, even a bad game for others.  

"Oh but don't you see? Most of the game is barren, these solar systems and assortment of planets that you landed on are... there are barely any things to discover or be amazed by, why would anyone like this?"

Going back to this game almost an ENTIRE YEAR after I abandoned it, in new game plus, only beating the main story and doing nothing else... has taught me at least, that there is more to this game than meets the eye...much much more. You are the one that creates your experience,not other people on the internet. 

There are 3 distinctive strengths that this game has : 

1.Atmosphere 

One moment you explore a random planet, on a quest or not, and you find some weird animals looking at you and some shady looking plants while being awe struck at the various biomes and landscapes and then, after 200 meters or so, you find an abandoned mine, or a 
pirate weapons lab, or a spaceship crash site or another 6-8 different types of settlements that you can engage in either combat, exploration or even trade with.  Some of these places have random letters and computers scattered in them where, besides being able to learn more about the place, it also gives you access to a completely different mission on a different planet or even an event happening on a much more far away solar system. 
At least 5 or 6 big cities to explore that offer amazing depth of structures and a variety of activities,missions,shops and secrets to discover.  I am talking about some areas with a main part of the city and then an underbelly and then yet another another underbelly of that too.  
You find yourself starting the game with 120 solar systems, where, in my experience, I have found at least half of them to be interesting and worth my while, not to mention a good 25 or so planets where you will constantly be tempted to go back due to various plot lines, updates and variety of factions within the game.

2.Factions 

SEVEN different factions. Some good, some neutral or suspicious looking but others outright evil or crazy.  In depth story-lines and at least a range of 7-15 missions for each of them, with unique armor, weapons. 
Ships and hideouts or headquarters, locations that you can visit with them
Please tell me what other game (besides an MMO maybe) has this many groups that are all fleshed out.

I played for every single one of them, I did all of the achievements for this game and even with groups where I did not have any achievement or immediate attachment for, I still got curious enough to see where will a random discussion heard on the various cities streets take me.  Man that was a good choice. 
Yeah we've all seen and heard about the boring "go here, get that, get back to me, done" type of missions and the "go to this obviously bad looking place kill anyone you see, bring back item from the bottom of the place, don't die" looking quests, and while Starfield does have these as well, I have seen that choice of an outcome or two and often a different approach as well, IS given and encouraged too in the mission briefing. 

There are things in the game that you are always shown about, either by the person that gives you the assignment or by your own imagination and skill.  Alternative ways to get into into a compound or a lab via the vents.
Skills like Persuasion, Bribery, Intimidation even Manipulation that can change the outcome of a conversation with the target of your mission.  Ways to jump start and surprise people with evidence found on an optional side objective that can turn the outcome of a mission instantly instead of needing to go along with it for another 15-20 minutes.Did i mention hacking turrets and robots via a computer so that in a hostile environment things suddenly get a lot more easier ?

Final rewards of a quest-line that have some of the most useful things a game has ever given me: 
Unique armor and weapons that both look cool and destroy the opposition.
Starships given to you so big that you have no idea where the cockpit is even or ones that are zippy and have some serious firepower added to them with a technician that only works for your personal pleasure and has exclusive upgrade parts that cannot be found anywhere else in the universe. 
Access to some of the best in class companions and VIP level discounts for shops and restaurants in your area. 
Houses located in some of the most exclusive,breathtaking or exotic areas of the city.  

3.Music and Sounds

The raw sound of the engines and turbines (not to forget about the smoke and the fire) of the ships that land and get airborne again at a space-station or on a planet where you are as well, almost as if you are near a NASA ship going into space. I have never head something like this prior to playing this, those ships made me feel as if I was a real person in that game. Next to a giant spaceship. 
Did I even tell you that you can customize these things up to a crazy level or buy a lot of variants? 

The creepy, mysterious or outright haunting music that you hear when being in a cave is a good fit for a game like this where, most of the time, you explore a place all alone.  
This feeling of "oh,this place feels wrong" or "I should not be here at all, I heard something slithering" could not have been expressed right without audio that doesn't make you anxious.
You thought that there are only rogue pirates in the universe and not also disgusting creatures lurking around as well in this game ? 

The exploration music
It really makes you realize just how lively and beautiful a planet with vegetation,fauna and a temperate climate is versus a barren planet that has been destroyed by radiation, has low oxygen and is risky to go on or even a completely isolated planet like an Ice or Inferno landscape, with nothing but constant snow or sand storms. 

The music that would play in each of the big cities. Various themes that do a very good job at describing the place for you, sound-wise, on your first and subsequent visits and make you realize, almost immediately what kind of people live on this part of the universe. 

The main theme of the game "Into the Starfield" is one of the most insane piece of music that I have ever heard in a game theme.
Not many games make me tear up and get emotional after the first few seconds of the game launching and also fewer make me stay on the home screen and listen to the theme to the end. 
Atmosphere and class. 

In the end I just wanted to say again that, yes, this is not a game for anyone and it has it's flaws as well. 
I am not gonna mention all of them here, but they can be found across the internet very easily. 
What I am going to do instead is this:  

Starfield in my opinion - 
Is not a game for you if you do not have the imagination to see the bigger picture that many at Bethesda wanted to replicate when making a huge space themed open world game.

It is not a game for you if you do not go beyond the casual gamer attitude and don't have the patience or attention to read many of the tips,chat logs, books and stories that await and present themselves to you in it's world.  

Is not a game for you if you are someone that has played Bethesda games in the past but you simply do not know how a Bethesda game should be played after all this time. You have to take it slow, and don't rush things as if you are on a speed-run.  This is a fine book that demands a little attention in order to be understood, it doesn't ask much more than what a high school student needs to read.  

I for one liked Starfield and would love for it to receive more support, updates or DLCs.

I gave Starfield 4.5 hours — WAY more than it DESERVED! Didn’t even bother with Lying Bethesda's Other Great Failure, Redfall (total disaster, everybody knows it), and I thought No Man’s Sky was one of the WORST games ever made — terrible, boring, EMPTY. And Starfield? Somehow even WORSE!

Let’s start with the BIGGEST scam — it’s running on the same ancient Engine used by FALLOUT 3, OBLIVION, even MORROWIND — a game from 2002, folks! Over 20 YEARS ago! And now they’re calling it “Creation Engine 2” like it’s brand new — just a rebranded, recycled MESS. That’s not innovation — that’s FRAUD with better lighting!

The gameplay? A DISGRACE. Totally lifeless. DEAD. You go from one Loading Screen to the next like it’s some kind of space-themed elevator simulator. The Planets — EMPTY. The bases — copy-paste TRASH. No real exploration, no real Freedom, just a bunch of FAST TRAVEL buttons disguised as a game. VERY SAD!

The characters? WORSE than the game. Every single one sounds like they’re reading from a TELEPROMPTER at a failed HR seminar. You try to pick up a CUP — a CUP! — and your companion starts whining like you committed War Crimes. Who wrote this stuff???

And here’s something NOBODY talks about — the Vending Machines are BROKEN. You land on a high-tech futuristic Moon Base in the year 2330, and the soda machine says “OUT OF ORDER.” Seriously?? We can travel across the galaxy but can’t get a bag of chips? Ridiculous. Total laziness. NO EXCUSE!

Where are the Aliens? WHERE ARE THEY? This is supposed to be a galaxy-spanning adventure — and it’s just HUMANS in different-colored jumpsuits! No Alien Races, languages, or mystery — just corporate sci-fi made by people who’ve clearly never watched the Fake News Media or a decent Movie. Absolutely ZERO imagination!

I quit after 4.5 hours because I realized I’d spent more time in MENUS than actually playing. It’s like a spreadsheet with spaceships. No Heart, no Soul, just a GIANT EMPTY PRODUCT made for Game Pass filler. That’s what you get when the LIARS at Bethesda receive UNDESERVED PRAISE FOR THE MEDIOCRITY THAT WAS SKYRIM!

Starfield is a monumental FAILURE — an overhyped, undercooked, committee-designed waste of time.

SAD!!!

9/10

Right away, Starfield impresses with how huge it is. You can travel to different star systems and explore all kinds of planets – some empty, some full of cities. It really feels like exploring space, and I often got sidetracked for hours checking out new things.

What you do in the game is super fun. The space battles are awesome, and I especially love that you can raid other ships! There's also building up your own ship, exploring old alien places, and dealing with different groups of people. Shooting bad guys feels good, and there are lots of ways to fight. Plus, like other Bethesda games, there are lots of skills to learn and interesting side missions.

The main story is really good – full of mystery and makes you think. The characters you meet are cool, and the game world feels very detailed and real. The game also looks amazing. Planets, ships, and space views are beautiful, and the music is great too, making everything feel epic.

It's not perfect, which is why it's a 9 out of 10. Some of the computer-made planets can feel a bit empty, and I saw a few small glitches. I also wish I could actually join some of the different factions in a deeper way, or that the main story felt a bit less linear at times. But these are tiny issues in a great game.

Overall, Starfield is fantastic. You can play for hundreds of hours exploring and having adventures. It's a game you'll keep thinking about. If you like Bethesda's other games or just love space adventures, you have to play this. I loved it! I can always count on Bethesda to deliver an supurb and enteraining AAA game.

I originally wanted to play this game since release, but for some reason, I kept putting it off. In hindsight, that might have been the best decision I could’ve made. Over the years, Starfield has received a ton of updates and quality-of-life improvements that turned it into something genuinely enjoyable – and I can see myself spending many more hours in it.

I honestly don’t understand the overwhelming negative reviews. I think a lot of people went in with completely wrong expectations. I, on the other hand, went in with none at all – and ended up having an amazing time.

You need to understand the game's strengths and weaknesses and focus on what it does well. It’s obvious that procedurally generated planets don’t offer the same joy as handcrafted exploration – I didn’t even need to try them to know that. But once you stick to the hand-crafted content, the classic Bethesda magic kicks in.

Starfield is something entirely different from Fallout or The Elder Scrolls – and that’s what makes it so fantastic.

This game is seriously overhated and deserves more appreciation. If you’ve been holding off because of the bad reviews, take this as your sign to give it a try. You probably won’t regret it.

I really hope Bethesda continues to support and expand the game with updates and fresh content for a long time.

Cons:

-Some NPC faces feel lifeless
-Melee combat feels weak and clunky

Summary
Starfield is a good game and a major improvement over Bethesda’s previous work. Animations are better, characters are more varied, and the design is beautiful. The graphics are stunning—still carrying that familiar Creation Engine feel.

However, the writing is severely lacking, which weakens what would normally be seen as Bethesda’s signature charm. If you can get the game on discount (say, for around $20) and don’t expect it to feel like Skyrim, it still has a lot to offer.

Positives
Amazing music: Classic Bethesda atmosphere. They absolutely nailed the tone once again.
Beautiful graphics: Not fully optimized, but visually impressive and immersive.
Content-rich: There’s a wide variety of activities to explore and invest in.
Passion is evident: This doesn’t feel like a lazy product. While not a flawless hit, it feels like a necessary stepping stone. With Creation Engine 2 in place, The Elder Scrolls VI has the potential to be great again.
That Bethesda feeling: The world and ambience feel familiar and welcoming, despite the flaws.

Negatives
1. "Tell, Don’t Show" Writing
The crew of Constellation has friendly banter, nicknames, and jokes, trying to feel authentic. But right after that, they go into long, explanatory monologues about how much they appreciate each other more akin to tell versus show.
It completely kills the natural flow and undermines emotional beats. What should be earned feels forced, which hurts the narrative's impact.
2. Unrealistic Reactions
Characters often respond bizarrely to major events.
Example: You discover a mysterious alien artifact—zero idea what it is or what it does—yet no one treats it with realistic caution like lets say a temporary quarantine. your building something that could be dangerous and yet nobody treats it with due carefulness in the name of "exploration" and guess what? it ends up being really dangerous. It's as if everybody is insanely naive.
Or: After nearly causing the destruction of New Atlantis, you can casually stroll around like nothing happened.
The lack of meaningful reaction breaks immersion. Characters often don’t feel like real people.

3. Shallow Worldbuilding
Bethesda usually relies on themes and clichés to establish mood and identity in its cities.
In Starfield, the cities feel like set pieces without substance. There’s not much under the surface to engage with—more style than depth. And i'm not talking about the amount of quests. its a shallow ocean versus a deep pond.

4. Clunky Systems
The ship builder sounds great in theory, but in practice it's awkward and confusing.
The base building system suffers from similar issues—good ideas, poor execution.

Neutral
Loading screens: Personally not a big issue. If you avoid the map and use the scanner, transitions feel much faster and less intrusive.

Final Thoughts
That’s it. Starfield isn’t perfect, but it’s not without value. It’s not the next Skyrim, but if you go in with tempered expectations, there’s still a lot to enjoy. Let’s hope this is the warm-up act to something amazing.

This is, unfortunately, one of the most painfully boring games I have ever played in my life. I bought the game on release day and all of Bethesda's updates since then have done little to improve the joy factor that it is sorely lacking. Exploration is dull and unrewarding, combat is woefully repetitive, most of the characters seem absolutely soulless and artificial, character customization is underwhelming, and the game is probably one of the worst offenders of 'quantity over quality' by including such a vast and desolate universe to waste your time roaming.

On the positive side, I do enjoy the shipbuilding aspect of the game. Even though the options available seem limited, players have shown great ingenuity in creating unique and iconic ships. Inon Zur's score for this game is absolutely stellar (no pun intended), which makes it all the more painful that it was wasted on a game such as this.

I can appreciate the main/faction questlines as well as the lore and major locations but having 1,000 planets, 120 stars, and only 82 of the locations handcrafted leads me to believe this game would have greatly benefited if it had been more streamlined. As I am writing this, I have invested 200 hours and only a fourth of that time actually went towards missions while the rest went towards charting planets and cataloging resources as I naturally came across them.

Updating this to a negative review, Bethesda has started outsourcing content-creation to their "creations" store, but this requires arbitrary and very broken account linking between Bethesda.net and Steam that usually doesnt work. I guess its their way of getting around selling DLC directly on steam to avoid steam fees. But it also means that people can buy "content" but not access it due to Bethesdas broken account linking system.

I want to sit here and lie to you. I want to say this game is amazing. I want to say that years later, Bethesda has solved the issues of Starfield. I want to say Starfield is an incredible addition to a studio that has become increasingly complacent.

I cannot. Starfield, despite numerous bug fixes, is riddled with network errors, crashes and numerous quality of life issues that have yet to be alleviated. The RPG aspects of the game have significantly diminished over the years as a no to an NPC has now become a "Later I'll say yes." How the weight management system has become increasingly annoying and dulling to the game. How the world is lifeless and unapologetically lazy from an equally unapologetically lazy studio. How the combat has seemingly regressed since Fallout 4. How the opportunity for choices has been stripped down to "yes" and "I'll talk to you later." It's a game that desperately wants you to be a hero, while providing no conundrums for the player beyond "good guys good, other good guys good, bad guys really bad."

I want to say the plots of Starfield's major narratives are what will keep you going. They're not. I want to say the companions are useful and will keep you engaged in meaningful and interesting dialogue. They don't. I want to say the gunplay feels smooth and strong. It doesn't. I want to say this game won't crash at least a few times a day; I can't. Starfield is less of a game and more of a cash grab. It's entirely carried by a modding community that puts more care in the game than the developers did.

All of this, however, is in the forefront of what is really a phenomenal ship design minigame, although, even this solid design system is offset by two major problems of space combat in general. The problems with ships, however, are 1) the inconsistencies in ladder and door placements coupled with 2) the lack of viability in weaponry outside of particle beam weapons.

I want to lie to you and say you should buy this game. I can't, and I won't. Starfield is not worth your time, your money nor your enthusiasm, because it will never reciprocate the potential the uninformed might assume it has. I cannot recommend you stay away from this game enough, and the only reason I'm continuing the game is to finally put another notch on my belt of completed games.

I restarted the game from the beginning, without mods, and immersed myself in the story until, with no choice, I had to engage in space combat. I press the button to fire, the ship shakes but nothing happens, I try the secondary weapon: nothing. Missiles? again, the ship shakes so there's a reaction but no projectiles...

Is Starfield a perfect game? Absolutely not. But with that said, this game gets much more hate than it truly deserves. The main story is actually good with decent replay potential, the different faction side quests are good, and the ship building mechanic is fantastic. The ability to fine tune the game's difficulty to fit your personal style or mood is a refreshing aspect that can actually drive you to personally challenge yourself to gradually get better at the game on your terms or to make higher level gear feel more or less balanced as you progress. As with any game, some NPCs are really well done while others are annoying or forgettable, but that is always a matter of personal taste. Being a long-term Bethesda fan, I do wish there were more romance options, but again, that is a matter of my personal taste. The only complaints I really agree with are those that revolve around outpost building. You can play the game 100 times and never need to use this feature. There are no quests that focus on it (at least that I have encountered), and outside of wanting an immersive experience, the rewards for doing anything with it are not worth the time you invest in it. The Creations modding community has also done an amazing job at expanding the content beyond what the developers included. Just keep in mind that mods for any game are a mixed bag and subject to personal opinion. All in all, if you enjoy Bethesda games and are a fan of Sci-Fi, I recommend you give this game a chance.

Starfield Review – A Vast, Beautiful Universe That Runs Flawlessly on the XFX SWFT RX 9070 OC Edition

Starfield delivers exactly what space exploration fans have been waiting for — an ambitious, expansive universe teeming with mystery, adventure, and jaw-dropping vistas. I’ve been playing it on the XFX SWFT RX 9070 OC Edition GPU, and I’m thrilled to report that the game runs incredibly well. Load times are quick, performance is smooth even in the most visually intense areas, and the card handles the game’s demanding environments effortlessly, maintaining high frame rates with ultra settings enabled.

What truly sets Starfield apart is the sheer scale of its universe. This is not just a big game — it's massive. Each star system feels hand-crafted, and the sense of discovery when landing on a new planet never gets old. From frozen wastelands to lush alien jungles, the variety in environments is stunning, and the game constantly surprises you with how different and alive each world feels. The inhabitants of these worlds — both human and alien — have unique cultures, designs, and behaviors that make every encounter feel meaningful.

At first, the story might seem straightforward, but it expands dramatically as you explore and dig deeper. What begins as a space-faring adventure quickly unfolds into a rich, branching narrative full of political intrigue, personal stakes, and philosophical questions about humanity’s place in the universe. The deeper you go, the more rewarding it becomes.

In short, Starfield is a technical and artistic triumph — especially when paired with powerful hardware like the XFX SWFT RX 9070 OC Edition. If you’re looking for a game that offers not just hours, but worlds worth of content, this one’s an easy recommendation.

I like but do not love Starfield. It is a game of things I love, things I dislike, and things I like. There is a symmetry between these three things.

The World:
-I love the handmade major settlements and major areas; they have such cool environments and things to do, they are truly some of the coolest locations Bethesda has ever made. If the game focused on just our Solar System and minimized the random generation, this could have been amazing.
-I dislike the generated overworld, as it get repetitive and there is too little to do in many places, and the native species are too similar.
-I like the overworld combat, the generated caves/space stations, and some bits of random generated settlements. There should be more to what kind of cover and interactions with overworld areas in combat should be used, and the random generated settlements should have variety. Yet, as they are, they are hard to get bored of unless you stick to the random generated areas a lot.

Space Combat:
-I love the space combat. Every weapon feels fun to use, moving feels fun, and it is such a unique gameplay system loop. I love how you can adjust the energy you put into anything in the ship.
-I hate how sometimes you can spawn in space and run into like 5 enemies and completely die. This happens too often.
-I like how you can navigate in combat with the environment. Asteroids, space stations and debris can impact combat. However, it does not have enough effect.

The Graphics:
-I love the general art direction. The way the environment and actors blend together can visually be really good. The sense of scale in this game given graphically is very impressive/
-I hate the level of detail. Things look kind of ugly, especially for what it takes to run this game. Some items and environments look so low resolution, and that is disappointing. It is not as big as a jump over Fallout 4 or 76 as one would hope. The graphical fidelity is very much worse than average for a usual big budget game.
-I like the character models. They can be really good or kind of bad, but most models are average to good-ish.

Everything Else:
-I love love love the gameplay. I covered the space combat, but the on ground combat is super fun. There are so many cool things to do. While I admit it is not particularly deep, it is so much fun.
-The Bethesda-y positives like looting and interactions remain as they are but better. This is a big plus.
-The Bethesda classic bugs are here. This is mostly a negative with some positives. It leans more negative than positive, but not in an overwhelming way.
-The Bethesda jank is here, and that is a slight positive for me, and likely a net neutral for most.
-The transition from space to land is awkward. While I dislike for instance in No Man's Sky that the transition takes too long, here it feels worse not having it at all. The game feels so detached, disconnected and not like a full game as a result. If that detachment was similar to the detachment from procedural generated areas and the handcrafted areas, it would feel more natural.
-The space area is so limited, and there is no real space travel. I want to mega boost into areas between planets and find settlements and randomly generated areas, but I cannot. Everything is tied to little sandboxes in a specific side of a planet. You cannot descend to the planet or leave the area of space just right above the planet. It is so terribly jarring.
-This game runs like crap. This game is terribly optimized. For a game with such low attention to detail and graphical fidelity, it should run much better on every system and PC.
-The items and usual item interactions are funny, the same as any Bethesda game.
-The party, main story missions, and all of that is very cool. I love all my party members.
-The base building is okay, but the starship building is AMAZING! I love it so much! It is so fun to build starships!

This game overall feels incomplete. The engine clearly held it all back, and the concepts as a result were not fully realized. I hope years in the future Bethesda can leverage new technology and development techniques to fix these mistakes, because underneath it, there is a great game.

I am giving Starfield a recommendation, but with many caveats. That said, I enjoyed most of my time with it.

After having played the game for almost 120 hours, and having just completed my first playthrough, I can say that this game is worth picking up with some considerations. Bare in mind that much of this is based on my personal taste and opinion.

[h1] The Good [/h1]

[h3] Class Roleplay/Variation [/h3]

I found a lot of satisfaction in building my character. It's a slow process that is more rewarding, the more you focus on specific traits. It's not as cookie cutter as prior BGS titles, and requires that you express experience with the skill you're leveling to level it. To increase carry weight further than a tier 1, for instance, the player needs to run a certain distance while above 75% carrying capacity. This is represented in every skill that can be leveled and gives some context to the player becoming more proficient within them. To be a master lock-pick ,you need to pick locks routinely. To become a demolition expert, you need to use explosives routinely. You must adhere to the role you intend to fill as you play in order to be any good at it, since the leveling process is slow and focused.

[h3] Sidequests [/h3] 

BGS games aren't known for having stellar story-telling in side quests. There are some gems that we all remember, like the Thieves Guild quest-line in Skyrim, or "Here there be monsters" in Fallout 4. But over-all, they are relatively uninspired from a plot stand-point. Starfield raised the bar massively in this regard. Rarely have I been immersed in a side-quest like I did [spoiler] being a double operative between Sysdef and the Crimson Fleet [/spoiler], or being a [spoiler] secret agent for Ryujin Industries [/spoiler].

[h3] Gunplay [/h3]

Some folks may disagree with me here, but I had a load of fun getting into scuffles with major antagonistic factions in Starfield. Every large gunfight felt smooth and exciting, especially for a BGS game. BGS took everything they learned with Fallout 4's vastly improved animations and gunplay, and dialed it up to 10 with Starfield. Sure, there's some jank here and there, being a creation engine game with all the limitations we're familiar with. But I was not left unimpressed with Starfield. Firing a lever action grenade (rocket?) launcher into a crowd of Spacers is exactly as fun as you'd want it to be, and mowing down crimson fleet with a microgun (minigun) is serotonin incarnate. If nothing else, I'd pay $40 for a game that takes just the combat in Starfield and throws it at you in a linear campaign. It's a good time, when it does come into play.

[h3] Difficulty Settings [/h3]

Normally, this isn't something I'd include in any review, and I'll keep it relatively short, but Starfield went above and beyond when it comes to customizing the difficulty in your playthrough. There is a feature-length list of settings to fine-tune every action you can complete in the game to be just as difficult as you'd like it to be. Enemy health and damage modifiers, item weights, you name it; starfield lets you customize it to a very detailed degree and rewards you for making it more difficult. If anyone has played the later entries in the Forza franchise, and is familiar with the difficulty settings and rewards for cranking anything up, then they'll be well aware of how starfield's settings work.

[h3] Ship Customization [/h3]

Starfield's ship customization is beyond in-depth. and it would be impossible for me to lay everything out here, but I'll give some examples of what you can do:

You can get up from your cockpit and fully explore the interior of the ship you, yourself, put together using hab modules.

You can equip different habitation modules that allow you to customize what you can do when exploring your ship, IE engineering hab for weapon and suit upgrading, med hab for pharmaceutical crafting, armory for storing and displaying your weapons of war, mess halls, computing habs, you flipping name it.

As you level your skills, you'll be able to equip better modules that allow you to build bigger ships (with more habs), defeat tougher pirates, go faster, carry more (or illegal) cargo, and last longer.

You can make your ship look DOPE AS F***, with different ship manufacturers providing different appearances that you can stay consistent with, or even mix-match. You can make a Deimos combat vessel with a militaristic appearance, or you can build a Stroud Eklund ship that looks sleek and clean. You can build a Hope Tech ship that looks like a massive cargo hauler. You can do ANYTHING. It's awesome.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

[h3] Ship Combat [/h3]

I personally find the ship combat being dull, having myself played a ton of Elite: Dangerous. Ships do very basic maneuvers, with the difficulty only really coming into play with the level of the combatant ships and their components. For me, personally, it's like fighting my spreadsheet against theirs, with little variance in HOW the ships maneuver or otherwise interact. Some will find it very engaging, and I have had some fun with it here and there, but over-all it feels meh for me.

[h3] Travel [/h3]

Oh boy... Here comes the source for all of the Starfield memes, and none of them are entirely out of place. topic is going to be two-fold, including locale travel, and interstellar travel. 

[b] On foot, [/b] Traveling between POI is mostly void of interaction or interesting centerpieces and world-building. Once at a POI, it can get quite deep and engaging (when that POI hasn't duplicated for you a dozen times yet with Starfield's randomization). But In between those points of interest are mostly either just passing eye candy or barren wasteland based on what kind of planet you are on. 

[b] In space, [/b] how you travel with your ship is... vacuous. During combat, your ship movement has some significance, but when traveling between star systems, it's simply choosing a location on the star-map, and waiting for your grav drive to spool up. While I'm not as concerned about loading screens as many folks are, it can get tiresome seeing it EVERY TIME you travel somewhere else. I understand that this is a limitation of the engine, but could we not, perhaps, decrease the amount of star systems we would need to travel to, or otherwise make jumping around more interesting?

[h3] Weapon Variety [/h3]

While there are a ton of different weapons in Starfield that might contradict what the title suggests, I find the lack of "unique" natured weapons in a BGS game quite saddening. There's no Starfield equivalent of "Mehrunes' Razor" or "Dawnbreaker" from Skyrim within Starfield. Starfield tries to fill the gaps left by not having these mythic unique weapons with variants of weapons you normally find everywhere, but with bunch of neat effects. Sure, the effects are cool and make the gun stand out to some degree, but it's still visually the same thing as the sidestar I have been using since level 10. I'd like to have a unique minigun that looks visually different while also having those effects. Give me more reasons to explore in Starfield.

[h1] In Conclusion... [/h1]

I think Starfield is well worth its price tag for a somewhat broad audience. The reviews, however, are mixed for a good reason. There are as many areas that Starfield was left with minimal effort or foresight, as there are areas with extensive effort and foresight. Sometimes, the two intersect, and what would otherwise be a phenomenal feature turns into one worth less player investment because of the limitations regarding what you can do with that feature (ship design).

It is, however, worth a shot. The quests in Starfield are stellar and well-developed in most cases, and there's plenty to sink your teeth into. Just be prepared for a frustration every now and then. 

I'd rate Starfield a 7/10, personally.

Today, I wanted to check on how the reviews were doing and it's not surprising that this game has lost a significant amount of core rpg players. I will provide my long-time been simmering opinion on the game.

[h3] [FOR VENT / OLDER BETHESDA FANS] [/h3]
On the premise of providing a classic rpg for the new generation, it failed.
On the premise of providing an amazing space rpg, it surprised on certain areas (ships, outposts, and planet exploration) yet it failed ultimately.
I think some people really do not know how much we enjoyed Elder Scrolls Bethesda despite its technical flaws, and even the awfully hilarious npc behaviors, and seeing a similar experience (one that did not improve on its core flaws) on a high-end hardware requirement setup was heartbreaking, still disappointing.
The promises were made, the hype was there, despite the pricetag and launch flaws I bought it at the time. On the same machinery I once played Skyrim, I haven't seen a Bethesda that improved on what mattered, but instead added fancy features and graphics to visually catch-up with its competitors / peers.
I have downgraded my experience of course to at the least give it a go and see if there was core value to play this game, despite the requirements. There wasn't. And imagine how much longer I would play if I really enjoyed the game.

[h3] [FOR POTENTIAL CUSTOMERS] [/h3]
If you have a computer that is within recommended requirements AND have seen an aspect of the game you want to try ( space exploration, ship building/combat, dungeon delving, outpost building );
I still recommend watching videos about it to really make sure you want to give it a go. You don't want to end up with a hole in your wallet for a one-night experience.

If you have the recommended machinery specs AND want to see what Bethesda offers in Starfield overall as a space rpg;
I recommend being an old Bethesda fan/player/customer and being familiar with their "storytelling", erratic gameEngine behaviors, funny interactions and really game-y (fast food-ish) rpg taste. I do not find it bad whatsoever (maybe also because Skyrim was my first open-world rpg experience). It is just awful to see it on a 2023 release game that had a big mouth on its pre-release phase.

OVERALL / TLDR; This game cannot be played outside its recommended specs, and deserves praise only on a couple aspects of many.
Very dull game and you need plenty of mods to make it playable. Will not buy another Bethesda game for a few years. Save yourself from sitting for hours on endless loading screens.

God....I wanted to love this game. It's got everything I would like, on paper. Cool setting, neat, solar-punk early space age art style, lots of loving throwbacks to older science-fiction tropes. If this was just fallout 4 in space, I would have probably been pretty happy.
But then, there's the actual meat and potatoes of the game. So, so much about the way everything in this game is set up, from the UI, to the main story quest, to the design of the planets themselves, feels rushed and cheap. Planet outposts are copy and paste, you WILL run into the same building layouts over and over again within the first few hours of play. Space exploration is famously limited, relying on load screens to get you from planet-orbit-system. Load screen to load screen to load screen, actually. Just creation engine things. 
When it's fallout or skyrim, and the only real load screens you see are entering and exiting building cells and dungeons, it's not really as noticeable, but try to get from the meeting table at the Lodge to the starport in New Atlantis and count the load screens. Just really immersion breaking in a game all about keeping you immersed, could've maybe hidden these cell changes with animations or something, riding an elevator, sitting in the tram, going bleep-boop with the buttons on the ship console when traveling, something that makes me feel like I am at least still in the game. I think the gravity drive does this well, it's a nice transition between places, but it's the only time in the game that happens.
Todd says this game took EIGHT YEARS to develop....how? 7 years to whip the ancient, barely functional creation engine into something useful and a year to develop the game, maybe. He says they wanted even more development time which sounds crazy, but I really feel like this needed possibly another 5 years in development. I would MAYBE recommend getting it on sale, if you really, really, like bethsoft RPGs. Otherwise, I would probably avoid. I can't see patches or updates changing fundamentally rushed things about the game
loading screens everywhere you go. boring story. dumb ai. etc etc.

I would not recommend starfield as it is, and saying that greatly disappoints me.
I spent over 130 hours in this game, and, while initially I was enthralled and having a good time, the gameplay and story quickly became clunky, poor and boring. In any other bethesda game you will *always* find something interesting between locations. This is not the case in starfield, it is an empty barren mess with the same POI copy and pasted on uninteresting worlds. it is rocks, hills, and the occasional bit of life whether it be some grass, a plant or some weird animal.
The main quest, while again, interesting at first, quickly falls flat, becoming a mix of loading screens, caves, funny pieces of metal and ancient temples you spend an odd 5 to 10 minutes walking to before doing some weird zero gravity floating light thing to get a super power. The companions are mostly uninteresting and two dimensional as well.
The faction quests aren't *great*, but they are at the least good. I haven't much to say about them besides how I think they're the most engaging story content in this game. 

I do have some positives about this game, building starships is incredibly fun, though a bit restrictive in areas like how some of it is locked behind perk trees and ludicrous prices that are insane to save up for (especially considering how little payout you get from many activities in the game)
Character customisation was a highlight for me, I enjoyed being able to choose a background and have it appear once in a while through dialogue, it was a far improvement on fallout 4s character creation.

It is possible, if slightly improbable, that in 5 to 10 years, this game will have received the same modding treatment as fallout 4, in which case, I imagine the community will create quality content for the game as the Bethesda modding community always has. 
I really hope that in however long I can recommend this game through modding, however bare in mind that this should not be the standard, a game should not need to be intensely modded to be fun, especially considering how much of a pain in the ass it is at the moment.

(P.S the environmental conditions system and the space suit system SUCKS)

[h1]Not Recommended[/h1]

Guys, fellow gamers — I gave this game [b]136 hours[/b] of my life.
I still haven’t finished it, and honestly, I’m not sure I ever will.

It’s not exactly a bad game. It has those classic Bethesda faction questlines, a mid-tier main story, and the usual pile of bugs. I’m used to bugs in the TES series — I grew up on them. But if there’s one thing [b]Starfield[/b] really excels at, it’s [i]scaling the chaos up[/i].

Broken saves? [i]Sure.[/i]
A pirate base that unmoors from its planet and follows you across the galaxy? [i]Of course.[/i]
A grind system more boring than learning Shouts in Skyrim? [i]Why not.[/i]
Atlantic City assets teleporting behind your ship? [i]Bethesda says hi.[/i]

And none of this is fixable through console commands or mods. You just have to [b]start over[/b].

The real issue? The game [i]isn’t fun at its core.[/i] It’s packed with odd design choices:
[list]
[*] No city maps at launch  
[*] Planet exploration is [i]painfully boring[/i] — like No Man’s Sky resource grinding, minus the joy  
[*] A lifeless crafting system with [b]hundreds of pointless materials[/b]  
[*] An overall vibe that sometimes feels more suffocating than [i]Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2[/i] — and I actually liked that game  
[/list]

Even if you remove all the bugs, Starfield still struggles as a game. And in its [i]current[/i] state? Plenty of those bugs are [b]still there[/b] (hello, flickering lights with DLSS...).

[h2]Final thoughts[/h2]
Starfield is a massive disappointment.

The saddest part? TES fans like me stick around because of the nostalgia — the side quests, the exploration, our ridiculously high tolerance for bugs. But the game gives nothing in return except frustration.

[spoiler]I wanted to love this game. I really did. But it just doesn’t love you back.[/spoiler]

Bethesda's visually and mechanically best game to date. The only real set back is the procedural generation once you get out exploring the star systems. The planets and locations you explore all look copy and paste with the exception of a few  places that are fun to be immersed in and feel unique. I think they should have focused on a few star systems instead of having hundreds of the same looking locations. Other than that its fun to play.

First and foremost: what the heck is this plot? I'm a miner, a simpleton, who suddenly, out of the blue, some captain just hand a spaceship because I find an item I don't even know what it is? And on top of that, the spaceship isn't a regular spaceship, like an old 1975 Scania, but actually, a very important one, the kind that needs training and a very trustable captain to man it? Come on.

Then, I spent more time trying to find storage space than actually being able to enjoy the gameplay and missions. That was already a dealbreaker. This Fallout mechanic of "everything is looteable" is way outdated. Fallout players like myself doesn't want to deal with this kind of boring mechanics any more. We just want to play the thing. 

Also, combat. For a self-called Role Playing Game, a combat mechanic thats way too arcade-ish and non creative. You just, you know, shoot around. And remove hitpoints of the target. While it is running brainlessy around the map. And you don't even need to find cover. Just run around trying to find that last pirate that its also running around, but far away, for no reason. Its just... childish. 

This one is a bad mix of Borderlands and Fallout. Not for me. 4/10. Tops.

This is an ambitious RPG, which allows the player to engage in many different types of activities to suit their own playstyle.   What the game lacks in depth, it makes up for in breadth - but it is perhaps a bit broad, with 1000+ planets and moons to explore.   The extensive breadth leads to some computer-generated repetition, but you can ignore what you have seem before.
Some of the game's best features are the quests (both faction and radiant), the ship builder, and outpost building,   The game is very re-playable, as you can start new games with different characters with different backgrounds and skills, or proceed with NewGame+ when you complete the main quest.  The game is quite stable on PC, and if you don't like the way something works, there are many mods on Nexus and the Creations that allow the game to be tweaked and added to. - even entire new planets or a Star Wars overhaul.  Besides Skyrim, I am finding Starfield to be my go-to PC game.  Starfield is not quite Skyrim in space, but it is more like Traveler - for those who have played that old pencil & paper tabletop sci-fy RPG.  Is the game perfect?  No,  But it's pretty good!

I originally started playing this game on PC day one through a Game Pass subscription and enjoyed the story however, it was incredibly buggy with poor graphic performance and AI response from NPC's.  I recently picked it up on sale (for about 50% off) and started playing again. I must say after cooking for a little while longer the game seems much better. It's looking and performing quite nicely on my system and the AI seems a bit more polished, even in combat. I can see how the public holds Bethesda to high standards and that some might be disappointed as the game might not have been exactly what they expected but I'm pretty satisfied with where it is and would recommend to players who enjoy a Mass Effect/No Man's Sky type feel with a really good story arch. Yes, it has a sort of classic Jules Verne innocence to it but that appeals to me. The music score and sound are very complementary (Cinematic dare I say). I haven't heard any F bombs or seen anyone hacked to pieces by a chainsaw yet but it still deals with adult themes in a PG-13 kind of way (If you want something more carnal the Doom franchise has got you covered). I think I had about 20 or 30 hours into it on Game Pass, did not previously finish the main campaign but my replay so far has been very satisfying as it seems to have improved quite a bit since launch. I love all of the detailing that was put into interfaces and objects. Vasco and the Frontier ship are super cool looking to me with its retro/modern combination aesthetic. This is very well done throughout the game so far.  I wish you could actually do a little more in unexpected ways (like other Bethesda titles) with some of the NPC's but this does help to keep the main story on track without getting too terribly distracted. The miners definitely don't appreciate getting clipped by a cutter. Its a fun game that ticks most of the boxes for me. There looks like there's a healthy amount of additional paid and non paid content in Creation. A thumbs up for me but I wouldn't pay 70 bucks for it, but I don't generally pay full price for any games.

Millennial Game Reviewer Extraordinaire

[h1]🎮 Starfield – 8/10 (NASA-core Meets Bethesda-core)[/h1]

[h2]TL;DR[/h2]
[b]✅ A vast, beautifully detailed sci-fi RPG sandbox that lets you live your best spacefaring life.[/b]
[b]❌ Interplanetary travel starts to feel like a glorified loading screen after a while.[/b]

[h2]What Works[/h2]
[list]
[*][b]World-building is top-tier[/b] — factions, lore, cities, and the endless vacuum of space all feel immersive and distinctly Bethesda
[*][b]Ship customization and combat[/b] are highlights — building your own spaceship and dogfighting in zero-G never gets old
[*][b]Quest design and RPG elements[/b] — classic Bethesda goodness: moral dilemmas, weird side quests, and memorable characters
[*][b]Graphics and atmosphere[/b] — gorgeous planetary surfaces and space vistas make exploration screenshot-worthy
[/list]

[h2]What Needs Work[/h2]
[list]
[*]The space travel loop gets repetitive — lots of menus, fast travel, and loading screens break the immersion over time
[*]Procedural planets feel a bit… procedural — not every rock needs a story, but some feel like copy-paste galactic filler
[*]Inventory and encumbrance management is classic Bethesda — and not in the good way
[/list]

[h2]Worth Knowing[/h2]
[list]
[*]This is very much a Bethesda RPG in space — if you liked Skyrim or Fallout 4, you’ll feel right at home
[*]Modding community is already heating up — expect this to be an entirely different (and better) game in a year or two. I personally can't wait to see the world transformed into the Stargate SG1 Universe. 
[*]Performance is decent but still occasionally janky — it's tradition at this point
[/list]

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
[i]Starfield nails the feeling of exploring a massive galaxy with all the charm and clunk you’d expect from a Bethesda epic. While the travel system lacks the thrill of real-time spaceflight and can feel repetitive, the core of the game — the quests, the world-building, the freedom — is rock solid. It might not be the future of space RPGs, but it’s a strong first step onto a bigger stage.[/i]

[b]💬 Verdict: Worth buying at full price if you’re into story-driven sci-fi — just be ready to fast travel a lot more than you’d hoped.[/b]

The game is beautiful, but an inconsistent mess.

It teases you with many romantic sci-fi tropes that are hidden behind many, many, many layers and hours of bad interaction designs.

It's like they're lying to me all the time. And they are. But are they all?


For example:

- It can clearly render a moving spaceship's interior, multiple buildings' interiors, a city, and a generated world surface simultaneously.
But half the doors have loading screens.

- The story themes and concepts are great, some of my favorites.
But the writings are mostly poor, too stereotypical, and talk too much redundantly, often over each other.
i.e.
NPC: Blabla- Are you sure you're ready?
Player: Let's do this.
N: Dam right. You must be so eager to -blabla-.
P: Ready when you are.
N: It's about time. You know, this reminds me -blabla-.
P: We should get on with it.
NPC: -blablablablabla-
*quest updates, *quicksave, *shoots his face, *savescums, *'why am I on this go-there-and-talk quest for 2 hours? don't they have email or something?'

- You can walk around your ship while your ship moves. Even go around a planet or its many moons in real-time if you can go fast enough (like, 100,000 ~ 100,000,000,000 times of the ship's maximum speed).
But only with a mod can those be triggered.
But those only needed to be triggered. They were already in the game. Why weren't they used, and instead most space travels are sudo-fast-travels?

- The visual aesthetic is seemingly focused on realism, also seemingly well-researched and detailed one at that.
The gameplay is nothing but. How the damage works, stats, crafting, ship physics (the non-existence of it), inventory management, and lasers don't do laser things (recoil and "projectile" speed).
If they had either gone with this game mechanic with stylish visual, or this visual with hard science realism, it would have been easier to digest.
The way it is now, though, it feels like I'm eating a roasted mushroom with strawberry jam, kinda gross. (And you know what's worse? I ended up liking it!)

- The combat can be realistic and tense, killing you or the enemy in a couple of shots with any guns, instead of stat-based bullet sponges.
But those settings are kinda hidden in the options, and not the default setting for this "seemingly realistic" world.

- You have a jet pack and can run fairly fast all the time. Stairs are pretty steep, too.
But can't go over an ankle-high rock without jumping.
So I jump, mid-combat, in haste. And, oh, it's 0.26 gravity. Now I have no cover for an entire duration of a yawn. *ded.

- The interaction with the UI is horrendous.
It's a long list. 
I'll just say, if this is their entertainment UI, I feel bad for their management UI. Clearly, a whole lot of people are not paid enough for their mental well-being.

- The game complements the modding community. A great community, as usual.
But it also sabotages them and itself with some updates.
It's like being a pretty bad host for their paid guests, sometimes.
And why keep putting more effort into making more mess instead of fixing known issues, I do not know.

and etc.

But, you know, whatever that does?

Honestly this game is actually good. Idk what all the hate is about. The key thing is to go into this game with an open mind and immerse yourself. There is some alien life on some planets and there is a whole galaxy to explore. I played when the game first came out. It was rough. But after a bit of time, it runs good, looks good, added lots to do if you know where to look. The dialogue options can lead to different outcomes. npcs remember certain things about you and the gameplay is easy to learn. crafting system is cool, and easy to learn. Think of skyrim but less uga duga hack and slash and more story driven and exploration driven. best part is you can be whoever you wanna be. Wanna be a spy? you got it. Space pirate? sure. most wanted criminal or thief? sure. This game lets you mold it into what you want it to be. Most planets are barren and empty yes but in a way its realistic. planets discovered in space irl are the same way. what I do agree with is they should have added an alien race planet somewhere. most complaints from what I read are small little things people find anything to gripe about. My advice is give it a chance. Try it on game pass or pick it up and play for a couple hours. I think its worth it and pretty damn fun. It scratches the itch like skyrim/ oblivion for me at least.  It just has its own modern twist. Try it!

A decent Bethesda-like-RPG. Pros:

- Interesting side quests
- Good lore
- Starship and outpost builders
- interesting leveling system, where you need to work for your skills
- music
- easy to jump into

Cons:

- main quest seems like it was written by high school fresheman
- space battles looks more like arcade shooters
- unstable and bugged

- fast travel mechanics prevent you from exploration

So, what do I think about the game?  
Hows the dialogue, I hear you ask.  
What's the gunplay like, you say curiously.  
What about the impact of choices, do they matter at all?

My answer to all your questions? I don't know.  I don't know, because I can't make it passed the first mission. At first, it's some stutters, forcing me to slow down and check my phone while things come back.  Then the very first pirate ship lands at the very start of the game, right after I create my character.  Then it freezes.  Sometime I can have a one frame per second firefight, other times it crashes.  I have never made it passed the first pirate base you have to clear because of how poorly optimized this game is.

You may say it's my fault, trying to run this game on a terrible PC.  Well, no.  I got a pretty good rig and have selected "Low" on all graphic settings.  I can run games like Delta Force, a massive multiplayer game that is in beta and developed by a studio that doesn't have the backing of one of the largest and most well known gaming companies.  I can run FO4 with ungodly amounts of mods with no/very few crashes or stutters.  I can run late game HoI4 and Stellaris with no crashes or stutters (a grand achievement if you don't know).  I literally have never had a problem with any game I own unless they were having trouble with their servers.  This is a Starfield problem.  I have come back every 6 or so months to see if they have fixed it.  I have tried to use the various mods that promise to fix the terrible optimization.  Nothing works.  Modded FO3 runs better than this.

A space exploration game with nothing to explore. 1000 planets with the same dozen or so installations that are all exact copies of themselves. Same layout, same loot in the exact same spot, same enemies with the same weapons in the same locations.  All alien life is either a bug or a dinosaur and they all act exactly the same, which is to charge the player while you yank the trigger and wait for them to die. Planets are randomly generated so one can be -20 temp and you get 'extreme cold' effects while another can be -170 with no effect. Nonsensical.

A space combat system that is pure arcade and is just 'hold trigger until enemy ship blows up'. Every ship moves and feels like every other ship.

Ground/internal ship combat has a ridiculously stupid AI with enemies that are literally bullet sponges. They often just stand still while you pump round after round directly into their heads until they die. The game completely ignores what happens when you put a bullet through a space suit/helmet on a planet with no atmosphere.

The main story line is supremely boring and pointless. I forced myself to finish it and start NG only to realize that it's the same thing with a few minor changes. The thought of having to slog through every repetitive quest just to reset the game so I could do it yet again made me truly understand the concept of 'ennui' and nihilism. I only lasted an hour or so in NG before uninstalling the game.

I love equipment modding/upgrading in games but in Starfield there is no point. It's incredibly grindy and you will loot better equipment from enemies or chests. Outpost building is similarly grindy. Why do I need to build my own coffee table for my outpost? There's no such thing as a Space Ikea? Seriously, I can become a cargo jockey and transport minerals etc to every settled world, but no one can deliver a lamp or a chair?

Finally, the NPC's. They are all utterly bland and boring and are essentially minor variations of the same archetype (good). The voice acting is atrocious, at least the English versions are. Why do they all speak at a speed that's about half of actual humans? I did the companion quests more out of duty than interest. I can't say that I truly cared about any of them and when the big story shock happened and one of them died, I really could only say "I didn't like her anyway."

The only semi-bright spot in the game is the ship building, once you figure out how it works.  It's cool to be able to build your own ship that you can actually walk around inside. However that's about all you can do. You don't actually fly it anywhere and all of the modules from the various vendors are just cosmetic variations of the same thing  The ship combat is exactly the same for every ship.

I could go on but I think that covers my main critiques.

The game has an identity crisis and the devs tried to do what star citizen hasn't been able to do in 10+ years. But if you can get through the mostly bad writing, half finished stories, bad performance (even now after multiple patches) etc. there is a hidden good time especially if you download a few mods. 
Hopefully now that they made this tech demo they can make a dark fantasy space rpg next time.

TL;DR:
The question that Starfield raises for me: What is it that this game brings to the table that isn't already brought by...

Fallout: New Vegas, Skyrim, Fallout 4, No Man's Sky, Cyberpunk 2077, Mass Effect: Legendary Edition, Oblivion Remastered, and so on

...that makes it uniquely worth buying? Especially when I'm pretty sure 100% of those games I listed are, at time of writing, cheaper than Starfield?

VERY LONG; DID READ:
I feel like the counterarguments for people not liking Starfield either boil down to "you didn't play it long enough; it gets better later", or the opposite, "Well, you played it for X hours; nobody plays a game they don't like for that long, so clearly you actually like it." But, like, the sunk cost fallacy exists, and is on full display here.

I really WANT Starfield to be good. The NASApunk vibes are immaculate and I DON'T think the game would be improved by adding sentient alien species or anything like that. There are hints of moments where the game is real neat: The propaganda hallway in the UC Vanguard orientation. Most of the Ryujin Industries questline. Some of the interactions introduced by traits, especially Kid Stuff. 

And, maybe an unpopular opinion, but I actually love the simplistic tedium of the scanning system.


But Starfield feels like the sterile, family-friendly theme park land of a much more nuanced and mature setting, which lacks any theme or message, because having a theme or message makes it harder to get kids to beg their parents to ride the Constellation roller coaster One. More. Time.

Maybe the theme of the game is supposed to be hope and human perseverance. I'd honestly love a sci-fi game that's just unapologetically optimistic. But Starfield isn't that. There's clear poverty and class disparity everywhere, there's infighting over territory in a universe where there's SO much unused space that it's clear that this greed has nothing to do with any demonstrable need.

So then maybe it's a game about the cruel and greedy face beneath a world of sterile propaganda. Which also would've been great if it leaned into that. But it doesn't. There are plenty of instances where you see hints of an ugly side of a seemingly-benevolent group, but those are always swept under the rug, and never in a way that feels intentional. A more competent game would either allow you unravel and tear those systems down, OR beat into you that you're ultimately powerless against this unstoppable engine of greed, so the best you can do is keep your head down and get yours. Starfield does neither. Most of the hints of real conflict or depth feel less intentional and thought-provoking, and more "We thought this would be a cool set piece. Don't think too hard about it."

Then is it a game about exploration and appreciating the vastness of space? Well, with the game's focus on fast travel, exploration doesn't really feel organic in the same way it did in pretty much every Bethesda game since Oblivion. Yes, sometimes you find cool locations. Sometimes you get wowed and humbled by the emptiness of space. But most of the time, you're just kinda chilling on some rocks and you see an abandoned space gas station that's inexplicably out in the middle of a barren planet. You almost never stumble on a weird rabbit hole on your way to something else and forget what you were originally doing, which has always felt like a big part of the Bethesda Magic.

I gave it a genuine shot. Discarded all the popular opinions and went in with as close to an open mind as I could get. I played all the major factions and multiple New Game cycles, downloaded mods and creations, waited on Shattered Space and played every quest I could find in it. And then I let the game sit, and came back to reflect on my experience. The only thing I can say about Starfield is that, in spite of the effort I put into trying to have a good time, I ultimately failed to do so. This game was not worth all the time I put into playing it. For a person who can't get enough of modern Bethesda's Output - Fallout 4 / Skyrim style design without any visible improvement to gameplay loops or content generation - there may be a good time here. I guess I'm just not that person anymore.

Important to be aware of some flaws and shortcoming of the game but it is absolutely possible to have a great experience with it despite these issues. There's so much to see and do out in the Starfield!

The game can feel short, it's very easy to breeze through the main story. It is an interesting story in my opinion and more interesting to me are the parts that feel very meta for Bethesda games. Procedural generation ruins a lot of the fun of finding handcrafted locations made by Bethesda. It can still be fun the first few times you discover locations but you'll very quickly recognize subsequent appearances of those locations. There's also a ton of loading screens, not entirely unusual for a Bethesda game but even by that standard there's a lot. 

With those flaws and shortcomings in mind though, there's so much *good* in Starfield. The game is visually breathtaking, so many stunning locations and if you're a space fan in general there's just so much to take in out there. The designs and themes for ships and spacesuits and everything is fairly unique as well. Ship-building is fantastic fun. The cast of characters at Constellation and the backstory for the different factions feels like a great foundation that I hope they continue to build upon in the future. The side stories and quests were also very enjoyable, as expected from a Bethesda game, if you enjoy the typical Bethesda quest gameplay loop you'll likely enjoy these too. 

Be aware there are problems but also be aware you can still have a great deal of fun with this game!

Great Game!

I've found that many of the elements in the game that others often criticize are actually aspects I really enjoy. The exploration is immersive and rewarding, the base building feels meaningful and creative, and space combat adds a nice layer of intensity. I also get a lot of satisfaction from crafting, researching new technologies, and customizing or building ships to suit my playstyle. The sheer scope of systems and mechanics at play keeps things fresh—even after over 200 hours of gameplay, there's still plenty left for me to discover and experiment with.

That said, not everything has landed perfectly for me. One of the weaker aspects, in my opinion, is the quest design in the base game. Many of the objectives feel formulaic or disjointed, and the reliance on fast travel between key points really breaks the sense of immersion and continuity. It often feels more like ticking off a checklist than being part of a living, breathing world.

Interestingly, I found the quest structure in Shattered Space to be much more engaging. It offered a better sense of pacing, more cohesive storytelling, and a stronger motivation to explore organically rather than jumping from one objective marker to the next. I would have loved to see more of that thoughtful design carried over to the base game.

A lot of the so called problems with this game are people expecting it to be something it was never going to be. This is a Bethesda game. It has the Bethesda charm and the quirks. It is an amazing game in its own right and a lot of people want to try and put it down for reasons that aren't actually as great as they sound in text. Yes there are a lot of loading screens and menus, however a lot of this can actually be lessened. The only one bad thing is that the game doesn't clearly tell you how to get around some of the menu navigation. The loading screens are also quite short. Sure some people will have longer than others due to the computer they are running but its not really that bad. I grew up on regular nintendo, super nintendo, playstation 1, n64, and beyond. Quite frankly the loading times now are abysmally small in comparison.
