I came back to this over a month ago and dumped another 80 hrs in, this time downloading a couple community mods "creations". I picked an alternate start 'mod' which allowed me to immediately explore. Despite this being a role playing game, the writing still pulled me out of my enjoyment time and time again. "Yes ma'am, it's a damned honor to meet you" and other similar personality-shredding statements being forced dialogue options Sucks. The [persuade] dialogues being nonsensical, followed by NPCs reacting as if I had intimidated/threatened/annoyed them into submission broke any feeling of social control I felt over my character as well. There is a margin of this that I can forgive, especially in games like fallout 4 where the character is voiced, but in Starfield I do not get to play the character I want to. I am MADE not to by the writing consistently. It is thoughtless in comparison to the other Bethesda games. No amount of mods will change that. You are forced to play a Bootlicking Loser in a Significant percentage of the questlines. 

The ship-building had me running back and forth between my ship and the technician over and over again to see how the doors unpredictably connected, how the ladders got randomly placed and whether they connect at all. Room elements including crafting tables, of which there are 5 kinds, get removed as a result of doorway or ladder placement. Any manual room decorating/customization you had done gets wiped if you connect a new room or shift its placement. There is No way to preview or control these things in the builder. You have to Manually save frequently while doing this as well, because if you make changes, check and hate it, the only way to go back to your customized well decorated interior is by reloading. I genuinely felt so much satisfaction from putting together a well organized, well decorated, functional ship. 10 hours of gameplay later I have access to better ship pieces and I have to shift things around, losing my hard fought customizations if I want to keep up with level scaling or expand my crew. It leads to so much investment and so much Loss over and over. Even if you couldn't care less about aesthetic, your ship will be nonsensical and nonfunctional if you don't take the time to do multiple trips back and forth to the technician making sure the doors and ladders don't eliminate your purchased worktables and interactables.

I picked this game up because a coworker raved about it, right after release. He called it "Skyrim, in space" but in a complimentary way. I had never played Skyrim (don't ask me how), but the screenshots he shared were enough. I was hyperfixated on Valheim at the time, so I didn't actually play very far till a year later.

Since early December, 2024, Starfield's been my hyperfixation game. I've been on it nearly daily, multiple hours a day. I dragged out completing the game, because I was constantly finding new things and getting absorbed in the role playing, the base building, the leveling. At some point, I finally started looking at reviews -- and was *shocked* at how much people hate this game. It's upsetting to realize that people who don't want the game have likely ruined the chance for it to be iterated on and made even better.

I have the advantage of never playing a BGS game before, I think. I was able to take this game as a stand-alone experience. I also hadn't been plugged into the hype, and got into it with zero expectations. I can't relate with most people who have found the game disappointing (or worse).

The story telling is delightful. The depth and intricacies of the quest lines are largely amazing, and the simple dumb ones are (usually) amusing. The grinding feels at a minimum, and totally optional. The skill tree stressed me out at first, but it's not like I was being prevented from doing things in the game at lower levels. I spent 375ish hours on my first playthru, being pretty thorough, and apparently still left things undone.

It's a piece of art made by people, which means there are flaws. I spent something like 12 hours messing with the outpost system, absolutely entranced in the process of building a system that fed raw mats into manufacturing -- then realized that was it, I'd maxed it out and probably never needed to touch it again. There's glitches, a couple borked quests, inventory issues. Some quest lines DO feel half-finished, or wrap unsatisfactorily. But none of this has stopped me from being sucked into the universe.

If you enjoy RPGs, space operas, gun/laser fights, and having options that aren't always "Shoot this NPC" then you'll enjoy Starfield. Extra so, if you're willing to enjoy something for what it IS instead of hating it for what it isn't.

It has some good ideas, but this is an obviously unfinished game.

The game is not bad. It's just doesn't give me that "Oh, a new elderscrolls game!" feeling. 1000 kilometers wide, 10 cm deep. Still, I'm close to 700 hours with several characters played at the time of writing this.

Most of the world generation is pretty nice and well done, it's just the outposts feel copy pasted into the game world and not adapted for it's environment, as an example i ran into an abandoned farm recently.... On Mars. What were the settlers thinking? And some settlers walk around in freezing cold (-30'C) or without a environmental suit on planets that would kill them in seconds, which breaks immersion.

The space combat is good, the storyline (main game) is ok, the side quests are awesome (Groundpounder, Crimson and Vanguard), but i found the (first) DLC to be a bit like they tried to make a Shivering Isles expansion to a space game.

Major plus points for NewGame+, but it only have so many rewarding levels. I'm at NG+16 on one character and the rewards kind of dwindle out after NG+15. There are some new dialogues you can say as you reenter the game, but there is not enough of them.

Did i like StarField? Yes. Did i expect new? Also yes. It would be better for Bethesda to make this game go it's on way instead of trying to slap an Elderscrolls magic DLCs onto it, a Fallout type of DLC would be better, like some "far harbour" thing that opens up a wormhole that took you to a new set of star systems closer to the galaxy core with new factions or even an alien civilization. There are plenty of options to step away from their traditional game design formula and create something new.

Bethesda said that they are going to support this game for 10 years. I hope they do so and don't look back at what they have already done and go in a new direction. That would include a new game engine, and i think their experiment with Oblivion Remastered and Unreal Engine 5 is a good thing - too bad they didn't do that earlier and could have made StarField into a spectacular gaming experience.

Bethesdas track record hasn't been good since Fallout 76 and they need to shape up, i think complacency has gotten to their studio. For now, as a gamer who like exploration and space, i give StarField a B+ - while hopeing that they go for an A++.

It's really not that bad. I used to be indifferent to the game but as the game has gotten older my opinion of Starfield has really softened. I think its pretty good. It's not dogsh** at all like some people say.

It runs great and is pretty stable. The questlines are really good. The UC Vanguard is probably Bethesda's best but the main storyline is one of their worst. It's not uncommon for their main quests to be kind of bad but the gap in quality has never been this wide. There are some great individual missions in the main storyline but the overall arc is just kind of eh. 

Ship building is fun, weapon customization is cool, outposts are cool, surveying planets is a great mindless activity. The cities are too big. New Atlantis is too big. Akila is way too big. Neon is okay in size.  Look, I'm not a proponent of bigger is better. Skyrim feels so big because its cities and towns are conservatively sized. They feel alive because TES cities are so dense with things to do and named people to talk to. If there is just a massive sprawl like Akila with randoms everywhere with nothing going on except being set dressing it feels dead in a roundabout way. 

Regardless, the dungeons are decent, the gameplay is fun, character progression is neat. Its just missing a capital "O" Open World... That Bethesda is known for.

It's also missing immersion. I've been saying that immersive loading screens would legit boost the public opinion of the game by like 20%. Instead of loading screens when you warp or take off, the game lets to maintain control over the camera, and plays mist/star warp effects around the ship when you take off, land, or warp. The game rips control away from you when you do these things and fast travel is 90% of the game so make it immersive. Let us chart courses with the star map in the captains cabin too. 

Uh good game. I like it. I want to play it again someday. Buy it for cheap, ignore the public opinion of it, look at subreddits and communities of people who like the game and it will be fun for you. I promise.

Emil needs to be demoted. Maybe not fired, its not like hes NEVER made a good side quest or something, but the man just isn't cut out to be the head honcho for an entire story, much less the lore behind that story. 

If the universe and story were intriguing, the lackluster gameplay and unending loading screens might be easier to look past. But they aren't, and often stop making sense as soon as you think about whatever plot point you've encountered for more than two seconds. As a result everything just feels pointless. 

Most resources were clearly intended for a more "survival"-esque experience, except that clearly got removed at somepoint so its all just worthless. Building bases to act as fueling stations, building living quarters on your ship, upgrading your warp drive or whatever to travel further distances... it just all means nothing when neither you nor your ship need any resources to function, you have more money than either of the main factions combined, and the only story beat to look forward to is finding another piece of scrap metal.

The ship builder is seriously cool though, easily spent most of my time just making the coolest looking ship I could. Just wish there was even a little more meat attached to that bone.

I'm a space science fiction nerd. When Bethesda announced this game, I was instantly sold. I love Elder Scrolls, having sunk thousands of hours in, and Fallout easily having over 10K hours in just 4 alone. I teeter between recommend and don't recommend. 

-The story isn't bad, I have my complaints and know people do too, but I think a lot of that is due to people having huge expectations. I can admit my early complaints were me just expecting a Skyrim caliber game. When I stood back and took it for what it was, it was the beginning of a story. Elder Scrolls started long ago, just as Fallout did, this is just new.

-I loved the Fallout 4 settlement building system, and was hoping for something similar.  It does have elements from it, but there is a lot to be desired. The ship building is the same way, after learning to use the frustrating ship builder it is fun coming up with all sorts of creations. I'm hoping in a future update they'll add more types of build-able ships.

- There's a lot to do, side quests, bounty hunter, faction quests. One of my main gripes though is how you can be cool with two opposing folks and nothing happen. I want consequences! New Vegas style factions. I miss the days of smarting off to the NPC and they just attack you.

- The cities are cool, but they're kinda bland. I understand the limitations for NPCs, but somehow Megaton felt more lively than Neon. I expected maybe 3-5 cities per "core" planet, one large and a few smaller. I am to believe the capital for the entire Freestar is in this run-down alamo looking city with like 40 folks?

- Space exploration is fun, but still feels like it is missing something. Going to a planet that is inhospitable has 30 different types of Outposts on it. Kind of takes away from the immersion I suppose. Didn't level up to build a base here just so some level 2 Raiders can shoot at my buildings for 2 hours. 

In the end, I love it for what it is, but mostly for what it could be still. I'd assume mods would have fixed a lot of these gripes, but it seems there's just hard limitations to what is allowable.
Despite all the criticisms I enjoy playing.

Want to love the game (I really do), and it's not about any of the gameplay that's making me give a negative review. Rather it's more about the seemingly lax attitude the Devs (or perhaps the management team), in just NOT bothering to update/fix the game. This latest update (April 25) is ALL about the "content club", NOTHING updated with the game. It's all about the people in charge wanting to see the Mod Community add ALL the content (while Bethesda eagerly scalp a commission for "allowing" the community to do their work for them). 

I'm usually pretty laid back on Bethesda games (I expect them to be buggy, yet strangely Starfield was probably THE best launch (bug wise) I've ever seen from the company over the past 25-30 years). But now I'm mad as hell, because the management team (pointing a finger at you Todd) just seemingly can't be bothered to bring the game up to date (and they are not even hiding it). 

Walk away from this one, it could have been great. It could have been the next Cyberpunk 2077 with the team bring the game back like a phoenix to raise up there with previous releases like Skyrim and see the game beloved by the players, Abandoned by the company, abandoned by the playerbase (due to the game not having the content needed, and seemingly it's not going to). It's all just........Grrrrrrrrrrrrr :(

Score: 3/4. A “best-of” Bethesda games collage - to a fault. Their assumed format works well enough for the boots on the ground settings of The Elder Scrolls or Fallout; however, less so regarding large-scale space exploration. Bethesda should have either scaled back the scope of this game or further iterate upon their standardised formular - leaving Starfield their biggest game world(s) yet, and most disjointed. If you’re a fan of Bethesda game’s and don’t mind their typical Bethesda’isms’ (or just have an inch for NASA-core RPG space exploration) - you’ll almost certainly find some enjoyment here; otherwise, probably give this one a miss :/

Don't pre-order games.

Do read negative reviews.

Don't rely on name recognition for a franchise or studio.

Do watch/read a handful of reviews from respected video game content creators (instead of randos like me).

Don't make the mistake I did - save your money and buy a different space-focused sci-fi game like:

No Man's Sky
Stellaris

Outer Worlds
Outer Wilds
Halo: MCC

Finally got to play this much debated game. Honestly, and I'll repeat myself after my reddit post with 1500 likes and 700 comments...I don't get the hate.
The game is your typical Bethesda game, with its quirks and perks but if you ask me, it was very immersive the whole time. Not necessarily because of RPG choices but just because of design, dialogues (voice acting), ability to build your own ship and walk IN it etc etc. Graphically very valid, the main quest really engaging and every substory with the various factions is also very well made.
Flying is fun enough, combat is simple. 
Of course as everybody knows there is no manual landing or taking off, but the "cutscenes" with the ship animations are very nice and never the same. Loading screens? Never lasted more than 2 or 3 seconds.
You don't want to fly? Fine, you can fast travel pretty much wherever you want. You like roleplaying? Then walk everywhere, get on your ship and walk to your cockpit...anything is possible.
I see the DLC is considered even much worse than the game...but I think I will get it once it drops in price.

All in all, to do pretty much everything (I didn't do every single random quest as I did in Fallout 4 and Skyrim but I did all main sidequests a many secondary random quests) I needed around 80 hours.
Long waited, fast played, fast forgot, lost opportunity

It was just OK, to be honest I expected more.  All the potential was there to becoming a game one would play over & over, 1000+ hours, like Skyrim or Mass Effect, but they just didn't pull it together.  My biggest lack of buy-in was the script writing, it had no personality, with weirdly bland & awkward companion relationships and a really feeble attempt at choice based dialog it all just fell flat and dissatisfying.  The only rewarding feeling (albeit small) was when people recognized The Mantis. Running through vast boring worlds and the same scene over and over got old, once the enjoyment of sniping people wore off.  Some aspects of graphics were well done.  One thing I hadn't expected to care much about but ended up salivating over was the ship building and space dog fighting, it got techie and seriously competitive.  I also enjoyed having to work a bit at mastering all the secret ins-and-outs of things such as contraband etc, that aspect had a gratifying feeling of hard work paying off.  But without the immersive cohesive feeling of connecting to the game and its characters, and the choices I make reflecting back at me, it ended up being just "meh".  4/10 stars.
Endless side-quests, fun crafting and interesting story line.

I love the game, and after 4 runs I'm still not done with it :) I pick one faction per run for RP, did some NG+ runs, but found that it does not resonate with me. Tried some achievement-friendly creations and found a few that improve my perception of the game without messing with the mechanics.

However, this comes with a disclaimer – discovering the game mechanics, some of which are poorly explained or not explained at all, was and still is a big part of what makes Starfield interesting to me. With that in mind, I strongly recommend any newcomer to not cheese the game and opt out of any "best way to do X" guides at least at the beginning. As with any Bethesda game, it is beatable without the need to be perfect and/or min-max. Trivializing the game is almost guaranteed to make it extremely boring. It's an exploration game after all – don't let someone else do the exploration for you.

Also – and this is pretty opinionated – ignore all the "you should rush NG+ X" advice (where X is any number above 2, usually 10) until you discover for yourself what it is and what it brings: the role-playing dilemma, consequences, and so on. The NG+ rush itself is absolutely boring and will likely turn you off the game if that's your first experience with it.

And last – a note on the complaints about constant loading screens: IMO this is mostly when you cheese the game. If one plays intentionally puristic, this is way less pronounced than it's made out to be.
Not worth it.

It's extremely rare that I would put over 200 hours into a game then give it a bad rating... At the start I sort of enjoyed it, did some exploring, built a base, built a ship then lost it all to start a NG+.  Decided to go for max powers which led to many more NG+ to the point of speed running them.  After clearing temples for the 100th time the joy was entirely gone.  There are a couple 'rare' universes you can stumble into after many NG+ which is cool in concept but really doesn't change enough to add any real excitement.

Overall my opinion is that they came up with some solid foundational ideas but utterly failed in execution.  Creating a massive universe wound up with endless soulless planets with copy/paste buildings and events.  Literally you can land on any planet and you will see the same things as any other.

Only slightly less disappointing than Fallout 76 which may be alright after the years but lost my interest after the lifeless no-npc launch.

Really hoping that companies eventually realize that massive scale or random online interaction does nothing to improve upon their games.  Can we just get back to focusing on solid game-play and a good story with interesting characters?

Starfield launches you into a massive universe filled with potential, but there are some some rough edges. The sheer scale of the game is impressive with an undeniable sense of wonder jumping through star systems and landing on new worlds. However, this expansiveness comes at the cost of frequently repeated POI's and loading screens.

At its best when you're off the beaten path, diving into faction quests, random encounters, and side missions that often outshine the central narrative.

This game has has it's ups and downs but I keep coming back. The side quest are the bread and butter. If your a fan of Bethesda games then you should give it a chance. I didn't really appreciate the game until I started developing a game myself. The amount of detail in level design and voice acting alone is staggering.
If you like open world games, then this game is great. It does require a lot of graphic power to play, but overall a very fun game to play if you like any of the Bethesda RPG games.

I wanted to love this game when i bought it. It was exciting at first. A new IP from Bethesda, the maker of some of my favorite games. It seemed like it had the bones to be the next one to hold that title. I ignored the haters for the first 30 or so hours (thought they were crazy, even). The graphics are great, the action is fluid, and the ship-building is easily the most engaging system I've ever seen. 

Then it sets in. The story is paint-by-numbers. You can choose from about 4 different paths, but they all go to the same place. The player character build and progression doesn't feel rewarding. The special abilities are useless and can be ignored entirely. The research system is a slog but failing to invest in it completely locks you out of gear customization. The combat quickly becomes monotonous, especially the space combat, which is a tremendous shame (considering how great the ship-building mechanic is). Building outposts is somehow less rewarding than the same activity in vanilla Fallout 4. But perhaps the most damning thing is the feature that Bethesda touted the most - the universe they created. 

The best part of my favorite Bethesda games is exploring the world they dropped me in. Discovering things. Joining those who inhabit it and feeling like you are truly a part of it. Starfield has none of that. The world is lifeless. I've never met characters I cared less about. Some of the intentionally-designed settlements are interesting enough, but those are few and far between. Most of the places you will visit feel like they were cut-and-pasted from the same CAD file. Even if the planets aren't barren, they feel as though they may as well be (although many of them ARE, in fact, barren and devoid of anything worth investigating). The encounters are formulaic. Exploration becomes a chore. I've never had less of an issue avoiding side quests. Stepping through Unity to start it all over again feels more like penance than a reward. 

Some people will undoubtedly find some fun here, as I certainly did at times, but I expect most will come to the same conclusion I did - this game is a giant missed opportunity. I'll keep some hope for a Cyberpunk 2.0-esque overhaul, or for the modding community to embrace it and inject some much-needed passion into it, but short of that, it is doomed. I cannot recommend it.

Starfield – A Flawed Masterpiece That I Absolutely Love

Starfield is, without a doubt, an absolute masterpiece in my eyes. From the moment I started playing, I was hooked by the atmosphere, the scale, and the sheer ambition of this game. It’s not just a space RPG – it’s a journey through a universe that feels alive, mysterious, and filled with wonder.

Pros:
	•	Incredible world-building: Every planet, space station, and city has its own unique vibe. Bethesda did an amazing job crafting a believable universe.
	•	Freedom of exploration: You can go anywhere, do anything, and play the game your way. Whether you’re a space pirate, explorer, or diplomat, there’s room for all playstyles.
	•	Immersive storytelling: The main story and side quests are engaging, with deep lore and well-written characters.
	•	Customization: From your ship to your gear to your character, the level of customization is fantastic.

Cons:
	•	Bugs and glitches: Yes, there are quite a few, and some can be frustrating. But they never took away from the overall experience for me.
	•	Loading screens: There are a lot of them, especially between planets or locations, which can break immersion at times.

Despite the technical issues, I genuinely believe Starfield is a game that will be remembered for years. It’s not perfect – far from it – but the heart, soul, and vision behind it shine through. I can’t stop playing it, and I’m already excited for what modders and future updates will bring.

Starfield is a flawed gem – and I absolutely love it.
Love this sci-fi Expanse like game, even though it has shortcomings. I have faith Bethesda can transform it to glory just like Fallout 4

This was the most boring Bethesda game I've ever had the displeasure of playing. Starfield features one thousand procedurally generated planets, but unfortunately, they offer very little. Most of the time, there's not much to do on these planets except for a lot of walking, although there is a rover to help speed up exploration. I encountered the same man-made outpost multiple times on the same planet, and the caves often had similar layouts, varying only by the creatures inside. 

While space combat is enjoyable and there are some cool weapons to use, the game is bogged down by too many tedious fetch quests. I'm looking for stories that draw me in emotionally, with well-developed characters and genuine opportunities for role-playing. One day soon, I plan to give it another chance and try the Shattered Space DLC, since it features a handcrafted world rather than the frustrating procedurally generated environments. I'm also looking forward for more information on Starborn DLC.

There's several things in game that are cool the first time you see them, then after you see them the 20th time, they're much less cool. 

The problem is that you'll see everything over and over again, because this is "Recycled Content - The Game", and getting anywhere requires just regrinding the same thing.

The storyline content is solid and in spite of weird choices, like meeting a guy who just randomly gives you a ship as the first step in the game, I did enjoy playing through it. Outside of the main storyline is where you have to get your XP and that's where it falls apart. 

In skyrim at least you could wander around and discover unique locations. In starfield you land on a planet with a slightly different color palette or texture palette, with tweaked gravity, and then go find bleak falls barrow over and over again. That's how it feels for exploration, bounty hunting, POI hunting and all of the other "repeatable" content. 

It's not repeatable content. It's repeated content. 

I got my money's worth but it left a bitter taste in my mouth. So much wasted potential.

I'm sorry Bethesda but you should be ashamed of yourself. It's May 2025 and the first character to appear when starting a new game had his head on sideways. This is the 5th and final time I've attempted to resolve the performance issues I have with this game. It's just the game itself. This is unacceptable from a AAA game studio and I am so disappointed.

A quiet triumph for players who like to live [i]in[/i] a world, not just sprint through it.

If you’re the kind of person who gets more satisfaction from building a moon base than chasing quest markers, Starfield will quietly sink its hooks into you.

Yes, the fast travel is an ode to loading screens. Yes, the game opens slowly. But beneath those surface complaints lies an immersive sim wrapped in a space exploration RPG — a game that rewards patience, curiosity, and a desire to carve out your own narrative.

This isn't a cinematic thrill ride; it's a system-driven experience where your choices, builds, and ambitions shape your own enjoyment. Whether you're designing outposts, tuning your ship, exploring skill trees, or getting lost in a derelict station — the game is strongest when you live in it, not just play through it. And for those parts that feel underbaked — clunky menus, UI friction, balance quirks — the modding community has stepped in with meaningful improvements, giving the game the long tail it was clearly built for.

The game doesn’t hold your hand. It doesn’t dazzle on command. But it lasts. You very much get out of it what you're willing to put in.

It has the potential to be a very good game. It has good bones. The problem is that it feels like just that. bones. Starfield is a skeleton of what it [strike] could [/strike] should have been.

 It feels empty and lacks good writing, soul, and interesting quests. The perversion of randomly generated quests absolutely killed this game for me. I have played every quest and had to go check a quest list to see if I had done it all and that realization came around hour 100. As someone who came from ES and Fallout and put thousands of hours in and not even done all the quests in those games I found that thought extremely disheartening. I even decided to go through their "New game plus experience" and that was so lackluster I almost quit then and there. The fact that to get the powers you have to do the same thing every time had me questioning who made this game to begin with. 

All That being said you can see I have put the hours in to really give a Bethesda game what it deserved and here is something that I believe was done decently

- [b]Ship building[/b] probably a good chunk close to half of my game time has been spent in this mode. I loved it and had so much fun making different ships. 

My Nitpicks on ship building
- Unfortunately due to NG+ you lose all your ships and designs every time. If there was a way to save your designs or upload them to the creation club or steam workshop then I wouldn't have to spend so much time rebuilding my design every time. 
- Door placement. not letting players choose where doors appear is the most backwards thing and makes me irrationally angry
-Only allowed to have a certain number of ships
- there is only ONE ship in the game that has a perk?? any of the factions could have had unique ship perks 



All in all unfortunately at the time of this review the content is just not there. I think they believed the community would hop on this like rats to a raft in the middle of the ocean but they didn't. There are mods out there but they just are not gaining much traction. If you read this (I doubt anyone will(Mostly just for me to rant about a game I wished could have been more)) and are looking to buy the game I would wait for the DLCs to come out as hopefully a miracle will occur and the game will get better. Your best bet is waiting for Elder scrolls 6.

Starfield may not be the best game to ever be made, some people i am sure were disappointed. But i for one love this game, i call it "spacerim." it has some really good missions, some really good questlines, it has fun gameplay, and the space stuff is entertaining to me. I enjoy every aspect of this game, and its sad to see how many people dislike it. I would suggest giving the game a try!

The game is just fun. Maybe it's the setting, but I am enjoying it at least as much as I did TES series, which I have played since Daggerfall. A bit part of the added enjoyment is the more personable companions, even if they don't match the depth and interest of Mass Effect (Bethesda, take note!). Something that would make the characters more alive would be to tie their affinity to certain quests and game events to pace out the relationships throughout the game rather than blasting through all their material right away. This would also encourage taking along different companions for different quests. 

Gameplay is a lot of fun. The quests and the story (so far) are engaging. Ship building is a lot of fun. The big criticism that the maps get repetitive and feel like reused is valid. At least the main quest maps and faction quest maps need to have more variety. In the future, the rest can be procedurally generated pretty effectively, I imagine. Procedurals have come a long way since Daggerfall's endless towns of identical houses.

Also, if they would have tied outpost building to the main quest (something like Mass Effect 3's galaxy map), that would give it more purpose rather than just a sandbox "thing to do." But I am just scratching the surface of outpost building at this point.

I'd give this a 6 out of 10 (the high water mark for this sort of game being DA:O and ME2).
i like the fact it brought a childhood dream of being a space pirate to life
I didn't think it would be possible but they actually made the game progressively worse with every patch. Bethesda will never see a dime from me ever again.

I give this a recommended rating, BUT I must say, that in order for this game to finally be something more than a 6/10, it just has to improve at least following aspects to be engaging and simply FUN:
- introduce SPACE ALIENS i.e. sentient aliens, that resemble humans in about the same ratio as aliens in Mass Effect. A game about space exploration where there are only humans and no other intelligent life is just so vanilla and self-centered on humanity, what becomes simply boring after a while.
- majority of the randomly generated maps/sectors on planets need to be made more interesting/varied and there should not be 5 minutes of running just to get to another mundane empty landmark which is just a stock asset and gives us nothing besides meaningless amount of "finder's EXP".
- too many loading screens in a game where you have to traverse many locations to get to the quest objective is really cumbersome...
- loot system has huge amount of Skyrim DNA in it... it already has been done to the death before, so loot could be make more interesting - we need more effects/attachments/functionalities added to the guns. Don't make guns be like a pew-pew space wazer wifles, but interesting Sci-Fi guns which could bring so novelty.
- many other obvious things others have pointed out.

In general I can leave this a recommended rating, but only as a sign/incentive for Bethseda to make Starfield not "just work", but finally work as a whole concept along with game mechanics being well thought-out.

In current state - if nothing particularly interesting gets introduced into the game and at least some of its annoyances are not eliminated, this might be that Bethesda game which may eventually fall into obscurity.

Bethesda - fix and expand this game. 
It's not a trainwreck like F76 on its release day, but it needs a lot of meat to be added to the bones - and the sooner the better.

Just yes. Don't expect a Bethesda version of No Man's Sky, don't expect an extreme story line. It's an RPG, not a story-based game, and not a simulator; you're not the main character of the universe, just the main character of your save file, which lends to a more unique experience to me. Starfield is cinematic as hell, so many interesting side quests, neat NPC interactions, and as usual with Bethesda games there is SO much replayability. It's not perfect, and a lot of people had too many expectations before launch, but honestly its just fun to explore. My biggest gripe is with the ~ console commands, as using any commands turns off achievements, which while it isn't a big issue it is still a pain in a Bethesda game which is as buggy as all their other RPGs. That said, I'm content that I paid regular price, but I wouldn't say it's worth the premium price. For me it's at least in line with No Man's Sky, way better in some ways and considerably worse in others, so if you like NMS but want something fresh then give it a try. I like it

In my opinion, this is a good game!

The main story arc is shorter than expected, but it introduces you to the world and some of it's secrets well. It's not that epic, galaxy saving, dragonborn type of story yet, but it surely feels like it is leading up to something like that, so it has a lot of potential going forward. Playing faction quests is pretty much necessary if you wish to get that full Bethesda experience. I'm only at 91 hours so far into the game, but I already had enough fun with it to know that I got my money's worth.

Ship building is a ton of fun! That mechanic alone is already worth playing the game for.

I got a lot of Wing Commander: Privateer vibes from this game. Starfield's space based missions could use some improvement though, like more variety, more complex scripts.

Overall, it is a good game with a bold and exciting vision. However, it feels unpolished, especially the inventory management, which is clunky and can be rectified through mods that should not be necessary. It seems like the developers lost focus by adding too many features like outpost building alongside buying flats and ship building, which do not quite fit together smoothly.

It is a shame they have not continued to refine the game without charging for more expansions. I am not even sure if it is still being supported. There is a lot of potential here that feels missed. Still, I really enjoy playing it especially the feel of the weapons and the zero-gravity sections, which remind me of The Expanse or Star Trek.

Despite the gripes, I've so far enjoyed my time with the game.   While there are things that could be done better, it falls in line with other titles in the general genre.  Doing a large open world space game has always had struggles with emptiness, but this game does better than most.  Perfect, no.  Worth playing, yes.  8/10.

I really wanted to like Starfield. i wanted Fallout 4 in space. Not the nuclear fallout part of the game...but the replay-ability that F4 offered me. I've played so much of it, restarted it, modded it....Along with NV and 3 this gave me hope that after all the boasting and bragging about how great this game was going to be (over-hype is usually like cake = A lie) with advancements in gaming and engines....i just expected something good.

I was wrong. My game crashed in the first 3 minutes. I rebooted it and after waiting through the egregious unskippable first part again....crashed again. Turns out it was a simple V-sync issue. Fixed that and the game continued. I kept waiting for the game to take off, so to speak. Every planet virtually empty, save the necessary building that you were supposed to go to via your objective.  Exploration, it's there. Explore for hours...but there's nothing except and alien animal or three and that's it. Memorable characters? No. I found my inventory bogged down with all kinds of curious items, none of which I could sell to increase my wallet balance very much. It was like an episode of pawn stars. In your inventory, this item is worth 300 credits, but at a shop, "best I can do is 7 credits". Not to mention, not really that much to spend your credits on. 

Menus, empty space, pointless dialog....i couldn't wait for the game to end. Once I got to the end and beat the game...disappointment. I won't spoil the ending for anyone, but it made 76 seem worth playing. I uninstalled it after finishing and I've had no desire to reinstall it, much less play it again.

I understand a lot of the critisism that has been uttered against Starfield. It's clear from the remains of certain mechanics that this game has undergone a bunch of redirections before settling on what is currently the game before you.

The original vision seemingly had way more intense diseases and afflictions, a fuel system and more a involved food system. (there is so much food in the game you guys, you have no idea)
The planets actually rotate around their stars and most of the technology is so grounded that it feels believable. The Nasapunk fibe is so intense that you spend more than half your time in sterile off-white space interiors it's honestly impressive.
The allien life you find grows like they are in Jurrasic park, while around you the ambient storm sounds so real you are there.

It's clear that at some point Bethesda's playtesters saw their space-hero coming back from a firefight in a hostile environment, riddled with bullet- and burn-wounds, radiation poisoning and multiple infections. Their health more than cut in half. The medicine in their inventory only improved their situation a little bit, and sleeping did not cure them at all. They had to either be in safe environment for a while, or find a doctor. So they went to the cockpit on  their ship only to realise that they were out of fuel and stranded in space. The playtester would ask...is this fun for most people?

No, probably not, but it absolutely is for me! So I crank up all the survival mechanics to the max and I mod in even more! I want to be scared of leaving a safe planet, I want to hear my character coughing and groaning in pain while I struggle to survive in the harshest conditions. Only to relax after I hear the sound of a pressurised door close.

This is far from a perfect game. But I believe, if you're a gamer that likes to play it slow, enjoys roleplaying with their own gameplay rules and don't mind the existance of payed mods, this game has a lot for you.

Starfield is a Bethesda game that dares to ask: "What if we made the most Bethesda game of any Bethesda game?"

It's all dialog and no choice. The two main factions are obviously horrible, but in a way that I'm not convinced that the writers actually know that they're horrible. The combat is either impossible or too easy. Sometimes NPCs fall through the floor and you can't finish quests. All NPCs are inexplicably hostile to the player in a way that is supposed to be funny (I think) but end up just being grating. It's a Bethesda game through-and-through.

The ship builder is fun though.

Despite the time I have with the game, 289 hours. 
- It's riddled with bugs, typical of Bethesda - e.g. i lost 2 hours of progress because of a bug that caused quicksave, inventory, tab menu and scanner to not work. REV getting stuck under my ship, on some rocks and one is that some dialogue choices get bugged out forcing to end the conversation when re-choosing back.

But all those bugs, I don't mind them that much. What's worse is the;
-THE PC(Politically Correct) language, the allied NPCs are all sooooo damn self-righteously annoying.
-You can't play a sarcastic, intimidating pirate as crimson fleet since they all treat you as a starry eyed rookie.
-Vanguard/MAST treats you like you didn't exist after everything. 
-Ryuuji Industries doesn't lead to anything more after, can't even call it a faction.
-Tracker only has 1 quest - the rest you have to pay real money aside from the game or DLC. 
-Freedom cowboy group has you singlehandedly storm a mercenary base yet they treat you like the a beginner.
-Varu'un DLC is pointless no matter which ending you choose, map is just uselessly large. 
-So many "girl-bosses" stereotype that every NPC in position that's female, is too haughty-arrogant, elitist, scheming, angry and prideful. 
-The "men", even if they are decorated or have a backstory of the toughest life, looks unconvincing. They look like salarymen/ average office worker. Not intimidating, only elitist behavior same with the girl boss archetype. 
-NPCs are ugly af, they're fat and weak looking. 
-Seriously, the Astral Lounge, that's the best Bethesda came up with? It's Neon, the dirty, hardcore city yet Astral Lounge looks like a gender studies students hangout place. The alien costume is silly af. One look at Cyberpunk 2077's clubs or bars, the difference is staggeringly obvious.

Explorations:
-Planets are still as empty
-Boring and repetitive
-Walking simulator
-REV is useless in a rocky planet (which most of them are), even a bush can stop it in the tracks

Combat:
-It's good, typical Bethesda combat but enemies just become sponge at higher levels. 

Space Combat:
-Strong ship can destroy everything, skills do not matter as there is no skill curve. 
-It's repetitive, random encounters, radiant quests on mission boards

Bethesda is compromised by woke political activism

What i like:

-When doing a NG+ i lose all my inventory eventhough i put them in the "captains locker" the ship only upgrades in terms of stats why do i lose my stuff???

- the story is still incomplete in terms of "starborn" 

- when facing the endgame and everyone want to come with me when i have the artifacts etc why do i only see myself and not the rest of the crew who wants to "gravdrive jump" with me in the final sequence?

I invited everybody and only see myself, not cool.

-there is no way to play "football" on the moon with your companion. I would love to play some sort of minigame on certain locations. Or play catch with edmond the desktoy just for fun.

-when having a marriage how can you share a single small stretcher with your husband/wife. There should be an option wich says that its a tight fit and you are not well rested etc. If i spoon with my wife on a 1 person bed i'm not well rested unless i kick her out of the bed and she sleeps on the ground :-).

- if married and doing an NG+ I want to have a chance to see my wife and that is not available at the moment eventhough i grind the game numerous times.
 
There should be an option to jump both partners to the same universe and continue their marriage.

- when visiting temples i want to see Vaasco (companion) also entering it and be flying like ED209 of robocop and making sounds like i'm falling etc. Those little humour stuff isn't there 

- you can not see that you pilot the ship like your hands on a joystick/steeringwheel etc. I mean i get an Tesla/SpaceX autopilot feeling out of it.

- i want to have a "minigame" in it in which i dock my ship on the eye etc instead of a cutscene. I want to center align it and connect the clamps that connect me to the station. How can i be a captain if i can't do it myself? And Sarah compliments me on a safe landing but how? I only see a cutscene. I want to land my bird on the ground and not some spaceX autopilot.

Those little things are annoying. So Bethesda, if you read this, please implements those little things.

Stupid idea:

In the end you can hear your voice why not give us a karaoke machine on board of a spaceship or in the eye and make us sing with vladimir some pirate songs like you can do in the Yakuza games. That would be hilarious IMHO.

Even though with all of the above i still give the game a big 2 thumbs up.

[h1] Such Potential... What A Shame [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Awesome Ship Customization 
+ Carried Over Fallout Weapon/Armor Customization Mechanics
+ Pretty Cool Companions 

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Bland Main Story
- Copy & Paste Moons & Planets (Outside Of Main City's) 
- The Bethesda Classic Bug Experience

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
[i] You had left your past life to become a miner for a mineral extraction company but fate has other plans for you. Due to unforeseen events you must now go out into the universe and solve a interstellar mystery! [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]
[i] Is it bad I had to force myself to play this game for more then 3 hours to actually get into it? Literally the first 3 hours was me playing an hour and getting bored and not touching the game again for a few days eventually forcing myself to pick it back up. After the 3 hour mark however I did start to find myself enjoying the game taking an interest in the companions and the factions which take up literally 80% of my gameplay time.  The storylines for the factions are decent (not great) but decent. My companions have there own personalities and all of them like to give you random crap almost after every outing you take them on which is something. The main story however is very boring to me and really didn't peak my interest and what interest I did have I lost after [spoiler] I gained dragonborn abilities half way through it. [/spoiler]  When I was getting bored with the game and had did everything besides the main story I begrudgingly finally did which took me on this A to B goose chase where I [spoiler] killed a bunch of teleporting douche bags that killed one of only few companions I actually liked only to find out that the evil factions main guy who killed my favorite companion was a f u c k i n g alternate universe version of my dead companion. [/spoiler] At that point I was checked out [spoiler] and killed everyone quickly and effortlessly and walked into my own alternate universe [/spoiler] and checked out of the game entirely after that. What could have been one of the best space RPG games out there was sadly rushed out before it was finished cooking.  You travel anywhere outside of the main cities in the game and what you'll find is a lot of different planets with some generic dog like creatures and some reused generic colony little habitat farmer outposts and maybe an abandon facility pirates took over. Some of the missions that you can play are bugged which if your like taking care of your side work like me will piss you off when you go and collect payments from a dead beat and because you didn't do it right away the guy just randomly dies and you can't collect from him because the loot didn't spawn on his body so your stuck with that quest in your mission board unless you do some command prompt bull s h i t which will disable your achievements by the way or install m o d s. By the way good luck beating this game without the use of at least some kind of mod because there are so many vanilla bugs you will trap yourself or break the game in some way where you will have to use patchwork mods to progress in this abandoned game the developers tossed aside when it didn't meet it's first quarterly projections. They made a DLC but they didn't listen to feed back and from what I hear it's worse then the base game so I ain't touching that trash. There is outpost building where you can build your own outpost and harvest resources on certain worlds but to be honest the only building that's worth building is in your own ship. There'll be a point where you'll make more credits then you'll ever spend. It's not a bad game but it lacks in major storytelling area's and world design for it be a proper hit. There new game + mechanic while interesting isn't enough to bring me back for round two. Let's not even get started on the hardware you need to run to keep this beast of a game from turning your computer into a toaster.  The lockpicking as well sucks I don't like it which isn't a surprise there really hasn't been a good lockpicking mechanic I have liked this one is just bizarre. Also the persuasion and charisma check mini-game they have you do sucks with you sometimes speaking none sense to persuade people. [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
[i] 70 dollars for this game is laughable at it's best it's worth 20 - 25 but nowhere near 70 dollars. It's got some good faction and side missions but this ain't a game you wanna play for the main story that's for sure. [/i]

I'm not one to typically leave reviews in general, especially for games. The only reasons I will leave a review is if I had an outstanding time and will partake again, or if the experience was so god awful that I wouldn't even recommend Satan himself to experience it. So you must be asking yourselves "where does Starfield end up?", the answer is somewhere in between.

What I mean by that is this, the game has its moments of humor, its quirks, its cool aspects and features, and a cool idea behind it. However, what it lacks is.........personality, emotion, something that makes it stand out, and something that in 10 years will make players think "I remember Starfield. I loved it and I hope they either remaster it sometime or they make a sequel." There are so many opportunities for this game to stand out against other games and for it to have a dedicated player base, and yeah it might create a cult following like so many other games have, but that's all it will probably achieve. 

I really wanted to enjoy this, I truly did, but it fell extremely short and extremely flat for me. I hope that in the years to come, a cult following is started and that there will be at least a few people out there that will remember this game with good memories, but I will not be one of those people.

On release, I dropped an easy 94 hours into this game and figured it was...okay.

Like everyone else I was a fan of the new worlds and a hater of the repetition and loading screens, but it was still fun and solid. Until I became a starborn.
There was no consequences, why would I care if John Character dies if I can simply hop into the next universe and he's wide awake smiling like a pig in crap?
It got very, very boring after my first 'Unity' and a few minutes into the second when I realized the biggest reward you get from doing it multiple times is (no joke) another ribbon or pad on your tacky looking starborn suit? I bounced.

Flash forward to May 2025, after being off the game for actual eons, I found a fun video explaining how Starfield in 2025 is good! Hooray! full mod support, lots of updates, surely this will be better.

It was worse, I can't speak for everyone in possession of a NASA supercomputer that will probably vent Earth's atmosphere into space (ehh see what I did there?). But for me personally, the same rig that ran this game just fine on release and has received a few upgrades internally since then, BSOD'd upon trying to boot it vanilla. I finally got it running enough to mod it, thinking the QOL mods and good stuff the world has put into SF would be sufficient...It was not, my PC was brought to it's knees like it stole a chip in the Mojave desert and BSOD'd even more commonly.

I am aware this may be my problem and "Muh nvidia 69420 poopfart card" and all that, but there's no reason in my mind that the same game, on the same rig, should suddenly go to garbanzo beans over a few mods and "updates"

It IS fun if you can get it running without looking like a mess and destroying your frames/crashing you to BIOS, but as it stands, I cannot say it's any good.

you've been making games for like 30 years Bethesda, learn to make a story line for gods sake. fallout 4 was pretty terrible but this games story really shit the bed. The ships and ship combat were great, the custom guns were good and the idea behind base building was good, but it was buggy complicated and broke the game financially when you used outposts well enough. carbon copy enemy bases and almost entirely empty planets yawn. pretty obviously should have added a ground vehicle from day 1 not months or a year later not that it would have changed the enjoyment on the empty copy pasted planets. the space combat aside this game has the depth and storyline of a much worse and cheaper indie game with like 3 devs not an entire game studio behind it.

I played Fallout 4 for over 100 hours, Skyrim for over 100 hours and spent some hours in FNV and Fallout online. So I have the background to say Starfield is a lot like Fallout in space with graphic enhancement. 
If you want to buy this game, do not buy at full price. But if there is discount on the game, then it is a good game to buy. I can give it a 7 or 8 out of 10.

It's simple; play the game and see for yourself. Don't let others make up your mind for you.

Yes, there are weeds in the garden, what garden doesn't, and you'll find stuff that may grate on you. BUT there is a much more good to great stuff.

[h1]I uninstalled Starfield twice—only to reinstall it and get completely pulled back in.[/h1]

Here’s how I think you can best enjoy the game:

[h1]1. Install StarUI.[/h1]
It’s a simple mod that improves the interface. Just drop the files in the right folder—done.

[h1]2. Treat it like a meditation.[/h1]
If you're after constant action, this isn't the game. But it’s perfect for when you want to fully engage with something. Too interesting to have a podcast or netflix in the back, too chill to get your addrenalin up like CoD / Warzone etc.

Id say: It’s chill, but immersive.

[h1]3. Stick to normal difficulty.[/h1]
The scaling is poor—harder settings just make enemies tanky and drawn-out. It’s single-player and story-focused, so crank it to normal and enjoy the ride.

[h1]4. Get into the story.[/h1]
Bethesda does narrative and world-building better than most. Even side quests and random notes can be surprisingly touching. A lot of small moments hit hard, even if they don’t show up as major quests. Generally, among the many dialouge options, it feels like there is a "human" option. Meaning that usually if you pay a bit of attention and just dont act rude most dialouge develop very logical and beneficial for you. The goal is to avoid shootouts and instead get everything for free. There will be plenty of opportunities to kill enemies.

[h1]5. Use fast travel.[/h1]
Yes, there are a lot of loading screens—but that’s true for every Bethesda game. Accept it, and the experience flows much better.

[h1]6. Build your ship, not your base.[/h1]
Base-building is deep but complicated. Early on, focus on upgrading your ship with storage and workbenches. Bases are mostly for farming and aesthetics and can be frustrating at the start.

Starfield has plenty of flaws, and much of the criticism is valid. But unlike No Man’s Sky or Elite Dangerous, this feels like a more grounded, adult sci-fi game. If you come for the story and the beautifully crafted universe, you’ll find something special. The graphics and design are excellent—and the fact that this whole world exists just for you on your PC makes it feel oddly personal.

Just my character his wife and their robot friend exploring the universe while doing science and defense contract work. Starfield is a good game overall with some rough edges that need polish but it’s a solid new entry point that I hope to see expanded on.

The overall theme of the game is exploration and I believe they did a good job keeping to that for the most part. There are a ton of hidden quests and random events that occur, some of which gleam a murky light on the world and lore of Starfield. It’s where the real grit of the journey can be found. There are occasional hard science, physics, and philosophical intrigue throughout the game to appease those nerdy interests, myself included here.

The storyline (no spoilers) sets up nicely for each new play-through being entirely different which is pretty cool overall.

I highly recommend the shattered space DLC as it adds a traditional planet map to explore on foot, the companions have some fairly extensive conversational stuff to chime in on, and the story arc is interesting and left me wondering where it was going. Plus I didn’t spot a single repeat voice actor which helps with the immersion.

The mod community has added a plethora of cool mods to help tweak your gameplay. I paired the built in combat difficulty sliders with dynamic universe for level scaling. As I grew in firearms power I adjusted the settings over time while including the advanced settings for the injury and survival systems. By level 100, I had player damage set to very easy with enemy damage set to very hard.. this translated to about 3-4 shots to kill an enemy with a pistol or 1-2 shots with a sniper rifle with melee enemies capable of killing me in 1-3 hits or 3-6 hits with ranged. Say goodbye to bullet sponge! Additionally bringing a companion + cover was necessary to help with large groups of foes.

-Anything from mod creator: ZoNE79
-Desolation
-Forgotten Frontiers
-Dark Universe: Takeover
-Dungeon Randomized
-Autoswap suit/helmet
-Dynamic Universe
-Royal Weather (lite)
-Realistic Ragdoll and Force + Corpse Collision


If you are like me and set environmental hazards to advanced difficulty, I recommend Shade’s Vehicle Tuner. There is an option to allow your vehicle to refill your suits environmental protection.. this is essential for mobile exploration of some planets.

A couple criticisms/needs some revision:

1- Occasionally there is zero immersive animations. The npc might say “let me check my computer” or “let me transfer payment” they just stare at you. No moving around the office to type up something on their computer, nor pulling out a data pad, nor looking busy at all. This really stands out in this day and age especially in comparison to other big studio single player games.

2- Ship customization needs a feature to tell you where doors are located on the habs and you need an option to prevent ladders from spawning. Nobody wants a maze for the interior of their ship. I lost a good 20+ hours trying to figure out this mechanic as some of the placements seem entirely random.

3- Whoever thought of the resource micro management “game” for outposts should be sacked like straight out of a monty python skit. It’s cumbersome, time consuming and poorly optimized at best. Resource generators are on a timer that exports resources to storage that is always too small. THEN you have to move them to your desired outpost and if it is out of the galaxy, GOOD LUCK balancing fuel demand. I don’t want to play some resource management sim. If I did, I’d go play one that is specifically designed around that. I just want a base where I can craft my team’s gear, ship parts, pick up missions, consumables, and research. This whole thing could have been simplified down to something like this: Project A requires Iron, does any of your collective outposts have access to Iron? Yes, cool and done. Project B requires 4 different resources, do you have access to those resources? No, okay get to exploring and build some mines/harvesters. It should be like an umbrella. It’s find to connect links but I shouldn’t have to spend hours of real life trying to move resources planet to planet. Of all the things to hand wave in the scheme of playability, this should have been one of them.

4- This is minor but mentionable; all the outpost habs are empty.. so you have to spend time setting them up. I wish they came furnished (like ships) or partially furnished to fill out on your own to save time.


All in all, I dig Bethesdas newest IP. It’s got some familiar along with some new. The mission statement was something like 10 years of support and growth for the game. This guy is curious to see where that goes and what that means to them but I’m fairly sure I won’t be disappointed.

This game is fun. Beware if you buy this though, if you expect a wild roller-coaster of a game, this is not the game for you. You will find yourself lost in a vast universe, wandering, taking sights, or doing a very menial task you prefer over the main quest.

If you ignore what is not trying to do, the game does has its flaws. Nothing that would not be fixed by mods. Really it would be just great to have steam mods. I wonder why there are no steam mods. It is almost as if they did not want steam mods so they could have the Creation Club. Surely not, that would be like adding a bug by design. Look--I understand the strategy, I am a ruthless capitalist too, but maybe I'd do the shameless cash crab on a well loved franchise when the players are ripe for harvest then wait for them to be ready again. Or maybe I'd tolerate steam mods because I'd be offering a good service or maybe I'd also do the strategy of 'You want to go somewhere else? Be my guest, I just demolished where my competitors used to live in.' Is it still a good review despite the lack of steam mods? Yes it is, because the game is still fun without them. I will rant about it because it makes a good game objectively worse. The game has tons of mechanics and free space, ready for modders to latch on. It could have taken the smart route and make modding a part of that game mechanics but instead chose to make it a part of its monetization. It did that while being utterly oblivious of its potential, instead choosing to slap an old formula that did not take well on the other games, expecting that it would work here. It's just pitiful--seeing the devs pump out Creations to keep the service alive--because you know fully well that if the modders come flocking in, they will be the next ones to be harvested like cattle because that's what every other service does these days. First you give something good to get users, then you invite other to milk the users with you at the cost of service quality, and then you milk everyone because the whole point was total domination from the very beginning. It used to be subtle but not anymore. Not when people realized they could own both the cash cow that is rapidly becoming fine compost and the shiny new thing that will cannibalize it, and evidently cares about its users, and is definitively not attempting the very same scheme. Maybe I'm just lazy and I should go to that mod website that provides a great service for its users at the low cost of creating an account. That's actually a valid point but then, why do they--Bethesda--remove the achievements? why do they even remove steam workshop to begin with? why do they make actual efforts to make things worse so they can sell a solution? Maybe I'm just wrong and not only Creation Club is bringing tons of money to the devs but it also brings people together in a way free communities would never be able to. Maybe Bethesda ought to fully own its IP and profit from all its derivative works, fan works, commentaries, heck even this review, neigh the whole internet and its computer too now that it's owned by Microsoft. Own everything, monetize everything. No more competitors. Sell a Creation Club game in a western setting, call it Oatfield or whatever, no game, just paid mods, people will still buy it because that's marginally better than nothing. Maybe I just fail to recognize a bad game and this has nothing to do with Creation Club. Surely, the design flaw of Starfield lays elsewhere but I'd never know because I'm not a game designer. The universe just ought to be owned by Bethesda, but it only works if it's a western, or it has dragons or whatever. Anyway, congrats if you read the whole thing it's full of bad grammar and bad faith arguments: you just wasted your time.

The "haters" say this game is boring and there isn't anything to do. You can become a bounty hunter and track bounties for cash, dedicate yourself to exploring planets by scanning it's flora and fauna for cash, become a Space Pirate, or a secret agent for SysDef. An Agent Provocateur for a Mega Corp, or even a Space Trucker who ferries resources between planets for cash. You can build your own settlement to either kick back and chill in or use it to gather resources and automate production of objects you can sell becoming a Captain of Industry. You can even design and build your own star ships and hire a crew to make them even better. There is a ton of stuff to do and so many ways to play this game. I give it a solid 8.5/10.

Having finished the main story and some of the most prominent side quests, I can definitely say I'm in love with this game and would recommend it to anyone looking for an immersive sci-fi story-based experience. Starfield was made by people enamored with space exploration and it shows. It has just about everything, from amazing world building and thoughtful dialogue to really smooth and satisfying battle gameplay, whether you're up in space or down on the ground. Character writing and acting are wonderful, whether it's the main cast or literally just some minor NPCs that you only meet once. There's also always plenty of stuff to do, from elaborate ship building or perfecting your space suits and weapons to pure exploration and base building (which can be both practical and cosmetic). It can feel overwhelming at first, but that's also one of the best parts - the world feels vast and full of wonders and perils waiting to be discovered. You aren't forced onto one single linear path, instead you're free to explore and set your own goals as you go. 

I would definitely recommend Starfield to anyone who already played previous Bethesda games because they took what already worked and improved upon it with great care and detail. And if you haven't played any of them, it'll make an amazing first experience. It gets criticized for being a "typical Bethesda title" but personally, I love their games and their approach to single player experiences. 

Another thing to add is that it's a completely different game now compared to what it was like when it first launched. I definitely recommend checking everything that's been updated and added since then! On top of that, their Creations (Mods) tab is packed with some really great stuff and plenty of free mods to try. 

With about 129 hours played at the time of writing this, I've only done one single playthrough - and that was mostly just the main story and some side stuff. There is still so much to discover, and with the NG+ system, that's exactly what I'm going to do next. This game is a gem and I'm excited to put more time in it.

If you like space, loot, and existential crises wrapped in stunning visuals, play Starfield. Just… maybe clear your schedule first.

Starfield was a mixed bag for me. The main thing I loved was the graphics and overall esthetic of the game. The nasapunk theme and look of the universe was stunning. I had lots of fun roaming and fighting pirates. That being said, without a gimmic like the vats system in fallout, the combat wasn't special. The big problem for me was the characters. Nobody stood out for me except Vasco the robot and that was only because I liked how his voice sounded. I'm a huge Mass Effect fan and was excited to play another space adventure with a memorable crew. Instead, I got characters that are as memorable as bland cafeteria food. Whenever I would interact with the crew, I'd think about and miss the crew of the Normandy. Even the bad characters like Jacob or Liam from Andromeda were more memorable and personality than the constellation people.

It is a good game, but don't expect the same replayability that other Bethesda titles have had. The game feel is astounding; the guns feel great to shoot, combat is engaging, fun, and varied, ship building is everything I've ever dreamed in a space game. 

However, there aren't enough factions, the factions that do exist don't have enough written content and rely too much on radiant quests, the new game + feature cheapens the decisions you make along the way, and there aren't enough important decisions to make in the first place. The game also shoe-horns you into a good play-through; all companions are good leaning at minimum, and there's only one quest line that allows you to really stray from the good path. 

It lacks that quality that FONV, FO4, and Skyrim all had, where it felt like there was a specific path to fit the character you created, factions that existed that aligned with your character's value's, and factions you don't join, decisions you don't make because they don't make sense for your character. The various options feel like vague, easy choices that you would make again each and every play-through, with the occasional difference. 

If you play this game with the expectation that it will be like other Bethesda games you have played; replaying over and over and doing vastly different things, prepare to be disappointed. If you play expecting to get a fun experience in space a time or two, you will for sure have a good time.

At this point the game is playable and has some cool systems, but still suffers from being a corporate, soulless, politically motivated, piece of garbage. Its tough to even get into it enough because every character is so hollow, predictable, and is just overall ...... soft. Instead of making cool characters, they wanted to make sure they were "diverse and representative" first and cool second. Its almost like the dialogue was created and then the character was randomly generated. 

It makes it boring whether you agree or disagree with this political viewpoint ; once you know what the developers believe ideologically, you can predict everything else in the game - which causes continual eye rolls on the part of the player and smells of heavy corporate oversight on a creative process. 

That oversight resulted in artists playing it safe and telling "the stories you are supposed to tell" as opposed to "the stories people didn't know they needed to hear".

I have a feeling this was Bethesda's trial run on using AI to generate a lot of the game. The creativity is so surface level, it seems like it was created by an AI with an objective as opposed to an artist with a calling.
No exaggeration, the worst game I've ever played in my entire life.

This game was my first real introduction to modern video games (Disclaimer: I did play mobile games, and some simple video games from 90s and early 2000s before). I bought a gaming PC pretty much exclusively for this game, and I was blown away with the scope and scale of it all. The graphics are brilliant, and while I have seen some negative reviews relating to loading screens, when they do appear, they only last a second or too, so don't  cause many problems with gaming. I cannot overstate how much this game means to me, It was my first introduction to open-world games, and offered more freedom than anything else I have ever experienced, and I often just stopped playing to admire the amazing scenery.

If you are brand-new to gaming, I cannot recommend this game enough. For those who have played for many years, all I can say is to approach games like this optimistically, and try to see it for the marvel of modern technology that games like these are.

Amazing game IMHO, with over 1500 hours in.  I've only CTD'd a couple times early on.  Its a very stable game on my middle-of-the-road game system (RTX 3080 and 12th gen processor).  The story line(s) are excellent, do captivate you along the way, and are fulfilling when you complete them.  You don;t have to do just the main quest line, just like other Bethesda games.  I haven't been to every system yet, not even close over those hours.  And yeah, I finished the first NG line a few times, and even done it in NG+.  People say the worlds are boring.  If you play vanilla, with no mods, it can be challenging on the high level worlds.  The truth is there are tons of randomly spawned sites and features no matter where you land on a planet, to the point that it seems like its too much for a "barren" world.  Land, look around and at least 5 different "sites" are showing up 360 degrees around the horizon that can be visited.  Everywhere.  Many comment negatively about that as well, ironically in direct opposition to the ones that say its "boring".  So what that should tell you is that this game is what it is and perhaps like all games, is not meant for EVERYONE's taste.

Further, although the actual sites themselves are repetitive after a while, they are challenging and afford you the chance to hone different approaches as you try them from time to time.  They don't repeat too often and I think I read that there are something like 100 different types.  Each one can take an hour to get through if you are meticulous and a looter.  Shorter once they get familiar and you know where to look.  The NG+ is an interesting effect like the Witcher III repeat but without all the goodies you collected except the Starborn skills.  I like it, and it provides a different repeat play-ability feel than other games because some things can change dramatically in the "new" universe you pop into.  Critics will say its repeat hash.  To some degree but with the random changes possible, the original fun content stays alive for me on the repeat.

But the absolute gem in this game is the shipbuilding.  Making a ship interior you love and almost feel like you can live aboard is a masterpiece.  The one thing I love is just being able to hang out in your new space-faring RV and relax, do things inside, whatever.  In space or on a planet.  Craft, or make food.  Chat with the crew.  I sometimes just land on a planet and watch the local fauna wandering outside the window, with the sun setting or a winter storm gale just outside, safe and warm in my ship.  It is 95% of what space legs always meant to me (other game, eh hemm).  I've spent many, many hours building and modifying my ship just the way I like it.  As more 3rd party and mod parts arrive, the sky remains the limit in this aspect.  Just look online and see the amazing varieties (and funny) ships people have built.  I would have paid some of the cash for the game just for this feature alone.

So bottom line, don't take every thing negative you read as gospel.  Valid for those folks, to be sure.  However, the game is meant for a specific game style.  Its not a game designed to "beat" or replace some other game(s).  And its not Skyrim in space (as I have read).  Todd said it clearly multiple times.  Its a unique experience.  Folks just didn't really listen to that word, and I believe, got disappointed.

Massive never ending story, prepare to be addicted, lots of repeatable stuff, kind of like real life; eat, sleep, drink, repeat. Replayable with variations, I think for some it might be too much, if you want a distinct end point you might not like this.

not even mods can fix this one.

It's exactly as advertised: Skyrim in Space.  There's a ton of quests, and while some of them are basic fetch or kill quests, just wandering around and talking to people will net you more interesting ones.  While not every mission has a handcrafted environment, the main questlines for each faction do.

Overall, I'd say this is an iteration more than an innovation.  But if you enjoyed playing Skyrim and Fallout, you'll probably have fun playing this too.

-edit-

Ok, I've logged more than 100 more hours since my initial review, and I didn't give this game enough credit.  On a New Game+ playthrough, I'm finding TONS of quests that I didn't find on my first playthrough.  All four of the main faction quests are interesting and unique, and highlight different modes of gameplay.  But there are also an incredible number of other quests you'll find just by traveling around the galaxy, and a lot of them are weird and wonderful.

I'd also like to shout out the voice acting.  While it's sometimes noticeable that an actor voiced multiple roles among the minor NPCs, the main Constellation companions are all excellently written and voiced.

Overall, this game is excellent, and I highly recommend it for anybody who enjoys science fiction.

Though the vanilla game is arguably the weakest out of the Bethesda RPGs, it still has a lot of genuinely good moments and ideas. Unfortunately, a lot of the potential isn't met on it's own which will lead to an experience that starts incredibly strong but dies out within 20-30 hours of gameplay.

That is without mods. Modded (free mods), this game reaches a lot of that potential and then some. I have almost 200 mods and 100 hours in the game right now and, in its current modded state, I'm honestly excited for the next 100 hours.

I know you can't entirely judge a game based on mods, but I'd argue that if Starfield didn't have such a strong base, technically and thematically, the modding scene couldn't have elevated it so high.
