In real life they can't blow up asteroids the size of moons while you fly circle behind them to flank your enemy....but that's what they do....if you try to flank them using an asteroid....they just blow it up.....so if your insanely outnumbered and out gunned, strategizing will not save you because they made sure to completely take that opportunity off the table and I think it's just stupidly ridiculous because I have never in my life played a space game where you can't use asteroids for cover.

Solid 6.8 out of ten. I wanted to really let this game marinate before I reviewed it, so that its "Fresh Game" shine had time to wear off and I could look at it straight on. 
REALLY enjoyed this for the first few weeks, but after that you begin to see its flaws. 

The one thing I will say is the shipbuilder, while sometimes frustrating, is a step in the right direction for games that let you fly spaceships. This level of customization should be a minimum requirement for space games. 

Has the width of an entire galaxy, but the the depth of a kiddie pool. 

Towns feel static and shallow, where nothing changes when you are not there. Cities feel like a movie set, with huge buildings that have zero function except to be a single storefront at street level. The Cities end up feeling empty and WAY too small. I get that this is a Bethesda game so i should expect cities to be about 10 houses MAX, but both oblivion and skyrim did the best they could with what they had and made their small little towns and cities feel somewhat alive. They (obl and sky) gave npcs schedules to follow and overhearing conversations could start a new quest, or give a hint as to where to go to get one. Fallout 4 had the too small city problem as well, but with it being a post apocalyptic game, with most of the world dead, I can't really blame them for that one. This game is set in the far future, with the technology to match. The only city that felt like it was actually kind of big was Neon, but I think that can partially be attributed to its density. New Atlantis, the CAPITAL of a interstellar Faction, looks tiny. It has what, 3 or so skyscrapers, the main spire and a few smaller buildings? Are we foreal right now? 

Akila City seems like it should get a pass, based on how it feels kinda of like a wild wild west style vibe, so its city and small and (frontier-like) to match, but then you realize its supposed to be the CAPITAL of the second largest interstellar faction in the game.... A town smaller than Solitude in Skyrim governs... multiple planets? OH and you might be thinking, "but hey wasn't it founded a few years ago? NOPE, it was founded ONE HUNDRED and SIXTY THREE YEARS AGO. Are you kidding me right now? Stuff like this pisses me off when a game is supposed to be set in the far space-faring future. 160+ years is nothing if you are in the bronze age, but this is an era with spaceships. 163 years later the entire planet should be basically one city. 

The weapons and gun-play are passable, they work as they should for the most part. I will say, the way they implemented weapon variety and randomization gets super annoying. I will have 5 of the same weapon in my inventory, but because a weapon can (NOT CLEARLY) change its stats and effects based on what perks, attachments, and effects a weapon has, I have to spend 5-10 minutes figuring out which of the 5 weapons is the best, or at least the most compatible with my particular play style. I think this system could have been simplified dramatically, or reworked to be MUCH clearer. 

Do not get me started on stealth. This game might have the worst stealth in any Bethesda game to date. I am a dedicated stealth player. My first character in every Bethesda game is a stealth character. I LOVE stealth. The stealth in this game SUCKS. It feels like an afterthought where they made the game and then went, "Oh woopsie! Some people like being stealthy, we better slap that on quick!" Even the missions where you are supposed to be stealthy are designed so poorly that It ends up just becoming frustrating and are some of my least favorite missions in the entire game. 

Enemy Scaling is wild and I have literally no idea from one encounter to the next whether the enemies I am about to fight will be able to be killed with a tickle and a feather or if I am about to get into a 1v10 cage match with the most ridiculously broken Steroid enhanced terminator Pirates you have ever seen. 

The Spaceship combat: 
This was not a major pain point for me. I didn't get this game with the expectation that I was going to be flying in space for more than just getting to place to place. Could it be much better? Absolutely. Was it fine and does the job for what Bethesda is becoming known for....  A relatively shallow, one size fits all, approachable, dumbed-down rpg experience that has bits and pieces of greatness? Yes. 

The writing- 
I am writing this review AFTER Oblivion Remastered came out, specifically because it came out and I remembered what Bethesda was like when they REALLY cared about well written and entertaining stories that had depth. The writing in Starfield is just.... meh. Nothing really stood out to me as a WOW moment when it came to any of the main, faction, or side quests story lines. I do not remember them being necessarily bad, but I also do not remember much of them, so take that as you will. 

The Universe-
I think Bethesda, as one of the kings of environmental storytelling, should have stuck to a game that was set in either one single larger solar system, or stuck to a few solar systems at most. This game is just too big and too empty. Bethesda making it was just kind of a weird choice. Using procedural generation was an absolute mistake. One of the most annoying things was landing on a planet in one solar system, and then going to a different planet in a different solar system, and those two planets look nearly the same, with similar foliage, animals, enemies, and locations. Don't get me started on how many times I saw the EXACT same space or pirate base layout on a randomly generated planet. Down to the exact same notes on the computer. If they wanted to make a huge randomly generated space game, they needed a MUCH larger bank of Pre-made elements for that system to pull from.

Planets- 
The random planets are also just way too empty to be interesting. Whats worse is, even the "handcrafted" planets that housed a capital or a relevant unique quest destination, did not even feel good. It looked like the planet was randomly generated, but then the quest location was just plopped down in the middle. 

Factions are bland and relatively uninteresting, with somewhat boring and too-quick quests that feel unrewarding. Too much busywork and not enough handcrafted content. 

This game COULD have been so good. I sincerely hope we see a return to Oblivion's care and concern for the depth of storytelling and RPG mechanics. IT IS OKAY if you are able to (somewhat) lock yourself into a play style (like oblivion did) for one run of a game. You don't NEED to keep everything so simple and accessible just so that anyone can do everything. Bethesda used to be one of the greats. Now I cant even recommend Todd Howard's Gem. The game he said he always wanted to make. Its too shallow. I hesitate to use the word "slop" but I am getting close. It sometimes feels like every new game they make, they make it easier and simpler, just to make sure that the widest audience possible can play it. Please Bethesda, Look at the reception Oblivion Remastered is getting. That isn't just because it might be the best looking game on the market right now. (It is.) It is because Oblivion came from a time when Bethesda CARED.

This review is unfortunately overall going to come across very negative. I don't want you to think I am hating for fun. I simply have seen Bethesda at its Best, (Morrowind, Oblivion), at its Great,(Fallout 4, Skyrim), and now I am seeing Bethesda at their worst. (Fallout 76, Starfield. The incessant paid creation mods)

[Primarily a Console player, 500 hours on my Xbox.]
Best I can say, is the game is mid, uninspired, lacking any reason to play more than 10 NG+. 

It does most things well: Gun-play, ship combat, Jump packs, back-story, traits, perk progression, research, powers, planets, sky boxes, lighting details, day/night cycles, environmental hazards, mining, and scanning are all good features that add depth to how you can play. the core of the game is good, in my opinion, all the things that matter on the surface, "just work".  

What does not "Just work" is everything that makes it a game instead of a solid tech-demo: 
- Weapon quality tiers (quality tiers tie to player level but do not always drop at that quality. getting god roll legendaries on a lower quality is absolute pain and "Slow [in french]")
- The Temples... they're slightly worse than Farcry's radio towers.
- The shallowness of dialogue and story telling. It does not feel good after 6 NG+, it becomes a chore...
- The Setting you play in is the boring aftermath to the War that should have been when the game actually takes place.
- There's no lock out of anything, you can help nearly every main faction in one play-through. They all accomplish nothing but pad your bank account for the rest of the run... nothing outside the quest changes, no actual affect is had on the world. Even though its brought up numerous times in the NG+ like our choices in the next game will matter.
- Loading screens... so... many... un-hidden... in-your-face... anti-immersive... spinning wheels (with the occasional gallery image). Literally just cutting the Grav jump burst animation and replacing it with a grav jump "wormhole" animation, viewed from the cockpit of your ship, that persists till you load the next area would hide 60% of the loading wheels and will make the rest of them, tolerable. 
- The Game puts you on the surface of a planet, outside your ship, when you use the star-map to travel to a settlement, city, or PoI on a planet you've already visited. (STOP PUTTING ME ON THE SURFACE OF MARS WITHOUT A SUIT).
- Lack of polish (One example is how people still teleport when entering and exiting doors, but now elevators don't even close to try and hide it like the devs did in Fo4).

Overall... Starfield is a solid tech demo, they put a lot of time and money into improving the core of the creation engine, only to cover it in a rotting husk of a "game".

A few questlines held my attention, notably the Crimson Fleet and Entangled. However, the main questline lacks any creativity whatsoever; unlock a new desolate planet, grab the new power from the temple. Rinse and repeat. 

Dialogue is boring and characters are bland. Combat and gun-play is average. Ship building is alright but most ship parts require a pretty heavy time investment to unlock. I'd rather spend my time playing something less bland.

Don't listen to Todd Howard's BS, this is an extremely poorly optimized game.

3.5/10 - The most disappointing game in recent memory.
No soul, no meat, no beans. Boring

Like Fallout 4 (pre-DLC), Starfield is a game that has a gimmick that kept me playing for a bit, but beyond that gimmick, the game feels rushed, incomplete and empty. For FO4, the gimmick was settlement building. For Starfield, it's ship building and customization. That part of the game is enjoyable, but the rest is rather dull and not particularly memorable. Empty planets, the same exact process to get each Jedi power, a needlessly-punishing encumbrance limit (unless you can cast the oxygen spell, which fully negates all encumbrance), zero consequence for your actions, and unbelieveably BORING companions. NPCs don't react to anything you do, including shooting the ground at their feet. The Gamebryo engine was outdated when Skyrim launched, and it hasn't much improved since. It feels like Todd is just clocking in and out of the office, counting the days until retirement, too disinterested in the games he's responsible for. I'm convinced the whole reason Bethesda stubbornly refuses to abandon Creation Engine *cough Gamebryo cough*, is because that's the engine Todd acquired his fame on, he understands it inside and out, and is vehemently opposed to having to learn something new, this close to retiring. That's why we're stuck with innumerable loading screens every time we want to do something that isn't run or shoot. He doesn't care that the more advanced their games get, the more held back they are by that obsolete engine.

People complain about the graphical quality, but it's fine. Hardly cutting edge, but nowhere near bad. The aesthetic designs are unremarkable at best, and dull as a math lecture at worst. But the graphical 'quality' is fine. There's zero space exploration in this space game. The engine simply wouldn't support it. The writing is comically bad. Bethesda's writing never recovered from the departure of Michael Kirkbride. The OST sets the mood, but you probably don't remember any of the music if you haven't played for a while. In fact, I can't even recall the theme music off the top of my head. The whole experience is about as remarkable as vanilla ice cream. And I don't mean the fancy kind with the vanilla bean shavings and those little black dots that add flavor; I mean the kind you get in the frozen foods section of Walmart, because your kids won't stop begging you for ice cream, but you can't afford the kind that comes with flavor, because you spent $100 on the Premium Edition of Starfield, and now feel you have little to show for it.

Again, I enjoyed the ship building and customization. Being able to design a ship from scratch and decorate it how you want is pretty awesome, and it kept me engaged far longer than anything else in the game. The UC Vanguard faction questline was pretty good, I admit. A few of the other quests had a strong start, but none of theme really ended up finishing strong.

I tried their version of New Game+ with an existing character, but that just made me feel like my character no longer belonged and the people he met weren't really his friends. My approach quickly devolved to getting all my powers upgraded, skipping all quests and content not necessary to speedrunning the ending and going to the next universe to do it all again. I burnt out around my sixth universe jump. It was a poor implementation of NG+, and it would've been better if you could just traditionally start a new game with an existing character without trying to tie it into the lore. If that confuses you, it's because you probably have never seen NG+ implemented in this way, before.

I didn't play Shattered Space, so I can't comment on that, but the reviews are not looking good.

I think most people don't really care if Starfield comes out with additional dlc at this point, but as Bethesda hasn't announced yet that they are abandoning the game, I suspect we'll get at least once more. If they can pull off a Far Harbor, that would be great, but I'm not optimistic. They could potentially release compelling dlc content, but the base game design (what people keep calling the "bones of the game") is outdated and I doubt this will ever fully recover. Many long-time modders of Bethesda titles aren't even touching this one, because they can't figure out how to make it worth playing, long-term.

As my play time and achievements will attest, I gave this one a solid chance and it's not completely without merit, though it is quite mediocre and not a game I would recommend at full price. If you're not going the Game Pass route, I really wouldn't recommend this game unless it goes on sale for around $35. You'll get your money's worth at $35.

Last game I’ll ever preorder:
I finally was compelled to leave a review after how well the Oblivion Remaster did.  I don’t hate that Bethesda experimented with this game and created something that didn’t work; I hate that the marketing around it was deceptive, a $70 price point on a game that had significantly less content than previous titles even 20 years ago and relied on procedural generation to fill in the blanks (and there’s a LOT of blank space here)

Boring.

It's fine, but it can get boring in parts. I think we all expected a lot more out of Bethesda which is unfortunate, because I think if the expectation had not been there, not as many of us would be disappointed. That being said, there is a some focus on fighting spaceships and the controls for that are absolutely diabolical. And the game does not evoke any sense of wonder or excitement in me, like the following games did: Oblivion, Skyrim, Fallout 3, Fallout 4, Prey, The Evil Within, Dishonored... I think the game suffers because of the lack of vision and purposeful scope. There are many random moons to loot on, but they don't feel different from one another and it would have been more interesting to have less of those, and more effort into fleshing out planets with interesting side quests and areas. It was trying to balance realism (which is mundane) with fantastical (which seemed out of place). And though there were some cool side quests, many of them seemed lazy or incorporated too much space fighting with dreadful controls. Okay, maybe it isn't fine. I don't recommend this game unless it's on sale.

I genuinely don’t understand the hate Starfield receives. When I played it, I had a lot of fun and consistently looked forward to picking it up again after taking a break. The story is solid, and the section where the Hunter is chasing you stands out as particularly engaging and tense.

I will admit the beginning felt like a bit of a stretch—it’s hard to buy into the idea of being "chosen" after touching an artifact and suddenly having a vision. In a game set so far into the future, where advanced medical technology is everywhere, it seems like the logical response would be a quick head scan and maybe some rest—not a prophecy. This kind of trope works better in fantasy or medieval settings, but felt slightly off here.

That said, the gameplay itself is fun and satisfying. Yes, other games offer more immersive or manual planet landing and takeoff mechanics, but it honestly didn’t bother me much. I ended up using fast travel most of the time anyway, and it worked well within the flow of the game.

Compared to other Bethesda titles, Starfield seems like it has less to do in terms of factions or sheer content density. But what is there is high quality, and I enjoyed everything I found. The characters are well written and engaging. The soundtrack, while not as iconic as Skyrim or TES, is subtle and fits the tone of the game very well—perhaps that’s the mark of a good soundtrack after all.

The gameplay is fairly predictable, but in a way that’s satisfying and familiar. It scratches that Bethesda itch. I’d happily play through it again.

I finally finished playing Starfield.
My overall mark is 6/10. The game is worth to buy when on the discount. Hardly it will give you more than 100 hours of gameplay unless you are "finish all side quest" guy. The game will offer you mechanics that you will both hate and love.
Lets dive deep into what I experienced during my 90 hours of playing:

The game provides 5 core game mechanics with my score for each:
World divercity 6/10
Quests 4/10
Space Ship management and space battles 7/10
Outpost management 6/10
Exploration 6/10


Before I start, i need to mention that I used couple of mods from Creations that altered my game experience:
- removed annoying conditions to all talens
- installed better outpost management mods (in the late game) that gave me rich trade authority terminals
- inventory size booster mod
- easy digipix 
I dont think that these mods impacted a lot on my gameplay, but made game more pleasant, less time consuming and less grindy. By the way mod system is a good thing in the game, that can remove/alter the most hated aspects of the game. 

So lets begin with entire world divercity 6/10.
The universe is still compact consisting of 120 star systems, while you will jump across 5-7 core systems all the time.
No aliens at all. This is the most dissapointing thing in the game. In the 120 systems there is no smart aliens except humans. This makes a spacegame poor in imagination and dreams. Planets are poorly visualized and looks like a big pixel from the orbit. (I know my laptop is not great, but other games could impress more even on my old kettle)
Usually, habitated planets will have only one core city and wildereness right outside city border. Seems ridiculous for me, since humans prefer to settle across the planet, build roads, villages, strip clubs... You can land in any point on the planet and it will generate you a random map covered with the same building types as in any other planet/rock/asteroid/outpost/whatever deep hole you can land in. Battles are usually boring in the game, although loot system is quite diverce. I need to mention that the game offers a lot of mechanics, that could be interesting to you but I cant list them all here (piracy as an example). Characters, heroes, teammates were boring to me and unimpressive. Loading screens everywhere is a real failure for Betheda. Luckily there are some mods that make game seamless. 

Quests 4/10
My overall opinion is that they are repeatedly boring. Maybe i couldnt fall in love with the the whole world and story idea, so I skipped many side quests. They looks the same, played the same and provides little interesting rewards.
Main quest story in my opinion is a complete bullsh*t. When playing space game you will less expect multiverse topic picked as the main idea. It was already consumed to zero by Marvel...
I would anticipate more alien contacts, rich history of each planet, complicated life on each planet. Perhaps Mass Effect is a standard/reference for these game type. Quests to find temples are the most stupid thing to me. How noone else had discovered these temples before main hero is a mystery. Overall temples, magical abilities are both idiotic game aspects that was stolen from Skyrim and looks really ridiculous and useless in the game.

Spaceships and spacebattles 7/10
Spaceships management is a tool where i really spent a lot of time and enjoyed it. It still has some problems, although it is something that really impressed me. Spacebattles are less interesting aspect since you will majorly face 2-3 enemy ships without any continuation of the battle in the location. I loved spending time with boarding and stealing enemy ships. Unfortunately the game offers little difference between ships and classes, but it was fun to me.

Outpost management 6/10
This game aspect was very fun at the beginning and very annoying in the late-game. Once you know how to extract first extractors you will be amazed how useless this process is. Still I spent a lot of time on this, and played SIMs like outpost management. Connection between outposts is a broken thing, although an idea with landing pads and shipments was great. I also bored to hell trying to find a perfect spot for my other outposts. The biggest problem here is that you are building outposts to gather resources for other outpost. Thats it. You will use resources for science and upgrades, whether it is much easier to buy these resources rather that mine in outposts. Some micromanagement of storages, connections, fabrication seemed inefficient to me.

Exploration 6/10
Again 120 systems... And almost nothing to do. Planets could have plants and animals which will live only in a specific biotope. I do inderstand the limitation of current game technologies, but I prefer to see rich, spectacular sightseens of alien planets made by a game designer rather than boring and automatically generated maps. Perhaps it is my prefference. The most annoying for me was riding a car and kick counless boulders and rocks each meter. You cant ride straight on any planet really. Nevertheless someone could find this technology of map and world generation interesting and promising. Scanning of planets is a strange thing. On the one hand why the hell I need to scan the planet with human colony. Should it be scanned by explorers in the past? Then you just scan to reveal resources without any other real purpose. Even with a proper talent "astrophysics" you need to scan each planet manually. Luckily it gives you some free exp in exchange of being bored.

In the conclusion. The game will definetely attract you for some time. It has very interesting mechanics , but once you will consume all interesting things you may find yourself immediately bored. Nevertheless I think it was worth of playing 90 hours.

An empty philosophy offering nothing.

I'm really sorry to have to give this a bad review. I've played it a lot looking for that Bethesda magic, hoping that it would appear on the next planet or in the next quest. But it's just not there. All the comments about the lack of exploration, the sterility of worlds, the blandness of quests, the poor loot variety are all true, but where Bethesda really failed here was with the story. When I solved the mystery, I was profoundly underwhelmed. The takeaway is that nothing matters. Nothing you did matters; no good you did matters; no evil you did matters. And yet somehow the game has to explain the motivations of the antagonists. Why do they pursue you when nothing matters? And the best Bethesda came up with is that they want power. Of course, that was the only explanation Bethesda could pick when it embraced a philosophy that denies that "every action and every pursuit aims at some good." But in Bethesda's telling, power has no use, no purpose, no ends. It aims at nothing at all. Perhaps some tiny number of empty people want power for no purpose at all, but they are not typical and they are not relatable. Yet Bethesda has built a game on the false premise that if any of us found ourselves in a world where nothing at all mattered, we would happily pursue power and resources for no other reason than to merely possess them. It isn't a compelling vision for a human life, so it can't be a compelling vision for a game.

Now it is time... I was really hyped by Starfield and thought it could be one of my favorite games of all time.

I even waited until now (April 2025) to write this because I thought Bethesda could change things around or modders could fix the game, but it was not the case. Instead, they (Bethesda) abandoned the game that I could only describe as a "shell for something that could be good".

The only flaw of this game is really its game design - and don't take this lightly, because game design is the foundation of all games. With a poor game design, everything else crumbles under its weight. Pretty much EVERY system of the game do not realize its full potential.

Core combat -> OK, as flawed as previous titles and not the real enemy here
Ship Building -> Arguably the only good system in the game
Ship combat -> Extremely raw and shallow, makes very little sense to invest on it
Progression -> Also very shallow, many things useless, don't make sense to specialize into anything or create a character
Story (and its loop) -> Interesting but really poor executed - railroads you with such a force that if you try to roleplay you will just eventually be pulled to the vanilla character they created, which brakes everything turning you into a miner that becomes an inter dimensional entity.
Planetary Environments -> Landing on Venus and on an asteroid almost feels the same (only different gravities). No sense of danger)
Planetary Content -> Not challenging, level scaled mess that basically says "if you land on this planet, ANYTHING will either kill you or be killed by a single bullet". A complete mess, I don't remember Skyrim being so scaled (by FO was, I really hated it).
Settlement Building -> Probably the most under developed system in the game. FO4 had it better a decade ago, WHY????
Economy -> Not existent
Lore Acuity -> Settlements are worse than abandoned bandit bases on the middle of nothing
Content -> Plentiful but shallow

That being said, Bethesda has only one option -> fire all of its PRODUCT management involved on this project because they actually requested and approved this grandiose, uninspired mess that is Starfield. I cannot blame who executed it because the makeup (visuals, overall art direction, tailor made content, etc) is actually fine. The problem is that is seems that it was requested by a bunch of gringey executives who don't play their own games. Peace

I really did enjoy the game in my first play through even though it was rough. The universe doesn't feel connected at all. One can join all these different factions, but there is no recognition or continuity of the "achievements" after completing faction quests. Very lack luster story. It would've been interesting to be a part of the war instead of the peaceful era with a hint of tension among factions in the game's timeline takes place in. Npcs and companions feel lackluster and uninteresting. Shipbuilding is alright at best; the module system, while cool, is limited to the lack of variety the base game offers (There are some mods, but the difference isn't crazy. You won't be able to build exact replicas of star war ships, interior wise). Introducing premium pay for mods for a mediocre game is crazy work. It just goes to show how detached Bethesda has become or the desperation they have to try to milk the game in whatever shape or form they can since it flopped hard. Now, modding is practically dead for Starfield.
I really tried to come back to this game to play a modded playthrough, but barely any mods, and the game is a pain to mod for no reason compared to older Bethesda titles. I looked forward to this game when it was announced, but it feels empty, especially now. An RPG with no replayability. The looping system was the worst idea, it honestly felt like the writers chose the easiest route, "Oh, let's just make players reset everything and go through some missions to get to the end rather quickly and give a cosmetic reward based on how many times they've done the loop." Like, you are not forced to do it, but you kinda have to since as a player you want to see where it would lead to. The loop can offer a variety of little quirky changes here and there (Very minor changes. Small wow factor at best). Insane. Really disappointed. I really do hope we get a sci-fi rpg game with the same scope that Starfield attempted, but done right. I really can't recommend the game. Modders gave up on the game. However, if you really want to scratch that sci-fi itch, then give it go, but don't expect much.

Starfield – A Space Adventure... Full of Bugs

Starfield had the potential to be a revolutionary space RPG, but instead, it’s a buggy mess that feels like a glitchy space station. Sure, the concept is cool—exploring galaxies, customizing ships, and getting lost in a massive universe—but the execution is ruined by constant bugs. From awkward character animations to missions that don’t trigger properly, it’s like you’re playing a beta, not a finished product.

The bugs don’t just mess with immersion—they ruin gameplay. Getting stuck in the environment, crashing ships for no reason, or having quests break halfway through? It’s more frustration than fun. All the promises of deep space exploration are overshadowed by technical issues that make you want to quit rather than keep playing.

Score: 3/10 – Great concept, horrible execution. If you like bugs more than space exploration, Starfield is for you.

As a space enthusiast, I deeply appreciate this game for what it is. It is set in "real life" with LOTS of fantasy elements of course (artificial gravity as one example), but in the future. The partnership with NASA to help this game feel "real" (if you can even call it that) lets me live the life that I will only ever be able to dream of. I will never get the opportunity to explore another world. I will never get the opportunity to fly a space-ship. I dream about it, I imagine it, and I wish for it, but it will never happen. Starfield feels like a game that was made for people like me. Unfortunately, I actually really love jumping around a nearly empty moon with no atmosphere, where I can look up and see the planet the moon is orbiting, and the star, and the milky way galaxy. I understand this is a video game that is supposed to be packed with content. But for me, a simple body of liquid methane on Saturn's moon Titan, is something that fills me with so much joy, to see it from the surface as if I was really there.

Soulless. There's potential for a game here, but it falls flat after the first couple hours.

It's a real shame.

[h1] A galaxy of potential... but some stars shine brighter than others. [/h1]

Starfield is ambitious. Bethesda set out to create a vast universe — literally — and in many ways, they succeeded. The scale is impressive, the ship customization is satisfying, and there are moments where the exploration genuinely captures a sense of awe. The faction quests (especially the UC Vanguard and Freestar Rangers) are some of the strongest the studio has ever done.

But then... the seams show.

The loading screens are frequent and immersion-breaking. Planets, while numerous, often feel empty and procedurally bland. Space travel is more of a menu system than an actual experience. The main story has interesting themes, but it takes a while to get going, and the dialogue is classic Bethesda: serviceable, but rarely memorable.

Mod support will likely transform this game (as with Skyrim), but as it stands, Starfield feels like a foundation — a good one, but not yet a great one.

I think this game is the perfect "mediocre" of what Bethesda Games have become. When comparing it to "newer" Bethesda Games, it's somewhere in the middle of Fallout 4 and Skyrim in terms of story and how I feel about it. As for gameplay system, it's closer to Fallout 4 if they fumble massively.

After reading all the stuff people had to say, this is a very "underrated" game for me. Sure it isn't game of the century, but in no way is it a 5/10 in my opinion. I really wanted a Bethesda game in space, with ship interiors and everything, and for me they delivered. It could have been much, much more that's true. Yet this is still a game that i very much enjoyed playing. 

The story, phiolosophy, narrative theme and design behind the New Game Plus is also one of the best i've seen, and the most satisfying. I really did feel something.

As for criticism, the game DOES feel a bit "lifeless", but i feel that in most Bethesda games. Oh and the loading screens. They're not game breakingly annoying by any means for me and didn't detach me from the game but come on this isn't 2005. If they'd just make something like the elevator in Cyberpunk, it'd have been much more immersive.

Changing the loading screen system, adding a bit more life with the addition of a more free space flight system, and this could've been a 9/10 for me.

First Impressions

I almost fell for the negative comments surrounding this game, and I'm so glad I didn’t! As a massive alien fan and its retro-futuristic style, this game is aesthetically a dream come true. The fact that the game is more science than fiction is also a massive pro for me, because it makes it even more believable as a future vision of humans in space.
Just to say in advance, I'm not a huge Bethesda games fan — not that I think they're bad, it’s just that I always preferred hack and slash gameplay from games such as Witcher. So I'm not someone with thousands or even hundreds of hours in Skyrim or Fallout. I'm well acquainted with those games, but I won't even compare them to Starfield because you will get it by the end of my review.

Why I Like Starfield

Starfield gives me the freedom to do what I want in the moment. It’s not just some big map with thousands of question marks that I need to check out. I can go and do missions, extract resources, build ships, upgrade weapons or space suits, etc...
My goal that everything revolves around is ship building. To build ships, I need money. I earn money by building outposts and extracting materials that I use for various upgrades and manufacturing, and the rest of those I sell. The other way I earn money is by doing side missions that I stumble upon accidentally while exploring or picking them up on mission boards. There are other ways to earn money of course, but this is how I do it, because it’s interesting for me.
When I do a couple of missions and check the outposts, I’ve earned enough money to construct or upgrade ships, which is the ultimate goal. Ship building is by far the best aspect of the game for me and most of my hours are spent there. You are basically free to construct your own ship from your imagination, and the feeling when you walk around your ship that you made is great and immersive.
The best thing about all of this is that if you're not interested in ship or outpost building, you just don't have to do it and do your own thing.

Addressing the Biggest Complaints

Loading screens: To be honest, if I had the option to land seamlessly on a planet from space, I probably would once or maybe twice, but that's it. I mean I really wouldn't want to waste my time on stuff like that, and I'm glad I don't have to. Would I want to go seamlessly through cities and buildings without loading screens? Sure, but it’s not a deal breaker for me, because a game of this size obviously has its technical limitations, and I mean, most loadings are like a second or two.
“Not enough points of interest and repetitiveness”: I mean, it’s space. Space is mostly empty. If they made a few planets with handmade stuff, then everyone would be like "yeah, space game with 4 planets...". You wouldn't even feel the size and vastness that space offers.

A Game to Take Slow

This is a slow game that lets you do your own thing. It’s not a game to rush, but to take it slowly and methodically, and enjoy the scenery in the process. It's a game that offers a large variety of systems to interact with, and is good at most of them, and excellent in some.
Do I think that this is a perfect game? Of course not, not even close, but for someone who is into space stuff, I think it’s great. Does it have the most interesting side quests? No, but they are good enough to enjoy most of them, and some are great with twists at the end. Do I want bigger and more dense cities? Sure, but it’s not that these are not enough for what they are supposed to be, especially Neon. Do I want better companions and dialogues? Sure, but it’s not so bad as to be unable to enjoy or care about a few of them. Are there various minor aspects that annoy me? Of course, and I solve those minor things with mods.
I didn’t even go through the main quest, and currently it’s not even my goal, and I think that the story is good so far and gives you things to think about. I won’t discuss Shattered Space DLC, because I haven’t played it yet.

Who This Game Is (and Isn’t) For

People who are searching for action-packed, fast-paced combat with bombastic cut scenes will be disappointed. Those who want to interact with various systems and exploit them and take it slow and relaxing, with occasional action, will enjoy this game. And I think that it’s great, because we have action-packed games in abundance, but not many games like this.

Final Thoughts

I think that the base game and its foundation is great for what it is supposed to be and offers a lot of potential for further upgrading and improvements.

I don't defend this game for its shortcomings, nor do I really care if someone plays it based on my review. I just wanted to give my opinion, for people like me that are misled by all the negativity surrounding this game.

This is one of those games that I have had a lot of mixed feelings with...on one hand, I do happen to like the space sci-fi setting and some of the ideas in this game (ship building, space combat, and zero-g firefights being pretty nice), and of course, this game can be eye candy at times if you're on the right planet at the right time...on the other hand, this being a Bethesda game, I do have my fair share of criticisms (especially with the last 4-5 months of radio silence). The writing definitely can be a bit jarring at times, especially with certain storylines in the game. I'm also not a fan of how the leveling system is handled, with the perk tree requiring certain tasks being done in order to unlock the next level of a perk. There are also some hub locations that have so much potential that leave so much to be desired (my choices being New Atlantis, Akila City, and Neon). I have plenty of other things to say, but I'd rather avoid repeating the same talking points that have been parroted by others over the last year and a half. I can't say that I love this game, but I don't hate it outright. But still, I do want this game to get a hell of a redemption arc like Cyberpunk 2077, Battlefield 4, Halo MCC...and yes, even No Man's Sky, one of the games that Starfield gets compared to the most (the others being Elite Dangerous and Scam Citi- I mean Star Citizen). In short, while I can't recommend this game, it also shouldn't be outright ignored by anyone, both players and Bethesda alike...there's a lot of potential here, waiting to be tapped into.

My advice is this: if you wanna give this game a shot, get it for as cheap as possible or play it with Xbox Game Pass (On a side note, I do hope Game Pass gets proper Steam integration soon).

Starfield is as epic as an RPG can be.  It's not just an adventure action game, it's the base and foundation of hundreds of possible games you can make it.  You can explore a thousand worlds, all with their own vistas, weather, and possible alien life.  While you're there, take some shots, go on a photo safari, and if you like it enough, you can build a habitat there whether you can breathe the air or not.  Of course, the game has it's RPG story lines, full of factions and moral conundrums, most fraught with danger and combat.  Puzzles and storytelling as Bethesda is known for is folded in and familiar.  One large DLC has already been added, and more are on the way.  Perhaps, after you've played for 500 or 1000 hours, you can then dive into the rich and diverse number of Creations and mods to improve and customize your UI or add to the already incredible number of ships, bases, clothing, weapons, and objects you have access to.  Don't listen to the hate, and get yourself a copy of Starfield.

I've been with Bethesda a while. From Morrowind to now, I've enjoyed my time. When I heard about Starfield, I was very excited. If they had simply put Skyrim in space, this game would be wildly popular. However, that's not what happened.

I made my way through the main story. It was not bad and relatively free of bugs. That was a relief and a surprise given the numerous mistakes of the past. However, I didn't feel good about the story. I've never liked being the main character and quickly started a new character upon completing it.

With my new character, I more or less ignored the main story and opted to do things my way. Explore, try out new things, play the game my way. That did not go so well. I quickly found that pretty much every game system had tons of bugs. I couldn't build a reasonable outpost. Rocks kept following my ships around causing the game to crash. Quests didn't work. Everything I have come to expect from the open alphas we call game releases quickly came true for Starfield.

This was very frustrating, so I turned to mods. Mods are what saved Skyrim, and maybe they could do the same for Starfield. Not so much. Mods added a lot, allowed me to play my character more freely, design better outposts, build better ships, avoid poorly thought out systems from the original game and so on. However, it was still the same problem. The base game is so rigid and unforgiving. Everything looks and feels like it was half developed and there are simply not enough mods to fix it.

So, I gave up. Maybe after the modders have a decade with it, the original game will be mostly gone and a new better Starfield will be born from the generic ashes. Go buy something else. This is not it.

Approaching 40 hours on PC + 70+ hours on XBox.

The many complaints in the reviews and the forums are obsolete in that modders have fixed all major game flaws. I will dismantle here the many complaints:

- A 'Perk Wall' system where you don't get immediately all the goodies. Right, did you play other Bethesda games? Hello...
- Fast-Travel is against immersion. Right, but you don't have to do it, fly manually to every orbit first before landing.
- POIs on planets are all the same? NO. Not anymore since there are good free mods to load, some of them linked to mission boards also, some doing their own story. 
- The story sucks? Maybe for you. Don't play the story, get missions on mission boards, explore, make your own story.
- You can't fly over planet surfaces? You don't have to, there is a vehicle in the game now to move faster and with the last update you can explore the entire planet surface (the map moves with you and procedurally generates unknown territory of the planet as you move on the map.)

All the negative arguments against the game are poorly justified, SF remains in the tradition of other Bethesda games, that was and is to be expected, before you think to buy it don't forget that SF is much more an RPG in space, not a space game. My recommendation is therefore for a good RPG with a lot of action and it works well.
Fun

Starfield... is a game with one thousand planets. And it works.

As Todd Howard would say... "It just works." And functionally, he's right. It is perhaps Bethesda's least buggy game to date. But here's the thing about functionality it doesn't always equal soul.

You travel from planet to planet, each one a barren husk of potential, a cosmic sandbox with nothing to do but find rocks. Temples float in space, offering you powers that are essentially Skyrim shouts... in space. And somehow, that sentence sounds more exciting than the experience itself.

The quests... are boring. There’s no other way to put it. Your companions? Equally boring. All paragons of virtue, like they were assembled in a lab focused on creating the most inoffensive AI personalities. They all agree with you. They all love when you make good choices. It’s like adventuring with a team of HR representatives.

And when you pick a space religion... the game nods. Once. Maybe twice. Then forgets. Role-playing in Starfield is not a journey. It’s a costume. A trait that’s only skin-deep.

The Settled Systems the world Bethesda spent years crafting feels like the sci-fi version of a gated community. It is sterile. Sanitized. A place where nothing dares to offend. A future built by people who listened to John Lennon’s Imagine... and took it literally. It is perhaps the safest vision of a post-colonial space civilization ever conceived in gaming.

This... is Bethesda at its worst.

Gone are the messy but passionate days of Skyrim. Even Fallout 4, divisive as it was, had something Starfield lacks: fun. You could lose yourself in that world. You could mod it into something wild, chaotic, beautiful.

And mods... haven’t saved Starfield. Maybe they can’t. The community hasn’t embraced it the way they did before. And Bethesda, ironically, has started selling paid mods on their storefront. So even creativity now comes with a price tag.

What are we left with?

A game that "just works."

And tragically... that's the best thing you can say about it.

Exploration? Empty.
Quests? Dull.
Lore? A shadow of what it once was.

In the end... Starfield doesn’t feel like a leap into the stars.
It feels like a fall from grace.
I love Fallout and I love Starfield! There's so much content to it, so many side quests which I love, and so many different things you can do. Build, explore, craft, create relationships.

The game follows the typical Bethesda formula of combat, explore, collect, craft known from their Fallout and Elder Scrolls series. This is a space setting, and I generally like those. I can forgive the loading screens that the game was so heavily critised for. It is weird that the game launched without ground vehicles. The cities are not meant to be travelled by vehicles, and vehicles are overpowered if used in combat. Vehicles do not feel like a natural part of the game. While the vehicles seem overpowered, the player can visit temples to acquire supernatural powers, but I hardly felt a need to use these powers during the game.

Like with other Bethesda games befor it, I find myself walking around too much, carrying around too much. The only solution the game offers to this problem is to get rid of superfluous things myself. I cannot command robots around me to deposit stuff for me on the ship.  I also have to visit shops, the vanilla game does not offer buying or selling by galactic mail. With the need for walking a lot, the game actually falls behind our current times.

I have completed the quest achievements in the main game, and I enjoyed the game enough to play a "new game +", where I can replay the game while keeping my character. However, many achievements actually focus on things that are quite boring to do, like visiting every star system or reaching a high character level, Those are boring achievements that reward mindless repetition rather than creative thinking.

While some of the quests are well-written with surprising twists, I wish that other quests had more possible solutions. The mission that felt most incomplete was "First Contact", where you have to choose between helping the crew of a generation ship or a corrupt board of leaders who simply happened to arrive first on a planet. Unfortunately, the game does not offer a really satisfying solution to this mission. A fair ending would see both factions governing the planet together, at least until my next space jump. Failing that, the board of executives deserves a thorough treatment with ranged weapons for their arrogance. While the game allows me to blow up the generation ship by overloading their reactor, a similar solution is not offered for the corrupt board of leaders down on their cozy planet, and that feels unfair, although I am allowed to bring ranged weapons to the meetings. The solution of leaving the crew of the generation ship as slaves really feels wrong. "New game +" allowed to follow this route to see if there is anything good about this choice, but it really left me feeling bad for a crew who struggled for generations to reach that planet.

I still feel that this kind of criticism is on a high scale, because I do enjoy playing the game for the most part.

A good game.  Wonderful environments that are rendered well.  Good voice acting, and the story is decent, but certainly nothing amazing, and the dialogue is silly at times.  The faction quests are excellent, and some of the side quests and companion quests are quite good as well.  Space combat might not be as exciting as something like 'Everspace 2' or 'Elite Dangerous' or even the old 'Freelancer' game, but I've enjoyed it, and this is partly due to the truly excellent shipbuilding/modifying that you can do (this is one of the game's strengths).

The game's ground combat is quite good, but the base-building and trading is mediocre at best (IMHO).  I did feel like the main factions should be busy building and doing things and a dynamic economy would be nice.  More should be done to make the game's world feel alive.  That is, after all, one of Bethesda's stated goals--to create the feeling of stepping into a living world when you play their games.  However, the world of 'Starfield' feels static and unresponsive.

Also, even though the environments are great (Neon, Akila, New Atlantis, Mars, Titan, etc.), they're too small.  For example, the base on 'Titan' looks great, and the moon is surprisingly realistically created, but the base on Titan is supposed to be like an underground town or small city.  There's even a place where the poorer people live, and you're expecting a village, something like the crates section in 'Cyberpunk 2077' (with the expansion), but instead it's only a few people living in a couple crates--not a slum.  It needs to be bigger to at least create the illusion that this is a town.  For the price and Bethesda's resources, I think they should have delivered a bit more in this regard.

Finally, I should mention that there are a lot of mods and dlc available when you go into "Creations", which is nice (though you'll have to pay for points, but the prices are reasonable).  Some of the content comes from within Bethesda while others are from independent modders, and some of the additional content is quite good, so that's always a nice bonus.  Lot of mods on Nexus too.

To summarize, this is not a perfect game, but it is a very good one, and it's about the most realistic futuristic sci-fi game I can think of.  However, with that realism does come some drawbacks.  Most planets in outer space are either lifeless rocks or gas giants, so if you want the feeling of exploring outer space as it actually is, this game was meant for you.  If you want an action-packed space opera, you'll probably be disappointed.  This game is more '2001: A Space Odyssey' than it is 'Star Wars'.  More 'Star Trek 1' than 'Star Trek 2'.

You know when you get that pull to boot up Skyrim again for the 50th time and you end up sinking another 100+ hours in spontaneously? I get that with this game here and there.

But the difference with Starfield is every time I come back and create a new character I always end up getting bored and falling off at the same point, normally around the time that the game fully opens up and you can build bases, or get new ships and customise them. I think that's because it's around this point you remember, or if you're playing for the first time you discover, that this game is just an empty shell with nothing but copy paste activities and an incredibly uninteresting main story and side stories that just leave me feeling absolutely nothing inside afterwards. I have to admit they did a tremendous job promoting this game and letting our imagination run wild with the possibilities that this game had to offer, advertising it as a "Skyrim in space" type of game, but that set the bar too high and I cannot and will not bring that bar down to where this game actually sits because skyrim was full of fun an interesting things to do, this game has none of that.

Just playing the game feels like a chore, even if this game is on sale I wouldn't recommend it, hell even if it was free I wouldn't go near it. There's just nothing to do in the game that's worth spending time on.

It has been one and a half years since the game was released, and it's still a buggy mess. Within three minutes of loading the game, I encountered a failed transition/load screen that prevented me from powering up my ship and geometry that almost completely blocked my view. When I got out of the pilot seat, I was greeted by the wireframe meshes of my ship intersecting with another that was a part of a random event (UC Ship Seeking Repair Parts). Upon reloading, I discovered that my newly acquired and upgraded ship had a reactor bug that had caused the power of my replaced reactor to be added to my new reactor, giving me 32 power instead of 18. As I set course to land on a planet, I was greeted with a load screen that showed my ship oddly tilted forward as it landed, resulting in the landing gear and landing bay being embedded in the terrain. Not to mention that I previously had to turn down all of my graphics settings to prevent the game from crashing. 

Reflecting on the game's issues with quality control and technical limitations, its overly simplistic approach to storytelling, and its cookie-cutter approach to game design. I'm left with the impression that Starfield's game design and development are deeply rooted in a culture of insecurity and risk aversion, which is driven from the top down (This may explain their sale to Microsoft). Such that if its graphics were stripped away, you could be forgiven for confusing it with a game developed 20 years ago, yet it's no Freelancer (2003), and it's certainly no Mass Effect (2007).

Ultimately, Starfield feels like a safe game that exists more for the financial safety of its developer, publisher and owner than the enjoyment of its audience. To achieve this, it appears that the developer has been compelled to cut a lot of corners and remove any rough edges that may have jeopardised the game’s general appeal. Resulting in what is overall a bland and empty experience that has had to be taped together using loading screens.  

Can it be a fun game? At times, Yes. 
Does it deserve an approval rating of 58%? Also Yes. 
Will Microsoft step in to take away the developer's safety scissors? Only time will tell

There is entertainment to be had in Starfield, but for the most part it's all things that other games do much, much better.  If you want a Bethesda style RPG, all their previous ones have much better writing and are more fun to play.   If you want a space-faring RPG that starts with getting a strange vision from touching an alien relic, the Mass Effect games are amazing.  If you want to explore procedurally generated planets, build bases, and craft your own starship try No Man's Sky,   Only buy Starfield if you are morbidly curious and bored.

8/10 game.  Solid good fun if you like Space RPG set in a space-faring future, with a minor factory-automation system build in as well.  
Yes it is a bit glitchy sometimes, it's built on the same engine and by the same team as the Fallout series so don't expect perfection. 
Yes there are a lot of totally barren planets where the only thing to do is look at the stars... but the stars are lovely. 
And there are also several worlds with wildlife and a small ecology:  small scavengers, larger herbivores, and predators.  The herbivores usually leave you alone, but the predators look at you and see "dinner."
And other worlds might have small cities, or pirate bases, or strange alien ruins, or good spots to mine for ore, ... 
And you can decorate the inside of your ship or your home with some pretty nice furniture, too, if that's your thing.
And there are a lot of mods... though most of them try to turn it into a Star Wars game for some reason.

Now, honestly, as vast as the galaxy is... it's very empty.  There are more barren uninhabited planets than there are worlds that support life (as we know it).  But it's all there for you, if you choose to see it.  And even on barren worlds you'll sometimes find a random event happening... like a space-pirate attack, or a happy meeting with a group of travelers.  You'll build and fly your own spaceship... in fact you can own a whole fleet and swap between them anytime you land at a spaceport.  Use your ship to battle pirates, or to become a pirate yourself.  Steal enemy ships... then sell them or keep them for your own collection.  Or become a mining magnate by building outposts on various worlds to extract resources like iron, neodymium, and the galaxy's fuel source of choice - helium-3.  Or build a more advanced system of outposts and automate factories across the galaxy to pull resources in from various planets where you have mines, and turn them into manufactured goods that are worth more when you sell them.  Or you can just fly around looking for "random events" to happen.  The galaxy isn't totally devoid of life, but there is definitely more empty space than inhabited space. 

The main quest will have you working with a company of explorers and scientists to find a bunch of strange alien artifacts, and eventually you'll start to gain super-powers.  Nothing super flashy, but it will make you feel like you might not be entirely human anymore.  And then you meet a reclusive group who... well I won't spoil it for you, get out there and see it for yourself.  Along the way, you can join up with the pirates, the frontier cops, the space-navy, or ALL of them.  You'll build and fly your own ship, which you can DECORATE inside and out.  You can even buy a house and decorate it, too... several options are available in the vanilla game and a few more throughout the galaxy if you look for mods.

Combat - both on foot and in space - is pretty simple to figure out, not terribly difficult.  But it's not supposed to be "really hard" it's supposed to make you feel tough when you can wipe out a team of pirate raiders and steal their ship... hehe.

For building outposts (for mining and factory) I recommend you go watch some YouTube videos on how to be successful.  The system is not super intuitive to learn, but once you figure it out it's actually not that hard.

The game also comes with a "Creations" system where you can download officially supported mods from the community.  SOME of them cost "creation credits" which you have to spend real money to buy.  But there are a lot of free mods, and the ones you can find (mostly for free) on Nexus Mods website also work if you know how to install them right - which is easy.
But even if mods aren't your thing, there will be two that you will find ABSOLUTELY INDESPENSIBLE and they should have been included in the main game from day one.  You'll have to buy about ten bucks of creation credits to get them though, they are not available for free.  The first is "Astrolabe" which adds a search bar to your map of the galaxy, so you don't get lost as often.  The second is "Compendium" which is a cross-referenced catalog of all the ores, minerals, gases, plants, animals, etc. on each planet.  If you plan to build outposts this tool will be your very best friend.  Aside from those, there are mods that make the game HARDER, and there are mods that feel like you're cheating, and mods that make it "prettier," and mods that add more weapons, armors, and spaceship pieces into the game.  It's a sandbox, much like Fallout 3 and 4 were, but with a larger scope.  

But is it FUN?  It can be.  If you enjoy immersive RPG set in a sci-fi space-faring future.  Or if you enjoy factory automation in a LIGHTWEIGHT style, no min/maxing needed.  Or if you want a game that makes it feel like you're a character in a movie for a little while.  I'm enjoying it. 

New Game + takes away all your items, all your money, your spaceships, your quest progress... 
But you keep your unlocked skills, your XP levels, and they give you a pretty cool spaceship and spacesuit-armor set when you reboot the universe.  The point of NG+ is to go around the galaxy and collect all the artifacts again, while simultaneously exploring MORE alien temples that improve your super-powers.  Those powers can be leveled up like that 10 times, so you can get some benefit from playing 10 NG+ universe reboots... but that will take FOREVER and even I will probably get bored after the first or second NG+ run.

So yeah, bottom line:  it's  8/10 game.  Sandbox RPG, in space.
Bethesda once again pushing out a great sandbox to play in.
But mod the heck out of it.  almost uplayable in its vanilla state.

Interesting ideas...but very flawed execution.  Ironically, despite one of the better ideas for replaying through a game in a long time, they created no incentive to do so.  The main scenario or any other quest or mission never changes even one iota...and your actions never really matter to the universe you are occupying currently.  They used procedural generation to create 1000's of planets, but only created a bare handful of things to put on them, so you are seeing the exact same things over and over and over again.  Same enemies, same dungeon layout, same everything.  Which largely does not make sense due to the supposed difference of cultures and governments and people.  Once you play through the main scenario and do a few sidequests, you are done with the game, since there is no real reason to level your character or try and see a different universe.  The DLC?  Added ONE new planet with a handful of new things, and it in NO WAY has any affect on anything else in the game world.  They have yet to even remotely address the copy and paste methodology...it's baked in pretty hard.  Yes I have invested a lot of hours into this game, just trying to see if anything else could be fleshed out.  I can confidently say that there's just not much here.  I'm not sure why this is a RPG with levels and stats other than that Bethesda only knows that style of games.  They might have created a better product if they focused less on needless rpg leveling and instead created things that people actually want to see and play with.  Definitely an rpg that makes leveling irrelevant despite a focus on such...very weird.

i'll be upfront and say i enjoyed starfield, but i don't recommend it to other gamers.  usually when i recommend a game, it's because i think it's something that can be enjoyed by folks from all kinds of backgrounds and of all kinds of tastes either because it's well-made, well-written, well put-together, or whatever -- you know, the works.

starfield's space and exploration aesthetic, as well as the bethesda DNA (yes!  it's still there, just perhaps in its worst form), are doing a lot of the heavy lifting for me, but its numerous flaws and sloppy, half-hearted execution in nearly all aspects of the game prevent it from being an authentically great one.  it's a shame, because even the most unforgiving player can see the boundless potential this game could have, but will never come to fruition, given the state of today's bethesda.  and don't even get me started on how outdated the creation engine is...over a decade and they still can't figure out why many outfits -- vanilla or modded -- sometimes don't load and remain invisible.

so all that, combined with the fact that any hopes of modding to fix or save the game have been crushed by bethesda's successful push for paid mods, the future of this game (and probably even TES6) is bleak.  i've played and enjoyed my fill, but given its future prospects, unless numerous changes and fixes are made, i will likely never fire it up again.

No game has ever touched me the way Starfield has. I firmly believe that it is Bethesda's greatest product and achievement, but I've been here before. I've explained it many times to many people why Starfield is good, actually... but, will you listen?

Maybe this time it'll be different. Maybe this time I can change things. Maybe not.

Starfield is every bit as good as No Man's Sky, Elite Dangerous, or whatever other space game you've spent hours on. In the following overview, I am going to use a series of shapes to represent what each game does, and doesn't have.

Starfield: ⬤
Star Citizen: ■
Elite: Dangerous: ▲
No Man's Sky: ⬧

I need you to trust me when I say that I am being objective about this. Starfield does have its problems, but they have been exaggerated. I really do mean that. So, let's begin.

Interesting Worlds - ⬤ ▲⬧
Well thought out Characters - ⬤ ▲
A good story - ⬤ 
A thoughtfully constructed universe - ⬤ ■ ▲ ⬧
Good Gunplay - ⬤ 
Good Piloting - ⬤ ■ ▲⬧
In depth Ship Customization - ⬤ ▲⬧
Replayability - ⬤ ■ ▲⬧
Roleplaying Mechanics - ⬤ 
Base Building - ⬤ ▲(colonization counts honestly) ⬧
Meaningful Progression - ⬤ ▲⬧
Character Customization - ⬤ ▲ ■
Loading Screens - ⬤ ■ ▲⬧

Starfield's not lacking in any of these.

-------------------------
Worlds
-------------------------
Starfield is rife with beautiful worlds that are absolutely photo-worthy, and all of them are procedurally generated outside of specific instances. If you think Star Citizen's are not procedurally generated, you really may want to think that one over. Core instances are not, but the rest absolutely is. (Probably serverside. But you know not every mountain and field is hand crafted.) Starfield's biggest problem there is that it has such a limited array of POIs and interactions. Yeah, it's really weird to find a cave with bones on Luna, and there really should be measures to prevent that. But, that's what happens when you build a single player game designed to compete with overhuge MMOs. I'd have narrowed Starfield's focus quite a bit were I in charge. Be that as it may, my gallery of amazing sights only grows.

I can not overstate the level of achievement Bethesda managed to pull off here, with Starfield's "Settled Systems". The amount of thought and effort put into each planet's properties, orbits, the ways they interact with each other, it's some really mind boggling stuff. Elite's is easily the best of that, but their engine is designed for it.

Somehow, Starfield did that on Creation. I *still* do not know how.

-------------------------
Characters
-------------------------

Constellation's cast is fantastic. As is The Vanguard's. The Freestar Rangers are great too. UC Sysdef and Crimson Fleet are if nothing else, memorable, and Ryujin's characters, while honestly odd in the context of a space exploration game, was really good too.

I don't know many characters from Elite. Everything they do happens in the background with no meaningful impact on the world. I've never heard of a character from Star Citizen, and No Man's Sky is anathema to the concept of characters. All three of those games are big open worlds where you and the other players are characters. I know that NPCs you can run into in NMS are apparently memorable, but nobody's ever given me a name.

But I can tell you the story of Sam Coe, a single father who's really struggling with it. I can tell you about Andreja, the displaced member of House Va'ruun. I could go on about Sarah Morgan, a woman who's had a lifetime of adventures in the last decade. Goodness knows I can talk to you about Barrett. That's just four examples. They're very well acted, well thought out, meaningfully interactive characters. They'll call back to actions of yours, things you've said, even their romances feel really good. I'm a very married woman who loves my wife very much, and it's actually quite impressive to me how genuine the acting and presentation of interpersonal relationships feels. Given the game is about how we all effect one another, how we deal with loss, moving on with the world and life, this shouldn't come as a surprise, but the characters of Starfield deserve recognition. I really like them all, even the utter bastards.

-------------------------
Story
-------------------------

Elite doesn't really have a story. It has a developing narrative that the devs guide gently. Yeah, the Thargoid invasion happened and those of us who participated in it had an effect - but to say it's a story is... lacking, I think. Star Citizen wholly lacks one, and frankly I'm not sure what No Man's Sky's is.

Starfield, though? Starfield is about discovering a mystery beyond your comprehension, but you get wrapped up in it. Starfield is about becoming part of something more and meeting new people, about learning who they are and what they've been through. You're likely the youngest gun in Constellation outside of Cora Coe, but your accompanying cast is all in their 30s and 40s, some even beyond that in their 50s and 60s. Walter Stroud is a rare character that way. I know this is the story section, but I have to go off about how aged a majority of the case is. Nobody's truly new to the job, but everyone's going into this mystery unprepared and ill equipped. The characters are all mature, and have beliefs and convictions informed by their lives.

You end up discovering what the story about the artifacts is, what they lead to, why they're being collected. It's a cosmic mystery without much of a definitive answer, but the answer really lies in how it makes you feel. On my main, I won't go into NG+. but going through just one NG+ has left a profound impact on me... and that's not even getting into what happened to me when The Death, occurred.

Few games have made me stop everything to put it all down and cry. Starfield has, and continues to. Fallout can make me sad, The Elder Scrolls can make me think and maybe even be mad, but Starfield can make me *cry*.

-------------------------
Universe
-------------------------

Elite, NMS, and Star Citizen do all have well thought out universes with factions and characters and gameplay that is informed by it. I won't deny that. It'd be intellectually dishonest to assert otherwise. Elite's is far future and a bit blase to me, Star Citizen's world is... I mean as unfinished as the product, and truth be told I know little about NMS' world. But I do know about Starfield's.

Starfield's world, its universe (and beyond) is a NASA Kid's playground (Hi, that's me! NASA kid! Through and through.) Starfield is for the stargazer. For the kid who wanted to be an astronaut, who wanted to be aboard a space shuttle. Starfield is for that person. It isn't for the person looking for a sci-fi military epic or a huge war, it's *about* the wonder of space, and the universe informs that. I could go on about the "Set design" of the ships, particularly Nova Galactic's interiors (AUUGGHH SO GOOD), about how the food is all thoughtfully packaged, about how the CHUNKS brand is inspired by existing space foods (technically, it ought to be some kind of hexagonal shape. But a cube of Sauvingon is just... *chef's kiss*), about how the spacesuits are big, baggy, clunky. About how almost every door is an airlock (even if that IS annoying!). The whole *world* is built around not just exploring space, but *living* in it. Which I just... don't get from the other games, who feel Transient by comparison. It's such a shame then, that Starfield's outpost building is quite lackluster.

(I reached the character limit. on my tumblr post, here!) https://www.tumblr.com/kcdodger/780581320775680000/starfield-a-review-by-kcdodger?source=share

It's not a horrible game, by any means, but the main takeaway here should be that it is NOT worth $69.99.

Look, I've played Oblivion, Fallout 3, New Vegas, Skyrim, Fallout 4, and Fallout 76; Starfield clearly builds off of 76's C.A.M.P. system but I have encountered a couple of bugs that I have NEVER come across from any of the aforementioned Bethesda games.

I know, I KNOW, "Bethesda games are buggy," I get it, and yet I have not witnessed the bugs in their previous games that I have witnessed in Starfield.
Literally my first Weapons Bench placed and it says it's obstructed so I can't use it.
I tried moving it, reloading a save, loading a prior save, etc yet to no avail.

As I said, do NOT pay $69.99 for this game.

The graphics are beautiful, but I personally don't give a rat's ass about the graphics.
I care about a smooth gaming experience with minimal, not non-existent just minimal, bugs.

So get this when it's at its lowest and you won't regret it, but buy it at its full price, because you've been fiending for a new Bethesda RPG, and you'll be sitting here thinking "When will I learn not to buy AAA games at their full price?" just like me.

I played this game when it released and I'm still pissed off. This was the most boring Bethesda game I've ever had the displeasure to play. It does nothing well.
