This game is seriously, seriously underrated, in a way nobody and everybody seems to be looking for at the same time.

Many call it "boring". But you know what it is? Deeply, deeply relaxing. A universe to explore to yourself, run locally, no DRM or servers that will go down some day, without grand themes of a space opera, or saving the universe, or having the burden of the galaxy on your shoulders. No choices with insane consequences for everyone and everything. There's you, your ship, a vast universe in front of you, (genuinely well written! see below) friends besides you, and wherever the road takes you, and choices that affect people along the way. That's it. People. Help or hurt people if you're so inclined.

We all want freedom of choice. To make our own fun. Well *this is it*. Do you really want it? I vote yes. This is my universe to retreat to and I like it *because* it's less grand, and closer to reality. *Science* fiction, not science fantasy. That makes it comforting, to see a universe where there's giant crises sure, but they can be understood. And people just do their thing. As people. Not grand overlords, or larger than life heroes. People who do their best. No elder gods, no blending of science and spiritualism, just a ship around me, interesting characters beside me, the stars in front of me. Adventures that really are *adventures*, of my own making or not.

I really do like the characters. They're not dependent on dangling fancy character designs in front of our eyes like jangling keys, because they're written to be...well, people. Like you meet on the street, for good and bad.  And as far as the main cast goes I really dig the voice acting.  Background NPCs too, they're Fallout 4 quality at least. Pro tip, turn off the dialogue camera, everything *immediately* stops feeling like Oblivion and much much better.

Another great thing here; though the maps may be largely procedural, every single planet, plant, creature, is handcrafted in a very Bethesda way. Every single biome of every single planet will have completely different animals, but they're not procedurally generated sloppy-feeling things like No Man's Sky does (all of my love I could possibly give to that game though xoxo, another favorite). For example, I landed on a random iceball, and saw there were plants and animals...and suddenly got really freaked out, because the animals walking around had the same names as the plants. Apparently, on that small little rock, when the plants grow up enough, they get up, start walking, and start hunting. It was horrifying and so much more horrifying because it was completely wordless. Lots of stuff is like that, love it so much.

This is by *far* the best Bethesda engine for modding. One of the best for anything. This is a trillion times better to mod for than any of the other Bethesda games, that includes installing and creating. Some of the common tools don't work because not enough people have sat down and given this game a fair try, but installing manually is genuinely seamless. I'm not kidding. No mod manager and I think I'm up to 40+ and a script extender, and not light stuff either. I hope that illustrates how much less spaghetti code is going on here; I'm genuinely astounded. This is also my favorite shooter of them all even just using my controls.

Last note, a super interesting one to me, something is *deeply* atmospheric about this game. It's seriously creepy, but in a very, very Bethesda way. Something is not normal here. At all, in a very very interesting way. The thing that first struck me in an incredibly unnerving way was finding some familiar faces on the planet of Khayyam II, Khayyam system :) No spoilers from me, but keep your eyes on the wildlife there, and let me know if that freaks you the hell out like it did me. Very different but equally upsetting vibe from the walking plant planet, maybe a little worse.

Quick summary to wrap up:
Genuinely incredible game if you want to adventure through the stars without losing your mind stressing out trying to save them. Good Bethesda writing as much as anything ever was IMO, putting aside rose tinted glasses and recognizing *everything* else they do is no different, just this is a little subtler, was a life saver. Handcrafted creatures to find everywhere you go. No DRM, no servers that will ever go down, really good modding capacity, good ship and ground combat, good vibes all around. I guess the question I would recommend you ask most when deciding whether or not to buy this is, do you want yet another "reinventing the wheel from the ground up, this must be everything" game? Cause that's valid. Do you want a really, really, really good RPG that knows what it is, does its best to be a really good RPG without throwing the genre out with the bathwater? That's valid too. If you picked the second answer, I recommend this game more than anything else for years, and years, and years. This gives you *so much freedom* in *balance* with you as a player. It's not your galaxy, but your life to live and path to wander in it. Seems like a lot of people *cough cough organized review bombers* don't want freedom like they think they do.
I genuinely regret buying this game.
todd really got me this time :(

Starfield is a little big game.  It's not bad, but certainly nowhere near the marketing hype, and not Bethesda's best work.  If you want it, wait for a sale.

One of the things I love about Bethesda's previous games, like the Fallout and Elder Scroll series, is that the world's felt large and textured.  Unfortunately, Starfield feels rather shallow and small.  Some have expressed the opinion that it's the games heavy reliance on fast travel, which is certainly part of it, but I believed it's largely because of the way it uses procedural generation. 

Beyond the relatively few specific locations Bethesda created, once the novelty wears of, the rest of what's being generated quickly becomes repetitive and boring.  So instead of using it flesh out a world,  it's hundreds of worlds with the same hand full of structures and environments.  Loot is everywhere, credits are easy to obtain, base building isn't all that important, and player homes are largely just storage and cosmetic.
yes.

[h1] I don't know. I tried to like this game. Maybe it isn't for me. [/h1]

I guess I'll write my review based on their talking points in the Steam listing. This was my experience based on my play style, if you enjoyed the game, I'm glad.

[i]"Tell Your story"[/i] 5/10
The character creation is as Bethesda as ever, that being quite in-depth. I guess you can Tell Your story, but the background you choose doesn't really affect your gameplay that much aside from dialogue and the occasional speech check pass. It's a nice touch, but not very well fleshed out. Traits have a bigger impact on your gameplay.

[i]"Explore Outer Space"[/i] 4/10, too much reliance on procedural generation
Yep, you can certainly do that. I don't think "more than 1,000 planets" should be a selling point (and hyped so much in their Starfield Direct livestreams). There's POIs (Buildings you can infiltrate and loot) - there's probably a dozen or so prefab "DANGEROUS BASES" that are procedurally generated across most planets, which sucks. I know they wanted their universe to be just as vast and lifeless as real life space, but it just didn't work in Starfield. I know, LOOK, another Mass Effect comparison! But I think they portrayed the vast nature of outer space in Mass Effect 2 just fine: have a couple dozen very well fleshed out locations (sure, not full planets in ME2, but Starfield could have expanded on that), and open the rest of the planets to extract resources from your ship.

[i]"Meet and recruit a memorable cast of characters"[/i] 5/10
I've experienced my share of memorable characters in games, but the writing in this game is just off. I went through all of the main companion's storylines, and honestly, I don't remember 75% of what I did with them. The only cast of characters I actually remember quite well (not recruitable) is from [spoiler] Operation Starseed, one of my favorite side quests. If you played it, you know it. [/spoiler] Ultimately a lot of my playthrough was solo unless a companion was required.

[i]"Join in the adventures of various factions"[/i] 6/10
Okay, sure, I did like the UC faction storyline. I forgot what I did with the Freestar and Crimson, and Ryujin was not enjoyable imo.

[i]"Captain the Ship Of Your Dreams"[/i] 7/10
They made ships you can move in space. A first for Bethesda games. And honestly, the ship builder is awesome. I spent a good few hours making my dream ship. Then, I realized how pointless space travel was. "High-stakes dogfights" can be tedious as space combat is tedious. "Encounter random missions" actually had some decent side quests. It's not mentioned, but the random encounters are fun.

[i]"Discover, Collect, Build"[/i] 4/10
Discover: Fun for the first hour or two (coming from someone with hundreds of hours in No Man's Sky)
Collect: Tedious.
Build: The outpost system is an afterthought. I'd rather just buy the resources I need to craft stuff, but I can see the joy to some from exploring and collecting resources that might be limited to specific planets.

[i]"Lock and Load"[/i] 8/10
Gunplay is fun, actually a good step up from Fallout 4. Melee is an afterthought.

[i]"Engaging and Tense Storyline"[/i] 6/10 ONLY because of NG+
Oh, wait. That's not in the description. Storyline is 5/10. Again, the writing is just off. The way Bethesda puts it in the description [i]"You will join Constellation – the last group of space explorers seeking rare artifacts throughout the galaxy – and navigate the vast expanse of space in Bethesda Game Studios’ biggest and most ambitious game"[/i] makes it seem (TO ME) more like a sandbox title than an action RPG with an engaging story you need to follow. Once I got down to the last few missions in my first playthrough, I ended up basically speedrunning them because I was just kind of over it. I did play through a few times with NG+ and [spoiler]some of the variations actually shook things up, which was fun. I ended up installing a mod that allowed me to choose which variation I wanted just to see them all.[/spoiler]

[b]Graphics & Engine Rant:[/b] 7/10
Decent graphics, but underwhelming for a 2023 release, and the game doesn't run well for how it looks. I would be impressed if this released in 2018. I know it's your pride and joy, Bethesda, but when I saw the Creation Engine 2 reveal, I knew it would be more of the same jank. And, once I opened your Creation Kit, I discovered it is (mostly) the same jank, just updated. The game is a loading screen simulator - seriously, even loading into tiny buildings. (Seriously, Bethesda, you were developing the game for Xbox Series consoles, which have extremely fast SSDs). At least load times were actually decent unlike Fallout 4.

Soundtrack 6/10. That's all I have to say. It was kinda generic but good enough to where I generally didn't have to put on my own music in the background while playing.

Ultimately, Starfield is a flawed game and I am surprised it took this long to develop, even factoring in updating the game engine to Creation Engine 2. I think the entire review can be summed up by their Steam description: [i]"Starfield is the first new universe in 25 years from Bethesda Game Studios, the award-winning creators of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Fallout 4."[/i] It's certainly a new Universe from an award-winning game studio. A game that I can see people actually enjoy. One that has so much potential and so many great ideas and so much incredible talent behind the name, but it was over-hyped by Xbox, who wasn't really going through the best of times this console generation, and it ultimately underdelivered.

The worst part is, I pre-ordered the $299 Collector's Edition for a carrying case and a watch that feels almost as cheap as your McDonald's Shrek watch, and an underwhelming DLC release. Sorry Bethesda, I know I did this to myself, but never again. Maybe I'll install the game when more game-changing mods release, but it's not worth my 135GB of storage space right now.

Reviewed on a PC with: AMD Ryzen 7 5800X3D, AMD Radeon RX 9070 XT, 64GB RAM, game installed on NVMe SSD.
It is very realistic game and  let you image what is gone be if we are able to travel in space. I think it is the best open world space game.

If I had to describe this game in a single word, there is no better word to use than 'mediocre'. This is the word that comes to mind for the majority of quest in this game, but not only that, it is also the mechanics that are not longer a 'fun feature' but a sign of stagnation, the 'big cities' which are mostly greenery and boulevards with the same old Fallout-type shops, the 'stealth' mechanics in a game that has less need for them than even Skyrim because of it's horrendous design in this aspect, vendors with too few credits, brainless combat 'ai' if you can even call that intelligence, the all present bugs, etc. Is not that Bethesda bit more than it could chew, is that they just became complacent, they seem to rejoice in mediocrity. 

I mean, is the same old Bethesda trope but with a reskin. The problem is that it does not have the backing of a good lore to somewhat hold it up like TES or Fallout (which mechanically are also mediocre games) and we are no longer in the early 2010's. We now have  games like The Witcher 3 Wildhunt, Cyberpunk 2077, Baldur's Gate 3 and Kingdom Come Deliverance 1 and 2. All 4 games put Starfield to shame in world-building, gameplay mechanics and RPG elements, and I'm not even going to mention space exploration with games like No Man's Sky or even Astroneer do way better.

I'm still probably going to complete the main story and maybe play the dlc too, but I won't buy TES 6 if it's going to be this same crap again. Quit the bs with the "physics-based" Creation Engine like it's the cure for cancer and make a proper 2020's game. Oh!, and do your self a favor a fire Pagliarulo, that man has been the worst disaster to ever happen to Bethesda. 

There's an allegory that goes "the size of an ocean and the dept of a puddle". For Bethesda, all their games after Morrowind have become increasingly like this, but for Starfield the ocean has finally dried up. You aren't missing anything if you don't buy Starfield. Don't even pirate it, it's not worth the time or disk space. 132 GB of pure disappointment.
I enjoyed the game on xbox . But with a new fPC and 4k  resolution,  adding in mods . It  is night and day difference.

Okay, I might be softer on this because I wasn't expecting much to begin with, but (with mods) this game has actually been really fun. I've barely touched the main story, only did a couple of radiant quests, and have just been blasting through side quests, and having a blast the whole time. It's actually fun.

Honestly, one of the most boring games I've ever played. There is no subsistence to be had in this world and no fulliment to be had.  There's a 1k planets yet there is nothing to had in any of them the amount of loading screens and bullshit you gotta deal with. Honestly what's the point. Only benefit is they reached a small % of the decades of Skyrim and Fallout 4 mods. But it looks more dated than the current generation of Skyrim moddings.

I feel like AI, when it achieves the ability of building games with creativity and function we will finally see a game that achieves what this game really wanted to be. On the surface the game had lots of potential. There's nothing like hopping into a ship and hopping from surface to space without a cut scene. Hello Games did this well. The sad part is I was waiting for this game to blow my mind...it didn't.  All of the hype that this game started with the hopes and dreams of every space sim player and fell apart with the idea that it wanted to be a space RPG without any of the meat on the bone. Go here...do this task...turn in task...get reward has been around for years. Opening this game up to the mod community could save this title. The potential upside is huge. There are fans willing and able to make a good attempt a great success. I haven't seen an update since November and at this point it seems the devs have given this up to other projects. There was a lot of money spent on the promotional videos...just not as much spent on the depth of game play today's gamers are looking for. From the outside looking in, it felt like there were several teams working on content and they all had opposing ideas and at the last minute they were all thrown together into a soup that left a bad taste in players mouths. I'm hoping we get more out of this title but with the lack of updates I don't see that happening anytime soon. For the price i think it falls short. For now I'd recommend a pass.

A waste of $75. Read the negative reviews and believe them. I've been a long-time Bethesda fan, but after this game, I'll think twice about purchasing a title from Bethesda. This game is soulless, has a terrible UI, awful animations and is just plain boring to play. I tried to get a refund, but because I have over 2 hours of game play, (that's what I get for giving this game a chance) Steam won't issue a refund.

Do not buy this game. There are plenty of other games that deserve your time and money.

A lot of the complaints about Starfield are rather silly in my opinion.  A huge ruckus is made about the fact that space travel is done via menu rather than actually flying there, but that's just not the kind of game Starfield is.  It's a Bethesda first-person action game with a sci-fi setting, not a space flight simulator (which, imo, sounds like a dreadfully boring genre, and I'm glad this isn't one).

There are also valid complaints about Starfield, particularly the side quests and some of the factions.  But in a Steam world where reviews are on a binary and I have to either recommend or not recommend, I'm gonna give it the thumbs up.  It kept me entertained for well over 100 hours, and some of the story turns were pretty interesting.

Absolutely brilliant game. Haters always gonna hate, Bethesda supporters always gonna support.

I see a lot of mixed comments towards this game. Im not sure why and didnt bother reading through them as i did not want anything to ruin my experience. This game is just beautiful, interesting stories and quests. And yes Its not Skyrim or fallout (I think most people expected more of a similar experience and thats where the negative comments come from). Its a different new experience, with some leaving you with a taste of fallout and skyrim, exploring the building on planets or caves, looting and crafting your gear, modifying them and just enjoying the experience. Dont compare them when you are playing, just enjoy what these developers put their heart and soul into. The finer detail of objects and the environment is just insane.

Played it a while. But now I almost saw everything interessting and I got no reason to start the game anymore.

DLC seemed to be a cool idea at first but it's comparable in size to like the other main quests like fleet etc.

Dunno how anyone could invest 10 years in that game or even the time until TES 6 will come out.
The map is huge, full of loadingscreens, pretty empty and repetitive.

Also I don't understand how the game can be that hardware hungry It doesn't even look that great...

I think it's a fine game but not even close to what was promised.
I don't have the time to tell you why it's bad when other's have made good enough reasons why.
If you like Bethesda games you can force yourself to like this, but you will learn that they don't understand why you like their other games.
While a little repetitive, it is still fun.

I personally love the game.

Positives:

- Non Linear RPG Space Adventure 
- A ton of RPG style customization
- Art style is epic and beautiful. Sprawling vast landscapes and BEAUTIFUL ship interiors. Love the bases and computer systems. Everything looks like 1990s NASA but way more futuristic lol. A lot of white.
- Various companions that you can customize in terms of gear and your relationship
- Space travel with a custom ship that includes space combat (NMS does this part better yes)
- It feels like a familiar experience. Feels like Fallout in space. Even the music.
- Feels endless if you want it to be
- Full Base building
- Combat is brutal and fun. Good ragdoll and the gravity will come into play

Cons: 

- The writing and voice acting isn't amazing if you compare it to something like Cyberpunk, but it is still good. The trackers Alliance was really cool for example and I really enjoyed meeting all those bounty hunters and hearing their stories. Main story is cool. 

- Too many menu screens when doing space travel, but its not game breaking to me at all
- I wish I could give orders to my companions in combat
- Some dialogue is sleep inducing and too many npcs have things to say lol (Some might like this)
- Melee combat could be better with the sword imo

Oh and LOl at all these self righteous dudes coming at me with some bs about "have you even played a true rpg like pathfinder though"? lmao. yes, yes I have. I ACTIVELY play Neverwinter Nights still. Starfield is a great fucking rpg regardless. I never said it was the same as a crpg. Get a life.
i could tell it was bad from the literal beginning of the game

I wouldn't have said it on release, but in it's current form it's fun. Original stories, lovely RPG gameplay, and plenty of mods. My complaint comes in how convoluted and unnecessarily complicated they've made mods. Its a bethesda game at the end of the day. Don't overhype skyrim. If you loved Skyrim you'll love this.

Don't bother, gave it more than enough time to get interesting and it just got more stale as I went along. Such a disappointment. Mind numbing CGI environments may as well be a copy paste job of No Mans Sky, at least No Man's Sky got the exploration down to a smooth process without all the loading screens. Then it is basically Fallout 4 with no VATS and a vastly less interesting world. No point in exploring, once you've seen a few planets and random locations, you have seen them all, they just get copy and pasted back in, with everything identical. No way this game can be redeemed, the modding community already gave up on it and went back to Fallout and Elderscrolls, you know, the games that made Bethesda what they are today. This game doesn't pull you in, it just smacks you in the face with another loading screen and CGI travesty while making you wonder why you paid money for it. If they wanted to showcase how boring space can be, they succeeded.

Empty, repetitive planets. After 5 hours you have seen every enemy type, every weapon type and every armor type. The story is redundant and boring. The "powers" are lame, I never even used them because they don't fit in this game at all.
Ship building is annoying and frustrating. Nothing to say against base building, I never used it. The citys are also really bland. Some Sidequests are really fun, but others could have been more in depth. There is so much potential in some factions, the history of the war and some planets, but they never used this potential. The companions aren't fleshed out either.
Buy it at a discount if you want a generic open world RPG where everything repeats itself.

This game is great for me. I am a 68 year old man that likes a game that you do not have to work to hard on. I like the mods and some  times need the mods for me to keep playing. I cannot pay for the game and the mods.
I payed for Nexis mods many years ago when i had money and it still works for me. I think Starfield people need to learn what a good looking girl looks like though. They look like Brits when I was in the army. Skyrim modes are real good for this. I play Skyrim if I need to get my heart started again. IT is good for that. Ha Ha HA.
Played a lot, pretty good game.
After finally moving from Game Pass to Steam with Starfield, I must say I,m all in.
Probably the only game that lets players level up to infinity.... Starfield is the gift that keeps on giving.
good game

Played through the campaign on release. The most memorable part of the entire experience is the audacity of Bethesda thinking I'd want to replay this in new game plus. 

Why'd I come back to review it now? Some faint hope that Bethesda would have pumped out consistent updates to try and fix this a la No Man's Sky. But they're a business, and there's no more profit to derive from this mess.

I will be comprehensive.  TLDR though you will learn much, without my preference for how NPCs are and stuff its basically due to being story-heavy  (it might rip you out of the mood) a 5/10, but with NPC mods etc their true vision shines, making it no less than an 8/10 which is exceptional in my book, its a rich and engaging story and the setting is good and game mechanics satisfying.  Yes you can technically play and enjoy a 5/10 in this rating system but why would you if you can make it 8/10.  Always gobsmacked when people come in to ruin projects.  IF you can get mods (and you can) to change NPCs to your liking, or change them yourself, thus dodging anything forced upon you then this game is good.  

Get the mod that always shows landings and takeoffs from the ingame mod section, it should be free or a similar one - should of been done by the games designers, its just way better and makes you not fast travel as much, which in due time is just better for immersion. Then the mod to lower/raise the ramp.  I also get/had to get the inventory and UI mods starUI but I make sure to run starui as vanilla UI - since the UI itself is really good but on PC you want them to run at 60+ fps.  The characters are great but the 'philosophy' not so much in all cases.  Which is meaning to say when this game is not tripping over itself, like someone came in after the fact and changed things for the worse, then its really good from voice acting to the models and the story's.  Long story short you will probably like this game now, many patches, performance upgrades, and whatnot.   

Good story, plenty to do, its a game you can sink your teeth into over time.  I would not preface my recommendation by saying the gameplay is not 'peak anything' or a jack of all trades, the game stands in its own right, but you should take steps to make it less bullet spongy, which is not hard to do.   

Loading screens yes but they go quick, you can grab 100s of objects in a scene, maybe its like that for a reason, just now.  

Got HD textures and planets.  

Lighting - I used enhanced lights and effects.  The lighting and global illumination is very good and shadows, but the aforementioned mod gets over the toned-down for consoles lighting sources.  Its a solid engine though.  Could be upgraded. I made shadows darker via numerous settings as per a mod suggestion.  

I raised variables in the starfield custom file for lighting, some mods tell you to do this, also did it for trees and landscape, another mod gave settings - so I raised one reflections setting its clear where it is/named, to 512, another to 32 and so forth.  This made reflections even better, because the game includes a form of Ray Tracing sort of thing.  It does not need like some video's would have you believe total ray tracing, its still very good and the gains not as much as you might expect for the scene.  Yes technically RT is 'even better wow gee whiz' but for the art style and atmosphere and whatnot, no its not fully needed - you will find it beautiful for sure.  So, too the clouds and stuff - I used a weather mod which just enhanced weather.  Clouds might not be star citizen but the planets are great nonetheless.  If you get a minor proceedual generation mod to clean up a few design choices you might like it even better but pure vanilla is just fine.  One made trees variable in size and some such.  

This title does not need excessive amounts of mods.  Its already smooth and fine as a game + concept.  I have listed mods I did, as per the desire of people to mod it - but its just rounding it out.  It came to my attention they had to cut development short in terms of trappings and extra bits, but its definitely polished.  So mods round this out rather than fix or implement drastic changes.  

All that hinges on being able to change out the NPCs and also a few mods like starvival (turned way down though) and I play with combat set to hard and mine set to easy (so there's no bullet sponges) and you get an AI mod and you get fairly decent combat then.  Yeah so its excellent.  And some ship mods, and the oxygen mod from TNs oxygen mod (turn off starvivals oxygen) (also I turn off starvivals encumbrance system so you still get penalty's but nothing that slows you down
which was never a good answer).   I then of course turn down starvivals food hits and turns down the suit/soak damage and just overall its all a slight tweak for survival.  It should not be harsh as this game relies on smooth/switf movement through the universe, don't fall for the 'harder survival is better stuff', planets are still deadly.  

With all the changes you can make this title you might come to think of it as an 8.5 out of 10.  Skyrim might of been a 10/10, but without making changes especially to the NPCs as the story is reliant on non-ruined NPCs and situations (yes, they absolutely did ruin it and it needed changing; finance people making stakeholders instead of shareholders is a terrible idea, we made this world) then the title is too excruciating and would only get a 5 out of 10.  

I do think they should make it for PC first and not consoles, its a major reason (always why their games can be real bad upon release).  And the artwork and the planets and overall scale and style of the game is really good.  So good, probably one of its best elements - so it all blends in over time, you will almost certainly like this game if you adhere to the above, it'd be impossible not to like it.  

Also, I got a planet procedural mod but nothing drastic changing it just made trees random sized or something (grindfeilds one, but got rid of their others as its too much, planets are meant to be barren but you could get the biomes etc), and I made shadows darker, I would suggest do not use 'clear/neutral LUTS' the game's art style is very good.  I think one mod changes tree sizes up/down etc, but it does not make planets unrealistic, and I got some 'realistic' planet mods.  The game is very cool in many ways.

NPCs when not ruined are simply sublime.  I suggest making them how they should be.  Its a really good title, but caveats.  I have not run into one sub-par quest.  And the conversations take their time, are not wasteful/boring, and the voice acting and npc acting is good.  Yes you do need to change the NPC's its true.

How to put this? hmmm... imagine you are wacthing a cowboy - and you see it acting like a cowboy but its a girl and the wrong country and its doing something wrong because of that - its odd, you would immediately stop and say "NO! Its not meant to be a gymnast! Its meant to be a cowboy on that horse!!!!"

See, it ruins the whole thing.  Thus you can find them.  A color fix mod but it does a lot of rearranging all the wrong NPCs, use that kinda search on based-mods.  So indeed I found one on based mods, the original mod didn't work for them but in the comments they had redone it, thus I finally found one, but I am sure it can be had elsewhere off the nexus.  

The one thing is I had to copy a folder from one of the two 'in the comments' mods and put it into the other update they did, so its really a combo of two mods - but also I had to start a new game so may be thats it.  

The industry has to change back to how it used to be, people have spoken.  Its manufactured to beat you down about it, no one likes what they did, thus it goes easily from 5/10 (forced ruined the game) to 8.5/10.  

Finally - yes there's a lot of loading, however yes the game would be even better if you could fly like star citizen but its not wholly disappointing its not in there - you miss it, sure, but its still a good game.  Planets are meant to be barren, dangerous wastelands.  The only other thing is building is not necessary, a missed opportunity.  But the space ships are good to have and fly nonetheless, you will probably like it because sure people detract from it a lot - but they are overplaying the detraction, its real good when you make it so.

It's fine. Without spoiling it, the post-story game loop kinda kills your desire to make and build stuff. But philosophically, that's kinda plot relevant.

All the romanceable companions are wet blankets. The companions that won't give you a 5 minute moral lecture for punching the wrong person are not romanceable and have like 5 lines of dialog.

Starfield is worth playing for the NASA-punk aesthetic they went for, and to just barely scratch the Bethesda game itch. But it is like the sucralose of Bethesda games. It evokes the same flavor, but it's just not the same, and something feels off the whole time.
It's alright with mods but you're better off getting No Man's Sky.

Here's the thing. I think Starfield is Bethesda's best written game. It's not Bethesda's best story (I think Morrowind keeps that Dwemer Crown), and by far does NOT have it's best cast, but there's a lot of moments in this game that are truly inspired and thought provoking. Bethesda's writers tried to go out there and say something profound, and touch on subjects that truly feel like they touch the edge of the Universe and Life itself.

It's too bad the game is empty as the void truly is.

Sure, there's so many star systems and planets to explore, but you will never find ANYTHING that makes that exploration worth it. In the Elder Scrolls games, you might find a cave with cool weapons inside, a lone house  in the country with a cool quest to find, or some ruin that contains a challenging boss. In Starfield, the only thing you will ever find is man-made outposts full of bad guys with guns. And the only thing of worth you'll ever find are guns and spacesuits to sell.

The ship combat is decent, and while finding/stealing/building your own ships is potentially fun, trying to upgrade your ships is MADDENING. You need to level up multiple skills just to fly higher class ships and get higher class components, and even then trying to upgrade a vital component isn't possible unless you go into the build mode, delete said component and add in the better one... IF IT FITS. The ship building system could be fun but is horribly inconsistent about what parts will connect to one another. I wanted to keep using a few favorite ships, but this system completely blocked me from improving them despite seemingly existing FOR this purpose.

It gives me no pleasure to not recommend Starfield. I wanted to like it, and I played over 225 hours, but while I did find fun and some very profound moments, there was so much useless tedium between those moments, and it just wasn't all that fun. I ALMOST want to recommend it for the frankly fantastic writing, but said writing just doesn't lead to a good overall story, much less any wonders worth exploring.

Starfield offers an expansive and immersive space exploration experience, now further polished with patches and enhanced by the addition of vehicles. The breathtaking universe and engaging gameplay make it a joy to explore, though the occasional lengthy loading times can be a bit frustrating. Overall, a fantastic journey for fans of ambitious RPGs!
Man, I hoped the people were wrong. I really wanted this to be good. But it's not. It looks like a game that came out in 2011. You should just get No Man's Sky.

Good game if your looking for a Bethesda RPG. 

There is alot to do but you have to find it. space between interesting stuff is far greater than other BS games. Take the time to explore. 

Not as in depth as other lore but also a new IP. They could have done better with the main story and should have more armor, more weapons, bigger cities, etc... Alot that could be improved but not bad. 

solid 7/10. Its good but not great. Its super fun if you like exploring space or like the space vibes.

It feels like a Bethesda game. The story is okay, but nothing amazing, I don't really play for the base building aspect, and worlds all feel very similar outside of the main quest locations. But if you basically want Skyrim/Fallout 4 in space this is a fun way to kill your hours.

I've finally got around to give a review.. honestly I share the same sentiment that a lot of other people have already shared. The game just feels empty. Vast emptiness. I just thought after a few years they would've been able to apply some QOL to the game but barely. 

Honestly, I loved the idea of the game- Exploring various planets, engaging with various factions, building bases, building ships, space fights that include boarding enemy ships, but man they just missed the mark. 

Allow me to explain:

-Base building is flawed. It's super frustrating building, whether you're snapping objects, placing objects(to find them glitch through the ground), lighting is atrocious; no matter how many lights you place it just doesn't light up the base and its fucking annoying, storage containers are just annoying managing and take up too much space, not to mention snapping the containers- it's just not easy doing and it seems as if that shouldn't be the case.

-Combat is really dumb. Like where's the diversity in gameplay? The NPCs are oblivious to everything, their accuracy or lack there of is ridiculous. There were very few moments that I felt challenged when it came to combat. The melee weapons are a joke, like you think that'd be quite the opposite, but yeah its a joke. There's a point where you find a weapon, I wont say what type, but it absolutely decimates enemies (the ammo is plentiful which makes it the best weapon in the game especially with its wicked fire rate), this makes it pointless in switching weapons. 

-Starborn powers are cool, but barely impactful. Not gonna lie, I played every faction quest line before finishing the main quest line and I feel like you get some powers way too late in the game. Your guns are powerful enough that the starborn powers don't really matter.

-Crafting reallllllllllllly was lacking in this game. While they offer different crafting options for attachments for guns and armor as well as food and other materials, it's very limited. Food crafting was such a let down. I invested in that perk to see what benefit I could gain from it and honestly, food barely helps, so it was just a waste of skill points. You spend all this time collecting materials, but for what???

-Factions were just poorly written. Like the Crimson Fleet were a huge let down. These are space pirates?? Like they weren't anything close to a space pirate. They were the equivalent to a high school bully. Absolutely nothing cutthroat about them at all. House Va’ruun should've been a more major rather than minor group with what lore was provided about them, but even they were paled in comparison to the Crimson fleet. Overall the politics between factions were very boring.

-NPCs were just.. very very very very boring. Talk about copy and paste. There wasn't anything unique about any of the NPCs. Nothing to cling to. Like they lacked substance- they're all quite forgettable. 

The ending was sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo lame. Like this is how it ends??? This is it? I maxed my character level for this shit? It was super disappointing, I guess I was expecting something more? Like when I finished and went onto to NG+, I uninstalled the game. I mean you build up this arsenal, you advance on the tech/skill tree, you buy/build the best freighter/fighter ship, acquire the best weapons/armor of the game for an ending like this? Very very very anticlimactic.

Overall, I think that Bethesda pushed this out way too early and marketed the shit out of this game, squeezing every penny out of the consumer. I used to love this studio, but now disappointment is just a common thing. I really hope that they really listen to the player base and apply a lot of changes to the concerns that we all have.

I know it doesn't have the same space travel capabilities, but I'd recommend The Outer Worlds over this. It was such a good replayable game that really satisfies that outer space protagonist vibe- combat, dialogue, armors, weapons and skills all just feel good (quite the opposite of Starfield).

skyrim in space with fallout 4 assets because bethseda has gotten bloated and lazy with DEI. Still a good game if you  ignore the main questline. The shipbuilding system could use way way way more parts to work with. I havent looked into the outpost building much, but there is a decent game buried here if you dig around long enough. 
Get it on sale and pray the modding community picks this one up and runs with it one day.

shit!

i liked the expansiveness of it and how you can pretty much be who you want with limitations ofc. i love the new game plus feature although i wont use it its a unique concept. its not a perfect game but it is a 10/10 for me. its got its flaws but its still perfect. if you hesitating giving it another try i say go for it.

As someone who spent hundreds of hours in both Skyrim and FO4, I sadly admit this thing just doesn't cut it.
While there are aspects of the game I did enjoy, starting with ship building through revamped engine and graphics, as well as the overall aesthetic, I just don't feel the urge to come back and finish the DLC.
Procedural generation simply has no place in Bethesda's lineup. You can feel it throughout entirety of the game: the same structures that you instantly recognize despite different planet or biome, same "random" ships encountered in space repeating the same damn comms, pointless terrain filler existing only so the POI can be spread out around an artificial square of generated terrain that is smoke and mirrors wannabe "planet". Quick glance at the map and you can instantly see SF doesn't even try to hide its shortcoming, ostentatiously slapping'em in your face like a hung d**k.

The only saving grace is when bases / POIs are part of a quest - it then feels like the classic Bethesda adventure you came to experience. And this is what they should've stuck with in the first place, instead of cloning pointless planets just for the sake of bragging rights.

It's hard to believe nearly 2 years have passed since release, and we've barely had one story DLC that I honestly didn't care to finish. And that is a sad state of the affair for a developer known for captivating stories and world building.

At 350 hours, I feel it would be unfair to say it's not worth buying. In the end, I've had some fun for what cannot be denied is a big chunk of time. But I don't recommend it at full price - wait for inevitable (summer, winter, Christmas, whatever) sales, and even then manage your expectations. Nuclear dose of suspension of disbelief is required to ignore the glaring problems this game has.

SIDE NOTE: At 70$, this game falls short on its face so this should really serve as a warning before ES5 that's supposedly in the making. But who am I kidding, the flock will zerg-rush pre-orders the second floodgates open.
If it's really cheap might be worth buying, but No Man Sky is better

I have played Starfield for 169 hours now, and while not Bethesda's best game, it is a good game. I purchased the game at launch and was initially disappointed with the finished product. I just recently started playing again and I am glad I did. This game has a lot to offer in building ships and outposts. The story is compelling enough and the side missions will distract you from it. Overall the game has turned around for the better and I can't wait to see how Bethesda continues to improve on this game. (I know they will like screw it up but I am hoping for the best).

Overall I think the game had more potential than it lived up to. Feels like it caught an excessive amount of hate and the devs have abandonded it now. Has great weapons and customizing for them. I’ll admit it — I was nervous about playing Starfield because of all the mixed reviews. But I took the leap… and wow, am I glad I did.
This game sucked me in. Jumping across galaxies, discovering strange new worlds, looting rare weapons and gear — it gave me that pure sense of adventure I’ve been craving. Sure, it’s not flawless, but what it does offer is something truly special if you let yourself get immersed.
If you’re someone like me who’s been on the fence, don’t let the noise stop you. Sometimes, all it takes is clicking “Play” to realize you’ve found something amazing. Go experience it for yourself — it might just surprise you.

I will say, it's a good game and I enjoyed playing it all (haven't done the DLC because not paying $30 for it), however I cannot recommend this unless you get it on HEAVY discount. The shipbuilding is fun, the missions are decent and tell the story and part of the background of the universe. The game is too empty. For this being that humanity has spread to the stars and colonized worlds, war or not, there should be more than 3 settled worlds. It seems like I run into more pirates in space than people in cities, I'd expect more people trying to make a homestead on habitable worlds. 
     Its a good game, I enjoyed playing it, couldn't do more than one playthrough even with all the NG+ shenanigans.

It's really not great, and it's definitely not worth 70 bucks. 

In a single sentence: Starfield feels like Mass Effect if it was made by Ned Flanders. 

In another: Starfield is an exercise in complete and utter mediocrity. 

Beyond the different quest lines, there is very little of interest. The time spent "creating" this massive universe should have been re-routed and put more into refining the combat, quests, and creating more interesting locations. Most planets have some semblance of procedural generation, yet they are generally barren, uninteresting, and not worth the time it takes to scroll through 4 menus to travel to, just to have to go into another menu to actually land on the planet. Points of interest repeat constantly and are generally copied and pasted. For instance, you will find a random named cavern on one planet, and find the exact same cavern on a completely different planet. Deviating from the quest lines WILL create a very boring experience, which is wild when you think about exploring other open-world RPGs made by Bethesda. 

Even then, some of the side quests are entirely there for padding. Do you like running around in an undercity where homeless people threaten to kill you with hammers while you try to flip 3 switches to figure out where the power drain is coming from? I don't.

Many quests also have some disgustingly long "follow 'X'" moments, and that's a major gaming sin with how bad Bethesda's NPC's pathfinding usually is. There have been many times where I had to reset to a previous save because an NPC got stuck on a railing and couldn't figure out how to....Step slightly to the left. 

There is a chunk of factions you can join as well, which all initially have pretty cool story lines, followed by extremely repetitive "Go kill those pirates" or "go rescue those captives" objectives. Sometimes they drop another interesting quest over time, but everything in between those quests is just really annoying padding. 

Starfield is incredibly too large and lacks substance. Take a fishbowl, for instance with the players as the fish. There is no water. There are a few pretty rocks (the quests). There is one dried out log propped against the wall (I'm not sure what this is, but fish tanks usually have one log propped against the wall.)

Anyway:

The whole ship system is clumsy and generally unsatisfying. Personally, I have stuck to buying or stealing better ships, because the ship builder is so poorly implemented that a recently lobotomized man would have a better time trying to build a functional helicopter. Many upgrades are also locked by arbitrary "challenges". You invest a skill point, only to have to turn around and train that skill anyway to be able to invest more skill points into it. Why even have the skill points? Just make it to where you can train specific skills and they auto-upgrade without the use of skill points. This creates a very unsatisfying dilemma because you WILL NOT be able to explore all aspects of character builds on a single playthrough, but I guess this was Bethesda's idea to try to keep players on the grind because the engagement/retention for this game is abysmal when compared to other Bethesda titles.

The base building is just depressing. Again, many things seem to be locked behind arbitrary skill point grinding followed by grinding even more to get to spend more skill points on the same skill. I personally wouldn't know, because the "outposts" are entirely optional, and you can buy/find literally any resource you need at vendors or corpses of pirates, religious zealots, and robots. 

This game has major pacing issues, as well. There's a lot of downtime when getting from point A to point B, and there isn't a ton of interesting or creative things happening in between. The most "random" event you will generally encounter is being threatened by a pirate, but even that just suddenly stops when you get into this groove of moving between the same 4 planets for 3 hours. 

All in all, this is a "Buy at your own risk" type of game. Either wait for a sale, buy from a key reseller, or try to find a moderately entertaining youtuber/streamer to watch and deprive Bethesda of any more money until Elder Scrolls 6 comes out.

This game is essentially Fallout 4 with a jetpack in terms of gameplay.

The campaign is boring, bland, and uninspired.
Fallout 4 is often criticized for its weak campaign and writing, right? Well, this game's writing makes Fallout's writing feel amazing.

The faction quests are also dull; there's nothing special about them. They feel like just another side quest, offering no sense of closure or accomplishment.

The decent quests (and that’s the best you’ll get) are few and far between.

In short, the game doesn’t offer anything more than a basic gameplay loop for those who already enjoy the Fallout formula. That means warping somewhere, killing all the enemies, and collecting random loot.

The constant loading of cells (interiors/planets) is worse here than in any other Bethesda game.

There are more flaws, like the lack of gore, but these are the core issues.
So far I am enjoying this one, I have enjoyed Bethesda games in the past, and I was aware that it was more of that type of game going in.

The campaign is just fucking garbage.

The Shattered Space DLC is not good at all.

The soundtrack is ok, but with the game it's just something you will ignore beside those big problems.

The Base building aspect is fucking garbage and a huge missed opportunity. There are literally thousands of items, objects, buildings, materials, and other assets in this game that could easily have been added to this system and made it a massive base building game, but instead we are limited to ~20 structure pieces & <200 furniture items, most of which are just different variations and near identical to each other.

The ship building aspect is far more satisfying than the base building aspect, but it is still very limited. Building ships is also extremely clunky because certain ship parts can only be attached at specific vendors.

The universe is boring and is just limited to a bunch of solar systems with a sun, gas planets, regular planets and moons. You'll never see anything cool like supernovas, black holes, neutron stars, pulsars etc.

The planets and moons you can visit are just boring procedurally generated surfaces with mostly nothing on them, and they completely lack any weather effects. Even planets in the Sol system lack familiar landmarks like the massive Olympus Mons mountain on Mars for example, and any ocean you find on the planets are only as deep as a puddle.

Space travel is unsatisfying (most due to loading screens).

Ship combat is unsatisfying and kinda boring.

The perk system is a good try but could use some polishing.

Some of the faction quests are fun, but that's it.

Bugthesda game overall that gets nearly no updates and just new shitty paid content (They never heard the word bug fix).

It's a decent RPG is space, it's on par with Bethesda's previous games in terms of quality, and graphically it's beautiful. The gun play is the best Bethesda's ever done, and despite all the criticism this game's received, it's overall a pretty good game.

The game compared to other SPRPG's like Cyberpunk2077, Elden Ring, and even Skyrim from so many years ago, lacks the attention to detail in all of the systems and writing within the game, depth that all of those titles had (excluding Skyrims combat systems)... and also lacking  a real sense of wonder with thought provoking stories and discovery. Its not a bad game, but its also not a great one, like a 6/10 for me. Very vanilla in my opinion, like a game made by workers going through the motions, lacking passion and vision whether it was in the development or leadership or maybe both or just a prioritization of the wrong things... Which is a shame as I was very excited at the time for this game.

I hope the studio doesn't take the criticisms too personally, especially coming from players who genuinely want for the game to be amazing. I hope we get better in the future with Starfield 2 in the games overall depth and ATD. 

To those people who love it, I'm glad for you and hope that love flourishes! To those that were disappointed, me too. Better luck next time, hopefully.

Starfield, Bethesda's ambitious space RPG, launched with sky-high expectations but landed somewhere between a stellar adventure and a buggy mess. It offers a vast universe to explore, with over 1,000 planets, a decent main story, and that classic Bethesda RPG feel—freedom to roleplay, craft, and build outposts. The ship customization is a standout, letting you design your own cosmic ride, and the visuals, especially in space, can be breathtaking.

Pros:

Huge, explorable universe with a sense of scale.
Solid ship-building and combat mechanics.
Engaging faction quests and companion stories.
Improved gunplay compared to past Bethesda titles.
Cons (and Bethesda’s Screw-Ups):

Loading screens galore—every building, planet transition, and fast travel feels like a momentum killer. Bethesda’s ancient Creation Engine chokes here, making the experience feel dated.
Empty planets—many of those 1,000 worlds are barren, with copy-paste outposts and little reason to explore.
Clunky UI and inventory management, a recurring Bethesda sin.
Bugs aplenty: NPCs floating, quests breaking, and performance stutters, even years after launch.
The writing and dialogue often feel stiff, lacking the charm of Fallout or Skyrim.
What Bethesda Fucked Up:

Beyond the excessive loading screens, they leaned too hard into quantity over quality—more planets doesn’t mean more fun if they’re lifeless. The engine’s limitations are glaring, with janky animations and dated tech holding back what could’ve been a next-gen leap. They also fumbled the pacing; the main story takes too long to hook you, and the exploration lacks meaningful rewards. It’s like they aimed for the stars but forgot to pack enough fuel.

Verdict: Starfield is a mixed bag—fun for fans of Bethesda’s formula, but it’s no Skyrim in space. It’s a 7/10 that could’ve been a 9 with polish and ambition better executed.

I'm writing to share my perplexity regarding the low ratings and numerous negative reviews and to ask for your opinion and experience with the Starfield game. 

I'm a huge fan of classic sci-fi movies, literature, and video games (Alien, Prometheus, Space Odyssey, Babylon-5, Life, Mass Effect, Prey, Dead Space, No Man's Sky, Elite Dangerous), and from my experience, Starfield has a lot of connections with the mentioned titles. Although I confirm many negative aspects such as bugs and poor design choices (loading screens, repeatable environments, boring characters, you can unwear your spacesuit on Mars and it will lead to slow heat deterioration, WAT?), there are a lot of canonical sci-fi tropes and references to the mentioned foundations, interesting locations, stories, side quests, planet exploration, abandoned bases with mysterious histories, comfortable controls and UI, space physics, low-gravity physics, space colors, graphics, and so on. 

Do you think my description is too subjective and based on not enough hours of gameplay, or have I missed something which has led to such low ratings?

p.s. I'm not a fan of Bethesda; I dislike Skyrim entirely.

This game is getting preposterously underrated.  

Look, we gotta stay in reality here.  There's plenty to grouse about if you're looking to complain, but this game's amazing.  There are downvote reviews in here with 150 hours of playtime in the game!  If you get two hours of playtime for every USD spent, you're getting your money's worth out of the game, okay?  No it will not solve all your problems, no it won't make you a perfect risotto, no it won't fight crime or solve mysteries, no it won't give your life meaning or purpose, no it won't bring her back.  

It's a video game, not a religious experience.  It's a tremendously fun video game with tons of things to do, including building a base or custom starship, getting into laser fights on an alien moon with space pirates, making a ton of (in-game!) food or mixed drinks or whatever, becoming a space sheriff, becoming a NOC Federation superspy and uncovering a horrifying conspiracy and / or running down alien wildlife in a dune buggy.  It's got a consistent through-line on a massive variety of recognizable sci-fi settings, from Star Wars to Aliens to 2001 to Gears of War to Cyberpunk to Firefly and more.  

There's certainly things to gripe about, but we gotta keep some perspective here.  I notice that the game is missing, say, custom dune buggy ramps for my outpost only because I got it into my head to fill my base with those and make a low-G Hotwheels track in the first place.  So, yes: it feels a bit sterile sometimes, they paid attention to some details (different switches thrown in different cockpits) over others (getting the **** weapons to align in the shipbuilder) and there haven't been that many "whoa, THIS is cool" pleasant surprises that earlier games in the series were so good at.  It feels built-by-committee a bit.  

But sheesh you guys, the game is huge and amazing.  It's got more gameplay than any Mass Effect or Star Wars game we've ever had and far, far, far more Firefly than we'll ever get :(  The price point burns, I know, but it's well worth it.

edit to add: There are definitely still some worthy "holy crap" moments, all the same.  The Entangled quest was up there with being flung into the painting in Oblivion.

So I will preface this saying I genuinely like this game. 430 hours, all achievements, multiple new games plus runs, played the DLC at launch. This game scratched an itch that The Outer Worlds didn't. All of that said there are some serious issues I cannot get past for a full priced game. Warning there will be spoilers for the story.

 It's a Bethesda game, jank engine with issues that come with all Bethesda games. Crashes, texture issues, ect. 
Good story, missed execution. HERE COME SPOILERS. You pretty much start off like you do in all Bethesda games, start off as misc person, something goes wrong and you're thrown into the story make your characters background, ect. But the background you pic, especially each new game plus doesn't really impact your experience or change it especially as you hit NG+ and adjacent in levels and skill trees. The ideal for the multiverse to allow new game plus' I really like, but it isn't done all that well. Your choices font have a huge impact, from my time playing there really isn't any huge repercussions from being evil. Nor do you really feel anything or accomplished for completing what are passed as galactic changing events. As you go to another universe you're shown the "results" of what you have done in this one, but it just feels hollow regardless of what choice you've made, even the main antagonist the hunter seems to allude to that as he's very much, "We're gods, we can do what we want in these universes and just hop to a new one" Very early on you're introduced to the knowledge that the galaxy is still recovering from a very destructive war among the two main factions UC and Freestar but despite tensions still being high, the most you'll get is some weak jabs over dialogue, no real emphasis to show just how fragile the political climate between the factions is. The worlds feel empty, and yes i know, they're frontier worlds that aren't all inhabited, but every last structure is reused on the same world, occupied by the same factions. Exploration after a while just feels hollow and unrewarding. while the vehicles are nice, worlds with low gravity it is more practical just to use your jump pack to get around. Factions feel hollow as well. The vast majority of their quests can be boiled down to fetch quests and go here and clear this area, I thought I was done with the minutemen, but apparently another settlement needs my help, but this time in space. I will say the UC and Freestar stories are a lot better than the main story. A large portion of the main story is "Go here there is an artifact here" or "Go here, there is a temple where you'll get cool space wizard powers" but each time it's the same. No variety really how to get the artifacts other than a select few, and no reall variation between the temples. Just float around each time, collect shiney space lights then boom the rings aline and you get your new powers. Each new game plus if you want to collect all the powers legit you'll have to do it over again meaning to max out all powers to 10 you'll need to do over 200 temples over the NG+ you do considering how there are 20+ temples per run. It gets tedious after the first 10. Each home world to the faction also just feels like a missed oppertunity. They feel devoid of life despite the countless NPCs, but remarkably few have anything to really add other than being vendors and giving some insight to the world. The characters for the most part you meet are fun and interesting. Ship building is jank and fairly confusing at times, but ship combat is fun and fairly streamlined imo. Gunplay is fine for the most part. Settlement building is a massive backtrack from Fallout 4 and even Fallout 76. The armor and ship you get after starting a NG+ get out competed really quick in higher levels which is a shame because both the designs are cool, That feels like a misstep as in the main quest your follows say that the Starborn ships could blow you out of the sky. The DLC is a missed oppertunity as well. Why cant I take over house Varuun after literally becoming the chosen one to save their people. I'm literally already and universe hopping god with powers that can summon a supernova, I think I can run one planet of religious groat hearders. That's not a jab at House Varuun. They have by far the best clothing and coolest weapons in game lets be real here. But even the DLC just felt like the main story. Where it had a good idea that was done horribly. Finally the creations. This one bothers me the most out of anything. I'm all for supporting mod creators, they do great work and are a HUGE HUGE HUGE reason why Bethesda games are so long lasting for many of us, but stuff like the compendium categorizing resources, where to find them, ect should have been a quality of life update for the game, not a paid mod, that right there is a huge issue with the current micro-transaction issue in games, and Bethesda keeps adding new ways to squeeze money off of us. All started with horse armor in Oblivion, then Skyrim, then Skyrim, and then you guessed it Skyrim. You're better off looking on nexus for mods that improve the game or add features that should have been implemented prior and not paid. I know there is a lot of negative here, but with all that said I still enjoy this game, it's a Bethesda game with all of its faults and glory, but this is also one of the reasons I dont pre-order games anymore. I just cant support games that feel half finished in a lot of aspects that Bethesda has been cranking out over the last few releases. Everything they try and build suspense or tention for in Starfield just misses the mark and no real conflict happens that is meaningful. Most of the side quests outshine the main missions and exploration gets to be a chore where as in games like Skyrim it was amazing, All that said I both dont and do reccomend this game. If you like Bethesda games, you'll probably like this, just get it on sale.

A little disappointed in the space exploration aspect of the game - I think I was a little spoiled with the 2025 version of No Man's Sky. BUT, at the end of the day, if you go into the game expecting a typical Bethesda-style RPG, quirks and all, Starfield does a fine job at scratching that itch. At least until ES6 is released when I reach retirement age ;)

One reason why I enjoyed prior Bethesda titles was the sense of mystery and exploration. You could just start walking in a direction without any idea of what you'll discover. Oftentimes I avoided doing missions of any kind in The Elder Scrolls games because I just wanted to explore. I made my own fun and didn't need the "rails" of quest lines. That was not the case in Starfield. This game's exploration was the opposite of seamless, it was disjointed and void of meaningful interaction. Endless menus, long pressing buttons, and an awful star map all made for such a disappointing adventure, which is a real shame since the setting is in space. Regardless, when I re-adjusted my expectation of the game and started leaning on the quest lines and the ship modifications I ended up enjoying my time with the game. I'd oftentimes find myself listening to lofi music in the background while chilling in my ship managing my inventory or preparing for the next mission. That being said though, while it was ultimately an enjoyable experience, I cannot fathom spending anymore time in the game (like NG+) than the amount of time I initially put into it. I explored all I cared to explore; the main plot didn't grab my attention; the DLC also didn't grab my attention; no pulls whatsoever. Oh well, it's just a game. Had some fun, time to shelve it.

sci-fi is my favorite genre. this is without a doubt the least creative sci-fi project i have ever seen in my life. the world is so safe, so boring, and so uninspired i wonder why they even bothered putting time into making a game set in space in the first place. this is one of the only games of recent memory where Nothing Happens. it's a miracle to me that this is an M-rated game because it is like the Weenie Hut Jr's of game design on almost every aspect. want to have cool space battles with dog-fighting and capital ships? good thing that the only war in this universe took place 100 years ago. the world has stories all about great battles and hardships and discoveries that humanity went through, all of which are uninspired at best. the game takes place entirely during an era of peace. it is constantly reminding you of a better game that simply doesnt exist. multiple occasions the narrative presents you with a semblance of choice, and by the end of the quest you realize that the choice was already made for you. example: one of the pirate buccaneers veers you in on a scheme to kill the captain and you have the option to either ignore him or say no. no matter what you say by the end of the quest he will apologize to you and the fate of the captain was never even a dialogue you could have in the first place.
you are spawned into this world just in time to be everyone's best working class saint. there are no stakes in this world. every npc is either immediately kind to you or attacks you on sight. everything in this universe just works flawlessly. fuel is unlimited and humans can instantly teleport anywhere they want in the universe (yet they cant figure out how to send emails to each other). the weapons are horrific in their design, even worse than it was in fallout 4, they are bulky and uninspired and totally unsatisfying to wield. every character has really awkward face animations with glistening eyeballs that stare you down during every dialogue conversation (im definitely looking forward to that in elder scrolls 6). also the persuade and lockpicking minigames are just .... complete downgrade from what came before

i tried for 200 hours (with mods) to find something that at least resembled substance and i came up with ship building. it's fun to snap spaceship parts together like legos, however even that has so many hard-coded limitations on it that it just completely ruins the experience of any kind of creativity you could have. you cant rotate modules, you cant have more than one shield/reactor/landing bay even if its just visually. every hab space is just a square, making any and all ship builds at least visually similar. not to mention that it is just not fun or engaging or immersive to fly your ship in orbit or even fundamentally use your ship at all. the ship builder has such little reason to exist, and no reason at all to be so held back mechanically.

i also have had this amazing bug where if i enter a menu, ie. inventory, pause menu, even ship building menu, the game will stop using my gpu altogether, the game will run at 5 fps until i either spam escape or if that doesnt work (usually doesnt), completely close out the game and restart. it was this way at launch and has been that way since. its the only bethesda game ever to do this.

even by bethesda's standards, which is miles under the ground, this game is the most soul-crushing and mind numbing thing that they have ever put out. i bought this game as a joke because i went in with expectations so low that there was no way i wouldnt get at least an absurd kind of entertainment out of it. and it somehow found a way to be even worse than i was expecting. which is, in fact, as absurd as it is hilarious to me.

for fallout fans, imagine if the infamous confrontation with colonel autumn in fallout 3 was stretched out to an entire open world video game. except this time, there is no gore or vats or other-worldly whimsy and charm or climactic moments to keep you entertained on even a surface level. i guess if you wanted a game where you can go around and collect sandwiches to fill your prebuilt spaceship bedroom with 1000 physically based sandwich models, and find a lot of entertainment and escapism in that fantasy, then this game might just be your game of the year. for the rest of us we will be looking out for a space rpg that is interesting, engaging, and above all the least creative enough to warrant its own existence

Starfield might be a game for you. It has a good amount going for it, and most of the reasons that made the game a train wreck at launch have been resolved. That said, some of the game is still lack luster.

Reasons you might like Starfield:
1. Sandbox galaxy
2. Original story for the genre
3. Several factions of optional content
4. Solid on world physics
5. On world based combat is fun
6. Combat and non-combat options frequently available
7. Combat and combat related skills are fun and interesting
8. Decent ship building

Reasons you might NOT like Starfield:
1. Outpost (base building) system is painful and pointless
2. Some skills are pointless
3. Visibility can be frustrating and challenging
4. Poor outer space physics
5. Outer space combat is mid

What I enjoyed most about Starfield was the ability to get in my ship and go anywhere. Like The Elder Scrolls (e.g., Skyrim) before it, you can play whatever content you want basically whenever you want. I would even go so far as to say that you don't even have to play the main storyline to have fun. You could skip it. Though the story has a good amount of originality to it and is worth playing. The combat on normal difficulty is no more than casual in actual challenge, but you can ramp the difficulty up to a moderate level of challenge. Starfield is a reasonably fun TES game in space.

The ship building in game isn't for everyone, but it is also entirely optional. If you are interested in building your own ship, the system is quite capable. There is quite a following of people designing ships after famous SciFi movies. And you, too, can create something that looks cool and is practical for the game. I generally enjoyed building my own ships, but I wish that all ship components could be acquired to install at your own spaceship builder instead of having to travel to many locations to have components installed.

What I was most disappointed in Starfield was for the absurdly poor outpost system. I wasn't expecting Satisfactory level outpost building and resource management, but what it did deliver is convoluted and lacking core features. You can spend tons of your skill points in anything from Surveying to Outpost Engineering, Planetary Habitation to Outpost Management. All of it is an absolute waste. If you just go to the appropriate store to purchase resources needed to upgrade any gear you want (given you even decide to invest points into any crafting/upgrade skill), you can probably earn all the money required and acquire all the resources in minutes of game play. Those minutes completely eliminate any need for any outpost skill or the time it takes setting everything up. If you can even figure it out. One of the most rare Steam achievements for the game has to do with setting up resource links between planets (~2% of players last I checked). And even if you take the time to figure it out and set it up, there is almost zero method for organizing the output of the links. Minecraft's redstone systems are easier to design and better capable to organize your resources. And potentially even worse yet, the only base buildings you can build are all prefabs. If the only reason you want to play Starfield is to build bases and gather resources, hard pass on this game. If you are ok hard passing on this feature of the game, you will probably find the rest of the enjoyable.

My biggest gripe with Starfield is the terrible visibility throughout the game. Worlds with decent vegetation at night, almost all caves, and many abandoned indoor structures have poor visibility. And the only tool you have to deal with it is a flashlight that seems like it is powered by a candle. The tech level of the game includes AIs, gene-splicing, giant mechs, and faster than light travel. But you cannot even acquire a low-light vision mod for your helmet. It's a travesty. It's manageable, but it is a serious pain to either manage the game's brightness manually in different environments or just deal with some aspect of the game being less than ideal (either too dark or too bright depending on what settings you leave static).

Combat in outer space could be anywhere on the spectrum of great fun to nerd rage, depending on what your expectations are. Essentially, if you are looking for ship-based combat to make use of cool combat tricks that can only be done in low to no gravity environments, then ship combat will be a turn off for you. If you prefer to just feel like driving a car in space and blow up some pirates, yeehaw! You'll have plenty of fun.

Starfield has some good draws to play it in 2025. It's come a long was since launch. It doesn't completely live up to its elder sibbling games (The Elder Scrolls), but it has enough in common with them that you could get hours of enjoyment out of the game.

I like the game I just don't like all the glitches you get most of the way through a quest and you cant finish some wont even let you start. I must ask how is it that every planet you land on has all the same features if you have been on one you have been one them all  when you land on earth in a spot that should be sand like the sahara and it is the same the mount Everest, That takes the fun out of exploring you did so good on skyrim and fucked this one up please do better and make some fixes.
