Wouldn't recommend, i highly regret buying the ultimate edition and giving it too much of a chance to surprise me that now i cannot refund it.

the only bethesda game with a new game plus, but its the least replayable game they have made. they did manage to make using meta knowledge part of the game. there is a lot of neat stuff in this game but it just tries too hard to be everything instead of working to be great at some things. i played 5 hours at release and put it down for a year and a half, i expected better after they had time to fix things.

the enemies don't scale with you so once you can beat them nothing is a challenge anymore, except the occasional clone you fight. honestly if you get lucky with your first couple gun pick ups you're set for the rest of the game, like i got a revolver on the second planet i went after the tutorial and put a binary trigger on it. it can dump 6 overpowered shots in half a second which on extreme settings was still overkill for a terrormorph which is supposed to be a big enough threat to overwhelm whole settlements, but my asthmatic character didn't even break sprint taking down three of them. 

the outpost system is kind of neat you can collect resources to make outposts to collect more resources and sell them if you want to take the time to load them all up and take them somewhere, if they even have enough money to buy a cargo load of resources. you can skip this whole part of the game and not miss out on anything, even if you do defending them is near impossible because you're limited to 6 turrets and 6 robots. so if you get attacked on a side you didn't put a turret the wave of ecliptic that attack can overhwhelm all your robots and destroy your place with little to no effort. building ships or outposts the clicking together of pieces is just painful. base game doesn't have a base/leveling option for outposts so you have to build stuff around the terrain that doesn't look as nice as it could. i've spent 10 minutes trying to stack a resource container because it glitched down a level or was half off the side and could not get it to go right. 

i was lucky about glitches and bugs in the game besides a couple locks i got that were fixed by reloading a save a couple minutes back, i only had one bug that i had to google how to fix and it was sleep for 24 hours to make the npc load. i even checked with console it just would not let him load anywhere. i have a friend that has had multiple game breaking bugs happen. 

mods disable achievements, even official mods from the creation club. which is really just dumb especially for a bethesda games, it discourages some people from trying a really fun option to add content and fixes to the game. these games are only kept alive by they modding community adding content and fixing the game because the developer won't. 

there is no real lock out from one faction to the other, you can still be top of everything with 5 or 6 missions. you just gain more things to use in conversations to convince people. sneaking is so so, there are some fun stealth missions though once you are done with them there is no point in running through vents again. 

i thought the buggy would be more fun, or a faster way to move around, it just isn't for me. nothing is flat enough for it to be much use, the boost is so low it doesn't help much in 1 or more gravity. its faster for me to use food and drugs to recover oxygen and run around the map. then sometimes when i'm landed it just glitches under my ship and makes everything vibrate constantly, like my controller rumbles all over new atlantis. you can't disable it after you buy it, they only ever put in the one vehicle no upgrades or changes besides painting. the one upside is sometimes it gets partially caught under my ship and launches out fast at an unpredictable angle, so its launched the ship services guy into orbit a few times which is always funny. 

powers are underwhelming, even without the "puzzle" of flying into the bright lights until the rings unlock and let you get them. that's neat the first time, then tedious after that. worst part is if you don't go far enough in one questline you can play most of the game without ever even knowing they are in the game. i think i played 120 hours without unlocking them, then barely used them after because all of them were less effective than items, they didn't offer a tactical advantage over just shooting enemies they just kind of were a thing to collect. 

new game plus is really not that great. you just get to keep powers, research, and your experience points/level. you just wind up doing the exact same thing all over again with a new option in most conversations, "trust me i already did this" type stuff. you lose all your items, your ships, your artifacts, your outposts, your progress in any missions. an hour into a new playthrough, i made a powered up assault rifle and food/drinks/drugs that all boosted speed and was able to just sprint through all the science outposts and what not too fast for the ai to keep up, get to the end and fast travel out. right after starting the only thing that slows me down is not having digipicks for the locked doors even on max difficulty which really just makes enemies more spongy and you weaker. the game is super grindy for no pay off, because when you get to the end all your work is erased so you can start over. 

i'm leaving my expectations for this out because i was looking forward to it at launch and thought it was bad enough i just set it aside for a year and a half to play now. i won't even go into how pissed off i am that they delayed elderscrolls 6 for this. there is so much potential here, but it falls on its face trying to do everything. it feels like 3 or 4 games jammed together last second. i think it would have been an amazing game if they had scrapped the outpost thing beyond maybe a place to hide out once in a while and stash stolen cargo or something, and not had the newgame plus/main quest part of the game. so if they put in a couple bases you could clear out and claim, then focused on quality of missions and world building so you don't wind up raiding the same lost science outpost 3 times with the same notes and everything, i'd have enjoyed this more. when i was just dinking around helping security on misssions, then flying around doing new stuff on different worlds i had fun, then it just looped content to add more time or something and it sucked.

It had potential. While it has the basics for a good overall story in place, with decent factions, and some good mission lines, it feels like they pretty much left it at that. Aside the main quest (which is endlessly repeatable and quickly becomes a forgettable grind), there are a few faction story lines, but other than that, it just fizzles out.

I feel that they got overconfident; they have a lot of experience building on the lore of Elder Scrolls and Mass Effect, but creating something entirely new is daunting: you need to draw players in with a huge amount of (ambiguous) lore, mysteries, and open endings that provide your basis to grow, but the game feels like they underestimated that and in the end, just gave up halfway through.

I had just completed another fetch quest.  I wanted to go back to Jemeson, see if there was anything I had missed there.  I went to Jemeson, fished around for some bounties, and then went back to my ship.  I got into the pilot's seat, watched the same animation I had seen by that point thousands of times, and paused.  I realized something horrible: I didn't want to play Starfield anymore.  I had seen the whole Bethesda-crafted universe: There was nothing left to see.  Just more procedural generated planets, more dogfights, more walking aimlessly around massive planets with nothing on them worth seeing.

I'm sorry that it took me 45 hours to realize how bad this game was.  I'm sorry I let myself get so excited for it.  I'm sorry I preordered it.  I'm sorry I defended it so fervently.  I was wrong, and I'm not going to let this company and their bad practices trick me again.  It's all my fault, I bought it, I enabled them.

Perhaps we should've seen Starfield as a warning of what the Internet as a whole was going to look like not far in the future.  The soul taken out of something everyone loved because it was soulful, the open-world RPG.  And what is left?  A universe of AI-generated slop.  Or in this case, procedurally generated.  What were they thinking?

Bethesda understands that people like space, but they apparently didn't have a clue why people liked space fantasy stories.  Space fantasy stories are fun because they expand world and tech nearly endlessly.  People like space fantasies where humanity and/or other species are spread across the stars, and have built their own new civilizations, cultures, etc.  People love that.

Starfield offers a universe so empty and hallow that it fills me with a certain dread and sadness to play.  Far from encouraging the imagination or wonder the game developers wanted, this world is not one I would ever want to live in.  But I wouldn't want to live in Tamriel, or the Wasteland either.  The difference?  Tamriel, and the Wasteland are interesting.  In the sands of Elsweyr or the Mojave, we find a world worth exploring.  In Starfield's numerous moons, what do we find?  Lonely, cosmic space dust.  If it could speak, it would scream, for it knows no friends, no stories to tell.

5/10 combat's good

97 hours played, I've beaten the DLC and made it to what I think is the end of Act 1 of the main story before taking a break. Bethesda's games are some of my most played by far in terms of hours both on and off PC. The reviews you may have heard that say 'it gets good after 12 hours' and 'if you just want a simple Bethesda experience, you'll like it' are somewhat accurate, but I'd like to add to it. This game is pretty frustrating in how it has good ideas in it that push beyond the Skyrim baseline but it's always undercut by the much higher percentage of still-present weaknesses made more painful by the measures taken to bloat your playtime. The effect is that a given play session is a repetitive drag with spikes of 'oh i want more of that', which is my experience with the game as whole.

The new Persuasion system is great, but the massive Perk system for getting basic gameplay features (like a stealth bar, a ship targeting feature, pickpocketing, and most crafting) an hour+ at a time is absurd.  What they do to make the lives of your companions important in the story was PERFECT for adding stakes, but the fact that your only four in-depth/romanceable companions are all within the same faction and mostly have the same exact Likes/Dislikes is baffling.  Your perks, background and previous statements are often remembered in conversation, but they never have an impact on the outcome. The ability to knock someone unconscious is equally underutilized and is essentially never acknowledged as an option in quests. It's a shame, because I find these very cool mechanics. Same goes for Grav Jumping out of combat, which is very thrilling when it works (though it takes a while to figure out when it does.)

Since most of your playtime is spent going from place to place and shooting stuff, what you see is a bigger consideration than usual. I often chose to switch up perspectives and use in-world Grav Jumping instead of fast travelling from the out-of-universe menu exclusively, even though it's always an option. The 3rd Person Idle stance for pistols is sweet, but the shooting and the 1st Person anims are all the same boring ones from Fallout 4. The animations when you physically interact with your ship's console are AMAZING for immersion, but they're few, short, and the exception instead of the rule with the world's technology. There are also too few ship animations to make up for the sheer number of fast traveling you need to do, leading me to feel like I know the same 5 or 6 take-off/landing/flying scenes like the back of my hand.

The best quest I've played was a crime investigation in the DLC, where you can interact with a computer and use some problem-solving with few hints to offer up additional evidence that can help prosecute a criminal. Even though your reward is functionally only a couple extra lines of dialogue in the confrontation, it was still a great breath of fresh air from the hundreds of other completely rigid quests that surround it. The same goes for the UC Vanguard and Freestar Rangers quests, where you have to make a relatively nuanced decision at the end that offers some satisfaction in role-playing, but lacks much consequence one way or the other in the overall factions (aside from the same four people in Constellation lining up to congratulate/berate you in the same way).

Clearly, I don't think creating a deep RPG or even a simple adventure game as iconic as Skyrim or Fallout 3 was what Bethesda actually developed. What I think they made was a space adventure template with a ton of potential for a future team to actualize. All of the complaints I made can be easily fixed with different writing and a direction that aims to make the most out of the systems already here instead of trying to add in as many things as possible. Though it's likely impossible, I would love for a New Vegas-style game where different directors/writers take what's been made and use it as a skeleton for a more decision-heavy action RPG ( with more cool animations and less time spent fast travelling in menus :) ).

My husband was never into video games—aside from GTA—but he loves this one. We play it together in a way that makes it fun for both of us: he handles all the fighting and shooting, while I focus on the story, interacting with characters and making decisions. It’s the perfect balance, and we’re both completely hooked.

Now, about the game itself—calling it an "open galaxy" experience is an understatement. I have over 100+ hours in, and I still haven’t explored all the galaxies, let alone the countless planets within them. The shooting mechanics are incredibly fun, and your interactions with your companions change depending on your choices, making every playthrough feel unique.

As a longtime Elder Scrolls fan, I can confidently say that Starfield surpasses it for me. The sheer scale of exploration, the endless side quests, and the ability to have a companion in combat make it an unforgettable experience. If you even kind of liked Elder Scrolls, just wait until you dive into Starfield. You’ll thank me later!

While this game is still buggy, and the main plotline is extremely underwhelming, it still has a lot to offer in the same vein as No Man's Sky. Explore a massive galaxy, create outposts with workers and robots, and follow a variety of alright side quests with zero impact on any of the other quests or the universe at large!

I put many hours into this game and honestly tried to love it. But every major location feels just large, boring and still empty. The planets structures are all copy-pasted, with generic loot and no interesting events. There even seems to be only one computer password in the galaxy, which is written on a sticky note on every second computer I came across.

I feel that the main problem that people have with this game is that we were basically promised "Skyrim in space" and got this game. Is it "Skyrim in space"? No. If you stop looking at the game through the lens of I need the excitement that the mods of Skyrim gave to Skyrim then it is a perfectly fun game. The main story is approximately the same length as the main story in Skyrim, there are less side quests than there were in base Skyrim, and it can get tedious to travel to different systems just to land on a planet that may or may not have more than just one building on it. However, saying that it is a bad game is a stretch. The side quests are, in most cases, just as fun as the ones in Skyrim. The "space magic" is a bit weak, even when maxed out, but used strategically is at the same time completely overpowered.

Why did modders abandon the game? I don't know, I rarely modded Skyrim and have approximately 750 hours in the base and special edition versions of the game combined (I know that is rookie numbers but I don't have the time that I used to to keep playing). As someone who rarely mods games, this game is almost the same quality as Skyrim (I know that it sounds like heresy to say but I said it), which has about the same amount of places to go as this game, just on a smaller map. Should Bethesda continue to add more to the base game which has a lot of empty planets? Yes, it doesn't have to be Skyrim levels of content density per planet but at least 10 locations to be able to find "easily" on each planet would be an extreme upgrade and I feel would assuage the annoyance of those that felt that they were robbed of a "Skyrim in space" game.

This review got a lot longer than intended. Overall, I recommend the game, as long as you buy it on sale (I got Skyrim on sale and was very happy with it) and keep yourself from comparing the game to Skyrim too much (in spite of how much I did so in this review). This game is not "Skyrim in space" it is similar to how it is titled, a field of stars to explore (although lots of them have very little on each planet). That is exactly what exploration really is, most of the time it is a lot of finding nothing, and only sometimes you find something interesting. That may be part of the reason why you have to join the SPACE EXPLORERS to progress the main story. The main thing for you to do in the game is, unsurprisingly, explore space.

The amount of negative reviews here that have more hours in the game than dollars spent to play it is hilarious to me.  

With that said, there are plenty of good points made in the negative reviews.  Neon should NOT be so PG.  The cities and player homes are way too small.  The dialog and characters can be bland at times.  Very few characters actually stand out in a memorable way, good or bad.  Many of the RPG elements in general are depressingly shallow.

All things considered though, there is also a lot to like.  I make a point to play pretty much every interesting looking space title out there, and believe me, there is a LOT you can do here that is not available in other, similar titles.  Honestly, what really hurts BGS here is that Starfield leaves you wanting more in many areas, and not in a good way.  That isn't great, but it doesn't make it a bad game necessarily.   For instance, The Outer Worlds left me wanting to play something entirely different.  Starfield just leaves me wishing that I could play a better version of Starfield.

I do recommend this game, but only to people who love Sci-Fi, love Bethesda Game Studios titles, and like to "lean in" to the RP in their head while playing.  If you check all three boxes, there's a great chance you'll enjoy yourself here.

I have been a die-hard fan of Bethesda ever since I was a child playing Morrowing, Oblivion, and Fallout 3. However, it's safe for me to say I have lost all faith in them as a company. They've lost touch with what made them great.

With that being said, Starfield is by far the worst Bethesda game I have ever played, and that's saying a lot since.. well you know.. Fallout 76 is a thing. 

Where to even begin.. It's riddled with bugs, more than your average Bethesda game to where it isn't cute anymore. 

The world building is sloppy, lazy, and BORING. Main cities are lack-luster and tiny, hardly anything to explore after the first 10 minutes of landing — and that's the populated areas of the game. They feel like cardboard cutout facades to mimic it's great size, but once you're in it you can feel it. Don't even get me started on how utterly sad the other planets and moons are, they're floating balls of nothingness with maybe a settlement or two, if you're lucky, dotted around. After a few hours into the game you'll notice they're the same buildings just copy and pasted here and there.

The story and overall writing is ABYSMAL! The main story is a watered down version of Skyrim's dragonborn (but in space oooo) with none of the likable characters. None of the NPCs have any comprehensive dialog or meaningful backgrounds to them so there is zero reason to get attached to any of them. Previous Bethesda games at least had the help of foundational material to work off from (and maybe better writers at the time?), but since this is their own fresh title, it really shows how lacking they are to create a story that promotes any emotional response from the player. Genuinely feels like it was written by AI and then hardly skimmed over for mistakes. No love, no passion, just dead empty eyes in their flat forgetful characters. Apart from that are the side quests, and they mainly consist of fetch-quests that make you run around in the empty nothingness that is Starfield's universe.

The weapons are rubbery and flat, there's no weight to them and you have to unload mag after mag to kill one guy. They made huge progress with guns in Fallout 4 but somehow made them worse again for this title? It's like fighting with nerf darts. Apart from that, there is also significantly less ways for you to customize your weapons to really make them yours. There ends up being more ballistic guns than any other type of weapon combined in the game, so much for variety. And if you think you can get around this with making a melee character, think again because there are only 8-9 different melee weapon options. Their damage is so poor you might at well fight space pirates off with a butter knife.

Settlement building is pointless, there's no reason to have a stationary base when you have one that flies around with you. The few perks to having a planetary base are not worth the grind to get to. And is also yet another feature that was somehow downgraded from Fallout 4, more clunky, harder to build with, etc.

The one saving grace for this game is the ship builder. I'll admit, out of everything, this game is a really fun spaceship builder. Especially if you get mods that allow you to be more free with the construction.

All in all I would highly not recommend, wait for the next Bethesda title. And even then I'd be very cautious and never never ever preorder one of their games again.

After a couple hundred hours, I am prepared to carefully endorse this game.  I have enjoyed my time with it, but you need to know a few things going in.

1.  You will need to expect standard Bugthesda glitches.  Most of them can be ignored.  For those that cannot...

2.  You will need a working knowledge of the console commands, and how to use them to fix broken quests, and fix NPC's that are stuck with bad pathfinding.  Other issues will come up, but there is community that has a lot of experience documenting bugs, and possible solutions.  Reddit will have most of the answers.

3.  For an optimal experience, you will need to use mods to correct certain silly game balance decisions, and improve the otherwise passable asthetics of this game.  I recommend the Vortex modding engine, and Nexus Mods for an excellent collection of community created content.

4.  This plays a lot like Skyrim In Space.  You can be an interstellar murder hobo if you want to be.

5.  Ignore the real world commentary about this game.  Play it because it looks like something you would enjoy, or don't.  

6.  Ship building is a lot of fun, but full access to that content is a late game feature that requires a lot of resources, and several levels and skill points to fully unlock.  

7.  There is no reverse pickpocketing, which was very disappointing to me.  (No Shady Sands Shuffle for you.)  At the time of this comment, there is no mod to correct this. (Boo!)

8.  Get it on sale, if possible.  Bugthesda needs encouragement to stop taking their fan base for granted, and paying full price is the wrong message to send.  All of the big game companies are guilty of this, but it has felt particularly egregious lately with this company.  


*** Minor Spoiler ***


9.  Do not spend a lot of effort in putting together your bases/ship fleet on your first playthrough.  The New Game Plus mechanic will have you losing all that to restart your progress with them while keeping your level and skills.  You will want to wait until your 10th playthrough at least to start getting serious about putting together a personal empire to keep you supplied with resources and money.

*** Conclusion ***

Despite an extensive list of flaws, I have enjoyed this game, and will continue playing it for some time.  If Fallout 4 and Skyrim appealed to you, and a sci-fi setting sounds like fun, you may have a good time here.

For a few years now I’ve been looking for a great game that would pull me in and enjoy for hours on end and I’ve finally found it. The fly, shoot, loot adventures are exactly what I’ve been wanting. I am glad I waited a bit for the initial bugs to be worked out, I got the game on sale and have absolutely enjoyed every moment so far. 

As a former Elite Dangerous player with over 2000 hours played, I find the fast travel system in Starfield fantastic. I spend half my time in Elite staring at a screen doing nothing waiting to arrive somewhere only to be met with more waiting to dock or land. I love the ability in Starfield to select a destination, wait 3 seconds to load and I’m there in the action and playing.

I do find some of the buttons annoying especially when using ship inventory, the E key is used to interact with everything except inventory, it’s take item, and you use R to open the inventory, really need to be able to flip that. I’ve also had a few glitches and little mission problems but it’s all common things I’ve seen in plenty of other games before.

I don't do mods, I wasn't looking for some new innovative masterpiece, I just wanted something fun to play. I am sorry so many players felt cheated or letdown by expectations of this game, but I am really enjoying Starfield it’s like Skyrim plus Fallout but in space and that is just perfect for me.

I understand why some players feel disappointed with Starfield. That said, I personally don’t mind it. I avoided the pre-release hype, having only seen a single screenshot—and perhaps that worked in my favor. After logging 242 hours (at the time of writing), here are my thoughts, spoiler-free.

My Bethesda journey began with Morrowind, a game that captured my imagination in ways no other Elder Scrolls or Fallout title has since. To my surprise, Starfield manages to rekindle some of that magic. I can’t quite pinpoint why, but it draws me in with its charm. For me, it’s a refreshing dive into space exploration, grounded in Bethesda storytelling.

The story, while engaging enough to see through to completion, often felt like the experience of a space archaeologist—uncovering ancient artifacts without the thrill of dynamic twists or unexpected developments. It may not be particularly exciting, but it holds enough intrigue to keep you moving forward.

Crafting is a feature I thoroughly enjoyed. It’s simple and intuitive, making it accessible to players of all experience levels. That said, I couldn’t help but wish for a feature similar to Diablo 4’s, where item modifiers could be ‘disenchanted’ and reapplied to other gear for greater customization.

Ship construction, gunplay, and space combat are standout features, adding depth and variety to the gameplay. However, from a melee perspective, I couldn’t help but feel the absence of stealth takedown animations—a touch that would have added even more immersion to these encounters.

Base building offers creativity but has room for improvement. My primary issue is the lack of a toggleable grid, which would allow for precise infrastructure alignment. Adding such a feature would elevate the entire experience to a new level.

Planetary exploration remains a mixed bag. While the "Shattered Space" expansion marks a step in the right direction, too many planets feel barren and empty. I understand what Bethesda was trying to achieve, but, stunning vistas can only carry the appeal so far. I wasn’t keen on empty planetary exploration in Mass Effect back in 2007, and my opinion hasn’t changed in 2023—or 2025 at the time of writing. That said, the addition of a post-launch rover has made traversing these desolate tiles significantly more bearable.

Ultimately, my relationship with Starfield is a blend of appreciation and critique. On one hand, I see the flaws that others point out. On the other, I can’t deny the game’s charm, brought to life through great companions and a universe that keeps pulling me back in. If someone were to ask me whether I’d recommend Starfield, I absolutely would—provided they understand it’s not Fallout or Elder Scrolls. Starfield is Starfield, and I truly hope Bethesda continues to support and expand upon its foundations.

You get to play as a random space mining loser who automatically joins some boring crew of forgettable people against your will, traverse across an entire galaxy of absolutely nothing and in the hours of patrolling baron planets and moons explore just how much of a "what if" this game could've been. "What if" Starfield was several mostly hand crafted planets within a solar system rich with lore and different intelligible alien races that all have culturally different views on the galaxy, instead we got 1000 squares of nothing interesting in a universe of only humans who have seemingly no problems with anyone at all except the space pirates who are also boring. I really wanted to like this game and I for a time convinced myself I did, after reflection I do not and I 100% wasted my time on this. Bethesda has always felt like they honed in on their fantasy elements in most of their games, even the ones that're lackluster in comparison to some of their older titles, this game strives to almost do the exact opposite and leaves you baffled by just how monotonous the entire world is.

I was going to write a long winded post. Instead, here's a pro's and con's list.

PRO'S
Ship builder is fun.
Zero-G combat in refreshing.

CON'S
Ship builder gets old becuase it requires an insane amount of investment to make anything interesting or useful.
Zero-G combat is rare.
You can have several different ships, and only one active.
All ships share one inventory reguardless of capacity.
Game is Desolate.

While I like a good space opera, Starfeild has that and there's a lot of side missions to keep me busy (that and my silly challenge of using only a mining laser!), but I feel like there is way too much dialogue. Maybe its my choice of trying to complete all the side missions ahead of the main story, but I find myself skipping dialogue and doing the bare minimum in order to progress a mission or activity.

Apart from the excessive loading screens and inconsistent requirement to undock, the most frustrating part of all this is the game-braking bugs. There are way too many. The game may as well be early access as it needs a lot of patching to fix a vast array of problems and the only way to mitigate this is to save religiously (it's no wonder Starfeild has been dubbed Skyrim in space).

Some of the issues I've had are:
- Weapon ceasing to be able to be fired!
- Unable to open doors and hatches
- Late or delayed dialog freezing the character completely (when leaving an area too soon)

Overall the only thing going for the game - and which is keeping me playing - it is the content and visuals.

What an incredible adventure I'm having. There is so much that I resonate with in Starfield. The sound design is so atmospheric, almost ethereal at times. One of the best decisions I've made with my play-through is taking the time to just immerse myself fully in this world and not feel like I need to rush through to beat the game. 

The story arc and exploration is really amazing. They have beautifully captured the vastness of space and at times I marvel at how small I feel in this world they created. 

The scenery, both on land and cosmic is outstanding. 

I just am so enthralled with this game, in fact it is one of the only things that has broken me away from playing SWTOR, which I absolutely love as well.

I cant believe im saying this about a Bethesda game! but this is probably the MOST disappointing experience ive had all year!
there is a LOT to this game that are small positives! and i mean a LOOOOOOOT
but the pure and simple truth is that it doesnt matter how many small pro's you have when you have the 2 MOST negative cons a game can have!
but as per usual i will list the pros and then the cons!

PROS
- the story doesnt take itself too serious but theres enough to do and learn about the settled systems that its just right for a no lifer (such as myself) or the causal gamer! 
- the skills arent overwhelmingly complicated and there are enoug of them that you can really get a playstyle going on as you work your way up to max level wherein you unlock all the skills! and the challenges required to be able to level up skills kind of synergize with exploration of the games many facets of immersion!
-even without modded content the game actually has really decent visuals despite some critical opinions on the front! there are a few places that are very bland but for the most part you can really enjoy the graphical design as long as you have the hardware to handle running the game at untlra settings!
-the game setting/environment is actually much larger than you would expect if you read the reivews of other people! granted there are a LOT of repetitions to be found but they play out in a way that doesnt make you hate it unless youre grinding for something! (DEVS NEED TO WORK ON THE CIVILIAN OUTPOSTS! NO REASON FOR THEM TO BE SO RARE!)
there are a few other minor pros i could list but they are trivial things that most wouldnt notice!

now for the cons! and i will only list 3. 2 are MASSIVELY impactful and 1 is just evidence of starfield either being rushed because of fan pressure or, evidence the game is just a cash grab! ill let you all decide
CONS
(in order from least bad to WTF Bethesda!)

WAY TOO MANY LOADING SCREENS!
you wouldnt think it matters all that much but they are not only ENTIRELY too frequent but they take an absurdly long time! mind you i have a very powerful computer! i can play 2 games at the same time, stream and have netflix running on my 3rd monitor while im watching a friends stream his game! and i have no frame drops on either game and perfect 60fps at 1080p on my stream and the one im watching! but this point is going to lead into the next CON i will list!

ABSOLUTE TRASH FIRE PROM NIGHT DUMPSTER BABY OPTIMIZATION!
ive quite seriously NEVER seen a game done this poorly! even without mods the game has micro stuttering when accessing a map mesh that is a sub mesh of another map! the more loading screens you have to access to get to a particular area of a map for a quest the more frequent and longer the stutters hang! the game crashes CONSTANTLY when going from one system to another or landing on a planet or just leaving the ship building menu.. sometimes it just crashes becuase it feels like it! how pathetic of a job are your devs allowed to do before you reprimand them publicly and fire people for poor performance at said job!? you guys (Bethesda's project leaders for Starfield) should be absolutely embarassed of yourselves for this! ABSOLUTELY PATHETIC! 

The game was supposed to be "a modders paradise!" but really its just a trashfire complicated process that deters people from modding from 1 update to the next!
and what make that statement even worse 2 facts that just make it not even worth wanting to really dive into all that starfield has to offer!
-the devs update the game version cuasing a LOAD of mods to break for an update that very seldom does anything to improve the game in anyway!
-they dont release a dev kit library change list that logs what exactly was changed within the engine itself! so most mods end up having to be re-written from scratch to be updated!
this wouldnt be a problem if they learned from the hard work the modders put in fixing and adding content the really brings Starfield to life! but they dont do that and they work with the content creators of said mods to incorporate their work into the game!

overall i would suggest leaving this game alone until Bethesda finally abandons it and the content creators can get the final version so that they can fix all the trash that has been vomitted out! 
there is so much potential in this game that it breaks my heart to have to call out bethesda like this! as i have never really fired shots at them like this but man they really SH*t the bed and used the pillow case to wipe with this one! 
i truly hope that they dont make the same mistake with the next entry in the Elder scrolls game or it WILL spell the end of Bethesda as we know it! you can have to titles this big fail this hard back to back!

I think most of the complaints for this game are unfounded. I do think generally that Starfield, as a new IP, is not yet the legend that Morrowind, or Oblivion were for me. However, if this is game one in another potentially 5 game long saga, then I'm here for it. Bear in mind, that Morrowind was game 3... and Oblivion was game 4. How many of you even played Elderscrolls 1?!

Starfield as a universe is in fact loaded to bear. True, they skimped on 'POI's' and if you play the game long enough, you will see the same places. Is it lazy? with a game this size, who is to say. The characters are interesting, it just takes a couple of anomalous trips through the unity to fully tease those depths out, and I'm guessing by most reviewers hours played, they have not experienced more than one at most.

Initially, I was turned off by their NG+ system. In a game where you can create settlements, or perfect your starship it hurt quite a bit to leave it all behind to start from scratch once more. Nevertheless, the depth of the game was in the NG+. The variance, and strange were typical BGS, just not in a format anyone was used to.

All in all, I hope you'll ignore the hate and enjoy the game. The gun play is fun, the space travel and combat is in fact fun, and the story, while not as riveting as KCD2 or RDR2, was still good enough to enjoy. 

As an aside, regarding comments about paid mods: 1) If you don't have the self control to not buy them, then the shame belongs on you. 2) People who put time and effort into creating content do in fact deserve compensation, especially if it is good content! If you freeload off Nexus exclusively, let me encourage you to support the modders, they are humans, not NPCs.

at around 60 hours, i told myself "this kinda sucks, but it's alright, it can be fixed with mods".

at around 120 hours, i realized the horrible truth. this can't be fixed with mods. at a fundamental conceptual and design level, this game is broken. it doesn't work. it hedges all of its bets on creating a deeply immersive experience around the mundanity of space, but utterly fails. i realize only as i write this that Bethesda probably no longer carries the capacity to make a new IP with a compelling setting. those who created the brilliant world of TES are long gone, and Fallout was created by a different company entirely, so having any hope that Starfield's world would capture that same magic was fruitless to begin with.

i will still call myself a hardcore Bethesda fan and still look forward to Fallout 5 and TES 6, and as a hardcore fan, i implore Bethesda not to return to this one. it doesn't work Todd, please learn from this.

TLDR: A mile wide an an inch deep

Bethesda is trying to look to the future while simultaneously refusing to leave the past. Once you get over the hype of "Fallout or Elder Scrolls in space!" you quickly realize that this game is empty and devoid of personality. Empty planets with the same procedurally generated ships and buildings. Total lack of dungeon crawls. Loading screen simulator. Weapon modding is stupid; you just flat out lose your old mod when you replace it with a different one. The temple mini game is the most rage inducing, waste of time ever. It feels like the devs are intentionally mocking you making you do it over and over again. No local maps at launch. Etc, etc. They should have just stuck to the solar system. Have some sort of Mad max scenario going on on earth, well developed moon base and martian society, colonies in the asteroid belt, etc. If you've ever seen or read The Expanse by James SA Corey, Starfield should have been basically just that. Keep it simple, keep it interesting. You can expand into deep space or other galaxies later with DLC or mods. They tried to do something new and bold and I appreciate that. They just way overreached their capabilities and delivered something lifeless and utterly boring.

So hitting this game hard! 
  I love space games and loved the custom feel of games like elder scroll and fallout series, and what they had to offer.  The game is a hard space adventure with custom choices to make your play-though different every time you play. Also offer a unique twists to play though.
 
 That said. It is SAD to say, its a different then Elder scrolls/Fallout. This game is a BUG FILLED GAME. From the audio clips never matching up (miracle if it does), to the auto click of parts (ship building and outpost building) causing more pain then help. I have played at this time 103 hours of game, 73 in the past week. 

This all being said. The game is a shooter-level up-custom charter builder-custom ship building- but I exclude the outpost/town builder part. IT SUCKS HARD. Why? Because you need to use these function to make it easier to make money in the game and to get resources you may need for building your outpost. I played on default controls. There maybe a setting that I may not being seeing but controls for building are rough.

  Your companions are nothing more the problems in combat. They will get between you and your target in a fire fight, to exposing you while sneaking, to as well want to UN alive them for the non stop "when you got a minute." dialog. Dont get me wrong, I love the dialog that characters have but OK! They said it! Make it a mission and drop it. A hour of game play, said it 20 times. Outpost building left me on the floor, I placed a desk and it goes right out the window, outside the build bubble. DONE. reload save and pissed. 
Ship building: sometimes you get double ship in dock and can not walk around have to reload game or worse reload save after it get stuck. 
Mind you I have not played with any Mods or DLCs.
 This game falls short, just like star citizen, and no mans sky.  Its like if we had all these groups team up we would really great space game! Worth the price that we pay for these games. That being said could the DLCs or Mods improve the game, yet to find out. 

So I am level 27 now. Most of the game is done. Love the story. Feels like it was pushed sooo hard! It could had been better? YES. Do they have a chance to fix it. YES. If they did fix all the major issues with the start of the story, the audio bugs and the builder bugs. The game could live on for 15 years. But I feel this will be dropped hard. 

After all that, will I still play? YES.

Do I recommend this game: YES, if you love space adventure. NO NO NO, if you want to build a space empire, like to add details to settlements. Looking for full immersion. 

Looking forward to the mod community saving another AAA game.
This game is really fun! But the main storyline ending is a little lackluster.

So much hate in reviews for this game... I can understand some of it, but i still find it somehow "unfair". I purchased Starfield with LOW expectations, here is what i can say after about 40 hours in:

CONS:
- Game is quite "bland", in the sense that there's nothing "masterclass" about it. The game isn't "bad", it just isn't "great", and many people wanted it to be "great". No epic feeling like The Elder Scrolls, no immersion and choices & consequences like Fallout... Not memorable at all, so far.
- Game can be very repetitive if you were hoping to have lots of "variety" when "exploring". As many people said, randomly generated settlements, enemies outposts and such end up all looking the same. In a way, this repetitiveness kills the "exploration" vibe. The hand scanner is more of a gimmick than an immersive way to reward exploration. 
- Characters, although being voice-acted, have facial expressions which fail in comparison to other games (Cyberpunk 2077,...), and.. i dunno, the magic ain't totally here.
- Ship designs is meh, ship combat is meh, not terrible but not "good" either.

All this confirms many of the "negative" reviews i have read. Now, if you are the "right type" of player, don't let this discourage you:

PROS:
- Graphics look good. Seriously, with a good PC you don't need to tweak the settings or such bullshit, game looks good. I was amazed as the details on space suits for example. 
- Game is very casual-friendly: if like me you have a job and a family, and just want to relax playing, Starfield is really easy to play and get into. Unless you make the enemies harder in the settings, they tend to pose a quite modest challenge. You have a sense of growing your character and equipping them with more powerful stuff, of getting richer, buying larger ships... It uses the typicaly Bethesda gameplay, made even more "casual" in a sense. This casual-friendliness may be a drawback for some players though.
- There are TONS of voice acted quests and unique interactions you can have with NPCs. Once you really get into faction quests and such, the game can become immersive. There's tons to do, so if you just play for a bit from time to time, you can get back to this game like you'd get back to your old comfortable pair of slippers. Not an "awesome" experience, but a "comfortable" experience.

I personally have mixed feelings for Starfield, but find it comfortable enough to enjoy the tons of content and chill experience it offers.

This is a phenomenal game.  Takes a little bit of time to understand how to do things, but once you get into it, it is highly addictive and fun.  

Whether it is upgrading and customizing your characters skills, building starships, creating outposts, etc., combat, exploring the massive game world, there is just tons and tons of things to do.  I've got over 100 hours into it so far and I've barely scratched the surface of this massive universe.
  
Being able to add mods to customize game play, graphics or anything else is a major bonus, too.  Again, this is a great game.  In the top echelon of fun.  Have no problem running this on a three year old PC running a GTX 3090 at 2k, everything maxed and graphics modded with HD textures, etc.  I'd easily rate this game a 90%.  There are very, very minor annoyances like every great game may have,  but nothing that takes away from this awesome experience.  Love the open way you can play.  You could spend hours and hours just exploring, building star ships, bases, etc. without touching the story line.  Well done, Bethesda.

The biggest issue with Starfield is that it doesn't know what it wants to be - quests feel like a checkbox on a spreadsheet, all facets of economy are meaningless and combat is gimped by repetitiveness. This is the first Bethesda game that just screams to be fixed by modders, but unfortunately, it doesn't attract enough of playerbase for people to care. And it's a shame, because there are some tiny nuggets, purely accidental, it seems, that could've been a foundation for another decade of mods.

Perhaps few years down the line, there will be an autist that will overhaul the game and if that's the case, Bethesda better recognize that, otherwise they too will drown in a puddle of their own making.

The game feels empty and it's completely sterile of any charm. RPG elements are surface level and ship building is frustrating if you can't ignore the gaps in your ships hull that arise when the jigsaw pieces don't wanna jigsaw. 

Menus are often laggy and you will be in loading screens most of the time. Doing anything with your spaceship will involve a loading screen. Any space travel, landing, docking or flying in orbit involves a loading screen. 

Without the Elder Scrolls or Fallout coat of paint, Bethesda's problems with their game design and rotting game engine all rear their ugly head. The game is frustrating to play and everything they attempted to accomplish has been done better by someone else. Spend your money on something else like No Man's Sky.

All that procedural generation but they couldn't make POIs procedural to be more interesting? And for a game with 1,000 plants there's many 20 POIs that you just see on repeat. Every layout, every body, every container all identical. Garbage.

It's a good game, and it's fun, but...

Years after release, and still riddled with bugs and giant holes. I'm into newgame+, and just can't enjoy it because of basic performance issues (graphics and audio stutter, audio desync, etc.) What's particularly frustrating about this, is that it worked fairly smoothly when I first played it, and nothing about my system has changed. 

Once I got to Newgame+, I just couldn't play anymore. There was so much potential, and so many story possibilities, especially with +, that are completely missed. I was really looking forward to seeing where the story and conversations would go when I told the main characters the whole truth, and the big reveal, but... that option isn't there. It's just the same story, with same dialog and choices, with a little bit of random surprises and fun references [i]maybe[/i] sprinkled in, depending on the rng when you [finish the artifact].

I really wanted to explore what they've done with the game and the ship/base building, and community content "creations", but the game just isn't playable with such a flat story and constant stuttering. Makes me sad to see the crumbling of something with such potential.

I've sat on this review for a while, trying to figure out exactly how I feel about the game.  

The idea behind Starfield is great, but the way Bethesda executed it feels... off. The game comes across as soulless and empty, leaving a sense of loneliness—not the good kind, but the kind that makes the world feel hollow.  

The only moment that genuinely broke through this feeling for me was meeting my alternate-universe self. It was an exciting moment! I thought, *What would my in-game parents and siblings (alt-me has two siblings) think when they see me with my twin?* So, I brought my alt-self to them... and to my disappointment, there was zero reaction. No dialogue, no acknowledgment—nothing.  

That was the moment my Bethesda fanboy shield cracked. Up until then, I was willing to overlook the game’s flaws, but after that? I started seeing the low effort that I had been blind to before.  

At first, I didn’t mind the fast travel system. I figured I could live without real, seamless space travel. Then, I played Star Citizen and realized how much I was missing. Starfield’s approach makes the galaxy feel disconnected and artificial.  

Melee combat? It's bad. I know Starfield is a gun-focused game, but they could have done something to make melee more engaging. With all the advanced tech and diverse factions, why aren't there any unique fighting styles? I dedicated my life to the Great Serpent, but he couldn’t teach me one cool kick or punch? Come on.  

The story is... alright. It’s not bad, but it could have been so much better. I genuinely thought the game was building toward a first contact moment—humanity finally meeting an alien race, our character making history. But no, the Starborn turned out to just be humans. Such a missed opportunity. Starfield could have delivered something unforgettable. And it doesnt have to be about aliens or anything. Like I know they wanted to do their own approach to it ig but you get what im saying. The starborn are cool but imagine if they weren't humans and instead aliens wanting to guide humans to like a next level civilization type of deal. Like how cool would that be. 

I’ve put a lot of time into this game—got my character to level 85, jumped the Unity multiple times, saw some of the unique surprises in NG+. Some quests are cool, but most feel too short and too similar. And honestly? None of my choices felt impactful. The only real effect my decisions had was making certain enemy types spawn less often. That’s it.  

Then there’s the DLC, which was... meh. The hand-crafted city area was neat, but the quests? Forgettable. I can’t even remember any of the characters’ names in the DLC. The story didn’t really grab me until the end, and even then, it wasn’t anything special (Boss fight was cool tho). I was expecting to meet the Great Serpent, but that unfortunately never happened. And don’t get me started on the ghost enemies—those things teleport at random and will appear behind you in an instant.

To top it off, the game forces you to join the city’s religion just to get inside. I was fine with that... until I realized the entire conversion process took five to ten minutes, and suddenly, I was in. It felt rushed and meaningless.  

Bethesda also needs to look into whats causing a specific bug that ruins the whole game for myself and thousands of others. Basically you could be playing the game and then when you hit escape to save the game or just hit escape in general and then back out to the game the FPS drops drastically to less than 20. No one knows why and it makes the game unplayable even on a god tier pc. Thousands of players have this bug even with no mods. PLEASE look into fixing it devs.

With all this in mind, it just leaves me heartbroken for what this game really could have been.

 Bethesda, if you ever need fresh creative vision, I’m ready to step in. I’ve got ideas.
I liked this game but I am not sure why.

Resoundingly just okay. If there was a "Meh" option, i'd pick it. Combat is fun at first, but becomes redundant, and side missions are repetitive after a short time. Play it if its on sale and you want to only play it for a few hours then let it gather dust in your library like me. Pass the Zyrtec, please.

I wanted so very much to enjoy this title.  There are dozens of videos, hours long, explaining what is wrong with it.  Here's a comprehensive criticism.    

https://youtu.be/urEMD71xdCs

For me, my primary complaint comes down to exploration.  I purchased Starfield because I wanted to explore space.  I wanted to see dangerous alien ecosystems, wild landscapes, multiple building types, interesting characters, engaging game mechanics, all supported by various playstyles,  I wanted to feel rewarded for exploring.   I wanted to get into a spaceship, fly to a planet, find something worthwhile, and leave with a sense of wonder, accomplishment or adventure.

Instead, I navigate several nested menus and magically appear on a meaningless AI-generated planet map.  Every boring world is either utterly barren or sporadically dotted with copy-and-pasted points of interest and the same three buildings on an embarrassingly flat landscape.  
This is a great disappointment from a game studio that has created magic before. 
It utterly spoils the dream of discovery.

Game is super weird.  For a game about space, all that exists in Bethesda's galaxies are a mixed bag of american characters. Life forms of anything other than human is left to the vastly under populated and underwhelming planetscapes. Game play is fine, as it plays like fallout 4 in space, just without the PIPboy or atmosphere (pun intended lol). Dialog choices are limited to a typical normal response on top, followed by a verity of seemingly unnecessary aggressive responses I personally wouldn't chose.  The impact the choices have on the story appear to not exist, so I have skipped most of the story and just shot my way to where I am now in the game.  Yeah, Ill probably finish the story, and most of the side quests that I can tolerate. would I have bought it new again, definitely not. Recommended price would be $10 max to play this empy vessel.

I'm 17 hours in and I explored leisurely a few planets, and reached level 10. First outpost is up and waiting for enough resources to be further developed. Exploration on a buggy is definitely better, once you get one. The basic buggy is cumbersome to drive, I expect the next one to have more grip. Enemies are not so bright, but they do offer enough resistence. I have yet to understand how research works, or what do factions do. Voice overs are professional. Flying the space ship is slow, but I'm still flying the first one, with no upgrades. Dogfights are relatively interesting, but then this is not a simulator. No crew yet. Flying from one point to the other takes time, but the map gives you the possibility to reach anything you have already explored. Charging screens happen often, they are not a big deal. POIs are large, well decorated, full of resources and trinkets. Mainly trinkets. No bugs, no clipping, no being stuck between two rocks. I have been killed once in an ambush, and later by flying squirrels. Effing flying squirrels are definitely the worst.
I'm mainly into indie games, so playing a polished game like this one is a nice diversion. The game is so good I'll buy the DLCs. I did the same thing for Fallout Las Vegas and Fallout 4, first tried the game, then took the DLCs.
You'll taste a nice balance between exploration, missions, resource gathering, base building, fighting, flying, driving, ship building, character progression, stealth (some), stealing, cooking, and all that I haven't experienced yet.
Highly recommanded if you enjoy role playing and space exploration.
------
278 hours later the game showed many of its glitches. I have yet to finish several missions, the content is there, fully voiced. Higher difficulty systems lack missions, life is quite scarce out there. The game offers many surprises. Even if the global faction system feels incomplete, the individual missions are very entertaining. POIs are repetitive but are also very large so that you need a few passages to remember them.
This game has all the quality (fully voiced, long and well scripted missions, hundred of planets, dozen of NPCs to meet and befriend), and the defects of a triple A game (mission stoppers, repetitive POIs, awkward inventory management, awkward base building, many features without purpose).

This game isn’t worth it. I really wanted to love this game, and my passion for it is the reason I started taking game design courses in college, but it’s not worth it. Often, I play the game and wonder why I’m playing it. It makes me ask myself what I’m trying to get out of it. Fun? Not having it. Intrigue? None anymore, but I think Hadrian is cute and the UC Vanguard questline is awesome. My love for Hadrian is what got me into modding, actually. I say Starfield inspired me to start designing games (I finished my first game in January, woohoo), but what I actually mean is Hadrian’s story, design, and lovely voice actor inspired me to start making my own things. 

The most important thing to take away from this review is that Starfield is a game with few very good parts, many mediocre, and more bad parts than good parts. The good parts are incredible, but the whole game is so bad that it forced me into making my own games just because I was so upset with how much Starfield sucked.

I'm going to be honest. I've tried playing this game three times now. The first two times, I was bored, but I wasn't offended enough to leave a review. This third time, I installed quite a few mods and I was no longer bored. In fact, I was having a bit of fun getting arrested by the UC Security before joining the Crimson Fleet and going along their quest line. Right at the end, however, when it should be challenging and fun, I was faced with what I believe to be, with no exaggeration, the least fun experience I have ever had gaming. There was no challenge. I simply had to attack the Vigilance. For 15 minutes, my guns did absolutely nothing to it. Its health pool, combined with that of its shield system and the recharge rate of its shields meant I could not progress. At the same time, its guns were doing absolutely nothing to my ship. It was a stalemate.

I thought this was simply a skill issue on my part. After all, my ship's weaponry wasn't the greatest. But a quick google search revealed that there were many people who faced this same problem. They recommended turning the difficulty down to very easy, which I did and tried to continue the mission. It took close to another **45 minutes** to actually disable the ship and board it. Thank God I had a second monitor so I could actually do something while my fingers were getting sore, pressing both mouse buttons and the G key. Never have I had the joy sucked from a video game so quickly (joy which, keep in mind, I had to mod into the game). It doesn't matter what I think of the other quests, the mechanics, etc. The fact that a major storyline culminates in such a garbage fight is a travesty of game design.

I bought this game despite the mixed reviews on it and have been pleased with it. It feels like there is a lot to do and the whole thing is voice acted. I enjoy the multiple companions that are available, which is a major part of the game. I like the shooty shooty missions and finding new places to explore. I bought my first new ship and still have many parts of the game to figure out. It is quite a fun game, though I'm still a noob with it. 

It's a heavily quest based space combat, FPS ground shooter with an extremely high NPC social content. Nay-sayers are upset that it isnt a new Skyrim or Elder Scrolls Six game... well, no, it is a well done, story-based, open-world space game that stands on its own. 

It reminds of the Mass Effect series ... except Starfield has space combat.

So, pros:

NPCs bring life to this single player game
Ship combat
FPS combat on the ground and in space 
Lots of quests
Open world 
A number of organizations to join and do missions with. 
A massive world.

Cons:

Cut scenes for ship take off, landing.
Actually travelling by ship from A to B can be graphically skipped and replaced by a button click if you've already been there once. The game is more an RPG and less of a space flight simulation.
Lack of in-game tutorials. I understand people are going to just Google their way to understanding the game anyway, but it would have been nice to not have to alt tab out of the game so much. 
Companion Sarah Morgan....chill the F out, girl!

Take care and enjoy the game. 

edit: 200 some hours in the game now. Still enjoy it.

Somehow... this game never grabbed me. Skyrim In Space, right? Skyrim grabbed me - close to 1000 hours of gameplay with two different characters, but Starfield? The whole way through the game it felt like something big was missing and I was never able to put a finger on it. It just felt...[i]flat[/i]. I hated the spacefight UI and I hated the lack of proper physics response. Hitting the directional thrusters while heading in a straight line should have resulted in a 180-degree ship rotation that should have it facing back along the line of flight while still continuing in the same direction. Instead you got a big loop that was much more like flying biplanes in a WW1 flight sim. The ship UI itself smacked of the simplest (and unfortunately the nastiest) way to solve the problem of displaying the same data across multiple cockpits. Instant immersion crash until you got used to it.

The only really meaningful companion story arc was Andreja. Sarah's story arc did its best but the rest were all meh. Surprisingly, the one companion NPC I did get attached to was Lyn. Unlike the others, even though she only had a relatively short appearance, for some reason she felt more real.

I also found the shipbuilding as frustrating as all hell. It improved with patches and practice but it was still possible to lose a part inside the main ship and the only way to recover was to bail out from the shipbuilder, losing anything you might have done along the way. I soon learned to save-scum that one.

I did complete the game and all of the relevant sidequests. Would I play it again? I tried and failed; I'll not be trying again.

Ah, Starfield—Bethesda's ambitious leap into the cosmos, where players can finally live out their spacefaring dreams. Let's chart a course through its stellar highs and black-hole lows.

Pros:

•	Expansive Universe: Imagine a galaxy teeming with planets, each waiting for your footprints. Starfield offers a vast playground for explorers. 
•	Ship and Outpost Customization: Ever fancied yourself a spaceship designer or a frontier architect? The game's robust customization mechanics let you build and tweak to your heart's content. 
•	Engaging Side Quests: Beyond the main storyline, the game offers a plethora of side missions that add depth and variety to your journey. 

Cons:

•	Underwhelming Main Story: The central narrative may not grip all players, with some finding it less compelling than expected. 
•	Repetitive Exploration: While there's a galaxy to explore, some planets and locations can feel monotonous, leading to a sense of déjà vu. 
•	Technical Issues: Despite improvements, players have reported bugs and performance hitches that can disrupt the immersive experience. 

In summary, Starfield shoots for the stars with its expansive universe and customization options but encounters turbulence with its main narrative and technical hiccups. For those eager to explore the cosmos, it offers a vast sandbox, though some may wish for a more polished voyage.

I wish I could recommend this game because I was really looking forward to playing it, but it doesn't add anything new to Bethesda's repertoire of games. It has very little personality and there's nothing to make it distinct. It's an open-world game that's a good time-waster and that's about it. It's not a very good FPS game, it's not a very good stealth game, it's not a very good crafting game. It's open-world and that's about all it is. It feels like they took a lot of what made Fallout 4 so fun--VATS and the crafting system and its zany dark humor--and removed all of that and made a game with whatever was leftover. If you want a game that feels like Fallout in space, Outer Worlds did it vastly better, and Starfield is totally unmemorable by comparison.

10/10 was a Bethesda game.

I'm going to keep the start of this short so I can get to the recent expansion (not really THAT recent, but Shattered Space is the most recent expansion and I did only recently check it out).
First, the core game I actually liked very much. The mods are also fun especially those that are "Approved" and don't halt progress. I've put in multiple hours, finding countless ways to occupy my time and I've stepped into NG+ multiple times now to enjoy the story in various ways.

I recently acquired Shattered Space and, frankly, I find it offensive that this was a PREMIUM charged add-on. Not only is the ENTIRE MODULE just a massive set of bundled fetch-quests and BS (thank GOD for the Model Atlantis or I probably just would've uninstalled it and missed all the INSANE BUGS in this nearly full-game-priced ripoff).

At one point, I actually had one of the phantoms  challenge me, asking why I'm doing this and, honestly, I found myself largely agreeing with her. What a waste of time and energy.
You know it's going south HARD when I'm playing a net-new branch of the game I've never seen before at all and I'm skipping all of the completely worthless and plodding dialogue, using my scanner to just find the damned path to get me through this nightmare of tedious BS, and just Googling the answers to puzzles because I'm so completely disinterested in the plot established that the prospect of me actually reading this crap and trying to figure it out is just unacceptable.

Honestly, had I not put the hours into it hoping it'd get good I'd be asking for my money back.

There is NOTHING more enjoyable than dropping a whole-ass-game's worth of money on an expansion that is SO BUGGY that quest markers stick, NPCs seem to just appear in places, completely uninterested in what's going on while I'm murdering spirits from the bloody beyond... It's just so insulting.

This is likely the last of my money Bethesda can hope to receive.

I can't believe how low they have stooped, how pathetic this module was... It's funny, my ship is right there, and I could leave just about any time, but I'm just trying to finish this crap so I can move past it and never look back.

literally skyrim but in space. the space ship customization will keep you busy for hours. The factions aren't as memorable as the guilds in skyrim but it definitely has its cinematic moments. It's baffling that this game was released by a AAA studio in 2023, when it feels like a weaker rip-off of so many other games: Outer Worlds, No Man's Sky, or Mass Effect Andromeda (none of which I would describe as stellar to begin with, pun intended). In some ways, it feels like a step backwards from Mass Effect 1 which was released back in 2007. In particular, traveling between planets feels extremely clunky and involves multiple load screens. In general, the story lacks any interest or stakes. The central plot doesn't involve anything life or death, and is ultimately based around space archaeology. That's a tough sell, and one that is poorly suited to a game that otherwise is based around gun combat. Bethesda doesn't seem interested in fleshing out the "archaeology" elements any more than a general "mystery box" plot in the style of Lost. In order for a low-stakes archaeology game to work, a studio really needs to double-down on those themes, like Heaven's Vault or at the very least Tomb Raider. In total, every element of the game from plot, characters, to gameplay/combat feels bland and generic. Any one of those might be passable if another element were amazing, but all of them being mediocre results in a soulless game.

There's no substance to this game, every world is the same, every gun the same, every NPC the same, every quest the same. There is nothing here worth it. 

Ships aren't flyable in atmosphere, only within certain zones, and even then, it almost feels like walking rather than flying a spaceship, Ships also are just loading screens to a point, imagine a horse cart from Skyrim, you get in, select a destination, and your there. I will be honest, i bought the collectors edition, and i do not regret it. I just wish it didnt come with the game at this point.

a massive universe to explore, promises of deep storytelling, and years of anticipation. Unfortunately, for many players, it failed to live up to the hype.

One major gripe is the game's world design. While Bethesda promised expansive, immersive planets to explore, many players find the planets barren, repetitive, and lacking meaningful content. The sense of wonder one would expect from exploring the cosmos often fades into tedium as the gameplay boils down to collecting resources or encountering uninspired procedurally generated content.

The storytelling, another hallmark of Bethesda games, feels thin and uninspired in Starfield. The main questline, while ambitious, struggles to maintain engagement due to predictable plot points and underdeveloped characters. Side quests, which should add richness to the world, often feel like filler missions rather than compelling narratives that reward exploration.

** 2nd Update 

After playing the game through almost to the end as far as missions go, and I'm now at a point where I want to build Outposts, decorate my houses, and so on .. I'm going to give Starfield 6/10, the 6 for some interesting parts, like the Ship Building and general ideas like the Research and Weapon/Gear modifications .. but, the game loses 4 solid points for one thing alone ..

.. the terrible restrictions on placing items, such a food items on a shelf, which you'd imagine was perhaps the easiest task imaginable, but Starfield turns it into a constant fight with the restrictions built into the game itself as far as object collision and physics goes.

So .. 6/10 for Starfield. 
Slightly above average for what should have been a great game, even with some very good mods, considering all the experience Bethesda could/should have gained from Fallout 4.

_______________________

** 1st Update 

Well, the game has bugs, after 7 years in development and nearly 2 years after its release, but then this is Bethesda, and this is not unusual for them.

My first game crash too .. so, definite Bethesda normalisation of SNAFU.

Also, Steam Achievements will be disabled if you ACCIDENTLY open the console window and don't enter any command, just opening it does this.

My next play through will be with Mods, much like Fallout 4, using a lot of good Mods which will make Starfield the game it was supposed to be.

________________________

So far, so good.

Starfield is my favorite game. I enjoy it so much I started a YouTube channel to share what I like about it. SF provides the systems, environment, and opportunities that I want in a truly open world CRPG. I'm not there for the story. I'm there for the chance to start the game and do whatever I'm interested in -- exploring, building a ship, creating an outpost, raiding a POI, rescuing a hostage, etc. The ability to create mods, interact with the engine, and learn how the game works is also unlike games from other developers.

I went into this game blind, not knowing anything and ignoring 'mixed reviews', but having played Fallout and Elder Scrolls in the past and looking for a single player, role-playing experience. I am hooked - This game is phenomenal - the story telling is excellent, the worlds are huge and well defined, the graphics are beautiful, and I am honestly blown away and enthralled. I haven't been this excited and into a game in a long time!! The game play is smooth - combat is fun and engaging and challenging on normal difficulty, space combat is a blast and super thrilling and also challenging - I got in over my head once with pirates and it was a tough spot to be in but very rewarding when I finally succeeded. 

Story wise - the stakes are high, the choices to become who you want to be in the starfield are amazing, the characters are intriguing and there are so many of them living their lives out there. This game isn't one you just pick up for a little bit here and there - it's one you sit down with like a good book and really get into.

The only caveat I would say to others is - don't expect the game to be No Man's Sky. It is not No Man's Sky. It's Bethesda - It's Fallout and Skyrim but in space. It's ~wonderful~!! <3

Fallout 4 in space. This is a great game. Granted, i haven't played too much yet, but this seems like a quality game. I don't understand why this has so many negative reviews. Only "negative" aspect of Starfield is that it seems to need very fast RAM (like prior Creation Engine games) to get very high framerates. I have DDR4 3200mhz and while it never drops lower than 40fps, most of the time i average around 50fps on high settings. This is a game that needs the fastest RAM you can find. Happened again with Fallout 4, which scaled almost lineraly with ram speed. So many people complaining about low framerates, really have potato pcs, and they think only their graphics card matters while in fact for very detailed openworld games like this, RAM speed matters just as much.

But then the flaws started to appear, so many that I don't even have the strength to name them. You will end up with the feeling of being inconsequential. The game is either rigged with heavily scripted and meaningless quests or barren proceduraly generated content.

Bethesda should have been cranking out new POI's in updates for the last two years. Expectations have changed since skyrim came out 50 years ago and no one at Bethesda got the memo.  This is an empty game/abandonware. It hasn't materially changed in two years.  I don't blame Bethesda really, you people buying Skyrim 5 times taught them to be this way. 

Another piece of advice from someone who works around M&A, as soon as your favorite software developer is acquired by a big company, like Zenimax, it's gone.  Bethesda isn't going to be anything more than what it is now, it is past its peak.  This isn't an opinion, Zenimax bought it as an investment instrument and expects it to pay out at better performance than what they paid for it, which would have been some multiplicative value of its revenue or EBITDA. They do this by "streamlining" , aka cost cutting, aka not taking risks for developing things that they know people are already paying for.  I'm not saying there aren't logical fallacies in that line of thinking - I'm just saying that is what happens. Todd isn't driving the ship anymore, and he wasn't the design visionary he worked hard to portray himself to be. Everything was about the sale to Zenimax and executives often receive great ongoing deals to stay on as the face after a merger to convince the idiots that they are still getting a great candid product.

This game is huge and varied. The first game since Sykrim(yes sorry that word) that I feel within an hour my game is totally unique for anyone else's. The space travel does to a point break you out of the immersion, in a way that a mythical single world game would but this has never claimed to be anything but a space game. 

After the initial how to, how you play is up to you, spend a day on a single planet scanning and building up a base, or maybe jump from tiny quest to tiny quest killing off. Spend a few hours engaging in space battles, or following up of companion stories. 

My advise is to ignore the haters who find one glitch and say its crap, and give it a chance. Anyone with over 100 hours on a game (sometimes far more) and then says they don't recommend it is just lying and trying to fill some empty space inside of them, that is not on the game - numbers are much stronger indicators than words. (I am 143 hours in for reference)
