I am a Space and science fanatic and have played countless space-themed games. I bought Starfield after sinking thousands of hours into games like Star Citizen, Stellaris, X4, Kerbal Space Program, Prey, Endless Space 1 and 2, Terra Invicta, Sins of a Solar Empire 1 and 2, and many more. So, when I heard that Starfield was coming out and was being developed by Bethesda, I was instantly drawn to it. I heard it had about 1000 planets and moons and so much more to explore so I was SO excited and I was instantly sold when I saw the gameplay videos and other content showcase videos. So I pre-purchased Starfield as soon as possible and started playing as soon as it released. Then I was taken back by all the loading screens and other various issues I had. So I put it down for a bit. BUT... I decided to start a new game and seriously put some time into it because I really wanted to love it. So, once I got a bit further into the game, I was hooked. It is gorgeous and there are so many places that are exactly the kind of awe-inspiring scenes I would hope to see if we were one day able to travel through the universe. I have FAR more hours than it shows here, too, but that's a whole other story. But after a couple patches and large updates, most of the issues people had with the game are fixed and Bethesda has a lot planned for the future of Starfield. So, anyone who is a fanatic of space and Sci-Fi like me and also loves really in-depth RPGs, you should DEFINITELY give Starfield a chance. I am REALLY happy that I did. It is a gorgeous, well thought out, amazing adventure. There is an incredible amount of content and things to do. The different jobs and ways to earn money is enough to keep ya busy for countless hours. I have definitely played over 300 hours (not counting the 38 hours in my new game) and I haven't even scratched the surface of all the places to explore and activities to start. The characters you meet are diverse and the stories that progress with each path you choose are very interesting. One thing I will recommend when you first start is don't worry about grabbing every bit of loot. There is SOOO much you can pick up so, especially in the beginning, just grab the most valuable stuff like gear and weapons and stuff like that. You can also go back to places if you need something later. So i suggest you just stick with it and once the story opens up and you can start choosing the direction you want, you will really start enjoying the gorgeous world they created. That combat and gun-play is definitely fun. The enemies are extremely diverse. The near-infinite possibilities of exploration form a wild ride. The ship building is really interesting once you open up the vast amount of options to customize them the way you want. The incredible amount of ways to make money definitely keeps you engaged and makes it so you can switch things up when one method starts to become a bit repetitive. Then there's the mods which offer an incredible amount customization with so many options. So, I definitely recommend you give it a chance. I can only imagine the work that went into creating a game of this magnitude. I believe it deserves an honest chance. I am happy that I looked past my petty disappointments and gave it a second chance because I am thoroughly impressed.

After countless hours in Bethesda’s Starfield, I’ve realized something: space is vast… and apparently, it can also be incredibly dull.

Starfield isn’t a terrible game. It’s the gaming equivalent of lukewarm coffee: it does the job, but it never excites you. The universe looks limitless at first glance, a thousand planets, endless promises. But the reality? Fetch quests across procedurally generated outposts that all blur together.

It’s like being promised a trip around the world, only to spend most of it stuck in identical airport terminals. Technically serviceable. Completely forgettable.

Verdict: Starfield proves that size alone doesn’t make a journey worth taking.

A sterilized fast-travel simulator functioning as an experiment to see if the endless profit system that arena shooters are popularizing can be converted into a single player format. (Nope, it can't!) The only reason I'm playing it still, and have played it as much as I have, is because I have not much else going on. Believe me, if I'd rather get another vasectomy but it's not really an option unless I want to browbeat my doctor into slicing open my beanbag again. I sincerely recommend NO ONE plays this game.

Gone are options from past games (the things that made the games so good) because you don't get to side with who you might want to for the grand finale, you HAVE to side with Conste-suck. Well, NMS is already a great game, and little boy bro Howard couldn't even figure out how to get from planet to space without a loading screen. But if little boy bro Howard thinks I'm even going to consider TES6 after this tragedy, well, there's a reason we call him little boy bro Howard. Well, that and ToddBucks, the HIGHLY PREDATORY in-game currency you can purchase to buy mods from the creation club. Mind you, you'll notice, you CANNOT buy ToddBucks for an amount equal to any one item you may wish to purchase. You will ALWAYS be just too short, or a little over, for how much you need. Oh, and on a personal note, to the absolutely low-IQ slug with a knack for little kids of a "lEaD dEvElOpEr", no, you loser. You wildly incorrect, butthurt loser, players aren't tired of 100 hour games. They're tired of Starfield's lack of variety in quests, constant crashes and Bethesda's subtle hand guiding players on the preferred path (if you believe in God, you'll HATE this game. If you enjoy freedom of choice in your RPG, you'll also hate this game. It's Bethesda's Way or the Highway.) New rule: little boy bro Howard fires that useless dev who isn't mature enough to accept responsibility, and maybe the community doesn't urinate all over the future of little boy bro Howard's grave with millions of unsold copies of TES6.

Whilst they have this "superior to thou" attitude (yes I'm looking at you Todd) and think they know better about what us consumers want in a game than we do, they will continue to make dull, soulless games. Anyway, enough of my rambling. Just don't buy the game, but if you do, you have been warned

Dogwater.

One of these days Bethesda really ought to hire one competent writer or a person that payed attention during game design 101 or even just anyone with a modicum of common sense. 
Edit: I wrote this in stark disappointment and would like to apologize to any Bethesda employees who are trying to create a better product but are held back by the economic requirements of the slop-mill.
Trash

The campaign is fucking garbage.

The Shattered Space DLC is fucking garbage.

The soundtrack is fucking garbage.

The Base building aspect is fucking garbage and a huge missed opportunity. There are literally thousands of items, objects, buildings, materials, and other assets in this game that could easily have been added to this system and made it a massive base building game, but instead we are limited to just 21 structure pieces and less than 200 furniture items, most of which are just different variations and near identical to each other.

The ship building aspect is far more satisfying than the base building aspect, but it is still very limited. Building ships is also extremely clunky because certain ship parts can only be attached at specific vendors.

The universe is boring and is just limited to a bunch of solar systems with a sun, gas planets, regular planets and moons. You'll never see anything cool like supernovas, black holes, neutron stars, pulsars etc.

The planets and moons you can visit are just boring procedurally generated surfaces with mostly nothing on them, and they completely lack any weather effects. Even planets in the Sol system lack familiar landmarks like the massive Olympus Mons mountain on Mars for example and any ocean you find on the planets are only as deep as a puddle.

Space travel is unsatisfying.

Ship combat is unsatisfying.

The perk system is trash and boring.

Weapons feels good to use, but the lack of gore and dismemberment sours the entire experience.

Some of the faction quests are fun, but that's it.

Fucking terrible game overall.

Interesting for about an hour. Not even new experiences and the "unique story" do nothing to save this game. Interesting ideas are barely given any energy, any thought, and they all fall apart before they can actually be realized, or they never actually reach a climax to begin with. It's a meaningless time sink.

If you're asking yourself "should I buy this?" here is a quick way to figure that out:
Are you going to mod the game? If yes, then buy it. If no, then do not buy it. It's that simple.

This game has 3 core issues:
a.) It tries to be a space game without actually managing to be a space game. The actual "space" part of it plays abysmally (ship combat is a joke, and you can and should skip 80% of ship travelling process with fast travel because otherwise you're wasting an unreasonable amount of time just watching the same cutscenes and animations for a 10 second or less in-space timeframe). This isn't a matter of the genre being a problem; we've seen games like No Mans Sky get this part right, even if the rest of that game was less than lively. But Bethesda just chose to make it a space-thematic game, not a space game

b.) It feels like we went backwards. It takes more from the Fallout progression system, where you just get total XP not tied to specific categories, and can level up anything. I personally feel this is going away from the iconic "level-what-you-use" system that TES has. Also, little things--taking gear off of enemies does not visibly remove it from them, the game has more bugs and more game-breaking issues than previous titles (as much as people give Bethesda a hard time about this, I think its fair to say that an average playthrough of Skyrim or Fallout has minor bugs or user-error type bugs. This game feels like there's a major game-breaking issue every 20 minutes to worry about), and the UI is disappointingly unintuitive compared to what I've learned to expect from previous titles. Also, the perk system just kinda... Sucks. You look at games like Fallout and Skyrim, then you look at this and ask yourself... Was this a completely different dev team?
*(Quick Edit, now that I've spent even more time playing... the gameplay loop doesn't even feel like thought or effort was put into it at all? Several of the MAIN STORY missions take place in the exact same couple of dungeons? Like, cookie-cutter identical. No feeling of new exploration, no unique puzzles to solve, just: go here, shoot this, grab that. I thought I was critical before I wrote this review, but it only gets worse. Imagine Skyrim if every other main quest mission was "return to Bleak Falls Barrow!" with the same exact objective and enemy spawns. Yikes.)

c.) The story elements. I've played a lot of games in my time, and there have been plenty where I picked up and said "ah, this isn't for me, its a kinda boring," but this? This isn't boring because its not a game for me. It's boring because the writing was just plain awful. The dialogue feels forced, the main story doesn't even feel like it was cohesive or made sense ("Oh hey, I just met you, take my ship and this extremely valuable thing I came here specifically for, I'll trust you!"), the options feel amusingly limited, and honestly... It feels like they only put enough effort into it to be able to legally call it a game release instead of an engine with a proof of concept attached. Besides the fact the gameplay feels super choppy (see section A about the nonstop fast travel), it just seems like a base created for the sole purpose of being modded / *actually developed* by the community.

So, TLDR, not up to Bethesda standards and buying Starfield is like buying Garry's Mod. Unless you're going to kit it out, don't bother. On that note, everything after the 24 hour mark of gameplay that I've done has been using the Star Wars Genesis modpack, and the game is actually enjoyable, so that's my recommendation to my fellow nerds.

Trust the mixed reviews and avoid this title. 

The writing is abysmal and the game play locks you out of "standard" game play functions. Everything is locked behind perks including stealth, you simply can't crouch or sneak until its unlocked. 

I gave it an hour and a half, what killed the experience for me was the way you were thrust into the story. You literally wake up in a mine as a new miner and within ten minuets someone from an organization just hands you his ship/robot. 

The robot sends you on a mission to attack some nameless pirates, you do so and then go drop off this mystical artifact to this group of people who instantly want you to join with zero information/motivation on who you are. 

The game-play feels alright, aside from the way progression locks out what I would consider basic features. The gun play actually is one of its stronger points. Ship to ship combat felt underwhelming and inconsequential. 

By no means is it worth $70

All and all I think it would be worth $35-$40 at most. I just wish the writing held up to any of the quality/level of content that Skyrim or even the previous fallout titles.

It's a good game but not a great game, unlike Skyrim which was amazing for TES in 2011. If you are a fan of TES and Bethesda games you should have already played this, especially if you can get it on a sale.

The good thing about this game is that if you are a fan of sci-fi you can find fun things to do. The faction you play as in the main quests sometime reminds me of a what a failed attempt to launch a Starfleet type organisation would be like in a world that is not so idyllic for humans and the universe reminds me of the one from Dark Matter.

The game mechanics we all know from Fallout 4 and others have been recycled to a very bland flavour with some exceptions: Good FPS mechanics and movement, some great quests and locations, ship building and editing, not the actual ship flying and combat though. The new stuff is often lackluster, like the ship flying, which only serves to limit you from fast travelling across the galaxy too quickly and to force some random encounters/events. The skills and powers mechanics are especially uninspired.

It's still a good game, that will give you dozens of hours of gamepaly if not hundreds, with or without mods.

It doesn't perform very well. I build this PC with this game in mind and needed an upgrade anyway, so it should have been running smooth as butter. The game was even included with the GPU... 

I run the game with everything on high, with upscaling disabled and game rendered at full resolution on 1080p. According to AMD i'm in the 95th percentile with 112 FPS on average. Yet the game has constant frame drops in cities, large inside locations or locations with 0 gravity, even when capped at 60FPS. Basically any time there are a lot of objects in play, it's gonna drop frames, so you better have a beast of a CPU.

Overall we need to let Bethesda know that this is not gonna be profitable for future TES or Fallout titles, if they even care.
They are now owned by the same company that owns xbox and windows... so what's the excuse when their game has a terrible launch and is simply not optimised to run on even just an above average PC?

Todd Howard sir, please try harder. Quantity is obviously not better than quality.

Just great

when i first tried it, i found the intro so uninspired, and all the dialogues uninspired, and the first city's look so uninspired and empty, that i thought the whole game would be like this.
unfortunately by the time i tried the game twice and had the same experience, too much time had passed and i could no longer refund.

so i pushed through, and accidentally discovered that this game is actually a jewel. yes the intro sucks and yes all the characters have uninspiring dialogue (and animations). actually, the dialogue is almost castrated: i think they let too many dei feminists play developer and the entire dialogue suffered.

but if you just ignore the dialogue, this is what you'll get: absolutely stunning environments (everywhere there's a futuristic hi-tech place to explore it's a joy), great looting and shooting experience (very fun & reactive), and super interesting missions (mainly because they lead you to cool places and the mission writing itself is good, but the dialogue sucks so you need to ignore it).

so, considering that the dialogue sucks but this game has tons of exciting places to visit with cool missions to do, i would say it's a 50-50: you either can ignore the dialogue and immerse into the atmosphere, and if so you'll love it a lot... or you'll  notice all the flaws (including loading screens) and won't be able to enjoy it.

i would strongly recommend checking out the game if you have a good gpu, bc it's such good environments that they offset all the other flaws. and the missions are plentiful: truly there's a lot of fun to have. this is one of the coolest most DETAILED games bethesda has ever done. i mean, there's details everywhere in the environment, everything was painfully hand crafted, it's just a joy to explore! and there's missions to keep you going, just jumping around admiring every environment....

it's too bad they ruined the dialogue and made the characters all stupid otherwise others would have enjoyed it too (everything is politically correct, the super cool mysterious leader of the main bounty hunters' assassin faction is some kind of non-binary they/them, men are gay while women are warriors, and every companion is super annoyed if you do anything remotely "bad"). anyway, i think it's nearly a masterpiece because i've never seen such detailed environments and solid questlines to get you around. others will say it's trash, i say it's nearly the best game bethesda put out (minus acting and main story), definitely the best world. do what you want write comments if you need clarification!

Now the the sting of the initial purchase has worn off I think it's fair to flip my review from thumbs down to thumbs up. That means the caveat to this is that you buy the game on a discount.

I think Starfield is a good proof of concept. It does some things really well. Different planets have different gravity which I think is something that is truly novel. Jumping into the game to shoot people in a sci-fi setting is pretty well delivered on. Overall, the mechanics of the game in a vacuum are all delivered upon competently and when you put them all together in one package you get a theoretically good game. That said, the game's practical issues are still pretty numerous. 

If you're not on a nicer rig, the load times are going to be a fucking pain in the ass. Overworlds are much smaller and more sparse compared to Elder Scrolls games so the implementation of load screens feels significantly more annoying. I'm running a setup slightly better than the game's listed recommended settings and playing on a modless game doesn't feel too bad. So if you're the same this won't be a significant issue.

The player background options are pretty neat. I liked being able to have access to parents and an adoring fan by choice. The parents also do their own traveling so you get some cute little easter eggs from time to time. The parents also get modeled based off your playable character so they "fit" in universe regardless of what you look like. That said, aside from the brief, "heh that's neat" moments you get with them, there's not much else interaction.

That's basically par for the course for the entirety of Starfield. You get a lot of stuff executed fairly competently on its own. You can see the amibition that was there, but none of it works well together. You can fly around in your space ship and dog fights feel pretty fun, but you can't explore the universe in it like you can in No Man's Sky or in Elite Dangerous. Ground missions are fine since you have a decent number of small immersive details that make it feel good, but you can't stay anywhere for too long since most planets are just boring and barren. There is something of a relationship system in the game, but it's not deep enough to feel worthwhile which sucks because you can create an entire crew to man your bases. And of course the whole base building aspect is pretty cool as well, but is really a fucking pain in the ass to grind out with out mods that essentially help you cheat.

So overall Starfield is a jack of all trades, master of none kind of game. I think it offers echoes of what we can hope for in the future when game designers can learn from its mistakes and technical tools improve to allow for more complex features to be easier to implement, but until that day we'll have to settle with sci-fi games that really focus in on certain elements of gameplay rather than trying to be as ambitious as something like what Starfield was imagined to be.

Warning about creation credits:

Bought $20 worth of creation credits in 2 seperate  purchases over a day ago.  Credits are not on my account.  Steam page says to go to Bethesda support, Bethesda page says to go to Steam Support.  Account is clearly marked as linked to steam on bethesda store page and have had no issues before.

Please note for anyone considering buying creation club points on steam, Points MAY NOT BE POSTED TO YOUR ACCOUNT, NO REFUNDS ARE AVAILABLE, and as of now, NO OFFICIAL SUPPORT FOR CREATION CLUB POINTS PURCHASE TECHNICAL ISSUES OR FAILED TRANSFERS IS AVAILABLE FROM STEAM OR BETHESDA.

$20 down the drain, can't play the game because I was specifically wanting to check out those creations, who knows if the points will ever come or not....  Absolutely unacceptable from a AAA game from a major company.


Edit:  This was finally resolved after 3 days - I did get my credits eventually, though I missed being able to play the game for a whole weekend I had off and could have been playing...

I do like starfield as a game pretty good, but I am leaving this up for people, be really careful buying credits on steam.

Note that if you do have problems, because it is really not obvious, I could never get a ticket to submit under the creation club or creation credit section of support - I had to go to the section for Starfield itself, go to purchase support, and submit a ticket under "I didn't get my stuff".   This will let you actually get into contact with support that can help you, but they still won't do anything if it hasn't been 3 days...

Just info for anyone contemplating buying points.   Again Starfield itself I like and the actual content I bought worked fine, it's just an issue with the store itself.

If you enjoyed their other games series like Fallout and Elder Scrolls you will enjoy the gameplay style. If you enjoyed Mass Effect you may enjoy the space exploration aspect of Starfield. While I definitely do recommend this game to others there are some aspects they could improve on. I would like to see more in game tutorials teaching us about some of the unique features in this game like outpost development and ship building. I would also really like to see a galactic community with intelligent alien species from unknown regions. The Starborn are cool but not quite what I was hoping for out of a space exploration game. I want to explore alien worlds and see how they evolved differently. I want their ships and architecture to look alien compared to ours. Maybe add a species that has evolved their tech through Biology instead of Electronics. They could even add little Easter Egg worlds that are small parts of their other games. I actually think that would be one of the coolest things they could do. Their other games could easily be added to Starfield as expansions or a way to link their universes like Marvel has done. I would be cool to have a quest line where we had to protect an under developed world like Nirn and broker a protection agreement between the UC and the leaders of Tamriel. It would also be pretty cool to find a Fallout Vault on Earth.

Basebuilding also seemed to me to be something they added in at the last minute as I cannot actually see the point in them. Money is almost pointless in this game aside from using it to upgrade your ship and restock on ammo.

There's nothing I can say that hasn't already been said, but I'm still going to say it. After pouring a substantial amount of time into this game and being an active supporter when it first released, I cannot recommend this game to anyone. If I hadn't received this game for free as part of a GPU bundle and paid actual money for this, I would have been livid. The comparison to No Mans Sky is getting old, but it's still fitting. This game is like when No Mans Sky first released - repetitive, dry, lacking anything interesting, and giving you no reason to explore or continue playing. The biggest difference is that the developers at Hello Games actually cared about player feedback. Bethesda has shown that they don't. The fact that it took months for them to implement things as minor as a map for the cities and planets that you FREQUENTLY visit is telling. The fact that they charged money for "mods" that don't work properly, the fact that the DLC they dropped after the vast majority of the player base already left was as bland as the base game (as well as the fact that your companion who *should* have strong opinions about what's happening in the DLC has almost no unique interactions or lines throughout but that's a whole other rant), the fact that the end of the story and main mechanic is in complete opposition to everything else the game tries to be, and the fact that not even modders care about improving this disaster shows how much of a stain this game is on the struggling world of sci-fi RPGs and the gaming community in general. Aside from a complete overhaul of the game, rewriting of the story, and greatly improved traversal, there's nothing that Bethesda could do to make me redownload this waste of storage space. Save your money and time. Go play something made by developers who actually care about their game and player base.

I tried to enjoy this game. I really did. I love the Fallout series, I love Elder Scrolls, and space/sci-fi is easily my favorite fictional setting...by all rights if this was a good game I should have enjoyed it.

I did every quest, the most interesting ones are still bland and rely on fetch-quest mechanics for 90% of them. There's very little choice interaction in the game, with a bunch of forced decisions. Nothing feels worth it for quest rewards, so you aren't really motivated to complete them anyway. Named weapons don't feel special. Skills feel more like barriers to enjoyment than they do ability.

Graphically the game is impressive, but performance wise you probably can't really enjoy them too. My PC is well above the recommended specs and I still have major performance loss in certain areas.

There's a bunch of random stuff to craft, but most of it is identical to one another in everything but the visuals. Crafting does not feel fulfilling. 

You can build a ship. It's one of the cooler parts of the game. The caveat is, there's a bunch of rules for how to build your ship, and they don't list what those rules are anywhere. Are you going to need more landers? There's no indicator for why you need a specific number, but they won't let you finish until there are enough. 

If I could give it a X/10 rating, I would say 4/10. It's not terrible, but it's definitely not good too. It doesn't help that Bethesda keeps patting themselves on the back over how good it is...like have you actually played it devs? I think you haven't.

TLDR: pass on this one if you expect a Bethesda game of the past.

If you want info on why the game is poor, you can find it in plenty everywhere. Best comment I ever read on this game was something like "an ocean 1 inch deep." If you want the opposite of this game, to play a game that did everything right that Bethesda did wrong, that gave a darn, that actually understand customer satisfaction, game design, etc, play Breath of the Wild. Leave it to the Japanese to put true heart and soul into a game, true mastery, true love. But Starfield, nope. My dreams of Elder Scrolls VI, letting go now. May our dreams and sense of adventure be immortalized in games past. For the future, don't look to the stars, don't look to Bethesda, RIP.

Starfield: A Game That Never Lets You Play

It’s not that *Starfield* is the worst game ever—it’s the worst because you never actually get to play the game. There’s nothing to explore, nothing to do. Instead, you’re stuck with tedious quests that boil down to talking to forgettable NPCs on outposts or planets. To get to any and every interaction is buried under multiple load screens, and you can’t even fly your ship there—you just fast-travel, sit through a dull conversation, and get a quest marker leading you to another empty planet.  

Bethesda somehow thinks this is good game design. Sure, it looks better than *Fallout 4*, but the writing is so lifeless that you’ll struggle to stay awake. Exploration? Nonexistent. It’s just fast-traveling through a never-ending loop of loading screens and menus, holding a button to trigger another loading screen.  

When you finally reach combat, it’s over before you can even wake up from the monotony. There’s no sense of adventure, no real immersion—just an exhausting series of menu clicks and loading screens pretending to be a game.  

This isn’t just a bad game—it’s barely a game at all.

I was sure I was done with one NPC's interactions when she asked me for another favor more than 25 levels later. Quite a shock! This is the kind of thing that has some people claiming the game is shallow - they don't dig enough. 
The game also requires some imagination on the player's part. You will not be spoon-fed every detail about your character. Who your character is and what they are doing in the Starfield is up to you. Your PC's motivations might matter a great deal. Some people play to build the game's outposts, some to tweak the UC's nose. You'll have to decide why you're playing.

I really, really tried to like this game. The idea of a new bethesda rpg in a sci-fi space setting sounds awesome, but honestly they really let us down. The game consistently fails the player in so many ways. Skip to the end for the tl;dr.

The UI is terrible. You have to press two different buttons to bring up the local map, and then leaving the local map takes four button presses, including a multiple second animation of you leaving the menu. Everything in the game is like this. Whatever the obvious, streamlined approach to designing an interface would be, bethesda went in the opposite direction. Basic inventory management feels like pulling teeth, which is terrible because inventory management is roughly 40% of this game's playtime due to limited storage options and cargo space.

If these were the only issues, I would probably excuse them and wait for the modders to do the work that bethesda is to lazy to do and release better ui mods. But the story also fails the player by fundamentally misunderstanding what an rpg is. In my opinion the rpg tag on this game's steam page is false advertising. The game forces you to play a very specific character. You have to play a space explorer that's obsessed with collecting artifacts and is willing to steal and murder to obtain them. One of the main quests literally involves slaughtering the crew of an innocent ship to steal an artifact from them. There is no way to persuade the owner of the artifact to sell it to you, nor is there a way to steal it without alerting the ship's security (it is scripted to always turn everyone on the ship hostile). All of the game's four main companions end up looking like hypocrites, because they encourage you to do this but in most other instances will get mad and leave you if you commit crimes. If you aren't willing to murder innocent civilians for the sake of putting together a cool looking rock, then this game isn't for you. The only "choice" you get to make with your character is in regards to the faction side quests, which essentially boils down to being one of two flavors of space cop, or being a pirate. And don't even think about getting attached to one of the four main followers, because the story kills off whichever one you like the most. Its specifically scripted to kill the follower you spend the most time with. And after they kill that follower off, they have the gall to not even let the player be sad about it, even if you were romancing that person. Your character immediately dusts themselves off and continues the previous quest, even though your spouse just died a needless death. There's no way to express any grief to any of the other characters.  The main story is full of moments like this, that completely remove the player's agency and railroad you into playing an unfeeling robot that is willing to do anything for the sake of the mission.

On a mechanical side, the outpost building is also missing a ton. There's no foundations, floors, or walls to build with. You can only place small prefab structures that link into each other in specific, limited ways. There's also no regular doors for outpost structures, only airlocks that essentially act as 10 second loading screens any time you want to enter a building. The "snap together" is incredibly overbearing, so you can't place objects in the vicinity of each other without the game automatically connecting them in rigid and awkward ways. All of the creativity of the fallout 4 settlement system is completely removed in favor of a cookie cutter "function over form" approach that leaves all outposts looking roughly the same.

The game is also very lackluster from a quality assurance perspective. Trees randomly spawned in the middle of my outpost, blocking access to my storage containers. Your followers clip through the floor and talk to you from the other side of walls. The game crashes at random intervals during normal gameplay (as of this review I've gotten five crashes). Enemies can shoot you through closed doors. Enemies also sometimes just stand in front of you not doing anything instead of attacking. The guards that scan my ship in orbit still call my ship the frontier even though I'm flying a completely different, story relevant ship (the razorleaf). Loading screens also occasionally spoil major plot points like [spoiler] Heat Leeches being the source of Terrormorphs [/spoiler]. I didn't even know that it was supposed to be a big reveal because the game told me matter of fact that it was the case before I even got to that quest. Resources you mark as tracked sometimes can't be untracked, so the entire tracked resource system becomes pointless.

The devs also obviously didn't play test the game, since its really easy to accidentally soft lock yourself if you don't play the exact way the devs anticipated. During one of the main story missions, I took a back door out of Neon (one of the game's major cities) instead of walking the long way. Going to the ship and leaving the planet in this manner permanently locks you out of fast travelling, forcing the player to reload. During another story mission (High Price to Pay), I parked my ship in a different spot than the game expected and it ended up soft-locking the game. I had to load an older save just to get the game to work. And these were both main story missions, not obscure side missions.

TL;DR: Overall this game just feels like a cash grab from an out of touch company that didn't really care about the quality of the product so long as it made them their investment back (especially with how much they keep pushing creation club content). There was obviously care put into this game, but no amount of care can overcome the bugs, ui issues, and bad writing. Only buy it if you are willing to install bugfix and ui mods to make it playable, and even then, be warned that the story is nonsensical and full of moments that remove player agency.

Its a tried and tested formula for Bethesda - if you've played any of their games then you will see that this is basically Fallout 4, which was basically Fallout 3 and then Oblivion before it...But the idea is the same 1st person character, wander round following storylines getting better kit and upgrading your character.  Crafting stations and settlements are all here (its basically Fallout 4 except re-imagined in space).  So its perfectly entertaining.  I haven't completed the main storyline yet as I have got too distracted in all the side quests, some of which are really quite fun.  

Some of the things I like - the look and feel is amazing, they've done a good job with the mechanics and I like the way the ship flies, its nice and easy (as someone who has spent a lot of time in Elite Dangerous I was worried how this would be) and you can wander round your ship.  

Some of the things I dont like:  the interface is incredibly clunky, confusing and oftentimes an absolute pain in the backside.  The Shipbuilding facility is also one of those that you're going to need to watch some youtube videos to understand - they could have made that a lot easier to use.  

It takes a decent PC to run it so make sure your hardware is up to date!

Here is a list of pros and cons I had with the game.

Pros
- Decent gun play for a Bethesda game
- Amazing ship building and customising
- Pretty good faction quest lines in the game
- Decent upgrading system for your character
- Some very good random interactions throughout space and side missions
- Some breathtaking scenery good for photo mode
- Decent space battles
- Solid companions and companion quests
- outpost building is pretty good
- very good main cities unfortunately their are only 3
- Good lore involving the war that happened

Cons
- Boring main story that takes too long to get anything going.
- Almost all planets are very barren, boring, and not worth going to
- Auto generation of planets ruins the game and goes against what made Bethesda games good in the first place 
- Many reused assets throughout auto generated planets results in repetitive game play 
- Traversal throughout planets is slow and bad even with the addition of land vehicles
- Lacking choice and consequence for siding with certain factions.
- A lot of loading screens and fast travelling
- Not much weapon variety
- No unique weapons, all randomly generated base weapons which really sucks
- The game wastes your time a lot
- Star born powers just feel like a watered down dragon born shout rip off
-Lack of handcrafted areas and main cities.

Overall rating 6.5-7/10

Lemme start off by sayin' that I absolutely love this game. Why can't I recommend it? Let me put it this way. If you are a Bethesda fan, you already know expectations for this game were way too high. That was inevitable. This game takes so many flaws of Bethesda in the past and multiplies them. That combined with the repeated layouts of locations, the poor writing, and the unholy amount of loading screens creates a symphony that reinforces the "Bethesda Cycle" that happens with every single release. 

The issue with Starfield specifically is that, again, it magnifies the problems of the past while also creating new ones such as repeated layouts for POIs over and over and over again. You will see Abandoned Cryo Lab a few times on different planets with the same lore in the same predetermined locations with the same enemy locations with the same locked doors. Over and over for as long as you can tolerate.

COMBAT! I was not even slightly surprised to find out that it inherits the deranged scaling of Fallout 4 with the added kick in the nuts of FURTHER NERFING your dealt damage in each NG+ cycle alongside increasing the damage enemies deal. Sure you can change it with mods that remove NG+ damage changes and use the gameplay settings to more broadly adjust the damage you and your enemies do. The problem is that doing it feels nearly necessary after a certain point and that shouldn't be the case. The gunplay is Fallout 4 without VATS and nearly no changes beyond that. Zero-G is a thing but it really isn't that special and melee isn't great like it was in every Bethesda game before. Aside from the typical basic animations, the scaling of melee is bad despite the buffs they later gave to melee.

The movement. Well, I don't really have any complaints there. The boost packs add a fair bit of vertical movement that previous Bethesda titles just didn't have, which is good for people who want the high ground in a gunfight. Adds a lot of freedom in how you tackle a situation. They aren't perfect but their quality is subjective in this case and I prefer the Skip Packs. Skips have the best forward movement, Power has the best vertical, Balanced is in between. They also consume different amounts of replenishing boost charge so keep an eye on that if you choose to buy this game. 

Ship building. I suck at it and all of mine look ugly as sin. The way this builder is handled is very basic. There is nothing special about it and there doesn't need to be. You have size limits for height and width but that can be modded out. You'll probably notice the theme of "It can be modded out" just like other Bethesda titles and that isn't a compliment. I've rambled enough, so I will conclude.

I do not recommend this game unless you are okay with the flaws I mentioned and many I did not. I love this game despite these numerous flaws.

Although do note that the negative criticisms are also valid in their opinions for the most part if the critiques aren't just mindlessly stated just to berate the game or Bethesda. Ignore any comments saying the game is "woke" when I tell you it isn't "woke" and that's coming from an anti-woke gamer. Just a couple hiccups in the game design by Bethesda that players have taken too far or added BS context gibberish to validate their biases. If anyone has questions I will be more than happy to respond with an answer as I have an in depth knowledge of this game at this point in time. :)

Pros:

-Good visuals
-Entertaining NG+ differences and the chance to do things differently per run
-Good music
-Interesting NPC variations and a lot of recruitable crew members
-Descent ship designs with some really great ones in the mix, you can also build your own or add too an existing one
-Good pacing
-Alright creations mods or nexus ones, although most will disable achievements of which I don't care about.
-Creations mod that is free by Bethesda based around their Doom game
-Fun exploration although it can get dull with the repetitive same design outposts and other POIs that you stumble upon on planets
-Outpost building can be very fun but is limited without the usage of mod
-Good stories to play out with plenty of side missions to take into account, no need to rush the game for enjoyment
-Wide range of Weaponry/Spacesuits/Packs with plenty of rarity variants of weapons and plenty of unique ones
-Loads of planets to get to know that each offer a scaling difficulty, allows to fun test or limit test yourself against wildlife or NPCs
-Space battles are entertaining, you can always fine tune NPC damage in the in game settings, much like in Oblivion uses of sliders but is far more refined in Starfield.
-Well known game mechanics that aren't hard to get into
-Currently most bugs for me are gone, just a couple that are annoying but are easily overlooked to my patience, rarely have to use console for anything.
-Some characters are annoyingly lovable
-Good voice acting throughout the whole game and especially my man Drexler...of Steve Blum I do so love you Space Cowboy.

Cons:

-Performance without the game on a SSD, strong GPU/CPU, and 12G minimum of ram is very poor and can cause plenty of stuttering or CTDs
-Some "woke" and "pronoun issues" that some tend to care about but mostly the "woke" aspects I don't particularly see but the pronouns I certainly didn't like
-Game can get boring if you rush it or you just generally don't like the limited cities within the settled systems and want more than just two giant ones of New Atlantis and Neon though each locations has its charms and lore as to why they're the way they are.
-The game can be judged as not being worth 70 dollars but 60 dollars with a 15-20 dollar DLC is more correct in my eyes
-The bounty system indeed sucks though I've used mods to correct this
-The game makes it apparent to only have one "spouse" but just like Skyrim, I don't care but I use a mod to allow me to marry both main women. Only a con because I like them both and in a game where morality comes into play often, I morally choose to enjoy my time in the starfield with two hotties. My lore, my universe, my Starborn interference.
-Not enough building variation in POIs on planets, they get stale
-NOT ENOUGH CLOTHING OPTIONS FOR MY DRIP (2nd biggest qualm with the game)
-Without mods the outpost and other options for decorations is too limited for my taste and lack functionality
-Food could be of more use since it still costs more credits than they are worth but selling them does net you a good amount of cash.
-Vendor credits are annoyingly small
-Not enough character creation components without the use of mods, too bland and uniform
-Parts of the game designs obviously feel not complete or empty when you focus on those parts but not hard for me to overlook for what there IS in the game
-Wish I could be more evil if I wanted too if I wanted to do a bad guy run, I'd like a full bad guy actual space scoundrel suite possibility


Overall from my 300+ hours of playing the game, I enjoy it and I have multiple NG+ runs. The pros outweigh the cons except the first con listed here because those issues will prevent you from playing the game to satisfaction to begin with. Make sure your PC is up to standard for what is required and do not put the game on an HDD and only SSD. I thought I was going to dislike the game at first when seeing all the negative reviews but the game in my opinion doesn't deserve all the hostility it's getting. I even got the Shattered Space DLC when I originally wasn't because I was looking for more. It is true that the DLC itself feels like it already should be in the base game but it does add some flavor to the atmosphere and it looks great.

The number one take from my time playing this game is I WANT MORE despite my current satisfaction with the game. That tells you that I really do enjoy it. Will it continue? Yes, for some time. Nothing lasts forever though but if they give me more....the longer it continues. *nudge* Bethesda, give more or I will need to Starborn your asses in the next universe when I come to hunt you down.

I find this game very enjoyable, there's nothing new in it's make up, which is the same for the vast majority of titles.

I do love this game but can't recommend as it's full of bugs, with zero chance of them being fixed. well it seems that this game isn't abandoned, but there are lots of silly bugs that still remain, some of them while not quest breaking, are extremely annoying with no work around..until all the quests  work, without bugs I still can't give this game a thumbs up.

I like the game, but would be wrong to change my opinion without fixes, and stability improvements
never preorder anything

I can't figure out how to move this from my documents and stop it from uploading everything onto my onedrive, which makes the whole thing impractical (it does work, but just means that is constantly uploading over poor connections, making the computer un-usable). Therefore uninstalled and not recommended. Waste of money

Bethesda Game Studios continues to solidify why they are the kings of the RPG genre. Bethesda allows us all to forget about the outside world and just live in another universe for a little while. Starfield continues to deliver that immersive role playing experience. 

Everything in the game is crafted with incredible detail not seen anywhere else, every pen and every piece of fruit can be interacted with. Bethesda has created an entirely new sci-fi universe which is filled with incredible lore to sink yourself into. The cities are vibrant with tons to explore at your own pace, combat is fast and complex both on foot and in space. Feature-packed character creator. Fantastic sound design. The wonderful "NASA-punk" tone the game sets is fresh and exciting. The shipbuilding mechanic is by far my favorite feature. Seeing your custom ship on the landing pad will make your eyes go wide every time. The only negative feature I can speak to is that you are unable to free fly your ship around a galaxy from one planetary body to another. 

Overall, truly a one of a kind, deep immersive role playing experience for sci-fi fans. Looking forward to Elder Scrolls 6!

As a Skyrim veteran, Starfield is exactly my cup of tea.

Gameplay wise it centres around Skyrim powergrind gameplay, where you were less immersed but focus just on the gameplay mechanics and improving your gear and character with absurd amounts of quicktravel. It ads variations of gameplay types, which are introduced in basics in Skyrim, but are all pumped up above "it's just a skyrim DLC".

The drawbacks are clear: Less immersion, less epicness. It's more sandboxy and you have to tell parts of the story for yourself. The different gameplay mechanics don't interlock as well, space venturing is independent from the ground combat. Exploring a planet for ressources is detached from "dungeon clearing" of abandoned outposts, grinding sidequest in cities/colonies is also detached from many mechanics. So sometimes you may feel a bit lost as there is not a clear and natural way of progression. In Skyrim it felt right just to venture to the horizon and explore and conquer dungeons as you go. Here you have to decide to do little 20 minute long segments of certain gameplay type. So all in all it feels less than one epic story but more like an video game.

As I like Skyrim as a whole better, I think Starfield has the better gameplay and could entertain you for a lot longer. 

I'm around 50h in and I'm still not bored and want to play more. Fallout 4 had lost me at that point.

The complete pack for around 50€ is worth it. So grab it in a sale, 75€ is imho to expensive and there are still better games available for that price tag. 

I wish for an TES V to have a more interlocked world with a better feeling for that one big epic tale you are part of. But until then, Starfield'll do.

I'm a big fan of open world games like Skyrim/Fallout4, so was hoping this game would at least be able to keep up. It has potential but if the real universe was as boring as Starfield, we'd all be looking to ascend to a higher realm. Bethesda may have been a bit too ambitious trying to fit the universe into a game. There's no real diversity, cookie-cutter landscapes and buildings, even the caves on each planet mostly look the same. I'm guessing each cosmic location is a stub for a future DLC. 
Overall, It's not really worth the coin until the modding community gets onboard with some real immersive content, not just face-lifts and fixes. I've stopped playing because basically it became boring. Maybe that's the business model behind selling DLCs - Shattered Space IMHO should have been a free upgrade

Shit game, got it for free with purchase of my graphics card and I still paid too much for it. freezes constantly, npcs are ugly, enemies are uninspired, game sucks. why aren't they working on elder scrolls 6

Honestly I didn't give this game a real chance at first. I just couldn`t get into the mechanics and all of the loading screens. Put the game down for over a year after trying it. Decided to try it again recently and I must say the game is awesome. There is just a ton of content and typical Bethesda thought provoking decisions that question your morals and principles. I even enjoy digging into some of its lore as well. Overall I feel the combat kind of lacks and planet exploration isn't great. But the questing and decision making make it a very fun and great game immersion experience.

The negative reviews for this game actually have great merit. Starfield truly is for lovers of Bethesda's games -- the Elder Scrolls and Fallout series. Which is why I LOVE Starfield! RPGs should incorporate fighting that depends on your avatar's skills and weapon characteristics, not my button-mashing skills. If a gamer doesn't like the gist of Bethesda-type games, don't buy them. We all know what to expect. I don't like the Dark Souls genre, so for those games I keep my CC locked up in the deep, dark dungeon of my wallet. I don't want to somersault fifteen feet in the air, or constantly roll left and right like a beer barrel to avoid an attacker's corkscrewed assault. I don't roll that way. It's supposed to be role playing, not roll playing. However, my CC will always break free and fly like a hungry dragon to devour the wealth of game play found in RPGs like Skyrim, Fallout, and Starfield, where I can live out great stories among varied NPCs while sightseeing fantastic scenery, without all those annoying hand cramps. Bethesda, excellent job on Starfield! Keep up the great work! Looking forward to TES VI and Fallout 5.

The first 60 or so hours are great if you can stand the strange writing for some of the characters you will be interacting with. after about 60 hours, the "cut and paste" nature of the points of interest (POI's), right down to the enemies, loot and loot type being identical across every iteration of the same floor plan. After you have visited about ten of these "procedural" locations, you have seen them all! 

Some missions from mission boards are locked behind pay walls, you start it but you wont get the loot at the end unless you pay! Last  time i played this game, there wasn't any vehicles to drive and the dlc had not come out yet but that wont address the repetitive nature that becomes very noticeable after 50 or 60 hours.

As for the writing, the first time i played and looted a CD player, not an IPOD, not a ZUNE or a smart phone, an CD player; that told me all i kneed to know about the writing! Its why even though the game is new, after playing for a while, it feels kind of old, and not in the good way!

Please don't say "you can mod it" I'm a consumer, i don't pay money to buy a game just to have to work out how to fix the game the developer was to lazy or talentless to get right them selves, even after years of updates. I play games, i don't pretend to make them.  

Why do i play? its not a bad game for the first while, i can only really do about 100 hours a play threw at the most, but until then its serviceable. This is the game i play when im sick of my other games and I'm waiting for a new game to come out!

This will be my third playthrough from start since the games original release on Steam. so i spent just over 100 hours a playthrough, at the start of playthrough #3 im at 215.8!

If you love Bethesda games, you will love this, it has all the bugs, jank, loading screens and the monetization of what was once a free community, MODs Bethesda is famous for! or if your looking at a serviceable space adventure with amazing ship building, repetitive cookie cutter locations, and an OK story with some compelling characters, you just might like this!

hope it helps!

Space fallout, pretty fun

This is the gaming equivalent to getting high on your own supply. Todd, everyone at Bethesda, and everyone out there praising this game have clearly been playing Bethesda games and *only* Bethesda games for so long that their entire perceptions on what games should be have been massively skewed. You can tell they built this game with the pre-conceived notion that it would be just as popular as Skyrim, and catered it towards the people still playing Skyrim in 2025, but without stopping to ask themselves *why* Skyrim is still being played in 2025, and what made it so good in the first place. 

This game takes the mechanics of other, better games, bundles them all together in a haphazard package, and presents them like they're novel concepts never seen before in gaming. Which I suppose makes sense if they thought their entire audience had been playing nothing but Bethesda games for the past ten years. But even if, by some fluke, you *have* only played Bethesda games for the past ten years, this game still manages to be the worst thing Bethesda have ever released. 

There is nothing remotely of note in this game. No storylines or locations that aren't bland, derivative, or otherwise predictable. No characters that feel truly unique or interesting. No standout moments from a mechanical perspective; no systems that feel novel or engaging beyond exactly what you'd expect from them. Even if you *only* engaged with the handcrafted narrative content, and only traveled to the locations relevant to the quests, you'd still find egregious repetition of dungeons and enemies, and you'd still be bogged down by bloated fetch quests and tedious missions. 

I can't believe they advertised "1000 planets" as though it was a selling point. I knew at that point that this game wasn't going to be worth buying. By sheer coincidence, I got a copy of this game in a deal with a new CPU, which is the only reason I even played it. And even though I didn't spend a cent, I somehow *still* feel as though I've wasted my money. Thanks, Todd.

A steaming pile of mediocre garbage that only serves to show how lazy of a developer Bethesda has become and even has me second guessing whether or not I will even get Elder Scrolls 6 on release.

Bethesda games have not evolved since Fallout 3 and it shows, same boring writing, same boring loop and it is starting to get very stale. TES6 is just going to feel like Skyrim 2.

I bought this game January 2025 having enjoyed many previous Bethesda titles, but being put off by the many negative reviews.

In my view, much of the criticism is accurate:
-Outside of the main quest and the faction quests, the side quests are often boring.
-The randomly-generated sites (e.g., abandoned mines / research posts) sometimes look exactly the same with the exact same loot in the same places
-The storytelling (incl. interactions with party members) is lacklustre compared to other recent role playing games like Baldurs Gate 3 or Cyberpunk 2077
-There isn`t much to discover in the cities/towns and the people generally seem quite bland
-The background you select in the beginning and many of the quests you do have no impact on the world

Despite all of this, I still like the game and would recommend it if you, like myself, have enjoyed other Bethesda titles. What I enjoyed:
-The main quest and faction quests were fun, original and captivating
-The space battles and also combat on land remains fun for me
-I liked the skill tree / leveling system. That remains a source of motivation.
aside from the ship builder nothing special. its OK i guess.

I get why people hate this game...but the weirdest thing is I played it without looking at a single review or score or rating, and I loved every minute of it. By the time I saw the mixed ratings on steam, I was already into it. 

It's a very shiny game, with really good gun combat, gorgeous graphics, fun mini-quests mixed in with bad ones. Plenty of jank, but that's exactly what makes Bethesda games good. They go way over-ambitious on everything they do, and end up making genre defining games that excel in ABC but they obviously ran out of deadline to polish XYZ. You play their games for the ABC, and then mods (if you can be bothered) fix the XYZ.
great game, thoroughly enjoying it

I never understood why this game got so much negative feedback. I really enjoy the missions, atmosphere of the cities and main planets, and especially the ship building. I probably spent 30-40 hours just building and experimenting with different ships. I do agree that advertising this game as having hundreds of explorable planets is misleading, most planets are just procedural generated nonsense. But outside of that, it's a classic Bethesda game.

Why create a game with so little motivation for players to be the main character?

I'm 100 hours deep and I've tried so very hard to like this game, but its hard.

1. The controller integration is only viable if I'm able to not touch or bump my desk in any way thus accidentally triggering a mouse input.

2. The "Calling" to the main character should have been much stronger. If "old man Walter" was the only NPC that could see the visions, and he was on his death-bed urging the player to take up the mantel and learn what the artifacts were, I would feel like my character had a purpose to fulfill. But Even Barrett can see the visions.  Even that looser of a member of consolation has the gift to see the visions of touching the "shining space thing". So the PC isn't special. I don't have a path of destiny that I need to fulfill. Why doesn't Barrett go and get the artifacts? How can the "main character" be the main character when NPC's like Barrett exist?

3. The freedom of game play afforded to the PC with the PC not being "special" or "the chosen one" makes the game flat. What am I supposed to do/ be? Why not act like the pirates? Why should I try to act like I'm more moral than the pirates when I'm not important to the galaxy? 

I am a story-teller who makes movies and writes novels, but this RP in this RPG is lacking all the primary compulsions for the Main Character to be of consequence.  There is no motivation to even try to be the main character. There is no mentor. There is no call. There is no reason why I want to play this game for 1,000 hours like there was for TES V Skyrim.

In Skyrim, the PC was special from the start of the main quest. The PC could consume a dragon's soul and prevent it from returning. The PC was the last of "its kind". The PC shaped the world. The PC could receive mentorship from the Blades or the Gray-beards. The PC had to settle the civil war. The PC mattered.

The PC in Starfield don't matter. They should have looked at The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim and carbon copied the skeleton of the PC's adventure into the universe of Starfield. The PC should have had to side with the Freestar Collective, the UC, ot the option to go "full Neon" and disrupt everything by becoming a "pirate king" of the Crimson Fleet or help prevent a civil war.

Regardless of the PC's actions, the status-quo doesn't change. The game play doesn't change. Nothing in this game matters, but it could have.

Ultimately, I regret purchasing this game; and I regret the 100 hours of my life that I have given it that I can never get back. This had so much potential, but the "developed by committee" killed this game before it was ever published.

Update:
I have created a new character and completely ignored Constellation and the main quest as much as possible. My current character is a member of the Hunter Alliance. I have gained the "Mantas" ship and I'm having fun just being a bounty hunter and being in the universe of Starfield. 

So I have been having fun by ignoring the main quest of the game and just being what I want the character to be.

It's okay. The world is there kind of for a Bethesda game, but I don't like the flying around from planet to planet. TES and Fallout games were open world in one place. Being in space breaks the momentum and intrigue. Dialog is so boring for the most part, that is probably the deal breaker for me, just boring characters that I don't find interesting. The creatures are strange (not in a good way).
I am enjoying the vastness of this space travel game

If I could have a thumb firmly in the middle, I would.  There's some good stuff here - the NASA-punk aesthetic in a lot of areas is nice, and I actually kind of dig the conceit of the main story - but a lot of the good is buried under design choices that left me wanting something more or something different.  As an example, the ship construction mechanic is a great idea in theory - build your ship your way - but is very much let down by the interface to build said ships.  It's a finicky system, and bizarrely you can't build a ship from scratch.

Where I think the game lets me down the most is in the proceduraly-generated exploration.  I get that with 1,000 planets to visit it's not really feasible to handcraft every one, but seeing the exact same science outpost or hillside cave on a dozen different worlds doesn't really instill in me a great desire to go exploring.  For that matter, neither does the surveying mechanic, which I think is far inferior to something like No Man's Sky.  

Procedural generation also represents Bethesda really playing against their strength, which has always been their meticulously handcrafted worlds (Fallout, Skyrim, etc.).  Those worlds are full of nooks and crannies and interesting distractions that have great environmental storytelling and real atmosphere (hah).  There are a couple of attempts at that (mainly abandoned space stations, and the questline that takes you to Londinion got really close), but they're few and far between.  By and large, almost none of the locations really seem like lived-in worlds; they're just isolated hubs that send you on radiant quests to Planet ABCDEFG.

I found enough to enjoy with Starfield (clearly, with almost 150 hours) and odds are that many Bethesda fans probably will as well.  But by the high standards we've come to expect from Bethesda, it's a really middling effort.


Final note/gripe: Bethesda could stand to review their quest flow.  On multi-part quests, it was a regular occurrence to be ping-ponged between quest objectives, and not in a good way.  Do something at Location A, then head to Location B for a couple lines of dialogue that send you back to Location A.  That's not a huge deal in a Skyrim, where you could choose fast travel or to meander between Location A and B to see the sites of the world around you.  With Starfield, you're always going to be fast traveling.

The stories aren't impactful, the exploration doesn't have a purpose, the sandbox is woefully unbalanced. It's a Bethesda game without any of the charm or depth you expect in a bethesda game. It's wide as a galaxy but as deep as a puddle.
Entertaining game. Some issues, but still good.
Elder Scrolls in Space. Lots of fun.

The FPS combat is fun, and like Fallout 4, I am sure the armor weapon customization is fun as well, however, ship combat is not intuitive, and I find myself frequently getting blasted out of the sky because the basic enemies can out-maneuver me. However, those are forgivable flaws, as there are definitely ways I could upgrade my ship and its weapons, but what is most annoying, is this seemingly unnecessary limit on how far I can fast travel. There does not seem to be a reason for this, as I can just jump again immediately after. The only reason I can think is so random encounters can still occur. Even so, the amount of loading screens, albeit short, are tedious and annoying, especially because the game insists on showing you the same animations while also making you load. I gave this game a fair shake, but I cannot get into it for these reasons. Maybe in the future I will try again, but this game seems very against it's players.
I'd better go play Fallout 3

I will say yes, I would recommend this game to other players. It has its flaws - but I find the positive qualities Starfield has redeems it. Just.

There is clear love and care put into the worldbuilding, the design of the world and its items, the sounds, the music, the quests. Dialogues can get surprisingly indepth. The combat is exciting and it's fun to finetune the difficulty settings. In the early levels of the game, exploration is a lot of fun and very rewarding.

However, don't expect exploration to stay fun. After a while, the mask drops, content will start to repeat, and you will see the randomly generated plants for what they are - square maps with four points of interest scattered inbetween pure nothingness. No planet holds real surprises, because those would have had to be handcrafted. You will start to avoid visiting planets if there's no quest for you there. Personally, building settlements has never appealed to me, so I do not spend much time collecting resources either. 

However, I've played Starfield for almost 100 hours now. Something about it worked for me. I see the work put into it, I appreciate the story, the companions are genuinely interesting, the writing is usually pretty good. Starfield is a good game. It didn't change the world, so don't expect it to change yours. But yeah, in summary, I do recommend it to anyone looking for sci-fi action RPG's.

I love the game despite its bugs and glitches. However, the expansion, The Shatter Space, is overpriced. The story is short and somewhat interesting but ultimately disappointing. I wish it was better, but the game overall is decent. The gunfights, suits, and weapons are good, and while the story could improve, I still enjoy it.

I hope future expansions leading up to Elder Scrolls VI offer free updates with new quests, rewards, and better stories. A better expansion with new weapons and intriguing factions would be great.

I rate the game 8.4/10 and The Shatter Space 5.5/10.

Is this a perfect game, no, but in my honest opinion is is probably just on the verge of being a great game. 

Cons:
-Visual artifacts during play: just oddities, most of the time these are experienced when trying to hold conversations with other NPC's.
-Glitchy cinematics: Even on an SSD, sometimes, not always, the in-game cinematics just don't work right. The camera wants to go one direction and the focal object just doesn't move...
-Designed for controller: Not a negative to all, but for those who prefer mouse and keyboard, a little disadvantage when it comes to navigating the customization options inside outposts / ships / homes / etc.

Pros:
-Good story arc: the first time through was a captivating arc. Even with enough side quests to sometimes forget what you were supposed to be doing. That freedom is truly appreciated in a universe as vast as the one offered here.
-Overall graphics: Does extremely well creating the random and varied expectations of visiting so many different planets and atmospheres.
-Shipbuilding: .... Very few negatives here, though I do wonder what it would look like if some of the constraints were differed just a little. Like this game with the ability to also make my own space station in order to be yet another income stream or just be a space-based base where I can see all of my ships parked at the same time.

I have come back after 176 hr play-through and wanted to reacquaint myself with the game and started over. Enjoying every hour of it and enjoying the many different ways to experience this game. Great replayability. Great investment.

See you among the stars...

Unmodded - unplayable garbage with terrible balance and pacing, not to mention the horrid writing.
Modded - playable, sometimes fun, in a casual, shallow, unchallenging and chill way ( if you can ignore / skip the bad the writing ).

What I like: ( best things first )
- making cool ships ( also a much better experience with mods )
- space fights ( only really fun with mods that scale speed better )
- shootan & lootan ( a weakness of mine, sadly )
- the locations are nice and detailed, albeit inconsistent in their use of physical & nonphysical props, also the generated locations have no awareness of the planet's environment ( snacks and drinks out in the open and no airlocks on dead/extreme env planets, etc )
- starting over with powerups ( literal isekai power fantasy, albeit it's still a terrible game if unmodded )
- almost infinite potential for mods ( unfortunately, most talent is not interested in modding this mess )

What I dislike: ( worst things first )
- 90% of the writing
- loading screens ( I recommend modding some of them out if you're on a fast system, nvme is a must )
- character design, especially NPCs ( a universe where ENHANCE exists, but everyone still chooses to look like an ork? )
- balance ( or maybe most enemies just train a natural immunity to projectiles - mods make this much more bearable )
- economy ( a SPACE SHIP can be built for cheaper than a f-ing M1911 ), by level 90 you get tens of thousands for basic fetch quests.

I really enjoy the game. The gunplay is smooth, the spaceship design is cool and obviously space battles are sick - the ability to disable an enemy ship and board it will never get old. The games been out for a while so I don't think I'm spoiling anything by saying the "New Game Plus" type mechanic is different and unique and offered a level of replay-ability that you don't usually get. I've replayed so many Bethesda games from the very beginning so many times to try new choices and new builds that this just felt like a natural extension of that so it was cool to see it as an integral part of the gameplay mechanic.

Yes, the game can be tedious when grinding for levels and the "exploration" isn't what we've come to expect from a Bethesda game in the same vain as ES or Fallout, but this is it's own thing and I can appreciate that. 

The mod support is limited when compared to some of the other Bethesda games out there, but personally I'm only looking for mods that add new weapons or armor or quests anyway, not things that drastically change the dynamic or world of the game. Again, that comes from being very pleased overall with the gameplay experience I had from launch (I played Starfield when it first came out on Xbox). 

Again, I can see why people are not thrilled with it, especially if they're traditional Bethesda game enthusiasts because it is a departure from the typical Bethesda formula of making exploration a focal point, but if you can look past that, I think it's a great experience on it's own and worth giving (another) shot.

~70hrs and I am still enjoying the game. I like it actually: all the "realistic sci-fi" settings (I believe the style it's called Nasapunk), huge amount of planets to explore, many of which have a lot of content and quests...

Of course there are of things I don't really like, especially the combat AI.

I modded the game, actually, since many people suggested me to do so, and I am quite happy with that, since mods improved the overall experience a lot: it's like Bethesda was scared to go "all-in" towards a single direction and preferred modders to specialize the game; it's like Bethesda creates games like base playgrounds so that modders can actually build on top of them. 

There are a lot of mods out there, among them, along with a much needed combat AI mod which slightly improves the AI situation and others minor mods, I am using the Starvival mod, which makes the game much more "specialized" (as I was saying earlier) towards the survival direction, making it more challenging and somewhat deeper.

This is the first review I've written, and given all of the mixed signals on this game, I hesitated for a long time before getting it. I will preface by advising to wait until it's on sale, mostly because $70 for a video game is still ridiculous in my book.  HOWEVER, I have somehow nearly logged 60 hours in the last week (much to my wife's ire) and I must say that I enjoyed it.  

Yes, it is a Bethesda game and therefore there are odd quirks.  My favorite is a spaceport technician whose arm accidentally got stuck in my loading ramp and went on a one-way trip into the cosmos when I launched.

Let's start with the criticisms: The open world that's not quite as open as No Man's Sky.  I really wish I had control over the ship during launch and landing, as well as space station docking. It's annoying, but you get used to it. The plot: it's not bad, but it falls flat in a lot of places.  They start really well, but then kind of taper out.  I like the characters they made, but I really with they fleshed out the conversations with them.

What I enjoyed: The graphics are beautiful, the worlds are beautiful, and the technology falls within the field of realism which I enjoy. I really enjoy how close to realism the facial expressions are in this.  The ship-building has to be my absolute favorite part.  I've spent hours playing around with my star-ship design, only for it to tell me there's a module not connected and I have to disassemble the bloody thing and start over. Love it.  I also got the nomad suit on Creations and can run around stabbing people with a wakizashi like a knock-off Muad'Dib.

In conclusion:  I enjoy playing it.  I'm also a 40 year old man with a bunch of kids, so I play at a much different pace. I'd still wait until it's on sale, because holy crap $70. But it's enjoyable.

This game is a mixed bag of good and bad.

The negatives:
-The main story doesn't seem that interesting. The game gives you side main quests from each faction way better and which i wish were the main story.
-Traveling to other planets or landing is tedious, requires you to open the map way too much and breaks immersion with the loading screens. Add to this that you don't go anywhere in space; can't go "warp 6" Star Trek style and slowly travel from one planet to another. You need to go through a loading screen.
-Not a lot of weapons to choose from.
-NPC movement is bad. They always go slower or faster than you and aren't that good at finding paths, which makes them get stuck often.
-Meh combat (space combat is decent). Enemies are literal bullet sponges.
-Repeating NPC encounters in space. I found the scientist asking for minerals at least 5 times, always playing the same dialogue each time.
-If you want to fully explore a planet you can't walk all the way round. Nope. You often need to go to your ship, select another biome and, surprise, another loading screen.
-Finite galaxy with finite planets + randomly generated planet surfaces with pre-made dungeons that get boring once you complete them the first time.
-Very tedious and slow to scan planets, even with the car to move faster. Special 'screw you' to whoever decided to add sea life to scan when you can't even swim most of the time due to the water being hazardous.
-No alien civilizations.
-Sarah Morgan.

The positives:
-Side quests were interesting and good. Some seen unfinished, like the one of the colony ship, but they are all entertaining.
-I dig the factions. Authoritarian government, cowboy space people and crazy religious zealots; the three very good looking and interesting lore and visual wise.
-The companions may be annoying sometimes with the constant dialogue but once you bond and unlock their missions to know more about them you get to care for them. Barrett, my beloved.
-Visually beautiful sci-fi. Space stations, ships, planets.... Exploring planets just for the visuals.
-Interesting choices when making your character regarding background. If you choose combat medic the police will thank you for your service, if you choose to have parents around they will talk about your accomplishments...
-And the greatest of all... the adoring fan. BEST. SIDEKICK. EVER.

So take your balance out and decide if it is for you. Personally, not full price. Half price? Totally.
