I love Bethesda games and I wanted to love Starfield. But I have invested serious time in this now and I am struggling to have fun playing it. So many of the side missions are just very basic and frankly underwhelming fetch quests with little meaningful combat, and plagued by loading screens constantly. The Characters (while Character development is never a clear Bethesda strength) is very thin, and for a game that encourages you to have a crew, companions, and has more investment in them than other games, this entry feels very lacklustre and hollow. The main plot is... ok. Just ok. The main quests are plagued by yet more fetch quests. Go to a planet. FInd a building, Go in the building, solve the puzzle, leave, shoot a baddie and get back on your ship. It also occurs to me that while there are some aspects of the game I enjoy (like building a cool ship or exploring some sites) I only enjoy these because I have modded the game to optimise it. In vanilla, shipbuilding is frustrating and clunky. Scanning and exploring is time consuming and unrewarding. The world is vast but sparse, with little interesting places to find. Sure you can find a disused mining facility inhabited by psychopath space pirates and fight them, and the first time you do this, it is fun. But by the 4th time, when the facility on another planet is the same map layout inside and its the same enemies... well its just a bit dull.  You can explore all of these places, but in terms of loot... its just resources to grind into building another roof on an outpost, or ammo, or the same gun you already have, or a legendary gun that is worse than your current gun. So you end up not exploring and just blasting your way through to complete a fetch quest and then you are back on one of the home worlds getting handed another fetch quest that will send you to blast through another mining facility. Snore. Some of the faction quests have the opportunity to be great, and some of them are fun, but some of them are confusing. The skill and level up system is thin and buggy. The factions promise cool arcs but never get going. Join the corpos and conduct espionage, but actually just sneak (you dont even have to sneak) into a building and hack a terminal then leave. Maybe 1 in 5 quests is decent. the UC questline has the opportunity to be fantastic, horrible aliens, space hulk, dark and scary... but its not. Its just blasting away. Every opportunity the team had to devlier excellence in quest story design was wasted. complete the quest line... little happens, now you have the option to do recurring procedually generated fetch quests! MORE FETCH QUESTS. Jesus.
85.8 hours. Most of that was just walking back to my ship.

I realized I didn't leave a review for this yet, but I've played it plenty since launch and might as well leave one now.

I really like this game.  It isn't perfect, and there's plenty of room for polish and improvements.  However, it scratches an itch for me that hasn't been hit since Mass Effect.  Is it as good as the original Mass Effect trilogy?  Not even close.  Is it better than Mass Effect 4?  Yes, by a lot.

Even so, comparing Starfield to Mass Effect isn't really fair.  Mass Effect lacked the open world nature of Starfield, which was probably to its strength, but Starfield manages to keep you engaged fairly well, always pointing you in a new direction as you make your way through the game.  For as "open" as the world is, going off into the nothingness will generally be full of northing and you'll find yourself picking back up and returnign to civilization and reconnecting with the quest opertonities there.

To be fair, I've never been able to get into any of the Elder Scrolls games.  I've wanted to, and I've tried to, but the first person questing in a fantasy realm never quite clicked for me.  However, first person here, with a gun and cross hair, feels much more natural to me.  The FPS elements are solid, and the difficulty can be adjusted on the fly, with expected results.  New gun models become avialable with higher levels, bringing better stats, and the ability to mod the guns adds a limited, but enjoyable aspect to getting the most out of them.

The RPG leveling is okay.  Early game you'll find yourself making difficult choices with where to put your precious skill points for each level up, but once you start rolling and get most of the obvious choices maxed out, it feels like it becomes less meaningful.  Still fun, but more of a choice of "that seems cool" instead of "oh, I need this."

The different main strorylines range from okay to really good.  Side quests are sometimes... bad, annoying, and poorly thought out/designed, and othertimes really fun diversions.  The main lines will often give you choices to make, some of which will have a major effect of how your character is viewed within the world, but generally... things flow to the same point.

The 1st expansion is out, but I've not played through any of the content yet.  I've heard good things, and I will aim to come back and give my opinion once I've done so.

All the "cheesy" elements you hear about of Bethesba games are here.  Awkward NPC responces, body language, facial features, all here in full force.  The mod community had a lot a great things inplace t help with some of these before the internal creations element was added, and I've not seen most of these reimplimented in the months since, which is very disappointing to me.  Not sure if its just not an easy transition between the old way and the new official way to mod.

As I said at the start, I like this game.  Its fun and solid enough that I will probably keep coming back to it over and over again over the years. It just keeps bringing me back in.

Save yourself a headache and a lot of money, don't buy this game.

Upgraded PC update:

Turns out, I mostly needed a new pc to play this game.
Had a core i9 RTX3060 with 32GB ram but I was playing on a hardrive not an SSD, but still, it should be enough to run the damn game but nope, you need at least an SSD and a better graphics card. But my review is still negative because:

-I thought the worlds were completely open like in No Man's sky, they are not, there is like 5x5km randomly generated areas in the moons and planets but you cannot just drive in a straight line and end up in the same spot eventually.

-There is so many animations that just drain your life essence after watching them over and over again like getting in the pilot seat, docking, getting in and out of your ship and more that I cant remember. These animations are unskippable and they feel like they're in slow motion

-facilities, locations, and random missions. After playing for a couple of hours in the open world just bounty hunting or exploring you're going to find out that the random locations repeat so damn often it's annoying. Across stars, moons, planets. like yeah, you can have different names of locations but outposts and civilian and pirate outposts are the same every time. whether it's an abandoned mine or just some random science post or whatever, same layout, same items lying around, same locks and same findables. It gets old fast.

The bottom line: 
The game is full of bugs still. Not funny crazy bugs either, no, just annoying and progress impeding bugs that make you go back a couple save files. Will they ever fix said bugs? NO! 
This game was supposed to be this crazy amazing star game and it just feels like a rushed early access demo crap. 

PS: IO is supposed to be this crazy lava moon and it's just like a regular boring rock moon.

A Vast and Rewarding Sci-Fi Adventure

As someone with a long history of playing Bethesda titles, I went into Starfield with high expectations like many after what has shown before launch. After spending over 130 hours exploring its vast universe, I have to say that while it didn’t hit me with the same impact as Skyrim, it still delivers an incredibly engaging and rewarding experience—especially for those who love space and exploration.

The core gameplay loop of Starfield is still mostly classic Bethesda: go anywhere (within the box), do anything (that isn't broken), and carve out your own path in a rich, handcrafted world (or in this case, worlds). The main story is compelling, with some genuinely thought-provoking moments, but where the game really shines is in its side quests and faction storylines. From corporate espionage with Ryujin Industries to the high-stakes political struggles of the Freestar Collective and United Colonies, there’s no shortage of meaningful content to dive into. all positives even though replayability is not what is expected from a Bethesda RPG.

One of my absolute favorite aspects is the shipbuilding system. The ability to design, upgrade, and fine-tune your own spaceship makes space travel feel truly personal. Whether you want a sleek fighter, a massive cargo hauler, or a heavily armed warship, Starfield gives you the tools to create something unique. It’s easily one of the most satisfying customization features Bethesda has ever implemented.

That said, Starfield does feel like it plays things a bit safe compared to past Bethesda games. While the scale is impressive, the sense of discovery isn’t quite as awe-inspiring as stumbling upon a hidden ruin in Skyrim or venturing into the unknown in Morrowind. Fast travel and loading screens can make space exploration feel more segmented than seamless, but once you accept Starfield for what it is a structured yet deep RPG rather than a true space sim it becomes much easier to appreciate its strengths.

Also, as with any Bethesda game, the modding community is already working its magic. Mods have vastly improved customization, UI, and immersion, and they’ll only continue to expand the game’s potential. If Starfield follows the same trajectory as Skyrim and Fallout 4, it’ll be an entirely different beast in a few years thanks to modders.

Overall, while Starfield may not redefine the open-world RPG like Skyrim did, it still offers an incredibly deep and rewarding experience. If you enjoy Bethesda’s signature style of storytelling, exploration, and customization especially when it comes to building and piloting your own ship then there’s a fantastic adventure waiting for you among the stars.

If you like Skyrim and think the formula sounds like it would be fun in space, you'll probably enjoy this game.

I am a big fan of Bethesda games, and I've played pretty much all the RPGs since the Arena. I was stoked for Starfield, especially given the talk about the new engine. Surely, I thought, this time, they'll get rid of the load screens, and make the cities look like actual cities...
Those are only two of the disappointments I had to soon suffer. And I bought this at full price! Unfortunately, I alt-tabbed the game instead of closing it, so I exceeded the time limit for refund eligibility.

Starfield is not only obsolete by at least a decade, but it is uglly, and boring. All the story NPCs are ugly as well, and extremely annoying. The main story line is so generic and unengaging that I'd rather stab myself in the leg with a fork than suffer through it.
The planets look okay, but the feeling of exploration is completely wasted by the heavy use of load screens and invisible border walls.

Also, there is practically no civilization in the game. It's virtually empty. I wonder, where all those space ships are produced, because the largest "city" in the game is physically smaller (except for its height maybe) than the village I live in.
Kuttenberg in KCD 2 is several times bigger than all the cities of Starfield combined, and, by today's standards, much less by those of the future, Kuttenberg is still a tiny city.

I just can't bring myself to pick this game up again. I was hoping for the modding scene to maybe save it, but reportedly, modding it is, compared to Skyrim, much more difficult, and there isn't enough documentation. So there isn't really any good reason to play this game.
Don't buy it unless it's less than five bucks!
Refund if you still can. It's even worse than the bad reviews on YouTube would make you believe.

It's another bethesda rpg. if you can align your expectations for that (subpar writing, annoying characters, very same-y plots, quests, ridiculous inventory management/uis, bugs abount), and enjoy other bethesda rpgs like I do, I think you'll enjoy this one.

Criticisms specific to this beth rpg as opposed to other beth games:
* LOADING SCREEN MADNESS!!! You will need patience
* INVENTORY MADNESS!!! The inclusion of ships has made what is already a nightmare of an inventory system in these games even more confusing. Again, patience requried.
* Insane performance requirements. I have 3090 and 5950x, and get sub 60 fps in many towns in 3440x1440. Interiors run well

Pros
* I really dig the art style in this game. I feel it's the polar opposite of fallout 4 - a game with hideous and nonsensical weapons, armor pieces and more. Here of course you'll still see ridiculous designs but IMO they're visually appealing instead of ugly. Overall, I think they nailed the design language with this in a way they haven't in a loooong time
* It's a good looking game. Lights and shadows in particular look fantastic. I think faces look pretty good, the best they've looked in a beth game.
* Great combat. Better than fallout 4, and the inclusion of space stuff like dead enemies having their jump packs go off gives combat an extra dose of gamebryo-style physics fun
* Great ship combat. perfect balance of management and gunning. Just tactical enough for my tastes, like NMS with a touch more control over ship systems
* I really like the way they handle perks in this game. Perks are rewarding not only to use but also in that the way you improve them means you're playing the way you want to - it feels like you're being encouraged for playing your specific way rather than nudged to change your habits

I'm really liking it. I should also put in a HUGE disclaimer that I didn't have to pay for it, I'm playing a copy from my Steam family. But I'm having tons of fun.
Paid modding ruined the one saving grace it had

5/10. Painfully mediocre, even for a Bethesda title. I'm usually the type of person who enjoys blank-slate RPGs like this, but this game isn't as gripping as Skyrim or Fallout 4. The faults are exacerbated by the fact that the experience of  flying on ships vs on-foot exploration is so disconnected that the emergent gameplay is basically nonexistent. Outposts are also seemingly tacked on with no real purpose for them outside of that one main quest.

The ships which have been memed to death at this point are mildly made better with mods, but that begs the question, if modders can make your game work (and it's not even that much of a change) why can't Bethesda? Personally I hope they learn from this when it comes to their vision for TES6. Leave the randomly generated content to space sims and return to hand-crafted areas.

Game is genuinely fun for when you just want to build ships and outfit a crew (at least for me). But and this is a big but, this is not the core gameplay. I would probably go back to this game every now and then just for the vibe but I don't think I would recommend it to anyone to actually play and enjoy.

- Well it's Bethesda what can I say (boring Companions)
- Price to high
- Bethesda don't mess up Fallout 5

300+ hrs in and I can say what most have already said.  Its Fallout in space. The story is good, and enjoyable.  The graphics are good but character modeling is mediocre at best.  Settlements feel spartan and don't really have any depth to them.  The grinding and loot system are fair but not really noteworthy.  The acting outside of Barrett's character are wooden and uninteresting.  Gun play is on par with most Fallout titles.  Space combat is pretty average, being blown away by 30yr old titles like Tie Fighter and X Wing.  Exploration is a bit limited but stumbling on a genuinely good mission is fun. Role playing and immersion are truly interrupted with the frequent punctuation of load out screens.  To sum it up, if you've logged more hours than you care to admit to in Skyrim, New Vegas, Fallout 4, etc.  you'll get your money's worth.  If you're looking for a more immersive space exploration game, this isn't it.  
Shattered space's game world is actually a much better look for the game than any of the main titles world builds.  It gives you several novel experiences in the game (note, not novel to other BGS titels).  It actually feels worth it's DLC price whereas the main title does not.

I suspect this game received mixed reviews due to the hype that surrounded its launch and its promise. Did it deliver? I don't think it's a revolutionary game, but it does provide an engaging core story line with a lot of room for freedom of choice and adventure paths. It will provide you with good hours of entertainment and fun if you can get past two contradictions.

1. Does the world feel vibrant, colourful, and full? At times, but it IS spotty. One of the main issues here is the scale of the universe in relation to the scale of the settlements. It doesn't feel plausible to have such small locales in such a vast universe. It's by no means a deal breaker, but I believe this contributes primarily to the feeling of emptiness.

2. Are the characters engaging? I think we are reaching a crossroads in game development where games have not caught up in realism, i.e., providing more fluid, dynamic, and random conversations while keeping to the core persona. The legacy model of scripted static lines and dialogues could fly with Oblivion, or even Skyrim, but now, I think gamers are ready for the next step of NPC interaction. The silver lining is that the game does offer different NPC behaviours and responses based on the own player's actions and responses through the concept of affinity. That said, although the NPC interactions feel static and are repeatable, there is a lot of work that was done to provide a decent script with quality voice acting and memorable characters and interactions.

What about creativity in ship building? This is definitely one of the areas where the game shines more. Ship building and customisation is relatively easy to learn and quite flexible, and does add a really nice interactive space for players. Could it be improved? For sure, but it's a great first iteration for Bethesda on this mechanic. 

Do I feel like I'm grinding or doing the same things over and over? To some degree, but Starfield offers a good variety of mission types and adventures to take on all the while being able to pursue at the player's pace the core story line and quests. This is something that is well executed in this game when looking at it more objectively. The game also offers decent replay value by allowing the player to explore different ways to engage in the Starfield world.

Do the combat mechanics stack up? Although nothing revolutionary, they do enable a quality experience without wanting to throw your controller out the window. Nothing ever feels like it should behave a different way or respond a different way.

All in all, I can see the love the developers put into this game, and it DOES show. There is a lot of work that went into this endeavour however imperfect it is, and there are many hours of enjoyment to be found with this title, which is why I would recommend players to give it a go.

The first time I played Starfield, I didn’t like it. The first 30 minutes of the story felt far fetched and didn’t pull me in at all. I refunded it. A year later, decided to give it another go – still didn’t like the first 30 mins, but god, it does get better. 

I understand what people don’t like about Starfield, but still think it’s great fun. It definitely made the mistake of overhyping itself and raising expectations to an extreme level, but if you’re going in expecting some space fun, that’s what you’ll get. It has a fairly basic and a little contradictory storyline, so it’s no Mass Effect, but it’s still very enjoyable. 

My favourite part is definitely the world design though – out of any sci fi media I ever consumed, this is the one game that feels like the most realistic ‘humans in space’ scenario. All the tech feels like an extension of what we have now, and there’s no form over function, it’s all clearly inspired by the International Space Station and our current space tech. Very cool!

Not the greatest Bethesda game, but I believe not as terrible as reviews are suggesting.

I'm finding that if I stick to quests and avoid random exploration, I'm having an enjoyable time. Ship combat is different but not a chore, and the ship builder is quite cool if you like tweaking designs. Combat in the short to medium range is good, and I do like the perk system with the way you have to meet checks before you can upgrade each level.

Stability wise is okay,  performance reasonable,. I'm not expecting miracles graphic wise with my machine (Ryzen 5900x with 3070Ti) and I'm seeing stable frame rates on medium settings, around the 75-80FPS in most built up areas.

As for downsides - the main thing I'd say is that the game is just too plain with a safe but unexciting soul. A lot of thought has gone into building the world, but it seems flat compared to the storytelling of Fallout 4. While the area of the game is huge, once you get away from the main centres and quest areas things start repeating - especially the wide open spaces with nothing. 

This does not encourage you to randomly explore as you would have  in Skyrim/Fallout 3/4/NV.  Companions come across as vanilla, and I'm not a huge fan of the outpost building part of the game (have done just enough to store resources for crafting).

But overall, I'd recommend this game if you go into it with your expectations tempered. Probably  not a buy at full price though.  I picked up a code in box on clearance for the equivalent of $11USD, and I'm more than happy with my purchase.

This is my first Bethsada game. So, I am not skewed by previous releases. I can't get enough of this. Keeps me up at night when I would do better if I got some sleep. There's always something to do.

So, I know it says only 6.5 hours played, but I have played on the Xbox Series X since launch.  Starfield isn't perfect, but I find it very enjoyable.

Word of advice: If you are expecting to plop down on any random planet or moon and find lots of interesting things, you will be disappointed. Unlike The Elder Scrolls and Fallout, Starfield is not designed for random wandering.

Instead, DO THE QUESTS. The faction quests, loyalty missions, and side stories are Starfield's best features. These activities will bring you to all of the unique and interesting locations, and open up tons of lore.

The main quest is more of a mixed bag... there are lots of really awesome moments and cool places to go, but it's interspersed with some very monotonous artifact/power collection. The surprise twists and intriguing plot does make it worthwhile to me though.

I would give Starfield an 8/10. Not perfect, but defenitely an enjoyable experience!

It takes a long time to see it, especially if you are historically a Bethesda fan or was enamored with an open world space RPG like I was. But you'll quickly find that there is nothing really to discover (yet it is open world), nothing really unique that you can build (yet there is base building), nowhere really to fly your ship (yet there is a ship builder)... 

Sigh, it's sad because an open world space exploration RPG game is EXACTLY the type of game that I'd love. I was so excited for this game and honestly I had a lot of fun playing it in the beginning. But I realized it just isn't all the way there. It is a husk of something that could have been platform changing.

Long story short: I played through several times, wanting to search the stars for something interesting. Turns out what I was searching for was justification for trusting Bethesda to give me something interesting and complex again...

Long story: I have loved Bethesda games, Morrowind was my first and I was in love. It's not nostalgia either, I still play it sometimes. They have totally lost their spark. Fallout 4 was alright story with improved systems and was decently fun. 

This game has all potential and none of the follow through. You learn nothing in the base game about the more interesting Varun faction, they had to add it in later. The space exploring was boring, barren frustrating planets, typical storyline, and then the "deep" stuff in the story was just boring and repetitive. I kept buying Bethesda stuff hoping for the same wonder, creativity, and joy I got from Morrowind and Oblivion. Now I know I won't get it. I'm probably not going to buy another Bethesda game, and I am committed to never paying full price. Todd Howard went from someone I liked to the villain in my gaming life. This game should never have happened and they should have stuck to their original IPs and innovated and made them interesting. They didn't, and when ES6 comes out shortly before I die, it will likely be formulaic and disappointing too, that's what happens when all you focus on is hype and rely on your modders to make your games good for you.

Here's the thing, if I never heard of Bethesda or even played a single game of theirs I would call Starfield "just okay". However since I've played past fallout and elder scroll titles, I am disappointed. I say this because I know Bethesda can really invoke a sense of exploration with Skyrim or Morrowind, and because of this I feel a little let down, especially since I got caught up in the hype. 

For starters it lacks anything resembling exploration, all it does is give you a loading screen to a "new" world that behaves and looks the same as any other planet. 1000 worlds...as vast as the pacific and as shallow as a coffee stain. I don't care if there were infinite planets to explore, this is not what I envisioned a Bethesda game to be. Would it have been better if they had a single fully explorable planet? A few moons? A station? I would say yes, but it doesn't really make-up for story. 
While I can easily start a new Skyrim game and play to the end, I haven't even touched Starfield in over a year, not since beating the story only once. 

In short, I would not recommend it, at least not until the community "fixes" it, like all Bethesda games. However with them monetizing the mods, the future isn't looking too great.

I changed my original review from a negative review to a positive view. You might be asking... "Why"? Well, its because of the modders. Before I would say the game is not a recommend unless you are a very specific rpg player who prefers a slow and realistic RPG, but even then I felt like there was better things out there. Now, even a original bethesda rpg fan like myself is enjoying Starfield.

Even though some would like to say base Starfield and DLC is either very bad or very good (the latter being more rare), I personally just think its average. Some parts of the game are really good and other parts really bad. However, when you play this game modded like I do then it does fix a lot of the issues the base game has and makes the game a lot better. I get mods that expand crafting, outposts, ship building, questing, gear progression, planet points of interest density, mods that add over 100+ points of interest, adds more encounters in space and on the planets, and improved enemy AI. It makes up for where Bethesda falls short. Some mods I highly recommend are DarkStar mods, Watchtower (adds fleets, orbital strikes, and a new enemy faction. By far the best mod), TG's Harvest, Gear Progression, Starshards, Standing Stones, and Wayliner. These are what I believe are core mods to have.

Closing thoughts: Overall, the game is average, but with the help of mods it does make the game feel a whole lot better. I do recommend the game if you are willing to mod it. If not, then I think you should still get it but when it is on sale. As it will still be good for a one time play through.

For Bethesda: If you really want this game to come back from the dead then we need more frequent updates that actually add content. You need to do the equivalent of a Cyberpunk 2.0 Update. We need you to not be radio silent because I'm literally about to walk in to your studio for a welfare check just to make sure you guys are alive. We also need a better endgame, more NG+ variants that are actually meaningful in gameplay, more quests that have meaningful choices that actually affect the game, a reworked starborn temple, and more unique handcrafted locations with puzzles and traps. If you can manage this with consistent updates then I can assure you the game will come back to the mainstream. Until then, modders are holding you on life support and we need you to come through.

I played when it released for about a month before all of the small bugs overwhelmed my will to play. I figured I would give it another try 1 1/2yrs later. Same bugs still present. I understand that pretty much all games start off a bit buggy and usually a lot of them get taken care of within the first few months. Bethesda’s magnum opus of mediocrity. Starfield is an unholy abomination of corporate laziness.

Enjoyed some parts of the game and definitely got my money's worth at least.  However, this game lost that feeling of exploration that their previous successful titles had due to all of the mandatory fast travel / loading screens.  Missed opportunity by not allowing space travel between planets within a solar system without the use of fast travelling, that may have allowed for some more interesting exploration opportunities.

Density and variety of POIs on planets was a huge let down.  Should of been way more given how many planets they let you land on.  If intentionally designed this way for realism, this is a good example where hyper realism doesn't equal fun.

Modular ship customization is a cool feature, but it lacked meaningful impact and was far too restrictive.  Ship module upgrading is a monotone experience and not worth the time.  It was far more fun to just buy prebuilt ships.

The quests / levels to unlock special abilities lack any variation what so ever and thus became a very tedious and unfun experience after the first couple of times.  Floating around in zero-G towards sparkling lights was interesting the 1st time but not the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th, etc. time.  Felt like those quests / levels were created by artists and not level designers.

I can't recommend this for the general, wider audience. If you want an aggressively average game following an aggressively average implementation of the Bethesda formula you'll like it. The setting itself is beautiful. The visuals are themed and even stunning in some areas. I personally enjoy the design aesthetic, but that can't make up for a Bethesda Game system implementation that feels like a step between Fallout 3 and Fallout 4 making it out of date out of the box. Combine that with a sense that the universe is a disconnected set of places via loading screen and you lose the main draw of Bethesda Games - Exploration. I personally enjoyed the time I got out of it and felt it was worth the money I spent, but I certainly never feel the urge to go back to it. It won't get anywhere near the playtime Oblivion, Skyrim, Fallout 3/NV, and Fallout 4 got out of me. If you want to take it for a spin you'll know within a couple hours if its for you or not.

I bought the Collector's Edition back at launch, and then it sat unopened for a year as I played other games. Typing this now, I wish I had just left it in the box. What a massive disappointment. I'm only 10 hours in and almost threw my controller at the TV because of how unintuitive and bad the controls and menus are. It was like they had a contest to design the worst user-interface in history.

And the game is just...so...boring! Absolutely nothing to engage or interest me whatsoever. 

Here is the most damning thing I can say. I am the type of gamer who reads *all* the quest text and tries every dialogue option. But this is the *first* game where I just started speed-skipping through all the talking because it was so inane and useless. The writing is bad, the voice acting is bad, and the entire universe feels absolutely empty and desolate.

Bethesda is no longer Bethesda in the same way that Blizzard is no longer Blizzard. Sad.

I just had enough after 200 hours.

This game is not finished at all. There are too many bugs, unfinished content, inconsistencies, bugs, unfinished content, bugs, imbalances, unfinished content, bugs, bugs, and bugs.

It is weird because the graphics, sounds, animation, and FPS (not spacecraft part) aspects definitely work for a AAA game. It’s like the different departments making the game didn’t communicate with each other at all. I would compare it to buying a brand-new immaculate Lamborghini that looks stunning, but 3 out of 4 windows don't work, the radio has a cassette player, one wheel is bigger than the others so it drives wonky, the gear stick can’t shift into 2nd, it leaks oil, and the air-con is stuck on heating all the time. But hey, it's still a Lamborghini. Although you can’t legally drive it on the road because of all the problems, it still looks great — but it frustrates you like anything. That’s how the game feels.

I would rather Bethesda had sacrificed the sound, graphics, item details, animal details, animation details, and planet details — which are too good compared to the rest of the game — and finished all the content they initially planned. Bethesda definitely started off seriously when making the game, but around 70% completion, they just stopped, tied the loose ends as best as they could, and packaged it up for sale. $120 AUD for an unfinished game — not good at all. Unless they release some major update adding missing content, fixing, and balancing the game, my thumb is staying down. Also, thinking ahead to when they eventually release Elder Scrolls VI, I won’t support half-finished products and will rely heavily on other people's reviews before purchasing. I feel like they cheated me with Starfield…

SOME SPOILERS POSSIBLE FROM NOW ON

There are lots of planets in the game, and some of them have life, but all of them have resources. Animals and plants give different resources, and some can even be domesticated. So you play the game and scan the whole planet — every plant, every animal. Bear in mind, this can take a while, as some planets have different biomes, and different biomes have different life forms. You have to land in different areas of the planet to scan them all. So after scanning everything, you leave to scan another planet, and after a while, you have quite a few planets with different resources. But there’s no in-game codex to check which planet has which resources. I had to keep a pen and notebook beside me and write everything down unless I wanted to repeatedly land, find, and walk to each plant or animal to see what it gave me. That got boring really quickly...

You also can’t land wherever you want or fly on the planet’s surface, which wouldn’t be so bad if they got everything else right. When you land on a planet with, let’s say, a toxic atmosphere, sometimes you start in the cockpit, but most of the time, you spawn 30m away from the ship. Maybe there’s a pattern, but it seems random. If you didn’t have your spacesuit on before landing, you’ll start taking damage while walking back to the ship to equip it.

Moon Buggy:
Sometimes your buggy won’t spawn, so you have to go in and out of the ship to get it to appear. I like a challenge in my games, so I set everything to max difficulty. But instead of challenging, it just feels unbalanced.

The buggy is indestructible and has an 80s-style arcade boost. You hold the boost for 4 seconds, wait for it to recharge, and repeat. No fuel, no upgrades — nothing. You can view it like your ship, except the ship has an upgrade tab and a shipbuilder tab. You can boost 200m into the air and crash down without a scratch. There's no reason to drive carefully, so it gets boring really quickly; it feels like cheating.

You also can’t store items in the buggy — it has no inventory. Your follower can’t shoot from it either, even though it has no doors or windows, but they’ll still yell threats at enemies. You can turn on the headlights and honk the horn, though. The buggy is visually detailed. If you have two or more followers, one sits in the passenger seat while the others awkwardly spawn on top of the buggy as you drive.

The buggy floats on water and drives across it — absolutely ridiculous. On low-gravity planets, there's no way to add weight for better traction, so it becomes tedious to drive. Your follower sometimes says, "We need to get this repaired," which suggests Bethesda initially planned for more mechanics.

Spacecraft:
Arcade-style spaceship combat… bad. Objects in space sometimes make your ship start gliding like it's on autopilot. Occasionally, you fall into a void beneath the ship, making it invisible.

I lost my full Mantis Suit from my ship inventory — that made me pretty angry, especially since I also lost some other legendary gear. On the positive side, the ship landing and takeoff animations are fantastic.

When you boost in space, the ship eventually slows down, like there’s friction… in space. The shipbuilder UI is clunky. Sometimes, invisible ships appear — just floating hatches with no body. And thruster flames can’t hurt you, even if you stand in them.

Planets:
The planets look beautiful, but the codex is missing, as I mentioned earlier. On low-gravity planets like during the Empty Nest quest, you enter a mine and suddenly the gravity becomes normal — despite being on the same planet.

If you fully scan a planet before upgrading your scanner to identify which plants and animals are domesticated, you’ll have to kill or pick them later to update the data. The planet map doesn’t show biomes even after scanning; you have to click random locations to find biome information.

Outposts look amazing from a bird’s-eye view, but resource logistics are ridiculous. You can’t limit production, and everything clogs up. If you build a landing pad, only one delivery route can connect to it, and each outpost only allows three pads. If you want resources from more than three planets, tough luck — build another outpost.

Some side quests are so poorly written. I didn’t even finish the main story because i got so frustrated. The main story itself seemed decent, though.

Other Oddities:
You can kill 15 enemies and then pass a speech check with their boss — and suddenly they're okay with you.
There’s an NPC that says it doesn’t have a gender...??!
Lots of quest glitches, plus you can steal everything from some areas without consequence.
Research mechanics are bad. If you track a resource, complete the research, and collect enough materials, the tracking doesn’t go away.
Custom map markers don’t show in your scanner view, so they’re useless.
Placing buildings removes rocks and trees temporarily, but they respawn later, sticking through your structures.
Outpost turrets occasionally vanish.
Resource connection lines are all the same shade of green and overlap, looking cheap.
Jumping forward on planets has no inertia — if you release the forward key mid-jump, you stop in mid-air. Zero-G stations are well done, but you can’t rotate your character while floating. So if enemy is right below you, you can’t shoot them as your angle of view when looking all the way down is not 90 degree it is more like 80 degree.
If you build an outpost 1000m from your landing site and land at the outpost later, you’ll spawn there — but your ship and buggy stay 1000m away. On toxic planets, you can fast-travel if you're not over-encumbered, but if you are, enjoy the walk.
There’s no way to select or track quests directly from the planet map; you have to hunt through the quest log manually.
This is a condensed review, but this game isn’t worth the money. The potential is there — you can see it — but it needs more work. A major update is needed to fix these bugs and missing features. I’m extremely disappointed

I like this game, I've played 1,500 hours on it, I'm still finding the odd side mission I've not seen before and it is my go to game for no stress random exploration. Often mission board driven, do the job, then explore all those other buildings, take the missions to find lost miners and help out those busy scientists. It's an easy and undemanding way to wind down after work. Maybe, that's the problem with Starfield though? Too easy and too boring, unless you happen to be in your late fifties and you're looking for something undemanding, without the stress of online multi-player, where the very familiarity of the locations and the predictability of the AI, makes for a cosy certainty of a successful mission. I have to confess though, it's beginning to wear thin now.

The Game has some nice elements, twists, surprises and good set piece fights, but I'm not really sure there is enough of it. I had hopes for Shattered Space and to an extent, it delivers. A decent story, some nice locations, sexy new weapons and demanding new adversaries, but you get one planet, actually it's a moon orbiting a planet, and that really is your lot. Now the scale of Starfield is epic and if you ignore some clunky game mechanisms and a plethora of loading screen transitions, which really don't belong in this day and age, it's a decent space explorer with a decent FPS element and an okay space combat element, which keeps you coming back to design new ships. Once you have the budget though, it's going to be a very bad day if your ship can't beat anything you encounter. 

So do i recommend it? Cautiously, yes. Will you get your money's worth, I think so. Will you keep coming back to it? I don't know. If it suits you and you aren't looking for edge of the seat excitement, once the main quest lines are exhausted, maybe pootling around the Galaxy taking out pirates and delivering miners , will hold your interest. If you still have the reflexes of a sixteen year old and a regular urge to melt the face off a noob, this is probably not going to float your boat.

So I am going to damn this game with faint praise:

It does have that Bethesda X factor (but diluted), is filled to the gills with (shallow) stuff to do and I get the feeling it really is trying.  Occasionally the script is funny or cool in spite of itself.  

I mean I somehow killed 160 hours playing it so it isn't all bad!

But this is one clunky game, with often awful storytelling, generic procedural slop everywhere, an AMAZINGLY poor UI that couldn't be much worse and remain playable, and Borderlands style loot.  You won't find gear that is your favourite and has good lore and a clever move-set or anything, because it all designed to be tossed five minutes after you get it for the next thing.  

The base building is awful and irrelevant and the ship building is awful and barely relevant and the resource collection and sharing system are atrocious.  

Bethesda - I'd advise dropping base building from your games completely but if it must stay, then make is useful and not atrociously clumsy.  Maybe take a look at actual survival games like Subnautica for how to do it!  

For a game that is supposedly all about exploration they fail miserably - mostly exploration is cardboard, dull and cut and paste!

It is the weakest Bethesda RPG game I have played so far (and I have played all from Morrowind onwards).  They really do seem to be doubling down on their worst design issues with Starfield though.  I hope they realise this before the next Elder Scrolls game or they may just suffer an irredeemable and damaging crash in popularity.  Starfield has relatively poor ratings and I can see why!

But hey - 160 hours and I don't feel like I hate it or forced myself to the end, so something worked out to make it decent!  I guess in the end I will say this - it is the longest 7/10 game ever!

Starfield is a game that feels years out of date. While the combat is the best it has ever been in a Bethesda game, everything else feels like it's stuck a decade behind. The storytelling feels stilted and amateur, the characters are one-dimensional, and the RPG and choice elements have been stripped to the bone. It is filled with terrible and baffling design decisions. There is no single standout aspect in this game. Every element is painfully average and culminates in an unsatisfying and underwhelming experience.

This isn't a game from "award-winning creators". It’s an awkward, directionless mess that fails to live up to its own ambitions.

Pros:
- Best facial expressions in a bethesda game
- Really distinctive futuristic style (like the space race never ended)
- No fallout 4 type conversation style (fully described options)
- Interesting story
- The DLC is actually kinda fun and interesting
- Barely any bugs

Cons:
- Procedural generation used for planets which is waaaay too obvious due to the abhorrent emptiness of the planets
- Optimization is kinda funky
- Ship barely utilized at all. I remember like 5 times where you had to actually fly the ship for stuff like combat (which is pretty boring in space) and docking with a station.

Regardless, still a fun experience. Get on sale :)

Starfield is ok. It's not terrible but it's not great, it's just ok. I played the game immediately upon release, expected nothing (the bar was in hell) and enjoyed it for about a month. One day I turned the game off to go to bed, forgot about it, and never played it again. It's not really memorable or exciting. There were some side quests I really enjoyed (probably because I was high AF) but the main story was boring and predictable. I lost interest in it and went to do my own thing, hoping to make up my own adventure. There is so much text given to you that you're not allowed to create a personal story, or imagine/roleplay how you got there; there is always an npc there with 50 lines of dialogue to explain exactly what's happening  so I don't get confused or hurt myself. Every merchant wants to give you their life story, even if you just want to vendor trash. Everybody just trusts you, and if they don't yet they will after 4 or 5 more clicks. It feels shallow.

I bought Skyrim and its various editions 5 times on 3 different steam accounts so you know I love to kiss Todd Howard's ass but this game feels soulless and it can't hold my attention. At least my jank 10 year old rig can run it decently. I recommend this game if you can get it on sale, purely because I really enjoyed that one quest while high as fuck. It's literally the only thing I remember about Starfield, but it's a fond memory. It's the quest about the charity event.

This is the worst game I've ever played.

 All the procedurally generated planets are completely empty and filled with the same repetitive dungeons over and over again. Exploration is completely worthless, which is a fatal flaw for an RPG.

And they're asking 70 FUCKING DOLLARS for this pile of shit.

I even pre-ordered this. Never again.

3 step Simple Guide to Enjoy the Game:  
.Only do Quests dont ever under any circumstances explore, Dont go anywhere Unless its for a Quest. You will find way more unique stuff generated that way. Every Quest ingame will lead you to "almost" everything.

.Put Ai Damage on Very Hard and Player Damage on Easy. Makes combat more fun/less spongy.

.Invest in Intimidation skill/ Manipulation Use it as much as possible makes the game more interesting.

This applies to the base game if you later on decide to put Grindfield mods/ Royal Galaxy  thats whole different thing. Many of the games issues can be overcome with those simple steps and the game is Fun If you follow them strictly. DO NOT EXPLORE the game is not built for it as it simply cant generate interesting content without a quest chain

[h1][b][u]A Beautiful but Hollow Voyage[/u][/b][/h1]

After spending more than my fair share of hours in Starfield, I can safely say the game has a lot of potential, but it’s a far cry from the space adventure I was hoping for. The universe feels huge, but not in a good way. It’s like being stranded in a vast, desolate empty mall where no ones around. Sure, there are things to explore, but every time I thought ''hey this might be exciting'', A companion wouldn't shut up with more of its pointless chatter, shattering MY immersion more times than there are stars in SPACE. And trust me, that's way too many!

A while back, I was feeling some space vibes, and since I knew Bethesda had released its expansion, I thought, ‘Let me give the game a new take, hoping for something fresh.’ After meeting with Constellation, I ended up encountering this space station, and I thought, 'Hey, maybe this will turn out awesome!' Only to noticed it was targeted towards level 35 players, and I was only barely level 18. You can guess how that went. Instead of excitement, I dried up very, very fast and it all turned into a brutal desert that had me questioning the game’s pacing. 

It felt, at least to me, like Bethesda was just throwing content at me without any real rhyme or reason. While I appreciated the attempt to shake things up, something is definitely wrong when what should have been a simple and enjoyable exploration experience quickly devolved into an incredibly tedious and frustrating grind, one that felt like an endless death trap just to get past the level gap. Moving forward felt like pure masochism, while pulling back felt weird, making everything feel meaningless either way, like nothing I did actually mattered at all.

I get it, Bethesda wanted to make things more immersive. But honestly, there’s nothing immersive about being interrupted every five seconds. It felt like my companion was tugging on my sleeve like an overenthusiastic child, desperately trying to drag me into a conversation about absolutely nothing. I’d be getting all excited about a mysterious cave or hidden shipwreck, and boom, here comes my companion rambling about artifacts, backstories, or some other random nonsense that had absolutely nothing to do with at all. It got so bad, I started trying to skip through it like it was an infomercial I definitely didn’t sign up for!

Companion and NPC dialogue intended to create an immersive, living world are repeated so frequently that it instead feels forced and becomes increasingly annoying over time.

The only time I felt a real connection to the world was when I explored in solitude, but even that didn’t last long. Space felt empty not just because of the lack of content but because the universe itself lacked a real sense of place. I wanted to feel like I was part of something bigger, an epic story in a vast galaxy. Instead, it felt like I was just bouncing around with no purpose.

Mods helped a little, but even with 145 deployed mods I can not say it was enough to save the game. Starfield felt like a dead party at times; you show up, but no one’s there. Bethesda promised updates, but it seems pretty clear they don’t really care. The art style? More “space fashion” than actual space, and the vehicle controls? Don’t even get me started. 

Speaking of which, the Rev-8's handling? Terrible. Every time I thought I was getting a grip on how the controls worked, I was slammed with a hard reminder that driving in Starfield was like controlling a tank on wheels. The sluggishness made every attempt to navigate planets a chore. To compare it to another game, the MAKO from Mass Effect was a gold standard of clunky vehicles, but Starfield somehow managed to make that look like a fine-tuned sports car.

Then, there’s the “freedom” of space travel. While the game promised it, Starfield felt like a glorified fast-travel system with combat attached. Sure, you can customize your ship, but that customization doesn’t mean much when all you’re doing is hopping between predefined points on the map. There’s no real sense of freedom, just a series of linear objectives with space.

Now, the spaceship building is where Starfield shines. You get to design and create your own ship, and the creativity in shipbuilding is truly one of the game’s stronger points. You can get into the nitty-gritty, adjusting every part of your ship to make it unique to your playstyle. However, as great as it is to build your dream ship, it’s disappointing to see that flying the space craft is reduced to a tool for fast travel rather than a meaningful part.

The promise of space exploration and discovery is present, but it’s buried under a mountain of frustrating design choices. It’s as though Bethesda had a grand vision and got too caught up in the details without considering the larger picture. The universe might be vast, but it feels empty. The shipbuilding might be fun, but it’s not enough to make up for the lack of substance.

If you’re looking for a true space adventure, you might get disappointed like me. Starfield has the right ingredients, but it’s not seasoned enough to be the feast it promises.

📜 SIDE NOTES:

[code][b]⭐ Exploration feels vast but empty, lacking dynamic content to keep you engaged.
⭐ Companion interruptions disrupt immersion and hinder enjoyment of the world.
⭐ Graphics are not the worst but the world looks very dated on this engine.
⭐ Shipbuilding is fun, but flying them doesn’t match with the limited exploration.

[/b] [/code]
[code][b]⚠️ Starfield has great potential, but it didn’t pull me in enough to stick through the entire experience. While it offers vast exploration and creative shipbuilding, the empty universe, constant interruptions, and lack of true freedom left me feeling disconnected. If you’re looking for a deep, immersive space adventure, this might not be the journey you’re hoping for, at least not yet.[/b] [/code]
[code][b]📢 There are no major updates for Starfield that address the issues I’ve encountered. While there’s potential for improvement, my experience remains unchanged at the time of writing this review.[/b] [/code]

I was a Bethesda fan for many years and, like many Bethesda fans, I was increasingly disappointed with each new Bethesda release. Starfield is in my opinion Bethesda hitting rock-bottom. It is a shallow, boring mess of a game, with terrible writing, devoid of meaningful choice. It is more "make your own fun" meaningless sandbox, with very little RPG elements to speak of. 

Space exploration is non-existent, with the player spending most of the time in menus and cutscenes to fast travel between planets. And speaking of planets, bar one or two main story / quest planets, each an every planet is essentially the same, boring, procedural-generated slog.  Once you've seen 3 or so planets, you've seen them all in terms of "content" to explore.  And even the two or so "main" planets are nothing to get excited over.

The main story is also very disappointing. None of the "big story" moments ever felt like they were building to something special, while the main cast of characters are shallow and I didn't care for any of them. 

The combat is fine. Similar to Fallout 4's. It's "good enough", but nothing worth praising.

Steady and slow exploration, while fast paced action.  I wouldn't even plan on completing a mildly interesting planet per game session (2 or 3 hours) if you want to fully explore.  To really enjoy this game I had to take a step back from the uneven pacing and just enjoy my time exploring as much as the combat.  I recommend to split those sessions apart.  Clear out a base, then plunder on the next session.  Role Play on the populated planet, then explore the cave or space battle the next. Starfield is 100% what you make of it, hear me out. Yes, it has a good amount of what feels like filler content in that the exploration is mostly fancy loading screens that you have some control over and vast, yet empty & repetitive planets copied and pasted in various solar systems. Yes some of the missions & activities (Activities especially) are as dull as staring into the void. However, overall the different story lines come together with some really incredibly well written & fleshed out dialogue and flexibility in how you play through them. I am a little surprised that some are saying that the game lacks independence; You are not obligated to do anything in the game at almost any point. As far as Bethesda games go, it is the most dependent on individually tailored experiences and role play that I've experienced (In my opinion). When I initially bought it I played through the first couple hours and uninstalled it and it took me a long time to give it another chance. If you have the time to spend to explore the game and immerse yourself in the universe that's built around it, the game just kind of becomes what you decide it'll be. It's definitely not for everybody but there is a reason a lot of the negative reviews are coming from people who played through the game for as long as I have or more. It's a great experience if you can get through some of the initial set-up in the world and figure what path you want to go down.

Starfield Review: A Galactic Disappointment

As someone who loves space, open-world RPGs, and Bethesda games, Starfield should have been a dream come true. Instead, it’s one of the most frustrating gaming experiences I’ve had. After spending 150+ hours exploring its universe, I can confidently say: I can’t recommend it.  

The gameplay feels clunky, the planets are mostly empty, and the much-hyped space travel is nothing more than loading screens disguised as exploration. The cities, which should have been vibrant hubs of activity, feel lifeless and uninspired. Quests range from decent to downright dull, and the lack of true player freedom—a staple of Bethesda’s best games—makes the whole experience feel restrictive rather than immersive.  

Even as a die-hard fan of open-world RPGs, Starfield never clicked. It lacks the magic of Skyrim or Fallout, and no amount of modding will fix the core design flaws. If you’re looking for a rich, engaging space RPG, this isn’t it.  

Score: 4/10 – A lifeless universe not worth exploring

I read a review that said “I enjoyed this game like I enjoy a fast food cheeseburger.” And that really hit home with me. Sure, I played Starfield all the way though, did all the faction quests, did best girl Andreja’s character quest, and did a ton of sides. But in after a while (somewhere in the 40-hour range), I hit the “Starfield wall” that so many others have mentioned, where I was decidedly disappointed and ready to be done. I ate my fill and looking back, it wasn’t as appealing as it seemed.

Bethesda has a captive audience for their games. I so thoroughly enjoyed the past Elder Scrolls and Fallout 3 and maybe 4 that I am a part of that audience.  But for this, I think their products suffer for it. Starfield has its good aspects, sure. It has an imaginative setting, it’s probably the least buggy Bethesda game, has good weapon variety, and I think there is some good writing in there. But man, it’s dragged down by it’s flaws and inadequacies. The RPG mechanics are almost completely gone, almost every other mechanic is worse than previous iterations, its worlds feel disconnected and unalive, its crafting and building mechanics are tedious and pointless, and spaceship flying feels like filler.

First, the good. There is a genuinely good stuff about Starfield. I like the new IP. I think they went out on a limb and crafted something that can stand on its own merit. I enjoyed what they did conceptually. I like the United Colonies “socialist dystopia” vs the Free star Collective’s “unchecked libertarianism” ideological clash. I think some of the quests tell good stories. For example, The UC Vanguard questline is legitimately well crafted and interesting. Aside from some poor writing, I enjoyed main quest as well. Also, shout out to the city of Neon for being a well-crafted in game metropolis. 

To its credit, the game has a TON of fun weapons to use and experiment with. I feel like its gunplay is a marked improvement from Fallout 4. Also, there is something to be said about the amount of content in the game. If I really wanted to squeeze 100+ hours out of it, I probably could. But aside from its setting, combat, and amount of content,  most other aspects disappoint.

I think the biggest issue with the game is that Bethesda completely gutted all of it RPG mechanics to the point where the game is not even an RPG anymore. Base stats are gone, skills are gone, leveling up is rarely exciting or rewarding. I think Fallout 4 was where Bethesda decided to begin to phase out RPG mechanics, but at least in that game we had SPECIAL. When you craft a character, all you do is you pick your first 3 perks and a background, which just offers a rare chance at special dialogue. Every time you level up, you pick a perk. And in order to make new perks available to be selected, you need to do little challenges. So sometimes you don’t even have any good perks to select when you level up. It’s a poor system and a part of the trend of Bethesda slowly eliminating the depth of its RPG mechanics. Its like “wow, I just leveled up and now I get to *checks perks* increase my ship’s shields by 10%? Whoopee.” Sometimes I just kept points in the bank so leveling up was such a ho-hum experience. A lot of perks are “required perks” like lockpicking and ship piloting. I never really felt like I was creating a “build” or customizing a character in any way.

Aside from the RPG mechanics being downgraded, almost all other gameplay mechanics are worse than previous Bethesda games. Lockpicking is now a tedious minigame where you can spend 2-3 minutes picking a lock just to get a grilled cheese sandwich for +5 health over 30 seconds. Crafting is not worth the time and effort. Cooking and mixology are basically pointless. When you crouch, your character does a “crouch animation” and doesn’t get smaller so all ventilation shafts are person sized. Stealth seems to be a design afterthought and difficult if you have any companions. Base building is less impactful than say, Fallout 4, where you can build settlements and populate them. In Starfield you can “populate” bases by assigning companions to them, but no random NPC citizens show up to be real pops. Base building as an aspect of gameplay is overcomplicated and almost pointless. Persuasion checks are an unintuitive mess that almost require you to take multiple speech related perks to navigate successfully. Status effects have been neutered. I swear one time I was frostbitten and it reduced my ship maneuverability score or something dumb like that. Melee mechanics are absent or weak. Ship designing and upgrading is horrible. I could go on but suffice it to say I am disappointed with the direction of most gameplay mechanics in Starfield as compared to other Bethesda games.

The worlds in Starfield feel unalive. NPCs do not have schedules or houses, unlike previous Bethesda games. You’ll have shopkeepers tending to their shops 24/7. NPCs never actually enter shops; they mostly just mill about. The “worlds” of Starfield are mostly made up of a few “copy and paste” locations. Fast traveling gets old and starship travel through space is limited to the space around planets and is definitely an afterthought. Support for flight sticks/joysticks is absent. Cities are the high point of the world building, with Neon being very cool. But unfortunately, many of the cities are one dimensional. Akila city is an egregiously boring place with little to no character besides being the “space cowboy town.”

Also, it’s a bad look that the core gameplay loop for the some quests is reduced to: find npc, talk to npc, fast travel to orbit, fast travel to planet surface, find npc, talk to npc, fast travel to orbit, fast travel to planet surface, repeated over and over. Like you can’t even mix it up by walking from place to place like in previous games, you basically need to pass through multiple loading screens to get anywhere. It makes you wish flying was more fleshed out and you could actually fly from place to place instead of “grav jumping” ie. loading screen ftl.

I’ve wrote enough. I mean, yes, I did play through the game and I even enjoyed some aspects of it. But I give this game a thumbs down because I feel like Bethesda is going the wrong direction with their game design. I don’t even think they made an RPG with this one. It’s a looter shooter with a bunch of frivolous mechanics you probably wont even use. Starfield doesn’t stand up to its modern competition. If you are a busy person looking for something to scratch that itch, don’t spend time on this one, just play Cyperpunk. I hope for a return to form with the next Bethesda game.

It's a Bethesda game, and I mean that in both the complementary and derogatory sense.

There is some utterly stupid stuff, like the stranded colonist who needed help back to his ship and ended up getting killed by wildlife, all while less than 100km from New Atlantis. And the locations can be horribly repetitive, with no variation in loot or inhabitants... it'd be nice to find an Abandoned Robotics Facility that's occupied by lawful salvagers, or colonists looking to use it as a home base. Or a seemingly friendly outpost that's harboring some dark secret. And let's not start about how there's nobody in Constellation who isn't a complete goody-goody even when they've supposedly got a chequered past.

But when it hits the mark it REALLY hits  the mark. The first encounter with the Terrormorph in the Vanguard questline is genuinely scary if you haven't met one before, and some locations feature some truly great level design. And the main quest, for all its repetitiveness at times is well-paced meaning you can almost immediately go off sidequesting without feeling like you're putting cataclysmic events on hold to go on a beer run.

aside from that, i am recommending it, enjoy.

I would have expected more variations in the side stories and more variation in the random encounters (pilgrim vessels with the same boring exchange for the 50th time, anyone?).
The real desapointment came from the outpost and the starship design. The design tools are very difficult to handle, there is too much to say to put it here, but clearly creating functional and realistic outpost is close to impossible. Same for a good looking and functional starship interior.

The darn thing crashes every 15 minutes and there is a HUGE frame rate drop before and after opening any in game menu. DO NOT buy this game. I have a Nvidia GeForce RTX 4060 Ti, so I know my GPU is not the issue, not to mention this is not an isolated case. These issues are prevalent all over the starfield community, and no one has found a consistent fix yet.

There's some downsides like a lot of loading screens and required fast travel, but past that there lies a solid game with tons of things to see and do. There is nothing more satisfying than boarding an enemy ship in the middle of combat, killing the crew, stealing the ship and then using said ship against your enemies. If that sounds like a good time to you, then play Starfield.

It's skyrim in space, like many have said. It's classic Bethesda. The main story is solid. Most of the sidequest chains and faction quests are better than solid; many are very good. Ship building is the new base-building, and I'm addicted.

There are a lot of small criticisms you can make, and many have, but nothing that's been a deal breaker for me. The skill tree balance too staggered and feels geared toward New Game Plus. Planet Exploration and Temples are repetitive and boring because of how they're designed/implemented. Ship and House furniture placement controls are garbage, making decorating painful. These are all disappointments, but the fun I've had with the combat and doing story missions has definitely made up for it. I still wish those things were better, however.

Overall, I definitely think it's been worthwhile. If you like Bethesda style games and the space/sci-fi aesthetic appeals to you, you'll probably like it too.

Starfield: A Galaxy of Missed Opportunities

I was incredibly excited for Starfield, especially coming from Bethesda—a studio known for legendary games like Fallout and Skyrim. Unfortunately, Starfield turned out to be a major disappointment. I had high expectations, but the game feels outdated, as if it should have been released a decade ago. While it introduces bold and ambitious ideas, many of them are poorly executed.

The world is undeniably vast and expansive, yet it often feels empty and lifeless. Some locations are beautifully crafted, but there’s not enough depth or engaging content to keep me invested. I started Starfield with enthusiasm, but I quickly found myself losing interest. It simply doesn’t have that immersive pull that Bethesda’s previous titles had. That being said, the time I spent playing was a blast. There were moments of real enjoyment, but they were few and far between. There just aren't enough of those exciting moments to look forward to. The game loses its pace too often, making it feel less engaging overall.

That said, there are some fun elements. Ship customization is a great feature, visiting different locations can be exciting, and the random encounters with bounty hunters add some unpredictability. The ability to hijack ships is also a highlight, and the gunplay feels creative and enjoyable.

While Starfield didn’t meet my expectations, I’m hopeful that future updates and expansions will improve the experience. Maybe down the line, with more content and polish, it will evolve into the game I had hoped for. Until then, I’d say give it a try—there’s still some fun to be had, even if it doesn’t quite reach the heights of Bethesda’s past masterpieces. Despite its flaws, I still think this is a game worth purchasing. There is something here for everyone, and I believe many players will find enjoyment in different aspects of the game. However, it's important to go in knowing that there are some significant shortcomings that may affect the overall experience.

I can understand the mixed reviews for this game. This game is made for such a wide variety of players that it's confusing for players to slot into one category to review due to the players play style. This game is a Open World Shooter/ Space Sim/ Building and Trading Sim all at once while not excelling at any one criteria. For me, playing it for the Shooter /  Space Flying that I prefer, I can see the Comparison to Mass Effect that players compare this game too. The difference is that this game which is "Story driven" is "not solely" story driven like "Mass Effect". Mass Effect Trilogy is a Brilliant story driven game and highly recommended to anyone who hasn't played it yet. Starfield is a Very Good game in it's own right, by adding in the different styles player's may want to do other than the Storylines. Build your own Base or Design your own ship, the options here are open to the Players discretion. The DLC while being a good improvement for the game , was priced to high for the content it brought. I can see the potential for this game  being "Highly Recommended"by all players with improvements, being added not only by Bethesda Games, but also by the Modder Community in the future, for everyone's different play style's. If you can buy the "Base Game and DLC " on special, I would Highly Recommend.

People keep complaining that the planets are too empty and there is not that much too see after you have visited a few. While I do agree that free roam exploration is weak to me the problem is quite the opposite. The planets are not empty enough. You can't land anywhere on any planet or on any moon without running into an abandoned robotics lab, a fracking station, a deserted relay or a civilian outpost. Take off and land somewhere else on that planet and its the same story. The game generates an explorable area of roughly 1 to 2 square km in size and then populates it with among other things, a few bases, outposts or stations to explore. That means that every square km of every rocky planet and moon in the entire game has some kind of habitation signs on it. That is absolutely ridiculous. So the problem to me is not that the planets are too empty but that there is not enough variety in the procedural generation. This is evident in the biodiversity of the planets as well. I can't remember how many times I've seen the same twisted red vine or the same walking brain creature on different planets under different names. The terrain also suffers from the same lack of variety in procedural generation. Since every generated tile is so small there can't be any land forms larger than 2 square km and usually they are much smaller than that. This gives the impression of a mostly flat landscape with some hills and small depressions no matter where you land. Nowhere is that more noticeable than on Earth where the Himalayas have been sanded down completely while the ocean floor has been filled in. In my 120 hours of game play I don't remember to have seen a river or a volcano for example, I feel like if there had been more variety to the terrain players wouldn't have felt so bored so quickly with the exploration. Admittedly I didn't go to every planet in the game but after a while the repetition kicks in and you feel like you've seen all that there is to see already so the drive to explore further vanishes. So yeah this was probably my biggest disappointment with the game. 

My only other disappointment was also related to exploration. That was the fact that the game didn't depict the surfaces of some moons in the solar system accurate enough to current scientific knowledge. For example landing on Jupiter's moon Io I was expecting a volcanic hell. Instead I got something far less interesting that looked somewhat like our Moon. So yeah I don't know how many people care about this.

I knew from the start I'll be playing the main story, the factions and a few other side quests with a little bit of exploration throughout. So in that sense the game delivered everything I wanted. I'll most likely go back to it at some point and play the DLCs.
