I think what most gamers wanted was for Starfield to be Skyrim in space.

In a way it is, but it has none of the gravitas of Skyrim or Oblivion. It feels as if the game was developed by ChatGPT in collaboration with Ubisoft. The locations are sprawly and uninteresting, exactly what you’d expect from procedural generation. The UI is amateurishly bland. The HUD is straight out of Assassin’s Creed with how gamey it feels (enemies literally have health bars on top of them). The writing and characters are so bland—even by Bethesda standards! And the generic music is unmemorable and falls awfully short of Jeremy Soule’s masterpieces for previous Elder Scrolls games.

To get even a better sense of how inferior Starfield is to previous Bethesda games just compare Starfield’s opening sequence with that of Skyrim and Oblivion:

Oblivion: You are a prisoner in a dungeon. The emperor and his royal guard enter your jail cell to go through a secret passageway to escape a cabal of mysterious and deadly assassins. As you fight alongside them, the emperor tells you that he has seen you in his dreams and thus gives you his Amulet of Kings to deliver to his son and heir. In the end, despite doing your best to protect the emperor, he is felled by the assassins before you or the guards could stop them. With the amulet in hand and the emperor’s dying wish in mind, you leave the dungeon through a secret exit… and so your adventure begins.

Skyrim: You open your eyes to find yourself in a wagon full of prisoners. In front of you sits the gagged leader of Skyrim’s rebel faction. The wagon makes its way through the city until you get to the place where you are all supposed to be executed. You see one prisoner get shot to death by archers trying to flee, and another getting his head chopped off by the executioner’s axe. Then just moments before suffering a similar fate, a huge dragon attacks the city, and all hell breaks loose. In the chaos that ensues, as the dragon unleashes its fiery fury upon the city, you make your way through the fire and carnage into a secret dungeon that would lead you outside the city. There you see the escaped prisoners fighting against the imperial soldiers even as the city above them burns. After fighting your way out of the dungeon, you are tasked by the person who helped you escape to warn the nearby town that a dragon is on the loose… and so your adventure begins.

Starfield: Open your eyes to see a girlboss yapping about… mining. You walk in a cave, pickup a mining laser and mine a rock. Then you walk a few meters and mine a few more rocks. Then a mining vehicle opens a new passage, so you walk straight in and pick up a McGuffin that makes you Special! That’s it! No enemies, no archeological remains, no dramatic buildup whatsoever! That’s literally it! You mine six rocks, you walk into a tiny cave, you pick up a piece of metal… OH MY GOD, YOU’RE THE CHOSEN ONE!

Who the **** wrote this?!!! 

I can’t think of anything positive to say about this game except to say, it looks kinda ok. I mean the whole thing feels less like a game, and more like a tech demo of a game engine. Even though I got this game for free with my new graphics card, I still feel ripped off!

Starfield is a game that was chalked full of potential that the developers refused to work with, resulting in a game worse than on-launch Cyberpunk. 

On the surface, it's not that bad. Granted it takes quite the pc to load anything, but we'll ignore that in the spirit of fairness. The game looks great, the dialogue is pretty good, and the movement of the NPCs definitely felt more real than those from Skyrim. (I will be comparing this to Skyrim a lot). But there's almost no depth to the game, especially if you don't care about the lore. It's like the developers didn't know what game they were trying to make. Let me dive into a handful of issues I myself had trouble with after 33 hours of playtime.

|:| Combat |:|
The combat in Starfield genuinely feels bad. All of the guns have weird ammo types and requirements, scrounging for ammo is extremely difficult because for whatever reason they decided we needed more looter in our shooter. There are melee weapons and 'guns' that dont use ammo (Like the plasma drill) but these become extremely obsolete at higher levels, forcing you to rely on guns that you do not have any ammo for. Speaking of higher levels, as you progress through the story, you will encounter higher-level enemies. You, however, will not be higher leveled. The game throws you into the story via the tutorial missions but never tells you when you exited the tutorial and entered the free-roam section of the game. If you decide to just grind through all the story missions, you'll notice that you physically can't fight against the enemies you're up against because they're level 45 and you're still level 10. This is because the game doesn't give you nearly enough XP from the main storyline. It expects you to go off and do side quests but there's 0 indicator of this, and anyone who wants to do the story first will not be able to. This ties in with the ammo problem. Imagine you're hardstuck in a mission with 0 way out (your last save is probably also in this mission, or quite a few hours ago). Your only way to get out of the mission is to complete it, but the people you fight are super high level and way stronger than you. You spend almost all your ammo just to kill one guy, only to find that he had a total of 3 damn bullets on him. Now, you might think "Oh, why not just buy it at vendors?" and that's a great question! So lets get into it.

|:| Economy |:|

Compared to Skyrim, I'm pretty damn certain the Starfield economy is in SHAMBLES. In Skyrim, a whole house WITH upgrades and furnishings could cost you maybe 10000 gold on the higher end. If you want to buy 6000 arrows, it'll set you back a couple thousand but that's it. Money is very easy to get, because you just loot weapons and armor from enemies and sell them. Not in Starfield. Weapons and armor sell for dirt cheap but the buy-back price is through the roof. A single magazine of 9mm ammo is almost 300 f*cking credits. Vendors barely have anything good for sale, and the few times you'll find a vendor that has ammo in the first place or maybe a set of clothing you want, you'll find that it's 2000 credits for a helmet with 1 extra armor than what you have. But your helmet can be sold for 40 buckaroonies. A similar problem existed in Skyrim but it was NOWHERE near as bad. And all of these economical problems are even more noticeable when you try to do anything with the shipbuilding. Speaking of shipbuilding-

|:| Space ships and space combat |:|
I'll give the devs credit for this one, the space combat was actually really fun. I haven't had as much fun fighting flying things in awhile. Granted, it's nowhere near as good as the space combat in similar titles (COUGH COUGH nms COUGH COUGH) but it is still substantial enough to keep someone like me entertained. Glazing aside, here's a couple issues.
THE. ECONOMY. SUUUUUUUUCKS!!! When you go to buy new ships, it is beyond expensive, and would take a couple irl DAYS of farming money to get close to. I spent a whole week of my free time (working a 9-5, coming home, playing this game) doing a bunch of side quests and long storyline parts and I could BARELY afford a ship. Which happened to be WORSE than the ship I already had! Speaking of which, why in the world is any obtainable ship gonna be worse than the one they give you in the tutorial? That makes 0 sense. The only remotely-good ship I was able to get was through a stupid long side quest, and even then the game wouldn't let me equip it until I transferred all of my stuff from my first ship into it. But I couldn't transfer it until I landed on the planet that I found it on and did it manually. It took an hour. This may have changed, it's been over a year since I played, but knowing Bethesda it more than likely has not.
When it comes to upgrading your ship, it's even worse. Starfield was hyped up heavily in it's customization of space ships, and yet you can't customize! If you want certain parts, you need other types of parts on your ship to begin with or it just won't let you put it on. And if you want parts so you can get parts? You can't put it on your type of ship anyway because the ship itself isn't compatible! BUT it'll still let you buy the part! So you can spend 40k on one singular engine (Not to upgrade your engineS, no, just to upgrade ONE of them) and then be told that you can't equip it. If you go to leave, you don't get your money back AND you don't keep the part! Isn't that spectacular? Even if you tried to get around this by going into the settings or by using mods, you can't. Speaking of mods, lets get into my #1 reason why I don't like Starfield.

|:| The Modding community |:|

Doesn't exist! Simple as. If you go to Nexus right now you will see jack sh*t that actually ADDS stuff to the game. The reason being that Starfield hasn't released it's coding stuff the same way Skyrim has. Starfield did "recently" get its in-game modding section that I forget the name of, but even in there you won't find anything good. All of the mods just change aspects of the game or rename stuff in the steam files because the base game is genuinely bad. Skyrim lives off of mods, every single Bethesda game is basically nothing without mods, we know this. But at least Skyrim can hold its own. You can play through Skyrim unmodded and the only major issues would be a few bugs and the awful (in todays standards) graphics. But Starfield isn't like that. The base game is just dogsh*t and makes me want to rip my eyes out. It's impossible to have fun. Even with mods, your experience will be bad, because the code isn't publicly available like it is for Skyrim, there are no mods that add anything new (we get retextures. Thats kinda it) and even the mods that change stuff in game 6 times out of 10 won't work. And it's not even the fault of the modder, the game's code is just made of fettuccine alfredo with extra sauce. I can't even say it's Dead on Arrival, this game died before they put anything on paper. "Years in the making" my *ss.
-----------------
|:| Conclusion |:|

As someone who tried her absolute best to enjoy this game, who pre-ordered the premium edition, who modded the sh*t out of it to try and make it bareable, I just can't recommend it. If you're wanting a space-Skyrim, you won't find it here. This game looks better, sure, but that's all it has. There won't be a space-Skyrim for years to come if this is the standard of Bethesda now. If you want a good space exploration game, go play No Man's Sky. Not only is it infinitely better but the replayability and creativity of the developers knows no bounds. Go show them some love.

Sadly, there is absolutely no point in playing this game. The reason is simple: There is nothing to do. 

I was so excited when I preordered it. I stopped playing one day when I got tired of fast-traveling. It's a space game, after all, and Bethesda way of dealing with that is to have you fast travel between stars, and even between planets and moons. There is literally nothing to do shipboard.

The game is an endless series of fetch quests with nothing to do in between. Imagine playing Fallout 4 that way: fast travel to Concord. Fast travel to Drumlin Diner, to Oberland Station, to Diamond City. Without walking, there would be nothing interesting: no encounters, noting to look at. No quests. And that's Starfield.

I came back to it intending to continue playing a few days later, after having gone back to Skyrim meanwhile. I sat in front of my screen, looking at my ship and my quests, and realizing I had to fast travel to Point A, talk to Person X, then fast travel to Point B, ad nauseam. The encounters along the way would be a few lines of dialog. Locations would be clones of previous locations. I closed down the game and never went back to it.

I had high hopes for the DLC. I really thought they would fix things, give us a star system which they promised would be as rich as Far Harbor. Of course, it bore no resemblance to Far Harbor. It was more of the same. No new culture, no new weapons, no new outfits, no new exotic ship designs of an isolated culture. Unlike Far Harbor, it looked and played like content cut from the base game, and probably was.

I did not even both to download the DLC. I've watched and listened to the posturing of folks at Bethesda, blaming everyone but themselves for this fiasco of a result. And that tells me that this is a dead IP. If Bethesda is even capable of something like Fallout or Skyrim, they will have to prove it. Todd has dropped the ball, big time.

Meanwhile, Starfield is uninstalled and will remain so. I'm not alone. Check the mods at Nexus. It's pathetic, half what Fallout 4, a broken game produces, and a fraction of what comes out daily for Skyrim.

I've decided to write this review now just to wrap my experience up and share it with others here. I'm not done with Bethesda. Their older games remain. But I'll never preorder another new IP.
DO NOT BUY

Starfield fails to deliver on expectations.  For this reason, I am not recommending it; however, I have quite a few hours into it and I still play it.  If you cast expectations aside, it does offer the standard Bethesda formula in a space environment.  Just like the Elder Scrolls and recent Fallout games, Starfield includes all the RPG elements – character customization, weapon/armor customization, followers, missions, exploration, buying/selling, top-notch voiceovers, along with strikingly beautiful graphics.  It also does a couple of things that stand out from the normal formula, including having a vast number of planets that can be visited and explored, and a ship design/construction feature.  

But first I will explain why many people’s expectations were not met.  

[list]
[*] [b]Spaceship simulation mechanics[/b]: Or lack thereof.  Starfield was very highly anticipated and many, including myself, were expecting it to feature some space simulation mechanics similar to Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous, or No Man’s Sky.  Mechanics like lowering your ship to a landing pad without crashing, setting up destination plans, traversing planet atmospheres, worrying about fuel, or just in general any mechanics that require some sort of skill or minigame for space travel. Starfield instead offers a series of fast travel clicks coupled with very pretty “leaving the scene” animations – you don’t even have to point yourself in the right direction. I believe this maybe the single largest gripe about this game.  I will mention that Starfield does offer spaceship combat with all of the normal ship movements, and speed control, thrust, and weapons variation – and I’m not really a spaceship combat connoisseur, but I believe those who are, are saying it falls short the aforementioned games.  With the amount of feedback on the lack of space simulation, I would hope that Bethesda is considering putting something in the works that allows for a “simulation” mode gameplay that brings all of the above-mentioned mechanics into the game.  That would seriously be a “game” changer.  
[*][b]Limited POIs[/b]: With the vast number of planets that can be visited, you will find quite a bit of re-used points of interest.  After taking on a few missions to eliminate a “bad guy”, you’ll begin recognizing and remembering the locations, buildings, sublevels, loot locations, NPCs, etc. even though you have supposedly never been there.  With as much effort that was obviously put into the game, you must wonder why they didn’t add more locations.  So these missions kind of “dry up” after a while and become very repetitious.  I believe there are some mods, called “creations”, that attempt to add POIs, but these cost money – I’ve tried some of these, but so far, I’m not super impressed.  
[*][b]Main story is a little weak[/b]: Some aspects of the main story are interesting but a lot of it seems a little bland, and the hoops that you have to jump through to gain powers are repetitive and not much fun.  I’m not really going to try to explain why, but I found myself much more interested in some of the faction questlines and have aligned with another reviewer’s recommendation to purposely stop main mission progress after visiting “the eye”.  Another minor annoyance is that all of the potential Constellation followers are just too judgmental – about choices you make, committing crime, accidentally killing a friendly, etc.….lol.  I ended up purchasing a modded follower so that I wouldn’t be judged every 5 minutes.  
[/list]

I feel like these items are enough to hold back recommendation for the game, but now I’ll list what I believe Starfield got right.  

[list]
[*] [b]Fallout 4 / Skyrim in Space[/b]: I think Starfield does a good job at bringing the Bethesda RPG formula into a space environment.  Some of the faction missions and side missions are top notch story telling and the NPCs are done well.  The weapon variety and customization options are very satisfying and are similar to Fallout 4 in that way.    I enjoy looting and searching for “legendary” weapons and armor, and then modifying them to be even better.  You can explore multiple universes, each with multiple planets, and moons. Graphics and sound are amazing.   You can build bases on planets, set up automatic harvesting, automatic storage and automatic shipping.  The amount of stuff that you can do in this game is pretty amazing actually.  
[*][b]Spaceship design[/b]: Starfield allows you to modify and redesign your spaceship, and this aspect of the game is immensely satisfying to me.   The building system has a set of rules that must be followed to validate any changes to your ship, and it is pretty intuitive.  You can choose to change weapons, storage, power reactor, engines, docking port, landing gear, cockpit, bays, etc; Changing these will change the performance characteristics of the ship – which can improve ship combat, storage capability, defense capability, speed, and maneuverability.  You can modify your ship aesthetically so that I looks like Serentiy (on the show Firefly), or the Halo’s Pelican, or the Millennium Falcon – although I wish they continue to add more aesthetic capabilities – I really want to build a Star Trek Bird of Prey – which I would say is not possible at the moment.  I’ll likely spend many more hours just playing around in the ship building area.    
[/list]

With that said, if you are not looking for spaceship simulation, and you are looking for a good space RPG, then you may want to consider picking Starfield when it’s on sale.  For me, Starfield is one of those games that you wish was better, but I still play it every now and then because it is still “fun”.

Most people will take the time to make a detailed review.....No way on this one.  I'm not spending more than 30 seconds reviewing this absolute garbage.  My review 2.5 out of 10 stars.  Just play it and you will understand.  There are fun missions (few and far between) and then there are massive stupid fetch quests.  Go here, talk to someone, now do some inter-planetary travel and talk to someone else.  Now go back to the first person you were talking to which may be a few planets away.  Go through 3-4 stupid responses.  Mash 'A' key on controller to skip, skip, skip!!!!  RU kidding me!?  Game came out in 2024 but must have been developed in the 90's.  WTF on fast travel and interstellar space travel?  Loading screens galore.  Just get me there, I don't need to see my ship take off, sit in space, figure out where you need to go, find the dock, dock, load new screen, exit ship.  ...Am I there?   I almost punched my PC of how bad this game is.  Ship building?  Have you tried this?  It's as intuitive as flying a rocket ship to the moon if you're a plumber. I was in the VIP lounge of some mission out of view of everyone but the entire base starting screaming and running around like I just opened fire on everybody with a machine gun.  I just wanted to kill everyone at that point, so I did....and then it just got worse.  Security force x 100 started spawning everywhere because I punched some dummy.  Pro-tip.  Just hide for 10 minutes somewhere so the AI space force gets off your back.  I kept playing to see if any of those 'fun' missions materialize again....but they don't.  This game just gets worse the more you play.  I'm now lowering my rating from a 2.5 to a 2 out of 10 stars.

Starfield: A Game I’ll Be Playing for a Long Time

I really enjoyed this game. What stood out the most were the countless star systems, each with environments that felt completely different from the others. The companions and the crew at the Lodge also had unique personalities that made the experience even better.

The shooting combat was simple and easy to get the hang of, which made the gameplay smooth. Exploring all the star systems feels like a huge task, though. I didn’t mess around much with Creations, and honestly, the character customization wasn’t anything special for a Bethesda game.
The main storyline was fantastic. The NPCs felt alive, and the missions were different enough to keep things interesting. I also loved the visuals—everything from the settled systems to the design of even the smallest objects was impressive. You can tell a lot of care went into making this world feel real.

The game ran great on my system (I’ll update with my specs later), and I didn’t run into any issues. The main storyline’s length felt just right, and I didn’t feel pressured to go after every achievement or 100% completion.

One thing I really appreciated was how you can build relationships with your companions—they actually felt like people, not just pack mules. The persuasive dialogue options were a cool touch, too, especially if you want to avoid combat. I also liked the personality traits you can choose for your character. I went with the “Dream Home” trait and paid the 120,000 credits for it. Now decorating my home has become one of my favorite things to do in the game.

Compared to other games I’ve played, like The Outer Worlds and Star Citizen, Starfield really stands out. It’s on a whole different level, and I know I’ll be enjoying it for a long time.

I'll offer a solution in front of my criticism.
Introduce an "interdimensional hub", a player home, a cosmic temple, in which every NG cycle will be commemorated on some kind of stone petroglyph, on the walls of the temple. This will serve to tell you what "significant events" did you encounter during that NG cycle and let you track which guilds did you ended up leading, which major characters died, which major decisions you made. And which universe nodes did you even visit.

Furthermore, the hub will serve as a place to store your valuables between NG cycles, preserving your "power level" and "hero fantasy" as you grow ever stronger with each playthrough, just like in Skyrim where you could accumulate power and artifacts for 1000 hours.

Next - Either let us take our ship with us to NG+ (preferred) OR make the Starborne ship as powerful as a fully decked endgame ship, as big, and as useful, so that we won't ever need to build another ship again, unless we want it for the aesthetics. (Reduced toil.)

Next 2 - The Starborne temples of the "Unity", make them bigger, make each one different, treat them more like the Stone Dovah tablets that the Dragonborn had to find - these were guarded by monsters, in varied locations, with puzzles, behind major quests, requiring far travel and tough combat.
While in Starfield each temple is exactly the same, with the same simple (and boring) puzzle, having no challenge behind it, no lore, no beauty - it just has Tedium.

Point 2.5 - reduce the amount of time to maximize the Starborn powers, 10 full cycles is insane and 99% of players won't do it without cheats, also the powers are a let down in their own right, they either break the balance or do nothing, and maximizing them is a terrible waste of the player's time.

Now my criticism, although you got the gist already.
---
Honestly feeling let down and disappointed. Just finished the DLC.
The game is unfinished and shallow.
The core mechanic of "resetting the universe" for NG+ doesn't work for the "Hero fantasy" that Bethesda games were always played for.
This is because NG+ takes away all your items which you've been farming for hours (legendary etc), and your ship which you've been building for hours, and leaves you with nothing to even remember your playthough by.

The world is bleak, the conflict and drama are superficial, the combat is boring, especially when you're swarmed by bullet sponge enemies, totally breaking any immersion. Fallout New Vegas stands high above this game, Oblivion too, Skyrim, Fallout 3, even fallout 4.

I don't necessarily believe that this game can be salvaged and turned into something exciting. It's too shallow and neutral, too bleak, it needs less tedium and more drama. There was like 1 good quest in the game that I found, about a station where 2 times lines were mixed together.

Bonus point - Never liked to build outposts. There is no reward and no incentive, it's boring, it's a chore, and it's pointless. (Ok you farm resources. Really now. And why would you need those in such quantities?)

Del out, see you at TES6 or Fallout 5.

For an engineer like me, it is a good game and i like space exploration theme. As i progress in game, it gets repetitive. When one plays this game, the player must choose a path in this universe. Whether great wealth or great reputation in every faction is the aim you should choose in this game.

It's all of the worst aspects of previous Bethesda entries without any of the things that made those games fun.

The Story is bland and uninteresting, There is no choice, no consequences, no nothing of that sort. I don't know what else to say, It was so boring i had no interest in engaging with it. The writing is amateurish at best, Character motivations make little sense most of the time. Factions are poorly written and uninteresting, and again, do things that just don't make sense in the scenarios presented and the lack of meaningful choice really brings all that to light. One of the notable ones is when you go to the wannabe night city planet to get an artifact back, You can say you'll kill the guy to get it, but the game goes NOPE and proceeds to play out exactly the same as all the other "choices".

The "RPG" mechanics, if you can even call them that anymore, have been stripped down to their most basic possible form, There are no builds to try out, basic mechanics are locked behind perks now. Melee was just ignored by the developers, it has a singular skill, which is just a damage increase, There arent any alternative moves or swings, no strategy, its just swing madly till whatever spongey enemy you're attacking is dead.

The worlds are VAST empty swathes of nothing, with the same handful of copy pasted dungeons scattered around it, I encountered the EXACT same mining tunnel, 5 TIMES IN A ROW ON 5 DIFFERENT PLANETS and when i say they are EXACTLY the same, I mean EXACTLY the same, the loot might have been randomized in the chests, but everything else was exactly the same, one chest in one spot was an expert lock, it was an expert lock in all 5. All the loot lying around on the ground, was the same, enemy placement was the same. People gave skyrim a hard time for its samey dungeons, but at least they were all unique.

The world does not react to your presence or your actions at all, The NPC's in towns have no AI, You can shoot an inch next to their heads and it will not even phase them, They won't move, react, or say anything, nobody will. They're better described as background set pieces youre not meant to interact with, which really sucks, one of my favourite things about bethesda games is messing around with the NPC's in towns and you cannot do any of that in Starfield because the NPC's simply lack any kind of AI beyond their walk cycle.

Space exploration cannot even be called space exploration, You can't fly anywhere, its all done through menus and loading screens. If you were to omit the space flight part of the game entirely, literally nothing would change, which is an extra double bummer as we were sold on the idea we'd actually be able to explore space as well as the spaceflight mechanics being probably the best part of the game. The other thing that irks me is the game calls the map "The Settled Systems" in a game where you're playing as an "explorer". Why am i exploring already explored space? That makes no sense.

Space flight and the ship building mechanic are the best part of this game, Its fun and criminally underutilised. Its complex enough to be interesting, but not so complex like some of the simulator games out there, its a good balance, its just completely pointless as you can't actually fly anywhere.

All in all, its not a good game, you work hard for your money, don't spend it on this, Bethesda doesn't respect you or your time and do not deserve your money. If you want to scratch that itch, go replay skyrim for the 479th time, you'll enjoy it far more than this game.

I think everyone knows [i]Starfield[/i] had some problems when it first dropped; loading screens, stability, an insufficiently developed world . . . the list of complaints was long and deep. I'm not here to say there weren't problems. But I will say that I believe nearly all of them have been solved. And the game we have now is genuinely stunning.

Space opera isn't for everyone. Nor is digital, computer aided roleplaying. But if you enjoy stories like [i]The Expanse[/i] or [i]2001: A Space Odyssey[/i], and you enjoy a good first person CRPG you're quite likely to find [i]Starfield[/i] compelling. There's some real mystery in it, and some real wonder. The game is surprisingly beautiful and the environments, while showing their procedurally generated edges even now, are quite well crafted.
Further, there are moments in the main storyline as sublime as any I've encountered in a video game; moments so engrossing you forget that you're sitting at a computer pointing and clicking at things and lose yourself in the wonder of "What is this?"; the "Eureka!" moment of discovery. And the music interweaves beautifully with the game, pressing you forward to do more, to accomplish more, even, maybe. helping you to figure things out in a quite cinematic way. This game had some real teething problems, but now it has some very sexy, and very dangerous teeth. If it sinks them into you . . . watch out. You'll lose some serious time exploring the [i]Starfield[/i].

It's a good game! The vibe is just a bit... lacking.. compared to other BGS games. But maybe that's just my taste because I'm not a big sci-fi head. Don't make the mistake of exploring random planets like you would for example the big elder scrolls open worlds, you'll probably be disappointed. Do the faction quests and side quests instead to get you hooked and get immersed, then maybe once you understand the formula go explore and look at all the procedurally generated stuff (it aint bad either). 

The companions are as annoying as they were in all of BGS's previous titles, it's just more jarring when they say things completely out of context of the situation or when they trigger every enemy around you when you're trying to sneak, because the rest of the game looks so much better.  I Personally never take any of them with me and the world feels a lot more immersive and believable because of it. 

Those are just my personal gripes about the game. But whenever I start playing this game I find it hard to put it down and there's a LOT to do. There's a lot to love and I don't think it deserves the hate. 

That said I think the ''Creations'' aka paid mods are a scheme.. Bethesda portaits this as a way to pay modders for their work, while actually it's a way for Bethesda to pocket most of that money and also sell their own lackluster DLC's (that should mostly be added for free or at a greatly diminished price) disguising them as mere ''Creations'' while simultaniously baiting you to look at the other (paid) mods on display, all of which I should say are NOT worth the money.

Starfield is a "new" take on the same old Bethesda formula that's been used for over 10 years. Right from the get go you realize that the game design has not advanced at all. The gameplay of this game feels incredibly dated. From the sluggish combat, to the ridiculous jumping and running, to the embarrassingly bad ship combat, everything in this game feels like it could have been done in 2010.

The absolute worst part of Starfield is it's story. The writing shown here is so terrible even compared to some of Bethesda's weaker entries. You start as a miner on a desolate planet and once you pick up a strange artifact, you are forced to join a research group called Constellation. Constellation is such an awful group, and all of the characters in it talk and act like robots. The game wants you to bring them with you as companions, but honestly they're all so annoying and emotionless that I played through the game without ever having any of them with me. Even the villain of the story is just as miserable to have to deal with. 

But what about the artifacts? What is this great mystery that you solve throughout the game? What is your reward for sitting through hours and hours of dialog and tedious repetitive gameplay? A big exposition dump. The final missions of the game try to make you understand how the artifacts came about and what they mean. You go through what is essentially a gallery of the past and learn how space travel was engineered, and then you fight the most boring final boss of all time and the game ends. This is so comically bad that it feels like Bethesda was trying to make this seem like the most boring thing ever.

Starfield was so disappointing for me on so many levels, because it's a concept that has so much potential. Traveling through universes and discovering creatures and people from all different backgrounds is something that should be fun. However, Bethesda made sure that none of it is. From the infinite number of loading screens, to the useless space combat that may as well not even be in the game, ever single part of Starfield is boring and does nothing to innovate on a formula that was outdated almost 10 years ago. This game is not worth your money or your time.

At the beginning, there were few glitches and it was manageable. However, now I can't play at all - as soon as I enter, the game stops. Initially, I thought the problem was with me, but when I tried other games on high settings, it became clear that the issue is with Starfield. This same problem is happening with Fallout 4 as well. You play for hours, enjoy the game, and then it unexpectedly crashes and more. I doubt that Bethesda will work on fixing it based on my past experiences with the company's games. I used to rely on mods for fixes, so wait for updates before buying the game, or else you will regret spending $70

Honestly, feels like a pretty solid modern RPG. I feel that most of the hate it receives is absolutely overblown, and while some of it may be valid (some corners of the overall experience feel about as shallow as Hearthfire's homestead building), this is a very solid modern RPG experience. I don't personally love the NASA-punk aesthetic, but by golly is the NG+ system just perfect for returning to the game after multiple periods of rest.

Starfield is not without it's bugs and issues, but if you can see past these there is an awesome game here worth exploring. This is my ideal game of space exploration (open world/planet format), ship building, faction(s) reputation, and depth of story content. The DLC Shattered Space expands the universe and should be considered if you are a fan of Starfield.

I'd say Starfield is decent enough for a positive review, but I recommend getting it on sale. I liked the companions the most but felt like navigation between star systems could be tedious at times.

Positives:
+Combat is fast-paced
+NPC/Companion storytelling is probably the best compared to Bethesda's other games
+Companion affinity progresses just by doing missions with them, but you still get Like/Dislike points from conversations like Fallout 4
+More build options/perk choices integrated into some quest progression

Negatives:
-There doesn't feel like much reason to explore planets/systems outside of quests
-Traveling to systems without quests (which allow you to quickly select destinations when active) can be tedious
-Inventory space (personal and ship) can feel limiting without perks if you want to explore a planet and hoard resources
-Planets can feel a bit bland and without purpose at times
-There is a LOT of downtime between fights; this could be a positive to some since it does include a bit more story
-Early leveling feels slow

[h2]Summary:[/h2]
I can see that a lot of work clearly went into this game, but it's glaringly obvious that either, or both
[olist]
  [*]Bethesda was not making a video game; they were making the template of one, by which they could sell you mods via microtransactions to fill out the husk.  
  [*]Nobody working on this title knows what makes a video game actually fun, or engaging, or enjoyable to play. 
[/olist]

Support from updates, consideration for modders early on (lul), and managing to deliver a solid DLC may have been enough to save the game if they had made major course-corrections in their launch window, but Bethesda seems to only be capable of doubling down when confronted by their community, and then following it up by providing further proof of their incompetence. It's looking like the ship may have sailed, unfortunately.

If you're on the fence, or got FOMO, I would recommend just picking up game pass for a month first instead, to see if you can sate your curiosity, get bored, and check back out. You may end up saving yourself some cash. Otherwise, wait for a deep discount of [i]maybe[/i] $35. 

--Full review below--

[h1]A Bethesda RPG only in name.[/h1]

It can be fun if you want to wander in a sci-fi space setting and halfway pay attention for a long time. 
I play this game to get sleepy.

The problem this game faces is that, at every possible opportunity, there are parts of gameplay that will suck you out of the world, just as soon as you feel you might actually be starting to be immersed or connect with... [i]anything[/i] in it.
[list]
  [*]Non-insignificant amounts of tedium
  [*]The graphics range from gorgeous to potato, and everything between, but the optimization has been (and continues to be [even though it has been improved]) hot trash, so you're likely going to have to heavily rely on upscaling, and then still get persistent framedrops that you can't really do anything about in most of the main city areas, which you have to spend time in for the main quests, because even the best CPU's in the world (7800X3D-9800X3D) can only manage an almost consistent 120 fps. My 7600X tops out in the 80's, which -don't get me wrong- is very playable, but if you're someone that usually opts for high framerates, the headroom just isn't there, and in demanding (read: unoptimized) areas you still run the risk of it bringing you out of VRR territory, unless you have a monster build [b]or[/b] you kick on frame-gen.
  [*]There are so many characters that seem like they should be cool and compelling, but the writing is so laughably bad and shallow that you just want them to go away. All of them.
  [*]The guns generally look and feel nice, and the sound design is pretty alright, however, upon further inspection, you'll notice that these are guns that were clearly designed by people who don't know how guns work; and not in like a "sci-fi write-off" kinda way either. Like, these firearms just don't make physical, mechanical sense. I'm not like a gun-nut either. This is the first time I've ever actually been distracted by how nonsensical the guns function in a video game. How do the people in charge of making gun models and animations not know how a shotgun slide works??? That's like 101-level stuff.
  [*]Space ship flying and building is really cool, until you realize that spaceships are usually just a portal to your loading screens. You can fight pirates, shoot rocks, or initiate loading screens.
  [*]Planetscapes can be beautiful, but they are quite empty. I was pretty okay with that, until I realized that every landmark on a planet that actually [i]is[/i] there, is just a copy/paste assortment of prefabs and POI's from a basket of like 20, all spread out about 500 meters from one another. And this shouldn't be a problem. The way the system is designed leaves so much potential for this wealth of surprise, unique POI's at a consistent pace. I don't get why you'd design the game to randomly generate stuff like this, and then not leverage it to keep a consistent stream of surprises for the player. One of the major benefits of designing it this way is that it gives the devs so much control over pacing, but like just about everything else in this game, the potential goes to waste. The rover goes a long way to alleviate the problem, but it doesn't solve the lack of variety. If anything, I imagine it just speeds up the amount of time before you've "seen it all".
  [*]Quests range from neat to meh. Nothing to write home about. They all essentially exist to make you go "wow, yeah. space is cool... and dangerous... uh-huh". There were some fun little moments here and there, but just never enough to feel worth my time.
  [*]Crafting and basebuilding... *sigh* Yeah, it's there, alright. Some of the systems are streamlined, some are [b]not[/b]. If you are the type of person that likes making mega bases just to generate one schmillion gargletite, and intricately link your gens and cargo tanks so that it can be distributed to planet Zornon, for no other reason than to get it there, then sure: I imagine you might possibly enjoy this part - and, come to think of it, maybe even this whole game.
[/list]

I bought this game, like many of you, because I had grown up on Bethesda games. But whatever good this company had left years ago. This game was the most vapid experience I've ever received from a developer of this size. After going back and playing Morrowind, I realize that Todd hasn't had a new idea in over two decades. He lives and dies off the work of others and their ideas. If this game truly was his magnum opus, it is akin to Megalopolis. Shit, they can't even come up with new music. They rehash old systems and somehow make them worse. They give you less and freedom or choice. The game lacks any human input. Most of the game is random generated places, that are really just the same few places mixed around. It is a slap in the face to any fan of any of their franchises. You are one of the richest companies ever and you can't even pay other people to make a good game anymore. If Bethesda ever releases another game before I die, I will not be purchasing it. But, I imagine the company will go under before they ever release another project. They could just continue to live off the works of their subsidiary studios, but they too are a subsidiary, so I imagine William Gates might give Todd the boot.

I’m writing this review with just over 20 hours into this game, but it feels like 100. Starfield is an  endless slog through a galaxy devoid of personality.  

To start, character creation is well done. You are able to design just the right appearance for your character and will likely spend a good deal of time doing so. It is a bright spot in a game with too few of them.  

Once your PC is created, you enter a soulless world of planets. The random NPCs that populate the cities appear to have been designed by random generation from each possible option in the character creation menus. They wander aimlessly, at zombie-like pace, and stare at you bug-eyed as you walk past. Most don’t even have names, just “citizen.” Style is gone in the future, as their outfits are shapeless and boring. 

Conversations with everyone, whether they are random or part of the main quest, are the equivalent of those that you would have at a corporate staff meeting. They are short, superficial and extremely polite. There are typically three dialogue choices for the PC in every conversation - a polite vanilla response that keeps the quest moving; a humorless, snarky comment; and a third that asks for more information. The option to keep the quest moving is typically the best, because the snarky comment is ridiculous and more information from any NPC is never that interesting. City guards occasionally make rude, unsolicited comments regarding your background. Persuasion is baffling. A persuasion situation can appear to be going your way only to fail for reasons that I still don’t understand. Also, persuasion situations allow the NPCs to continue a conversation, which becomes more banal as it progresses.

The User Interface is cumbersome. Moving around requires multiple stick movements and button pushing. Also, it is difficult to compare items and their usefulness. Normally I do not like to mod a game until I have played through it first, but I did download a UI mod from the nexus just to eliminate the frustration of the existing UI. 

Finally - Gameplay.  The Main Quest is tedious and, as far as I played, represents a series of fetch quests. I did not join any faction because the “Faction Recruiters” were unexciting in their offer. I tried ship modifications, weapon and suit modifications and research - but there was nothing fun about it. Combine a couple of things, press a button and there you have it. I got to the point where I just didn’t want to do much because the “reward” didn’t match the burdensome slog of obtaining the necessary items. Even the cities are so poorly designed that you don’t really want to explore them. I mean, it is the future. If we want to speak with someone, don’t they have a mobile phone? If we need supplies, doesn’t anyone deliver? 

So, overall, I cannot recommend this game. I am going to continue to play on and off as I really want to like this game. I think I will try to investigate and download some mods and start another playthrough, seeing if the mods help. It may be great in a couple of years, but right now, it is just a time dump.

Short version:
If this was released 10 years ago it would be great, now its just an average game that will make you feel bored quickly. Why? Because it has nothing really unique to offer unfortunatelly.

Long version:

Visuals: The best part of the game. I love it all. Planets, ships, people, weapons, buildings, nature  all of it.
Audio: The worst part of the game. There are so many different sound effects that it blends into one awful noise. Music is average, voices are ok.

Gameplay: As a proffessional analyst, amateur programmer and a veteran game player (understand, since Golden Axe and such lmao) I do not consider technical bugs a big deal. It happens, it should not with budged like they have but I am more concerned about the game it self anyways. 
 Even as mentioned I play games since ever, I was always a guy who need to play at the lowest difficulty as I am really poor at gaming. So that was really big surprise to find out that the main story and many many other quests can be done without spending one single skill point. In many ways, the skill tree looks pretty useles. What you can not do you hire a crew memeber for it, what you can not manufacture you buy it. So the main RPG feature (leveling a character) is unimportant, which is crazy. Next they say this is exploring game. Well I do not consider visiting same looking places with different names exploring. They call it FPS. Well I spend more time to actually get into a shooting than the shooting lasts. 

 What I really miss and what i expected from new game like this one is this: 
 I expect that when i join a faction i can progress through the hierarchy and come to the top and each rank will give me some advantages or new options (quests, arms,..., whatever). I expect my actions will do some reactions with the world, if i join someone, somebody else will hate me for it and such. There are different factions in the game but you dont really rank up and it does not affect the world around you. 
 I do expect that every character is killable as it was in Arena or Daggerfall too i think. And if the character was necessary for some mission so let happen with the mission something. End it, or allow the mission to start with another character or open the possibility of starting a brand new missions and so on. 
 I do expect all actions will have consequencies. This is way too linear and BORING. 
 I do expect to have some market in such game. With goods, arms, real estate, whatever. 
 I do expect that if i attack big producer of iron it price will go up and will be difficult to buy and if i protect a planet producing foods, they will be abundant everywhere and so on. (consequencies)

That is a bit of my expectations. This game is worse than Skyrim in many aspects despite it has all the conditions and premises to be the GOAT of all games.

I've never written a Steam review before, but I felt like I had to with this game. I don't think I can say you shouldn't play this game... its a big Bethesda title with a lot going for it. I think everyone should take a chance and experience it for themselves. I knew what the reviews said before I bought it (I waited til it was 50% off) but I couldn't not try it always wondering whether I would feel the same way.

BUT

That being said, I COMPLETELY agree with the large majority of reviews and feedback from the rest of the community. The game has an interesting main story and builds on (or recycles, call it what you will) a lot of the RPG mechanics seen in previous titles like Skyrim and Fallout. I liked the combat overall and some quests were really enjoyable.

However, right up until the end when I uninstalled this early today, I was forever frustrated with the complex multiple-layered menus, immersion breaking loading screens and boring exploring component. There are so many unnecessary complexities, too many key binds, etc.

Most AAA RPG quests involve some combination of "talk to quest giver > travel to place > combat > fetch item/information > return to quest giver". In Skyrim, part of what made it great is you get to "travel to place" and before you know it, you've come across some random cave, or found a beautiful village, or a fort with enemies to distract you, or you speak to the guy in the pub on your way out and wake up in the temple of Dibella with no memory of how you got there...

Starfield doesn't have that. When you land on a planet you have to consciously seek out places of interest if you're going to see anything (and even them most of them are cookie cutter locations like 'abandoned mine' or 'thermal pools' - to the point where the enemies and clutter are in the exact same locations). I also got so sick of the menus and 5+ loading screens just to get into my ship I resorted to hold the 'fast travel to quest marker' button every time I wasn't where I needed to be. The fact that button exists shows the developers realised they needed a faster way around the fact they weren't able to build a game that allowed seamless travel between quests. In reality, there just isn't a lot out in space that is exciting.

These issues extend into all the other features they built into this, like the outpost building, equipment upgrades, research etc, which were so painful to progress because of the sheer number of different resources required conflicting with the low carrying capacity. I get to my outpost only to realise I don't have some random item needed to build something and find out I'll need to progress through a bunch of cut scenes/loading screens, shop vendor menus etc to get the item and back again - it is not worth the hassle or the time.

I also played this game immediately after HFW which was such a beautiful open world, great characters and stories, and while it is a very different sort of title, really highlighted the level of quality and detail I feel is lacking in Starfield.

Call me a Bethesda sheep - I REALLY wanted to like this game. I really wanted it to be immersive and repeatable (NG+ is sort of forced on you at the end of the main quest line). But at the end of the day its something I glad I played once, just to know I never need to play it again.

"How do you play a game for so long and give it a negative review? "

is something I would always ask myself, then I sunk 100 hours into Starfield and understood.

I regret playing this much. Andrea was the only upside, but BGS goes down each new game. At this rate, Skyrim will suck unless they bring new blood into leadership and remove the OGs.

Honestly not bad. Performance is unacceptable on a 4070ti. sub 60fps in a barren, boring plaza area with almost nothing going on is just ridiculous. Game isn't even bad I actually have fun when the game is running in acceptable framerates.

At first the negative reviews kept me away thinking this wasn't that great.  However, after watching so videos about Starfield, I decided to give it a try and honestly I was not disappointed as far as a game goes for me.  I haven't really had any large bugs or game breaking experiences as of yet.  The game has been fun and entertaining for me so far.

My Pros for this game are:

 - A pretty good amount of planets and systems to explore and survey
 - Building and Customizing your own space ship. (Gain certain skills to unlock unique ship parts)
 - Build your own outpost like base on a planet.
 - No planet maps are really the same and locations on planets are randomly placed depending on where you choose to land
 - Space Pirates and the chance to become a space pirate in the game


Some of my Cons for this game are:

 - Life on planets should be more abundant and diverse.
 - Its way too easy to make money in the game early on.
 - Weapon customization and diversity seem to be lacking.
 - Some modules for ship building should be able to rotate to give better ship customization

Overall, this game is fun and if Space RPG is your genre, then give this a try.  
 - I have not used mods as of yet, so my review is purely on the Vanilla game experience.
not as good as fallout but its good

When I went into Starfield on release, I was expecting something more like No Mans Sky or Star Citizen with a Bethesda twist, I thought space exploration was going to play a much bigger part than it did, only to realise the "Space Sim" aspect of the game is essentially cut scenes of space travel, I was left very disappointed and decided to uninstall. Not to mention the game was running so poorly, it was borderline unplayable. I was getting 20FPS in New Atlantis on LOW SETTINGS!?

After seeing some much needed updates recently with the addition of the rover and some graphical optimisation, I reinstalled and the game runs SOOO much better! I'm hitting my monitors refresh rate in most places (165hz) with slight dips in New Atlantis (around 80fps) on HIGH, it's now in a playable state to enjoy.

It's nice to see some (mostly free) content added by Bethesda in the Creations menu also; (new quests, another new vehicle that has a missile launcher, ships, interiors, weapons, armour, outpost furniture)

If you were disappointed, like me on release. I would highly recommend giving Starfield another go.

Hopefully they can redeem themselves similar to how No Mans Sky and Cyberpunk did.

[h1]As a modder, this is one of my favorite releases in the past decade. [/h1]
[h3]As a player, I would be more conflicted.[/h3]
Oblivion, my favorite Bethesda game, launched with game-breaking bugs and to this day suffers from a save-game bug that will cripple your character save and render it unplayable. This issue persists almost two decades later.

Skyrim, closing in on fifteen (15!!) years since launch [11/11/11] had similar issues - Bethesda overpromises, underdelivers, but the open world and customization options provided by the Creation Kit (or GECK, for the Fallout fans) allow for a nigh infinitely customizable experience. TES VI will likely be met by a similarly critical eye - justifiably so, mind you.

That being said, there are no space games on the market that allow for the breadth and depth that Starfield permits. Star Wars games, solid or not, keep you bottled up in that universe. The Outer Worlds, a game from the Obsidian team that brought you F:NV, faced problems not unlike Bethesda, where the scope of their goal crept out of their reach throughout the dev cycle. Starfield, being created through an unprecedented global pandemic, ran into similar problems.

These several paragraphs serve to contextualize the game itself. It faced close to Half Life 3 levels of hype, and could only disappoint (peep GTA VI when it drops). CDPR faced similar challenges when it hyped up CP2077 (a rig-melting garbage heap with the skeleton of a good story/world underneath at launch, now touted as an elite cyberpunk RPG{still clunky, but buy it}).
Is it a perfect game? Absolutely not. Is it a good space exploration FPS? Yep, let's ride, space cowboy.
_____________________________________________________

The characters? Moderate to insufficient depth.
The world? Decent, plot holes if you think about the science too much, but it's space fantasy.
The gunplay? Bethesda bullet sponges still exist, but the base gameplay is alright.
The story? "You're the Dragonborn/the one from my dreams/the Sole Survivor/etc". It's cookie-cutter Bethesda protagonist. 
The polish? Surprisingly good in some areas, lacking in others. 
The updates? We got buggies for driving, and space serpent cults for finding. 7/10
----------------------------------------------------------
I liked it, then when they let us loose with Creation Kit 2, I loved it. A space playground with all the hard work done? We don't have to build a space game, we can just use the knowledge from previous Bethesda mods to change this one to our hearts' content? Hell yeah. It can be anything you want.

[h2]Verdict? [/h2]
It's fun, albeit flawed. But if you flip the release order with Skyrim, we're here arguing over the Hearthfire DLC and the amount of bugs it introduced. I grew up on the early 00's games, and everything nowadays is a marvel of technology compared to what I had to work with as a kid. It's like turning a kid who had one box of standard Legos loose in the primary Lego store. So maybe the jaded attitude coupled with my age has led me to enjoy this experience more than one should. 
I would recommend it with reservations, but Steam continues with the binary Yes/No options instead of a sliding scale. Therefore, given those parameters as options, [b]I will cautiously endorse Starfield.[/b]

Its super duper grindy for a Bethesda game. You can complete the game playing through twice, but not hit all the achievements. Overall an enjoyable game. Discover planet, clear dungeon, repeat. A solid five out of seven.

A very light "Yes." I've long been a Bethesda defender and I enjoy Starfield quite a lot, but it lacks too much of what makes their game so special to a larger audience. I respect taking a big swing, and it succeeds at a lot of things, but I feel creeping dread about TES VI.

40 hours in, I loved it. The onboarding was very rough though, but I still would have recommended it. I loved the ship building more than expected and it is a gorgeous game. But then about 70 hours in, I got more fed up with the glitches (had a save get corrupted somehow), repetitive gameplay, and the ending was so frustrating. I have never seen the ending of a game be so hard to finish. Usually there is an apex and drama, but the "unintuitiveness" of this game ruined it. I just wanted to finish the game and spent an hour reading other people's frustrated posts to figure out what was wrong with mine. I think they overpromised and underdelivered. Had the game been 50% of what it was and they just focused on that, it would have been phenomenal.

I did my first playthrough at launch, and like everyone else, I hated my experience. Then, a year later, I gave the game another chance, and I don't know why, but it clicked. Now, I could say I’m kind of a Starfield fan? Weird, I know...

Is Starfield the best game ever? No. Is it the best Bethesda game ever? No, not even close. But that said, Starfield is a unique experience. It’s great when you accept it for what it is and play it for what it has to offer. It’s a relaxing game, and you can see the Bethesda magic behind all its flaws. It’s weirdly appealing, and if you let yourself immerse in its universe, it’s kind of cute. Maybe I’m getting older, and slower-paced games like Starfield appeal to me more, but I don’t know. It has its charm and its magic.

I was once on the side of saying Bethesda should cut their losses and give up on Starfield, but now I’m on the complete opposite side. I hope they continue updating and adding content to it. It’s a fun universe to be in. It’s not a grand, epic adventure; it’s more like a morning coffee—just a warm, comforting experience. This game might not have had the greatest direction, but it was made with love.

The faction quests are more fun, and interesting to me than the main story. I do really enjoy the ship-building, and ship customization options. The game is a solid 3.5/5.

3.1 out of 5. 
Wish there was a neutral option. Has much of the expected Bethseda Jank, with new annoyances added by some of the UI decisions. Every good aspect is overshadowed by the annoyances inherent in some design decisions. such as how easy it is to accidentally take tons of gear from your ship inventory by interacting with the cargo pannel instead of opperating the way past titles did. The extra option are obnoxious and seemed designed to mess you about when you do things by the instinct you built up with their past titles. Also the "press vs hold" button design is a pain as you can press a button, have nothing happen, then you hold it down and it makes you get up from the pilot chair in the middle of combat.
If you can look past these, there is a bunch of stuff to do, but don't expect the game to grant you full agency. Some things that should be able to be bypassed by Persuasion checks don't seem to be, and the the skill system seems to be deliberately obtuse, so you have to fumble around with your precious skill points to try and figure out what lets you do what you want to.
Writing isn't as bad as some say, and not as good as others say. 
Overall, it isn't bad per se, but it does feel like it is in need of major overhauls to make it less irksome.
I am trying to like this game, I really am, but it is so hard to do so when every few minutes i have to wrestle the UI to do what i want.

-Requires modern hardware to streamline load screens, and present accurate lighting.

EXAMPLE:   "Hey aren't you that guy that flew in on the ship"  "I KNEW it!  I was right about you being the guy that flew in on the ship!"  "Is it your ship?"  "Really"  "I just can't believe it's you!"   "I've been looking all over for you, and recognized the ship as it came into the port.  I noticed the color and call signs and was like, Hey I think that's them!"  Turned out I was right, and now I can finally ask you what I've been traveling all this way for.  "But before that let me just congratulate you on landing your ship here in front of me."

Guy could have just said:  "Thank the stars you finally landed!  I need to talk to you!"  For all I know they just asked AI to take what they were saying and just make it use more words.  So strange and lazy.  I'm getting tired of hearing the question "Is that right? or Really?"  I feel like Dr Evil in his frickin electric chair responding to Frau Farbissina while she says "REALLY" over and over.   JUST SPIT OUT WHAT YOU WANT TO SAY FRAU!  Throw me a frickin bone here.  Scotty use the big boy voice ok?

Skyrim I turn off subtitles so I can get immersed, Starfield I turn them on so I can skim over all the crap.

Why am I playing this game?  I love exploring, scanning, traveling.  I like walking/flying around on a ship I customized.  I love the graphics.  I love digging through space stations for loot.   I like crafting weapons and gear.  I like bounty hunting, mining, building.  I like not having game breaking bugs.

That being said, I would actually go crazy playing this game if I couldn't skip redundant dialogue.  I've lost count of how many times I've actually said out loud "OMG get to the point."  Even for stories I was interested in.  Just sad that I have to power read so much fluff to get to story.  I know I'm exaggerating a point, but I do find it fun to poke at the dialogue a bit.

I avoided this game for a year because I assumed that the overwhelmingly negative response meant that it was some unacceptably broken release like Cyberpunk 2077 or something.

I finally picked it up on a sale and after 60 hours of playtime imagine my surprise when...it's a totally normal Bethesda game.

This game is not broken. It's not empty. It's not overly-infested with loading screens. Does it feel a bit out of date as an AAA game? Sure, but anyone playing a Bethesda game knows and is [presumably] okay with that. It's a modest technical and graphical improvement over Fallout 4 that has a similar amount of hand-made locations, a huge bevvy of side quests that vary in quality, and tons of flavor text to find that flesh out the world. The addition of a really fun ship-building mechanic is a lovely bonus that I've sunk a ton of time into.

Procedurally generated content and New Game Plus exist on top of what is a fully complete game in order to give career grinders and replayers a bit of extra spice in their playthroughs. Expecting those things to be as fleshed out and detailed as the totally normal-sized base game is, frankly, absurd. All the people leaving vitriolic reviews over that stuff should be ashamed of themselves for getting so upset at a problem of their own making. [b]It's like getting a second cherry on your ice cream sundae and complaining that it didn't come with a whole second sundae.[/b]

Do you want a normal Bethesda RPG in a NASA-punk setting with a bit more grounded of lore than Fallout and Elder Scrolls? This game is for you.

Ugh... can't believe it took me this long to come to this conclusion. Yes, the memes were right, this IS Oblivion in space.
So, TL;DR: If you're someone who enjoys NotSerious™ gaming, have some fun with this (especially with mods and [i]especially[/i] with amazing creations like that Star Wars-themed total conversion modlist), but FOR THE LOVE OF ZAPHRAM COCHRANE GET IT ON SALE.

Because this result of scope creep is the perfect example of what's wrong with AAA gaming these days, but somehow still manages to be an insult to it.
After comparing it to other space adventure games like Star Wars Outlaws, No Man's Sky and the great indie game Everspace 2, after comparing it to another recent Western ShooteRPG, Cyberpunk 2077, and especially after comparing it to the over fifteen years old Western Space ShooteRPG Mass Effect, I've concluded that this game is so unacceptably outdated and limited in its design, it would be funny if it weren't so sad.
Oblivion in Space WOULD have been great... If it had released around the time Oblivion released.
Yeah, Bethesda, it's great that you have a whole galaxy arm's worth of accurately modeled and scaled planets... BUT THERES NOTHING TO DO ON EM.
The atmosphere (or lack thereof [GET IT?? GET IT?? SPACE PUN!! HAAAAA FUNI... iamgoinginsanepleasesendhelp]) and level of detail, as well as worldbuilding are [i]chef's kiss[/i] too, but again, this is a video GAME. Not an interactive education program on what space colonization might look like! I want things to do beyond
"Go to this planet, talk to that guy, shoot a bunch of those guys, pick up that thing (in the same copy-pasted structures and spaceships over and over again), fly away, grav jump and repeat."
And it's not like that can be blamed on the hard sci-fi setting, you can still come up with stuff.

In retrospect, Bethesda's Devlogs on this game show what really went wrong: Yeah, cool that you know and care about the nonsense that players get up to in your games, but those things are fun precisely BECAUSE they're not part of the intentional design.
Ultimately, it feels like Bethesda were overconfident in their ability to create beloved RPGs based on massive worldbuilding, made a massive sci-fi world, then forgot that they were making a video game.

I've never posted a review of a game on steam in my life. They say "if you like Skyrim, it's more of the same", except Skyrim wasn't un-laughably boring and had a level of handcrafted care. Bethesda should work in PR and PR alone because I don't know how so many people (including me) got tricked again. It wastes the player's time and then calls those time wastes "mechanics". I would understand a level of tedium in a resource management game, but everything regarding resource management is so half baked. 

"Space is supposed to be empty, that's what makes it so immersive":

1. I'm not going to Space, I'm playing a Video Game
2. There's nothing immersive about a loading screen
3. Not once did I feel like an explorer, because everyone has seemingly discovered everything JUST or RIGHT AFTER you get there
4. The emptiness does nothing to serve the game's Sandbox claims because there is little meaningful variety in player choice (What if we made Fallout NV's class system and Fallout 4's melee combat SUCK?)

"Gamers want shorter games":

Gamers want engaging games, regardless of length. I don't know how the entire quest is based on looping over and over, and barely anything changes. You can literally feel the ones and zeros of each new universe's variants, and somehow you very rarely can change the outcome of any quests based on previous universe's knowledge. Also how short can y'all claim it is if there's 1000+ planets and like 9 of them are fun.

If you just want to turn your brain off and play a silly little game there's a lot of good stuff (ship building, base building, standard Bethesda quests, etc.) but beware that not only are those things done better in several other games, but done better in previous BETHESDA games.

It exists almost solely for the people who are looking to share silly anecdotes with their friends and not think much further (see HMS Platypus)

"I just killed the space pope while running away from the Glupporpians in the Spoobeep System"

I genuinely wish I had the patience and imagination to make that gameplay experience somehow feel more fun than that sentence. AND I admire those of you who are truly getting the bang for your buck, but I didn't spend ~44 hours playing this game because I thought it was fun. I genuinely was confused as to when it would get good and left with the feeling,

"I guess that's it!"
I first didnt like Starfield, because it was sold to me as "Skyrim in space". But its nothing like Skyrim. It is a totally different game.

I originally completed this game on Xbox and loved every minute of it. The story, sidequests, all of it. 9/10 experience for me. Many people have hated on it since launch, but I loved it from the beginning. That and the New Game + implementation is probably the best I have ever seen in a game. Fast forward to me getting a new PC a little over a year ago, and this game just became a whole new level of amazing with some simple mods implemented, along with the updates they implemented. Completely changes the game IMO. 10/10, but only because 10 is the highest I can give. Amazing experience.

What do I say,
I was initially pretty hyped about this game but after playing for some time I have to admit, it just feels so generic and extremely boring. There's nothing special about it and at some point the game literally just feels like a ginormous walking simulator, which is one of the reasons that lead me to drop the game before even finishing it.
The only way it shines is through interesting small details like some cool and sometimes funny side missions you can pick up, but sadly that's about it. Please spend your money on something else!

The critics are right: This is Fallout 4 reskinned to be a space game. If you're reading reviews, you probably know you can make your own ship and outposts, they've added a buggy, and there's very little use of actually flying the ship. Space combat is semi rare, and travel from planet to planet or star to star is just a loading screen. Anything outside of actual landmarks are procedurally generated, so alot of repetition on the worlds. I have counted as many as 4 loading screens in traveling from one spaceport to another by actually getting in your ship, navigating to a star, navigating to a landing site and leaving the ship. Or you can just fast travel from place to place after initial discovery like any bethesda game.

All that said: I liked fallout and elder scrolls, so I'm having a great time in this game. It also had so much more potential if they'd just come off that formula a little bit to make the "space" part of the space game a larger part of the game.
One of the best sci-fi games ever made. A must-play for those who seek a great open-world shooter RPG.

Very large open world(s) format, lots to explore, lots of stuff to collect to craft the items you need for your journey, but the basic games story-line is a bit boring to be honest.  I'm only a short way thru the basic games story, it's going to take a long time. Wonder if I'll bore of the grind? 

It's a very slow grind to level up, so far the best way I've found is to scavenge enough basic items to do some basic crafting and then hock your created items to vendors, and if your lucky you come across some pirates to eliminate for a bit of extra XP along the way.

There is no sense of wonder or exploration. Traveling is done through menus, fast travel and loading screens, or a shitty-to-drive-crashes-into-pebbles buggy. The dialog is absolutely first draft quality. The persuasion checks are a prime example of placeholder text. It would break immersion if there was any to be found. The story and combat are ok but unremarkable. the harder enemies are only harder because they're bullet sponges. You get fairly unremarkable magic abilities that you could beat the game without. It takes about 12 hours to get to the "main story" and, if you lasted that long, you might have fun for about 2 more hours.Most missions involve going through about 7 doors or elevators and/or a couple of flights. All involving loading screens. and a few short movies. The ship building is ok but you can't place doors so you get dead ends. The outpost building is a huge step back from Fallout 4's limited building. At least that had settlers. All I can do is staff my space office space. There's no terramorphing or tunneling into that mountain or building near Points of Interest or aquatic settlements and the settlement size and budget are too small for complicated (or fun) builds.
 I have heavily modded it to be a 5/10. Even the mod support isn't close to other bethesda games.
 I am in a gaming rut and i hate myself, that is why i have put in over 400 hours. 
Don't buy this shit.
