poopoo game

Starfield really shows how much Bethesda relied on existing lore and IP to prop up their games. Without a long history of lore and worldbuilding like Fallout and Elder Scrolls, Starfield has nothing to offer. The setting is shallow, the writing is juvenile and poorly thought out, and systems like outpost building or ship dogfights are so optional there's no reason to participate even if you enjoy those systems. The one thing I can praise Starfield for is being the most stable and least buggy game Bethesda has put out.

Starfield puts all of Bethesda's weaknesses on display while removing their strength - world design. Many people have mentioned how barren the planets are or that you'll be running the same prefab dungeons over and over, but forget that, you're going to be spending most your time in menus and loading screens just trying to travel around.

For the love of god, hire writers, stop shunting the role onto your quest designers.
Favorite part is the space ship building and fighting.
More than 250 hours played and most of that was spent doing the same things again and again and again and again.

[i]„You can’t fast travel  while you’re jumping in the air“ [/i]
and other funny quotes from Starfield. Well, let’s wrap this up:

I somehow finally finished the game and overall I wouldn’t recommend it if you’re not a Bethesda Fangirl. (And even then...)

Why? 

[b]Story:[/b]
- The game fails to set up a meaningfull and engaging plot. The first few hours are nice. You start as a miner and eventually get to know the people of Constellation: Explorers who want to get to know the universe better and apparently collect some Artifacts, one which you already stumbled upon. But it gets worse after that.. 
In Skyrim you are thrown into a conflict between civil war and dragons, in Fallout 4 you are on a quest of revenge, in Fallout 3 you’re looking for your father. Here… All that drove me was my curiosity – and a lot of loading screens on a spacemap (which really doesnt make things easier). 
The plot immediatly turns into a very basic „fetch the artifacts“ quest after a while. You don’t get more insight into what they are or who made them. 
There is little tension in the plot. The Starborn attack you (apparently) out of boredom. When one of your friends is killed this is the only part where things got a „little“ bit emotional, but on the other side it also felt hollow because you lost them for nothing other than the fact that Starborn exist. You learn nothing, you’re just left finding the other Artifacts. My problem is that none of the other factions are involved – no one but Constellation cares about Starborn, not even New Atlantis after they were attacked by the Hunter. Wtf? the main plot feels like it exists separate from all the faction quests (none of which have any influence on anything).

Spoilers ahead: [Spoiler]It’s a multiverse story with the goal to leave this universe (because of boredom.. or curiosity.) I find multiverse plots difficult because it makes the events of the current time and being feel irrelevent. Sooner or later it becomes very obvious that nothing you are doing that isnt Starborn related narratively matters.. so why bother helping Andeja with her side quest at all?
There is also no resolution in the end oft he game. You never find out who made the Artifacts, what they are or why you get powers through them. (The powers feel terribly copied from Skyrim, too.. really Bethesda, first I am a Dragonborn and now a Starborn?) 
 
It would have been sooo much more enthralling if the writers had used some of their further introduced factions to fight over the Artifacts and not the Starborn. Imagine the Va’Ruun wanting the artifacts because they thought the Armillary would create a doorway to the Serpent? [/Spoiler]

Iit would have been even gripping (not even us, the player) would KNOW what the Artifact actually do: The final revelation would have been a surprise to everyone! 

The faction quests could have mattered at this point – and to our companions, too! 
By the way, those always felt out of place..
Apart from a few very inappropriate moments in which the companions were annoying (I'm currently in the middle of a fight against a fat terramorph but Andreja really wants to talk to me about her family! Really? ) they felt like something Bethesda added to have at least some part of bonding going on. but they really just seem like programmed robots that run after you and shoot every now and then.

[b]Writing in general (Characters/other quests):[/b]

I couldn’t really enjoy the faction quests, even though I never had problems with that in other Bethesda games. Starfield just never hits a button. I’ll take the Crismon Fleet Questline as an example because I think it could have had so much more potential!  

The characters in the Crismon Fleet are pirates – and they could have been charismatic rogues, laughingly planning clever break-ins. They could have been people who had to deal with their past and had mistakes but also some heartfelt moments that made them real. Or they could have made them anarchists, fighting against the expanding system. Following a charsmatic leader that promised them a better political system.. 
But instead Bethesda chose to make them assholes. In a pathetic way. People who only care about money and greed. They are portrayed as people who just insult each other and I kept wondering why everything isn't just blowing up here. 
In the end you have to choose how you deal with them.. but the way they are shown is that much black and white that it the choice here was easy. A pitty! I would have liked to become a space pirate so much!

Other than that the quests feel so.. unrelevant? Most of them are fetch quests and I rarely encountered meaningful people. Everybody feels so copied or “made up”. 

The cities are not very unique, too. Neon is a very very bad copy of Night City, New Atlantis is as interesting as very diluted peppermint tea (and not remarkable at all), Akila city COULD be in a Star Wars pilot episode.. if it were to be taken more serious, because the "danger" everyone always talks about there is but a few biting kangaroos on level 4.

After a while I realised all the quests that were thrown at me were meaningless „get me xy“ quests which made exploring the universe so much less fun. 

[b]Other things that made me dislike the game:[/b]

+ Ship combat. Like a super bad 3D simulation at the fair. Ship upgrades are expensive, tiring, and somewhat annoying to obtain. I avoided the space combats as much as possible.
And who decided that it was okay to put “E” for hail (another ship) and “press E slightly a longer time” to stand up and leave the cockpit ON THE SAME KEY? The cutscene for that is incredibly long and my ship was blasted more then two times during that. Well.. maybe I’m not cut out to be a captain.

+ Explanations:  ship building, upgrading..was something I had to find out for myself. 

+ My crew only stood around while being on my ship and stared wholes into the universe. Can you, please, just once, do something that HELPS me?

+ After exploring 10 planets I started to find copy pasted stations. Wandering through abandoned places was always something I absolutely enjoyed in Fallout. but here  it feels meaningless. the little notes of the people who left their traces and memories there. - It's rare to find anything like this here.

+ Landscape is disappointing, too. The planets almost all look the same. Forget unique flora and fauna. Sure, you can scan and study everything... but that's just an endless fetch quest.

+ The temples feel soooo boring! I have to keep doing the same thing over and over again? It’s not even a puzzle! There’s no story behind the temples, nothing to explore!

+ Companions (again).. somehow Bethesda liked the idea of quantity over quality and it really shows. I met some of the people outside of constellation and they all felt uninspired and boring. And the people at the lodge... well, they were a little better written but I'd still rather run around with Dogmeat if I'm honest. These rigid facial expressions don't really help and the one short personal quest you get with them feels  is completed super quickly.

+ Sneaking should be forbidden as well, especially if you have somebody following you.. 

[b]TLDR: Please don’t buy this game. It’s not worth it. [/b]

Play Mass Effect if you want a unique story and emotional characters. AND better exploring, too.
Play Outer Worlds if you want (a similar gameplay) a funny story with unique dialogues. Play Borderlands, if you’re in for the loot and the shooting. Play No mans sky if you want better exploration. 
OR just play Cyberpunk 2077 if you want a wonderful and unique story.  Well.. 

If this game would have been published 10 or 15 years ago I might have liked it slightly,  but nowadays it's kind of embarrassing to publish something like this and comment under other reviews with [i]"The astronauts back on the moon weren't bored when they found a stone landscape!”[/i]
Please get better, Bethesda. Or stop trying.

It’s a good game. I’ve gone to a planet that I thought nothing was on and next thing I know im 2 floors deep on a giant research facility unlocking the mantis ship which I had no idea was there. Forget about doing the Constellation mission board, I started one of the missions and gave up about 95 percent into scanning of the planet and I haven't had the desire to go back to check the board again, but to each their own, they say. I read all sorts of things before Starfield came out. They talked about massive worlds, free roaming, building ships, outposts, space stations, fleets. The more I read the more interested I became. The semi finished product however, was nothing like I was hoping for. I guess I wasn't the only one. Mind numbingly boring. Played the hell out of it when it first came out, made the mistake of finishing crimson fleet and UC. Finished their story lines and NO ONE attacks me. So I have no enemies on the board. I go into cookie cutter buildings without any conflict. I had to add mods to build ships freely, and ended up discarding main companions rather quickly due to them constantly screaming at me for shooting things. The ship travel became worthless due to fast travel, and even the mass of hours I spent build an outpost seemed pointless as I could simply buy materials with ease. The characters themselves are devoid of personality and offer no depth. I found a handful of side quests more interesting then the main ones. I finished it once, and let it die on the shelf.

I keep coming back thinking I can try to get back into this, but I just can't. It feels bare bones, and unfinished. I really need to stop pre-order deluxe or premium editions, I never seem to learn.

Game is missing just one thing: a soul.

An extraordinarily boring, uninspired game, which is frankly astonishing considering the setting is literally limitless and could be filled with mysteries untold. 

This doesn't feel like it was made by a studio with the budgets that Bethesda can muster with ease.
Literal maps of the main settlements in the game were nonexistent. Even now the new "maps" they have placed are basically uselessly cluttered with icons with no real understanding of the layout of a city. 

Basically every single selling point of this game, is underwhelming, and was unfinished upon launch.  Less buggy than nearly every other game they have produced however, what does that matter when the gameplay is so mind numbingly boring. Shipbuilding was the only mechanic that felt different or close to what they promised but in the end mechanically they provide almost nothing for your character. 

Out of my entire steam library, this is the only game I've had TRUE buyers remorse for i could have burned the 70$ and gotten more warmth and value from it than this game provided. 
 
Probably worth a buy if its on sale for 10$. But even then you would have to spend time installing it, and is it really worth it? 

Best thing that came from this game are Dunkey and SSethTzeentach's reviews of them, and I find far more enjoyment in those videos than i could ever find in this uninspired mess, and i genuinely think I've watched, and enjoyed those reviews for a greater length of time than I could stick with this game. 

Also I'm one of those idiots who has like 400 hours or so on Fallout 4, so, not sure how they missed the mark so drastically but maybe they'll make a complete game when the next Elder Scrolls Game comes out. Or maybe they will have the modders fix it as always, or sell us the same mods who knows the glory days that Todd will bring us soon!

I need to make this very clear right up front; This Mess Is Not Worth $70.

This game is death by a thousand cuts.
The moment to moment, hour to hour game-play is engaging and enjoyable. Maybe not exciting, but enjoyable. I want to play this game.
But then dozens upon dozens of strange, bad, and outright stupid game-design choices start to pile on. It's mostly little things, sure, but it's little things you can't ignore. You find yourself asking over and over, "Why the hell is this a thing?"
I'm going to use the rovers added almost a YEAR after launch as an example of what I mean.
Bethesda adds a rover so that players no longer have to walk several kilometers when exploring planets. That's great, but there's a glaring issue; The controls suck. The rev-8 is actually worse than walking, but why? 2 reasons; Camera Relative Steering and an Automatic Handbrake. If you download a mod that disables these, you discover that the rover is actually kinda fun to drive. So Why The Hell Is This A Thing?
That's the experience you'll have with almost every system in the game.
Why the hell is it raining on a planet with no atmosphere?
Why the hell can't I upgrade the quality of my gear?
Why the hell can't I control where the doors are in my ship? Why the hell does it have to be a maze?
Why the hell am I taking damage from toxic gas while wearing a space suit? WHY THE HELL ARE NOBLE GASES TOXIC?
Why the hell is the colony war so stupid?
Why the hell is there zero variation to the points of interest?
Why the hell this
Why the hell that
Why The Hell Is This Game Still $70?

The overall vision for this game is completely off the mark. Sure, it's commendable for BGS to try something new, however they've completely ignored what made their previous games so enjoyable. They could have done an engaging space RPG with some of the Fallout or Elder Scrolls DNA but none of that is here. It is absolutely lacking in soul and charm: writing, npc's, combat, game mechanics, etc. They have become so delusional (due to their previous successes) that they view everything they do as being fine. This is Bethesda's legacy and it's so sad.

I wanted to like this game, I followed its development since it was announced and was super hyped on it. I do think there are caveats with space games that make the genre inherently difficult to get right like the fact that a futuristic-multi-planet civilization is going to have A LOT of people and A LOT of cities that should be ENORMOUS, and how do you balance that feeling with the limitations of modern computer infrastructure? I wouldn't say many games have been wild successes in the genre and a lot have tried.

Farming/medieval towns with a few castles are much more "believable" in comparison to a futuristic setting like Starfield.

That said, this game is pretty painful. I hate inventory management, it's annoying and Bethesda thinks immersion has to do with having a million items you can pick up and a text based inventory that you can't sort or manipulate easily. If you're going to give me text based inventory rather than the more obviously popular visual inventories used in nearly every other game then you better let me sort it like an excel spreadsheet on any parameter that I want. Why is my food gumming up my Stim/Med menu? I collect food to cook stuff, but uncooked it's worthless compared to my meds. The UI is atrocious and seems to completely disregard how actual players want to spend their time in the game. Why can't I sort based on weight when you penalize me for picking stuff up in the game.

Some of the faction quests are fun, I enjoyed the Terramorph questline, but so many quests are just "go here get this, bring it back," even the main storyline ends up feeling like this. And then you end up locking a bunch of combat mechanics behind NG+ when I didn't enjoy the game enough to finish it in the first place and you want me to play through the whole thing over and over to unlock everything?

I haven't even bothered to try to figure out what's going on with the marketplace stuff and I pre-ordered the fancy edition so they gave me credits to get the DLC and some other stuff, but it just feels ridiculous to be paying for these other things or trying to find mods to fix the base game if the base game feels so far from what I'd expect from a AAA title.

If I'm going to sit down and devote what little free time I have to a game I want devs to be considerate of my time, I don't want to spend a bunch of extra time trying to fix everything they were too lazy to do themselves. If your game has great story and fun mechanics and epic battles then give me an interface that lets me experience those things easily rather than me editing everything to make UI and superfluous cutscenes take up all my time.

If you're a fan of Bethesda games, there's little doubt you'll enjoy Starfield. The game offers improvements compared to earlier titles like Fallout 4 and Skyrim, particularly in performance, character interactions, and the leveling system. However, it falls short in ambition, leaving the experience somewhat lackluster.

Players expecting a grand sci-fi adventure akin to Mass Effect, with diverse alien races and thrilling exploration, may be disappointed. Instead, the game presents a universe populated by humans with a light sprinkling of sci-fi elements.

While Starfield includes several engaging storylines, not all of them land successfully. The addition of base-building is an interesting idea, but it feels undermined by the mechanics of New Game Plus and the talent system. For instance, some talents feel disconnected from the gameplay, such as needing a specific talent just to use the backpack boost effectively.

One of the standout features is spaceship building, which can be quite enjoyable. Constructing your own spaceship is rewarding and gives you a meaningful use for credits, though more customization options would have been appreciated. Unfortunately, a major downside is that you lose your ship in New Game Plus, which dampens the overall experience.

Nothing is intuitive, controls are difficult to manipulate, and the terrible UI means you'll have to repeatedly deconstruct and nudge your outpost beacon around just to find sufficiently overlapping resources. The gameplay is classic Bethesda bugginess where NPCs glitch out, quests become incompletable, etc. I want to get to the later game to see if the space ship fighting mechanics are decent. I'll probably end up modding the game to get stability and quality of life that should have come out of the box. Overall, pretty disappointed, I'd recommend you play No Man's Sky instead for basically the same game.

Pretend other video games didn't exist for a second. 

Starfield delivers on the concept of games in an incredible way. It's got the base building. It's got gun customization. It has NPCs following routines and doing things, different factions, it takes the concept of a sandbox and ramps it up to eleven.

Except space is vast. It's empty. And so for exploring a game that calls itself "NASA-punk" despite not understanding punk at all, it needs to do more than be an interesting tech demo. It needs to be human. It needs to feel like after you summit a mountain, defeat an adversary, do /anything/, it needs to feel larger than life.

Instead, we get books filled with public domain literature, we get the masquerade of consequence when in reality the systems are too big and too thin to cover it. The games largest victories are also it's most hollow and disappointing, and even though I played it for over a hundred hours, I truly cannot recommend this game. 

More than a year after the fact, I came in looking to experience Starfield a second time, to see if maybe my perspective was wrong. But unfortunately, we live in a world where there are other videogames. So I'm going to go redownload Oblivion and play the Knights of the Nine DLC, with it's extremely reasonably priced and highly enjoyable horse armor DLC.

This game really shows that Bethesda's game design has aged very poorly. What worked for Skyrim in 2011 doesn't work for 2023 onwards. Everything this game does is done better by other games. Combat (any other FPS), space exploration (No Man's Sky), seamless open world (Cyberpunk 2077), world interaction (every other RPG ever made), and UI (every other non-Bethesda RPG). Hopefully this is the wake up call Bethesda needs to improve their game design.

This is barely a recommendation. 6, 6.5/10. It'll scratch your Bethesda RPG itch but it's not as good as previous games.

You can collect companions! They're largely useless. You can make outposts! Largely useless, and honestly annoying to lug materials around to build until you earnestly upgrade your ship to hold materials. 

There are lots of planets. Most are boring and pretty empty of anything worthwhile- I'm not upset about it, I don't even consider it a Negative. They could either give you a couple full star systems and/or make most planets unexplorable, or they could have a vaguely realistic amount of things on a bigger spread of systems. It's whatever.

They updated the game and added land vehicl--- haha no, unless I'm mistaken they added one (1) vehicle. You don't need any more, but all you can seem to do is change the color. Want a different one? Different weapons? Sucks to suck unless you get a mod. Inclusion of vehicle? Good. Lazy and disappointing, but good.

Look, it's a Bethesda RPG. You're largely going to get what you think you will. You'll be able to put hours and hours in, but this particular one doesn't hold up as well as it should.

A failure to understand what people find compelling about open world experiences.  I find it really hard to write about this game because it's issues are big but nuanced. the game is massive, huge amounts of content that for the most part are completely functional, from a purely mechanical perspective. its remarkably lacking the heavy jank of typical bethesda, which is why its also sadly ironic; it is broken on a deeper conceptual level. I want to theorize that maybe there was an ideal of this game that exists in design docs that because of technical constraints was more and more compromised over the course of development, you simply cant handcraft a map this big, the engine couldn't handle seamless space to planet surface flying, and on and on until you're left with this horribly hobbled and flavorless definition of "exploration" devoid of discovery or meaning.

And without compelling space exploration, without being able to immerse yourself in the fantasy of being a space pioneer, what is left? Tragically, without this key element on which the heart and soul of the game was staked, all  that's left are the elements that bethesda has already been fumbling for over a decade narratively. weak characters, weak plots, wasted opportunities. 

And this is basically an aside, but how did they manage to make such a boring scifi setting?

I've gotten exhausted with the flood of fast-pace, better have 20 year old reflexes, multiplayer FPS stuff. Sometimes (a lot of the time?) I don't want all of that. Instead, I want something that I can play casually. Something where I don't have to be in peak form, or else I'm gonna get murdered quickly over and over. I wanna be able to chill and take my time, and explore around if I want, or seek out skirmishes if I want, but at my pace. Not at the pace of the best player in the round. 

This is that game for me. I found it hella interesting right off the bat, and it's only improved with the updates and DLC. I've enjoyed exploring the world, and I didn't discover SO MUCH the first run. I didn't even use weapon crafting until NG+, and didn't mess with the Starborn powers until NG+2! And that's okay. That just means there's so much to discover, that it's taken several playthroughs to discover what I have. That just means it hasn't gotten stale. I know there's so much more I simply haven't gotten around to doing (have yet to build an outpost), and I'm looking forward to when I decide it's time to go down those paths. And while it was traumatic to [spoiler]lose all my... well, everything upon first reaching the Unity? Now it just means I can start the next NG stronger than before. I can learn from earlier mistakes. And it even means that when the main game gets stale, no problem. There's a big ol reset button I can use.[/spoiler]

There was so much noise at launch, and then the same thing every update and with the DLC. People develop expectations - how many articles do you see around the internet? "what starfield needs to do," "what might be in the new update?," "will the DLC tell us everything we want to know about the Va'ruun?"  So many of those articles are just speculation and wish lists. And when Bethesda releases something without the wishlist features that they never promised, people get bent. It's just so weird to me. 

In any case, if you want something chill, to run at your own pace, and have so much to explore and learn and do, this is it right here. This is the decaf to those manic FPS games. So pull up a seat at the Viewport, and see what the Settled Systems have for you. Good luck.

I feel like in a lot of ways, Starfield is some antiplatonic ideal of "Skyrim with guns" that you can slap a "in space" to the end of. There's a load of generated planets with a steady loop of maybe like ten or so routinely generated interiors that spawn on certain planets with loot and hostile NPCs similarly generated. You go to the place and kill the guy and take his stuff and gain experience points and level up in the piecemeal way that both Skyrim and Fallout 4 manage level-ups as so they feel almost like they've crammed the experience of a gacha game into a AAA open world adventure RPG in how much they're blueballing you but it's fine in Skyrim because the vistas are nice and it's fine in Fallout 4 because the gunplay is smooth.

Starfield tries to blend both into the context of a vast-space exploration game and it's insanely weird in ways I cannot describe with words. It feels like a game cooked up in a lab to be stereotypically Bethesda-ey with some considerations of contemporary roleplaying titles' directions, with the most interesting being the sliding-scale difficulty modifiers wherein players can shift their yield of experience points by making certain elements of the game harder or easier by select categories. Additionally, aspects of its story later delve into metatextual conceptualizations of certain themes of videogames as a medium themselves.

The issue with Starfield is that a lot of the time it feels more like a time sink than a compelling title. Like previous Bethesda titles, its primary form of interaction is ultimately combat, which in the setting of a shooter is expected, but naturally means its ultimate impact on play, and especially grinding, shifts into the realm of mindlessness as you fly to different planets, kill all the pirates at procedurally generated facilities take their stuff and sell it etcetera until you get enough money for the ship or home whatever expensive thing you want. The game's strategies are about as limited as Skyrim's insofar as doing a sneak archer build is good at killing people but this time with a bolt-action and this is a game where a majority of general interactions are between you and random goons you can't negotiate with, and the consequence is that, unlike its contemporaries such as Baldur's Gate 3 or Elden Ring, where strategy is more than picking up a big gun and killing the guy, the gameplay is held to the unfortunate limitations that come with shooter-RPGs, such as Cyberpunk 2077. But where 2077 more than makes up for the rudimentary nature of the genre by inviting players into a fleshed out world with compelling characters and striking intimate narrative beats in its story - alongside a wider-array generally of its combat mechanics - Starfield is often left in the unfortunate position of tracing in the footsteps of Bethesda titles' complicated relationship to open world games. Fallout 3 and 4 are fun romps, but that they begin the exact same way in Vaults 101 and 111 is a trait shared by Starfield. Fresh new games always begin with you being a lowly miner despite all of the genuinely well-developed character backstory traits that can color your experience - and they genuinely do, especially the trait that gives you parents - means that there's an unfortunate hold on this tradition, even as new game plus runs give variety to this. The consequence is that the game is structured by certain limitations of the player's origins in a way that unfortunately bleed into the rest of the title. The game nominally can be played with the player becoming Doctor Murderhobo and Murderhobo-ing their way across the Settled Systems, but you'll eventually run into some guy you can't kill who will take a knee because he's too important to die in the game keeping true to an unfortunate Bethesda tradition in their brand of storytelling. I don't particularly mind this; ultimately, Bethesda titles are highly structured and in many ways assume players won't be put in positions where they'll be upset about the guy you can't kill because he takes a knee because you respect the social contract of the game's flow and narrative pacing and won't randomly decide to break a guy's legs because why not this isn't real life, but, as a safeguard, they make sure certain characters are essential until they aren't in service of preserving their narratives. This structuring isn't inherently bad in stories - most players, after all, don't decide to randomly snap and start beating people to death in the middle of an otherwise amicable environment - but Bethesda titles unfortunately often feel small because of this. As consequence, the game's general tone is further numbed into this idea of a grand space adventure where you and your band of nerds who really like space go on adventures and kill more people than any of us will in our lives and take their stuff and then maybe go to a quest in the libertarian society's mini Night City and convince Ancap Board Leader Mr. It's Actually Called Ephebophilia that he should stop being such a bastard.

Starfield's characterization of its companions often feels genuinely nice, a better trait it inherits from previous Bethesda titles. Sarah, Sam, Barrett, and others all bring nice little stories that help illustrate the world, but it's unfortunately often in service of a fiction that's been often underwritten in ways that feel simple. A simple example of this is that the libertarian country that I made a pedophilia joke about earlier caps out their discount Texas Rangers elite deputy organization with twelve members total. A dozen guys for a political bloc that collectively controls three planetary systems and is one of just three governmental organizations in the entire game. Meanwhile, the Colony War, a devastating conflict between two of the factions, is stated to only have taken around thirty-thousand lives of the larger of the two factions. These numbers don't automatically damage the game's backstory; the libertarians might just have set the limit of active Freestar Rangers to 12 to remind everybody what the age of consent is and it's meant to illustrate that they aren't exactly a competently militarized state like the larger United Colonies, but there's more to the game's notes that unfortunately keeps eating away at the title's inner cohesion, namely the fact that earth was destroyed. Which is a lot.

That's pretty big. Earth is gone and it's ambiguous as to what the population of the Settled Systems is in actual terms given the fact that it's pretty hard to rapidly evacuate several billion people from a planet rapidly experiencing that sort of collapse. While companions' warm personalities help explore this and flesh out the human element of living in what is essentially a quasi-post apocalyptic society in many unspoken ways, a lot of answers from the story carry flimsy explanations, which unfortunately erodes on much of the game's believability insofar as its story seems ultimately often clinical and restricted in service of creating a title that holds certain norms towards the space exploration group Constellation despite the gutting implications of certain elements of the story's lore that often hand-waves, if not ignores. Broader questions as to the population of the Settled Systems and why the vast populations of criminal enterprises are not a more existential threat to humanity given the seemingly limited numbers of species evacuated from Earth prior to its atmosphere collapsing and killing everybody. This is somewhat microcosmic for my issues with the story, as the game drifts into the territory of feeling textually vapid in key aspects that would otherwise populate the scenario with a greater degree of intrigue. Anyways, the companions are nice even if they'll loudly talk about how good you are at sex after you've romanced them in front of Sam's ten year old kid if you invite them on your ship. This is hilarious and very Bethesda-y and I would not change this but it is very funn

Despite all of the controversy, I actually mildly enjoyed this game. I thoroughly enjoyed the story, and there are some great moments of immersion, specifically [spoiler]UC Vanguard's missions with the terrormorphs[/spoiler] and [spoiler]The Starborn quest when they invade New Atlantis and chase you[/spoiler]. I thought the leveling/experience system was [i]decent[/i], the upgrade system for weapons was [i]decent[/i] -- really a lot of things were just [i]decent[/i], not overly great or terrible. The concept of [spoiler]New Game+[/spoiler] was semi-marvel, I guess, albeit tiresome to completely start over with [spoiler]just your research and skill tree upgrades[/spoiler].

There's not a whole lot of cinematic moments, and what you could consider cinematic doesn't hold its charm for very long. I felt the experience of exploring a whole procedurally generated universe fell flat, the 'repeat' missions are quickly boring, the game still has a significant amount of bugs (i.e. bounty missions where you take them alive never works). 

[h2]Verdict[/h2]

For a AAA game, and for $70 (at time of writing, still the original cost as it was at launch) no, I wouldn't recommend this, made even worse for a $30 DLC. It's clear where some places they included some things just to say the game 'had' a feature and then called it a day, or they stopped short of finishing a feature. There were a lot of things that were 'on the cusp of greatness' that just falls short. 

Get the base-game at a steep discount. At a discount, I'd say it's worth the experience. At $70 though, find yourself a couple of $30 games and get yourself that $10 coffee.
Would not recommend to anyone who likes playing games.

Starfield is an engaging and entertaining experience, a quintessential Bethesda game, quirks (bugs) and all. There’s an abundance of content to sink your time into, and while it’s not perfect, it’s undeniably enjoyable. That said, I did wish for a more immersive experience in certain areas, like ship piracy, which feels limited when you encounter ships you can’t board, especially bounty hunter vessels. Inventory management is also a mixed bag, creative but tedious, especially when managing resources. An unlimited storage option for outposts, akin to the containers in the Constellation lodge, would have been a welcome addition.

The main storyline and lore offer a decent level of immersion, but the constant chatter from NPCs, particularly on the ship, can be chaotic. While this adds a sense of realism, I’d appreciate the ability to adjust volumes for clarity. Exploration, one of the game’s highlights, felt slightly underwhelming due to the lack of variation among planets. Despite that, wandering through Starfield’s universe still has its charm, offering some breathtaking vistas and day-night cycles that are stunning to behold.

Core gameplay systems like scanning planets, space combat, and ground combat have their strengths. Space combat, especially against capital or multiple ships, is a chaotic delight, requiring thoughtful ship builds. Ground combat showcases decent NPC tactics, depending on your chosen difficulty level. However, resource management can be frustrating, particularly for aspiring space traders, as vendors often lack the funds to buy your wares. Bethesda, we need a Space Supermart!

Visually, Starfield delivers. While flora and fauna could use a touch more realism, the overall design, especially the vistas and planetary skies, is mesmerizing. There’s nothing quite like sitting on a planet and watching the sky as the day passes. It’s moments like these where the game truly shines.

Side content and faction missions are plentiful, perhaps too plentiful, but they do add value. However, more dynamic consequences for faction decisions and a greater variety of ground-based random encounters would enhance immersion. Dialogue choices in encounters, while decent, could be more dynamic and impactful.

Customization is a standout feature, with robust options for character creation, shipbuilding, and gear upgrades. The hard choices about where to invest your skill points add a layer of strategy that I appreciated. Still, a deeper backstory option for your character could elevate the immersion further.

While Starfield does provide a sense of freedom, it often gently nudges you back onto the intended path, likely to prevent unintended consequences from derailing the experience. This balanced approach ensures a positive gameplay experience, though replayability might feel limited due to fixed outcomes.

My favorite aspect of the game is exploration. There’s so much to see and do that it’s easy to get lost in its vastness. On the flip side, the lengthy conversations with NPCs can sometimes drag and pull you out of the action.

Would I recommend Starfield? Absolutely. But as I always say, my experience might not be your experience. Use my thoughts as a guide to make your own informed decision. If you love vast, immersive worlds and enjoy taking in the sights, Starfield is worth a try. It’s not the best game ever, nor the worst, it’s a fun interstellar romp that lets you escape into another universe. A true time sink, it’ll take you away... just like Calgon.

I'm still replaying Skyrim once a year, but with Starfield I just want that 60 hours back. Definitevely not pre-purchasing another Bethesda title.

My group had a discussion about games we regret playing. It turned into an hour long discussion on how Starfield is broken down to the fundamental level.

The game would have to be completely remade from the ground up.
First off the engine is still out of date and busted.
Worlds are copy pasted poorly designed messes of mostly empty space. 
The cities are little more than spread out shops.
Inventory space is minuscule requiring you to make frequent trips back to your ship.
You want to build your ship to have more inventory space but if you don't build a fighter style ship you get shot down.
There's no space flight, just an arena next to the planet for getting into fights or do nothing events. 
There is no planet landing or taking off, you teleport to and from space and from planet to planet.
The guns are poorly animated and often don't operate in the way the designers obviously wanted. 
Some of the guns are useless while the others have tiers of power.
The weapon upgades/mods can't be removed and put on another gun. (Attachments are not items so upgrading lower tier items are a waste of resources.)
There is base building that is completely pointless and wastes your time. 
There's challenge based progression in the skill tree. (You must complete a challenge in order to unlock the ability to spend a skill point on a certain skill.)
Some quests break other quests. 
And as always there's Bethesda bugs abound.
Finally they attempted to block mods at launch so they could include creation club content. (micro transactions.)

Do not get this game.

After 25 Hours of pure disappointment I can clearly say I regret buying this product even it was 20% off and i call myself a Bethesda Fanboy since Morrowind came out. 
I was open-minded before, giving the game a fair chance for myself, honestly i didn't think i would settle my negative opinion about it that quick. 
What you get is not a Skyrim, no Morrowind or Fallout in Space, you get a boring, souless RPG,  with the same old Engine and the same old problems like before. Still after a year and patches, i experience a lot of bugs, still your KI Companion is running against walls, still you are glitching trough stairs like it was 2002.
 
About the Gameplay: the whole game feels a bit numb while playing. Part wise it's more like you play a nice made mod right from nexus, than a full price product. Of course, it has its quality, the voice actors are professional, but the dialogs lack a lot of this good old Bethesda sarcasm and humor, you could find in games before like Fallout.

Instead of this feeling a skyrim gave you before when you explore this great wide landscape, you can expect way more restricted areas like caves and space stations, everything else like exploring the planets gets boring pretty fast, you need to see way too much of plain dust and sand landscapes.

Update: it's been 50 hours of gameplay now and I don't think there will be added much more time in the future. I can finally say I understand the disappointment some Bethesda fans have, there is so much I want to criticize at this point, it would be a novel before I could end this review. I don't think that future patches or add-ons will fix the game to a halfway decent and enjoyable product, like it happened to Fallout 76. The Lack of companions, less interesting background NPC story's & Quest and a pretty flaw main story ain't helping much to identify yourself with this new universe Bethesda has set up for us. I would say it's neither fantasy nor fiction, it's more about science and about future NASA Technology. This game feels like it was made for Astronomic and Hobby Rocket scientist, then for real RPG Gamers.

( some worlds and bases are 100% copy and paste) that is annoying, but the bases are old military structures, makes sense they are similar. 
Is this game perfect.. no. but looks amazing, runs smooth and has great content and plenty of mods to make it even better.. 
And the NG+ makes its play through nice and interesting..

Interstellar travel - Loading Screen

Land on planet - Loading Screen
Take off - Loading Screen

When I gave it a try at launch (I was busy with Baldur's Gate at the time) I couldn't really get into it, but now that I've given it another try, I'm really enjoying it. It has all the charm and fun that I've come to love from Oblivion, Skyrim, and Fallout 3, NV, and 4. 

The key for me was to be patient through the introductory stuff and wait until the game sets you loose.

Also, I recommend avoiding automatically generated stuff (planets, quests, locations) early on and focus on the main and side quests and major cities for the first 10 or so hours until you get the hang and feel for it. The stuff that the Bethesda team created by hand is where the game shines and is what is going to get you hooked enough to want to do the auto-gen stuff.

Starfield Review: A Monumental Journey to the Stars

Starfield, Bethesda’s highly anticipated sci-fi RPG, is a massive leap into the final frontier, offering an expansive universe ripe for exploration. As the studio’s first new IP in over 25 years, it sets its sights on delivering a deep, immersive experience blending Bethesda’s signature RPG elements with the uncharted vastness of space. After hundreds of hours, it’s clear that Starfield largely succeeds in realizing this ambitious vision, although it’s not without some bumps along the way.

Gameplay: Exploration and Freedom
At its core, Starfield offers players a truly open-world experience, but this time, the world is a galaxy. With over 1,000 planets and countless space stations, moons, and star systems, the scale of the game is impressive. Space travel itself is immersive and expansive, letting players fly seamlessly between planets, engage in dogfights with hostile ships, or explore the depths of alien worlds. The flight mechanics and ship customization are deep enough to appeal to fans of space simulators but remain accessible for those who simply want to explore the unknown.

The planets themselves vary widely in their biomes, from lush forests to barren rocks. The most captivating part of exploration is the sheer freedom it offers. You can choose to follow the main story, focus on side missions, or carve your own path through the cosmos. Whether mining resources, upgrading your ship, or stumbling across hidden artifacts, Starfield encourages curiosity at every turn. However, while the number of planets is vast, some lack meaningful content, feeling like empty, procedural landscapes with minimal depth.

Story and Quests: A Mixed Bag
The main storyline of Starfield revolves around the Constellation faction, a group of space explorers seeking answers to the mysteries of the universe. It’s a solid narrative, with intriguing world-building and fascinating lore surrounding the ancient artifacts scattered across the galaxy. However, while the main story has its moments of grandeur, it occasionally feels bogged down by slow pacing and predictable plot beats. It’s a familiar tale of discovery and exploration, but it doesn’t offer the same emotional punch or complexity found in Bethesda’s other iconic games like The Elder Scrolls or Fallout series.

Side quests, on the other hand, are a mixed bag. Some are standout experiences, delving into intriguing character arcs, faction politics, or moral dilemmas. Others feel derivative, recycling similar tasks like scanning plants or gathering materials. Still, the sheer volume of content means there’s something for everyone, and even the more mundane quests can be a good excuse to explore the world further.

Character Progression and Combat
Bethesda’s signature RPG elements, such as character creation, skill progression, and dialogue systems, are present and well-executed. Players can tailor their character to their playstyle, be it as a skilled pilot, an efficient engineer, or a smooth-talking diplomat. The skill trees are robust, and there’s a lot of room for experimentation with different builds. That being said, some aspects of character progression can feel somewhat shallow, particularly when compared to other modern RPGs that offer more complex systems.

Combat in Starfield is another area that shows both promise and frustration. The mix of ranged weapons, power armor, and space ship combat is exciting at first, but it often devolves into standard third-person shooting with less depth than one might hope for in a Bethesda RPG. Melee combat feels lackluster, and while the variety of weapons is impressive, it often feels like there’s no real weight behind them. Space combat, however, is thrilling, particularly when battling in zero-gravity or engaging in tense dogfights with enemies.

Graphics and Performance
Visually, Starfield is a stunning game, with breathtaking vistas of alien planets, dazzling space scenes, and detailed environments. The lighting, especially when transitioning from the depths of space to the surface of a planet, creates a sense of scale that’s difficult to capture in words. However, despite its impressive visuals, the game suffers from occasional technical issues like frame drops, glitches, and texture pop-ins, especially on older hardware. These hiccups can pull you out of the experience, but the game’s sheer scale makes it easy to overlook them in the grand scheme of things.

Final Thoughts: A Cosmic Achievement with Room for Improvement
Starfield is undeniably an ambitious and impressive game, offering a massive universe filled with potential for exploration, discovery, and adventure. The depth of its world-building, combined with its open-ended gameplay, will keep players hooked for hours. Yet, while the game succeeds in creating a compelling space adventure, it struggles in a few key areas—namely, its storytelling, combat systems, and occasional technical performance issues.

Still, Starfield is a game worth experiencing for any fan of open-world RPGs or space exploration. It’s a monumental step forward for Bethesda, even if it doesn’t quite reach the same heights as its other legendary titles. For those willing to overlook some rough edges, it offers an unforgettable journey through the stars.

I played Starfield upon release and recently picked it back up a little over a year later. Starfield just comes across as lazy to me. Just about every aspect of a "Bethesda game" is worse in Starfield than it was in Fallout 4. The game has little improvement from release with many of the same issues STILL in the game 1 year later. 

Issues:
1) The perk/skill system is over constrained. Not only does the player have to level up to gain the skill point, but they also have to complete various requirements to be able to advance in that skill. Have a skill point available? Want to level up ballistics from 1 to 2? Did you kill 10 guys? No, too bad. In addition to this, the skill system is also very bloated with combat, social, crafting and ship combat all competing for the same skill points. I think you need to reach level 350+ to get all the skills, but only need to get to level 60-70 to complete the game with a reasonable amount of time spent on side quests. Due to all these issues, the player either has to give up on aspects of the game because they are locked out due to the skill system OR the player grinds in some manner to skill up (I am 2 hours of story into this play through, but have spent 20+ hours grinding so I can get to level 65 to have most of the "baseline" skills I think I need).

2) Creation engine is far past its self life. The game NPCs look fairly poor, there are lots of glitches and it still bugs out occasionally. There are many games the look better and handle the demand better than Starfield.

3) The story is fine, but nothing to write home about. As with most Bethesda games, the found side content is the best part. 

In summary, Bethesda is milking their audience. I do find this game better than some other games because you can transition quickly between places of interest. The downside is that the game has a ton of loading screens. The combat is fine for the most part. Most of the main issues are with Bethesda's poor support and an outdated engine. If Bethesda wants the community to fix the game, they did a poor job with that because the vast majority of mods disable achievements.

Edit upon playing another 15ish hours after this review. 

I have uninstalled the game and hidden it from my game list. As my game progressed, the load times became longer and longer; with a load after a death taking upwards of 10 minutes on a brand new computer with the latest SSD. I can tolerate  this if I only need to load once per play session and it supposedly resets upon NG+. 

Let's stack on top of this a gear/skill check mission where space combat is required AND no supporting quests in the quest line to build space combat skills. I died twice, taking 10 minutes between 20 second attempts, and finally set all the space combat setting to very easy to get through this mission. Wouldn't you know it, the game bugs out and my space ship is uncontrollable causing me to die for a 3rd time. Instead of waiting another 10 minutes to try a poorly implemented mission due to a save issue the community has diagnosed months ago, I decided I would uninstall and play something else.

Starfield, 1 year later, is still in an unacceptable state.

All the Skyrim fans hated this game for having too many loading screens. But now they're all playing the Oblivion remaster, unperturbed by the fact you sometimes have to go through 3 load screens just to go from your room at the inn to the wilderness. (I do like Oblivion please don't hurt me)

Don't trust reviews, make your own opinions, I like this game.

For a breakdown of my own opinions, consider the following Pros/Cons section. These are my own opinions so you can decide for yourself which are Pros and which are Cons for YOU.

[h2] Pros [/h2]

- Effectively endless exploration and dungeons
- The best character creation in a Bethesda game (imo)
- Spend 50 hours just in the ship builder
- Huge variety of companions with useful skills for your ship & outposts
- Romance is much more natural & interesting than previous Bethesda games
- Slow-burn main story with a surprisingly great mystery and multiple good twists
- Less load screens than Oblivion
- Planets are re-generated on every new playthrough.
- Spend another 50 hours decorating the interior of your ship.
- Shutting off your brain and surveying planets while listening to music or a podcast is surprisingly relaxing
- Game is very pretty (except for the barren planets that are just alot of brown)
- So many novelty coffee mugs to collect, I'm still finding new ones
- World-building on par with any other Bethesda game (or maybe better)
- Tons of books and terminals to read for additional world building
- Space politics?!
- Phil Hill

[h2] Cons [/h2]

- Planets are procedurally generated so exploration feels less like Fallout and more like No Man's Sky (subjective, I don't consider this a con but you might)
- Fewer romance options than previous Bethesda games (But romance is deeper)
- Repetitive dungeons (but less so than Oblivion or Skyrim imo)
- Game is too big to possibly explore everything in one human lifetime
- Outpost building is much more limited than settlements in Fallout 4
- Opening hours of the main story are very slow, but the twists it takes are crazier than any other Bethesda game so I encourage you to be patient with it. The buildup is well worth it.
- Spend 50 hours just in the ship builder
- Phil Hill won't marry me.

5/10 - TLDR: A game that promises so much but continually half-delivers. Starfield's narrative says nothing which makes it toothless and boring. Same goes for the characters and underfed environments. Outpost stuff is fun and some of the spacecraft flight can be enjoyable. 

I put about 70 hours into this game. I wanted to give it an earnest play-through before I collected my thoughts about the elements that do and don't work. Hopefully, others will find this review useful. 

Starfield kicks off with potential. The space-rock miner bit is fun and hints at a gameplay mechanic which you, the player, continue to wield for the entirety of the experience. Soon after, you receive your first ship, one of the most exciting prospects of gameplay that attracted so many, including myself, to this title. Most of us arrived to this Steam page with the hope that Starfield would fulfil our fantasy of captaining a spacecraft across a vast galaxy, exploring the cities and towns across planets, encountering troubling scenarios to solve, meeting and leaving lovers, battling other spacefaring captains, and building space outposts to secure your place across the galaxy. 

Starfield only delivers on one of those fantasies. 

THE GOOD: 
The developers did well in the creation of the outposts and their customization. It's probably one of my favourite parts of the game. There are plenty of custom elements and it's fun hunting down planets with the resources you need. Creating your little compound and outfitting it is something that this game does well. 

THE BAD: 
There is a lot. I'll start with the narrative. Starfield's core plot has no bite. Its characters are blank slates. The side-missions available on a staggering amount of planets grow stale quickly as they repeat in structure and look. I can't imagine how difficult it is to ensure your narrative is cohesive and entertaining with recognizable themes for such a massive title. But it's not impossible, because CD Projekt Red has done it time and time again. If you want an immense open-world experience with carefully crafted stories, a narrative responsive to your choices, atmospheres and places that feel real, characters that have a voice, and a plot that has decided to actually say something, don't play Starfield. Try Cyberpunk 2077. Btw the only enjoyable character is Barrett. Shoutout that guy and his voice actor. Well done.

Beyond the narrative, which is truly a let-down, the next worst element is ship flight and crafting. I'll say it: they should have let you fly onto the planet, or at least had some gameplay sequence where you get to land... if you want to. It would just tie the whole piece together. The flight in space isn't bad and there is some essence of depth to it but why are the crew not a part of the fun? What is the point of hiring or collecting a crew if they only add numerical augmentation to the flight? The crew should be active participants in the flight gameplay - responsive to where you fly, how you fly, what you shoot, where you land. The other disappointing bit of the spacecraft gameplay is the customization. While it's awesome to customize the outer pieces of your craft at spaceports, why can we not preview them after confirming a selection... before purchase. Secondly, the customization on the craft is abysmal. We should be able to move around internal elements like lockers and beds and sinks and stuff. 

I'm going to wrap the review up on romance because this is a lot of writing but I promise there is a lot wrong. The romancing sucks in Starfield. It's dry and feels so... unromantic. And yeah, there should be some physical response to good/bad romancing via animation or cutscenes or something. You can really tell that the amount of planning that went into inter-character relationships is poor. There was seemingly no investment in the characters and their relationships and it showed. 

Last thing. I promise. The design and/or look of each city looked like a poor mix of retro-futurism and utopic-futurism. Even if it was purposeful, each of the cities feels strangely cloroxed. See Cyberpunk 2077 for an example of a city and districts that felt alive.
I hope that Bethesda continue with IP but this game just ain't it chief

260+ hours, longtime Bethesda fan.

What I loved: The interior design elements aka NASA-punk theme. Combat. Photo mode.

What I liked: Spaceflight mechanics/combat, NewGame+/Starborn concept, the main story/theme, the side missions.

What I disliked: the Starborn power mini games (what kind of crack are y'all smoking at Bethesda that makes these fun?), the Ship Design perk that allows improved ship building is fundamentally broken as the player has to sink hours upon hours of gameplay to make enough credits to afford the whopping FIFTY UNIQUE modules needed to max out the perk.

What I hated: the dialogue is atrocious, when people call the Crimson Fleet "the Disney Pirates" it's not an exaggeration - the fact that the player never gets a choice to overthrow All Bark No Bite Delgado and become the pirate king is a maddeningly lost opportunity. On that note, you can't become the leader of ANY faction in this game. Not one. What does Bethesda have against the player holding positions of power? This entire game feels like a missed opportunity because while it does have elements to love and enjoy, unfortunately the bad outweighs the good.

Played alot when it came out and wanted to decorate my ship more with gear and wanted a car/truck to do the long traveling and now started back again to find we now have all that. such a great game.
it's alright

the ship building component is beyond broken as F***... the largest components of the game are just broken, and possibly beyond fixing... 

Ship Building: more than half the time the habs dont connect correctly, missing doors... it tells you modules aren't connected but dont show where or what module... 

Questing: missions are broken with no way to progress because NPC's have to move to various locations to trigger the mission to continue, but the NPC's are bugged out and either stuck in place with no way to push into action, or hit an "invisible wall" that you need to push them past... 

Companions: they are beyond garbage... often getting bugged out and creating a wall you can't move past... they get angry if they see you do something bad... telling them to wait across time makes no difference apparently they can see you from over 200 kilometers away through many many buildings... they stop moving... you can't talk to them... they become barriers that keep you from moving... they get angry regardless if you shot someone or the air...

i think i'd rather have bamboo shoved under my nails, my PC easily beats the requirements to run this game smoothly and im still running into so much lag that the game just isnt functional. 0/10 i do not recommend. it's like bethesda put a turd into our hands and said "here have fun with this! its not actually a turd, its just fancy chocolate"
